report:
It appears that exams## school commitments and other issues are going to make it very difficult to put out a team in the MBL.

A decision will be made shortly as to whether we try and complete the remaining fixtures or drop out
Due to a complete over sight by NK no team had been selected for this match. Very annoying

It appears that exams## school commitments and other issues are going to make it very difficult to put out a team in the MBL.

A decision will be made shortly as to whether we try and complete the remaining fixtures or drop out

Only 3 overs were possible at a very soggy Ballinger . In some corners this was greeted with sighs of relief as 8pts may have been more than the team would have achieved against a strong Broomwade side

On the opening day of the season Ballinger were greeted with an excellent track## a short boundary and an Aldenham side short of bowlers. Rollo McIntyre took full advantage of all this and bludgeoned 120n.o. in no time. He added 206 for the second wicket with Matt Riley. Riley scored 70 at a more stately speed. Ballinger declared on 218 - 2 with only skipper Salisbury missing out.

Aldenham's batting was some-what better than their bowling and with the track still playing well they reached 190-7. All the Ballinger bowlers performed well but it was particularly pleasing to see the spin duo## Davies & Hardy## bowling well in tandem. New 'keeper Riley did an excellent job behind the sticks.

They don't come any closer than this! Ballinger win a cliff hanger of a cup game against Flackwell Heath.

Flackwell batted first and were contained by a tidy opening spell by Luke Hughes and Charlie Mead. At the mid point of the 20 overs they accelerated but were then pegged back towards the close of their innings by two good spells by James Rose and Sebastian Richards who each bowled two overs and took two wickets for 5 runs. At the close Flackwell had scored 60. However the grass in the outfield was very long and we reckoned that it was worth 80 to 90 at our ground.

Ballinger lost Alex Humphreys early to a very good catch. George Bailey and George Kinston then both batted well and gave us a good base. They were both dismissed for 11## which on a better outfield would have been worth a lot more. Charlie Mead came in at second wicket down and batted really well to accumulate 25. Ballinger were well on course until Charlie was out and then the middle order lost composure as the run chase was reaching its climax.

The light was poor as the last over was bowled with Ballinger still needing two to win. A wicket fell and Matthew Rose joined Sebastian Richards at the crease. A dot ball was followed by a scampered single (encouraged from a rather vocal square leg umpire!). Basty was now on strike. Three balls left one run to win. Two dot balls. One delivery left - one run required. The tension was mounting. Basty middled a leg stump delivery which went crashing past mid on and Ballinger had won.

The team bowled and fielded well. Next match we need to cut down on the opposition's singles and scramble a few more of our own. All in all a very credible performance by the team with every one contributing with either bat or ball and in the end a thoroughly deserved victory.Paul Rose

On a beautiful spring evening BWCC U11A's got off to a disappointing start to the season. Playing off 22yards!!

Ballinger put Beaconsfield in to bat and they took full advantage of the difficulty some bowlers were having bowling on a longer than usual pitch and were rattling up the runs. They were helped by some some beginning of the season sloppy fielding & after their 20 overs they were 273 for 4 with Tom Edmonds getting 8 for 32 off 2 overs. Will Smith kept really well.

After the first 2 pairs we were only 4 runs behind but our inability to pierce the field meant when the last pair came in they needed to make 38 runs in 4 overs. This proved an impossible task.

We need to put this behind us and in the next match## ensure our fielding is up to Ballingers usual standard## bowl a good length and look for the gaps in the field to get boundaries.

When the teams arrived at the ground the game was in doubt due to a wet out-field and light rain. However the 2 team coaches agreed to start the game and review the situation after 3-4 overs. The game was played under Barrington rules and Amesham won the toss and asked BWCC to bat first. Once the game was underway the weather improved immensely and soon the sun was shining and the outfield was not as slippery as we thought it might be.

The BWCC opening pair gave the team a steady start despite loosing an early wicket. Subsequent pairs batted sensibly and carefully and kept the score ticking over. The final pair scored 26 runs to set a target of 265 runs. In total BWCC lost 5 wickets. There was good batting performances from Jamie Wise## Josh Livingstone## Monty Cuthbert## Alex Welsh and Joe Carey.

When Amersham batted## the BWCC bowlers bowled a very good line and length and prevented Amersham from scoring too many runs. The BWCC fielding was excellent with good backing-up from the players plus lots of encouragement from each boy to their team members. The BWCC bowlers conceeded many fewer extras than the Amersham bowlers.

What was particularly pleasing was that only one bye and only 3 additional runs from wide deliveries were conceeded - well done to Alex Wills for keeping wicket so well. In the end BWCC only took 3 wickets - 2 in the final over. However their overall bowling performance restricted the Amersham batsmen.

Josh Livingstone captained the side well and all the team members accepted his field placings without question. There were good bowling performances from Max Bailey## who took all 3 wickets## Duncan Healey## Eddie Bentley## Tom Harrison and John Martin.

I would like to thank Jeff Moxom for umpiring the match - with the permission of Amersham CC officials.

Finally all the boys behaved impeccably and were a credit to the club.

Thanks to all the parents for suppporting the boys.

Chris Moxom BWCC Coach.BWCC 264-5 Amersham 235-3

The game started on a damp Sunday morning. There was a slight mix-up with the times in that Aston Clinton thought the game started at 10. However the match proceeded as soon as possible and Aston Clinton won the toss and asked BWCC to bat.

Stephan Otto and George Barlett opened the batting and proceeded to make steady progress against the very good Aston opening bowlers. Stephan and George put on 23 in 7 overs before George was out for 7. James Wood came in at number 3..

Sadly## as the match progressed## the strip become much more slippery and it began to cut-up. The home umpire proposed that the game be abandoned because of the potential risk of injury to both bowlers and batsmen. After a brief discussion between the coaches of both teams it was agreed to abandon the game.

At this point Stephan was 11 not out and James 6 not out. All three BWCC batsmen had batted very well in the difficult conditions.

The full team wasStephan Otto## George Barlett## James Wood## Jeff Moxom## James Miller## Jack MacIver## Luke Martin (capt.)## Jonny Freeman## Aaron Bailey## Michael Bryant## Richard Wise.BWCC U14 29-1 (9 overs)

High Wycombe proved too strong for us on Thursday evening. Wycombe batted first and were restricted to 32 off their first 10 overs## however## they accelerated to reach 83 for 4 after 20. All the bowlers bowled well and kept their heads when confronted by some clean striking of a cricket ball by some of the Wycombe batsmen. The fielding was also of a good standard and to limit a side with a number of county players to 83 in 20 overs was a very commendable performance. Will Clarke and George Bailey both bowled 3 over and took 1 for 7## which was an excellent analysis on an evening made for batting.Unfortunately we struggled with the bat. The opposition were quick and pretty straight## which proved a lethal combination for most of our players. Sam King put up some good resistance and scored 9. James Rose showed a commendably good technique and occupied the crease without adding much to the score. We were eventually bowled out for 33. I would be surprised if we come up against a bowling attack as good as that again this season. Having said that## we need to look closely at our basic technique## ie getting in line and playing straight to straight balls.There is no need to feel disheartened by defeat to a very competent opposition. And the boys now go on to a league match at Amersham followed by cup game at home to Beaconsfield on Monday 15th May.Paul Rose

With a school game at The Beacon not due to finish until 6.30## Ballinger had no choice but to start the game with 5 players (including 2 subs.) which had a major impact on the batting order. This was no way to start a game against a strong Chesham side including several county players. Chesham sportingly agreed that Ballinger should bat first on a wicket with variable bounce and a great deal of sideways movement. 100 would have been a good score.

The first few overs were negotiated safely until the wicket's variable bounce played its part in accounting for the first two wickets. Adam clipped his 2nd ball over the deep square boundary and Alex & Tom (Watts) mixed good defence with sensible attaching shots. The score was on 31 after 12 overs & acceleration was needed. Woody and Stefan led the way with George & Kristian playing their part. Somehow we managed to scrape our way to 82.

Luke & Richard opened the bowling against as good a batsman as they will play against all season. Both gave it everything. Looking for inspiration Stefan then turned to James “golden arm” Stoddart who opened up with a double wicket maiden including the prize scalp - great catch by Stefan. Jack produced 4 tidy economical overs## picking up 1 wicket and Ballinger were now back in it. Ballinger kept up the pressure with the excellent ground fielding all the way through. 26 off 6 needed & the Chesham batsmen (and coaches) were starting to feel the pressure. Great catch by Luke followed by an equally good run out by Woody & the pressure continued to mount. George## now into his rhythm picks up 2 quick wickets. Kristian## Tom Sperring & Callum continued to set the example in the field & two runs are needed off the last ball. Unfortunately Chesham managed to scrape home in the dark.

Summary.Under the circumstances this really was a great team effort and hopefully everyone who played now knows they can compete (and beat) anyone they play against. On difficult wickets## against good quality bowling## patience is needed. We have to play straight. Extras on both sides were top score so the need to bowl straight (especially on this type of wicket) is key to defending a total.

A special mention to Tom S. & Callum. Your attitude & team spirit set the tone. Stefan## captaincy wise## that's as hard as it will get!

Team: Stefan Otto## James Woods## Luke Martin## Richard Wise## James Stoddart## Jack Maciver## Callum Bright## Tom Sperring## Kristian Otto## George Bartlett## Adam Robinson.Subs - Alex Morgan## Tom Watts
. . . shortly

A determined and focused U13A team eased into the second round of the cup overcoming Gt. Kingshill.

On a damp and dreary Sunday morning Ballinger were put in after losing the toss. Sam Privett and Stefan Otto batted solidly to see off the dangerous Kingshill opening bowlers with Sam being a little unlucky to be run out.

Following the departure of the openers James Wood produced some beautifully timed drives on his way to 16. Luke Martin scored some quick fire runs before hitting all round a straight one and Tom Sperring batted well to reach double figures before smashing a drive straight to a Kingshill fielder who did well to hang on given the cold and damp conditions. At 66-5 off 14 overs though## Kingshill must have had hopes of restricting Ballinger to a reasonable score. James Stoddart however produced his best innings for Ballinger for some time mixing excellent strokeplay with intelligent running between the wickets. Well assisted by Jack MacIver and Tom Watts they pushed the score on to 102 after 20 overs.

The Kingshill reply started briskly reaching 26-0 after 4 overs. This was largely due to both Jack and Richard struggling with their footing. The introduction of James Stoddart brought immediate success (again!) bowling Kingshill's best batsman and along with Sam who bowled an excellent line and length pegged back the Kingshill reply with only 15 runs coming off their 8 overs. Off a shortened run up Jack still managed to fizz one past the edge of the batsman's bat with James Wood completing the dismissal with a good catch behind the wicket. Richard managed to conjure up an amazing run out hitting the stumps from out by the boundary. If the Kingshill batsman were hoping for some respite they didn't get it as Adam Robinson bowled quick and straight to finish off the tailenders. The bowlers were well supported in the field with Callum Bright and Tom Watts in the thick of the action.

Stefan again captained the team well## leading from the front and always giving encouragement and assistance to the team along with making sure the ball was as dry as possible for his bowlers!

In the end a comfortable win built on sensible batting## all the bowlers bowling a good line and length backed up by some solid fielding.

Scorecard:
Ballinger 102 for 6 (James Stoddart 16*## James Wood 16## Stefan Otto 12## Tom Sperring 10)

Gt Kingshill 58 all out (Adam Robinson 3-2-3-3## James Stoddart 4-1-8-3## Sam Privett 4-2-7-1)

Taplow 168 - 4 (Declared)
Ballinger 169 - 8

Ballinger captain## Ian Maciver## won the toss and decided to field on an overcast## muggy day at Taplow. Openers Lloyd and McNeil made good use of the conditions to bowl very tight opening spells## the batsmen finding it hard to score off the swinging ball. Lloyd was first to make a breakthrough with a diving catch off his own bowling (fortunately not followed by the 'twang' of breaking hip replacement components)## he also took the second wicket with a ball that surprised the batsmen by swinging right round his legs and striking leg stump. The openers were supported admirably by some fine bowling from Colts Stone## Hughes and Maciver Jnr (4 overs## 3 maidens) and a nine over spell of off-spin from Maciver Snr. The Taplow run-rate was not allowed to accelerate until after their no.4's solid inning of 53 was ended in the safe hands of Maw off the bowling of McNeil. This brought on Taplow's big-hitting no.5 who struck a quickfire 28 before skying one to Maciver Snr off Ballinger debutant Johnson. Taplow's innings ended with a score of 168 declared## at tea.

Ballinger's innings started steadily with both openers going for less than 10. Nos. 4 and 5 helped accelerate the scoring but both also went cheaply; McNeil swiping and missing a slow## looping full-toss which he thought would be called a no-ball## and possibly should have been## harmless though it was . . . except for hitting the stumps. This brought on Maciver Snr who## in a partnership of 67 with Kellock## helped steady the ship and put Ballinger in a position to take the game to Taplow. Kellock's solid knock of 54 ended with an acrobatic one-handed catch deep in the outfield. Maciver Snr was next to go## falling just short of his half century on 47. The game was left delicately poised with a handful of overs left to bowl and Ballinger 24 runs from victory. Phil Lloyd did the rest## along with a couple of low scoring tail-enders## Lloyd striking the ball imperiously to the boundary## including the only six of the game and the winning runs## a four off the first ball of the last over of the match.

A game played in beautiful surroundings## on a very fine wicket and in the true spirit of Sunday cricket was enjoyed equally (almost) by both teams.

MACIVER I(Captain)
KELLOCK(Wicket Keeper)
STONE
LLOYD
JOHNSON
MAW
McNEIL
MACIVER J
HUGHES K
HUGHES L
TIVEY

Penn cancelled this fixture at the last moment after NK had spent hours sorting out the team

Still another 2 points in the bag.

Ballinger won the toss and decided to field first. Amersham got off to a flying start racing to 44-1 in 7 overs. Will Clark taking the wicket## which was well caught by Sam King. Amersham's opening batsman retired on 30. Captain James Rose took 2-13 (1 of these a very good caught and bowled) and James Butterworth had figures of 2-11 the second wicket a brilliant catch from Alex Humphrey## which put us back in the game. Then Charlie Mead came back to bowl and took 2-4 in his second spell to restrict Amersham to 103.

We started our reply from a steady opening base from Alex Humphries (6) and James Rose (5) but both of those were out in quick succession leaving Charlie Mead and Sam King. They batted well for a couple of overs but then Charlie was unfortunate to be caught by a very good slip catch. Sam King and Robbie Branfield decided to attack the bowlers and crashed the ball to the boundaries## which gave Ballinger a glimmer of hope. When Sam King retired on 31 Robbie continued for about 4 overs before being caught for 12. Daniel Stockdale and Will Clark were both out quickly and we finished 28 short of Amersham ending on 75.

Team J.Rose (Capt.) A. Humphrey G. Kingston## C. Mead## S. King## R. Branfield## D. Stockdale## J. Butterworth## W. Clark## H.Rix## M.Rose Sebastian Richard

Ballinger and Ley Hill fought out another nail biter at LHCC on Saturday Batting first the Waggoners struggled to 167-9 with only skipper Matt Riley showing any form on a slow pitch.

New opener Andy Branigan and Riley looked in no trouble but found it difficult to get the ball away. McIntyre's introduction at the fall of the first wicket soon upped the scoring until he was dismissed by a clever bit of ball juggling by the Hill's gulley fielder. A brief flurry from Davies and a turgid innings from Kerry meant another failure by Ballinger's middle order. Adams then came to the rescue with 25 off 10 balls and with a bit of help from the tail 167 was riches indeed.

Skipper Riley then pulled off a master-stroke when he opened the bowling with Maciver. His left arm spin was very difficult to attack and with Adams as miserly as ever at the other end the Hill found runs equally difficult to acquire.

Slowly but surely Ballingers spin trio of Maciver## Davies and Lawson tightened their grip on the game but with the Hill's Rennard now in full flow would they be able to get the required run rate high enough to overcome the inevitable late charge.

Wickets were beginning to fall as the pressure built but slowly the Hill got closer and closer. Danger man Leadbetter was removed by Adams but then Rennard took 11 off Adams penultimate over. This left him on strike and only 14 needed off the last 2 overs. Lawson concede 8 off his last over and now the game had swung in the Hill's favour. The Hill were now on 162 for 6 needing just 6 to win off the last over. Adams to bowl. The first ball had Nick Lee caught at cover## 1 run off the second brought Rennard on strike then the stroke of luck that changes games. Having batted serenely for his 72 Rennard played on.

5 now required off 3 balls. A scampered single## then a 2 meant 2 required off the last ball. A good clean hit sent the ball steepling into the dark evening night## a roar went up from the Ley Hill crowd only to be stilled when Kerry calmly moved into position to take the catch.

A really good game of cricket## enjoyed by both sides.LHCC 166-9 BWCC 167-10

H+C very graciously played us## although expecting us the night before! It was a good win to start the season## although extras played a large part on both sides. Best batting and bowling performance was by Xavier Owen (batting: 10 for 0## bowling 9 for 2).

A tougher match against keen opposition ended with a narrow victory. Josh Livingstone and Xavier Owen both gained 2 wickets with excellent tight bowling and Harry Glenister achieved a wicket maiden.In the batting Alex Wills stood out with a splendid 19 for 1 (net 13 runs). Of 6 wickets lost 3 were to runouts and poor communication between the wickets## something to improve on in the future. A good cup win. Onwards!BWCC 36 for 6## Wendover 10 for 9.

"Match played on Sun 14th May. Although BWCC lost we were highly praised for our excellent cricket and spirited stand against a very good team by the opposition coach and spectators. Despite facing County bowlers we were unphased and had so many big hits not got to hand it could have been a very different story! Excellent batting performances by all## notably Tom Harrison (14 for 0## net 14)and a confident opening by Rory Seekins in the batting (9 for 0## net 9) as well as the wicket keeping## holding onto a low catch behind the stumps on their first ball.Harry Wells picked up 2 wickets for 11 runs and Jake Cutter the off cutter took a wicket on his first spinny ball! Toby King and Rory also clean bowled 2 batsmen.Communication between the wickets was excellent## in the future we can work on improving our field placement## as despite the Captains instructions fielders crept closer to the wickets and were not always in their optimum position despite clear ""favoured strokes"" by the batsmen.The side was ably captained by Josh Livingstone## Alex Wills bowled very well (6 for 0)batted very well (10 for 1 net 4) and kept well## Xavier bowled in the very tight way we have come to expect!(3 for 0). Joe Carey and Duncan Healy also added to the team effort with very good all round performances.Very well done all.Chesham 292 for 5## BWCC 260 for 6."

Ballinger U13 B's v Beaconsfield15th May 2006On Monday evening## despite heavy threatening skies the U 13B's took on a strong Beaconsfield U13's in a cup game. As has been the case with a number of our fixtures this year we were up against a lot of boys who were a year older## which## at this age makes quite a difference. Beaconsfield batted first and were kept in check by a good opening spell by Jack Hankinson and Luke Hughes. Mid innings acceleration lifted them to a total of 104. The highlight from Ballinger's point of view was a magnificent over from Jack towards the end of the innings which began with a wicket## clean bowled## was followed by two fast dot balls## followed by a wicket and then another wicket as a result of a great one handed catch by Sam King. Jack was now on hat trick and had a good shout for an LBW turned down## to complete a triple wicket maiden. Tom Branigan## in his first outing also bowled well and took two wickets.Ballinger batted against good straight bowling and never## with the exception of James Rose who showed a very good technique## got to grips with the Beaconsfield attack. We were dismissed in the 20th over for 48.The boys and girls need to have the more experience against the hard ball and work hard on their batting. The odds are always going to be a bit against them this season when up against clubs fielding only effectively an 'A' team## but hopefully this will provide good experience and practice for next year when most of the team will still be eligible for U13's cricket.Team: G. Bailey## J. Rose (capt)## A. Humphreys## S King## L. Knowler## T Branigan## H. Rix## H Graham## H. Stone## L. Hughes## J. Hankinson.Paul Rose

Wendover 189 for 10 BWCC 230 for 10.A good win## with very consistent bowling by all## exceptional figures from Harry Wells (4 wickets for 3 runs) against their better batsmen## Robert Rose (2 for 3) Alex Howe (2 for 1) and Joe Carey (2 for 8). Robert and Alex both bowled wicket maidens. Rory Seekins and Jake Cutter bowled excellent spin and were unlucky not to get results. Only 7 extras (14 runs) were conceded.Jamie Wise led the batting with an excellent 19 for 0. Joint 2nd highest scores were Joe and Daniel Cady (both 9 for 0). Everbody scored runs although too many balls were skied (and caught). Luckily some lapses in running between the wickets with the associated poor calling went largely unpunished.The fielding was of a high standard with a fantastic diving catch from Alex Wills in the slips## 2 catches from Rory and 1 from Robert. Euan Jackson was particularly good in the field with a very good eye for the ball. Joe conceded no byes in his 10 overs keeping## Rory only 1.

Ballinger played High Wycombe on Thursday and just for once the sun shone. Unfortunately this might have been one of those occasions when a downpour might have been a saviour.

Batting first Ballinger's main hope was not to let their score go below 100 which they just managed by 8 runs. All the team tried their hardest## especially first timer Charlie Rodwell## but they were no match for Wycombe's accurate bowling.

The Waggoners then has to try and limit Wycombe's strong batting line up to under 300. Again they achieved this keeping them to 280. We even took 4 wickets thanks to some smart fielding and good use of the sun.

Harriot did an excellent job of captaining and the team all worked well together but##we were well and truly trounced by a good Wycombe side and it was with some trepidation that the manager gathered his team around him. Did you have fun he asked and the resounding cry was YES. Well so did I he replied

Harriot Stone## Emily Gould## Gaby Sims## Elliot Davenport## Claudio Bassano## Nick Bartington## Charlie Rodwell## Josh Bright## John Martin## Charlie Hendrson

The 15s made a sound start to their league campaign against strong local rivals Chesham. Batting first against a side containing several county players BWCC lost an early wicket when Richard Clarke was out LBW before Charlie Wells and Ollie Richards steadied the innings. Charlie was the second out## to another LBW decision## with a useful score of 19## bringing in Tom Crick to join skipper Ollie who## having opened his innings with five singles## began to find the boundary. With Tom scoring exclusively in ones## Ollie pushed the score along well until he was out to a brilliant one-handed catch by Andy Goddard off the talented Ali Birkby for 31. Chesham's joy at dismissing Richards was short-lived## however## when Alex Macdonald struck his first ball for four and his second for six## Birkby's first over gaining a wicket but having gone for 19. Alex had found his timing straight away and raced to 30 in only nine scoring shots before being caught. Nick Rose and James Woods added useful## quick runs as the innings drew to a close with a score of 125## probably a few short## given the dominance enjoyed in the middle of the innings.Chesham's top three were all county players and it was important to bowl tightly early on## which Tom and Alex managed## but it was a change of bowling which gained the first wicket when Andy Goddard## playing for the off-spin## was deceived by a perfectly pitched top-spinner from Fergus Hardy. Jason Rance was then dropped first ball off a difficult low chance to square leg. Tight bowling and athletic fielding kept Chesham below the run rate required as they managed only six boundaries in total. James Woods kept tidily and took a neat stumping off Charlie and Tom Crick came back at the end to pick up two wickets including that of Ali Birkby who top-scored with 40. Chesham finished on 87 never having matched BWCC's run-rate in the face of a good all-round bowlingperformance; Tom and Alex being the pick with 2 for 6 and none for eight respectively## both off four overs. Thomas Maw## Jason Stone## in the outfield## and Jeff Moxom distinguished themselves in a very tidy fielding performance for the first match of the season.

Saturdays game was abandoned after we'd fielded for 20+ overs and got very cold and grumpy

Fortunately for Nick the bowling analysis won't appear in the stats.

Amid## steady drizzle we assembled at Flackwell and after a delay we started a reduced length 16 over a side match in what was now steady rain.

We lost the toss and fielded## a decision that backfired on Flackwell as Jack Hankinson## fresh after bowling a triple wicket maiden with his last over against Beaconsfield bowled the best best spell our team have seen this Spring. His four overs yielded 4 wickets for two runs and he was supported by Freddie Gamble who was economic and took a wicket. Luke Hughes took over from Jack and took a wicket with his first ball## leaving Flackwell at a vunerable 19-6 after 9 overs.

The ball soon resembled a bar of soap and Flackwell re-grouped well to finish on 49-7 from their 16 overs## almost half their total comprised of extras due largely to the wet ball and terrible conditions.

After further rain (it never stopped) the Umpires agreed that the game could not continue and as this was the last permitted day to play the match the points were shared. This was a frustration to all of the players however they can be congratulated for sticking at a tough job and playing themselves into a position of strength.

Tim Rix

On a wet## windy and gloomy evening the match at Aston Clinton went ahead thanks to the home side's willingness to play. Aston won the toss and elected to bat but were almost immediately in trouble when BWCC's opening pair of Richard Clarke and Ollie Richards both struck## to leave the home side on 5 for 4 after three overs## good catches in the gully/point region being taken by Richard Wise and Richard Clarke off his opening partner. Although Aston worked hard to improve their score## the BWCC bowlers## using the conditions well## never let them back into the match. Richard Wise## looking quite at home in the older age group## picking up 2 for 8 off his four overs and Freddie Cooke bowling what turned out to be Aston's last man coming in at No. 8. James Stoddart and Dominic Hutson missed out## having been kept back to complete the allotted overs## as skipper Ollie was unaware that Aston were fielding a depleted side.Aston were always going to have difficulty defending a total of 33 and so it proved## BWCC overtaking their score half-way through the fourth over## as Ollie realised the priority of winning the match as soon as possible in the threatening conditions rather than risk giving more of the team batting time.Great credit went to the younger players## who enabled BWCC to fulfil the fixture (and pick up the league points) with only five U15s and fielded with the athleticism and enthusiasm that## together with their vocal support## is becoming their trademark.

The U13A's were beaten by the weather on a miserable sunday morning. Despite the oppostion appearing reluctant to make a start the game finally got under way. BWCC made 19-1 after 6 overs before the rain finally forced a halt to proceedings with Sam Privett not out on 13.
The game has been rearranged for Sunday 28th May.

The U14's came up against a very good Dinton side. The match was played in overcast conditions with rain not far away. BWCC won the toss and decided to bat first - perhaps not the best decision. Within the first 3 overs 4 of the top order were back in the pavillion with 4 runs between them - a disastrous start. James Miller and Jonny Freeman steadied the innings and put some runs on the board. James top scored with 19 runs. Wickets then started to fall regularly as the game progressed. However the U14's managed to bat out the 20 overs## with Chris Coldwell being undefeated on 7. Dinton made short work of the 57 runs required to win losing only 1 wicket due to a good catch by Michael Bryant of the bowling of Jack MacIver. As Dinton progressed towards the target a number of catches were offered but none went to hand. Scores:- BWCC 56-8 Dinton 57-1Team:- Tom Sperring## Jeff Moxom## Luke Martin## James Miller## Jonny Freeman## Lewis Ostacchini## Chris Coldwell## Jack MacIver## Michael Bryant## Aaron Bailey## Paul Probert

The match was played on a very pleasant sunny evening. BWCC won the toss and asked Winslow to bat. Winslow made a good start but some good bowling by Jack MacIver and Luke Martin soon got among the wickets to peg Winslow back. The turning point for BWCC came when Alex Morgen took 3 wickets in his second over and ended with figures of 3-1-6-4 - well done Alex. As the final overs came## Winslow increased their score as BWCC tried to take the last wicket. BWCC were set a stiff target of 96 to win and sadly lost an early wicket. However Tom Sperring and Luke Martin steadied the innings. When Tom was out for 11## James Miller came to the wicket and the game turned again towards BWCC. Luke and James took BWCC's score to 81 for 2 when Luke was out for a very good 34 and James followed him shortly after for 28 - his first four deliveries being dispatched for 4's. There then followed a flurry of wickets but Jack MacIver used his county experience and held the innings together and hit the winning run to end up 6 not out. BWCC got home with over to spare but it was becoming very tense over the last few overs. All the BWCC team contributed to the win and was well deserved.

scores Winslow 95-9 BWCC 96-7

Team:- Tom Sperring## Jeff Moxom## Luke Martin## James Miller## Lewis Ostacchini## Aaron Bailey## Jack MacIver## Alex Morgan## Michael Bryant## Chris Coldwell## Jonny Freeman

Scores BWCC 303-1 Taplow 184-9

Full report to follow

The league match against Holmer Green was a victim of the current drought. Although the square was playable## standing water in several places around the outfield rendered the ground umplayable. Match abandoned - one point each.

The U13A's scored a comfortable league win against Cublington. Batting first Cublington struggled against all the Ballinger bowlers who restricted the oppostion to 43 all out in the 13th over.

In reply the Ballinger batsmen edged their way to victory taking few risks in the process eventually reaching their target for the loss of two wickets after 16 overs.

Not a great match for the spectators after the last ball thriller at Chesham but a solid performance by the team looking to put together a good run

Scorecard:
Cublington 43 all out (12.5 overs) (Alex Morgan 3-13## James Stoddart 2-6## Jack Maciver 2-18## George Bartlett 1-2)

Ballinger 45-2 (15.3 overs) (James Wood 14*## Stefan Otto 13)

"

From a precarious 16-4## Ballinger recovered magnificently to reach 120.
Kristian Otto led the charge batting aggresively even after being struck a nasty blow on the arm. Kristian finally holed out to deep mid wicket. At the other Luke Martin batted with great timing and power constantly piercing the Amersham field. Luke was finally forced to retire on reaching the maximum score of 30## a great knock under immense pressure. At 94-8 off 16 overs the tail responded magnificently with 26 coming off the last four overs with Dominic## Stoddy and Adam (a six over cover) all scoring vital runs.

The Amersham reply got off at a tremendous pace scoring at 10 an over for the first few overs. Adam Robinson produced a great spell to stem the tide and picked up a couple of vital wickets. Jack Maciver responded to the challenge with a couple of great overs and George Bartlett also bowled a great spell getting both turn and bounce to trouble the Amersham batsmen.

So after all that had gone before it came down to the final over with responsibilty falling on Sam Privett with eight needed by the home team. Two from the first ball## 6 from 5 needed## then a wicket## dot ball## dot ball## two scored so finally four needed off the last ball. The ball went in the air## but how far was it going## not far enough as Stefan took the catch## Ballinger had sneaked home. All the five Amersham dismisals were catches## all going to the Otto's with Kristian collecting one and Stefan the other four.

Credit to both teams## a fantastic game of cricket.
One key stat from the game## Amersham conceded 17 byes## Ballinger just two## which shows that Woody was great behind the wicket but also that the bowlers bowled straight even when under tremendous pressure.
One final memory of that evening. A snick from the Amersham batsman to the keeper and great shouts of Howzat! Definately out if the ball carried## but did it carry. As the umpires shrugged shoulders at each other## James Wood was heard to say ""It didn't carry umpire## not out!""Fantastic sportsmanship in an extremely tense## close game## well done James!

One final thought## at their respective schools I hope the two camps are back talking to each other!!

Scorecard:
Ballinger 120 all out (20 overs) (Luke Martin 30(retired)## Kristian Otto 19)
Amersham 117 for 6 (20 overs) (Sam Privett 2-6## Adam Robinson 2-10## George Bartlett 1-16)

"

How much longer can we live on the success at Ley Hill.

2 of the the matches we've missed playing have been against opposition that we should be looking to beat. You can bet your mortgage that it won't rain when we're playing Holmer Green

Under some welcome sunshine at Wooburn## Ballinger were asked to bat first by the opposition.
Although not in any real trouble against the bowlers## Ballinger found runs hard to come by on a slow wicket and slow outfield. Sam & Tom Sperring put on 36 for the second wicket. It was vital to up the run rate in the final few overs and Richard Wise and James Stoddart managed this with some clean hitting and quick running between the wickets with Richard hitting a couple of much needed boundaries. A couple of run outs today## guys you need to run that bat in.

In reply the home batsman struggled against a Ballinger attack that all bowled a good line and length with Wise## Maciver## Robinson and Stoddart all conceeding just 8 runs with Richard & Jack unlucky not to pick up the wicket their bowling deserved. James Stoddart was the chief destroyer picking up four wickets## being a fingertip away from taking five. It was good to see Dom back bowling after his injury troubles. Callum Bright bowled a fine over picking up a wicket and Sam Privett with his consistent straight arm took two wickets including the final wicket to clinch the victory.Joe Carey and Jamie Wise both fielded well with Jamie showing good speed and an accurate throw to set up a run out.
Only one bye conceeded## well done Tom Watts behind the stumps. There were seven catches taken (2 c&b) and the team was well led by James Stoddart

Scorecard:
Ballinger 85-4 (20 overs) (Sam Privett 24## Richard Wise 17*## Tom Sperring 14## James Stoddart 11*)
Wooburn Nark's 46 all out (19.1 overs) (James Stoodart 4-8## Sam Privett 2-3## Callum Bright 1-5## Adam Robinson 1-8)

BWCC 220 for 9 Beaconsfield 282 for 8

An excellent effort against a top A team. Looking at the Stats## extras were low and equal and ignoring wickets they scored 97 runs off the bat against our 41. In other words their tight bowling restricted our batsman## as did their field placement that was set deeper preventing 4's.

Otherwise our bowling was of a high order with an equal number of extras (exactly the same) and wickets (roughly the same. Xavier Owen's figures were 1 wkt for 7 runs off 3 overs## Jamie Wise 1 for 7 and Tom Harrison an excellent 2 for 9.

Everyone batted well against consistent and aggresive bowling with Harry Glenister top scoring with 9 runs for no wickets and Jamie Wise and Xavier both getting 7 for 0. All 3 scores were against their best bowlers.

Lesson to learn: deeper field placement and response to where the batsmen are hitting the ball.

Ley Hill 237 for 8 BWCC 278 for3

Congratulations to all on very consistent play. Josh Livingstone was the star in the batting with 20 (5 fours). In the bowling Alex Howe and Xavier Owen both took 2 wickets for 4 runs## Alex narrowly missing a hat-trick## Nick Batington and Josh L. both took 1 for 1.

Fielding was generally good.

Areas to work on: backing up## 2 runs were lost for running short and the calling between the wickets was sometimes quiet or non existent.

The Waggoners overtook Wendover's score comfortably in the end but it could have been so much more difficult for Ballinger if Wendover had held their catches. This match was played on the artificial wicket at the Witchell ground## Wendover's main ground being out of action because of insurance problems relating to balls being hit onto the by-pass. Batting first## Wendover began steadily## with opener Morley picking up what runs were offered by tight bowling from Alex Macdonald and Ollie Richards. Once the Ballinger quicker bowlers were off they attempted to pick up the scoring rate and## although Charlie Wells kept control## Aaron Bailey and Sam Privett suffered from some heaves. Two went to hand to give Sam two wickets and James Stoddart and Thomas Maw finished the allotted overs tidily## James getting a bit of swing and a wicket. Alex and Ollie finished with one for ten off four overs and one for five off three respectively. Morley batted through the innings to finish on 42 not out## out of a total of 93.

In reply Jeff Moxom and Charlie Wells opened with 20 from five overs before Jeff was out to a smart catch behind the wicket. In came skipper Richards## to be dropped first ball from a none too difficult chance## off a leading edge## at mid-off## and then survive a run-out chance taking a second on the mis-field. They were opportunities Wendover could not afford to miss but they were only the first as every Ballinger batsman survived a chance as the run rate accelerated; Charlie Wells making 16## Ollie a quickfire 18## Alex a brutal not out 31 and James Woods 8 not out. The innings closed as the evening got gloomy in the 14th over. Ballinger are through to the next round of the cup with much credit going to the younger players as only four 15 year olds were available. Lewis Ostacchini and James Miller performed athletically in the field and Aaron## Sam and both James all contributed with ball or behind the stumps.

Ballinger notched their fifth win in a row on a glorious sunny evening at Stokenchurch.

Although this looks a comfortable win on paper in reality it was a different story. To many of the top order fancied their chances against the Stokenchurch bowlers but lack of concentration and application meant early wickets fell cheaply. Richard Wise made double figures then threw his wicket away with a rash shot while Callum Bright## Evan Webster and Jamie Wise batted sensibly to see out the 20 overs and to push the score past 80. The innings was rescued by Luke Martin. Carrying on his good form of late he showed the others how to mix solid defence with attack (4 fours## 1 six) finally being forced to retire having made 33. Fortunately Stokenchurch also gave us 22 runs in extras.

It was hoped that the Ballinger attack would be too strong for the opposition and so it proved with only 25 runs conceeded off the bat off 20 overs. However## a somtimes sloppy performance in the field cost 25 extras. Adam Robinson bowled well again conceeding just one run off his four overs. Six Stokenchurch batsmen were bowled## three by James Stoddart (Captain for today)## one by Sam Privett and Callum Bright making the most of his opportunity picked up two. Well done to Joe Carey## Jamie Wise and Evan Webster for their commitment and concentration.

Scorecard:
Ballinger 87 for 8 (20 overs) (Luke Martin 33 (retired)## Richard Wise 10## Callum Bright 6)

Stokenchurch 50 for 7 (20 overs) (James Stoddart 3-5## Callum Bright 2-2## Sam Privett 1-1)

Downley 202 - 5 BWCC 204 - 5

Ballinger skipper Matt Riley had a great time on Saturday when he led Ballinger to their 1st MBL win of the season.

Winning the toss and putting Downley in on a good pitch always looked a difficult decision but good opening spells from Adams & Humphreys calmed his nerves. Sadly Downley's Peacock hadn't read the script and his 120 was one of the best innings seen at Ballinger. 202 looked a useful score but Riley and Branigan gave the Waggoners a solid start## then Mathews and Humphreys helped Riley edge closer to the finish line. Two lusty blows from Adams reduced the asking rate and finally a huge 6 by Riley## in the last over## finished the game in the Waggoners favour.

A perfectly timed innings of 108no by Riley was the toast of the day ( especialy by those belonging to the God Boycott faith) but once more everyone enjoyed an excellent game of cricket played in the right spirit.

Chalfont St.Giles 280 - 5 BWCC 193-14

Ballinger's beginners had another tough day at the office on Sunday. With three of the team playing their first hard ball game and others playing their first match of the season the team were no match for a strong Chalfont team.

Bowling first Ballinger's bowlers did well in that they only concede 18 wides or no balls. Pick of the bowlers was Ed Cousins with 2 wickets and Michael Hinds who bowled two very tidy overs of leg spin. Harriet was her usual economical self## conceding only 1 run in her two overs. Max or Ben Dugdale (give me a clue how to tell them apart) did and excellent job behind the stumps and only 4 byes went past.

When batting the first 2 pairs## Chris Cooke## Max Dugdale## Charlie Rodwell & Ben Dugdale## were doing really well and had 33 on the board then disaster struck in the 8th over when 3 wickets were lost. From then on it was down hill as each pair lost wickets too frequently for the coaches comfort.

Chalfont were a good team with mostly U11s playing whilst Ballinger went for the youth policy and played mostly U9s. The team were well led by Harriet again## the sun shone## everyone enjoyed themselves so it was a lovely way to spend a Sunday morning.

Coaching points to work on - a few defensive shots with a straight bat would be a start.

TeamHarriet Stone## Chris Cooke## Ben Dugdale## Max Dugdale## Tom Moody## Charlie Henderson## Harry Wills## Charlie Rodwell## Michael Hinds & Ed Cousins
The match between Marlow Park and BWCC U11A had to abandoned because of the weather in spite of twice trying to get it played.

"A tight game with generally good bowling (King Rose and Bassano geting maidens)and Cady and Jackson getting wickets## the former with a catch by Rose## the latter with an LBW. Only 5 extras (10 runs).Wills got an excellent stumping as wicket keeperThe batting was consistent with the odd breakdown in communication giving away 2 wickets. Glenister got 14 for 1 (net 8) and Jackson got 10 for 1 (net 4).Seekins and Rose batted last needing 29 to win. They put on 21(net 15) sadly for the loss of a wicket in their 4 overs## Seekins top scoring with 16 and narrowly missing a 6 on a distant boundary. They gave an excellent diaplay of good communication and running fast between the wicketsAreas to improve:Communication between the wickets by everyone and fielding. Out of 10 ""fieldings"" only 2-3 were not fumbled on pick-up losing several opportunities for Run outs.BWCC 244 for 7 Winslow 256 for 3"

Hawridge & Cholesbury 181-4 v BWCC 177-3

Ballinger were Srilankered on Saturday.

Batting first Ballinger crawled to 177 off their 45 overs. Rollo McIntyre scored a belligerent 95 but only 74 came off the bat at the other end which## on a good wicket at Hawridge## was never going to be enough.

Hawridge's new Sri Lankan## Sankalpa## opened the bowling with a tight spell of 1-16 then opened the batting and was 76no as Hawridge passed the Waggoners total with 14 overs to spare. He was helped by a rapid 39 by Suranga.

Hawridge are a good side and being beaten by them is no disgrace but the manner of the defeat is another matter

Matt Riley## Andy Branigan## Rollo McIntyre## Ian Davies## Paul Humphreys## Nigel Kerry## Ian Maciver## Roger Lawson## Phil Lloyd## Nick Adams## Jack Maciver

Aldbury 92-10 v BWCC 93-9

Stonewall Jason saved the day for Ballinger on Sunday.

Playing on the worst pitch seen for many years Ballinger managed to scrape home in the last over thanks to some valiant defensive work by Jason Stone and a controlled innings from Paul Humphreys.

The bowlers had done their job with the wickets being shared around. Even skipper Salisbury recognised the chance of some cheap wickets. Aldbury managed just 67 off the bat but chasing their 92 on this pitch always looked a difficult task. Their determination to win was shown in their use of just 3 bowlers.

Ballinger's batsmen had to decide whether to go down all guns blazing before they got out to the dreaded shooter or just block. Paul Humphreys managed to mix a bit of both and found a valuable ally in Jason Stone who chose the blocking option. Slowly and not without alarms they edged the Waggoners close to victory. Then disaster. Paul got one that pitched then shot straight along the ground.

Out marched Dom Birkby with 6 needed to win off 2 overs. A confident drive## a couple of byes## an overthrow## 2 edges and finally a deft prod by Jason was just enough to win the day

It was an exciting finish but not a game for the purists and a venue the fixture secretary needs to play at next year.

TeamGraham Salisbury## Ian Davies## Jamie Kellock## Tom Maw## Tom McNeil## Rick Brockett## Dom Birkby## ##Jason Stone## Richard Clarke## Michael Maw## Paul Humphreys

Holmer Green 52 -10 BWCC 54-4

When Holmer Green reached 28 off 3 overs Ballinger fielders were looking at each other trying to guess how many over 200 they were going to have to chase. 13 overs later Ian Maciver and Paul Humphreys led the Waggoners off the pitch have bowled Holmer Green out for 52. Ian Macivers figures were 8-5-8-6. This was high quality left arm spin. Humpreys did his job at the other end taking 4-29 and## for once## Ballinger's fielders had their catching hands on. Ben Whelan set the example with 3 fine catches but Andy Branigans diving effort was probably the pick of the 7 taken.

The Green made Ballinger work for their runs but it was always going to be too much to ask and Ian Davies led the Waggoners home in just 15 overs

Matt Riley## Ian Davies## Andy Branigan## Jeremy Hunting## Rollo McIntyre## Tom McNeil## ##Ian Maciver## Ben Whelan## James Fallowfield-Smith## Paul Humphreys## Nigel Kerry

Presidents 204-8 BWCC 205-9

Ballinger enjoyed another victory on Sunday against a strong Presidents X1. Batting first the Presidents side reached 204 with only Nick Adams 3-58 and Ian Davies 2-45 making any impression.

President skipper Matt Riley used a missing jock strap as an excuse to drop down the order. He then sent his younger brother in to blunt Ballinger's opening attack## in particular Adams. Having made sure the bowlers were tired and the ball soft he made maximum use of an excellent batting track and rattled up a quick 92 (quick being a relative term).

The Waggoner's then timed their run chase to perfection. Fallowfield - Smith led the way with an excellent 41. Making sure the Saturday skipper was watching in the hope it might get him moved up the order (buying copious quantities of beer tends to be more effective Fally). Then Jeremy Hunting's first appearance in a helmet at Ballinger obviously helped him as he added a watchful 49 and got Ballinger very close to their target## but with 9 wickets down and Pete Clifford on fire## it needed a skippers innings from Salisbury to guide them home in the last over.

It was a great day and it was wonderful too see many people (especially children) watching. A very big thank you to Matt & Big G for putting on a fantastic lunch## Ben for sorting out the tea and Nigel for picking 12 players - again

Salisbury## Davies## Hunting## Adams## Humphreys## McNeil## Fallowfield-Smith## Hughes

Despite the rain Ballingers C team enjoyed another outing on Tuesday by the river at Marlow

Fielding first Ballinger kept Marlow down to 285 but too many of these were extras. Max Dugdale did another good job behind the stumps but work needs to be done on backing up as too many overthrows etc.

Max Wilson and John Martin both did well with the bat but although Ballinger scored more runs than Marlow they also lost too many wickets

Compliments were received from the opposition manager and from the spectators as how well the team tried and behaved

Hooray! We played on grass## albeit a very slow and low wicket.

Winning the toss James Rose chose to bat and we got off to a great start with an opening stand of 49 with Charlie Mead and Freddie Gamble both striking the ball well. This impetus was continued well by Alex Humphrey and James Rose who mixed good shot selection with some solid hits. We lost only four wickets in making 103 which showed good control with four boys making 20 or more.

In the field we were keen to keep the run rate challenging and this was helped by a good opening spell by Charlie and Freddie who were both accurate and frugal. A run out off the first over helped our cause and Bovingdon were always behind the run rate required. Bowling changes allowed seven boys the chance to bowl## each of whom created problems for the Bovingdon bowlers. Harry Rix picked up two wicket including one in his first over as did Sebastian Richards who was unlucky to bowl just two overs when proving hard to hit with some nice flight despite being weighed down by a plaster cast on his right arm!

Good support came from Hugo Graham and Tom Branigan at the death and we ran out good winners.

>Plus points were our best batting performance of the season## some accurate bowling and loads of encouragement in the field between team members. Well done all of you!

Home Team: Bovingdon (Batting second) 49 for 5 Away Team : Ballinger Under 13B (Batting first )103 for 4

Away again!

Kingshill batted first and their District openers took full toll on anything short with excellent pulling and hard hitting. One opener retired after reaching 30 and their number 3 continued the strong scoring. Harry Rix at first change took two wickets including opener Charlie Young and the run rate was held in check somewhat by some better bowling by Basty Richards and an inspired spell by James Rose who managed his first ever 5 wicket haul. Well done James!

Ballinger however did not help their cause in the field with sloppy ground fielding and lack of concentration with field positions. In all around 30 runs were probably given away needlessly and this can make the difference between winning and losing.

Chasing a challenging 127 we lost an early wicket when Freddie Gamble was run out after a mix up. Thereafter the boys batted sensibly and consolidated their position. Alex Humphrey again batted well and he had good support from Sam King## James Rose and George Kingston.

Kingshill bowled well and fielded better and we eventually ran out of overs with our score on 89. So a loss by 28 runs to a team of mainly Year 8's## not a disaster but a match where more concentration on the basics of fielding and good length bowling could have seen a different result.

Stick at it boys and girls!Tim

Beaconsfield won the toss and decided to bat. In spite of scoring 8 off the first 2 balls Ballinger soon started to put the screw on the opening pair with tight seam bowling. At the end of 4 overs Beaconsfield were 199 having lost 4 wickets. Some great bowling from Tom Edmonds and Matthew Dunnington. The bowling continued to be very tight backed up by some great ground fielding which resulted in a run out. With the combination of spin bowling and genuine pace Beaconsfield found it hard to accumulate runs. They ended on 266 having lost 9 wickets in the process.

Ballinger started their innings by losing a wicket on the first ball. This just served to get the openers to dig in and progressed to 204 losing another wicket in the process. Will Smith and Andy Rishton had a little trouble in their calling but also managed to add valuable runs taking the score to 217.

Tom McIntyre and Tom Butterworth came in and showed how runs can be easily accumulated by using the pace of the ball and playing simple cricket shots. They moved the score on to 233.

At this point it seemed that if we carried on playing in the same vein we could win.

Max Maciver and Harry Bartlett did just this inspite of Beaconsfield continuing with their probing bowling and good fielding.

The last pair of Joe Hankinson and Matthew Dunnington took the responsibility of stearing the team to victory. 266 was passed in the 19th over and then they knew they just had to get 6 runs ahead in case there was a wicket. This they did with confidence.

We now look forward to playing Winslow Town in the semis.

England football teams poor effort in failing to finish 2nd## as usual## means that they have spoilt Ballingers chance to continue their winning streak.

When asked## skipper Salisbury felt that an extra days rest might just give his top team that extra edge for the next game

Ballinger 113-7 (20 overs)
Winchmore Hill 64-8 (20 overs)

After a mixup on dates between the two clubs## this match was re-arranged for 7th June. An important date for all the boys who had sat Common Entrance exams that day## and arrived tired but in great spirits for the match## and were determined to enjoy themselves ! Sam Privett was captain for today.

Ballinger batted first## and although Sam Privett and Stefan Otto got off to a slow start with only 15 runs by the end of the 7th over## their excellent technique and some encouragement from their team members boosted their confidence## and they started to find the gaps in the field## putting the pressure on the Winchmore fielders. Luke Martin and Richard Wise both batted well## before a very lively Kristian Otto came into bat## and scored a smart 17 off the bat## and seized every possible opportunity given away by the fielding side## before eventually being Run Out. The boys had done enough with 91 off the bat## 22 extras## making their score 113 for 7 off 20.

Sam 28 bowled; Stefan 23 caught; Kristian Otto 17 run out;Luke Martin 8 bowled ; Richard Wise 8 caught

Adam Robinson opened the bowling with a wicket off the first ball of the first over## and set the tone for the bowling to come. James Stoddart bowled beautifully## with 3 maiden overs and only a 4 scored against him. Dominic## Sam## Richard## Luke & Callum all bowled well too## keeping the Winchmore Hill batsmen right down to just 49 runs. Luckily they could afford the 15 extras given away! Three excellent catches in the field## one behind by Tom Watts (w/k); one by Tom Sperring## and one somersault catch by James Stoddart to make Callum smile from ear to ear with a final maiden-wicket-over!

Bowlers: Adam Robinson 2 for 5 off 3## Golden-arm Stoddy 0 for 4 off 4 - and very unlucky not to pick up the wicket(s) he deserved## Dominic Hutson 2 for 15 off 4## Sam Privett 1 for 17 off 4 (with a change in bowling action)## Richard Wise 0 for 5 off 3 (again## unlucky not to pick up a wicket)## Luke Martin - 1 for 3 off 1## Callum - bowled the final over - only maiden-wicket-over of the match - well done !

Well done to all the boys ! The parents all remarked on what a fun match it had been to watch as well (that may have been down to the refreshment provided by Steve P!!). To top it all## we discovered an excellent scorer in Steve Sperring - you're forgiven for leaving your chair behind because all your scoring cross-added perfectly! Thank you.

Match Summary from last night:Although Chesham were not the strongest opposition they have faced the overall performance by everyone was excellent. I asked them to concentrate this time on not loosing wickets and building a score. Without exception everyone tried to do this and only 2 wickets were lost in the whole innings. Everyone batted well. The wicket was dreadfulEvan & Tom B - Good steady start## good running. Highlight## probably Tom E's lofted drive straight back over the bowlers headMax & Will. - Built on the start## continued to pick up the singles. Highlight - Will stepping slowly down the wicket to every ball in the last over which was OK because he didn't slog it & made sure he got something on it.Tom B & Tom Mc - Batted in a similar fashion to the other night . Nothing stupid## picked up the singles and hit the odd bad ball for 4 four. Highlight - Tom B taking a lifting ball on the helmet.Andrew & Guyan - Both reasonably calm ## good running with Guyan looking to give Andrew more of the strike. One wicket lost - run out. Never run if you cannot see the ball. Highlight - Shot of the day by Andrew## a clip off his legs through mid wicket.Mat & Joe. Much the same as the other night. Probably added about 30 even after loosing one wicket. Joe's was the innings of the day with some terrific off drives.The fielding & bowling was good throughout and wickets fell all the way through. One area of improvement - reduce the extras## especially wides. They also need to make sure that they don't loose their shape in the field as there is a tendency for everyone to slowly creep in.Finally and the most important point of all. The attitude of all the boys towards weaker opposition was fantastic. I received several comments about their conduct on & off the pitch. All were a credit to themselves & the club.

On an absolutely baking Sunday afternoon## the boys met their toughest opponents yet with the U13 cup quarter final against High Wycombe played at home. Very few of the boys have had an opportunity to play on a real pitch so far## and a full-sized pitch too.

Ballinger opened the batting with Sam Privett and Stefan Otto## who braved a phenomenal opening spell from the fast High Wycombe bowlers. Luke Martin at 3## batted well## and scored 9 before being bowled. It looked as though we were going to be all out rather quickly## but then we had some solid performances by our mid-order to tail end batsmen## who recovered the situation quickly and impressively. Alex Morgan 8## James Stoddart 9## Richard Wise 11## Dominic Hutson 21## and Tom Sperring 7. This recovery spurred the boys on## and dented High Wycombe's confidence## denying them the last three wickets.

Dominic 21 not out## Richard Wise 11 caught## Luke Martin & James Stoddart 9 apiece## Alex Morgan 8## Tom Sperring 7 - (and a debate re the contentious runout followed over the next week!). Final Score 68 off the bat + 34 extras = 107 for 7 off 20

High Wycombe came in to bat a little less confidently than might have otherwise been the case. James Stoddart opened the bowling with a serious maiden over## followed by really good spells from Luke Martin & Richard Wise as well kept the HW score down to 16 off 5; then 39 off 8 before things started to slip away from them. Despite some good bowling by the boys## and captain Stefan desperately trying to keep one particular batsman on strike## the High Wycombe batsmen 3 & 4 started to really put the runs on and denied the Ballinger bowlers the wickets they so desperately needed. High Wycombe finished on 84 off the bat + 20 extras = 103 for 1 off 16 overs.

I know the boys were disappointed - but I was pleased with their performance - we were simply outclassed on this occasion. At least they made HW work for hard for their victory.

BWCC 185-5 (20 overs)
Ley Hill 76-7 (20 overs)

Knowing that the famous king-of-swing Jack plays for Ley Hill (8 wickets in a single District match last year!!!)## and finding ourselves back on artificial## didn't do my nerves much good on the evening.

Ballinger batted first## opening as usual with Sam Privett and Stefan Otto. However## despite Jack Thompson bowling Stefan for an unlucky 2## Ballinger upped their game and started to really put the runs on## taking advantage of some sloppy fielding## several wides## and a very fast outfield with a short boundary one side to achieve a magnificent 185 for 5 off 20. (A total of 23 fours & 3 sixes !!)Top scorers: Alex Morgan 37 not out (got to 36 before needed to retire## but with only 1 ball to go## the LH umpire insisted he stay put …. Shame you didn't hit another 6 then Alex ?!)Luke Martin 31 retiredJames Stoddart 28 (caught)Dominic Hutson 28 (bowled -jinxed after being told by scorers he had to retire## but this turned out to be an error - byes didn't count !!)Sam Privett 18 bowledFinal score 155 off the bat + 30 extras = 185 for 5 off 20

Often when the boys bat well## the fielding slips## but not tonight! Tom Watts kept wicket like a dream (having been fed an espresso coffee after a week's school trip away !!)## and was only escaped by 1 bye. The boys shared the bowling between 8 of them## and did so confidently knowing that their generally superior fielding would be enough to hold onto their victory comfortably.There were some superb throw ins from Sam Privett and Dominic Hutson; catches by Sam## Tom Watts & Adam## and the boys kept up the pressure throughout## keeping the Ley Hill batsmen down to just 66 + 10 extras = 76 for 7 off 20

Top Bowlers: James Stoddart 2 for 14 off 4## Adam Robinson 2 for 13 off 3## Richard Wise 1 for 14 off 4## Luke Martin 0 for 7 off 3## Stefan Otto 1 for 4 off 1

Ballinger batted first again## comfortable that even though they lost the toss## with the breadth of batsmen and bowlers within the squad## they no longer need to work out what score they're chasing## but leave that to the opposition to worry about!

Alex Morgan and George Bartlett opened the batting facing H&C's top bowler - who proceeded to despatch our first 3 batsmen a little quicker than anticipated## despatching top scalp Luke Martin for 0 . Kristian Otto (batting at 4) came in and proceeded to chalk up some sensible quick singles## a couple of fours and a six. He was as stunned as the H&C wicket-keeper himself to be caught behind after scoring 26 runs and snatching several byes & misfields. Dominic added a further 12 runs off the bat before also being caught behind with an unlucky top edge. The wicket-keeper's 2 minutes of stardom faded quickly as Jack Maciver and Richard Wise both met their targets of batting sensibly and retiring at 30 and 31 respectively - well done lads ! The sudden disappearance of batsmen 6 & 7 caused panic in the Ballinger dressing room as not one but two batsmen were suddenly needed within one run of each other## and someone wasn't ready at all ! Never mind Tom Sperring - you redeemed yourself in the field as usual with your steadfast fielding & excellent concentration.

Richard Wise 31 retired## Jack Maciver 30 retired## Kristian Otto 26 caught behind## Dominic Hutson 12 caught behind## George Bartlett 11 caught##
Final score: 113 off the bat + 32 extras (whoops!) = 145 for 6 off 20

Jack Maciver opened the bowling## finding excellent line and length## with only one run off the first over## a wicket maiden in his 2nd and only 1 run again off his 3rd over to complete a really good spell. Luke Martin quickly despatched the other opening batsmen (tit-for-tat!) in a superb bowled & caught. Luke continued to keep H&C's number 3 in check## and despite a couple of byes and a few wides## he regained his composure with a total of just 7 runs scored against him off the bat in 4 overs.

H&C started to up the run rate## using Richard Wise's speed against him and finding the boundary on several occasions before Gary Emery retired on 31. Dominic captained well## encouraging the rest of the Ballinger bowlers to re-focus on accuracy## and with the help of Tom Sperring## regained control of the match by reminding a few of the fielders about concentration and team effort. W/Keeper Tom Watts - you certainly had your work cut out for you in this match! Well done.

Jack Maciver 1 for 2 off 3## Luke Martin 2 for 7 off 4## Richard Wise 0 for 22 off 4## Adam Robinson 1 for 4 off 3## JoJo Stevens 1 for 10 off 3## Dominic Hutson 1 for 7 off 2## Alex Morgan 1 for 1 off 1
Final score: 56 off the bat + 27 extras (16 wides + 5 noballs; 3 byes & 3 leg-byes - whoops !). = 83 for 8 off 20

Widmer End 164-10 BWCC 162-10Adams onslaught fails at End

Ballinger missed the opportunity of moving into the top half of the table on Saturday when they contrived to lose a game they should have won easily. Widmer End won the toss and elected to bat first. They were soon in trouble at 19-3 with Lloyd in particular causing lots of problems. An excellent innings by Saead enabled Widmer to reach 164 but his dismissal by Davies started a rapid collapse. Davies finished with 5-38. Not a true reflection of how he bowled.

Ballinger had 54 overs to score the runs but only Riley and Humphreys played with any conviction and at 121-9 the Waggoners were down and out. In strolled Adams and in 20 balls he completely changed the game. He scored 39 and with 5 overs left the game was in the bag. Unfortunately he tried one heave too many and lost his middle stump leaving the Waggoner 3 runs short of victory.

Skipper Riley said that to get so close and not win was very frustrating but until we bat as a team we're not going to win these games.

Monks Risborough 308 -3 BWCC 192-10

Ballinger would like to draw a veil over events at the Green on Saturday.

A combination of injuries## holidays and some football match left the Waggoners with a much weakened team. Monks Risborough took full advantage of this and## batting first## rattled up the first ever 300 score at Ballinger. The wicket was fast and true## the outfield like lightning## the temperature in the 90s and Ballingers bowlers were put to the sword. 308 came up in only 32 overs.

Ballinger's reply was brilliantly led by Adams who for some time had the Waggoners up with the required rate## but when he was out for 90 the rest of the batting subsided tamely and the Waggoners finished on 192.

Injured skipper Matt Riley would like to thank Jack & Max Maciver and Andrew Rishton 12##10 & 11 years old respectively for turning out in place of some senior players and many of the older juniors. Ian Maciver got his wish of playing in the same side as his sons but I don't think he expected it to happen so soon

BWCC 220-9 Penn St. 141- 10

Another blistering hot day at Ballinger saw the Waggoners batsman take full advantage of the conditions. With skipper Salisbury leading the way with 57no##Webster (37) and Camp(39) making useful contributions on there season debuts## Ballinger were able to declare on 220.

Webster then removed Penn Streets openers## Lloyd produced a good spell of 3-24 and Fallowfield-Smith cleaned up the tale with 3-11. Not a bad effort whilst wearing his pads and gloves. A good all-round fielding display by Ballinger reduced Penn Street to 141 -10

The Salisbury machine rumbles on.

Ballinger Under 15s Against Ley Hill Under 15s on 16 June 2006

Ballinger Under 15s produced another excellent performance in beating Ley Hill. Ley Hill batted first but struggled early on against a superb display of pace bowling from Tom Crick who had match figures of 3 wickets for 7 runs off his 4 overs. He was well supported by his fellow bowlers## in particular Fergus Hardy 1 wicket for 5 runs off his 4 overs## Charlie wells 2 wickets for 10 runs off 4 overs and Jason Stone 1 wicket for 5 runs off 2 overs. Ley Hill were dismissed for 75 runs off 19 overs.

Ballinger made an excellent start in reply with a fine opening partnership of 29 runs from Richard Clarke and Charlie Wells.## The team were brought home by Ollie Richards with 28 not out and James Wood 13 not out.

A thoroughly professional performance from Ballinger Under 15s.

The Nick Rose - Ollie Richards combination swept away the top of Winslow's batting order to set up a comfortable win that confirmed Waggoner's place at the top of Conference 3 and earn them a place in the league semi-finals. Batting first after winning the toss Winslow opened with Bishop and the dangerous Callum Price. Tom Crick and Alex Macdonald opened the bowling for Ballinger and made good use of a quick## bouncy pitch but without taking a wicket as they completed their allotted overs.

With the bowling changes came the wickets however. First Fergus Hardy tempted Price into a lofted drive but “did” him in the flight. Tom Maw judging the catch nicely at mid-on and making it look easier than it was. But it was Ollie Richards charging in from the White Hut End who found the pitch most to his liking. Getting plenty of bounce he had the Winslow batsmen constantly in difficulty on the back-foot and induced four chances behind the wicket where they were gobbled up by Nick Rose. Nick## who has not kept regularly this season## turned in an immaculate performance## not just in taking the chances but in his glove work generally. Ollie finished with 5 wickets for 8 runs from his overs before Charlie Wells and Jason Stone polished off the tail. Charlie taking 2 for 6## aided by a stunning one-handed catch by Jason at slip## and Jason 1 for 1 off one over. The last wicket was a smart run-out by Alex Macdonald who removed the brave H. Bishop## youngest of the Bishop brothers## who had been pressed into service after a late drop-out and offered some late resistance## pulling Wells for a boundary. Winslow finished on 70 all out## probably a few more than they should have got after Ballinger placed some over attacking fields and conceded a few too many extras.

Ballinger started steadily but Richard Clarke was bowled off an inside edge to bring Ollie Richards in to join Charlie Wells. They progressed steadily until the beginning of the 9th over when Ollie cut lose against the leg-spin of the felicitously named Turns## smashing 18 off 5 balls## before offering a hard caught-and-bowled which was taken. Tom Crick then came in and he didn't hang about either hitting a rapid 9 before Charlie caught the mood and pulled a six to finish the match on the last ball of the tenth over## unbeaten on 21; 34 having come off the last two overs as Waggoners came home on 71 for 2. Ballinger now go into a semi-final against Stokenchurch away.

Ballinger won comfortably on a beautiful evening at the picturesque ground on the common but this was only possible because of 6 players from younger age groups who allowed the fixture to go ahead.<e>Batting first Ballinger openers Richard Clarke and Nick Rose opened fairly steadily but## seeking to push the score along## Nick holed out for 13. Ollie Richards## arriving straight from a school game to fill his customary slot at first wicket down## came to the wicket in good form but## hit on the pad sweeping## was adjudged leg before wicket. Ballinger were now in some trouble because## at number 4 while other batsman were en route## was Fergus Hardy## yet to bat this season## a fair striker of the ball but not a batsman guaranteed to occupy the crease. He started with a couple of customary swipes before nailing a powerful straight drive for 4. This seemed to give him confidence and he started to score quickly## some powerfully hit pulls mixed with some genuinely classy drives off the back foot. Meanwhile Richard Clarke was batting confidently## running unselfishly and keeping the score moving and together they took the score past the hundred mark both completing their fifties; Richard for the third time this season and Fergus for his first ever half-century. Jeff Moxom## Jason Stone and the classy James Wood## who had been delayed## added a last flurry of runs to post a total of 150 for 5.

A combination of a blistering onslaught by Nick Adams and another brilliant spell of left arm spin by Ian Maciver were just too much for Ley Hill on Saturday.

Ballinger won the toss and## for once## decided to bat first. Good opening spells by Ottaway & Peterson had made Ballinger work hard for their runs and a couple of wickets from Helm tightened the screw. The appearance of Adams changed everything. He made his intentions clear when hitting his first ball for six and the mayhem continued in the same vein with him reaching his 50 off 18 balls. This enabled Ballinger to reach 221## which looked a good total on dusty pitch.

When the Hill batted they were in trouble right from the start when they lost Lown to the 4th ball of their innings. This was the first of Ian Maciver's 5 victims and skipper Riley's decision to open the bowling with him was vindicated with Maciver finishing on 12-9-16-5. With the other bowlers all doing their bit## and the fielders taking the catches## in particular “buckets Riley”## the Hill were hustled out for just 76.

TPCC 151- 10 BWCC 152- 5

Ballinger visited Tring Park on Sunday and on another scorching day had to field first. All the bowlers put in good spells with the pick being Dom Birkby with 4-21. Tom Crick bowled really quickly and on another day will get a better reward than the 1 wicket he took. Tring were bowled out for 151.

In reply Hardy & Riley got the Waggoners off to a steady start but a stand of 90 between Hunting and Riley set the seal on the game. When they were out in quick succession it was left to Jason Stone to guide Ballinger home
For the second time we lose the opportunity to beat a side below us in the league. It doesn't happen when we play Holmer Green

When Downley gave Ballinger first go on what looked to be a difficult wicket## the visitors were a little concerned. Fortunately for the Waggoners Riley and Humphreys were in imperious form. Their opening partnership of 80 gave the innings substance## which## with the help of a well paced innings by Kerry was enough to get the Waggoners to 183- 9.

Downley were then treated to a master class in spin bowling. Fergus Hardy took 6-42 in 12 overs of high quality off spin. His line and length were immaculate and none of the Downley batsmen were comfortable against him. Aided by some excellent catching## including 1 brilliant effort by Ballinger's new keeper Davies## Ballinger's bowlers hustled Downley out for 133. This gave Ballinger a much needed 25 points.

H&C 275-5 BWCC 195-5

Ballinger played host to a Sri Lanka B side on Saturday and the difference in class showed. There was a lot at stake on this game and Sri Lanka made the strange choice of batting first. Their openers put on a 100 with Gunasekara scoring an immaculate 85 and the strangely named Pritchet 57. The loss of Gunasekara to an excellent catch by keeper Fallowfield- Smith didn't slow Sri Lanka's progress as his replacement Daluwata scored 29 at more than a run a ball. In the meantime## Pritchett had been removed by Davies## and Sri Lanka's Rifai had been quietly scoring an excellent 64. Sri Lanka declared on 275-5 off 39 overs.

When the Waggoners batted Sri Lanka opened up with their 2 spinners Daluwatta & Dias and had immediate success when skipper Riley was bowled first ball of the innings.Branigan also went early but Sri Lanka's spinners## nor their change bowlers Rifai and Gunasekara## were able to remove McIntrye. He batted resolutely for his 98no and was helped by Davies (39) and Kerry to secure the draw. Ballinger ended on 195-5. This was the first completed game that Sri Lanka B have failed to win this year and their decision to bat first may cost them the title.

BWCC 180-6 30 overs The Lee 106-9 30 overs

Ballinger played the Lee on Sunday. The weather was pretty awful and this efected the way the match was played. Having started a normal time match a long interruption forced the skippers to decide to change it to a 30 over game. Ballinger were batting at the time and a rapid change in tactics was required. First Fallowfield-Smith(24) and then Davies (54no) went on the charge but it was the 76 added by Davies and Macdonald that enabled the Waggoners to set The Lee the difficult target of 180.

Crick and Macdonald make a formidable opening attack and they soon removed the openers with just 19 on the board. Then a fine spell of 3-5 in 4 overs by Stone ripped the heart out of the Lee innings. Guy Morgan did his best for the visitors with 21 and his son Alex## a Ballinger junior## was 13no at the end.

Sadly it was obvious from the 15th over when the Lee needed 130 at nearly 9 an over that the game was over and there was nothing left to play for. As it happens the Waggoners were unable to take the last wicket and the Lee ended on 106-9. An honourable draw in a time game - a stuffing in an overs match

BWCC 232 - 8 Long Marston 122-10
