Furthermore## there have been reports that current record holder## Danny Draper## was seen to be hiding in the trees surrounding the ground at the time of the dismissal prompting suspicions of serious foul play. An internal investigation has been launched. Anyway## back to cricketing matters## joining Matt at the crease was Rollo McIntyre-Hunting and both soon got into their stride with Rollo especially playing with considerable authority. With each bad ball being ruthlessly dispatched to or over the boundary Ballinger rattled along at a good rate as the 100 partnership was brought up in the 19th over. The mix of Rollo's flamboyance and Matt's obduracy proved to be a perfect partnership## but unfortunately## all good things must come to an end## as the partnership of 115 was broken when Matt was caught for a well made 54. This brought Ian Maciver to the crease and he helped Rollo add 37 for the third wicket in double quick time until he took one swipe too many at Holloway's bowling and was bowled for 8. Will Smith then kept Rollo company for a while until he was caught. Tom Maw then swiftly followed as seeing Paul's anguish at getting out## played a captain's innings to relieve him of collecting duties by getting out to the worst shot in cricketing history as a full toss## which Geoffrey Boycott's grandmother could have hit for six with a stick of rhubarb no less## was tamely hit back to the bowler for a caught and bowled. This dismissal paved the way for Max Maciver to support Rollo McIntyre-Hunting to blast the Chesham Bois bowlers around the park and occasionally into orbit. Soon enough Rollo passed 100 for the second time this season and really began to cut loose with the ball often looking like a dot on the horizon as it disappeared out of the ground. This was not the end## though## as the last couple of overs received particularly brutal treatment. 40 runs were plundered off the last 2 overs as such savagery has not been seen since the publication of William Golding's 'Lord of the Flies'. Eventually Ballinger finished on 253-5 off 37 overs with Rollo McIntyre-Hunting finishing on 148*## a new club record## (of which 130 came in boundaries: 22 fours 7 sixes)## and Max Maciver on a very good supporting 23*. For Chesham Bois## Holloway was the stand out bowler with 4 wickets and Hinks bowled economically as ever.

After tea the Chesham Bois response began at a rapid rate with 25 coming off the first 2 overs## but as the Ballinger opening bowlers## Nick Adams and Tom Graham## began to find their rhythm the run rate was strangled considerably although no breakthrough came until the score had reached 66. Change bowlers Ian and Max Maciver both bowled very tidily and slowly but surely started to chip away at the Chesham Bois batting order. Clark was trapped in front for a breezy 35 and when Ian picked up his second wicket## that of J O'Brian for 4## Ballinger were back in the hunt. Max soon followed his father's footsteps as he too got in on the act by picking up 2 wickets## the opener Withams for a patient 27 and Kitching for no score## both caught by the strategically placed Nick Adams and Ian Maciver respectively. With Ballinger bowling and fielding well## none more so than Paul Humphreys who prowled the cover boundary with particular enthusiasm and vigour## a positive result looked on the cards. However## they did not bank on stonewall Holloway leading his side to a draw. Although Max continued to toil away with little luck## Alex Howe bowling an excellent ECB restricted 4 over spell where he picked up 2 wickets and the old pro remaining wicketless## Ballinger could not press home their advantage fully (even with 10 players around the bat) and although Nick Adams took another wicket to set up a potentially close finish Chesham Bois saw off the remaining overs with little fuss and therefore## finishing the match on 157-7 off 42 overs with Holloway making 45*.

So as another match passes and the end of season draws even closer## Ballinger can probably reflect on this match as a missed opportunity but it was a decent game with the major highlight being Rollo McIntyre's majestic and magical 148 not out. Chesham Bois proved to amicable hosts and although the result was not perfect it was good to bounce back after last week's loss. Next week Ballinger visit pastures new as they travel to Jordan Taverners and rumour has it they provide food after the match. I'm looking forward to it already!

Disclaimer: The views expressed in this report are that of the author and not of the club. Any offence caused is purely accidental and intended for comical effect only.

BWCC 207-9 Jordans Taverners 171-9

In 1922 the Great Fire of Smyrna marked the beginning of the end of the Greco-Turkish War. In 2009 Ballinger's match away at Jordans Taverners marked the beginning of the end of the 2009 season as for the first time the start was brought forward by an hour to 1 o'clock. With Ballinger putting out one of the strongest Sunday sides## possibly in world cricket## Jordans Taverners eventually succumbed to a 37 run defeat that perhaps was much closer than it should have been.

On a rather overcast Sunday afternoon visited Seer Green for the first time to play Jordans Taverners and having lost the toss Ballinger were put in on a pitch that looked like it would deteriorate as the game went on. With the Ballinger line up providing a plethora of riches## the capacity crowd were expecting something special in this 40 over shoot out especially after last weeks fun and fireworks at Chesham bois. Opening up for Ballinger were Matt Riley and Paul Humphreys and the Ballinger innings really set off at break neck speed. 0-0 after 2 overs: tremendous stuff. However runs were gradually accumulated on a tricky pitch and the 50 partnership came up in the 14th over as the run rate began to crawl above 3 an over. Unfortunately record hunter Paul Humphreys was first to go for 31## bowled by Paine## most certainly put off by Danny Draper's appearance behind the bowlers arm. This paved the way for the newly crowned King Rollo and scorer of thousands of runs last weekend to enter the fray much to the joy of the crowd who anticipated another innings of flamboyance and ferocity. It all looked well as his first scoring shot was a 6 but then the unthinkable happened with Rollo bowling bowled for 6and the score on 73. Richard O'Kelly then helped Matt consolidate and slowly but surely the run rate was dragged up with the 3rd wicket partnership reaching 62 until Matt went for a patient 55## an innings that suited the perilous situation that faced Ballinger and which provided a foil for Richard to play his shots. Eventually he then went for a stylish 46 and at 154-4 the platform was set for Ballinger to reach 200. This was indeed exceeded as Jamie Kellock (19) and Nick Adams (16*)## along with extras and dropped catches (which were cruelly laughed at by Mr. Chairman)## helped accelerate the scoring rate with Ballinger eventually finishing on a rather good total of 207-9## a much higher score than initial estimates had forecasted.

There is one glaring omission from the Ballinger first innings that I have not included though as it deserves its own paragraph. For many years coaches have gone on about how aggressive running between the wickets puts pressure on the fielding side## well there was no better example when openers Paul Humphreys and Matt Riley completed an all run 4## the crowd could not believe it and to top it off there was no dive sight!

After tea Jordans had the unenviable task of chasing down the target of 207 on an increasingly bowler friendly pitch. Ballinger opening bowlers Jack Maciver and Andy Thompson kept it tight early on and Andy was soon rewarded with the wicket of Leybourne. However it was only after the introduction of Nick Adams and Ian Maciver that the reigns really began to be pulled in and Jordans reply started to hit the buffers. A miserly 8 over spell from Nick ripped the heart out of the Jordans middle order## yielded only 15 runs and 3 wickets while Ian unluckily remained wicketless conceding only 17 runs. At this point victory was virtually assured with 3 further wickets from King Rollo and 1 from club pro and bat supplier Paul Humphreys even despite some absolutely abysmal attempts at catching the small red ball particularly by the captain (yes it was 3 drops). Eventually## Ballinger's victory was wrapped up pretty uneventfully with Andy Thompson finishing with very economical figures and was unlucky to pick up only 1 wicket## while Jeremy Hunting showed plenty of flight and guile in an economical 2 over spell which yielded 40 runs.

In summary another good win in which Paul was unlucky not to break the coveted runs scored in a season record## never mind there's always next week. Anyway a match against new opposition turned out to be very fruitful with good opposition## good tea and good post match nourishment. Lets hope for another away match next season!

On a glorious September day Ballinger entertained Sarratt for the first time in many years. Once all the pleasantries had been exchanged to the ex Ballinger players and opening bowlers from other local clubs (Ley Hill) ## and someone had finally arrived with a key to the pavilion## skipper Salisbury won the toss and elected to bat.

Openers Humphreys and Riley began the innings in circumspect fashion due to some excellent opening spells from Helm and Lumley. Once they had settled in to the pace of the pitch## which had to be flooded 48 hrs before by the grounds men due to the unseasonal heat wave over Ballinger over the past month (good decision Ian!!) the scoring rate picked up. Humphreys counted himself to 48 which took him past the club record for the most runs in the season## and then decided to ruin the figures of Sarrats top wicket taker this year by taking 23 one over.

Paul eventually departed for 73 caught on the 3rd attempt## but this only brought in Rollo## who signalled his intentions by hitting his second ball for 4 and his fifth for 6.Whilst all this was going on Matt was quietly going about his work and reached his hundred with an enormous single## and once the over was finished skipper Salisbury declared with BWCC on 233-1. Matt scored an excellent 101no and Rollo 32no.

After the usual Ballinger gastronomic feast Sarratt began their reply but were soon in trouble as Tom Graham 3-30## and Nick Adams 1-23 reduced Sarratt to 46-4.Ballinger's change bowlers kept the wickets falling at regular intervals with Lloyd (2-21) and Max MacIver (4-29) bowling Sarratt out for 125.Top scorer for Sarratt was Randell with 35.

An excellent game played in the right spirit## and plenty of jugs down the Swan to finish with.

Ballinger had a gentle opener to the season against Chorley Wood on Sunday. Ballinger fielded first and an excellent opening spell by Humphreys and Adams kept Chorley Wood in check reducing them to ? for 3 after ? overs.
The introduction of Ollie Richards was interesting with 18 coming off his first over then a double wicket maiden in his second. With Ian Davies bowling well at the other end Chorleywood were reduced to 70 -7. An excellent innings by ? helped Chorleywood reach 171.

Matt Riley started his season with a well paced innings of 71. Some excellent running between the wickets with Graham Salisbury kept Ballinger in with a shout until the last 2 overs. BWCC eventually finishing on 141- 7 with a very alert Kerry keeping out the last few balls.
A difference of 6 overs in Chorleywood's favour probably made the difference but it was very pleasant match played in an excellent spirit. Shame we have to start the league season.

An almost full strength Ballinger side went to the Nags head ground on Sunday and## in the end## enjoyed a comfortable victory.

Batting first Riley & Salisbury got Ballinger off to a slow but steady start but the side slipped to 56 -6 before Lloyd## Fallowfield-Smith & extras brought Ballinger up to 130.

Adams & Lloyd then made short work of the Pelicans batting taking 2&3 wickets respectively for a total of 13 runs. Lawson's spin removed another 3 but the prized wicket was taken by pace man Tom Graham when he removed the Pelicans top scorer M.Hull.

An excellent evening was enjoyed in the Nags Head afterwards.

The first league game and the question is are we ready? Skipper Matt Riley had a good start to the tossing season when the opposition made the wrong call. Asking Monks to bat first looked like a good choice when## after 20 overs## they had only score 72. Phil Lloyd led the way with 0-14 in his first 6 overs. He was ably supported by Tom Graham with 0-20 in his 6 overs. The introduction of spin increased the wicket taking but## unfortunately## also the run rate. Ian Davies ended with a creditable 3-52 off his 12 overs but Monks Risborough finished on 215-10## which included 37 extras. BWCC set off at an incredible pace scoring 28 off just 16 overs. A 50 partnership between Davies & Hunting gave Ballinger a chance but time (overs) weren't on their side and although Davies reached 85* he was unable to get Ballinger close enough to force the win. Reaching 180-6 meant a loosing draw but by bowling the opposition out## plus batting points## gave Ballinger a reasonable start to their campaign. BWCC 10pts Monks Risborough 15pts.

BWCC Under 11b's lost a close fought 1st round Cup match against Wendover last Sunday. Batting first Wendover scored slowly but steadily against some tight bowling by BWCC. Wickets then fell at regular intervals with Dan Stockdale picking up 3 catches behind the stumps including one great one-handed effort. Wendover increased their run rate over the last 6 overs of their inning by running & calling well. Harriet Stone slowed the run flow with a great spell including a wicket## but Wendover's best batter took his toll on a sloppy last few overs from Ballinger. Wendover ended on 255 with BWCC having taken 7 wickets. BWCC also off to a slow start in their inning but crucially no wickets were lost. Although behind the run rate BWCC were always in with a chance## unfortunately then two quick wickets did fall which undid all the early good work and with 58 needed off the last 9 overs all seemed lost. However some solid and safe shot making## plus a few extras helped the Ballinger cause and the run rate was kept to 5 or 6 an over. The good news was that all of the batters were contributing to the effort## particularly James and Matthew Rose## Dan Stockdale and Harry Rix. Our last pair## Harriet Stone and Will Clarke needed 21 off the last four overs - a hard ask when Wendover's County player swapped his gloves for the ball but some good calling## quick singles and a few extras kept BWCC in the chase leaving us just 9 to win with 8 balls to go. As often happens when the pressure is on for runs## a desperate attempt at a single resulted in a run out## even then Harriet and Will stuck to their task and took 8 off the last over to cut the final margin between the teams to just 7 runs. The lessons learnt? Practice that ground fielding## think about fielding positions for each batsman and when batting get that calling LOUD and FAST! Well played everyone!

On a very windy first day of the season Cublington won the toss and decided to bat first. They had a very lucky first over that went for 15 runs. Beginning of the season rustiness by Ballinger bowlers and fielders. Ballinger fought back with some very tight bowling by Harry Wells## Evan Webster and Robert Rose pegging the batsmen back and taking some well deserved wickets. The bowling continued to be tight backed up by some very athletic fielding## the star fielder being Andrew Rishton in the covers. With the last Cublington pair coming to the wickets they were on 225. These batsmen hit the ball hard and scored quick runs. This did not faze Harry Wells who continued with his line and length taking a brilliant bowled middle stump in the last over. Ballinger started their fight back with some patient batting with the first pair of Andrew Rishton and Tom McIntyre. There was some classic strokes in their stand of 15 not out. Harry Wells and Robert Rose continued in the same vein but were really unlucky to be out on their last ball to the catch of the season. Tom Butterworth and Toby King put up some stout opposition but unfortunately lost a few wickets. Rory Seekins and Guyan Ratnavel ran really well between the wickets and gave some lusty blows to take the score to 225. The last pair of Evan Webster and Tom Edmonds came to wicket and with 2 glorious 4's of the first 2 balls by Tom the 245 seemed in sight. A wicket and some tight bowling took the score out of sight. With 15 runs scored off the last over this brought Ballinger's score to 235 and made everyone realise that the catch off the no ball## the LBW not given or the spilt chance was the difference between the teams. The U11C's were gracious in defeat congratulating Cublington and look forward to concentrating on the league.

Danny Draper made his first appearance of the season for Ballinger today and it looked as though he had put the miseries of last season behind him. Opening with Rick Brockett he scored an excellent 46 but was by no means the leader in an opening partnership of 47. Brockett scored a brisk 23 unfurling a whole range of shots previously unseen by his team mates. 21 from Andy Branigan helped BWCC to reach 174-8 declared. Excellent opening spells of 3-42 by Peter Rushforth & 2-11 by Ian Davies reduced Taplow to 44-5 but BWCC were unable to press home their advantage and Taplow ended on 103-8

We were unfortunately knocked out of the first round of the cup despite a good first effort from the boys. Top batsmen: Luke Martin 31 (retired not out); and Stefan Otto 15. Top Bowlers: Alex Morgan (2 wickets)## and one wicket each from Privett## Martin & Hutson.

The game was played at Aston Clinton on Friday 13th May (not a good omen) in bright sunshine. Sadly BWCC had only 9 players and lost the toss. BWCC were asked to bat and their opening bowler quickly disposed of our top 3 batsmen. A couple of badly judged runs which led to run-outs did not help the team. BWCC were all out for 48 with only 14 runs coming off the bat. BWCC bowlers did not have much of a total to defend and Aston Clinton reached their target in 11 overs. Brough and James Stoddart both bowled well and took a wicket each.

Ballinger enjoyed the short trip to The Lee on Saturday when they gained a comfortable victory over their very local rivals. Asked to bat first Ballinger reached 187- 8 thanks mainly to a far from chanceless 109 by Rollo McIntrye. He was well supported by Matt Riley who scored a dogged 44. They put on 129 for the 2nd wicket which was just as well as no other Ballinger batsman got into double figures. The Lee got off to a flying start but eventually accurate bowling by Humphreys and Adams## who took 3 wickets each## gave Ballinger control and only an excellent innings of 60 from Warren Davies kept The Lee in the game. Spin duo Davies & Maciver with 2 wickets each finished off The Lee innings. BWCC 25pts The Lee 6pts.

Batting and Bowling orders sorted this time! Some good captaining from Dominic Hutson## particularly with the team one man short on the day - some excellent all-round fielding. An impressive game## and a good start to the season of league games. Aston Clinton 93 all out (.... the last ball being Jack Hankinson's stunning one-ball over in the 15th to knock the opposition out !!!!!!!!) Ballinger 140 runs for 3. Best Batsmen: Luke Martin 32 retired not out; Sam Privett 29 not out## Chris Keen 26 (who decided that wearing boxer shorts with a box meant he'd have to hit 4's rather than run anything !!!!!!!!!!!!!) Best Bowlers: James Stoddart (2 wickets including a stunning caught & bowled .... and he nearly got a 3rd !!!); Dominic Hutson (3 wickets); Sam Privett 1 wicket and Jack Hankinsons (1 wicket off his one & only ball)

The game was played on Tuesday 17th May on a bright sunny evening at Ballinger CG. As some Chalfont players were delayed in arriving## with each captains agreement## Chalfont batted first. Chalfont fielded some good batsmen and they reached 154-2 off 20 overs with Jeff Moxom capturing the 2 wickets. There were good bowling performances from Brough Downey## James Miller and Will Cousins. Sadly many runs were given away with wides## byes and backing up. In reply## BWCC start badly with James Miller being run-out through lack of clear calling between the 2 batsman. Brough Downey batted very well for his 30 runs and held the innings together as wickets fell regularly through the innings. At the end of the innings Lewis Ostacchini batted well for his 13n.o. The low sun in the sky did not help some of the BWCC batsmen - they will have to learn to cope with this.

Chenies won the toss and put Ballinger into bat. Ballinger did not build on there good batting of last week and managed to lose ten wickets in their 20 overs. This was due to poor shot selection## bad luck and tight bowling. Tom Edmunds and Evan Webster were the only pair to bat through their four overs without losing any wickets. Chenies opened there batting confidently and scored 237 for 4 in their 20 overs## winning comfortably. Congratulations to Chenies and to Xavier Owen making his Ballinger debut. He shows as a 7year old he has quite a future in cricket.

On a cold## windy night at Shardoloes cricket ground Ballinger under 11A's played their second game of the season. Amersham won the toss and chose to bat. Our opening bowlers Alex Morgan and Adam Robinson put their first pair under a huge amount of pressure and managed to take 6 wickets in the first four overs it has to be said that Amersham were trying to run everything and this proved costly for them! Clever fielding and good positional tactics from George Bartlett the captain kept runs to the minimum with Sam King and Sebastian Richards proving their worth in the field. Wickets continued to fall with George Bartlett## Jeremy Steel## George Bailey and Oliver Lloyd all causing chaos with their accurate bowling. Joe Hankinson was unlucky not to take a wicket but had 2 maiden overs. Wicket keeper Kristian Otto was in fine form evidenced by a marvellous stumping and great run out. He also cleverly left an awesome throw from the boundary by Alex Morgan## which hit the stumps for yet another run out. The highlight of the evening was a brilliant and well-deserved hat trick by Thomas Brannigan. Amersham finished their innings with a total of 143 runs from 20 overs putting Ballinger in a very strong position. After some interesting and heart stopping batting from the opening pair (Kristian Otto and George Bartlett) Ballinger were on 212. The light was fading badly by now and dark rain clouds threatened when Adam Robinson and Tom Brannigan came into bat. This pair really got the scoreboard ticking## scoring lots of runs for no loss of wicket. Despite the rain and continued pressure from Amersham## Joe Hankinson and Oliver Lloyd continued to increase Ballinger's run rate losing only one wicket in their 4 overs. Sam King and Jeremy Steel put on a stand of 30 with Sam finding the boundary 6 times. The rest of the team cheered off the pair. Derek (the umpire) was never going to let bad light stop play with the team in this form and so Alex Morgan and George Bailey went out as the last pair in the gloom of the approaching night. The pair held their own and George was unlucky to be caught on the last ball by Amersham's star bowler. The final score Ballinger 306## Amersham 143. A well deserved win. Thanks to Derek Richards for coaching the team.

This match showed a big improvement by BWCC and we were always on top. A solid top of the order start from Hamish Elliott and Anthony Mousinho set the tone and useful contributions came from all batting pairs. Key to our decent total was the loss of only 4 wickets in our 20 overs## also the team were more forceful with their shots## selections were better whilst calling and running showed a major improvement - so well done! Useful contributions came from Dan Stockdale## Harry Rix & our Captain for the day James Rose to boost our total to 280. Defending their total BWCC got off to a good side with Beaconsfield finding it hard to score regularly## the match was effectively decided when Will Clark (1-1) and Harriet Stone (2-2) had their spells. They were very well followed by Hamish Elliott (1-2) plus two run outs off his bowling by Will Clark helped up our cause as BWCC picked up 7 wickets during the inning. Overall a very pleasing performance with some big improvements; harder hitting into the right areas## good calling## tighter bowling and very much better fielding with some good vocal encouragement. Well done everyone!

Hoping for two back-to-back league wins in two days we approached this match with confidence which was boosted when Winchmore Hill batted first and we made a run out from the first ball of their inning. However thereafter WH batted sensibly and lost only 3 more wickets in compiling a competitive 279. WH fielded three excellent batsman who hit the ball hard and choose their shots carefully. BWCC generally bowled well with improved accuracy but could not penetrate. There were bright moments however none better than when Luke Hughes held onto a full blooded pull to square leg - the best catch anyone had seen this season. Batting in failing light on a wet grass wicket on the edge the square meant that BWCC got the worst of the conditions and sadly things got worse from then! Our opening pair lost three wickets and we never got in touch with the run rate. In all we lost 11 wickets which made a huge difference to our run chase. In fairness BWCC improved towards the end of our inning with Will Clark and Harriet Stone adding 22 with no loss of wicket - showing that accumulating runs without losing wickets was possible!

This was a very comfortable victory for Ballinger. The team are now well organised and playing to their true potential. Luke Martin again batted well and was well supported by Dominic Hutson but all the boys contributed to a good team effort Top batsmen: Luke Martin 25; Dominic Hutson 20 not out Top bowlers: (forgot to write this down from scorebook - tba !!!!!!!!!)

Ballinger Under 11A's turned in an extremely professional performance to beat a talented Winchmore Hill side. Winchmore Hill batted first to score 244 runs. Ballinger bowled extremely well to take 8 wickets. The pick of the bowlers were Adam Robinson## Sebastian Richards and Alex Morgan## each of whom took 2 wickets## ably supported by Joe Hankinson## George Bailey## Mathew Dunnington## George Bartlett and Jack and Max Maciver. Kristian Otto turned in another superb display of wicket keeping. In reply Ballinger Under 11A made 301 runs for the loss of just 2 wickets. Highlights included a ferocious opening stand of 42 runs between Jack Maciver and Kristian Otto. Kristian## in particular## played a superb attacking innings. Each of the remaining batsmen built on this fine start and the innings was completed with a fine flourish from the last pair of Adam Robinson and George Bartlett. Once again Jack Maciver displayed a mature grasp of his role as captain. This was a fine performance by Ballinger Under 11A's and all the boys were a credit to the club.

On the hottest afternoon of the year Ballinger played Farnham Royal in a crucial double header. We lost the toss but were put in to bat anyway so we were not too downhearted about that. We got off to a very steady start against a disciplined bowling attack## reaching 80 before losing a wicket after 13 overs## with Sam Phillips and Andrew Branigan both making 38. With so few wickets down we could afford to accelerate and did so in style making 73 off our last 7 overs with Olly Richards making a rapid 29 to finish on 153-8 off our 20 overs. In reply they started very positively getting to 93 off 15 overs for the loss of only two wickets. However they then collapsed after some fine bowling by Fergus Hardy## Andrew Branigan and Dan Camp to finish on 113-6. Fergus took 3 wickets including 2 in 1 over## Jono Lacey took 1 along with a couple of runouts. For most of the game this was a tense and exciting encounter.

On the hottest afternoon of the year Ballinger played Farnham Royal in a crucial double header. We lost the toss but were put in to bat anyway so we were not too downhearted about that. We got off to a very steady start against a disciplined bowling attack## reaching 80 before losing a wicket after 13 overs## with Sam Phillips and Andrew Branigan both making 38. With so few wickets down we could afford to accelerate and did so in style making 73 off our last 7 overs with Olly Richards making a rapid 29 to finish on 153-8 off our 20 overs. In reply they started very positively getting to 93 off 15 overs for the loss of only two wickets. However they then collapsed after some fine bowling by Fergus Hardy## Andrew Branigan and Dan Camp to finish on 113-6. Fergus took 3 wickets including 2 in 1 over## Jono Lacey took 1 along with a couple of runouts. For most of the game this was a tense and exciting encounter.

Ballinger and Little Gaddesden played out a slightly dull draw on Saturday. A very slow pitch made it difficult for both sides but having been asked to bat first Gaddesden made better use of it than Ballinger. Good running between the wickets enabled Gaddesden to get off to a good start and gave Ballinger's fielders chance to demonstrate their speed of thought and action. 2 quick wickets brought in danger man Barrington who was immediately dropped by skipper Riley. A rapid 34 by Barrington helped Gaddesden to 172. Late wickets by Adams and Davies prevented too much damage. When Ballinger batted Riley's day was made complete by getting a golden duck and BWCC were reduced to 7- 4. Only Humphreys## for Ballinger## was able to overcome the slow pitch with an excellent 57. He and Kerry added 50 for 7th wicket and looked as though a win was on but it was not to be and Ballinger ended on 125-9. BWCC 8pts Little Gaddesden 15pts.

On a beautiful evening Taplow won the toss and put Ballinger in to bat. Every one contributed with the bat and thanks to the loss of only two wickets and a contribution of 26 from the last pair; Jack Bugden and James Rose a good total of 273 was achieved. On the plus side no one was bowled out - the two wickets being an unusual caught behind off the back of the bat and a run out. The bowling display was good. Harry Rix and James Rose opened and both bowled with good pace each taking one wicket. Will Clark bowled some useful off cutters and took a wicket. Nick Bartington bowled a good spell taking two wickets in his second over. The last pair for Taplow were un done by some good spin bowling by Anthony Mourinho and the deadly accuracy of Harriet Stone who bowled two overs without conceding a run and took one wicket. There were two excellent run outs by Harry Rix and Harriet Stone. In total Ballinger took 8 wickets leaving Taplow on 224 at the end of their innings. So all in all a very encouraging win. Things to work on….. calling and running between the wickets and putting the bad ball away. Well done all the boys and girls who played.

Thursday 2nd June was a beautiful sunny evening at Ballinger. Unfortunately that was the only good thing about the evening. Marlow Park won the toss and asked the BWCC to bat. Even being 1 player short shouldn't have led to the catastrophe that then occurred as BWCC were bowled out for 15. Marlow scored the runs to win in 2.5 overs. Less the best me thinks.
Cancelled due to the building of Ark!

Pathetic was one of the milder words used to describe Ballinger's inept performance on Saturday. Having been asked to bat## the early signs looked promising for Ballinger but a combination of poor shot selection and running ensured a miserable day with the home side being all out for 73 in 28 overs. Broomwade's latest import was too good for Ballinger's middle order. An excellent catch by Kerry and a sharp stumping and catch by Fallowfield- Smith## all off Humphreys## gave Ballinger some hope but 73 was always going to be difficult to defend and Broomwade ended on 75 -3 off 15 overs. BWCC 1pt Broomwade 20pts.

The Lee won the toss and put Ballinger into bat. Ballinger's opening pair of Tom Edmonds (bowling captain) and Evan Webster batted with authority and put on 27 runs. Next pair Harry Wells and Robert Rose continued in the same positive way and put on 13 runs. Guyan and Rory then mixed defensive and adventurous batting to add a further 24 runs. Xavier and Andy had to cope with widely variable bowling but kept their heads to add 2 runs. The final pair Tom McIntyre and Tom Butterworth played some fine strokes and ran well adding a further 16 runs. 284 for 2. Ballingers fielding was excellent with every bowler taking wickets apart from Harry Wells who made up for it by taking 2 of the most stunning catches seen at any level of cricket. Tom McIntyre (fielding captain) kept wicket impeccable throughout. The Lee's final score of 208 for 11.

A bad weekend was completed at Ballinger when they were easily beaten by Albury Entertainers. . Batting first Ballinger were unable to capitalise on an excellent stand between Andy Branigan & Ian Davies both scoring 40s## collapsing from 90-2 to 136-10. Some sloppy fielding by Ballinger## apart from a brilliant run out by Davies## enabled Albury's opener Ellis to score 57 and they reached Ballinger's total for loss of just 2 wickets.

Ballinger Under11A's produced their finest performance of the season to defeat a strong Cublington Under 11 side. Particularly pleasing was the manner in which the side recovered from a difficult start to the innings. Ballinger batted first and the opening batsmen faced some aggressive and accurate bowling from Cublington which reduced Ballinger to 197 runs after 4 overs. Ballinger dug deep and produced a number of fine partnerships## Joe Hankinson and Sebastian Richards (23 runs)## Max Maciver and Mathew Dunnington (20 runs)## Alex Morgan and George Bailey (21 runs) and a final flourish from the two closing batsmen## Adam Robinson and George Bartlett (36 runs). This was a fine fightback by Ballinger and particular praise must be given to Max Maciver for his mature innings and to Adam Robinson for his aggressive batting at the end of the innings. Cublington## in reply## were restricted to 215 runs for the loss of 11 wickets by some tight Ballinger bowling. All the bowlers made significant contributions backed by another superb display of wicket keeping by Kristian Otto. Pick of the bowlers were the opening bowlers## Jack Maciver and Alex Morgan. Jack Maciver in particular bowled a superb hostile opening spell. Special mention must go to Mathew Dunnington who bowled superbly to take 4 wickets## including 3 wickets in one over. The day belonged to the whole team## each of whom made a vital contribution to the victory and the team was splendidly captained by Jack Maciver.

There were some unusual names in this U15 side## which included three U12s & one U13. It didn't make any difference## as Ballinger were still too strong for Wendover. Batting first a very composed innings of 42no from Nick Rose plus a brilliant innings of 33 from James Wood## in his first appearance for the U15s## helped Ballinger reach 126-4 off their 20 overs. Another new boy James Stoddart bowled a very tidy spell taking 2-18 but Fergus Hardy did most of the damage with a spell of 3-5. Wendover finally reached 109-8.

In another close fought encounter between these clubs Ballinger just squeezed home off the penultimate ball. Batting first Kingshill reached 130-5 thanks mainly to 61 no out by Major. Only Crick and Macdonald caused the Kingshill batsmen any problems taking 2 wickets each. Then Crick & skipper Charlie Wells opened up for Ballinger and paced their innings perfectly. Kingshill used 8 bowlers in an attempt to remove one of these two but to no avail and with the help of 29 extras## 68 from Crick & 34 from Wells Ballinger sneaked home.

Another comfortable victory for the boys although losing 6 wickets in chasing just 60 isn?t good for the coaches nerves but reaching Chesham's score in 15 overs helped soothe them. Some extraordinary wicket-keeping from James Wood with 2 catches## 2 run-outs and a stumping - great to have him back in the team after recovering from a broken collar-bone !! Best batsmen: Stefan Otto 25; Dominic Hutson 17 Best bowlers: Richard Wise 3 wickets## George Bartlett 3 wickets

This fixture was rescheduled to enable the Cup match against Tring Park to be played. Sadly we were unable to re-arrange it to fit in with tournament organiser's schedule and they called it an abandoned game.

Ballinger's woeful season continued at the weekend when they suffered another heavy defeat. Having asked Widmer End to bat it looked like they were going to have to chase a huge target when Widmer reached 130-3 with 20 overs to go. Then an excellent spell by Davies and 2 brilliant catches## by Whelan and Adams enabled Ballinger to bowl Widmer out for 182 in 37 overs. The extra overs should have been a bonus to Ballinger sadly all that happened was that Widmer had longer to bowl them out. A poor pitch didn't help Ballinger's efforts but all out for under 100 two weeks running is relegation material. BWCC 6pts WESM 25pts.

On Sunday Ballinger had a very enjoyable game against The Scuttlers. Batting first the Scuttlers quickly rattled up 199 - 4 with no Ballinger bowler able to make an impression. Jeremy Hunting led Ballinger's reply with 41 before being brilliant caught by Kerry. Davies (47) & McGowan (20) kept the score moving but a fine spell of bowling by Kerry kept them behind the clock. 175-9 was a good effort but BWCC can thank their umpire for staving off another defeat at the hands of the Scuttlers.

A much changed U11B's batted first and started well## posting 216 for the first pair## but wickets then tumbled fast. In all 13 wickets fell## mostly to straight balls and lobbed catches. This was disappointing as we have practising playing each ball on its' merits and using our feet better. The team were a little low as we changed over and when we started fielding things improved quickly. We bowled straighter and fielded really well - Luke Hughes taking a great catch a short extra cover supported by a catch in the slips by Will Smith and a couple of test book run outs. After 16 overs we had taken 8 wickets and pegged Gt Kingshill back to under the 200 mark and any result was possible. Sadly the last Kingshill pair got after us a bit and our offensive fielding positions leaked a few runs - a good gamble that did not quite come off. All the same an exciting game with the result in the balance until the last over. Lessons learnt? Losing 6 runs from a lost wicket is expensive## so patience and concentration is as valuable as the big hits! We all agreed after the match that we would win next time!

An unbeaten 70 by Jeremy Hunting got the Waggoners rolling again on Saturday. Ballingers bowlers did an excellent job of keeping Lacey Green down to 156-9## with wickets been spread between Lawson## Humphreys## Maciver & Lloyd. Then even the loss of Matt Riley## to yet another golden duck## and the high temperatures were unable to stop Hunting and Humphreys(51) passing Laceys score with nearly 12 overs to spare. BWCC 20pts Lacey Green 6pts.

Two excellent spells of spin bowling were too much for Bledlow on Sunday. Fergus Hardy 4-31 & Andy Branigan 3 -38 were well supported by Jono Lacey 1-7## Rhodri Webster 2-6 and a master class in tight bowling from Nick Adams. The 112 Bleldow scored was never going to be enough on a good track and Ballinger duly passed their score with 4 down. Two making their season debuts Tom Wells (27) & Nick Rose (25) led the way with Rhodri Webster making it all look very easy.
Cancelled and team have taken to the Ark!
Match Abandoned due to monsoon.

In a nail biter at Ley Hill on Saturday## Ballinger managed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory. Asked to bat first Ballinger were soon in trouble on a difficult wicket but a typically gritty innings from skipper Riley (44) and another flamboyant knock from McIntyre (46) managed to dig BWCC out of trouble. Sadly the 169 Ballinger finally limped to was always going to be difficult to defend on such a small ground. A superb opening spell by Humphreys of 5-11 gave Ballinger some hope and reduced Hill to 44-5. Then a courageous 63 from Leadbetter put Hill back in it## but wickets were still falling and Ley Hill were 9 down going into the last over still needing 3 to win. A boundary off the first ball ended an exciting game. BWCC 8pts Ley Hill 20pts

An excellent bowling and fielding display by a young Ballinger side## including 5 catches by Rhodri Webster## wasn't enough to beat Penn Street on Sunday. By bowling Penn out for 140 it looked as though the Waggoners were in for an easy afternoon sadly their batting didn't match up to the bowling and they were dismissed for a disappointing 123. At on stage Ballinger were 52-5 and only a stand of 70 by skipper Davies and new boy Dom Birkby enabled Ballinger to get close.

Farnham Common batted first and made 199 during which Ballinger took 10 wickets. Pick of the bowlers were Charlie Mead and Joe Hankinson## each of whom took 2 wickets## and Jack Maciver who accounted for 3 wickets## They were well supported by Alex Humphrey and Sebastian Richards who each took a wicket apiece. Once again Kristian Otto showed what a good wicket keeper he has become. Ballinger replied with 343 runs for the loss of 5 wickets## of which the highlights were a superb display of hitting by Sam King who made an unbeaten 32 and an extremely classy innings at he death by George Bartlett who showed excellent technique in his unbeaten score of 29 runs. All the batsmen contributed in a typically aggressive batting display with Jack Maciver and Kristian Otto contributing 18 in their 4 overs## Joe Hankinson and Sebastian Richards18 runs in their 4 overs## Sam King and Charlie Mead making 41 runs in their partnership## George Bailey and Alex Humphrey contributing 27 runs and an excellent final partnership between George Bartlett and Alex Morgan of 39 runs. Congratulations to all the boys for their contributions during the 2005 league season.
Match abandoned due to total darkness only brightened by regular lightning strikes.

This was incredibly exciting match to finish off the league season for the boys. Just to trying to get any match in last week was an effort with the continuous rain! However## with plan 13.f. in place from moving the game to Sunday and then back to the Friday again## we had a good strong team out. Gt Kingshill have won every single one of their U13 matches this season## so we knew we were going to be up against some really stiff competition.  GK had a particularly strong couple of batsmen## so I was particularly glad he had to retire at 30! They reached 125 for 8 wickets (2 great run outs) - our boys put up some splendid bowling: particularly James Stoddart with 3 wickets## and Richard Wise## Luke Martin and Dominic Hutson with 1 each. Only 14 extras given away (7 bowling## and 7 byes/leg byes). Our boys opened well## but the run rate was a slow## leaving a lot to do. Although we benefited from 31 extras (mostly byes)## it wasn't until James Wood joined Dominic Hutson at the crease## that things really started to get exciting. James batted in his usual expert way hitting 2 fours## and a magnificent 6 straight out of the grounds. Both James and Dominic scored 28 each before being bowled. Luke Martin did well on 10 runs## and Sam Privett on 8. James Stoddart and Richard Wise came in as the light was fading fast (miserable rain clouds)## and the scores were getting closer. Three runs were needed off the last ball to tie (in which case Ballinger would have won on wickets) - they managed to score 2 runs off the final ball## leaving Gt Kingshill to win by just 1 run !!!!!!!!! (Not dissimilar to the match the following day at Lords between England and Australia - down to the last ball## and just that tiny bit too much to do too late!) Well done boys - I'm proud of the way you have all played all season - you've been great fun to work with as always## and I've seen a huge improvement in the batting from everyone!!. Here's to next season when you all become proper U13's !!! Wendy.

BWCC found itself on the wrong end of another nail-biter against Hawridge on Saturday. Hawridge were put in on a damp pitch and through some excellent bowling particularly from Davies were reduced to 82 for 7. However the Hawridge tail “wagged” and scratched its way to 171 all out. The Ballinger top order made a poor start. Then coming in at number five## Ollie Richards made a brilliant 70 to get The Waggoner's into a winning position. With 9 down going into the last over## and only 3 runs## required any result was possible. Sadly a dramatic run out gifted victory to Hawridge thus spelling heartbreak for Ballinger for the second week in a row as they came up short by 1 run. BWCC 9pts Hawridge 25pts.
Another good fielding effort by this young side kept Longwick down to 140 in their 40 overs but once again the batting was poor and Ballinger were all out for 90.

A brutal innings of 72 from Jono Lacey smashed Ballinger into the final of the Bucks Cup on Wednesday. Jono denied to score singles choosing the more direct route of eleven 4s & three 6s. Ballinger had been given a steady start by openers Phillips & Lowe## who put on 44 for the 1st wicket## but when they went in quick succession and were followed unluckily by skipper Richards it was left to Lacey and Camp to destroy Buckingham. Their partnership of 94 in 8 overs was thrilling to watch and helped Ballinger to 165. Then Lacey## opening the bowling## produced a blistering spell of fast bowling taking 3 - 14 in 4 overs but the bowling plaudits really belong to Charlie Wells who mesmerised the Buckingham batsmen taking 4 - 21 in his 4 overs. Skipper Ollie Richards was very pleased with the team's performance and was looking forward to the final when Ballinger take on Burnham.
BWCC 7pts Monks Risborough 25 pts.

Ballinger scored a comfortable win over local rivals The Lee on Saturday. The Lee won the toss and decided to bat. An excellent opening spell of 3 for 17 from Tom Graham soon put The Lee on the back foot and their troubles continued as the spinners were introduced. A devastating spell of 5 for 5 by Ian Davies rolled The Lee over for a paltry 64. Ballinger were clinical as they set about cantering home before tea with skipper Matt Riley steering his team over the line with 26 not out. BWCC 25pts The Lee 1pt.
BWCC 3pts Holmer Green 20pts

Ballinger had a comfortable win over bottom of the table Lt.Gaddesden on Sat. Having been put in Ballinger abstained from their normal crawl at the start of an innings and galloped to 50 off 10 overs with Kerry encouraging skipper Riley to run the occasional single. Once Kerry was out though the run rate really accelerated with Draper back to top form and scoring an excellent 102no. This plus 65 from Riley and a very rapid 41no from McIntyre took the Waggoners to 240-2. A wet ball prevented Ballinger's bowlers from ever really dominating but Lawson's 5 wickets and another tight spell of 2-11 from Humphreys was too much for the Gadd with them all out for 190. BWCC 25pts Little Gaddesden 5pts.

Ballinger completed an excellent weekend with a win over Chesham Bois. Batting first Chesham Bois were bowled out for 108 with off-spinner Fergus Hardy doing most of the damage with 4-17. Rhodri Webster guided Ballinger home with a well crafted 57 as the Waggoners reached 109-2.

Ballinger took on league leaders Broomwade on Saturday and current form suggested a heavy defeat for the Waggoners. Once again they confounded their critics by putting in an excellent bowling and fielding display which kept Broomwade down to 176. Ian Maciver## with his first 5 wicket haul of the season## led the way but he was well supported by some excellent catching## particularly by Whelan. Kerry made an important breakthrough when his under utilised off spin accounted for Broomwade's latest import. A little more ambition from Ballinger's early order batters may have helped the Waggoners get closer to Broomwade's score but Broom's excellent seam attack gave Ballinger no chance of causing an upset and they had to be happy to settle for a draw finishing on 128-5. BWCC 8pts Broomwade 14pts.

A strange event took place at Ballinger on Sunday when the Waggoners played Monks Risborough in a 40 over game. Agreeing to play a limited overs format has seen many captains hauled before the committee even though it may have been an away game but agreeing to play one at Ballinger could well be a flogging offence. The Club President## Gerry Hunting## who was at the ground to check out the offering of Ballinger's' latest recruit to the Tea Lady rota## was apoplectic and was telling anyone prepared to listen that it wouldn't have happened in his day. Fortunately no-one was prepared to listen. The game revolved around another excellent bowling and fielding display by this young Waggoners side who kept Monks to 193-10. Olly Lowe(3-34) and Tom Graham(3-37) bowled exceptionally well. Unfortunately skipper Davies allowed Ben Whelan 2 overs because it was his last game of the season. 34 runs later Davies realised that there's no place for sentiment in this game Ballingers reply started awfully with 3 wickets falling in the first 8 overs Davies and Wells batted well and a late flourish from Tom Graham and Alex MacDonald kept Ballinger up with the run rate but sadly they lost wickets too quickly and ended 22 runs short.

Ballinger eased their relegation worries on Saturday with a comfortable win over Lacey Green. Batting first the Waggoners reached 155 - 7 with the main contributions from Riley(32) & Davies (43no). Then expert use of the old ball by Maciver with 4-31 & Lawson 3-24 reduced the Green to 79-8. Two balls with the new ball was all that Adams needed to finish off the tail with Lacey Green 83-10. BWCC 25pts Lacey Green 4pts

Ballinger were invited to bat first against The Minn on Sunday a decision their skipper probably regretted when the Waggoners' openers Webster & Phillips added 121. This was followed by a rapid 23 from Richards and a stand of 70 between Davies (50no) & Tivey (25no) enabling Ballinger to declare on 240-3. Despite a spell of 3-0 in 4 overs from skipper Davies## Ballinger were unable to winkle out the Minn batters and they finished on 149-6.

BWCC fielded a very much under strength side supplemented by a number of colts (3 of which were asked to play 5 minutes before the start of the game). However## those asked to feature in the top 4 all contributed with the bat## even the somewhat elevated No. 3 James Fallowfield-Smith who chipped in with a useful 20!! Openers Humphries and Riley scored at nearly 5 an over before Humphries became the fist of 3 wickets for Lown who claimed all of the top 3. Davies looked to push the score along and looked set for a big score before being brilliantly caught on the long-off boundary by a guy who (he was reliably informed) had not taken a catch all season## his innings ending on 29. N. Adams then “joined” the party walloping the opening bowler back over his head for two huge sixes and finished 20 not out. In reply BWCC's miserly opening pair immediately removed the top three without greatly troubling the scorers. Ley Hill's numbers 4 and 5 however had other ideas looking to bat positively and scored at a rapid rate before Davies struck twice to remove both. Ley Hill were always in the hunt after this## scoring at the required rate before Lawson produced a masterclass in slow left arm bowling to mop up the rest of the side finishing on 5 - 37 with the Hill trailing by 44 runs. BWCC 25pts Ley Hill 6pts.

Another fine display of bowling and fielding from Ballinger's youthful Sunday side saw Wendover dismissed for a low score of 128 on a good batting wicket. Davies and Hardy did most of the damage bowling 19 overs between them and taking 6 - 37## before Crick and Kellog came on to mop up the tail. Chris Mitchell## making his senior debut behind the stumps## took an excellent catch off Crick. In reply Andy Branigan batted solidly for his 44 before being stumped## while Kellok flailed his bat for a quickfire maiden half century for the club (It had to be quickfire as a severe case of cramp set in after running one too many 3's!!). BWCC suffered a mini collapse shortly before the end (similar to the game being played at Trent Bridge## ironically with the same target to chase) but the experienced I. Hardy saw the Waggoner's home with 5 wickets to spare.

Ballinger's U15s ended their season in style with a comfortable win over Beaconsfield in the league Cup final last week.. Batting first a good team effort enabled them to reach 123-6## with the main contributions coming from Lowe## Crick & Camp. Then tight bowling and excellent fielding enabled skipper Richards to keep the pressure on the Beaconsfield batsmen with only Rory Mcarthy (50) making any impression in their total of 90-6. Coach Nigel Kerry said the boys were disappointed to lose to Burnham in the BCB Cup final## so were even more determined to end the season on a high. Team - Ollie Richards## Charlie Wells## Fergus Hardy## Richard Page## Ollie Lowe## Sam Phillips## Dan Camp## Chris Mitchell## Jason Stone## Nick Rose## Tom Crick & Andy Branigan. Coaches Nigel Kerry & Ian Hardy

An unusual occurrence happened at Hawridge on Saturday when Ballinger's league season ended with an enjoyable game against their local rivals. Batting first Hawridge reached 244 - 6 off their 45 overs thanks## in some part to 8 dropped catches## and an excellent innings by Rifai (68). Will Hunting was a man in a hurry scoring 51 in 25 minutes to give the Waggoners the start they needed he was helped by another belligerent innings from Mcintyre (61) but only Adams (25) of the later batsman could cope with the spin of Rifai. It went to the wire though with the Waggoners being bowled out for 209 in the 45 over. BWCC 8pts Hawridge 25pts

Sunday's game at Ballinger belonged to the Birkby brothers. An excellent catch by skipper Kerry set elder brother Dominic on the way to his first 5 wicket haul (6-44) in senior cricket. He was well supported by some excellent ground fielding & a sharp spell (2-25) from Fallowfield-Smith with Fulmer ending on 171-10. Salisbury (50) & Fallowfield-Smith (45) set about this target with great gusto but it was Ali Birkby (26*)## making a guest appearance## who led the Waggoners home in style.

Winning the toss and batting first is the usual ploy on Sundays but on a damp wicket in September against a strong Beaconsfield side it may not be the right decision and so it proved on Sunday. Only opener Riley(26) and Andy Branigan(44) were able to make any progress and Ballingers final score of 148 always looked to few. When Beaconsfield batted the Waggoners were looking for some early wicket from Adams. He duly obliged but unfortunately it brought in Carter who proceeded to smash the Ballinger bowlers to all parts of Beaconsfield. His 84 helped Beaconsfield pass Ballinger's total in just 21 overs. The only high point for Ballinger was the rare appearance in the scorebook of “ Bowled Hardy - Stumped Riley”

On a beautiful early autumn afternoon Ballinger started their last match 2 short. Team secretary Kerry was heard cursing email/mobiles/BT and colts in no particular order. Fortunately Ali Birkby was on hand to fill one of the slots again. Perhaps we ought to pay Chesham a transfer fee for him. Batting first on a very difficult wicket The Waggoners were soon in trouble when Hunting was brilliant caught in the gulley. Riley& Davies followed shortly and it was left to Maciver(44) and Kerry(25) to rebuild the innings. Another brilliant knock by Birkby(34) helped by a battered Kellock helped the Waggoners reach 161-5. Penn St set off in a very positive manner but Ballinger's spinners soon held sway with Fergus Hardy bowling a marathon spell of 19 overs taking 5-70. He was helped by Davies(3-21) & Maciver (2-4) and Penn were bowled out for 121. A very pleasant end to the season.

This was a very strange game. It looked likely at one stage that Ballinger were going to dismiss the Weekenders relatively cheaply but then their No6 played an extraordinary innings during which he played and missed## heaved and missed## heaved and hit and somehow ended up with 86*. Skipper Davies used seven bowlers all to no avail and the Weekenders finished on 226 - 5. Rick Brockett(21) & Jeremy Hunting(27) gave the Waggoners a good start but it was Davies(74) who took the attack to the opposition. Then the light deterioted so much that umpires Hunting & Hunting had to ask the opposition to bowl their slow bowlers if they wanted to continue the game. Unfortunately Davies decided to keep hitting these bowlers for 4s so the Weekenders brought back their quickies at which point amid much grumbling the umpires called a halt. All was well in the bar afterwards - unlike a league game I suspect.
My match report

It appears that exams## school commitments and other issues are going to make it very difficult to put out a team in the MBL.

A decision will be made shortly as to whether we try and complete the remaining fixtures or drop out

Only 3 overs were possible at a very soggy Ballinger . In some corners this was greeted with sighs of relief as 8pts may have been more than the team would have achieved against a strong Broomwade side

On the opening day of the season Ballinger were greeted with an excellent track## a short boundary and an Aldenham side short of bowlers. Rollo McIntyre took full advantage of all this and bludgeoned 120n.o. in no time. He added 206 for the second wicket with Matt Riley. Riley scored 70 at a more stately speed. Ballinger declared on 218 - 2 with only skipper Salisbury missing out.

Aldenham's batting was some-what better than their bowling and with the track still playing well they reached 190-7. All the Ballinger bowlers performed well but it was particularly pleasing to see the spin duo## Davies & Hardy## bowling well in tandem. New 'keeper Riley did an excellent job behind the sticks.

They don't come any closer than this! Ballinger win a cliff hanger of a cup game against Flackwell Heath.

Flackwell batted first and were contained by a tidy opening spell by Luke Hughes and Charlie Mead. At the mid point of the 20 overs they accelerated but were then pegged back towards the close of their innings by two good spells by James Rose and Sebastian Richards who each bowled two overs and took two wickets for 5 runs. At the close Flackwell had scored 60. However the grass in the outfield was very long and we reckoned that it was worth 80 to 90 at our ground.

Ballinger lost Alex Humphreys early to a very good catch. George Bailey and George Kinston then both batted well and gave us a good base. They were both dismissed for 11## which on a better outfield would have been worth a lot more. Charlie Mead came in at second wicket down and batted really well to accumulate 25. Ballinger were well on course until Charlie was out and then the middle order lost composure as the run chase was reaching its climax.

The light was poor as the last over was bowled with Ballinger still needing two to win. A wicket fell and Matthew Rose joined Sebastian Richards at the crease. A dot ball was followed by a scampered single (encouraged from a rather vocal square leg umpire!). Basty was now on strike. Three balls left one run to win. Two dot balls. One delivery left - one run required. The tension was mounting. Basty middled a leg stump delivery which went crashing past mid on and Ballinger had won.

The team bowled and fielded well. Next match we need to cut down on the opposition's singles and scramble a few more of our own. All in all a very credible performance by the team with every one contributing with either bat or ball and in the end a thoroughly deserved victory.Paul Rose

On a beautiful spring evening BWCC U11A's got off to a disappointing start to the season. Playing off 22yards!!

Ballinger put Beaconsfield in to bat and they took full advantage of the difficulty some bowlers were having bowling on a longer than usual pitch and were rattling up the runs. They were helped by some some beginning of the season sloppy fielding & after their 20 overs they were 273 for 4 with Tom Edmonds getting 8 for 32 off 2 overs. Will Smith kept really well.

After the first 2 pairs we were only 4 runs behind but our inability to pierce the field meant when the last pair came in they needed to make 38 runs in 4 overs. This proved an impossible task.

We need to put this behind us and in the next match## ensure our fielding is up to Ballingers usual standard## bowl a good length and look for the gaps in the field to get boundaries.

When the teams arrived at the ground the game was in doubt due to a wet out-field and light rain. However the 2 team coaches agreed to start the game and review the situation after 3-4 overs. The game was played under Barrington rules and Amesham won the toss and asked BWCC to bat first. Once the game was underway the weather improved immensely and soon the sun was shining and the outfield was not as slippery as we thought it might be.

The BWCC opening pair gave the team a steady start despite loosing an early wicket. Subsequent pairs batted sensibly and carefully and kept the score ticking over. The final pair scored 26 runs to set a target of 265 runs. In total BWCC lost 5 wickets. There was good batting performances from Jamie Wise## Josh Livingstone## Monty Cuthbert## Alex Welsh and Joe Carey.

When Amersham batted## the BWCC bowlers bowled a very good line and length and prevented Amersham from scoring too many runs. The BWCC fielding was excellent with good backing-up from the players plus lots of encouragement from each boy to their team members. The BWCC bowlers conceeded many fewer extras than the Amersham bowlers.

What was particularly pleasing was that only one bye and only 3 additional runs from wide deliveries were conceeded - well done to Alex Wills for keeping wicket so well. In the end BWCC only took 3 wickets - 2 in the final over. However their overall bowling performance restricted the Amersham batsmen.

Josh Livingstone captained the side well and all the team members accepted his field placings without question. There were good bowling performances from Max Bailey## who took all 3 wickets## Duncan Healey## Eddie Bentley## Tom Harrison and John Martin.

I would like to thank Jeff Moxom for umpiring the match - with the permission of Amersham CC officials.

Finally all the boys behaved impeccably and were a credit to the club.

Thanks to all the parents for suppporting the boys.

Chris Moxom BWCC Coach.BWCC 264-5 Amersham 235-3

The game started on a damp Sunday morning. There was a slight mix-up with the times in that Aston Clinton thought the game started at 10. However the match proceeded as soon as possible and Aston Clinton won the toss and asked BWCC to bat.

Stephan Otto and George Barlett opened the batting and proceeded to make steady progress against the very good Aston opening bowlers. Stephan and George put on 23 in 7 overs before George was out for 7. James Wood came in at number 3..

Sadly## as the match progressed## the strip become much more slippery and it began to cut-up. The home umpire proposed that the game be abandoned because of the potential risk of injury to both bowlers and batsmen. After a brief discussion between the coaches of both teams it was agreed to abandon the game.

At this point Stephan was 11 not out and James 6 not out. All three BWCC batsmen had batted very well in the difficult conditions.

The full team wasStephan Otto## George Barlett## James Wood## Jeff Moxom## James Miller## Jack MacIver## Luke Martin (capt.)## Jonny Freeman## Aaron Bailey## Michael Bryant## Richard Wise.BWCC U14 29-1 (9 overs)

High Wycombe proved too strong for us on Thursday evening. Wycombe batted first and were restricted to 32 off their first 10 overs## however## they accelerated to reach 83 for 4 after 20. All the bowlers bowled well and kept their heads when confronted by some clean striking of a cricket ball by some of the Wycombe batsmen. The fielding was also of a good standard and to limit a side with a number of county players to 83 in 20 overs was a very commendable performance. Will Clarke and George Bailey both bowled 3 over and took 1 for 7## which was an excellent analysis on an evening made for batting.Unfortunately we struggled with the bat. The opposition were quick and pretty straight## which proved a lethal combination for most of our players. Sam King put up some good resistance and scored 9. James Rose showed a commendably good technique and occupied the crease without adding much to the score. We were eventually bowled out for 33. I would be surprised if we come up against a bowling attack as good as that again this season. Having said that## we need to look closely at our basic technique## ie getting in line and playing straight to straight balls.There is no need to feel disheartened by defeat to a very competent opposition. And the boys now go on to a league match at Amersham followed by cup game at home to Beaconsfield on Monday 15th May.Paul Rose

With a school game at The Beacon not due to finish until 6.30## Ballinger had no choice but to start the game with 5 players (including 2 subs.) which had a major impact on the batting order. This was no way to start a game against a strong Chesham side including several county players. Chesham sportingly agreed that Ballinger should bat first on a wicket with variable bounce and a great deal of sideways movement. 100 would have been a good score.

The first few overs were negotiated safely until the wicket's variable bounce played its part in accounting for the first two wickets. Adam clipped his 2nd ball over the deep square boundary and Alex & Tom (Watts) mixed good defence with sensible attaching shots. The score was on 31 after 12 overs & acceleration was needed. Woody and Stefan led the way with George & Kristian playing their part. Somehow we managed to scrape our way to 82.

Luke & Richard opened the bowling against as good a batsman as they will play against all season. Both gave it everything. Looking for inspiration Stefan then turned to James “golden arm” Stoddart who opened up with a double wicket maiden including the prize scalp - great catch by Stefan. Jack produced 4 tidy economical overs## picking up 1 wicket and Ballinger were now back in it. Ballinger kept up the pressure with the excellent ground fielding all the way through. 26 off 6 needed & the Chesham batsmen (and coaches) were starting to feel the pressure. Great catch by Luke followed by an equally good run out by Woody & the pressure continued to mount. George## now into his rhythm picks up 2 quick wickets. Kristian## Tom Sperring & Callum continued to set the example in the field & two runs are needed off the last ball. Unfortunately Chesham managed to scrape home in the dark.

Summary.Under the circumstances this really was a great team effort and hopefully everyone who played now knows they can compete (and beat) anyone they play against. On difficult wickets## against good quality bowling## patience is needed. We have to play straight. Extras on both sides were top score so the need to bowl straight (especially on this type of wicket) is key to defending a total.

A special mention to Tom S. & Callum. Your attitude & team spirit set the tone. Stefan## captaincy wise## that's as hard as it will get!

Team: Stefan Otto## James Woods## Luke Martin## Richard Wise## James Stoddart## Jack Maciver## Callum Bright## Tom Sperring## Kristian Otto## George Bartlett## Adam Robinson.Subs - Alex Morgan## Tom Watts
. . . shortly

A determined and focused U13A team eased into the second round of the cup overcoming Gt. Kingshill.

On a damp and dreary Sunday morning Ballinger were put in after losing the toss. Sam Privett and Stefan Otto batted solidly to see off the dangerous Kingshill opening bowlers with Sam being a little unlucky to be run out.

Following the departure of the openers James Wood produced some beautifully timed drives on his way to 16. Luke Martin scored some quick fire runs before hitting all round a straight one and Tom Sperring batted well to reach double figures before smashing a drive straight to a Kingshill fielder who did well to hang on given the cold and damp conditions. At 66-5 off 14 overs though## Kingshill must have had hopes of restricting Ballinger to a reasonable score. James Stoddart however produced his best innings for Ballinger for some time mixing excellent strokeplay with intelligent running between the wickets. Well assisted by Jack MacIver and Tom Watts they pushed the score on to 102 after 20 overs.

The Kingshill reply started briskly reaching 26-0 after 4 overs. This was largely due to both Jack and Richard struggling with their footing. The introduction of James Stoddart brought immediate success (again!) bowling Kingshill's best batsman and along with Sam who bowled an excellent line and length pegged back the Kingshill reply with only 15 runs coming off their 8 overs. Off a shortened run up Jack still managed to fizz one past the edge of the batsman's bat with James Wood completing the dismissal with a good catch behind the wicket. Richard managed to conjure up an amazing run out hitting the stumps from out by the boundary. If the Kingshill batsman were hoping for some respite they didn't get it as Adam Robinson bowled quick and straight to finish off the tailenders. The bowlers were well supported in the field with Callum Bright and Tom Watts in the thick of the action.

Stefan again captained the team well## leading from the front and always giving encouragement and assistance to the team along with making sure the ball was as dry as possible for his bowlers!

In the end a comfortable win built on sensible batting## all the bowlers bowling a good line and length backed up by some solid fielding.

Scorecard:
Ballinger 102 for 6 (James Stoddart 16*## James Wood 16## Stefan Otto 12## Tom Sperring 10)

Gt Kingshill 58 all out (Adam Robinson 3-2-3-3## James Stoddart 4-1-8-3## Sam Privett 4-2-7-1)

Taplow 168 - 4 (Declared)
Ballinger 169 - 8

Ballinger captain## Ian Maciver## won the toss and decided to field on an overcast## muggy day at Taplow. Openers Lloyd and McNeil made good use of the conditions to bowl very tight opening spells## the batsmen finding it hard to score off the swinging ball. Lloyd was first to make a breakthrough with a diving catch off his own bowling (fortunately not followed by the 'twang' of breaking hip replacement components)## he also took the second wicket with a ball that surprised the batsmen by swinging right round his legs and striking leg stump. The openers were supported admirably by some fine bowling from Colts Stone## Hughes and Maciver Jnr (4 overs## 3 maidens) and a nine over spell of off-spin from Maciver Snr. The Taplow run-rate was not allowed to accelerate until after their no.4's solid inning of 53 was ended in the safe hands of Maw off the bowling of McNeil. This brought on Taplow's big-hitting no.5 who struck a quickfire 28 before skying one to Maciver Snr off Ballinger debutant Johnson. Taplow's innings ended with a score of 168 declared## at tea.

Ballinger's innings started steadily with both openers going for less than 10. Nos. 4 and 5 helped accelerate the scoring but both also went cheaply; McNeil swiping and missing a slow## looping full-toss which he thought would be called a no-ball## and possibly should have been## harmless though it was . . . except for hitting the stumps. This brought on Maciver Snr who## in a partnership of 67 with Kellock## helped steady the ship and put Ballinger in a position to take the game to Taplow. Kellock's solid knock of 54 ended with an acrobatic one-handed catch deep in the outfield. Maciver Snr was next to go## falling just short of his half century on 47. The game was left delicately poised with a handful of overs left to bowl and Ballinger 24 runs from victory. Phil Lloyd did the rest## along with a couple of low scoring tail-enders## Lloyd striking the ball imperiously to the boundary## including the only six of the game and the winning runs## a four off the first ball of the last over of the match.

A game played in beautiful surroundings## on a very fine wicket and in the true spirit of Sunday cricket was enjoyed equally (almost) by both teams.

KELLOCK(Wicket Keeper)
