Best batting was John Martin 11f0##King 6f0##Brooks 4f0.In bowling Will Reid (9f1) and Alex Howe (11f2)are to be congratulated for switching to spin (which matched the pitch## relatively new to both of them## but success in practice was emulated on the pitch today). Alex narrowly missed his hatrick. Lots of good bowling## in particular: Matthew Fennell (11f3## all wickets in one over)and Eddie Bentley 3f2## including a maiden in the 3 overs). Brandon Plumb achieved 6f1 and Monty 7f1. Claudio Bassano was agressive as always in his bowling and batting##including a wicket maiden. Fielding was generally good with 2 runouts and 3 catches## including an excellent difficult midfield catch by Eddie Bentley.Well done by all## in particular John Martin who not only top scored but guarded his wicket very well.
Hughenden Valley 211 for 9 (43 overs) Ballinger 169 for 7 (47 overs)

Longwick 161 for 10 (32.5 overs) Ballinger 165 for 6 (36.2 overs)On a hot Sunday afternoon Ballinger travelled to Longwick with the youngest team it has put out all season. Apart from three adults the Juniors ranged from 17 - 11.Ballinger won the toss and decided to field first in a 40 over game. All of the 7 bowlers used took wickets## with 2 each for Humphreys## Hutson and Stone and one apiece for McNeil## Martin## Kellock (yes we were that short on bowling!!) and Hankinson.Longwick were eventually dismissed for 161 in the 32 over.In reply Ballinger lost Clarke early on for a duck## but Mason (31) and Kellock (32) put on 70 for the second wicket before Mason was caught and Kellock was controversially given out stumped. This bought the 11 year old Will Smith to the crease who batted with maturity beyond his years. Wickets began to drop in clusters with the score not getting going## and it was left to Tom McNeil and Luke Martin to provide the entertainment for the day## by smashing the bowling to all parts of longwick.Victory was achieved in the 36 over with Tom not out on 26 and Luke not out on 35 including three big sixes.The game was enjoyed by all## and played in the right spirit throughout. Congratulations must go to all the juniors who performed exceptionally and are a credit to the junior section.Man of the Match - Luke Martin for his 35no. Combined good defence with attacking instinct and produced the shots of the day when he cover drove the opening bowler for two fours in a row.

Chesham B won the toss and elected to bat first. They started very quickly with former Ballinger Waggoner Alex Morgan hitting 46 runs. Then our bowlers found their length and line and they restricted Chesham to 104-5. Tom Sperring took 3 wickets thanks to a great catch by Jack Hankinson and 2 in the deep by James Miller. Nigel's fielding session the previous evening proving fruitful.

When BWCC started we lost a couple of quick wickets but kept up with the run rate. A good partnership between Luke Martin and Jeff Moxom saw us reach 55-3 after 10 overs. Sadly## once Luke was out for 40## with 2 sixes and 6 fours## the innings lost momentum. All the remaining batsman contributed runs but no-one was able to stay around long enough to see us home. The team were un-done by Chesham's spinners and could not cope with their accuracy and length.

Again extras were a contributory factor## we conceeded 22 (13 wides) against their 8. We must improve this area of the game. This was a much better performance than the last match - well done to all.

Batting: Martin 40## Miller 9

Bowling: Sperring 3-13## Hankinson 1-12## Bailey 1-12

Ballinger 211 for 6 (44 overs)## Aldbury 100 for 10 (32.4 overs). Ballinger made the most of the good weather in their fixture against the Albury Entertainers on Sunday posting a competitive total of 211 for 6. It was Richard Clarke who (aged only 16) stole the show for Ballinger batting unbeaten the whole way through the innings scoring a elegant 99## leaving him just one run short of his maiden century.Ballinger's youth were no less competent in the field with James Stoddart (aged 14)## Luke Martin (aged 14)## Tom McNeil (17) all claiming wickets. But it was Rhodri Webster## still only 19 himself## who polished off Aldbury taking 4 wickets and 4 catches as there were bowled out for 100.

A good win## top scorers Brandon Plumb (11f0)## Eddie Bentley (9f0)Alex Howe scored 15 for 1 wicket. Max Bailey led the bowling with 5f1 off 3 overs with Tom Ryland's 1st appearance with 5f0. Will Reid achieved 7 for 1 and Mike Thomas bowled 2 tidy overs of spin (3f0). The fielding was satisfactory although controling a team and ensuring fielders are in the right position is not as easy as it seems as our rotating captains are finding out...

MBL Premier DivDownley 115 -10 v BWCC 117 -7

Ballinger managed to dodge the showers on Saturday to record a much needed win over Downley

Winning the toss skipper Riley put Downley in on what looked a difficult wicket to bat on. He guessed correctly as the slow pitch made runs hard to come by. First Adams and Lloyd bowled with their usual miserly economy and took 2 wickets each## then spinners Hardy and Davies finished the job off with Hardy recording the excellent figures of 4-16.

The Waggoners set off in pursuit of Downleys 115 with a certain amount caution with Riley batting 40 overs for his 49. Adams gave the innings some impetus with 21 off 8 balls then Lloyd and Maciver saw the visitors home - but only just - as the players walked off the field the heavens opened.

BWCC v Scuttlers Scuttlers 221-7 BWCC 120-9

On Sunday Ballinger played host to a very strong ScuttlersX1. Following an excellent lunch the Waggoners were forced to chase leather for the next 2 hours as the Scuttlers rattled up 211.

Ballinger openers Webster and Hughes did a great job in putting on 67 for the 1st wicket but after Will Hunting removed them both in successive overs and then Waggoner's danger man Hunting 2 overs later the writing was on the wall.

The introduction of the Scuttler spin king Kerry saw the wheels fall off completely as a combination of his guile and some stunning fielding reduced the Waggoners to 9 down## but skipper Salisbury## and last man Tom Graham## managed to hang on for an honourable draw.

A very pleasant day

An evening that started sunny got rapidly gloomy as a poor batting display by Ballinger amassed a total of only 71. Fortunately it was also getting literally gloomy and the rain when it came was torrential ending any hopes of a result and ensuring the points were shared.

Ballinger won the toss and elected to bat first. Openers Joe Hankinson and Dom Hutson had to face 2 of 3 County bowlers in the Amersham side and they saw off 6 overs from the opening bowlers. However runs were hard to come by and Joe was bowled for 6 by the first change bowler. A partnership between Dom and Joe Stevens of 25 upped the scoring rate until Joe and Dom were out in quick succession. This brought together James Miller and Jeff Moxom who then batted out the remaining 8 overs## putting on 47 un-beaten runs. The Amersham bowlers all kept good line and length and made Ballinger work hard for their runs. Whilst 95-3 looked a reasonable score we felt that another 15-20 runs would have made it more difficult for Amersham.

When Amersham started their innings## Joe Hankinson and James Stoddart opened the bowling and kept the run rate under control and each took a wicket to remove both openers after 6 overs. Aaron Bailey and Tom Sperring then came on to bowl and Tom got a wicket in his first over. However Amersham started to up their scoring rate even though Tom Sperring took two more wickets and ended his spell with excellent figures of 4-1-3-14## the second match running Tom has taken 3 wickets in a innings. Unfortunately the our bowlers could not exert the required control on runs from both ends and some loose bowling allowed Amersham to reach their target in the 16th over for the loss of 5 wickets.

This was a competetant display against a team containing 3 County players. The team fielded well and took all the catches offered. The boys should feel proud of their performance against goo opposition.

Batting: Miller 26 no## Moxom 16 no## Hutson 19## Stevens 12

Bowling: Sperring 3-14## Joe Hankinson 1-7## Stoddart 1-18

Haddenham 100-10 BWCC 101-6

Ballinger managed to sneak in another win in amongst Saturday's thunder storms. Playing bottom of the table Haddenham meant this was a must win game for the Waggoners.

Skipper Riley did his job by winning the toss and inserting the visitors. A brilliant catch by McIntyre should have set the standard for the Ballinger fielders - sadly not. Fortunately the Haddenham batsmen gave them plenty of practice. Davies took 5-20 in an a spell that Mr Bassett would have recognised## a brilliant run out by Hardy and the return of Adams saw the end of The Haddenham's innings for 100.

The Waggoners were reduced to 30-4 by some interesting umpiring. A stand of 60 between Kerry & Birby(21no) steadied the ark and Ballinger eased home with 15 overs to spare

Beaten## by a vocal## determined and very good bowling side. Ignoring wickets we scored 70 runs## they scored 65. Its nice to dream. Our bowling was also tight which restricted their run flow. Fielding too from both sides was generally sharp

MBL Premier DivisionBWCC v Monks RisboroughBWCC 165-10 Monks Risborough 115-10

Having beaten two of the bottom sides the previous weeks Ballinger took on high flying Monks Risborough on Saturday.

Asked to bat 1st the Waggoners were soon in trouble at 55 -6## then an excellent stand of 50 between James Fallowfield-Smith and Ben Whelan got the Waggoners back on track. Fergus Hardy and Dom Birkby added another 30 precious runs at the end so Ballinger reached the relative safety of 165-10.

The Monks went about the task of chasing Ballinger's total in their normal flamboyant style but Birkby was on top form with ball and his spell of 3-23 kept the visitors under control. A brilliant reflex catch by Whelan had removed danger man Shah and with Hardy( 4-46) weaving his magic The Monks were bowled out for 115. Leaving Ballinger winers by 50 runs and 25 points better off.

Hyde Heath 109-10 BWCC 113 -7

On Sunday Ballinger visited neighbours Hyde Heath. On a difficult wicket Ballinger kept the Heath down to 109 with Phil Lloyd (3-27)## new man Richard Holden (3-21) and a very short but effective spell from Zorro Webster (3-0) doing the damage.

Ali Richards then did his best to keep Hyde Heath in the match with a brilliant spell of 14-7-19-6. He reduced Ballinger to 19-7 and it looked as though it was all over for the Waggoners. Then skipper Graham Salisbury (30*) and pace-man Lloyd(39*) took control and saw the Waggoners home to a 3 wicket win.
BWCC 163 for 10(39.4 overs)Amersham Hill 64 for 10 (28.1 overs)

Ballinger batted first on a warm late-September afternoon. Kellock joined Phillips at the crease after Humphreys was out caught in the second over. A second wicket stand of 132 ended when Phillips was out caught for 70. Kellock went on to make 87 ending a partnership of 65 with Mason. Mason(46) was joined by Jack Maciver(37) and the 40 over inning was concluded without further loss of wickets(264). After a fine tea(thanks to the Birkbys) the match was over in 4.4 overs with Nick Adams taking 6 wickets in 2 overs(no runs!)## only 2 of Cheshams Bois's 10 players troubling the scorer and finishing with a total of 9## 6 of which were byes(making wicket-keeper Mason the highest scorer).

Ballingers opening match of theseason was against local revials Hawridge. Played at Ballinger on a damp pitc with a wet outfield scoring was never going to be easy. Hawridge batted first and with O'Kelly taking a wicket with his first ball on debut the visitors were soon in trouble.

All the Waggoners bowlers did their job and restricted Hawridge to 232

Dom Brown and Monty Thompson got The Waggoners off to a good start and with each pair edging the total further and further past the Hawridge score Ballinger came home comfortable winners## finishing on 262
Sadly Holmer Green couldn't get a team out and although we get the points it would have been good for the boys to have a run out

Cadmore 81-10 BWCC 82-5At last a Ballinger 2nd team to took to the field.This historic match against Cadmore End was played on a very slow damp pitch which meant run scoring was never going to be easy.Skipper Kerry won the toss and had no hesitation in putting the visitors in.Excellent opening spells from Thompson and Harry Rix meant the vistors were 5 down inside10 overs. Sebastian Richards then weaved his spell taking 2-17 off 7 overs. A couple of wickets for Luke Hughes and 1 from Tim Rix finished the innings off.Derek Richards and Will Smith started the innings well but Ballinger found run scoring no easier than the visitors and at tea the Waggoners had struggled to 45 - 5. After tea the flashing blade of Rix senior soon made short work of the deficit and 10 man Ballinger were home with 30 overs to spare.Highlights of the day were abrilliant catch by O'Kelly off Thompson to record the first ever wicket for the 2s and a brilliant runout by Tim Rix## managing to hit the 1 stump he had to aim at.

BWCC 178 for 8 (37overs)Aldenham 45 for 10 (21 overs)A strong Ballinger side (bolstered by a number of Sat 1st XI players) made a good start to the season. Kellock and Humphries made 39 and 27 respectively(the power of net practice!) and Ian Davis top scored with 49. Fergus made a cameo appearance at No.8 and finished 18 not out after some lusty blows.The Aldenham innings was a fairly brief affair with Nick Adams taking 4 for 9 off 6 and Alex Macdonald 4 for 2 off 5.The beer tasted good.

BWCC 303 Good batting throughout with the Waggoners only losing 2 wickets enabled the 'A's to reach an impressive 303.Top bowling then restricted the Saints to 175. Pick of the bowlers were Tom with 3 wickets## then Ollie Bull and Dom Roberts had 2 each with Toby## Will## Rob## and Junaid taking 1 each. The side were well led by Xavier
Waddesdo 194-10 BWCC 110 - 7

Playing a full strength side with all the boys at the proper age i.e 11 was always going to be a problem for the young U11c team. Holmer Green took full advantage of the difference in size and strength bolwing Ballinger out for 185. Although all the bowlers did Ok it was always going to be difficult to keep the Green in check and they rattled up 295 in their 20 overs

Chiltern 303 -1 BWCC 200 - 10Playing a bunch of U13 county players even though they were girls was always going to be a tough call for the learners from Ballinger.Our 2 girls Jess and Alli did well with Jess taking her first wicket for the club. Some poor running between the wickets let the team down with 5 of the 10 wickets lost coming from run outs.Still it was a very enjoyable evening

Beaconsfield 101-5 BWCC 76-5Ballinger gave too many runs away with some slopping bowling and poor fielding. Chasing donw the visitors total on a very slow outfield was always going to be a problem and facing some tight bowling the Waggoners batters didn't look for enough singles. Favouring the swipe rather than the dab.
Sadly our U12s weren't strong enough for a good Amersham U13 side.

Ballinger secured a comfortable win over Calfont by playing as a team. Batting first Max Dugdale and Monty Cuthbert put on 40 for the 1st wicket with some excellent running between the wicket. Cuthbert was bowled and Dugdale had to retire shortly after but Wise and Bull kept up the momentum.A final score of 123 always looked too good.Very good opening spells by Howe and Bryant put the Saints on the back foot and with every bowler sticking to a good line Ballinger never looked in trouble. Brilliant fielding by Wise and Ben Dugdale helped the bowlers keep the Saints at bay.A very good all round performance
Ballinger lost to a Lee team who were used to playing as a team as opposed to Ballinger who still had boys arriving 30 mins after the start.

He's back - A commanding performance by Danny Draper as Batter and Bowler reminded us what we had been missing. Out bowled by an U15 and outscored by an U13. Welcome back Danny.Rollo's first go at captaincy on a Sunday produced a brilliant game of cricket with 6 runs between the teams and a very nervous Taplow overseas player bowling the last over to prevent 2 U13s ( Hankinson & Smith) winning the match for Ballinger

"Excellent performance in the field - both bowling and fielding enabled BWCC to get one back on GX. BWCC got 9 wickets in all which was the difference between the teams. BWCC openned the batting and played some sensible if not expansive cricket with only 4 wickets lost## two of which were run-outs. Has Monty lost his wicket this season? Oliver N-M scored the first 4 and shared the second the highest score with FD-S (capt). Hamish showed the most intention## but George Ryland top scored on 9 with no loss.Spirit and enthusiasm in the field was supported by some excellent bowling and fielding. Monty developing his role behind the wickets. Direct hits on the stumps were prolific - two of which caused superb run-outs (Macintyre## and Freddie from side on). Wickets were taken by almost all the bowlers## but George's two wickets including a CAB justified ""Man of the Match"""

"A spirited performance in the field presented BWCC with a gettable 53. Will Gibbs would have had a hat trick in the first 3 balls of the match had we decided to play LBW; having GX 12 runs in the red half way through the first over was quite a boost. Tight middle order bowling from Oli C## Freddie T## Hamish kept the run rate down. BWCC got 10 wickets from some excellent bowling.Monty cementing his position as an openner## kept out the fast bowlers. Freddie (13-1) and Theo's (capt) (7-1) partnership in the middle order meant that the run chase was still on. A flurry of wickets followed which gave Hamish and James Mac 27 runs to score from their final partnership - they never quite got close enough despite having the most profitable partnership of the innings of 16 runs.BWCC lost only 7 wickets to GX's 10 but were not able to find the boundary as frequently. James Mac top scored on 8 with no loss. The difference between the sides in the end was the 11 runs which GX managed to score in the last over## 10 of which came from Ben ""the county player""!"

BWCC batted first - 224## for 8 wickets. Marlow Park## 219 for 10. It seemed that with 224 we had not made enough runs## in the face of some good brisk bowling and fielding from Marlow Park. However## the BWCC bowling was even better and the fielding also very good. Freddie D-S opened the bowling and put BWCC on track with 2 wickets in one over## both bowled. Then tight bowling from Will Arnold## Monty Thompson## Freddie Thompson and Harry Livingstone in particular kept Marlow Park pegged back and ensured a regular fall of wickets## leaving them with 20 to get off the last 4 overs## and setting up an exciting finish. Marlow Park fell just short## due to some excellent ground fielding under pressure from BWCC## who then rounded off the match with an impromptu lap of honour!

"On a wet miserable day at Ballinger the 2nds entertained The Lee.Skipper Richards did his job well by winning the toss and inserting the visitors.Excellent opening spells from Thompson( 3-21) and Sperring (0-18) soon had The Lee on the back foot. With ""Fingers"" weaving his spell once more ( 3-22) the home side were always in control. Finally dismissing The Lee for 104.Another mature innings from Smith ( 38) and a blistering onslaugth from debutant Paul Rose (40no) were just too much for the visitors and The Waggoners romped home in 28 oversAnother excellent tea was provided by Heidi Petrie"

Starting a match against one of the better sides in the MBL with only 8 players doesn't bode well## especially as it as Holmer Green which is probably the biggest ground we play on.The late arrival of Sam helped but the Waggoners were always going to struggle to contain the home side.An excellent century form Kevin King made sure Ballinger had little chance of winning but had it taken too long.The rain had ensured that it was going to be a miserable day for all but the reduction of overs meant that we ONLY had to bat for 39.Blockers Salisbury and Brockett were sent out to do the job and were soon frustrating bowlers and fielders alike. Sadly their demise let to another Waggoner collapse and it was left to skipper Davies and LLoyd to try and bat out time.They managed this even though it was pitch black by the time the game finished - MCC##ICC##ECB## where were you when needed - unfortunately the gallant efforts of the 9 men gained Ballinger 1 point. 1 more than if we had scratched but stopped Holmer from getting 25. Will that make a difference at the end of the season.One bonus from the day - Our TLO is better than theirs.

Potten End 208 - 9## BWCC 74-10

Sadly the 2s unbeaten record was smashed on Saturday

Skipper Kerry won the toss again and offered Potten first use of the pitch and with Sperring and Harry Rix bowling well it looked like a good decision. Unfortunately the Waggoners catching was not up to it's normal high standard and with 6 catches going down## and with 52 extras conceded## it was always going to be a struggle to keep an aggressive Potten batting line up under control

Bastie Richards bowled another fine spell ( 3-35) and he was well supported by Tom Sperring (4-48) and new boy james Rose (1-23)

Only Michael Bryant and Tom Sperring reached double figures as Ballinger collapsed to 74 all out in just 24 overs

Derek and his team worked very hard to make this game happen but sadly were let down by the weather and the governing body

The club will be exploring the avenues taken by the BCBto see if further clarification can be made re teams inability to field a team.

"BWCC 183- 10 Braddenham 130- 10

It had to happen and what a pleasure it was to watch Tim Rix take full advantage of his Skippers failure to win the toss by scoring the ""2s"" 1st 50

 

A 100 partnership for the 2nd wicket between Rix (59)and Peter Petrie(32)put the Waggoners in a strong postion against visitors Bradenham.

Unfortunately a flurry of wickets meant that on a very slow wicket it was always going to be difficult to decide on a sensible total

New boy Carlin (31) helped Kerry add 52 precious runs for the 7th wicket and with the Waggoners closing on 183 anything was possible

.

Another top spell by Sperring(1-11)meant that ""Fingers"" Richards could weave his web once more. 12-1-32-2 are impressive figures but after Carlin ( 2-24) had done his bit the sting in the tale was delivered by Rix with a brilliant spell (4-0-16-4). Max Maciver ( 1-7)did his job by removing a truculant last man

"

Hughenden Valley 48 - 10 BWCC 49-4

After a couple of miserable weeks Ballinger got their MBL campaign back on track on Saturday.

Top of the table Hughenden made the strange decision to bat first on what was always likely to be a difficult wicket. In Nick Adams (4-12) and Phil Lloyd( 3-20) the Waggoners have the ideal bowlers to exploit any oddities in a wicket and by the time they had finished their spells Hughenden were 30 - 7. Dom Birkby ( 2-10) and Fergus Hardy (1-1) finished the job.

The bowlers were for once supported by some excellent outfielding with 6 catches being taken and another good display by Charlie Wells behind the stumps

Hughenden's 48 shouldn't have been a problembe a problem but Ballinger like to make things difficult and managed to lose 4 wickets before over taking the home sides total. Only Charlie Wells ( 20 ) looked comfortable against the Hughenden attack

Ballinger Under 15s gave agood account of themselves against a strong Bovingdon team narrowly losing in the penultimate over. Ballinger batted first and made a steady 96 for 7 off 20 overs. The highlight of the batting was the impressive batting of Jack Maciver 29 and Max Maciver 20. Their excellent batting was well supported by the running and intelligent batting by James Rose who scored 11 and George Kingston who scored 8.Bovingdon in reply batted excellently and scored 98 for the loss of 3 wickets.Ballinger## however## bowled well and the pick of the bowlers who maintained a good line and length were Sebastian Richards with 2 wickets for 9 runs off 4 overs## Harry Rix 1 wicket for 18 off 3 overs## J.Rose 0 for 18 off 3 overs and an excellent opening spell from Jack Maciver 0 for 10 runs off 3 overs and Jack Hankinson 0 for 10 runs off 4 overs.

Ballinger Under 15s## starting with 10 players and reduced to 9 following an injury to Mathew Rose## were beaten by a strong batting performance by Wendover which Ballinger were unable to match.Wendover batted first and scored 129 for 4 wickets on a fast batting track. Ballinger bowlers did well to stick to their task## in particular George Bailey with 1 wicket for 15 runs off 4 overs. The other bowlers Jack Hankinson## Sebastian Richards## Dominic Hutson## James Rose and George Kingston stuck manfully to their task and did well to keep the score at just over 6 an over.Ballinger## in reply## never really settled and finished on 72 for 7. The highlight of the batting was the stand of 32 between Simon Brooker who batted particularly well for his 13 not out## well supported by Sebastian Richards with 11.

Widmer 104 -10. BWCC 105 - 6

On a very slow wicket at Widmer End it soon became clear that flashing blades weren't going to be the order of the day. What was required was a bit of grinding and in Derek Richards and Will Smith Ballinger had the perfect opening parntnership.

Chasing 104 was likely to be a problem but an excellent opening stand of 45 between Derek(35) and Will(16) broke the back of the job.Acceleration was provided by Tom Sperring(16) and Matt Rose(12)and when things looked like getting tight a huge 6 from Paul Rose and couple of good shots from Ben Carlin saw The Waggoners home

Earlier Ballingers bowlers had kept Widmer on a really tight rein with Sperring (5.3.6.0) and Carlin ( 10 3 19 3) leading the way. They were ably supported by James and Matt Rose and once again Bastie Richards bowled his 12 for just 3 an over## taking 2 wickets in the process.However the star of the show was Rob Rose taking 4-8 in 5 overs of quality off-spin. The fielding was excellent with Sperring leading the way and another tidy display from Paul Barnigan behind the stumps

Widmer End 198 - 7 BWCC 177 - 8

The 2's managed a very creditable winning draw and an important 15 points in a match against Haddenham where all 3 results were still possible late on in the game.

Bowling first Ballinger took 4 wickets in the first hour thanks to a tight spell from Peter Petrie## Andy Thompson and a wicket in his first over from Basty Richards. Haddenham then dug in and their 5th wicket partnership proved vital as stand in skipper Rix's bowling changes failed to click.

With Basty tying down one end a return from Thompson did the trick with a wicket and a slowing of the scoring rate. The remaining Haddenham opener was unmovable and carried his bat for a hard worked 95 not out## Haddenham finishing on 194-8.

Ballinger lost the early wicket of Michael Bryant (2 bounces or more?) but Petrie and Richard O'Kelley moved the score on well. Paul Branigan batted sensibly after O'Kelley was dismissed with Petrie playing the senior role.

After Branigan was out Paul Rose kept Petrie company and any result was still on however with Rose's dismissal and the loss of 3 quick wickets meant that only a winning draw was really possible.

This was achieved emphatically with Petrie scoring at will and never looking in trouble. A mighty 88 not out was well deserved by Peter - well done!Everyone was happy with the result and 15 points and everyone got involved in the game which was a plus point.

7 games in it's 4 wins## 2 draws and only one loss so far - bring on Prestwood on Saturday!

Haddenham 191-8 BWCC 65-10

Last year Haddenham were the wipping boys of the Premier league and twice Ballinger bowled them out for low totals so what happened on Saturday?

Somehow a side with 9 bowlers in it managed to let the home side score far too many run on a slow pitch notoriously difficult to chase a total on.

Having conceded 191 runs Ballinger then took 40 overs to score 65 so didn't even manage a batting point.

There were no heroes and too many villans to mention them all.
A classic Kerry/Webster admin error meant we had a team and a fixture but sadly not on the same night.

Chalfont St.Peter 91-6 BWCC 93 - 7The Saints spent so long bowling their overs that it was 9pm before the match finished and there were still 5 overs to go when Alex Howe finally steered the Waggoners home.

BWCC 58 -9 Chenies 58-10How Ballinger managed to win this game is beyond comprehension.

From 6-5 after 2 overs they managed to drag themselves to the riches of 58 - 9 thanks to the efforts of Rory Seekins and Monty Thompson

This never looked like being enough when Chenies were 24 after 8 overs but some more magic from Seekins and some unbeleviable batting from Chenies meant that they needed 1 run with 2 wickets left and managed to lose them both. Therefore Ballinger won by losing less wickets

Amazing

Prestwood 58-10 BWCC 60 - 0

Skipper Kerry won a very important toss on Saturday. With rain around it was a must that## bottom of the table## Prestwood batted first

Having done his part it was then up to the Waggoners bowlers to do theirs and they duly obliged

Harry Rix was the first to strike curtesy of a difficult catch made to look easy by Derek Richards. Then father Tim got in on the act with Kerry taking the chance at slip.Then it was a father son act with Tim taking an excellent catch at slip to help Harry finish with 2-20 off his 5 overs.

The introduction of 'Fingers' Richards normally causes the opposition batters a problem and once he'd settled into his ryhthm Saturday was no exception. 3-15 off 9 overs was reward for another excellent spell

With Petrie causing chaos at the other end (4-2-4-3)Prestwood were soon bundled out for 59 in only 26 overs

Derek Richards and Adam Riley opened up for Ballinger and on what was now a very slow wicket worked their way to the 60 runs required for victory. It took 20 overs but neither looked in an trouble

Victory was achieved 20 minutes before the heavens opened and it's doubtful if any further play would have been possible. Hence the importance of the toss

"BWCC went into bat. There were plenty of runs but nearly as many run outs..often the wrong person calling the wrong decision and CSG bounced on these opportunies with well drilled precision. This was a fast outfield and most of our batsman found the boundary. George L## Ollie## Freddie## Theo and Kenny all played some good strokes but the wickets fell too fast and 245 never looked like a defendable total.Seth was the pick of the bowlers## pitching the ball perfectly and getting some good swing away from the batsmen. Dom's caught and bowled to get ""Big Harry"" out first ball was a high-light. However the big guy had the last laugh## reverse sweeping the last ball for 4!"

Ballinger batted first and everyone contributed to post a solid score of 289. Hamish (top score of 9) and Ollie C openned and took every opportunity with excellent running between the wickets. Will Gibbs played the two shots of the day. Matthew and Ollie N-M posted the leading partnership of 24.As usual## it was the performance in the field which really impressed. The first ball (Freddie) of the innings was caught sharply by George. 17 wickets taken in all. Two fine catches by Elliot and a very relieved looking Oliver N-M held his chance. Tight accurate bowling from Ollie N-M## Will G## Hamish## Theo## and Elliot. Our glove man. Stephen had his work cut out and took a sharp catch to an excellent ball from the Captain Elliot. Nepostically## I awarded Freddie man of the match for his season best bowling tally of 4 wickets for 5 runs.
BWCC 71-8 Amersham 73-4

Ley Hill 265-8 BWCC 245- 6

Ballinger's skipper Nigel Kerry## was somewhat taken by surprise when on winning the toss Ley Hill elected to bat first in this top of the table clash.

On an excellent track He was soon shown why as The Hill were soon rattling along at over 6 an over.

Ben Carlin and Tom Sperring both bowled well again with Ben being rewarded with 3 wickets But Tom had one of those days when nothing went to hand or the ball beat the bat.The introduction of Seb Richards immediately brought reward with a wicket first ball. Unfortunately Bastie struggled with the wind and was hit out of the attack by Hill's Phillips.

Meanwhile Andy Thompson was putting in a top spell with 3-51 off his 12 overs. He removed danger man Phillps and then was helped by a brilliant catch by Sperring and another top delivery to remove the Hill's middle order

.Hill's skipper Bell## meanwhile## was moving serenly on to an excellent 79 no. A couple of late wickets including one from new man Nick Howe gave the Waggoners another bowling point

Ley Hill finished on 265.

Balinger were surprised that the visitors had batted their full quota of overs but by setting the Waggoners the tough task of reaching 236 for the winning draw it made sense.

.

Unfortunately the Hill hadn't allowed for Richard O'Kelly who batted brilliantly on what was still an excellent track. Not wanting to take too many singles Richard put the fast out field to good use by scoring 20 fours## throw in a couple of 6s and you soon get to the 107 he scored.

Without any of the regular openers available skipper Kerry was press-ganged into opening.After a few scratchy moments early on## especially against the excellent Asquith## Kerry soon settled down to help O'Kelly move the score along. By the 30th over the pair had reduced the asking rate to 7 an over## which was easily achievable on this pitch. Unfortunately Richard perished going for one more big hit and with the fielders all on the boundary it was now going to be difficult to win the game. Kerry kept going but with 5 overs to go he to went for the wrong shot and was caught on the boundary for an excellent 97. This left 40 to score off the last 5 over for the win but only 10 for the winnin draw. Sounds easy but 3 quick wickets put the Hill back in the game. A nerveless Alex Howe then led the Waggoners to 236 they needed for the winning draw and managed to hang on with Tom Sperring to frustrate the visitors.

Another really enjoyable match played in an excellent spirit

Ballinger Under 15s completed a comfortable win against a competitive Amersham Hill side.Ballinger## captained by Sebastian Richards## won the toss and scored 106 off their 20 overs. The highlight of the batting were the performances of Chris Cooper with 19 and Mathew Rose with 22. Chris Cooper showed that he is developing into a fine attacking batsman. The performance of Mathew Rose particularly caught the eye with a stylish 22 before being unluckily run out. Mathew is clearly going to develop into a fine number 4 batsman.Amersham Hill in reply reached 83 for the loss of 9 wickets.The opening attack of Jack Hankinson and Tom Sperring was too strong for the opposition who were reduced to 7 runs for 5 wickets. Jack Hankinson's bowling figures of 5 wickets for 6 runs off 4 overs again showed that he is fast becoming a top bowler at this level## well supported by Tom Sperring who returned 1 wicket off 3 overs## bowling into the sun.Tidy performances from the remaining bowlers## Sebastian Richards## George Bailey## Harry Rix## George Kingston and Luke Hughes ensured a comfortable win.Finally well done to Jack Bull who kept particularly well looking into the sun. Jack is a fine prospect for the future and already looks comfortable keeping wicket at this level.

BWCC 379 - 3 Chenies 237 - 10For the first time we were able to field a full strength side but## unfortunately## it was against pretty weak opposition. Chenies were no match for the strength of the Dugdales and the style of Xavier and 400 looked on the cards at 1 stage. The same applied when Chenies batted with accurate bowling from Xavier and the rest of the team keeping them down to 237.

Chenies did their best but with the majority of their team only 10 it was always going to be a tough task for them.

Sadly this was the last league game of the season and although we finished 2nd in the league I don't feel that we didn't reach our full potential.

Hopefully the boys will take advantage of summer coaching and the winter programme that is now being put together

Ballinger batted first. Everyone batted sensibly against some good bowling. Only 5 wickets lost## two of which were silly run-outs## Poor calling and bat running-in being the culprits. Monty and George top-scored on 8 - both playing good looking shots. Hamish kept his average up## contributing 7. The final score was 258.In the field## the team showed the usual resilience and commitment in adversity. There was consistently good fielding and backing up although catching opportunities were not taken. Good inexpensive bowling from Ollie NM## Matt OK## Ollie C## who have all tightened up their line and length - well coached## Roger. George's very economical 2 overs for 2 runs and a wicket was not quite good enough to earn him man of the match## which went to Will G for an outstanding 3 for 7. I also awarded Monty a batting Man of Match for his fine come-back (from injury) top score.Although the gap was quite large## really the difference between the sides was one player who tonked some reasonable bowling around the ground## including a 6. Saif## who captains the U10 County team## scored 38 with some crafty harvesting of the strike - this took the game away from Ballinger.Overall## a mixed season with some good wins and a few losses but a pleasure to manage a highly spirited and commited U11B team## whom I am sure will form a great U11A team next Summer.

Cadmore 147 - 10 BWCC 137 - 10Skipper Kerry won the toss again and was happy to insert the opposition on a pitch that was difficult to tell from the outfield.

Cadmore End is a difficult place to bowl especially when the strip is at the very top of the square. Anything short normally ends up in the cemetary and Saturday was no exception. It took openers Tim Rix and Andy Thompson 4 overs to find their range by which time Cadmore had scored 50

Once they'd settled down things moved back in the Waggoners favour. With Rix taking 3 - 37 and Peter Petrie ( 4-16) amongst the wickets again it looked as though the visitors were going to remove the End for about 100. An annoying 7th wicket stand of 40 took the home sides score to 141 then Ballinger let 2 youngsters add anothe 6 runs. How important would these be in what was likely to be a tight game

Along side the senior bowlers Rob Rose had bowled a tidy spell of off-spin and Jake Cutter a couple of excellent overs of leg-spin.

Only 32 overs were used to bowl the home side out so Ballinger set off in pursuit of their target with quiet determination.

Skipper Kerry did his best aided by first Jake Cutter with a stand of 19 then with Evan Webster with a stand of 20 but when Kerry fell with the score on 130## with still 10 overs to go## his frustration was obvious.

Rob Rose and Evan added another 7 when a suicidal run ended the Waggoners innings on 137.

The 6 runs given to Cadmore last pair## too many byes and 8 dropped catches all contrived to make Ballingers task harder. Add a dodgy LBW and an unlikely catch to remove 2 top batters and you have some excuses for this loss

Positives were Jack Bull's and Evan Webster's batting and Rob Rose and Jake Cutters bowling

Ballinger Under 15s lost off the last ball in an exciting match against Ley Hill.Ley Hill batting first were restricted by some fine bowling to a score of 85 all out off 20 overs.All the bowlers contributed which was particularly pleasing## namely Jack Maciver with 1 for 17 off 3 overs## Jack Hankinson 2 for 13 off 4 overs##Sebastian Richards 2 for 10 off 4 overs## Tom Sperring 1 for 12 off 4 overs## George Kingston 2 for 16 off 3 overs and Harry Rix with 1 for 8 off 2 overs.In reply Ballinger made 82 runs for the loss of 8 wickets. The highlight of the batting was the fine innings of 33 runs from Will Smith. Unfortunately none of the remaining batsmen made double figures. A flurry from Jack Hankinson and George Kingston at the end which yielded 13 runs from the last over almost saw us home but in the end we were undone by the failure to capitalise on Will's fine innings.

An understrength Ballinger Under 15s lost an exciting match in the last over against Hawridge and Cholesbury.Ballinger batting first made 107 runs for the loss of 3 wickets. The highlights of the batting was the partnership of 95 runs between Will Smith who scored his maiden 50 for the club abd Jack Hankinson who was dismissed for 37. Will Smith## in particular has developed into a fine opening batsman and is particularly strong off his back foot.Jack Hankinson## in turn## has matured into a fine batsman at this level and has the ability to develop into a fine stroke player.Hawridge and Cholesbury in return made 109 for the loss of 7 wickets## principally due to an opening partnership of 62. Once this partnership had been broken Ballinger tore into the remaining batsmen taking 6 wickets for the next 37 runs.The pick of the bowlers were Max Maciver with an excellent spinning display which yielded 5 wickets for 13 runs off his 4 overs. Tom Sperring bowled extremely well taking 1 wicket for 6 runs off 4 overs.The failure to break the opening partnership was however to prove fatal and in the end Ballinger were just unable to pull off what would have been a great comeback in the circumstances.
Cheham A proved too strong for Ballinger but the team to their credit fought to the end.

Even without playing we manged to maintain our place in the top 3.

Sadly Ley Hill managed to play and got 25 points so have opened up a gap at the top.

Our next match at The Lee has now become very important and choices may have to made re batting first etc. Lets just hope for a dry day

The Waggoners ended their losing streak on Saturday with a much needed win over bottom placed Chesham Bois

Batting first Ballinger were struggling at 51 -5 when Sam Phillips and Jack Maciver came together. Their stand of 40 helped the visitors to their first batting point. Sam was out with the score on 91. When Tom Maw was out Jack Maciver hung around to help Nick Adams add 59. Nicks whirlwind 50 came off just 21 balls and enabled Ballinger to reach 176 -7.

On a lively track Ballingers bowlers were always likely to cause problems and with the wickets shared between all 5 bowlers the home side were bowled out for 106 giving Ballinger a much needed 25 points.

"

With strong bowling side## but a badly under strength batting line up## having won the toss## Holmer were duly put in to bat first. They were quickly scoring at 6 an over## with only Nick Adams able to apply the brakes.Wickets kept falling and at 112-6## things were looking up. Not for long!By the time we took the last wicket the score was 193## made in only 40 overs.

Setting about this target##eminently gettable in 55 overs (one might think)## by the 14th over we were 18 for 6## with our batsmen doing a passable imitation of their England role models.That we eventually actually achieved a batting point was due to the removal of Holmer's openers from the attack## plus some application from skipper Ian Maciver aided by another lusty assault by Nick Adams.

High time some of the ""batsmen"" got stuck in !!!

"

Batting first after winning the toss (rash?) we managed to reach 64 before the 3rd wicket fell## thanks to a stand by Rollo & Ian Davies## but therafter only Tom Maw stuck at it## and we subsided to a pathetic 122 all out## using up only 35 overs. Ley Hill simply cruised past this score## losing only 1 wicket en route. Oh dear..... p><

Downley won the toss## batted first## andutterly annihilated what should have been a strong bowling side.For the second successive home game we conceded more than 300 ! Downley's J Cox made 171## the only man snared by a bowler## the other 2 wickets being late run-outs.

With 52 overs at our disposal## we certainly had time to win## but apart from a spirited 84 by Ian Davies no-one else got beyond the 20's## and we ended up 87 runs short.

Inserted by Knotty Gn## an under-strength BWCC side batted slowly but steadily## reaching 70 for 2 before the wickets started to tumble. Ian Davies (42) and Jeremy Hunting (21) kept us in the game## and we reached a respectable but hardly match-winning 155 all out in the 44th over.

Knotty Gn lost 2 quick wickets## to give us some illusory hope## but we eventually succumbed by 6 wickets in the 43rd over.Spinners Fergus Hardy and Ian Maciver were the pick of our bowlers.

The Monks' openers treated our bowlers with care for a few overs## but soon were scoring fast. and the score was 123 before the 2nd wicket was captured in the 23rd over. By the 31st over we had them 5 down for 156## but an unbroken 6th wicket partnership of 56 saw them reach 243 at 45 overs.

With our first 5 batsmen failing to reach double figures## our reponse could hardly be called convincing## but the later batsmen## led by Alex Macdonald (34) at least ensured some measure of respectability## before we made it to 143 (of which 40 were extras!)

Skipper Davies## bold as ever## thought his bowlers should have a good chance of getting among the WESM batsmen. Unfortunately## Mr Hashmi had other ideas. Amazingly## given that his 16 sixes and 17 fours gave our fielders plenty of time searching the hedges and nearby roads and gardens## we didn't lose a ball. In their desire to to see him reach a well-deserved double-ton## WESM left thir declaration (312-2) a bit late!

Two down by the 7th over## we were struggling## but some fine batting by Rollo McIntyre(36) and Ian Davies (61) rescued things## and Ian Maciver saw us safely through to a draw on 210-6.

"

High time for a morale-boosting win (we thought). Sunny & warm. Welcome return from injury of Matt Riley & Paul Humphreys## and Ian Davies from hols## to bolster our jittery batting. For a while things went well## and Monks' free-scoring early batsmen were being contained at 77-4 after 22 overs## thanks to tight bowling from Nick Adams & Jack Maciver. Could have been better still if a couple of sharp chances had been grasped. Then S Yacoob decided to change gear and raced to a ton## while wickets fell at the other end.

A total of 210 should have been easily within reach## with 46 overs to get them. Indeed## our score at 22 overs was virtually identical at 79-4## but with Riley and Davies having barely troubled the scorer## and Humphreys out for 20/20-style ""cameo"" (26)## the writing was on the wall. Fally (26 in over an hour) showed commendable tenacity## as did Jack Maciver(18)## but the innings crumbled to 127 all out## and relegation now looks a depressing probability unless our batsmen can find some form.

"

Potten End 235-5 BWCC 175-6On another belter of a wicket at Ballinger the Waggoners bowlers lacked the control to keep the Potten End batsman in check.

With ball swinging around in the humid atmosphere Ballinger's youngsters found it difficult to find the right line. It wasn't until Peter Petrie was introduced into the attack did skipper Kerry finally get some control.Peter's 5 over spell 2-9 followed by an excellent spell of 7-0-32-0 from Jake Cutter meant one end was being tied down. Unfortunately runs were coming at 7+ an over at the over end.

Jack Hankinson's second spell was much better than his first with just 14 runs coming off this 5 overs

Potten suprisingly batted there full 45 overs when an early decleration might have given them more chance to bowl out theyoung Balinger side

Peter Petrie also starred with the bat scoring an excellent 61. He was well supported first by Jack Hankinson(21) and then by the injured Ben Carlin (22).

Ben had damaged his knee whilst fielding which meant he was only able to bowl 5 overs and had to bat with a runner. He was also run out in slightly odd circumstances. He was at the strikers end and having played a shot the non-striker called his runner through for a single. The fielder launched the ball at the 'keeper and Ben had to take evasive action. The keeper removed the bails in his attempt to run out the non- striker but recognised that he was probably in and was somewhat surprised to find the batsman had been given out. Unfortunately in getting ot of the way Ben had moved out of the crease and was given out.

Peter was out shortly after this with score on 120.It was then left to James Stoddart(20*) and skipper Kerry to guide the home side to maximum batting points. Which they achieved## just## off the penultimate ball of their innings.

Another enjoyable game played in the right spirit and the oppo even came for a drink afterwards

The Lee 212 - 8 BWCC 215 - 7

After the disappointments of the narrow loss against Cadmore End and a rained-off match against Waddesdon it was important to get back in to winning ways against The Lee.

The game was played at Missenden's Misfits ground i Little Missenden## a great outfield but a slow pudding-like pitch which meant that anything short sat up and begged to be hit.Winning the toss and fielding first (no surprise there) Ballinger started well thanks to a tight length and line from Andy Thompson and James Stoddart. Two quick wickets## one thanks to a great catch behind by Paul Branigan## and some slow scoring gave encouragement but a determined 3rd wicket partnership helped The Lee steady their ship and they started to score more quickly.

Bowling changes did not really do the trick but a great catch by James Rose at mid off got us back into things and a T. Rix caught and bowled helped. However## it seemed that every poor ball was punished and The Lee's number 4 rode his luck and accelerated## scoring a good 91 supported by various partners## so much so that 110 came off the last 15 overs as The Lee reached a competitive 212-8 off their 45 overs.

A steady reply was what was required and despite losing opener James Stoddart early on Derek Richards & Paul Rose batted sensibly to add 70 for the 2nd wicket. Paul was hampered by another muscle pull (when will he learn to warm up?) necessitating a runner but the good news was that the run rate picked up with James as runner! Derek was out for a well crafted and elegant 38 thereafter Rose and Paul Branigan kept up the good work. When Rose was out for an excellent 47 the run rate was down to just under 6 an over. Tom B departed despite looking good and another 80 was needed off 14 overs. Branigan senior hit well before being caught behind for a timely 44. After which Tim Rix and James Rose nurdled a few and ran as fast as possible keeping the run rate manageable.

When James was caught at point young Ian Stoddart came to the crease but was treated cruelly by Rix who demanded quick singles and quick 3's when young Ian would have rather dealt in 4's## so much so that Ian became the 2nd batter with a pulled calf!

A winning draw was passed and when the 38th over yielded a vital 15 runs we were almost there. A casual flick for 4 from Thompson confirmed the win with 5 balls to spare## Rix the older not out on 37.

Overall a very good result - and after the collective batting failure of the Dad's at Cadmore End the threat of further disciplinary action from Skipper Kerry could be lifted. However the win was tighter than it needed to be due to too many long hops and another batch of shelled catches. We don't half make life hard for ourselves - but a win is a win and it was a good game of cricket.

I wonder if the weather Gods are on our side. A match against the top side and another against our least favoured opponents rained off on consecutive w/es.

Come on chaps you can do it

Hooray - A dry day at last## even though the pitch was very damp and the outfield in front of the pavilion positively swampy. Inserted by Haddenham## our batsmen made slow progress against tight bowling - unsurprising## given the conditions. With commendable application## Paul Humphreys(27)## Richard O'Kelly(unluckily run out for an impressive 20 on his 1st Team debut)## and Fally with a very solid 35##kept the scoreboard ticking over## but with the overs running out Ian Davies ( 24) forced the pace## while wickets fell at the other end. A final total of 145-8 didn't look too great## but the wicket was drying out...

Ian Davies## skippering## decided not to waste a new ball## and entrusted the old one to his spinners## Ian Maciver and Fergus Hardy. An inspired decision## as it turned out## with the Haddenham batsmen all at sea from the very start. Sharing the wickets## as Haddenham tumbled to a miserable 53 all out## Ian took 5-34## and a severely hung over Fergus amazed us (and himself ?)with5-14.

A really good team performance## and an enjoyable game played in the right spirit. Brilliant !!!

Ian and the team would like to thank the ground staff for making sure the match was playable

The 2s had to cool their heels again this w/e when Haddenham had to scratch. 25 points is good news but skipper Kerry needs to bowl a few more overs to ensure he stays at the top of the bowling averages.

For the second week running the 2s had to miss a game because the opposition couldn't raise a team. That's 4 weeks on the trot without a match.

Not sure where that will leave us re promotion but it might mean we're in with a shout.

Our last game is against top of the table Ley Hill who were playing Cadmore End this w/e.At the moment the Hill are 21 points ahead of us and if they beat Cadmore we can all relax. If by some strange event they lost then next weeks game could be important. Lets hope the weather doesn't interfere

BWCC 76 -9 Ley Hill 79 -2

The excitement of getting so close to promotion was too much for the 2s on Saturday.

The numbers were simple## we had to get 25 points and stop the Hill getting 8.The opposition very kindly put us into bat so now it was up to us. We knew the wcket was going to be interesting and with a very slow outfield it was difficult to decide what a winning total would be. Unfortunatley trying to decide was as far as we got. With only Kerry and Thompson getting into double figures Ballingers total of 76 was never going to be enough.Paul Rose being take off to hospital with 2 broken bones in his hand didn't help matters## but the Waggoners had no answer to Thompsons leg-spin and were bowled out in just the 31st over.

Ley Hill's batters took a much more positive approach than Ballinger's had and were soon punishing any lose deliveries. Andy Thompson bowled his usual economic spell and was rewarded with 1 of the 2 wickets to fall. Kerry took the other as a C&B.

.

The Hill were home and dry in just the 21st over and were desereved winners of this match and the league title

It's been a really enjoyable first season and I would like to thank all those who took part. In particular Jon Bryant who has managed to umpire most of the matches. It makes a huge difference to have someone in the white coat each week.

Now we must go away and start plotting next seasons campaign

BWCC 251 -3 Knotty Green 139-10At last Ballinger managed to put together a top batting and bowling performance on the same day

Put into bat by 2nd place Knotty Green the Waggoners batters knew they had to perform to avoid the spectre of relegation. With his season spoilt by injury skipper Riley was please to help Rollo McIntyre put on 35 for the 2nd wicket but with Riley's departure the real fun began. Joined by Ian Davies the 3rd wicket pair put on 194 in only 27 overs. With McIntyre 106no and Davies out for 98 Ballinger finished on 251-3

Now that the Ballinger bowlers had a decent total to work with could they take advantage? The Green batters were moving serenely toward their target until the introduction of Fergus Hardy. Hardy proceeded to produce a master class in off-spin bowling. By the time he had finished his spell (12.4.41.5) he had removed the Greens top 4 batsmen and with Phil Lloyd (9.2.24.1) providing a tight grip at the other end## reduced The Green to 118-6. Jack Maciver continued his fine run in 1s with another 2 wickets## Davies grabbed 1 wicket and Hardy finished a perfect day by running out The Green's last man which left the visitors on 139

An excellent alround performance to finish the league season on and the curry afterwards tasted that much better

"

A glorious sunny day - and the Iconoclasts arrived with only 8 players! Of their three absentees## 2 found the attraction of last-minute tickets to watch the Davis Cup irresistible## and the 3rd was told he had to put up shelves..... After much debate## the teams were ""balanced""## with Jeremy Hunting defecting to the Icons## and their fielders were given a substitute## thus affording extra exercise for the younger BWCC legs.

Batting first## a combination of a slow wicket## grassy outfield and some challenging bowling never let our batting line-up (which included all 3 Macivers) too much freedom. The innings was anchored by a magnificent undefeated ton from Danny Draper## whose return this season from ""semi-retirement"" has been a big bonus. Ian Maciver (21) provided some late fireworks## and we declared on 209-5 off 45 overs.

A tall order for a side with only 9 batsmen## and at 24-3 it looked as if the game would be over disappointingly early. However## Jeremy H had other ideas## and was soon scoring rapidly and cleverly farming the bowling as he steadily ran out of partners. 7th out with 75 (sorry! highest score of his season## but doesn't count in the club averages)## the end came soon after## with the Icons all out 165. Jack Maciver (3-16) and Tom Graham (3-51) were the pick of the bowlers## and the fielding was very sharp."

"

The sun shone (a rarity this ""summer"") for our trip to Stoke Green(Beaconsfield having cancelled on us). Winning the toss## skipper Salisbury opted to bat## and we were soon in trouble with an over-confident Jamie Kellock rapidly holing out. Good knocks from Fally (39) and Rollo (38) soon repaired things## but three wickets went down in the 80's. Then Ollie Richards (82) and Jeremy Hunting(30) ensured that the 5tth wicket did not fall until 177## and we were able to declare on 222-8 off 42 overs.

Stoke Green got off to a good start## putting on 60 for their first wicket. Thereafter the batting looked pretty shaky with Dom Birkby (5-39)bowling extremely well## until Gilham(59)joined opener Bourne(50)and the score had reached 177 before the 8th wicket fell## with the runs flowing as darkness descended.Then Ollie rounded off a fine day with a couple of wickets## and Stoke collapsed to 188 all out.

"

"

Unbeaten since 10th August and with two convincing wins in the last two games## we were confident of finishing the season in fine style against Fulmer## on yet another unbelievably glorious sunny afternoon. We even had 12 players - belatedly only discovered by skipper Salisbury as he went to complete his batting order - so he gallantly stood down. For ""confident"" read ""over-confident"".....Four wicets down for 20 in only the 5th over## our batsmen were rash in their shot selection (and running## Jamie ?). Partial recovery was started by Tom Maw who batted well for 15## and Jeremy Hunting## but both were out with the score at 50. Then Ian Maciver (40) showed the rest what sensible batting could do## ably assisted by Basti who drove Fulmer's bowlers to distraction with an epic hour-long personal best of 21. After Ian unluckily played on## the final total of 129 seemed at least almost respectable.

Unfortunately## Fulmer didn't think so. It took their openers## each of whom made undefeated 50's only 30 overs to put Ballinger's batting - and bowling - into perspective. Enough said. At least the last visit of the season to the Old Swan got off to an early start.....

"

BWCC 170 -8 Holmer Green 139-10

On a beautiful sunny afternoon at Ballinger the Green won the toss and put Ballinger in. Ballinger lost wickets steadily to an accurate and hostile attack## sinking to 55 for 5. But then the middle and lower order staged a steady fight back led by Ian McIver (33*) and a late flourish from Tom Graham (16*)## to ensure Ballinger used all their 45 overs and posted a respectable total of 170 for 8.

Ballinger bowled tightly## opening with a father-son combination of Ian and Jack McIver## with Tom Graham first change. But Holmer Green looked to be heading for an easy victory but then the Waggoners got a bit of luck## to take 2 quick wickets## and put the squeeze on The Green## who crumbled to 139 all out. Ballinger held all our catches and a top spells from Andy Thompson who took 6 for 31 off 8## and Jack McIver with 3-18 were enough to finish Holmer off.

A very good victory
Due to the closeness of the 2 matches v Amersham## it was decided that the result of the Tuesday 12th May match would also decide this Cup Fixture. For a report## please go to May 12th.

A brave young Ballinger team took on the experienced Amersham U11's last night in a League and Cup double-header. Amersham batted first and knocked up a creditable 170-3 with the help of 57 extras! Highlights of our fielding were a great catch by Freddie Sanders from Archie's bowling. Finn Hynes bowled out one of their openers for 1 run## with Max Firth also getting a wicket. Our lads batted out the full 20 overs but were kept to a low score by a tight Amersham field. Lots of work to do. Better luck next time lads!

Having won the toss## Waddesdon elected to bat## perhaps unwisely## but not all of their players had turned up on time. (A lesson to be learned ?) Against a tight opening attack of Tom Graham and Nick Adams their progress was painfully slow## and the pressure was maintained when Rollo McIntyre and Ian Maciver took over. Wickets fell steadily## and Waddesdon only reached a total of 87 in 39 overs. Had butterfingers Ballinger not dropped half a dozen catches## their innings would have been even shorter. Best figures went to Nick (4-23) and Ian (4-25)##but Rollo's 1-13 in 9 overs was remarkable## in that he seldom gets a bowl!

Facing a less than daunting task## Ballinger quickly lost Jamie Kellock## but thereafter Paul Humphreys (40*) and Rollo (42*) cruised to victory in a mere 24 overs.

Maximum points for the second week running## but doubtless much tougher times lie ahead....

Losing the tosss for the opening match of the season on an unseasonably fine and warm afternoon## we were soon put to the sword (not for the first time !)by messrs Cox and Ali## but our bowlers ensured that wickets kept falling## Phil Lloyd (5-21) and Andy Thompson (3-46) being the pick.

Chasing a total of 209 we were given an excellent start by Matt Riley (38) and Paul Humphreys (35)## and we were well up with the run-rate when an injury to Matt## causing him to retire## and a middle order collapse put paid to the chase. Thereafter dour batting by Jamie Kellock and Phil Lloyd endured a draw## closing on 128-6.
Full match report to follow

Sunny & warm## good-looking track## win toss = bat first. Which is exactly what skipper Ian Maciver did. Unfortunately the in-form Paul Humphreys was run out just as he was getting going## but in came the equally in-form Rollo to join Jamie K## and proceeded to blitz the Widmer End attack as he raced to a superb ton. First Jamie (29) and then Andy Thompson (18) lent support## then 2 wickets fell at 187## but Alex Macdonald (36*) and Jack Maciver (27*) took us to a useful total of 238-5. Useful## but given the flat pitch and fast outfield## the fear was that it might not be enough## bearing in mind that in the corresponding match last year## W/End amassed 312-2 !!

238 might have been enough## had Ballinger not replicated last week's abysmal dropped-catch epidemic. Although W/End were always well ahead on run rate## they lost wickets steadily## and at 123-6 in the 25th over it looked like a win## or a winning draw for Ballinger. However## W/End's skipper Degelas had other ideas## and caned our bowlers with 63*## and had the game won in the 43rd over.

All in all## a very good game of cricket## but## for us## the wrong result

Ballinger 244 - 5Chesham 235 - 7Ballinger just pipped Chesham in a really exciting game last night.Ballinger batted first and the opening pair of Jack Peck and Max Firth did a good job until the last 2 balls of the innings when both were out. The next 2 pairs (Jamie Fulcher and Jamie Kingston## Harry Livingstone and Taylor Levitt) moved Ballinger back to over 200. Then Rob Farquhar and Angus DS batted and ran between the wickets really well to put on 20 in their 4 overs. The final pair of skipper Tom Petrie and will Arnold added gloss to the innings with a classy 17.Ballinger then bowled and fielded very well including a couple of good catches. But Chesham kept going and with 3 overs to go they had sneaked 10 runs in front. On came the skipper to ake a vial hat-trick. Another tight over from Max Firth meant Chesham needed 10 off the last over. A 4 of Will Arnolds first ball## followed by a single meant they were within a boundary of Ballinger's score then Will produced a'jaffa' to put the game beyound Chesham's reach. A very enjoyable game played in excellent spirit

Finally## we play one of our older fixtures in glorious weather after 4 years of being rained off! What a game it was## too! A wonderful advertisement for timed games## rather than limited overs. At the start of the last over any one of three results was possible.

Bourne End won the toss and elected to bat## scoring 216-4. They were assisted early on by some dropped catches and ordinary BWCC bowling. However## Ian Maciver (1-10 off 5 overs)## with assistance form Jack Hankinson (2-45) and Jack Maciver applied some brakes## and B/End declared their innings after 36 overs##leaving BWCC with what turned out to be 41 overs to reach this target.

James Wood(16) Phillip Doyle(17)and Jeremy Hunting(27) had good starts## and at 70-1 BWCC looked in good shape. Two wickets in two overs slowed the run rate temporarily.

Enter Fergus Hardy and Will Smith. A stand of 62 was the key partnership of the innings## with Will giving Fergus most of the strike. Fergus made his highest score (and first 50) in senior cricket(56)## hitting cleanly and very responsibly. However## both were out in quick succession. 14 overs left and 6 runs an over needed.

Enter Jack Maciver(29) - again- batting sensibly and not panicking despite losing two more partners and bringing the total needed down to 24 off 4 overs before he was dismissed. Eight wickets down! This dismissal brought Sebastian Richards in to join Ian Maciver.18 runs needed off 3 ## then 15 off 2 overs. Ian hits 8 off the first 2 balls and is bowled next ball. 3 runs needed## 4 balls left. Dot ball## single## dot ball leaves 2 needed off the last ball to win. Only a single - so the scores are level - a just result!

For the second week running BWCC won the toss on a perfect sunny day## and decided to bat on what looked a good Ley Hill wicket. Skipper Matt Riley## back from injury## and Paul Humphreys gave us a bright enough start## putting on 29 for the first wicket in 7 overs. Then the rot set in. Against tight bowling and fielding## our batsmen were tied down## and wickets fell with monotonous regularity. Dogged knocks by Andy Thompson (28 off 65 balls) and Jack Maciver(26)kept the scoreboard ticking## but the last 5 wickets went down for only 28 runs## to leave us with a measly total of 126## and gifting Ley Hill 6 extra overs.

In reply## both Ley Hill openers were dismissed with only 22 on the board - an excellent start for BWCC - but then the catches started to go down - yet again! - and Ley Hill were cruising towards victory with 66 on the board off only 15 overs. At which point the dangerous and experienced Rennard was clean bowled by an exuberant Phil Lloyd. This seemed to induce panic among the following batsmen## and with top-scorer Peterson superbly caught by Ian Maciver 4 runs later## the remaining Ley Hill wickets tumbled in the space of 7 overs## to leave BWCC## amazingly## winners by 22 runs. Star bowlers were Andy Thompson with 4-20## and Phil Lloyd 4-32. Nick Tegg took 3 catches behind the stumps in only his 2nd gamefor the Firsts## and there were smart catches by Matt## and Charlie Wells. Keep it up##boys!

A remarkable turnaround## in a game which had seemed lost from its early stages.

Ballinger arrived at the largest ground around## at Taplow## on a sunny day with the youngest team put out for a long time. Things got tougher before the first ball was bowled## when our keeper/opening bat failed to turn up. Not a good start!

Skipper Salisbury won the toss## and asked Taplow to bat first on one of the best tracks around. When both openers were removed with only 19 on the board## thanks to Nick Adams and Jack Hankinson## the three Ballinger seniors wondered if it was going to be our day. Oh how wrong they were.The next batsmen added 219 runs before normal service was resumed## and wickets started to fall. Taplow eventually finished their innings on 262-8## the wickets being shared between Adams## Jack Hankinson## Richards## Humphreys## Cutter and Matt Rose.

Ballinger's openers Humphreys and Joe Hankinson started the reply## and put on 99 before Joe was bowled by Taplow's first team captain and opening bowler for 8 in an hour and 15 mins.Joe batted beyond his years##and was a valuable ally to Humphreys who was sending the ball to all parts of the ground. Wickets fell at regular intervals## and Humphreys went on to score 133 before he was bowled attempting a pull shot to a ball that rolled along the ground. The remaining batsmen hung around for more than 15 overs## before Richards received an unplayable delivery## giving victory to Taplow by 90 runs with only 9 balls of the game left.

All the juniors performed exceptionally## and are a credit to the Club's Junior Section. They stuck to a hard task in the field## and played the game in excellent fashion.

Some good bowling## in particular Alex Howe (1-13) and Jake Cutter (1-9). Batting was good: Martin 33 retd## Ben Dugdale (31 retd## Webster 24 no## Rice 20. The effort was let down by poor fielding (41 extras!!)which must improve if we are to progress to the true standard of this team and appear at the finals at Stowe

Braddenham 175 - 7 42 OversBWCC 164-9 43 Overs

It was a beautiful afternoon at Ballinger but skiper Kerry was concerned about his 11th man. When he won the toss## which appears almost inevitable these days## was he to field first whilst 1 man short or take the corinthian attitude and bat first on what looked like an excellent track? Could he trust his young bowling attack to stand up and be counted?

As usual he took the negative approach and elected to field

Opening with Tom Sperring and Evan Webster the young Waggoners attack soon got into their stride and with Webster swinging the new ball prodigious amounts and Sperring bowling a tight line they kept the Braddenham batsmen in check

Alex Howe and Matt Rose continued the job then Rob Rose settled into a 10 over spell where he took 2-47. Bastie Richards was his usual economic self with 1-15 off 7 and Jake Cutter finished the job by taking the wicket of the visitors danger man.

Ballinger's fielding and bowling was excellent all afternoon and forced Braddenham to declare at 175 - 7

Last minute substitute## Derek Richards opened the batting with Peter Petrie and they both looked in good 'nick' sadly Peter was undone by an inswinger and Matt Rose followed next ball to a 'jaffa'. Paul Rose## with his new bat## helped Derek add over 40 for the 4th wicket. Then Derek's 1st innings of the season ended with an inglorious swipe but in the mean time he had given the team an excellent platform with his 49 (jug avoidance). Tom Sperring fell to a good catch and Evan Webster## after looking in no trouble## also fell to a wild swipe.The skipper and Bastie then added 50 for the 8th wicket bringing the Waggoners within 13 runs of victory## but with 5 balls left Nigel became a member of the swipers club and left 4 balls for the last 2 batsmen to survive.

At this point parental (Sara) and sibling ( Matt) influence came into play and instead of listening to the instructions from his skipper Rob Rose decided that family ties were more important so ' going for it' was the order of the day. Consequently he became the 2nd member of the Rose family to be out 1st ball.

Fortunately his dismissal meant that Bastie ended on strike and was able to see out the last 3 balls

The average age of the bowling attack was 14 and the skipper was able and happy to let the boys do their job. All the boys need to do now is recognise that batting against adults isn't that hard then we can all rest easy.

We should have won but it was an excellent game enjoyed by all.

Finally## as the skipper tries to learn how to walk again## a plea. Please can all the 'keepers in the club not be away on the same day

A good win## fielding still needs attention (4 dropped catches) Excellent batting and bowling by all. Rice 30 retd no##Dugdale B 21 Dugdale M 19. Owen 3 (wickets) for 1 run off 2 overs## Bailey wicket maiden
A good win## though fielding must improve. Rice 29 no. Bowling shared by all and done well

An unknown opposition## a large ground and a good looking track greeted us at Aylesbury on Saturday and after a win the week before we were keen to add more points.

Batting first a mix up resulted in debutant Ian Hardy being run out## a real shame. Jack Bull got a start but was then out for 11 leaving us at 12-2 and needing consolidation. A good partnership then developed between Petrie and Rix (Snr)## watchfully to start with but then scoring more quickly to the point that after 31 overs we have reached 130. Rix (54) departed and thereafter## instead of building a competitive total## we capitulated in fairly spectacular fashion## all out for 148 in 40.1 overs##

Petrie making a fine 51 but a total that was looked very much on the light side.Quick wickets were required and with openers Tom Sperring and Harry Rix bowling well they both obliged with a wicket apiece and at 15-2 there was every chance that we could force our way back into the match.

Sadly a combination of some hard## adventurous hitting## a pitch that seemed to get better as the afternoon wore on and too many bad balls meant that our total was overhauled quickly with Aylesbury winning by 7 wickets.

T

he positives were some decent fielding and a competitive opening attack but these positives did not make up for some poor stroke decisions and at least 2 bad balls an over.

With that in mind we must learn to be more ruthless## more consistent and a little more positive with our batting.

After a successful first season in the league we wanted to start this term with a win against Prestwood to maintain our development. We fielded a very young (and old) side## with 9 under 16's and no one between the ages of 17-46!

Losing the toss and being inserted was not what we would have chosen and at 10-2 after 10 overs it was clear that someone was going to have to play an anchor innings. Step forward Peter Petrie! Peter batted for the majority of our innings## giving no chances and crafting a well judged 72. It was the backbone of our total as it grew to a very respectable 196-9.

Importantly we also batted our full 45 overs with every batsman contributing around Peter. First Rix (snr) hit a quick 47 before needlessly holing out at long on## then James Rose hit some powerful blows (before needlessly holing out….). Enter Bastie - promoted up the order and boy did he take his chance## hitting a very assured 30 in the partnership that took our total from slightly wobbly to very acceptable.

Time for tea - thanks Veronica! And to plan our attack on the Prestwood batters

.Spoilt for choice with up to 10 bowlers to pick from stand in skipper Rix opted for Ben Carlin and Jack Hankinson to open. After two overs and at 2-2 it was the dream start## a wicket apiece## one thanks to a great catch at square leg by Robert Rose it couldn't get much better could it? In fact it did## with Hankinson taking 3 wickets with some great controlled bowling - late in duckers that the Prestwood batsman just couldn't handle.

Carlin picked up another and it was time for a change. Evan Webster and Bastie took over and we didn't have to wait long for results. Evan was in-swinging the ball a good 4 inches a time which combined with a good length meant that he was a real handful. At the other end Bastie soon settled into a repetitive groove tempting the Prestwood lower order and giving little away.

Wickets fell quickly and after 20 overs the match was won## Prestwood limited to 61 all out and a very impressive winning margin of 135 runs for the 2's.

Special mention must go to Jack Hankinson (3-15) for getting us off to a great start## Evan Webster - also 3-15 for keeping the first change very tight and to Bastie (2-11) and Ben Carlin (2-20). Important mentions too to Robert Rose for two excellent catches and to Jack Bull who kept wicket well despite a swinging ball and little carry.

The recent rule changes also helped. As well as the 25 points for the win we added 3 points for providing an umpire and 1 for a scorer - many thanks to Derek and Roger for umpiring and to Dave Carlin for scoring (job for life there Dave) - those points might well come in very handy.

Well done everyone## an excellent performance by the boys## one that the Prestwood players were quick to congratulate us on. Keep it up!”

Dylan Shellard led his team to a very close defeat at the common last night. After a tight bowling display keeping Wendover down to 119 runs## with Dylan taking 2 wickets## Waggoners looked favourites to win## until a late collapse saw them end up 32 runs short. Highlight of the innings being Dylan with 19 until being finally run out. Good try lads!
Test

The Waggoners 2ndX1 returned to winning ways on Saturday with a comfortable win over Haddenham

Hadenham won the toss and decided to make first use of what was likely to be a slow pitch - it had been under water on Tuesday. Unfortunately they came up against 1st team super star Phil LLoyd making a forced appearance for the 2s.He immediately removed one opener and bowled an intial 6 over spell of 2-9

. This was very fortunate for skipper Richards because at the other end first Tom Sperring ( 1-27) and then Ben Carlin(2-37) decided to test the middle of the pitch. This was much to the liking of the visiting batsmen and reguar excursions were made into the carpark and neighbouring gardens. Fortunately they both sorted themselves out and bowled decent spells.Evan Webster( 1-19) started as the others but adjusted his length quickly.

 

The two spinners Rob Rose (2-42)and Sebastian Richards (1 -28) struggled with their line and length on the slow pitch before Lloyd returned to finish the Haddenham innings on 168.

 

Skipper Richards opened Ballingers innings with Will Smith and##following a sumptious drive and an easy single from Will## Derek decided to leave his first ball - fatally. Kim Hughes went in the next over which brought in-form Peter Petrie to the wicket. After a couple of exploritory swishes Peter set about the Haddenham bowling with relish. In 18 overs he and Will added 109 of which Peter scored an excellent 51.Will(82*)continued on serenely and with help from Paul Brannigan and Ben Carlin guided the Waggoners home to a comfortable win in only the 29th over.

This was a very mature knock from Will and bodes well for his future
