It was a beautiful afternoon at Ballinger## an enjoyable game played in an excellent spirit## a fantastic tea provided by Heidi and a couple of pints to finish with. What more could we ask for.

A perfect sunny day greeted BWCC on their first ever visit to Ibstone's attractive ground. The wicket looked to be a good one## but when Ibstone won the toss and bowled first## Ballinger's batsmen were definitely uncomfortable. A combination of low bounce and accurate bowing meant a run-rate of barely one per over after 14 overs## and both our openers gone.Paul Humphreys and Ian Davies steadied the ship## but with the score on 44 Paul was unluckily bowled## then Rollo went first ball - LBW## one of several apparently harsh decisions. Jack Maciver too perished LBW## and at 61-5 in the 25th over## things were looking distinctly unpromising. However## Ian Davies## back after a 5 week break (in the middle of the season## Ian ? ) was growing in confidence## and with solid support from Jamie Kellock took the score to 143 before Jamie was bowled. Enter Ian Maciver ! Apparently having been inspired by 20/20 heroics elsewhere## he proceeded to smash the Ibstone spinners to all parts## including three 6's off consecutive balls. Ian D finished with a superlative 82*## with Ian M on 41*## and the final score 197-6 - quite an achievement.

Unfortunately## BWCC's bowling and fielding was not in the same class as Ibstone's## with the praiseworthy exception of Jack Maciver## whose two 5 over spells yielded figures of 5-25.. Several fine catches were held## notably two in the deep by Tom Graham## but other## easier## ones went begging.A stand of 97 for the Ibstone 4th wicket left Ballinger facing defeat with the score on 165-4 with only 31 overs gone. Then the batting started to wobble## and Ballinger sniffed a possible upset.With luck it could have happened## but for another dropped catch## and the odd misfield. It was not to be## though## and the tension was over when Ibstoe sneaked home by 2 wickets off the first ball of the last over of the match## to their great delight## as it was their first win in the MBL Premier Division.

This was an excellent game of cricket## played in the right spirit by both sides. Just a pity we lost !!

"

Choosing to bat first against Monks Risborough on a pitch that might (or might not) have been affected by a little overnight rain## with a good deal of cloud cover around## could be deemed a risky gamble. At 30 for 5## the gamble looked a dead loser ! Mark you## at least 30-5 was an improvement on 8 for 3## but even so## Ballinger's batsmen were proving themselves inadequate against a pacy accurate attack which was extracting a degree of lift that they were obviously unused to. Then Monks started spilling catches## and a gritty revival was set in motion by Ian ""lucky x 3"" Davies## partnered first by Alex Macdonald## then Andy Thompson. From 87-7## when Andy went## the remaining batsmen steadily improved the scoreboard## with Macivers## father and son## giving Davies excellent support. When Davies was 9th out with a valiant 43## with the score on 121## a rather inadequate total looked on the cards. Messrs Lloyd and Adams had other ideas## and their last-wicket partnership added 40 invaluable runs befor Nick was bowled for 26.

Given Monks' batting feats against us in the past## the match still looked more likely to be lost than won. However## a combination of fine bowling## especially by Adams## (almost) faultless catching (and when was that last written about Ballinger?)## and some irresponsible slogging by Monks' batsmen when they had all the time in the world to win the match## gave Ballinger the impetus to achieve a 70 run victory in a mere 21 overs. Especially noteworthy were catches by Alex Macdonald and Andy Thompson## plus a stumping by Ian Davies (standing back!). Nick finished with 7 for 47 -after two wicketless matches## it's good to report that the great man is on fire again!!

The pints at the Old Swan afterwards tasted particularly good - now for the league leaders Knotty Green next week....

"

Excellent 30 and 33 retd from Max M and Harry and 16no by Dom## excellent 4-14 bowling by Harry## Josh 2-20##Dom 2-22## Alex 1-24 and Max M 1-17. A good all round display of batting bowling and fielding## well done all.

Frieth 194 - 9 45 overs BWCC 194- 10 40 oversThis is a difficult game to write a sensible report about.

 

Frieth won the toss and chose to bat.

 

Skipper Kerry couldn't believe his luck and with 1st teamer Tom Graham opening the bowling he was quietly confident that tea would be taken early. Unfortunately he hadn't allowed for the vagories of village cricket which meant only 10 players were on view for Ballinger and that Frieth had a batter who had no regard for reputations.

 

Once Tom Sperring had woken up and found the right place to bowl he produced an excellent spell ( 5 overs 3 for 10). Harry Rix followed with 3 -26 and with the two spinners Bastie Richards( 1-44) and Tom Branigan (1 -48)doing their bit it was only the the top man who got a pasting(1 -57).

Ballinger's reply was led by Richard O'Kelly who looked like a man on a mission. His opening partnership with Derek Richards(21) set the tone. Tim Rix( 15) added momentum and Paul Brannigan(46) helped Richard add 65 for the 3rd wicket. With 160 on the board Richard finally fell but with 8 overs left he should have felt his job was done. Unfortunately Tom Sperring fell in the same over followed swiftly by Bastie Richards both first ball. Paul and Tom Graham then put Ballinger within 8 runs of victory but their skipper didn't do his bit and was out with 5 required. Tom then decided that with 2 required he would shoulder arms to a straight ball. Tom Brannigan sneaked a single off the last ball of the penultimate over. 1 to win## Harry Rix on strike## a wild swipe## middle stump out of the ground and victory had been stolen from us

Ties shoul be exciting but when you have lost a game you should have won it's difficult to accept. Still it was fun and a lovely place to play cricket

 

It appears that having 12 on Wednesday is no longer a guide to how many may be playing on Saturday. Therefore Nigel has decided to pick 15 for every game on the basis that he might have 10 by match day

Another toss won## and we elected to bat against top of the league Knotty Green - though had skipper Riley arrived in time## he apparently would have decided otherwise. With the scoreboard showing 33-2 after 20 overs## and having departed for a duck himself## he was doubtless cursing his deputy. However## Knotty Green's opening bowler Widdowson had figures at this stage of 10 overs##7 maidens##6 runs## 1 wicket## and the normally free-scoring Rollo managed one (iffy) scoring shot in the first 47 balls he faced. Paul Humphreys showed what could be done## and had scored 25 of the total of 31 when he was bowled## but in-form Ian Davies was equally shackled for a while. Then a sudden spate of boundaries loosened the bowlers' grip. Rollo started to hit out## with enterprising support in particular from Andy Thompson (29) and Ian Maciver (again !! - 22 off 12 balls). Rollo's 55 was a fine knock in the circumstances## and the final total of 191-9 showed## for the second week running## the value of Ballinger's in-depth batting.

Knotty Green got off to a rapid start## but were three down for 32 in only the 8th over## with Nick Adams and Jack Hankinson among the wickets. There followed a hard hitting stand of 59 for the 4th wicket## and clouds## both imaginary and real threatened Ballinger## as thunder rolled around the ground## and lightning lit up the sky.The rain started## and for a moment it seemed the weather might win## but the elements relented## and once the main partnership was broken## Knotty Green's under-strength side showed little resistance in the face of Phil Lloyd (4-39) and Ian Maciver(3-18)

< A very satisfying win.

BWCC 218-9 Bledlow 188 AO

Ballinger hosted Bledlow on Sunday and after winning the toss elected to bat first. Humphreys and Draper opened but were kept in check by a tight opening spell by both Bledlow bowlers. Humphreys soon departed for 8 and was quickly followed by Kellock who was run out after a 'mix up' with Draper## leaving the score at a precarious 11-2. This meant Will Smith came to the crease and batted beyond his years frustrating the opposition bowlers and dispatching any bad balls. In the meantime Draper was steadily compiling runs and these two put together an excellent stand of 105 for the third wicket which ended only when Smith was caught for 41. Useful contributions were then added from Max Maciver and Jeremy Hunting who both supported Draper## who eventually fell for a patient 94. Will Rawlinson (23*) and Bastie (12) added some late lusty blows as Ballinger closed on 218-9.

With 218 to defend## Ballinger had to bowl well and openers Tom Graham and Jack Hankinson did just that by restricting Bledlow to 46-6 with Graham taking 5-28 off 9 overs. The bowlers were also backed up with some excellent fielding with Paul Humphreys## Tom Maw## Max Maciver and Will Smith all taking fine catches. At this stage Ballinger looked on top## but Bledlow's 7th wicket pair had other ideas as they added 101 which got them back into the match## this was however until Jack Hankinson bowled Downes for 65. One more wicket for Hankinson (3-45 off 11 overs) and a run out later the game was wrapped up for a good 30 run victory.

As everyone knows life is simply a metaphor for cricket. Cricket in April is rarely as wonderful as this. With Ballinger needing 9 off the last over with no wickets left## Bastie and Tom Graham cruised to a win with a single off the last ball. Fifties from Davies and Humphreys thrilled Aldenham village. High drama.
BWCC 215-7 Pelicans 171 AO
BWCC 211-9 Longwick 158-7
BWCC 238-5 Ley Hill 162 AO

BWCC 152 AO Gaddesdon Row 153-8

After Penn Street's cancellation## Gaddesdon Row stepped in to fill the fixture on what looked like a very green pitch. Having lost the toss Ballinger were somewhat unexpectedly asked to bat first but it soon became apparent that runs would be hard to come by.

With Rick Brockett going early## Will Smith and Paul Humphreys consolidated well adding 54 for the 2nd wicket## but both run and over rate were painfully slow. When Will went for 30## no other batsmen showed the necessary patience on an uneven wicket to stay with Humphreys as GR held most of their catches (8 in total). In the end Ballinger were bowled out for 152 in 39 overs in just under 3 hours. Paul Humphreys and extras were the other major scorers with 53 and 38 respectively.

With only 152 to defend Ballinger had to bowl well again and both Jack Hankinson and Dom Birkby had the GR openers in trouble straight away. Dom took the first wicket after a high catch from Tom Maw and at 47-5 Ballinger looked in control## with Birkby taking a further 2 wickets## Humphreys taking 1 and George Kingston taking a good caught and bowled. Only Flynn troubled the scorers by edging his way to 25. However this brought O' Sullivan and Tyne together who both survived a couple of close LBW shouts early on. They put on 59 and suddenly GR were back in the match; however when Humphreys claimed the wicket of O' Sullivan## Tyne and J Woof soon followed leaving a tight finish in prospect. Unfortunately a couple more edges were found which went to the boundary and GR crossed the finishing line with the loss of 8 wickets. Stand out bowlers were Dom Birkby who took a 5 wicket haul on his return and Jack Hankinson who perhaps bowled too well and remained wicketless.

Prestwood 188-6 BWCC 188-7

Skipper Kerry left Prestwood on Saturday with a feeling of another job not properly finished.

Playing the bottom of the league meant that the selction policy had been aimed more towards the youth end of the market rather than the over 50s end. This is fine if you have 11 players on the field but when one of the slightly older members (18) of the side doesn't turn up because he didn't know he'd been picked that makes life a bit harder.Add to that your opening bowler ( Ben Carlin) breaking down in the 3rd over and you definitely have a problem.

All the bowlers gave their best but it was difficult to get fielders in the right position when you weren't quite sure where the batsmen were going to hit the ball## and that had nothng to do with where it pitched.

Evan Webster(10-2-30) and new boy AJ Cooper (12-1-40) were the pick of the bowlers. Rob Rose ( 9-1-39) bowled another tidy spell and Michael Senior added some pace to the attack whilst exploring all areas of the pitch.

Prestwood's opener## Taylor## scored 71 in their 45overs and as he's 62 there's hope for Derek and Nigel yet.

Prestwood ended on 188-6.

With a limited amount of batting it was important tha Ballinger got off to a steady start. Unfortunately Derek Richards decided to see how far away from him the ball needed to be before he could hit straight to point.Jack Bull(13) then joined Will Smith in an enterprising 2nd wicket stand which gave the innings much needed impetous. When he was out out the score was 43 and the Waggoners were up with the run rate.Kerry joined Will Smith at the wicket and with a mixture of luck and skill slowly worked Ballinger into a good position. Will passed 50 for the 2nd match running and had once more shown incredible concentration and much skill##but had he left his skipper with too much to do? 73 off 13 overs was very attainable but how much batting was left? Michael Senior(14) helped add 21 in 5 overs then Bastie Richards and Kerry put on another 39.The pressure was mounting for both sides and with Evan Webster out on 180 in the penultimate over it was all down to the last over

Kerry on strike and 9 required to win. 1st ball big swipe and a miss## 2nd ball big swipe and a miss## 3rd ball proper shot and a 6.3 required of 3 balls and what does Kerry do off the 4th ball? He takes a single.This left Rob Rose on strike with the instruction to run at all costs## unfortunately he hadn't been told he also had to hit the ball. Run out! AJ in his first innings has to score 2 off the last ball to win the game. Sadly he only managed a single and the scores were tied

This Prestwood side were a far better team than we had played against before and although we should have won## there was no disgrace in coming away with a winning draw.

Occupation of joint top-spot in the MBL Premier Division was evidently a step too far for Ballinger's batsmen## and the match at home v Downley saw them tumble back to the real world. Matt Riley won the toss## and decided that our recent performances batting first were good enough for him to repeat the process. Alas## our run-machines Humphreys## McIntyre and Davies all had an off day## and the only bright spots in a rather shabby batting display were Matt himself## who played his way back into form after a very lean spell following his come-back from injury## making an invaluable 67## and a hard-hitting 27 by Tom Graham. We failed to bat out our overs## and the total of 146 was never going to worry Downley## who had 48 overs at their disposal.

Downley's batsmen showed how quick singles can pressurize a fielding side## and although their prolific openers were dismissed relatively cheaply## there was little joy thereafter for Ballinger's bowlers## not helped by some indifferent fielding. A rapid 3rd wicket partnership of 86 destroyed any hopes we might have entertained## and although two wickets fell late on## Downley sailed to 150-4 in only 29 overs.

Ballinger were deservedly beaten by far superior opponents## and need to bounce back quickly from this set-back.

Hyde Heath 213-9 BWCC 170-9

Ballinger made the short trip to Hyde Heath in what was billed as the big game of the weekend## never mind the Lions or Wimbledon## Hyde Heath was the place to be.

The day started well for Ballinger as captain Salisbury won the toss and elected to field. Soon both opening batsmen were back in the pavilion relatively cheaply with both Jack Hankinson and Dom Birkby bowling tightly. However this brought Shrimpton to the crease who mixed attack and defence to good effect and punished anything short or wide. He passed 50 in double quick time and held the Hyde Heath innings together as no other batsmen stayed long enough to form a considerable partnership. New boy Carlton Siddle was the chief destroyer bowled a miserly 11 over spell and taking 3 wickets. In the end Hyde Heath closed on 213-9 off 44 overs. Wickets were shared between Birkby (1)## Hankinson (3)## Siddle (3) and Humphries (2).

After tea the Ballinger reply got of to a great start with the opening pair of Paul Humphries and Will Smith. Both looked at ease on an increasingly friendly batting track and put on 93 for the first wicket before Paul bowled for 53. Unfortunately no one else could get the big score that was required to win the game and when Will was out for 47 it looked like Ballinger would have to settle for the draw## which they duly did ending on 170-9 from 40 overs. Other notable batting contributions came from Kellock (19) and Siddle (13).

In the end both teams played but in the end it would seem a draw was the correct result.

Playing at Holmer Green has never been at the top of Ballinger's wish-list## but for once the pitch behaved itself## which is more than can be said for the opposition's fielders## who seemingly pride themselves on a version of sledging from a few of their senior players## who one might think should know better##that verges on the offensive. That said## Ballingers's batsmen## batting first after losing the toss##spent most of their time ducking and weaving against fast and furious bowling## rather than worrying about the verbals. Openers Riley and Kellock had both departed by the time the score had reached 24 off 10 overs## but then Rollo McIntyre was joined by Ian Davies in an initially nervy but increasingly confident stand of 56 for the 3rd wicket## before Rollo fell for a hard-earned 40. Richard O'Kelly was next in## and helped Ian add 91 for the 4th wicket## before he went for an excellent 34. Ian then upped the tempo and was 83 not out when the 45 overs finished## a match-saving knock one might have hoped## giving us a total of 197-5.

By the time Holmer Green commenced their innings the clouds were threatening## and light drizzle gradually turned heavier## the ball turned into a bar of soap## and our bowlers found nowhere near as much life in the wicket as had the home bowlers. A further disadvantage was an injury to our steadiest bowler## Andy Thompson## which limited him to a mere 4 overs.Two interruptions saw us return in increasingly unpleasant conditions## but the wickets refused to come## a couple of dropped catches not helping. Holmer Green had reached 172 before their second wicket fell## with both K and B King making 50's## and although two more fell in quick succession thereafter## it was too late## and for the second week running we went down by 6 wickets.
BWCC 198-6 Long Marston 199-6

BWCC 228-7 Amersham Hill 228-5

After last weeks no show from the opposition## Ballinger returned to action against Amersham Hill## albeit in a 40 over contest## on what turned out to be a nice sunny day## in complete contrast to the previous day's rainfall.

Surprisingly## the ground had dried out well after the rain and Ballinger won the toss and## as usual## chose to bat first. However## this decision looked questionable as after just 2 overs both openers## Phil Lloyd and Jamie Kellock## had perished for ducks leaving Ballinger 4-2. All was not lost though## as Jamie had immediately worked out that Phil had faced fewer balls## thus avoiding the collection of match fees. Staring down the barrel Ballinger slowly began to rebuild with Paul Humphreys (35) and Jack Maciver pushing the score over 50 with a partnership of 53. Jeremy Hunting (25) and Tom Maw (9) continued the scoring## sharing partnerships of 67 and 37 respectively with Jack. Eventually## he fell for a very well made 79 where he was particularly proficient through the leg side. Late order runs from Graham Salisbury (14)## Nick Tegg (11*) and a blistering 29* from Basty Richards helped Ballinger reach 227-7 from their allotted 40 overs.

In reply## Hill got off to what one might call an eventful start. Opening batsmen## Hedley## firstly called for the miniature sightscreens at each end of the ground to be moved a matter of millimetres and then secondly asked that Ballinger's Jimmy Gibbs be removed from the bowling attack for bowling 2 over head height no-balls. (Strictly true## but not really in the 'Spirit of Sunday Cricket'). This was not the end however## as Hedley was on his way back to the pavilion minutes later after being run out## trying to take on the tracer like arm of Jack Maciver. Meanwhile## a couple of balls later a very confident appeal for caught behind was turned down. And that was all in Jimmy Gibb's first couple of overs! At the other end Jack Maciver was operating less eventfully bowling a fast accurate opening spell applying pressure to the Hill batting line up. Soon enough 2 wickets had been taken## which brought Mackenzie and Telford to the crease. Early on it looked like both men would be dismissed relatively cheaply but as they survived a couple of dropped catches confidence grew## as did a partnership. Eventually## Mackenzie went for a 63 when he was caught low down by Maciver. Telford## though## carried on his more agricultural approach and bludgeoned his way past 50 and beyond## smashing many a ball out of the small ground and into the gardens. Unfortunately for him## he fell just 2 runs short of a quick fire century when bowled by Maciver. Collins soon followed for a duck (again bowled by Maciver) and Ballinger sensed the game was starting to swing back towards them. However## Joseph played a controlled innings of 29* to guide Hill home by 4 wickets## finishing on 228-6.

One might have thought that bottom of the league Waddesdon## on winning the toss on a damp looking wicket at Ballinger## would opt to field first. Instead## they batted## and indeed batted very competently in the face of a Ballinger attack that was rather mundane. It was only by dint of two superlative catches## first by skipper Riley## then by Phil Lloyd## that the first two wickets were taken## by which time the score stood at 118 in the 30th over. Sadly## Phil injured his shoulder in the process## and with Nick Adams already having done his back in## we were short of bowling resources. Fortunately## Ian Maciver (4-49) was bowling well## supported by son Jack## and Andy Thompson (2-16)## himself bowling gingerly after last week's injury## and a target of 180'ish looked likely until an entirely unexpected assault by R Ullah## a teenager who looked much younger than his years and made 20 off only 9 balls.

Ballinger should really not have been troubled in chasing a total of 209 to win. However## Paul Humphreys gifted his wicket wafting at a wide ball. There followed an impressive partnership of 108 between Matt Riley and Rollo McIntyre## and when the latter fell for 68## the score was already 123 in the 29th over## ahead of the game. However## the light was deteriorating steadily## and the troublesome Mr Ullah appeared and proceeded to bowl extremely fast. Rain stopped play after 32 overs with Ballinger on 132## now behind on run-rate. 4 overs were lost## but more importantly so too was our momentum. Wickets fell quickly trying to speed the scoring rate## but with the loss of Riley (59) the task was beyond us## and at 167-8 after 41 overs the rain returned and left us with a very disappointing losing draw.

Winning the toss at Widmer End## skipper Riley lost no time in asking the opposition to bat on a damp looking wicket. His choice soon paid off## as Widmer quickly lost 2 wickets## one apiece to Nick Adams and Phil Lloyd## but then our usual nemesis Mr Degelas took root## and the score had reached 77 before the third wicket fell. Then##hooray## Degelas was bowled by Rollo for 57## following which the remaining batsmen collapsed in spectacular style## with Ian Maciver (6-20) the main destroyer## Rollo bagging 2-16## and the innings was concluded in the 34th over for 106.

Faced with making 107 in 56 overs## Ballinger then proceeded to make thoroughly hard work of the job. Opener Humphreys went early again## for only 5## but Matt Riley and Rollo put on 80 for the second wicket## when Rollo fell for 50## leaving Matt (35 not out in 43.2 overs !) and Ian Davies to finish matters off.

A win that looks good on paper## but achieved with little flair. Still## the points will do nicely...

"

The match started on time## though an ominous weather forecast indicated that play might not last for long. Invited to bat## Ley Hill lost an early wicket to Jack Maciver (whose first 5 over spell yielded 3 maidens## 1 wicket for 2 runs!) The second wicket did not fall until the score stood at 56## shortly after a stoppage for rain## when there was the rare sight of three batsmen bowled playing-on## two of them to consecutive deliveries by our ""born-again"" bowler Rollo. Two more rain breaks## and Ballinger's bowlers were struggling with slippery run-ups and a soggy ball## and did well to get Ley Hill all out for 135## three overs short of the revised 40 overs maximum. Rollo and Ian Maciver each picked up 3 wickets## and Jack Maciver 2.

Tea was taken early in the hope of better weather to come## but the clouds were even more ominous as Ballinger's openers reached the crease. Six overs later## with 13 on the board## rain and murky light drove the players off## and within minutes puddles were spreading across the square.

"

"

Another damp track to contend with## after a wet week## so no surprise that Ballinger were asked to bat first. Matt Riley and Paul Humphreys gave us a good start## with an opening stand of 67## before Paul was bowled for a confident looking 36. Three more wickets went down for the addition of only 20 more runs## and then## with five gone for 106 in the 32nd over## the innings was looking distinctly shaky. Enter Jack Maciver## who calmly kept the scoreboard ticking## while two more wickets fell## ending undefeated with a vital 46 when the overs ran out## and the total stood at 162-7.Probably 25 runs short of a really competitive score## we feared.

The Lee started badly## losing a wicket to Phil Lloyd's second ball. With Jack Maciver bowling as meanly as ever## the scoreboard crept along## but the worry was that we were very short of bowlers## and Paul Humphreys was called up for his first Saturaday bowl of the season. L Rafferty and Jon Swain were both batting with increasing confidence## and had reached 79 before Swain was bowled by Jack## a wicket as vital as his batting earlier. The Lee still appeared confident of victory## but had counted without the notable ""death bowling"" of Ian Maciver## who is making a speciality of inducing batting collapses. None more remarkable than the way he finished off this innings## with 5 wickets in 9 deliveries !!

An extremely satisfying victory against our local rivals by a Ballinger side beset by unavailability of regular players## but grateful for the resources supplied from the Seconds. Thank you## Nigel ! Also a mention for a ""first"" - Matt's three catches - we enjoyed the jug afterwards## thanks Matt.

"

BWCC 222 all out Ibstone 195-9 (all out)

Matches against Ibstone are liable to be high-scoring affairs - the previous fixture was lost by Ballinger defending in vain a total of 197-6## having been invited to bat first## but it was a close-run thing## with Ibstone wobbling badly towards the end of their chase. This Saturday##things went rather differently. Firstly## Ballinger enjoyed their first century opening partnership of the season - Paul Humphreys(60) and Matt Riley (85) putting on 105 together##at a rapid rate of 5 an over## with Humphreys in dominant## if occasionally lucky## form. Thereafter## apart from an attractive cameo 22 from Ian Davies the remaining batsmen all contrived to get themselves out without reaching double figures## whilst Matt held the innings together## being fifth out when the score was 187. Ibstone## fielding only 10 men## held their catches well and fielded impressively## and Ballinger's final total at 45 overs of 222 all out looked vulnerable on a good batting track.

Ibstone set off after their target as if they had a plane to catch. Despite their losing an early wicket to Nick Adams## the score fairly rattled along## with opener Redrup in magnificent form. Unfortunately for Ibstone their early batsmen were simply too impatient## and courtesy of two fine catches by Charlie Wells## they were soon 60-3## but with only 10 overs gone. Ballinger's under-strength bowling was suffering## with Jack Maciver## unusually## having a bad day even though he bagged a couple of wickets. When the next wicket fell Ibstone had reached 157 in a mere 22 overs## and Ballinger were staring down the barrel. But it was the key man Redrup who perished for a superb 121## clean bowled taking an ill-considered swing at a good delivery from Ian Maciver. That proved the turning point. The Ibstone wobble reappeared## and Paul Humphreys (4-38) and Ian Maciver (1-24) took control## with Nick Adams reappearing to finish with 2-44.

Ibstone ended 28 short of their target## and with only 38 overs gone## had they adopted a less cavalier approach## they could surely have made it. A fine win## though## for Ballinger## and one that keeps them hard on the heels of league leaders Knotty Green.

BWCC 187-8Aylesbury 189-5

Skipper Kerry new this was going to be a tough one and it would have helped if he could have won the toss

it would also have helped if he had 11 players. Another avoidable cockup.

None of the batsmen looked in any trouble but against a tight bowling attack on a very good pitch most got themselves out. Will Smith top scored with 34## Nick Tegg(28) ## Jack Hankinson(29)and Ben Carlin( 21)all added valuable runs but 187 was never going to be enough.

Jack Hankinson( 3-43) did his best but with the wicket playing well and the Aylesbury batsmen prepared to chance their arm it didn't take long for them to knock off the runs

BWCC 60- 10 ib 35 oversWaddesden 64-6 in 19 overs

If ever a toss decided a match this was it and skipper Kerry wasn't the most popular member of the team when he informed his team mates that they were batting.

It was dreadful and the home side didn't need the help of some interesting umpiring decisions to make life difficult for the Waggoners. After 16 overs two of the clubs more aggressive batsmen in Peter Petrie and Jeremy Hunting had managed to acquire 27 runs between them. The wicket was drying out and was obviously going to be easier to bat on later but that wasn't any good to us as we all contrived to get out leaving us on only 60.

This was never likely to be enough and a few lust blows from some of the early Waddesden batsmen made it look even easier but the team stuck at it and and managed to get the home side 6 down again with some help from the umpire. Sadly it was all over in the 19th over and the skipper was to blame!

Cadmore End 143 -10BWCC 145 - 4

Having seen the whole square under water on Friday skipper Kerry was keen to win the toss and let the visitors have first go on what could only have been described as a slow wicket. When he lost but the oppo still elected to bat first he had to ask if he'd heard correctly

It was impossible to decide what was going to be a winning score so when the vistors started off at around 3 an over and had posted 50 by the 16th Ballinger weren't sure whether they had control or not. Ben Carlin removed their danger man Dutton and then the first wicket for the 2s for Max Maciver followed by a bizarre run out got Bllinger back in the game. The introduction of Tom McIntyre changed the whole innings. He took 5 - 17 in 5 overs of high quality leg spin. Cadmore were thus bowled out for 143.

Cadmore's bowling was some what eratic and the 23 extras helped

The Lee 164 AO BWCC 138-7

On a day when the construction of the Tower of Pisa began 836 years ago and Edward VII was crowned king of the United Kingdom a mere 107 years ago exactly## Ballinger faced their battle Royale as they played near neighbours## The Lee## for only the third time this weekend (both Saturday teams had done battle the day before). The scene was set and so it started## as The Lee won the toss and chose to bat and bat and bat…

After an intense pre-match warm up## which didn't include 5-a-side football## Ballinger took to the field with a good mix of youthful enthusiasm and experience and no little confidence after the heroics of both Saturday sides the day before. Jack Maciver took the new ball and was right on the money straight away as he started off with 2 maidens; meanwhile## at the other end Tom Maw operated equally efficiently and was soon ripping into The Lee's top order with his pace and steepling bounce. Well## not really. However## his sedate medium pace did cause a few problems and was rewarded with the wickets of Phelps and Channer. Jack kept up his tight line## but unfortunately## remained wicketless from his first 5 over spell. His replacement from the 'White Hut' end was Jamie Kellock## who rolled back the years to bowl a miserly 9 over spell which kept the squeeze on The Lee's score. However## enter P Neal## ex-Hertfordshire captain and apparently the star of The Lee's batting line up. He quickly moved onto 28 and looked likely to help The Lee recover from a shaky start. But he had not counted on a perfectly concocted plan by bowler Kellock and captain Salisbury which put paid to that. A perfectly disguised longhop was creamed straight to short midwicket into the grateful hands of Salisbury (he hasn't dropped a catch in 4 years did you know?). 3 wickets down soon became 4 as that man## Kellock## did it again as Jones was bowled by a ball that sent the leg stump cart wheeling into the next county. Once the medium pacers had had enough## mainly due to tiredness## the spin quartet where brought on to try and tidy up The Lee's lower order. However## father and son combination of John and Julian Swain had other ideas and they steadily accumulated runs. Jake 'little man' Cutter bowled better than his figures suggested but it was Ballinger's very own father and son combination that finished off The Lee. Max Maciver broke the Swain's partnership as he had John Swain caught by resident slip fielder Paul Humphreys. Soon enough father## Ian Maciver## rattled through the lower order which included Julian Swain for a patient 36. With no sign of a declaration in sight Ballinger eventually finished off The Lee for 164## at roughly 5.03PM having bowled 48.1 overs precisely.

After a well needed tea Ballinger set about trying to chase down 164. Usually this would be a score that the home side would be confident of chasing down but a combination of limited overs to do it in and the fact they were 14-3 in the 9th over put paid to this. Young Henry Quinn bowled very well (1-6 off 5) and the slightly older Neal made runs very hard to come by as Ballinger were trying very hard to emulate the success## or lack of it## of the England cricket team. Even the stinging Yorkshire words of Geoffrey Boycott could be heard as star bowlers## Kellock and Maw## were out in quick succession to balls that Boycott's grandmother could have hit with a stick of Rhubarb. Anyway## never fear## Jack Maciver continued his ridiculously good batting form of late and helped add 76 for the 4th wicket before his Dad Ian fell for 37. While Jack made batting look a breeze## further wickets fell with Max Maciver (11)## Salisbury (0) and Richards (0) leaving Ballinger 114-7. However## the injured warrior Jeremy Hunting hobbled out## with the aide of a runner (after pulling a hamstring when fielding)## to mostly pad## and occasionally bat## Ballinger to a well deserved draw. He ended on 6*## Jack on a chanceless 59* and Ballinger on 138-7.

On reflection it was a fair result on another scorching hot day for cricket. The local derby that had been billed by the national papers as 'The Clash of the Titans' had ended in a not so memorable draw## but special mention goes to Jack Maciver who took his tally to 105 undefeated runs for the weekend against The Lee. (That will do his average no harm at all!).

BWCC 159-9 Cublington 120 AO

Exactly a year ago Usain Bolt broke the 100m world record in Beijing; exactly a year later he did it again in Berlin to become the undisputed king of the track. 32 years ago## to the day## Elvis Presley died at his home and was crowded the King of rock and roll. Sunday's match against Cublington gave Ballinger the chance to welcome back two of their very own royals: Will Smith - Prince of Ballinger and Dom Birkby - King of the no-ball. Anyway## onto the match. After both Saturday sides won## the pressure was on to make it a perfect 3 and this duly occurred when Ballinger recorded an ultimately comfortable 39 run victory.

Winning the toss## Ballinger had no hesitation in batting first on a wicket that looked as green as the outfield but defied its initial inspection to play consistently throughout the match. The little and large combination of Prince Will and Paul Humphreys opened up for Ballinger and initially runs were hard to come by as Cublington's opening bowlers bowled generally a tight line. At 20-0## just as Humphreys was beginning to get into his stride## he was adjudged LBW for 11 after a slow death that Rudi Koertzen would have been proud of. Things did not get much better as 20-1 soon became 32-2 and then 42-3 as the well-oiled Ballinger machine began to splutter along as Jack Maciver (10) and Fally (3) fell quickly. Some partial relief then followed as Jeremy Hunting (6) and Prince Will shared a partnership of 26 but when Jeremy was out at 68-4 Ballinger were staring right down the barrel. Joining Prince Will at the crease was Tom Maw and these two steadily went about trying to re-build the innings. Prince Will was batting very sensibly and showed what could be done with a bit of patience and soon enough brought up a very well deserved 50## though not before he hit his first 6 in senior cricket. Those that have batted with the diminutive right hander will know that his life long ambition is to hit a straight six## unfortunately for him it was not a straight hit but one that went sailing over square leg## but they all count. Whilst Will went past 50## Tom Maw supported him and hit a couple of lusty blows in his patient 24 before they both perished trying to go for one big shot too many. However## 62 were added for the 5th wicket and at 130-5 the platform was set for some late order impetus. Unfortunately## this did not really materialise as only Mr No-Ball himself## Dom Birkby## got into double figures with a very useful 16* allowing Ballinger to declare on 159-9. Credit must go to Cublington who managed to bowl 46 overs in the allotted time.

After tea## Cublington seemed confident of chasing down the Ballinger total as the pitch was still in good condition. And at first the Cublington freight train was steaming along as openers P Orchard and Burton rattled along dispatching the bowling all around the ground. Once Orchard was out## (to Birkby for 4)## wickets started to fall at regular intervals as the Cublington freight train started to hit the buffers## though at 72-2 they were still in with more than a chance. However## the decision by stand-in skipper Ian Maciver to bring on Humphreys from the 'football ground' end perhaps changed the course of the match. His 4 over spell claimed the vital wickets of Burton## for a stylish 46## Mitchell and Farr leaving Cublington teetering on the brink at 96-7. At this point the spin twins of Max Maciver and Basty Richards were brought on and both showed considerable control and guile in the face of older opposition## slowing the freight train almost to a stop. Max's first over was tight as ever while Basty's shall now be christened 'Basty's magical over'. With one over to go before drinks Waugh was the batsman and Richards the bowler. This was not a West Indies vs. Australia match of yesteryear and nor was it at the MCG or Antigua## but Basty bamboozled the batsmen showing the sort of form that bagged him thousands of wickets last year. With 2 balls of the over remaining## the batsmen feigned to charge down the wicket## undeterred Basty bowled a ball of good line and length and induced Waugh into another false stroke but this time it was a top edge straight into the reliable hands of Nick Tegg at gully. The double figure crowd were in raptures! And to top things off## the batsman's follow through resulted in the bat crashing into his head - that is why helmets are useful. Meanwhile at the other end Max toiled away with absolutely no luck whatsoever## with the ball missing bat## pad and stumps by centimetres on numerous occasions and he certainly deserved better figures than 1-14 off 8 overs. 23 were added for the 8th wicket as Squires and Barker delayed the inevitable but as soon as Max trapped Barker in front for 19 the game was over as Basty polished off the Cublington lower order## the final wicket being that of P China who tried to smash the ball to China but only ended up offering up a chance for Fally to show us his rather good juggling skills before finally grabbing hold of the ball on about the 12th attempt.

Overall another satisfying performance with everybody in the team contributing. Brief mentions go to Rick Brockett who kept tidily and Dom Birkby who bowled well to collect 3 wickets on his brief return to Ballinger before going on holiday and missing more games. I doubt we'll see him again. Lets hope this good run of form continues next week as we visit Little Gaddesdon.

"

Monks Risborough 148 BWCC 87

Another toss won by BWCC## on a gloriously warm## sunny afternnon## and skipper Ian Davies asked lowly Monks Risborough to take first knock on a green-looking strip## although he must have feared what their famously aggressive batsmen might do to a bowling line-up missing the Macivers amongst other regulars.But as his batting was equally denuded## it was a risk worth taking. As things turned out## the Ballinger bowlers did a good job in restricting Monks to 148 all out in 42 overs## with Ian Davies## surrendering the gloves to Richard O'Kelly## taking 4-32## and Tom Graham mopping up the tail with 3-27. Ballinger excelled in the field## with some smart catches## notably a blinder by Tom Maw##and a neat stumping by O'Kelly (should have been two## rumour has it !)

After a lonely tea break (the opposition being absent due to the rigours of their Ramadan fast)## Ballinger's batsmen set about what should have been a very feasible target## with 48 overs in hand. Sadly## Monks' bowlers had other ideas## and were far too penetrative for Ballinger's flimsy efforts. Both our ""bankers"" ## Paul Humphreys and Ian Davies perished rapidly## and although Richard O'Kelly hung on in for nearly an hour for 8## no-one else looked like getting on top of the bowling until a spirited last wicket stand of 30 between 13 year old debutant Josh Livingstone## who made a very assured 22 not out## and Nick Adams (14). 87 all out in 41 overs was a pretty lamentable effort for runners-up hopefuls versus relegation candidates. But that's cricket. Hopefully the return of some of our absentees will give the side more success in the final league match## against leaders Knotty Green.

"

Frieth 181-10BWCC 111 -10

A beautiful day and it looked like it was going to be hot but skipper Kerry wasn't sure about the pitch so## now he was back into the groove of winnning the toss## asked Frieth to have a bat

The Tom and Harry show did us proud by only conceding 30 runs between them in their 11 overs with Tom picking up the one wicket. Evan then bowled a tight spell of five overs during which he had to endure the umpire giving wides against him him then explaining what Evan was doing wrong.Tim got in a cheeky 3 overs 1-17 but it was good to see Batsie back to his wicket taking best. 4-55 was a fair reflection but most concerning was the amount of turn he was getting. - They thought they had problems at the Oval.

Hary Bartlett bowled with a really bad back and only took 2 wickets in his 6 overs but once again the star of the show was 'Full Toss' Rose. His double act with Bastie at short fine leg was too much for the opposition and they subsided to just 181

Derek and Harry set off in hot pursuit but it soon became apparent that the wicket was going to be too slow to make run scoring easy.Harry's demise with the score on 32 opened the flood gates and only a bit of a flurry from the tail gave any respectability to the score.

It appears that a team consisting of 3 adults and 8 boys isn't going to be strong enough to win matches at this level - at the moment. Another year down the line all the boys who have played this year wil have gained enough experience to move the side forward next year.

The Lee 213-8BWCC 132 -8

This was always going to be a difficult one with only three adults in the side and so it proved.

The Lee batted first and were soon rattling along at nearly 6 an over. The introduction of Rob Rose( 1-32)brought som sense to the carnage but it wasn't until Tom McIntyre got into the action did Ballinger get any control over things. His 4-40 was another excellent spell of leg spin. Unfortunately by this time The Lee were on their way to a decent score finishing on 213 in their 45 overs.

In reply The Waggoners were laways going to be up against it wit only 3 adults in the side. Derek Richards(31) and Paul Rose ( 49) did their best but both were out to the wiles of Guy Morgan.

By the 31st over Ballinger were 8 down and looking down the barrel but Evan and Rob Rose managed to frustrate the visitors by batting for the last 9 overs and thus earning a draw.

A miss match in terms of the score but all the boys did well again

BWCC 194-8 Little Gaddesdon 156AO

With considerable pressure to produce a literary masterpiece## the writer has found it a little difficult to write anything of substance this week## but here goes...

With the Battle of Stalingrad (1942) and the liberation of Kharkov (1943) and Marseille (1944) occurring on this day in history## Ballinger had their own chance to write themselves into the history book as the well-oiled Ballinger machine commenced battle against the 'Gaddenaut'. This was the definition of an unstoppable force meeting an immovable object## and as Murray Walker once said “you could cut the tension with a cricket stump”.

The scene was set: pitch marked out## boundary freshly painted and the opposition warming up (surely not)## but the only problem was that Ballinger had 8 players at 1.50. Finally## with a minute before the scheduled start## Ballinger had 10 players. So now for the 11th… a quick glance at the team sheet led captain Salisbury to realise he would be a man short as an administrative error back at the Ballinger Common stadium had cruelly robbed us of our extra man. Never mind## the game got under way in glorious conditions on what was a perfect day for cricket as the sun was out in a cloudless sky and the pleasant surroundings of the Chilterns provided the back drop. In between the merciless slaying of the Aussies by the English on good old TMS and the occasional complaints from Will Smith at having to bat at No. 3 rather than opening## their was actually a game of cricket going on (who would have thought it?). In form Paul Humphreys and the less in form Jamie Kellock opened up for Ballinger and found the pitch very much to their liking## a batsmen's paradise some might say. Paul was quickly into his stride and looked comfortable while Jamie was less so## although his first scoring shot was a 6. With early nerves dispersed both Paul and Jamie used the massive outfield to full extent and you could have been forgiven for thinking there were two cheetahs running between the wickets as they dispelled any myths about not running 3s## as they did so on 3 separate occasions. This deserves to be repeated for emphasis## PAUL AND JAMIE RAN THREE 3S! They pushed the score onto 116-0## until Jamie (43) holed out to part time wicket keeper/off spinner Odera and soon after Paul followed in similar fashion for 67## being caught at mid on. Will Smith was then the mainstay of the innings with a pugnacious 36## which included loitering outside his crease and tempting the Little Gaddesdon fielders to try and run him out## whilst collecting overthrows when the throws missed! Tom Maw was the next highest with a superb 8* which included a run 4. After 44 overs Ballinger closed on 194-8 and looked forward to what Gaddesdon call 'The Best Teas in The LeagueTM'. They did not disappoint and Ballinger took to the field a little fuller than one would expect of a professional and elite unit such as Ballinger.

With a decent total to defend and a large outfield## Ballinger's youthful side looked to finish the game before bedtime## and they had a dream start. Jack Hankinson bowled Lupton second ball and then proceeded to terrify one batsman so much that in an attempt to get off strike he ran out his partner. At this stage the rose garden looked… well## rosy but soon enough Marriot and Hodge began to rebuild. As Marriot began to cut loose## Tom Maw smashed his leg stump bail into oblivion and he was on his was for a quick fire 25. This brought Odera to the crease and he made his intentions clear straight away## smashing Rob Rose and Josh Livingstone for some streaky boundaries. The runs kept coming as the ball narrowly avoided any fielder on an increasingly annoying number of occasions. With both batsmen surviving close LBW shouts and the score rattling along## their was only one man to turn to## the old pro Paul Humphreys. Like last week## he turned the game in his 6 over spell as 2 key wickets were taken## including that of the increasingly confident Odera who made a very useful 33. Six wickets down## Little Gaddesdon were by no means out of the game but the combination of Ballinger fielding like Hyenas looking for a kill and Paul Humphreys leaping like a salmon to catch Hodge for 59## the game began to look like a formality. It was duly finished off by Jack Hankinson in the most spectacular way by taking a hat trick (to end with a 5-fer)## although you wouldn't have known it by the muted celebration! So there we have it## the Ballinger machine rolls on with another win and hopefully this will continue next Sunday away at Wendover.

With everyone retiring to the bar## all that is left to be said is that the game was an enjoyable one## played in the right spirit against very amicable opposition. So therefore## it is very apt to finish this report by quoting English poet Edmund Blunden who once said## “cricket to us was more than play## it was worship in the summer sun.”

Haddenham 161-10Ballinger 165 -4

Ballinger 2s had a comfortable win over lowly Haddenham on Saturday. Skipper Kerry finally managed to win the toss and sent Haddenham into bat. A strong wind made life difficult for opening bowlers Tom Sperring and Josh Livingstone and Haddenham got off to a good start. The introduction of Peter Petrie and then Josh changing ends reduced the run rate and Josh finally sent back Haddenham opener Pawsley.

Max Maciver ( 4-36) was then brought into action and immediately changed the course of the game. Using the wind cleverly he soon had the home team batsmen in a spin and with Bastie Richards bowling well at the other and Ballinger took control of the game. The introduction of Rob Rose(3-29) also brought success## including the stumping by Will Smith of their skipper McArren who had scored and interesting 57## and with new boy Bartlett cleaning up the tail Haddenham were bowled out for 161.

Ballinger openers Derek Richards and Will Smith(25) set off at a good pace putting on 60 for the 1st wicket. Max Maciver went cheaply(15) but Harry Bartlett(38) and Derek soon settled the game with a 79 run partnership in just 16 overs. Harry was out to an incredible catch and Tim Rix had to collect the money following his 3rd ball duck. Meanwhile Derek continued serenely on taking his score to 68no as the Waggoners sauntered home in the 36th over

BWCC 235-9 Knotty Green 136 AO

127 years ago the defeat of England by Australia at The Oval led to the formation of the Ashes cricket series which is recognised by some## but not all## as the battle for the No.1 test side in the world. 127 years on from that day Ballinger hosted Knotty Green as the top 2 sides in the league met in the last league match of the season to battle it out for bragging rights## but not much more## as league positions had already been decided with Knotty Green being declared champions last weekend. With second place secure## Ballinger looked to finish a good season on a high and this duly occurred with a comprehensive 99 run victory over a Knotty Green side that weren't taking the game quite so seriously.

Winning the toss## captain Ian Davies opted to bat first and opened up with Paul Humphreys and Richard O'Kelly. They were soon into their stride as Paul especially ripped into the bowling## cutting majestically and driving with aplomb. At the other end Richard seemed happy to play the supporting role but both kept the scoreboard ticking over. The 100 partnership was brought up in the 19th over## but only one over later the first wicket fell as Richard was caught for a tenacious 38. 31 runs later Paul was on his way back to the pavilion after counting his way to 85 and in the process achieved 1000 runs for the season. Rollo then followed for 11 after Irvine nonchalantly caught him one handed and it looked like Ballinger's blistering start may be wasted; however## enter Ian Davies and Andy Thompson## these two added 42 in decent time establishing Ballinger's early dominance. When Ian (26) and Andy (9) departed## Jamie Kellock and Tom Maw helped keep the score moving but it was the late innings impetus from Ian Maciver and Phil Lloyd that really pushed Ballinger to a very competitive score## the last 4 overs yielding a massive 52 runs! Ian finished on 24* off 7 balls## including a 6 that ricocheted off a nice shiny BMW leaving a dent for the returning wedding-goers## and Phil who was bowled for 12 having smeared the league's leading wicket taker## Widdowson## for 2 mammoth sixes back over the bowler's head. Never has such fury been unleashed on a cricket ball in the history of the game. Irvine's bowling was particularly savaged as his 2 overs went for 34 runs## although he did pick up the prized wicket of Kellock.

A typically good Ballinger tea followed## which this week was provided by Rollo who took the meaning of 'freshly prepared' to the next level by making the sandwiches just before play started. After tea## Ballinger took to the field hoping to replicate the bowling performance of last year's home match against Knotty Green (which incidentally was the last match of the season) where the opposition were bowled out for 139. However## it soon became apparent that they would be helped in this task as Knotty had reversed their batting order. As a result## wickets fell at regular intervals as the lower order batsmen could not handle the fearsome Ballinger attack## with Jack Maciver picking up 3 wickets in his first spell and the irrepressible Phil Lloyd getting 2## one of which## a catch by Jack Maciver which looked about 10 times harder than it should have been## although it would have looked good had the Sky cameras been there. With Jack having bowled his ECB allocation of 5 overs## this brought Andy 'Thommo' Thompson on from the 'football pitch' end and he proceeded to bowl with pace and verve that would have put his namesake Jeff to shame. After three overs he had 3 wickets for no runs and although he did eventually concede some runs## this spell turned the match firmly into Ballinger's grasp## with top order batsmen Widdowson and Mahmood## No.8 and 10 respectively## being two of Thommo's victims. At this stage 9 wickets had fallen with 79 on the board## and Ballinger were as hungry as piranhas in a meat shop to wrap up the win. However## usual opener Hill and Bartlett had other ideas and showed some late resistance that was lacking earlier on as many a batsman got out trying to score off every ball. Patience was the name of the game and with 57 added for the 10th wicket Ballinger superstar Jack Maciver finally bowled Bartlett via an inside edge for 42 to finish things off## with Knotty Green bowled out for 136 in a match that virtually mirrored last year's clash.

Overall## Ballinger produced a thoroughly professional performance with plenty of energy that befitted the day when Michael Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction 178 years previous. Although Ballinger won the match very little changed in terms of standings as Knotty Green became champions of the Kookaburra Mid Bucks Premier League for the first time and Ballinger secured second place for only the second time. Throughout the season Knotty Green have undoubtedly been the most consistent (and friendliest) side and deserve to have won the league## and although we may look at missed opportunities second place must not be scoffed at. Plus we (may) get a medal to boot. Happy days!

BWCC 200-8 Wendover 201-3

In recent times## matches against Wendover have usually been close affairs## but ones in which that Ballinger have eventually come out on top## but Sunday was a different story as they crashed and burned to a 7 wicket defeat.

After many years of playing Wendover at home due to problems with their Ellesborough ground and its proximity to both the Aylesbury bypass and train line## it was a bit of a novelty to play away## and like the space shuttle Discovery taking off on its maiden voyage on this day in 1984## for many of the Ballinger team it was the first time they had played at the ground. Upon arrival## the distinctive hum of the power lines could be heard and this was supplemented by the occasional passing of a car or indeed a train. Furthermore## for the second week running an administrative error back at the Ballinger Common Stadium had left us with 12 players although this was settled quickly enough.

With 11 players the cricket could begin as we grudgingly decided to play a 40 over shoot out. Stand-in skipper Jeremy Hunting## on his comeback from injury## won the toss and chose to bat first on a decidedly dodgy looking wicket with the sunny delights of Saturday long gone as the sun and blue sky was replaced by a blanket of watery-grey cloud. Whether or not this affected the Ballinger batsmen## who knows## but they did not get off to the greatest of starts. 1000 run man## Paul Humphreys## perished in the second over and 500 run boy Will Smith didn't fair much better## being trapped in front for 7. Jack Maciver showed what some application could do for a well made 20## but when he was caught and then Jeremy was bowled in quick succession## Ballinger were once again staring down the barrel (it seems this phrase is used nearly every week) at 35-4## and things could have been much worse as Ian Maciver clipped a ball straight to midwicket## when he hadn't scored## but thankfully the chance was put down. So with 4 wickets down for 35 runs in the 15th over a period of rebuilding was necessary. Ian Maciver continued his form with the bat## mixing defence with attack while Tom Maw displayed considerable patience to play the supporting role. Slowly## but surely these two began to pull Ballinger out of the mire with the 50 coming up in the 18th over. As the partnership grew the run rate increased with Ian particularly brutal off the back foot and using the large outfield to good effect to bring up his 50. Eventually## when he was on 62 and the score on 128## the partnership of 93 was broken as Ian was bowled by Seabrook after attempting to hit another boundary. A key feature of the partnership was the running between the wickets with the pair running seven 3s and one 4! Joining Tom then was Rob McIntyre and again a very useful partnership of 59 was added with both players taking a liking for the leg side displaying some shots that wouldn't have looked out of place on a hockey pitch. When Rob departed for a hard hitting 26## a score of 200 was on the cards and this is what Ballinger finished on exactly## an excellent effort considering the predicament earlier in the innings with Tom (54*) scoring his maiden Ballinger 50 - a performance most definitely put down to getting in at 1am after the curry the night before. For Wendover## Burns was the standout bowler with 8 overs for 19 picking up 4 wickets.

Following another excellent tea## Wendover seemed confident in chasing down the total on what they thought was a batting track. The fearsome Ballinger opening bowlers## Jack Maciver and Jack Hankinson## found the going tough early on as the Wendover batsmen started off in what can only be called cavalier fashion## although Hankinson took the first wicket of Hazelbrook for a rapid 22. With the run rate well above the required rate## the old pro Paul Humphrey was once again called upon to make the difference. Unfortunately## his bowling was treated equally disdainfully and the ball was disappearing to the boundary too often for Ballinger's liking## although their was many a time when the ball would land in front## behind or to the side of a fielder but never actually go to them. Very frustrating. Anyway## Green and Heffard continued their carefree batting## swiping the ball on numerous occasions to and over the boundary and although Max Maciver and Tom McIntyre bowled well neither could get that important breakthrough. So with the smell of victory in the air## Wendover captain## Green## was told he was only 4 runs away from his century and so refused a single off the returning Hankinson so he could hit the winning boundary and wrap up a century. However next ball his leg stump was ripped out and it turned out his teammates were having a bit of fun and Green departed for 75! 2 wickets down became 3 down next ball## as middle stump was ripped out this time and Ballinger thought they were back in with a chance. Crowding the bat to prevent those precious last few runs Heffard smeared one over point to wrap up the win and finish on 82*.

Overall## it was a disappointing result but## as usual## it was a game played in very good spirit against decent opposition. Maybe we should have looked at the weather before the match as it seemed to be a metaphor for our performance## gloomy for the most part with a couple of bright spots. Anyway## onto next week## away at Chesham Bois## and hopefully a return to winning ways for the Ballinger machine. Anyone fancy a curry Saturday night?!

BWCC 253-5 Chesham Bois 157-7

Rollo's grand day out

The onset of September usually signals the beginning of the end of the cricket season for Ballinger and with only 3 matches left after this one the cut-throat world of selection reared its ugly head as plenty of money changed hands during the week as adults and children alike vied for that all important spot among the elite of Ballinger's Sunday side. As it was## a strong Ballinger side made the short journey to Chesham Bois to attempt to continue their imperious form that has seen the likes of Bledlow and Cublington been savaged by the Ballinger machine.

With the tree-lined surroundings providing the back drop and the sun occasionally squeezing through the branches to scatter some sort of sunlight on the outfield## el capitano Tom Maw## won the toss and decided to have a bat on what looked to be a decent batting track. Opening the batting for Ballinger was Matt Riley and club pro Paul Humphreys. After a rather circumspect start with Matt playing out a maiden## the second over brought drama. O'Brian's 4th ball swung down the leg side with Humphreys attempting to play the ball down to fine leg for it only to end up in the wicket keepers gloves. A muted appeal then followed as did the dreaded finger of doom## consigning Paul to another week before another attempt to break the record for runs scored in a season. It is not for me to say whether it was out or not## but let's just say Paul was not too happy. Furthermore## there have been reports that current record holder## Danny Draper## was seen to be hiding in the trees surrounding the ground at the time of the dismissal prompting suspicions of serious foul play. An internal investigation has been launched. Anyway## back to cricketing matters## joining Matt at the crease was Rollo McIntyre-Hunting and both soon got into their stride with Rollo especially playing with considerable authority. With each bad ball being ruthlessly dispatched to or over the boundary Ballinger rattled along at a good rate as the 100 partnership was brought up in the 19th over. The mix of Rollo's flamboyance and Matt's obduracy proved to be a perfect partnership## but unfortunately## all good things must come to an end## as the partnership of 115 was broken when Matt was caught for a well made 54. This brought Ian Maciver to the crease and he helped Rollo add 37 for the third wicket in double quick time until he took one swipe too many at Holloway's bowling and was bowled for 8. Will Smith then kept Rollo company for a while until he was caught. Tom Maw then swiftly followed as seeing Paul's anguish at getting out## played a captain's innings to relieve him of collecting duties by getting out to the worst shot in cricketing history as a full toss## which Geoffrey Boycott's grandmother could have hit for six with a stick of rhubarb no less## was tamely hit back to the bowler for a caught and bowled. This dismissal paved the way for Max Maciver to support Rollo McIntyre-Hunting to blast the Chesham Bois bowlers around the park and occasionally into orbit. Soon enough Rollo passed 100 for the second time this season and really began to cut loose with the ball often looking like a dot on the horizon as it disappeared out of the ground. This was not the end## though## as the last couple of overs received particularly brutal treatment. 40 runs were plundered off the last 2 overs as such savagery has not been seen since the publication of William Golding's 'Lord of the Flies'. Eventually Ballinger finished on 253-5 off 37 overs with Rollo McIntyre-Hunting finishing on 148*## a new club record## (of which 130 came in boundaries: 22 fours 7 sixes)## and Max Maciver on a very good supporting 23*. For Chesham Bois## Holloway was the stand out bowler with 4 wickets and Hinks bowled economically as ever.

After tea the Chesham Bois response began at a rapid rate with 25 coming off the first 2 overs## but as the Ballinger opening bowlers## Nick Adams and Tom Graham## began to find their rhythm the run rate was strangled considerably although no breakthrough came until the score had reached 66. Change bowlers Ian and Max Maciver both bowled very tidily and slowly but surely started to chip away at the Chesham Bois batting order. Clark was trapped in front for a breezy 35 and when Ian picked up his second wicket## that of J O'Brian for 4## Ballinger were back in the hunt. Max soon followed his father's footsteps as he too got in on the act by picking up 2 wickets## the opener Withams for a patient 27 and Kitching for no score## both caught by the strategically placed Nick Adams and Ian Maciver respectively. With Ballinger bowling and fielding well## none more so than Paul Humphreys who prowled the cover boundary with particular enthusiasm and vigour## a positive result looked on the cards. However## they did not bank on stonewall Holloway leading his side to a draw. Although Max continued to toil away with little luck## Alex Howe bowling an excellent ECB restricted 4 over spell where he picked up 2 wickets and the old pro remaining wicketless## Ballinger could not press home their advantage fully (even with 10 players around the bat) and although Nick Adams took another wicket to set up a potentially close finish Chesham Bois saw off the remaining overs with little fuss and therefore## finishing the match on 157-7 off 42 overs with Holloway making 45*.

So as another match passes and the end of season draws even closer## Ballinger can probably reflect on this match as a missed opportunity but it was a decent game with the major highlight being Rollo McIntyre's majestic and magical 148 not out. Chesham Bois proved to amicable hosts and although the result was not perfect it was good to bounce back after last week's loss. Next week Ballinger visit pastures new as they travel to Jordan Taverners and rumour has it they provide food after the match. I'm looking forward to it already!

Disclaimer: The views expressed in this report are that of the author and not of the club. Any offence caused is purely accidental and intended for comical effect only.

BWCC 207-9 Jordans Taverners 171-9

In 1922 the Great Fire of Smyrna marked the beginning of the end of the Greco-Turkish War. In 2009 Ballinger's match away at Jordans Taverners marked the beginning of the end of the 2009 season as for the first time the start was brought forward by an hour to 1 o'clock. With Ballinger putting out one of the strongest Sunday sides## possibly in world cricket## Jordans Taverners eventually succumbed to a 37 run defeat that perhaps was much closer than it should have been.

On a rather overcast Sunday afternoon visited Seer Green for the first time to play Jordans Taverners and having lost the toss Ballinger were put in on a pitch that looked like it would deteriorate as the game went on. With the Ballinger line up providing a plethora of riches## the capacity crowd were expecting something special in this 40 over shoot out especially after last weeks fun and fireworks at Chesham bois. Opening up for Ballinger were Matt Riley and Paul Humphreys and the Ballinger innings really set off at break neck speed. 0-0 after 2 overs: tremendous stuff. However runs were gradually accumulated on a tricky pitch and the 50 partnership came up in the 14th over as the run rate began to crawl above 3 an over. Unfortunately record hunter Paul Humphreys was first to go for 31## bowled by Paine## most certainly put off by Danny Draper's appearance behind the bowlers arm. This paved the way for the newly crowned King Rollo and scorer of thousands of runs last weekend to enter the fray much to the joy of the crowd who anticipated another innings of flamboyance and ferocity. It all looked well as his first scoring shot was a 6 but then the unthinkable happened with Rollo bowling bowled for 6and the score on 73. Richard O'Kelly then helped Matt consolidate and slowly but surely the run rate was dragged up with the 3rd wicket partnership reaching 62 until Matt went for a patient 55## an innings that suited the perilous situation that faced Ballinger and which provided a foil for Richard to play his shots. Eventually he then went for a stylish 46 and at 154-4 the platform was set for Ballinger to reach 200. This was indeed exceeded as Jamie Kellock (19) and Nick Adams (16*)## along with extras and dropped catches (which were cruelly laughed at by Mr. Chairman)## helped accelerate the scoring rate with Ballinger eventually finishing on a rather good total of 207-9## a much higher score than initial estimates had forecasted.

There is one glaring omission from the Ballinger first innings that I have not included though as it deserves its own paragraph. For many years coaches have gone on about how aggressive running between the wickets puts pressure on the fielding side## well there was no better example when openers Paul Humphreys and Matt Riley completed an all run 4## the crowd could not believe it and to top it off there was no dive sight!

After tea Jordans had the unenviable task of chasing down the target of 207 on an increasingly bowler friendly pitch. Ballinger opening bowlers Jack Maciver and Andy Thompson kept it tight early on and Andy was soon rewarded with the wicket of Leybourne. However it was only after the introduction of Nick Adams and Ian Maciver that the reigns really began to be pulled in and Jordans reply started to hit the buffers. A miserly 8 over spell from Nick ripped the heart out of the Jordans middle order## yielded only 15 runs and 3 wickets while Ian unluckily remained wicketless conceding only 17 runs. At this point victory was virtually assured with 3 further wickets from King Rollo and 1 from club pro and bat supplier Paul Humphreys even despite some absolutely abysmal attempts at catching the small red ball particularly by the captain (yes it was 3 drops). Eventually## Ballinger's victory was wrapped up pretty uneventfully with Andy Thompson finishing with very economical figures and was unlucky to pick up only 1 wicket## while Jeremy Hunting showed plenty of flight and guile in an economical 2 over spell which yielded 40 runs.

In summary another good win in which Paul was unlucky not to break the coveted runs scored in a season record## never mind there's always next week. Anyway a match against new opposition turned out to be very fruitful with good opposition## good tea and good post match nourishment. Lets hope for another away match next season!

On a glorious September day Ballinger entertained Sarratt for the first time in many years. Once all the pleasantries had been exchanged to the ex Ballinger players and opening bowlers from other local clubs (Ley Hill) ## and someone had finally arrived with a key to the pavilion## skipper Salisbury won the toss and elected to bat.

Openers Humphreys and Riley began the innings in circumspect fashion due to some excellent opening spells from Helm and Lumley. Once they had settled in to the pace of the pitch## which had to be flooded 48 hrs before by the grounds men due to the unseasonal heat wave over Ballinger over the past month (good decision Ian!!) the scoring rate picked up. Humphreys counted himself to 48 which took him past the club record for the most runs in the season## and then decided to ruin the figures of Sarrats top wicket taker this year by taking 23 one over.

Paul eventually departed for 73 caught on the 3rd attempt## but this only brought in Rollo## who signalled his intentions by hitting his second ball for 4 and his fifth for 6.Whilst all this was going on Matt was quietly going about his work and reached his hundred with an enormous single## and once the over was finished skipper Salisbury declared with BWCC on 233-1. Matt scored an excellent 101no and Rollo 32no.

After the usual Ballinger gastronomic feast Sarratt began their reply but were soon in trouble as Tom Graham 3-30## and Nick Adams 1-23 reduced Sarratt to 46-4.Ballinger's change bowlers kept the wickets falling at regular intervals with Lloyd (2-21) and Max MacIver (4-29) bowling Sarratt out for 125.Top scorer for Sarratt was Randell with 35.

An excellent game played in the right spirit## and plenty of jugs down the Swan to finish with.

Ballinger had a gentle opener to the season against Chorley Wood on Sunday. Ballinger fielded first and an excellent opening spell by Humphreys and Adams kept Chorley Wood in check reducing them to ? for 3 after ? overs.
The introduction of Ollie Richards was interesting with 18 coming off his first over then a double wicket maiden in his second. With Ian Davies bowling well at the other end Chorleywood were reduced to 70 -7. An excellent innings by ? helped Chorleywood reach 171.

Matt Riley started his season with a well paced innings of 71. Some excellent running between the wickets with Graham Salisbury kept Ballinger in with a shout until the last 2 overs. BWCC eventually finishing on 141- 7 with a very alert Kerry keeping out the last few balls.
A difference of 6 overs in Chorleywood's favour probably made the difference but it was very pleasant match played in an excellent spirit. Shame we have to start the league season.

An almost full strength Ballinger side went to the Nags head ground on Sunday and## in the end## enjoyed a comfortable victory.

Batting first Riley & Salisbury got Ballinger off to a slow but steady start but the side slipped to 56 -6 before Lloyd## Fallowfield-Smith & extras brought Ballinger up to 130.

Adams & Lloyd then made short work of the Pelicans batting taking 2&3 wickets respectively for a total of 13 runs. Lawson's spin removed another 3 but the prized wicket was taken by pace man Tom Graham when he removed the Pelicans top scorer M.Hull.

An excellent evening was enjoyed in the Nags Head afterwards.

The first league game and the question is are we ready? Skipper Matt Riley had a good start to the tossing season when the opposition made the wrong call. Asking Monks to bat first looked like a good choice when## after 20 overs## they had only score 72. Phil Lloyd led the way with 0-14 in his first 6 overs. He was ably supported by Tom Graham with 0-20 in his 6 overs. The introduction of spin increased the wicket taking but## unfortunately## also the run rate. Ian Davies ended with a creditable 3-52 off his 12 overs but Monks Risborough finished on 215-10## which included 37 extras. BWCC set off at an incredible pace scoring 28 off just 16 overs. A 50 partnership between Davies & Hunting gave Ballinger a chance but time (overs) weren't on their side and although Davies reached 85* he was unable to get Ballinger close enough to force the win. Reaching 180-6 meant a loosing draw but by bowling the opposition out## plus batting points## gave Ballinger a reasonable start to their campaign. BWCC 10pts Monks Risborough 15pts.

BWCC Under 11b's lost a close fought 1st round Cup match against Wendover last Sunday. Batting first Wendover scored slowly but steadily against some tight bowling by BWCC. Wickets then fell at regular intervals with Dan Stockdale picking up 3 catches behind the stumps including one great one-handed effort. Wendover increased their run rate over the last 6 overs of their inning by running & calling well. Harriet Stone slowed the run flow with a great spell including a wicket## but Wendover's best batter took his toll on a sloppy last few overs from Ballinger. Wendover ended on 255 with BWCC having taken 7 wickets. BWCC also off to a slow start in their inning but crucially no wickets were lost. Although behind the run rate BWCC were always in with a chance## unfortunately then two quick wickets did fall which undid all the early good work and with 58 needed off the last 9 overs all seemed lost. However some solid and safe shot making## plus a few extras helped the Ballinger cause and the run rate was kept to 5 or 6 an over. The good news was that all of the batters were contributing to the effort## particularly James and Matthew Rose## Dan Stockdale and Harry Rix. Our last pair## Harriet Stone and Will Clarke needed 21 off the last four overs - a hard ask when Wendover's County player swapped his gloves for the ball but some good calling## quick singles and a few extras kept BWCC in the chase leaving us just 9 to win with 8 balls to go. As often happens when the pressure is on for runs## a desperate attempt at a single resulted in a run out## even then Harriet and Will stuck to their task and took 8 off the last over to cut the final margin between the teams to just 7 runs. The lessons learnt? Practice that ground fielding## think about fielding positions for each batsman and when batting get that calling LOUD and FAST! Well played everyone!
