Wycombe won the toss and elected to bat. The Waggoners skipper Freddie Thompson opened with Gus DS and what a selection. A hatrick and a run out gave the Waggoners the ideal start. Freddie then bowled from the other end and started with a 2 wicket maiden. Gus took another wicket in his 2nd over and by then end of the first pairs 4 overs Wycombe were in dissaray at 167. (Each side starts on 200)
Max Leane and hector Gibbs kept up the pressure with Max taking 2 - 6 and Hector only conceding 7 runs.Ollie Hardman and Zac Bischoff carried on the good work with another 2 wickets each. Joe Turrel then bowled 2 overs of high quaility left arm spin taking 1 - 0. Taylor Levitt did his bit as well. Then Wycombe staged a recovery with Liam Morgan scoring 24 and the last 4 overs conceded 28. This took them to 210.

Freddie opened with Joe and were soon running frantically between the wickets. All good stuff but the runs off the bat and extras were negated by them losing 2 wickets. The pair added 12 and then Marcus Tingey and Ollie added another 10## Hector and Zac another 7. Then the big stand of 20 between Max and Taylor which took the Waggoners to a postion of safety.Harry and Gus finished off the innings playing careful defence to ensure no wickets were lost.

An excellent performance all round with Freddie marshalling the troops with great aplomb.

The second round of the cup was played at Chenies and Latimer with a new look team as five regulars were away on a school trip. Batting first## Ballinger lost two early wickets against some good opening bowling## but then Max Dugdale and Will Gibbs put on a great 50 run partnership. Max played yet another attacking innings and retired for the third time out of five matches so far. Will took his opportunity to bat higher in the order## scoring a very good 25## with some thumping leg side boundaries. Monty came in at five and upped the tempo## hitting a big six to midwicket that just missed a spectators dog## while scoring 23. Wickets kept falling in the last few overs which pegged Ballinger back a bit. The last ball was crazy as James Rackley took an all run four## pressurising the fielders into multiple overthrows. 116 for 7 looked a parr score## that Ballinger could defend with good bowling and fielding. Ballingers bowling didnt start well and the opening bowlers both had an off day## each starting their overs with a couple of wides. They werent the only bowlers whose radar wasnt working as Ballinger gave away a total 17 wides (and all those extra balls). Fortunately Ben who came on as first change bowler## was on song## and picked up two early wickets in a four over spell with two maidens and taking 2 for 5. Even so Chenies were doing well and looked set to win at 87-2 after 15 overs. But then Monty came on and bowled the 16th over. He steps up with a couple of gentle paces## bowls his slow and accurate spin....one run off the first ball## wicket - caught next## dot (good shout for lbw declined)## another dot## wicket (bowled)## wicket (lbw)!!! Definitely the turning point in the match - the spirit of El Alamein perhaps? Almost everyone got a bowl and George## James## Will and Kenny all took wickets as Chenies crumbled## although a few more wides kept the nerves jangling. Fortunately Ballinger were holding their catches all day long## five in total. Kenny came on for the final over with 13 needed and after a couple of nervous full tosses## he managed to keep it tight. It was too much for Chenies who lost another wicket to a run out and whose last pair could only manage 3 runs. After trying to snatch defeat## Ballinger had finally won by 9 runs  a third final over win in a couple of weeks. But for the wides it wouldnt have been nearly so close. They progress into the cup quarter final. The match was played in a very good spirit and was enjoyed by everyone involved and all the spectators. BWCC 116-7 (20 overs) Chenies & Latimer 107-9 (20 overs) Ballinger won by 9 runs

Result BWCC won by 66 Runs
BWCC  267-7  Dinton CC 201-9

Harry Livingstone won the toss on a pleasant morning at the attractive Dinton Cricket ground and elected to bat. Some rash shots and risky running between the wickets in the early overs put BWCC in a  precarious position. However## powerful hitting by Zak and Hector steadied the ship and put BWCC on top. Monty Weatherall batted very sensibly picking up quick## but safe## singles off most deliveries he faced. Harry L and George Cook scored 17 off the last four overs to give BWCC a respectable 267. The loss of 7 wickets was a little disappointing## that  said##  Dinton had some very decent bowlers and the boys did well to keep out their best bowler  who only took one wicket from 3 overs.

It was now BWCCs turn  in  the  field. The opening overs by Taylor and George Cook were tight. The highlight however was two outstanding pieces of fielding by Zak and George who both had direct hits to secure run outs. This put Dinton on the back foot and  after 4 overs they were on 187. George Cook bowled an excellent line with good pace. In all BWCC took  9 wickets which was a tribute to the accuracy of the bowling of the entire team. The left arm spin of Joe and Harry was excellent. Hugo## bowling right arm round the wicket## was accurate and picked up a wicket. William bowled a variable line## but when on target was too good for the opposition and bowled out two of the Dinton players.  I particularly enjoyed watching Montys leg spin## which left the opposition mystified as to what was going on. After 20 overs Dinton were 201## a victory by 66 runs

A word about the fielding. It was excellent. Catches were taken## half chances attempted if not  taken## and a number of run outs as mentioned above. Marcus leapt backwards to take a great catch  whilst keeping wicket. The boys were also impeccably behaved on and off the field. Well done.

Paul Rose 2/6/10

Two of our players had to drop out at the last minute## which was probably the difference between the two sides.  Whilst## the Ballinger batting performance to put on 98 in 20 overs was a reasonable target to defend## the opposition scraped home with a ball to spare.  Ballinger's batting depth helped.  Although we lost 7 wickets## in each case## this was down to the batsmen unselfishly trying to force the pace.  Kingshill fielded very well## taking 5 catches including two which would have impressed Collingwood.  James Mc (12)## Hamish (16)## Dom (16)## Will G(14) and Freddie T(12) all made useful double figure contributions - in particular Dom changed the pace of the run rate by scoring his equal top score of 16 off just 9 balls.

Having taken 6 catches and dropped none against Wendover## we let ourselves down by doing exactly the opposite## dropping 6 and catching none.  Just one of those catches would have delivered a victory.  The two Thompsons bowling 4 overs back to back each in the middle slowed down the run rate but it was Dom Brown's crucially tight spell at the end which gave ballinger the scent of victory..not to be as the Kingshill 5 was able to get bat on ball against Hamish in the last over and found the boundary. To be fair## most of the catches did not go to hand.  Man of the match was awarded to Dom Brown.

It was an exciting finish and despondend U12 team## who could not quite contain the opposition.

Ballinger were thrashed with some very good batting by the Chesham top order including our ex teamsman## Theo Reynolds who scored 29.  A significant contribution to this one sided result was the weather; by the time Ballinger took to the field## it was non stop raining and none of the usually tight Ballinger bowlers were able to control the ball or their feet.  Ballinger had to give up the considerable advantage of fielding first because of the late arrival of 3 of their team members.  The batting started well with Freddie (17) and Brandon (13) steering Ballinger to 50 for 2 off the first 10 overs.  With so many wickets in hand## a 120 looked feasible. However in attempting to force the pace## both gave away their wickets and a middle order collapse followed with S Rance taking 3 wickets for 6 runs of 4 overs. 

Thanks to late flourishes by Oscar## tops scoring on 19## Ballinger posted what seemed to be a defendable 93 runs.  Given that Chesham had only managed 87 (we had scored 98) off their 20 overs against Kingshill## we had hopes of containing them.  However with 17 off the first 2 overs## Chesham quickly quashed any hope overhauling their target in just 10 overs.  Our usually tight openners had no grip whatsoever which left our pace man## Hamish bowling off a 4 pace run-up and Will Gibbs being given a rare opportunity to prove to his coach that he can bowl spin - a first over of 1-1 might have proved a point but 14 of his 3rd suggests that there is some work still to do on this fledgling talent!   Given the conditions## the fielders all put their bodies on the line with William Arnold and James Mc both nursing bruises but stopping runs.

My man of the match goes to Oscar## who both top scored but also fielded superbly causing the first wicket with an excellent throw to Brandon.

On a lovely warm evening our U13s took on Great Kingshill at their Widmer End ground in the league - it was half term and several regulars were away. The oppositions openers and top order batsmen scored heavily at the start of their innings## reaching 73-3 in the 13th over. It was a difficult track to get used to bowling on with a tricky slope making it difficult for many bowlers to find a good length and very short boundaries on one side. The fielding was also poor which didnt help the cause. Ballingers attack fought back in the latter part of the innings with Hamish Sim## Ben Dugdale## Will Gibbs and Dom Brown being the pick of the bowlers. The umpire (Bill) took a painful blow from a forceful shot at square leg## inadvertently blocking another boundary. Another incident was a hit wicket off a very wide ball with the umpires having to double-check whether the batsmen could be out - he could. Kingshill finished on 110-8## a good total## but which shouldnt be out of reach as Ballinger had passed 100 in three previous innings.

Ballingers reply started badly with the seasons top scorer## Max bowled in the first over. Hamish and Rob settled down and laid a foundation talking the score to 30 before they lost their wickets in quick succession. These two and Ben who was the highest scorer with 17## got a start but none went on to a big score and wickets fell rapidly from then on through the innings. The home team had two leg spinners who were very effective and extracted considerable turn from the pitch## bamboozling some of the batsmen. They also fielded well and held some excellent catches. But our batting wasnt good enough and after losing the last 6 wickets for 30 runs## Ballinger were all out for 75 in the 16th over## losing by 35 runs.

Bill Senior

Knotty Green v BWCC          MBL Premier Div          5 .6.10

BWCC 169 8   (45 overs)    Knotty Green 172 4  (31 overs)


The first encounter of the season between the 2009 League champions and the Runners-up. The gap between the sides last season was narrow. This year it looks rather wider !

Another lost toss saw Ballingers openers fending off some lively bowling## but all went well until deafness (or was it mute-ness?) resulted in the farcical running out of Matt Riley## who had looked in prime form. Rollo came## and went## but Ian Davies joined Paul Humphreys## and they took the score to 104 by the 29th over## even though they were never able to dominate the bowlers## on a lively pitch.The loss of Ian for 38 to a blinding catch## followed quickly by Paul for a very patient 42 led to a rapid clatter of wickets## with only Jack Maciver standing firm (32 not out). A few lusty blows by Nick Adams saw BWCC reach 168 for 8 wickets at 45 overs a total well short of par## one thought.

And so it proved.  Knotty Greens batsmen started pasting some unimpressive looking Ballinger bowling to all parts## and continued in that vein. A brilliant catch off a skyer by Fergus Hardy gave Adams a wicket with total on 58## but skipper Rileys bowling changes went unrewarded until he brought on Jack Hankinson in the 21st over## with Paul Humphreys at the other end. Suddenly batting became difficult## and three wickets fell## all to the impressive Jack Hankinson## who finished with 3 22 off 5.1 overs. But it was too late. As expected## Ballinger didnt have a total big enough to defend## and so went down by 6 wickets## with 14 overs of the game still to run## defeated by a markedly better side.

MBL Div 3 League Saturday 12th June

The Lee 212 - 6 BWCC 163 - 10

A trip to The Lee is always going to be interesting and Saturday was no exception.

The ground## as always## look as pretty as a picture and when skipper Kerry won the toss he was for once undecided as to whether to bat first or take the safety first route. His choice was clouded by the fact that he actually had a decent batting side.


As usual he chose caution and after 15 overs it looked like his decison was going to work. Evan Webster and Phil LLoyd both bowled really tight opening spells keeping The Lee openers down to 3 an over which is good going on this ground.When Evan finished Kerry turned to Carlton Siddle playing his first league game for the club and his battle with Lee opener England was worth the admission fee with Carlton finally winning the battle. In the mean time Tom McIntyre had been weaving his magic at the other end and thanks to a brilliant stumping by Jeremy Hunting and an easy catch by the skipper took  2- 52 in his 10 overs.


Jake Cutter had a brief foray into the attack but by the time he came on Lee top scorer Susman was into his stride and anything short was despatched.Evan was returned to the attack and quickly restored order by first bowling Susman and then having Lapham elastically caught by Jeremy. He finished with an excellent ct & bld. 10 - 3 - 25 -3 are pretty good figures in any company.

The Lee declared after only 40 overs on 212 - 6 which looked very sporting on a decent track.

Bastie Richards and Ian Hardy opened up for the Waggoners but Ian set himself up to collect he money when he was out to his first ball. Tim Rix replaced him and looked like a man wanting to make sure he didn't miss the start of another match being played on a different continent.
When he was out Carlton continued with the bat where he'd left off with the ball. His full range of shots soon had the Waggoners back up with the run rate but following a camoe from Tom McIntyre it was a Hunting/LLoyd partnership that looked like turning the game in Ballingers favour. 60 in 8 overs what was just what the visitors needed and a win looked on the cards. Unfortunately the Geoff Boycott philosphy of 'add 2 wickets and then see how it looks' became apparent when Jeremy and Phil were out within a couple of overs of each other and the skipper was left with the tail.

 Keep going or play for the draw was the question and with the demise of Jake Cutter he decided to shut up shop. Unfortunately a long hop was too difficult to refuse so he pulled gently to mid on. 12 year old Oliver Cooksey playing his first game for the adults managed a single off his second ball before Evan was caught off a skier to bring proceedings to a close.

A lovely day## a really enjoyable game game even if it was the wrong result##a bit of bite between a couple of senior pros## a fantastic bit of fielding from Harry Rice of The Lee## and a wonderful tea.

Ballinger U10A beat Beaconsfield by 108 runs.

Skipper## Angus Denison-Smith## won the toss and put the opposition into bat on a sunny Sunday morning.  Tight bowling by Rory Bland and Angus and some excellent run-outs early on had Beaconsfield in deficit at 195 from their opening pair after 4 overs.  The major impact bowler of the day was Max Leane## who was pitching the ball perfectly and swinging it away from the right-hander.  His first two overs delivered 3 wickets for 6 runs## leaving Beaconsfield reeling after their 2nd pair## with a total of 176.   The run rate picked up a little## however sharp fielding by Ballinger led to a total of 5 run-outs in the innings.  Ollie Hardman had an excellent spell of 2-8 and Max Leane wrapped up the innings to secure his 4th wicket in the innings despite the fact that “Mum was chatting on the boundary all the way through my last over”.  So impressed was he with the Leane out-swingers## the Beaconsfield umpire was later to be seen asking for Max’s autograph.

The Ballinger batsman managed to keep their innings in the black from the start.  Kit (15) harvested the strike and scored quickly in his pairing with Ollie who faced just 2 balls but played the shot of the day through the covers for 4.     Taylor (14) played some good looking strokes.  Monty top scored on 17## with the last wicket partnership between Angus and Monty putting on 32 runs including one shot## in which they managed to run 5 without any overthrows (helped by the fact that the Team Manager had forgotten to put out cones to reduce the boundary).

This was a very convincing performance by Ballinger## who were not fielding their strongest team## which shows the depth in this year group.  Behaviour was exemplary and the attitude in the field and the running between the wickets was fantastic.  Unbeaten so far## great stuff!

Ballinger beat Chenies by 60 runs

Following our performances against Kingshill and Chesham## Ballinger needed a victory to avoid being in the relegation zone of the league. Whilst there was never much doubt of securing a victory## like at Chesham## a good run rate in the first 10 overs with 79 for the loss of 3 wickets was not matched in the second 10## where we gave away 7 wickets for just 33 runs.

Credit to Chenies who raised their game and fielded with aplomb## taking 4 catches and stopping some hard drives and hooks. Freddie looked very settled on 17## holding up one end of the wicket until## like almost all the batsmen## he had a rush of blood to the head## charged up the wicket and was clean bowled by fellow school-mate## Will Rance## who delighted in the fact that he managed to have a hand in getting out both his Beacon mates## having caught Monty in the preceding over. Monty's rapid 15 helped keep the score ticking over but it was Oscar## who had been advanced up the order on the back of his Chesham performance## who delivered and retired on around the 12th over for 31. Dom Brown## coming in at 5 delivered a typical Dom Brown performance - a couple of boundaries and then caught for 12. Ballinger finished on 112 with most of the batsman having given their wicket away## playing across straight balls or attempting to drive good length balls. Forward and backwards defense will be the strokes## we will be focusing on for the rest of the season! If I was disappointed with the batting##

I was conversely delighted with the bowling and fielding. Everyone played their part with catches being taken by Monty## Matt## Brandon## Will and James Mc. Will Arnold bowled out one of the openners with a very good spell of 1-5 off two overs. Monty got revenge on Will Rance## by running him out when he was ambling back to the crease in the mistaken belief that he had scored a 4 (inevitably Will expressed his disappointment - I was very impressed that after the game## he came up and apologised - a good example to all our players). However## the match winner for Ballinger was undoubtedly Will Gibbs. Chenies were on 21 for 2 of the first 5 overs and Will really secured victory for Ballinger in one over by taking a triple wicket maiden. It was a remarkable display of accurate good length bowling## angled into the batsmen.

With Will on 4 wickets## the skipper## Monty T## elected to give him a 4th over; at least two very difficult catching opportunities were put down and with one ball to spare## Will came steaming in and bowled probably his best ball of the day## hitting off stump and securing a rare "Five-for"## with figures of 5-10 over 4 overs. James Mayo also bowled his left arm spin tightly and secured two wickets## including a good stumping by the ever threatening Brandon## who only let through one bye all day (and only his 4th this season## which included a very wet day at Chesham!). Monty T had an opportunity at the helm and whilst there is some work to do with respect to setting and adjusting sensible targets for the batsmen## the leadership in the field was excellent## with some very tactical and sensible field placing and a mature approach to bowler selection. Good stuff Ballinger - next up Gerrards Cross.

The U12B team recorded a convincing win at Bellingdon. Due to a rough## long-grassed outfield## our brave boys had to run nearly all of their 109 in 20 overs. The highlight of the innings being Monty Thompson`s 30 retired.

Our bowlers steadily took wickets despite a pair of very generous umpires## (one of which was me!) until the final batsman fell to Dan Adams` yorker for his second wicket. Ley Hill were all out for 31 in 13 overs due to some superb tight fielding from our lads. JG

The visitors won the toss and chose to bat first. They batted very well against some mixed Ballinger bowling and fielding with three of the batsmen having to retire with 30 or more. Several of our bowlers struggled to find a good length although Ben and Will Gibbs were pretty economical as ever. Josh turned out to be the pick of the bowlers used##  taking two wickets - both bowled - for four runs in his one over with his dibbly dobblies – straight and on a good length. Unfortunately he was the 9th bowler used and only came on in the 19th over as he hasn’t been in the front line attack up until now. He also made a great run out from square leg. Unfortunately some of Ballinger’s fielding was poor## with a few mis-fields## overthrows and several possible catches going down. The total to chase was 156## challenging but perhaps achievable.

By the time our boys batted the sun had  dropped down and was straight into the batsmen’s eyes at the western end. This made batting very difficult## especially against Heaney## the opening bowler who bowled fast and straight## taking two consecutive wickets in his third over which left us reeling at 13-2 in the fifth over. Max survived the opening spell and batted superbly to top score once again and retire on 30.  Brimming with confidence## Josh played a really good innings (24). Along with Ben and Will Reid Ballinger staged a fight back to 113-4 in the 16th over. Although there was a glimmer of a chance## the rate required was too much as the opening bowler came back on and we lost wickets quickly in the run chase. Although it was one of the highest scores this season## 127-8 wasn’t enough and we lost by 29 runs. It was an enjoyable game played with great enthusiasm by both sides and in good spirit.

Bill Senior

Ballinger 2nds gave a hardworking performance against a more experienced Prestwood side but were unable to close out an exciting match## which was played in an extremely sporting manner.

Ballinger batting first## once stand in captain Richards had made his one significant contribution to the day and lost the toss. A fine opening partnership from Will Smith and Ian Hardy set the base for a useful first innings score. Highlights## followng the opening partnership## included the second wicket partnership between Will Smith and Joe Hankinson.

Joe made a quick 28 and Will provided the backbone for the innings in making a mature 54. The stage was set for a blazing performance from Rob McIntyre who contributed 630 not out## ably supported by Kim Hughes and Peter Petrie## which carried ballinger 2nds to a score of 200 for 7 wickets off 45 overs.

An excellent teafollowed## provided by Veronica## and ballinger 2nds entered the field## suitably replenished. Oh what joy followed as the first three Prestwood batsmen were each dismissed for nought. Excellent bowling from Evan Webster with 1-36 and Joe hankinson with 1-24. Surely victory would follow but Prestwood fought back with a fine 55 from L. Capeling and 89 not out from N. Heasey.

Tom McIntyre tied down the batsmen bowling superbly for 11 overs with figures of 1-53 which did reflect how well he bowled as the ball beat the bat on a number of occasions. It was Tom however who removed L. Capeling when Will Smith made a superb stumping off a snorting delivery.

Robert Rose came into the attack and was immediately successful## two wickets in his first over## surely victory would now follow. Robert's figure were a superb 3-34 off 7 overs.

In the end the experience of Prestwood's captain## J. Laxton## with 30 not out saw Prestwood home but Ballinger 2nds fought to the end in a match that could have swung either way.

A spirited Ballinger effort with bat and ball was not enough to overcome a strong Chesham side who secured a 31 run win on a chilly Sunday morning at Ballinger Common.
Batting first the home side looked to attack early## with topscoring Joe Turrell (22) exploding in the third over## notching 3 consecutive boundaries off the Chesham opener Hamza. Their progress was slowed however by timely wickets## Hamza himself picking up two to limit the opening pair to a still impressive 26. A steady stream of runs followed but a solid bowling performance from the visitors culminating with two wickets in the final two overs left the home side with a total of 261.
The Waggoners## needing a excellent fielding performance to stand a chance of keeping Chesham below the target## started brightly with the ball. George Cooke struck in the second over as the Chesham opening pair struggled to impose their game onto the hosts bowling. Seven wicketless overs followed however and Chesham began to build a healthy total## with the score 249 at the halfway mark. An agile caught and bolwed from Zach Bischoff followed by a double wicket over from Angus Dennison-Smith couldn't halt the visitors momentum and they coasted home with an impressive total of 292 from their 20 overs.

BWCC v The Lee               Mid Bucks League      12/6/10

 

BWCC 139       The Lee 142 – 5

 

Umpiring decisions can rapidly spoil a batsman’s Saturday afternoon enjoyment## as Ballinger found to their cost against The Lee. It is hard enough to face zealous interpretation of the laws from one end## but with their persistent inability to provide their own official## Ballinger were in deep trouble facing the same difficulty from both ends. And so it was that they sagged to a miserable total of 139 all out## with 10 overs of batting time going begging.  Among the batsmen only opener Paul Humphreys ## 6th out with a watchful 35## and No 8 Jamie Kellock with an enterprising 49 did themselves justice## though Nick Adams helped Jamie in the best stand of the innings – 42 for the 9th wicket.  For The Lee## opening bowler D Peins did the damage with 5 – 41 in his 12 overs.

 

With 50 overs in which to make 140## The Lee had an easy stroll to victory## in spite of a wobble when 61-2 became 67-5## thanks to two (more!) lbw’s ## and a splendid run out from Joe Hankinson.. But that was the limit to Ballinger’s success## as Blakely and## particularly## Peins saw them coast home in only 29 overs. Had the swarm of bees (yes## real ones## not vuvulezas !) that sent the players running or diving for cover early in the innings been better targeted## who knows what might have been. As it was they disappeared in a trice.

 

With Ballinger currently finding league points so hard to come by## they can ill afford to miss out on the 3 league points on offer simply for having an umpire. Unless one can be recruited fast## relegation may well ensue from this deficiency alone.

BWCC 139       The Lee 142 – 5
