Ballinger arrived at bleak## cold## pavilion-less Monks Risborough with yet another weakened side## and could muster only 10 men## until Jon Hankinson (Snr) who had driven Jack to the match## gamely volunteered to make up the numbers## having never previously played the game. Skipper Riley was resting an injury## but stood as umpire (hooray)## thus saving us 3 precious points. Monks opted to bat first## and immediately targetted  Jon H with a vicious barrage of shots## bravely and competently fielded.

Ballinger's opening bowlers Nick Adams and Jack Hankinson both bowled tidily## as did Carlton Siddle## making his debut for the Saturday 1sts. Monk's batsmen are renowned for their rapid scoring and fast running between the wickets## and although the bowlers kept Ballinger in the hunt with wickets falling steadily## the batsmen kept the scoreboard moving. At 137-8 and 36 overs gone there was hope that Ballinger would only be facing a total of 150ish. However## the tail wagged and Monks had reached 174 in the 43rd over before the final wicket was taken. Nick Adams (2 for 32 off 12 overs) and Ian Maciver (3 - 43) were the most successful of the bowlers.

A target of 175 looked attainable## especially with 2 extra overs. Three balls later it looked rather less obtainable with Paul Humphreys gone for a duck. Richard O'Kelly then showed some fine shots before falling victim to an athletic catch## for 24. Thereafter## things went from bad to worse## and J Iqbal (6 - 20) made a serious mess of the middle order## though some would blame umpiring injustice for their downfall. A defiant last-wicket stand of 14 between Hankinsons## father and son## saw Ballinger to one measly batting point - but possibly a precious one come the end of the season.

Ballinger 2nds had a hard match against Frieth who brought an extremely strong batting line up and made the most of a perfect batting track. Evan Webster and Peter Petrie opened and stuck well to the task.

It was the young spinners## Jake Cutter and Tom McIntrye who were able to extract some movement from the pitch and both bowled superbly. Jake returned figures of 4-84 off 11 overs and Tom returned 3-53 off 9 overs. Tom Graham supported the young spinners in a fine 6 over spell. However despite the efforts of the bowlers Frieth were able to reach a total of 294 for 8 off 40 overs.

Ballinger in reply were never really able to approach the total despite a cultured 40 from Rob McIntyre## well supported by Peter Petrie who fell on 14 when looking to step up the run rate. Tom Graham contributed a lusty 20 but it was left to Tom McIntyre with 13 not out and Jake Cutter with 10 not out to see Ballinger safe. Ballinger eventually finishing on 130 for 8.

Chenies & Latimer 233 - 11 BWCC 265 - 6

It was the longest day and the concern was that it might feel like a long night when one of Ballingers least experienced sides took to the field. Only one of them had played in a hard ball game for the club before

On a beautiful evening in the Chilterns##Ballinger won the toss and skipper Ben Westland chose to field. His opening attack of Charlotte Wingrove ( Charlie) and James Arnold set the standards for the rest when they took 4 wickets for just 20 runs. Ben and Will Piper followed with excellent 2 over spells and then James Bunce and Henry King tightened the screw. Connor McAlister and Sam Powell only allowed another 21 runs in their spells and took 2 wickets. Hugo Eaton-Hart and mixture of Henry and James A finished the quota keeping Chenies down to a managable 233.

Joe Farrelly had been press-ganged into keeping wicket and he was a natural. Soon shouting at everyone about what to do next - wonderful. The rest of the side fielded really well with special mention of Charlie and Henry.

The skipper had spent ages agonising over the batting order to the point that is was all organised and the openers out on the pitch before the manager was able to have a cup of tea - very bad form.

Hugo and James B set about their task with great gusto and no little skill. Excellent running between the wickets and some good shots meant they left the side in the black by 14runs. Sam and Will took a very defensive approach and the score was still 212 when they finished. Connor and Charlie took the score along to 223 and then and enterprising stand between Joe and Ben took the game away from Chenies finishing on 260. Blunters James A and Henry then took no chances over the last 4 overs scoring just 12 runs but only losing 1 wicket.

A really enjoyable evening and a good experience for all concerned.

Lost by 18 runs.

A night of firsts:

  • The first time I have seen a Ballinger player get 4 wickets in 4 balls
  • The first time the captain entered the field wearing make-up
  • The first time## the captain attempted to abdicate his leadership position half way through the first innings (but was overruled by the coach!)

On paper## this was always going to be a tough match.  Gerrards Cross has an impressive line up of County names and it was clear that Ballinger were initially somewhat in awe of them. 

Gerrards Cross decided to bat and set off at clip of 7-8 an over. Dom took an excellent catch to start the fall of wickets with Hamish taking a couple in his first spell - this kept Ballinger in the game. Gerrards Cross kept up the run-rate and Ballinger heads dipped as they envisaged a target of 160; On comes Dom and with a fabulous display of line and length## takes 4 wickets in 4 balls. Dom managed another to be the second bowler in the season to get a five-for and suddenly Ballinger's heads were up. At 87 for 7## Ballinger were dreaming of a 2 digit chase.  GX of course batted all the way down the order with the Number 10 putting on 18 runs and ended up setting a target of 122.

Extra's top scored for 40 runs and was the difference between the two teams## however## generally the fielding was high quality - in particular in taking the all important catches (Matt## Dom -2## Monty) and George Ryland was very impressive at Square Leg.

I was very happy with the Ballinger batting.  Only one player threw away his wicket; all others played themselves in sensibly## getting out to good balls.  Matt O'Kelly and James Mc played very important platform innings and Hamish came in needing to up the run rate## which he did to great affect## scoring 26 not out.  An 18 run over on the 17th left us needing 30 of 3 overs and gave the side hope but it was not to be.

Very enjoyable evening; hopefully the team have learned a valuable lesson that in cricket## its never over and a few quick wickets can turn the game. 

With his 5 wickets## 2 catches and 9 quickly scored runs## Dom was the obvious choice for man of the match.
Great Kingshill couldn't raise a team because of some stupid football match so the Fixture Sec. has crossed them off his Christmas card list. This is the second year running they've let us down
Sadly for the first time in it's short history the 2s had to scratch. Very annoying on such a beautiful day.

On a glorious summer evening our U13s took on top of the table Gerrards Cross at the picturesque Coleshill Ground. After winning the toss## Will put the opposition in. They had a very strong batting line up and scored heavily. Will bowled an excellent opening spell## starting with a maiden which surprised the openers. Joe bowled a good line and length getting one of the openers in his first over and  keeping it pretty tight. Kenny took a wicket first ball## thanks to a superb catch by Joe running backwards and over his shoulder into the sun. Ballinger had their moments but the bowling was inconsistent (once again) in the face of the attacking batting. Our ground fielding was much improved.  Even so Gerrards Cross had put on 177.

Batting  against this attack also proved tough.  Max and Ben got off to a good start## but Max lost his wicket to Seimon in the fourth over. This bowler picked up two more wickets in his next over which was pretty devastating. Their keeper was a South of England star and got two sharp stumpings. Ben continued to enjoy himself thumping a few good boundaries and top scoring with 18. James and Jasper played enthusiatic knocks but wickets kept tumbling and we were all out for 56. Mullered as they say## but always enthusiastic and playing in good spirit against a very strong side.

Hot sunshine at Ballinger persuaded Matt Riley to bat first against visitors Ibstone on a good-looking track## even though his batting line-up didn't look the strongest. By the 30th over with 141 on the board without loss## the decision seemed a good one## though it must be said that the master of the dot ball Riley (32 consecutive dot balls in a  becalmed period) had only contributed 30 ## when Paul Humphreys## hurtling towards a ton## missed a straight one## and departed for an aggressive 90. Matt## to be fair## then speeded up## but the Ballinger middle-order## under pressure to pile on quick runs## experienced one of their all too familiar collapses## and an innings that really needed to yield a total of 270+ could only manage 239 with 6 wickets down## by which time Matt## striking the ball beautifully towards the end## had reached an undefeated 89.

Ibstone## in reply## never looked in the slightest trouble on such an easy wicket and lightning fast outfield. Opener M Nilham struck an imperious 139 not out (haven't Ballinger suffered at the hands of Sri-Lankans somewhere before ? )## well supported by B Mills (60). The total was already 172 before Ballinger took their first (and only !) wicket## courtesy of an (over?) exuberant Ian Davies. Carlton Siddle bowled his full allotment of 12 overs## conceding only 58 runs - good going in the circumstances## and Jack Hankinson as usual bowled tidily but unluckily. Ibstone won in the 42nd over - significantly not a single maiden among them.

On the bright side## with the Seconds having to scratch## unable to raise a side## at least we had an umpire## courtesy of Ian Hardy## and the Chairman graced us with his presence## until he became too depressed at the sight of impending defeat (or threats from home ?).

Half the season gone - time for a fresh start ???

Ballinger beat Gerrards Cross by 4 wickets with 6 overs to spare.

On paper## this was going to be a tough fixture## but an excellent all-round team performance resulted in a convincing victory## keeping Ballinger in with a chance of making the top two for the league.

Gerrards Cross batted first and from excellent## tight bowling by James Reid and Ollie Cooksey## we had them on 6 runs for 4 wickets after the first 4 overs.  This included Seth taking probably the catch of the season - a hard hit to Square Leg taken over his head and ensuring that one of their key strikers was despatched for just 2.

James Frey and Seth also bowled tightly## with Seth getting one to turn a foot## resulting in a catch to skipper## James Mayo (who caught 2 and stopped several hard driven 4s at mid-off).  Some expensive middle order overs meant that GX were able to reach a total of 97; this could have been a lot higher had it not been for excellent last overs from James R and Olly C resulting in just 2 runs.  Ollie C took 3 for 10 of 4 overs.  Ollie N-M also took an important wicket. Catching and fielding was nearly faultless; the only weakness being the numbers of wides and no balls (26).  Just 5 byes was a tribute to our glove man## Stephen Cady playing at his energetic best.

I felt that 97 was going to be a big ask - how wrong I was.  Toby played a superb openers innings## nearly carrying his bat to retirement on 30. Seth justified his personal campaign to bat at 4 by scoring a quick 30 and setting up Ballinger's assured victory. 

Seth's catch## wicket and 30 runs earned him the man of the match.

Great team spirit and very enjoyable to watch.

In a rapidly re-arranged fixture and with a severly dpleted team Ballinger overcame an inexperienced Ley Hill team last night in a thrilling encounter.

BCB U11 Cup

BWCC 114 - 3  Ley Hill 109 - 7

 

Skipper James Mcintyre lost the toss and the Waggoners were asked to bat first. James opened with Fred Sanders. Fred was under strict instructions to bat 'properly' which meant he was very confused and was out in the 2nd over trying not to hit the ball into the next county.

James was then joined by Rob Farquhar and with a combination of good running between the wickets some excellent shots and a bit of luck these two added 80 for the 2nd wicket before James had to retire (30*). Will Arnold then ran himself out## Rob had to retire(32*) so it was left to Jamie Kingston## Jack Peck and John Collier to take the Waggoners to their final total of 114. A bit below par given the start given by Rob and James but James Cullen bowled a really tight spell for The Hill at the death.

Ley Hill set about their task with great gusto and were soon rattling along at the required rate. Unfortunatley the were also loosing wickets until Asquith and Wallis came together. Asquith used local knowledge to great effect by playing the pull shot to nearly every ball and depositing it onto the golf course. Fortunateley he had to retire(30*). Wallis then carried on with Lee and it looked like a Ley Hill win was on the cards but skipper McIntyre had other ideas and having done a stirling job behind the stumps deceided that he was needed with ball in hand. Fred Sanders took his place and James then bowled 2 overs of high speed accuracy## and with Rob bowling his last for only 4 runs it was down to the last over with 10 required. Gethin Ross was given the reponsibility and having been savaged during his first spell was a bit nervous but he held up well and only concede 5 to leave the Waggoners winners by 5 runs.

A really enjoyable evening with the game played in exactly the right spirit.

High Wycombe beat Ballinger by 80 runs.

Its not often as a coach that you get beaten by 80 runs and come off the pitch feeling very proud of your team.  Skipper## Hamish Sim deserves significant praise## leading by example but also with huge encouragement to ensure that the team never dropped their heads and continued to perform right the way through the game.   Once again## taking wickets was a key part of that performance.  Apart from two difficult chances put down## the catching was once again superb. 

Hamish led the way with a superb CAB in the first over and went on to bowl the perfect ball## hitting top of off stump to get their dangerous looking number 4.  George Ryland bowled as well as I have seen him bowl all season## took two wickets and kept the run rate under control.  Seth took two very good catches.  Will tried out his spin with some success and took a good catch.  Hamish and Dom shared the wicket keeping and managed just 4 byes between them## considerably less than the opposition. Dom was particularly impressive## particularly in dealing with Hamish's fast bowling.  At one stage## Wycombe were 90 of 9 overs; they ended up setting us a substantial target of 160 runs. 

Hamish (24) and Dom (30) batted very sensibly.  Dom's innings against some of the best bowling in the counry was a lesson to himself in shot selection. The middle order struggled after this## however a final flourish from Henry Turrell and Ollie Cooksey (who each played the two best shots of the day) in the last over meant that we posted a perfectly respectable 81 in reply.  

My man of the match is Hamish## who led the team very well## took two key wickets## wicket kept and scored a controlled 24

Ley Hill 165 - 10 BWCC 166-3

When he lost the toss on Saturday and Ley Hill elected to bat## the Waggoners skipper Nigel Kerry## and his team## thought they were in for a long## unpleasant##afternoon in the field  but## once the wiles of opening bowler Phil LLoyd and his young pretender Joe Hankinson were on display## the gloom of the day was dispersed to become like the blue sky above.

Ley Hill were under the cosh from the first ball as## on a good track and fast outfield## only 23 were score off the first 12 overs## with Phil taking an excellent C & B to remove 1 of the openers and Joe giving the batsmen no room to play any run scoring shots.

 Ben Carlin took Joe's place and struck immediately. His first ball for a year was a cunningly delivered full toss.This was sent straight up in the air by the Hill's no 3 for Max Dugdale## making his debut as 'keeper## to run to square leg and claim the catch.

Phil was then rewarded for his efforts with another wicket before being replaced by Evan Webster(6.0.1.30). At this stage The Hill were stuck at 46 off 17 overs. Ben then took an unbeliveable caught and bowled to reduce Ley Hill to 67-5. The Hill skipper## Dave Peterson## dug in and## with Connolly and then McCarthy## added nearly 50 runs but## by this time Tom McIntyre was weaving his web of leg spin magic.

It was difficult to know who was more confused## the batsmen or the close fielders## as Tom was turning the ball so much. After a bit dodgy footwork by the fielders during his first couple of overs## Tom hit the mark and bowled his next seven overs for 21 whilst taking 3 wickets.

Ben had by now been replaced by Joe who## once more## gave the skipper a level of control he would only normally dream about. Phil came back to take another wicket and## with Tom## cleaned up a Hill tail which had a wracked up a rapid 20 runs under the guidance of Wilson.

It was a good fielding effort by all but should be noted in particular for Max Dugdale making his debut behind the stumps in an adult game. The records are carefully being searched to see if a "keeper has ever been involved in 5 dismissals before- especially as he did it reasonably quietly. Also Joe's bowling efforts as## at the moment## 0-24 off 12 overs at Ballinger is something to be cherished.

Peter Petrie and Ian Hardy then set about the job of winning the game for Ballinger but## unfortunately## no-one has taught Ian how to play leg spin or Peter to play left arm over. Having hit 4 fours Peter obviously felt every ball should go the same way so was bowled round his legs and Ian was put out of his misery when someone was finally in the right place to catch him.

Kim hughes played a brief cameo to end his season and then we were treated to a demonstration of how easy batting is if executed correctly.

Joe Hankinson(61*) and Rob McIntyre(43*) traded shots whilst they took the Waggoners past the finish post. It was difficult to believe that one hadn't played cricket for years and the other was only 15. 27 overs was all it took for the home side to overhaul Ley Hill's score 

Every now and again the captain of a team gets to sit in the armchair whilst his team go about the job of winning a game. This was one of the few. It was a beautiful day## the pitch was good## the opposition were proper cricketing people## the tea was Irish## but no less excellent for it## and the skipper only had to field the ball 4 times - Perfect

Widmer End's skipper was dealt a rotten hand when two of his players cried off on the morning of the match## leaving him down to nine. Winning the toss## he had little choice but to ask Ballinger to bat## and given their parlous league position## Ballinger were unlikely to be over sympathetic. The pitch rapidly started to break up## and WESM's opening bowlers made Ballinger fight for every run## to start with. Matt Riley## Paul Humphreys and Richard O'Kelly all perished## victims of good catches. However## with such limited resources## WESM had no option but to go to their second string bowlers## and the result was a run-fest## as Ian Davies## Jack Maciver## and Rhodri Webster laid into some wayward offerings with a vengeance. Ian achieved a personal milestone with his maiden ton## and it was noted by certain connoisseurs of the game that## remarkably## he scored some of these with leg-side shots. Be that as it may## congrats## Ian ! Rhodri was playing his first knock of the season## and notched up a very handy 62. The return of the opening bowlers slowed up proceedings markedly## and BWCC closed on 259 for 9## using their full 45 overs.

Key to the WESM reply was always going to be their danger men## G Pearson and B Saeed. Get them out## it was reckoned## and Ballinger should cruise home. In the event## a couple of early wickets were snaffled## but then the aforesaid duo got going. However## Jack Hankinson bowled a mean spell of 7 overs## conceding only 11 runs and taking a vital wicket (after missing a dolly caught & bowled chance !)## as Saeed took one risk too many.. Pearson batted on## steadily running out of partners## until he was last out in a valiant but vain attempt to save the day## as Ballinger wrapped up the innings in 33 overs for 136## with Nick Adams the pick of the bowlers with 4 for 49 off his 12 overs.

25 more than welcome points for BWCC (but yet again 3 more dropped for no umpire) - a good start to the second half of the season## but they will meet sterner (and more numerous !) opposition than this in their remaining games.

On a hot## hot early Sunday morning## some tired boys## 1 player short and a very short boundary on the treacherous “road side” at Ley Hill Jack lost the toss and Ballinger were asked to bat.
 
Fielding several 6 foot plus players including one with a beard the young Ballinger side and diminutive openers## Max and Will had balls around their ears from the first over on a rock hard pitch and out field but nicked and nudged well. Will fell to a good ball but Max found his range and with brother Jack saw off the openers and scoring progressed well. Max skied a pull and departed for 27 followed quickly by Harry Bartlett who## having given up his lie in## was promptly run out without facing a ball! Run your bat in next time Harry!
 
Jack M was joined by Jack Bull and the scoring momentum resumed with Jack M especially starting to dictate terms## scoring to all parts and punishing any short or over pitched deliveries. After JB’s cameo JH came and went leaving our guest player## George Bartlett## to finish off the inning. By now Jack was scoring at will## it was an incredibly impressive sight and despite being dropped he took full advantage. Amazingly his century came up very quickly and he finished unbeaten on a tremendous 107 not out. Well done Jack!
 
Needing 165 to win## Ley Hill attacked from the first ball. Thompson especially hit brutally and brought up his 50 from a team total of 60 in just 6 overs. With Ley Hill ahead of the required run rate Ballinger needed his wicket or the match was lost. The crunch came when Harry Rix put one in short to the advancing Thompson as he charged down the track## batsman missed## bowler hit top of middle and Ballinger were back in game with Thompson out of an extremely rapid 74.
 
Enter new bowlers Evan Webster & Rob Rose to tie things down which they did very well including a stunning one handed caught and bowled by Evan.
 
The run rate increased and a couple more wickets were taken. Jack & Jack finished their spells efficiently and despite a last ball four which involved Jack Mac reversing off the pitch## on to the road## falling backwards and cracking his elbow very loudly on the tarmac the boys saw us home by 9 runs.
 
A high scoring and fun game with everyone participating. An excellent win to see us progress in the Plate and a wonderful ton from Jack all completed by lunchtime!
 
Well done everyone.
 
Tim

Haddenham 152 - 10 BWCC 155 - 9

 

On another wonderful sunny day the 2s travelled to one of the less glamorous grounds on the circuit - Haddenham.

The skipper lost the toss again and condemend his team to another long hot day in the field. Opening the the bowling with Tom Sperring was always likely to be a gamble as he hadn't played for 10 months but although a little wayward he was no where near as bad as he thought he was and it would all have been much better if the skipper had hung onto a sharp chance at slip.

At the other end Evan Webster was producing yet another spell of high class swing bowling which once again frustrated the coach in the skipper. Why can't he do it when playing with his peers? His 6 overs cost a miserly 9 runs and he removed their danger man Pawsey with a beauty.

Ben Carlin ( 2-27) replaced Tom and after a couple of wayward overs removed the other opener with help from a good catch by 'keeper Nick Tegg and skipper Kerry made up for his earlier miss with sharp catch at slip. The arrival of Haddenham's Heggie## who is renowned for his big hitting## pushed the skipper into a change of pace with the introduction of Max Maciver's off-spin. At the other end Tom McIntyre was introduced to weave his leg-spin magic. We then saw the contrast in fortunes that can favour bowlers. Max produced an interesting selection of deliveries designed to confuse all as he used as much of the cut part of the pitch as possible. His tally of 6-36 off 7 overs was as much a reflection of the batsmen's abilities rather than Max's skill. Although he did produce a couple of beauties to remove first Heggie then the last of the Haddenham tail. Meanwhile Tom is producing a wonderful demonstration of the leg-spinners art with the batsman absolutely clueless as to how to play him. 1-43 off 10 overs does not reflect how well he bowled.

Chasing 152 on an interesting wicket wasn't going to be easy and and Ballinger were grateful in the end for having bowled out Haddenham in only 32 overs. Bastie Richards and Nick Tegg put on 26 for the 2nd wicket but it wasn't until Tom McIntyre joined Tom Sperring(21) that the Waggoners finally made any head way. With both running well between the wickets and Tom Mac in imperious form they added 50 for the 7th wicket. Evan helped Tom add another 20 for the 8th but with only 3 required Tom then committed the cardinal sin of running out his captain. Forcing the skipper to collect the money and leaving the game slightly closer than need be. Fortunately the cool head of Rob McIntyre guided the side home. Tom's 44* was an excellent knock on a difficult track.

Having an umpire and a scorer was an added bonus to round off an enjoyable afternoon.

.

BWCC 200 -7 Prestwood 203 7

Ballinger 2nds gave a hardworking performance against a more experienced Prestwood side but were unable to close out an exciting match## which was played in an extremely sporting manner.

Ballinger batting first## once stand in captain Richards had made his one significant contribution to the day and lost the toss. A fine opening partnership from Will Smith and Ian Hardy set the base for a useful first innings score. Highlights## followng the opening partnership## included the second wicket partnership between Will Smith and Joe Hankinson.

Joe made a quick 28 and Will provided the backbone for the innings in making a mature 54. The stage was set for a blazing performance from Rob McIntyre who contributed 63 not out## ably supported by Kim Hughes and Peter Petrie## which carried ballinger 2nds to a score of 200 for 7 wickets off 45 overs.

An excellent teafollowed## provided by Veronica## and ballinger 2nds entered the field## suitably replenished. Oh what joy followed as the first three Prestwood batsmen were each dismissed for nought. Excellent bowling from Evan Webster with 1-36 and Joe hankinson with 1-24. Surely victory would follow but Prestwood fought back with a fine 55 from L. Capeling and 89 not out from N. Heasey.

Tom McIntyre tied down the batsmen bowling superbly for 11 overs with figures of 1-53 which did not reflect how well he bowled as the ball beat the bat on a number of occasions. It was Tom however who removed L. Capeling when Will Smith made a superb stumping off a snorting delivery.

Robert Rose came into the attack and was immediately successful## two wickets in his first over## surely victory would now follow. Robert's figure were a superb 3-34 off 7 overs.

In the end the experience of Prestwood's captain## J. Laxton## with 30 not out saw Prestwood home but Ballinger 2nds fought to the end in a match that could have swung either way.
Sadly for the first time in it's short history the 2s had to scratch. Very annoying on such a beautiful day.

BWCC paid their first visit to Aylesbury Town's ground## lost the toss on a fine and increasingly sunny afternoon## and could have been forgiven for fearing that the Town's batsmen would give them a hard time. But the pitch was not as true early on as it looked## and some excellent bowling by Jack Hankinson saw him take the first couple of wickets with only 31 on the board by the 10th over. A fifty partnership for the third wicket ensued## but then more wickets fell## largely due to a fine 12 over spell by Carlton Siddle (4 for 54)## and a splendid 3 catch haul by skipper Riley (jug next week## Matt?) When the 7th wicket fell at 137 in the 37th over## Ballinger's hopes were high## but alas the tail wagged## and the final total of 198 for 8 was rather more than had been hoped for.

Nevertheless## Ballinger started well## with a confident 50 opening partnership by Riley(19) and Humphreys(35). Then Town brought on Talib Hussain## who proceeded to take two wickets in his first three balls## both cleaned bowled. He continued to make mincemeat of Ballinger's middle order##even though Jack Maciver (29)showed some fine shots## finishing with 5 for 20 off 9 overs. However## Carlton Siddle was going well## and## joined by a limping Ian Maciver## they put on 60## looking well on track for a memorable victory when Ian took one risk too many## and ran himself out in the 41st over. Cue frayed nerves and chewed finger nails## as Carlton tried to shepherd the tail## only to fall for a valiant 43 in the final over. It was down to Nick Adams to hit a six off the one and only ball he faced## and with his past record of mighty blows## it seemed a possibility. But the boundaries at Aylesbury are a lot longer than at Ballinger. All Nick could manage was a two - and thus Ballinger fell an agonizing 3 runs short of victory## in a thrilling finish to a thoroughly satisfactory game of cricket.

According to the MBL website## the result of this match was Holmer Green 280-5## BWCC 160 all out.  This was the result submitted to the league## but as no-one  from the BWCC team has compiled a report (yet) and the scorebook is only partially ( and very inaccurately) completed## all that can be said is that apparently HG gave Ballinger a good thrashing## with K King making 79 and B King 110## Paul Humphreys taking 3 wickets.. In reply## Ballinger lost 4 wickets for 22  before tea## all to Steve Jermain## who finished with 8 wickets. Ballinger staged a major recovery## thanks to Rhodri Webster (66) and Jamie Kellock (29*)## putting on over 100 for the 7th wicket## but they still contrived to lose to the league leaders by over 100 runs.

It is a sad reflection on Ballinger's senior players that supervision was not given to the young scorers in this game## and that apparently no attempt was made to check or complete the scorebook after the match.

Post-script:  Forensic analysis of the scorebook has at last enabled me to reconstruct the bowling figures## which are now included in the stats below.

Cadmore End 141 - 10 BWCC 143 -1

Ballingers U14 team were to strong for visitors Cadmore End on Saturday.

The skipper won the toss and having looked at his young side decided that discretion was probably the best option. Little did he know.

Evan Webster was on fire. By the end of the 7th over## his 4th## he had reduced Cadmore to 22-3. Ben Carlin was struggling to find his line at the other end but finally managed a decent spell(6-0-28-0). He was replaced by Alex Howe who was immediately on the money and soon had the basmen playing and missing. 1-18 off his 8 overs didn't do him justice. Meanwhile Max Maciver had replaced Evan and was starting to weave his magic. At least it was magic this week unlike last week. Cadmore skipper Croft had decided to dig in and was taking no chances but eventually Max persuaded him to try a slog to the short boundary and bowled him. Derek then helped with another good catch and Max finished with 2-26 off 11 overs.

Cadmorewere now enjoying their best spell of the game with a partnership of nearly 70 before the recall of Evan quickly put an end to proceedings. Another 4 wickets including an excellent catch by Harry Bartlett behind the stumps was too much for Cadmore and they subsided to 141.

This was a high class spell of seam bowling from Evan and record books are being searched. Certainly it's the record for the 2ndX1 and 11.4 - 6-15-7 is top stuff in anyones books.

The bowling figures show that an U14 was involved in all the wickets.

Max and Peter Petrie set off in pursuit of Cadmore's total and it soon became apparent that it wasn't going to be competitive. Baring a couple of lucky breaks Max was in imperious form. Playing shots all round the wicket hesoon left Peter in his wake.

Peter had the daunting prospect of being in a match-winning opening partnership with someone 30+ years his junior who was out scoring him 2-1. He wasn't going to get to 50 and was going to have to collect the money. Fortunately for him## with only 11 required##Max couln't resist a slog atthe new bowler and was LBW for a fine 83. Bastie popped in to finish off proceedings.

Another beautiful day and an excellent afternoons cricket## add in a top tea from Sara Rose## an opposition who were good company in the pub and all was fine with the world.

Please note messrs Webster and Maciver senior that jugs will be required to be purchasedat the next home game.

Cublington  230 – 8 dec  BWCC  - 234-5

 

The Sunday batting machine rolls on.  Cublington won the toss and chose to bat first on a pitch that had seen its first rainfall for weeks. The  strip was a little slow and low at the start of Cubs innings## Jack Maciver (6-1-26-0) and Jack Hankinson (7-2-16-1)## keeping a stranglehold on proceedings.

The strip was cut on the car park edge of the square which meant the boundary was reachable with a defensive push. Goldberg (25) and Westlands (90) batted sensibly until a freak dismissal occurred whereby that normally sartorial (?)  wicket keeper## Kellock## took a catch inside his split –crutch flannels but couldn't find the ball. The bowler## Phil Lloyd## being very anxious that the ball did not touch the ground## spent a couple of minutes with his hands in Jamie’s nether regions groping for said ball## whilst the batsman stood his ground!

Phil’s figures (12-1-76-1) did not do justice to the way he bowled. Stuart McGowan ( 5-0-40-1) was disadvantaged by a very short leg side boundary to a left hander who hit a colossal 6 onto the roof of a house beyond square leg. There was a clatter of roof tiles following by metallic “tings” as the tiles fell on to the bonnet of a car in the drive – fortunately the house owner## Mr Jones## was extremely understanding and even helped in our search for the ball.

Cubs were heading for a substantial score until the introduction of Max Maciver into the attack in the 27th over. Max bowled their most accomplished batsman## Westlands## for 90 after which wickets fell regularly with Max ending up with figures of 8-0-35-4 which were in not the least flattering.

Cublington declared at 230 -8 after 42 overs batting which was probably 30 runs short of a par score.

After a first class tea##courtesy of Maciver I##  we set about our run chase. Smith W  and Humphreys were unable to repeat their substantial opening stand of the previous weekend with Will being dismissed in the 2nd over. Humphreys (83) and Joe Hankinson (57) took full advantage of their respective  rich veins in form## putting on 128 for the 2nd wicket.

Hunting J (26) and Maciver J (32*) also contributed in a largely incident free march to victory with 7 overs of the final 20 remaining.

Berkhamsted  238-4 after 40 overs

BWCC – 241 -3 after 34 overs.

Limited 40 over game

 

 

Having lost the toss and consigned to field first against a side  whom we  had never played before## it was with some anxiety that we took the field on a baking hot day with more than the usual complement of juniors playing.

Jack Hankinson (9-1-57-1) and Jono Lacey ( 7-0-27-0) struggled to find their line and length early on although it is fair to say that there was a fair amount of playing and missing too (particularly to Jono).  Berkhamsted scored at a steady rate##largely because of the speed of the outfield for  the first 25 overs##  S.McGowan (7-0-44-0) and D Birkby ( 5-0-28-0) were unable to effect a breakthrough and it took the introduction of Alex Howe (5-0-21-1) to change the momentum – Alex bowled extremely well## keeping a good line and length and was rewarded with  the wicket of their No.3## Brown## caught behind by debutant## 11 year old Brandon Allen. Brandon also had a hand in the next wicket## a smart piece of glovework## stumping Berkhamsted’s overseas Kiwi player off Humphreys for 17.

Berkhamsted’s innings was held together by Langley who carried his bat for 131* although soon after he had reached his ton he was reprieved by the umpire who incorrectly called dead ball  when Jack Hankinson had bowled him neck and crop because the wind had blown off a bail  at the non strikers end!

 

Messrs Humphreys and Smith set off chasing the target as if they were playing 20/20 rather than 40/40.## scoring 42 off the first 5 overs. Their partnership was worth 66 off 9 overs when Paul was bowled for 48. Joe Hankinson came to the crease and proceeded to dispatch the ball to all parts in a partnership of 154 off 24 overs with Will who was eventually out for a well crafted 69. Joe went on to score his maiden century (101) – well done Joe## it will be the first of many ( although your Dad will not buy the obligatory post match jug of beer  for anymore than the next couple of years!)

The victory target was reached with 6 overs to spare – a comprehensive victory achieved by steady bowling## enthusiastic fielding and positive batting on a very hot day when it would have been very easy to be less than energetic in the field!

Ballinger vs. Hyde Heath## this was the definition of a local derby. With an atmosphere reminiscent of the Milan derby at the San Siro and intensity of a certain World Cup final## this really was a battle of cricketing superpowers! Both teams were clearly ready for the battle that lay ahead of them## this came out especially in the pre-match interviews were respective captains## Salisbury and Samuels## refused to give much away to the capacity crowd of 4 at the Ballinger Common Stadium. As tickets were at a premium both teams knew they would have to put on a show and as the clock edged its way towards 2## Ballinger drew first blood as Salisbury won the toss and elected to bat first on a day that was fast turning into a splendid day for cricket.

For Ballinger the usual suspects of Will Smith and Paul Humphries opened up and got the home side off to a flier with 15 coming off the first 3 overs## however Will decided to give the HH slips some catching practice by just guiding a ball from Shrimpton straight towards second slip. Unfortunately HH didn’t enter into the spirit of things## and unlike so often for Ballinger## the relatively straightforward catch was taken. This brought local hero Joe Hankinson to the crease. Gradually Ballinger rebuilt and Joe began to feast on some of HH’s bowling from Stevens and HH’s multimillion pound overseas player Amla. Paul was rather subdued at this point and he soon went with the score on 58. This set off a collapse however## much akin to the collapse of Italian agriculture under Mussolini in 1937… BLAH BLAH BLAH. Anyway it was only the old pro Jeremy Hunting (14)## Tegg (15) and Jack Hankinson (27) that reached double figures as Ballinger were bowled out for a rather disappointing 173 in 40.2 overs with Stevens taking 6 wickets for HH.

After a typically good Ballinger tea## HH began their reply. The two Jacks## Hankinson and Maciver## opened the bowling and soon had the HH batsmen in trouble. Whilst Capper looked relatively at ease; Haddock looked like… a fish out of water! Despite beating the bat on numerous occasions the HH opening pair started to accumulate runs and it brought a bowling change that put an end to the partnership. McGowan steadied the sinking Ballinger ship as he introduced a measure of calm## as the run rate was stifled by some intelligent bowling. As a result Capper’s runs had been capped and he departed for 21 as he gave a caught and bowled to McGowan who took the catch at the third attempt## whilst doing his best to impersonate a circus performer! This brought Shrimpton to the crease and whilst Shrimp and Haddock is more widely seen on the menus of fish restaurants## the stormy Ballinger waters were too much for him as he was caught by Salisbury off fisherman’s friend## Jack Maciver. 2 wickets down soon became 3 as Napier-Munn was cleaned up by the impressive Maciver who was bowling like a cod (or should that be god?). Suddenly Ballinger sensed a way back into the match. Unfortunately Holt played a sensible innings and moved HH to within reach of the target## meanwhile Haddock was still scoring runs but was getting well and truly battered by the Ballinger attack and on many occasions went fishing outside his off stump although Ballinger could never reel him in. However once geography genius Dom Birkby had gotten rid of Holt with the worst ball of the day## Haddock soon was caught. Maciver bowled an absolute kipper of a delivery## Haddock took the bait and ‘safe hands’ Salisbury took the catch. Out – hook## line and sinker for a decent 75! With 5 down## was their really a chance of an unlikely victory for Ballinger? Unfortunately not as Burgham played a powerful but chanceless innings of 40* which brought HH home in 33 overs.

 Overall a disappointing result for Ballinger although it was a good## if not a bit dull## game played in the right spirit. HH deserved their win and Ballinger now look to rebuild next week against Berkhamsted where cross-county honour is at state! Special mention goes to Jack Maciver who was very impressive with the ball## finishing with figures of 9-2-25-3.

On paper this was going to be a toughie. Phoenix are the current table toppers and look set to gain promotion to Div. 2## however Ballinger did enjoy a relatively comfortable victory in the reverse fixture earlier in the season. So the question on everyone’s lips was whether or not Phoenix would continue there winning ways or would Ballinger rise from the ashes much like a… Phoenix## and claim quite a scalp.

Having lost the toss Ballinger were put into the field and the mix of youthful exuberance and experience at first capped the Phoenix run scoring with Joe Hankinson and Evan Webster bowling well. However no wicket was taken and Phoenix began to get into their stride as Jackson especially started to bludgeon the Ballinger bowling attack around. Unfortunately for Ballinger bowling changes did not stop the momentum and whilst wickets fell steadily at one end Jackson continued his onslaught## helped considerably by Ballinger’s profligacy in the field## dropping him 8 times! In the end he went for one too many big hits and was stumped by Will Smith for 159## Phoenix then very sportingly declared soon after with the score on 260 off 40 overs.

In reply Ballinger were up against it with the required rate up around 7 right from the off. This however did phase Ballinger’s young batting line up and Max Maciver and Will Smith played very positively with both particularly strong off the back foot. The partnership however was broken when Max was caught at slip unluckily for 47 and soon after Harry Bartlett followed. The brought Bastie Richards (47) to the crease and he straight away took the attack to the Phoenix bowlers with some crushing blows on the leg side. With Ballinger still in with a shout of winning the game Will eventually fell for an excellent 80 and Joe Hankinson came and in and out in quick time. As Ballinger started going for there shots and pressurising the opposition##  more wickets fell## which left Rob McIntyre (23)## Tom McIntyre (12*) and Nigel Kerry (2*) to bat Ballinger out for the draw at 239-7.

Overall this was an excellent game played in good spirit and a very good result against top the table opposition. Particular mentions got Max Maciver## Will Smith and Bastie Richards for some excellent knocks## especially Bastie for smashing a tile on the clubhouse with a huge six! Finally thanks to Phoenix for being amicable hosts and providing an excellent tea!

Nearly an hour into the match - J Cox (Downley's prolific opener and serial destroyer of BWCC) going ominously well - the ball soars upward and straight down into the waiting hands of Paul Humphreys - then out of them onto the parched turf. Ballinger joy turns to instant grief. Paul wishes aforesaid turf would open and swallow him (as did the bowler).

Having lost yet another toss ## but seen his ploy of opening with spin (Ian Maciver) pay off with a wicket in the first over##and the Downley No 3 virtually strokeless against very tight bowling from Maciver## and especially Nick Adams(12 overs for only 18 runs## but undeservedly no wickets)## skipper Riley must have thought## as that ball flew skywards## that at last it was going to be his day. But in fact Cox was to add only 1 run to his score before being comprehensively bowled by Ian Davies (cue display of unbridled exstatic joy by bowler). After this reverse## The Downley batsmen dug in## but steadily became more aggressive## the change bowlers suffered accordingly## and the 4th wicket did not fall until 176 was on the board## with 38 overs gone. Two excellent run-outs## and Ballinger had hopes of wrapping up the innings for under 200## but as last week## the tail wagged## and the innings closed on 225-8## with Ian Maciver (limping again## hamstring this time !)the chief wicket taker ( 4 for 52).

In reply## Ballinger's early batting failed for once## and 3 wickets were down for 31. However## Rollo(25) and Richard O'Kelly(24) repaired the damage for a while## but with 7 down for a mere 113## and 29 overs gone## the target of 226 looked a far distant dream. Not for the first time the Maciver family had other ideas. Jack was striking the ball cleanly and hard## and Ian## making light of the hamstring## took every half chance of a run. They had put on 62 for the 8th wicket before Jack fell for a fine 43## with 6 overs left. By this time Downley were visibly rattled at the prospect of losing a match that had for long seemed in the bag. Ian's excellent knock ended when he was bowled for 35## but Nick Adams kept home hopes on the boil with a trademark bustling 22## before he too perished## leaving Ballinger a tantalising 17 runs short.

For the second week running## a close finish## with a good team performance  -AND we had an umpire ! (Roger Webster - thanks!). All we need now are some winning points.

Ballinger made the trip to one of the most picturesque grounds we play at yesterday as they took on Long Marston on baking hot day. Captain Hunting won the toss and opted to bat on what has been a notoriously flat wicket. Unfortunately for Ballinger things did not start too well with both Paul Humphreys and Will Smith going early. However with the score on a precarious 33-2## Joe Hankinson and James Wood steadied the ship with a partnership of 70 before Joe went for 28. James then went soon after for an excellent 54## and thereafter it was left to Jamie Kellock (37)## Jeremy Hunting (28) and Tom Maw (21*) to take Ballinger to a respectable 220-9

After another excellent tea Long Marston set about the task of chasing down the runs. The two Hankinson’s opened up for Ballinger and whilst not being too threatening they did contain the Long Marston batsmen well with Joe taking the first wicket. This however brought Slade and Beardmore to the crease and both started to play with a bit more freedom as the Ballinger change bowlers came on. Jake Cutter bowled well on the while whilst Phil Lloyd was his usual steady self. However it brought another change of bowling that brought the prized wicket## Phil Doyle having Beardmore caught off his first ball by Jake Cutter. This led to a mini collapse as 4 wickets fell quickly## however this did not change the cause of the result as Beasley and Wareman saw Long Marston home with 6 overs## finishing on 224-6.

Overall this was another good game played in good spirit at a very good ground. Teas were excellent as usual and James Wood’s 54 was probably the best innings of the match. Next week the Ballinger machine will try to get back to winning ways against Amersham Hill at home.

Phew – where do I start?  A strong BWCC Sunday side brimming with batting and bowling## an Amersham Hill side wishing to play 40/40 rather than a timed game.

 

Home advantage prevailed and “proper” cricket was duly played. BWCC were inserted and AH looked to have made the right decision when the BWCC was 0-1 after 1 over with Max Maciver back in the hutch.  They would have changed their minds when the next wicket fell 230 runs later when Paul Humphreys was out for 150 having surpassed Rollo McIntyre’s highest previous individual score of 148* set only last season. Paul’s dismissal also saw a new record for the 2nd wicket with  Danny Draper (playing his first game of the season)## beating the previous record of 220 set in 1976## one of the longest standing club records.

Whilst AH’s bowling was pretty mediocre## it takes concentration and application to develop a score of this magnitude## and Paul destroyed the bowling after a watchful start – well done## Paul!  Danny went on to score 87 with a rapid partnership of 37 with Joe Hankinson (22). Bastie Richards sacrificed his wicket in the search for quick runs to get to a declaration score of 271 – 5 after 39 overs.

 

In common with BWCC## AH also lost a wicket in the first over## an opener comprehensively bowled by Jack Hankinson who rediscovered the zip and control missing for the last couple of weeks. After a stand of about 40## largely as a result of attacking fields and risky lofted shots against Jack Maciver (6-0-47-0) ## the second wicket fell ## again bowled by Jack Hankinson.

 

The AH No.4 played a few shots but was caught by Jack Maciver off Phil Lloyd (5-0-53-1). This bought Newton to the wicket who signalled his intentions by hitting his first ball for 6! 

 

Enter Dom Birkby## obviously buoyed by his personal dietician in attendance ( his Mum## Linda## providing a first class tea!). Dom dismissed their other opener for 31##courtesy  of another Jack Maciver catch and went on to bowl a fine spell of 12-1-44-3##  the only bowler to exercise any control on the batting side who## by this stage## were plundering runs with Newton in full flow and clearing the boundary ropes on a regular basis.

AH entered the last 20 overs with approx 120 needed to win. Max Maciver ( 11-0-78-2) was already bowling by this stage but## whilst managing to take a couple of wickets## we were unable to get the prize wicket of Newton (133*) who reached a fine## if lucky## century.

6 overs left## 30 odd runs needed and 8 wickets down. Last throw of the dice## Jack Hankinson (10-0-35-3) back into the attack and bowling their no.10. Ultimately## we were unable to take their last wicket and AH scored the winning run of the penultimate over## having faced 47 overs..

 

Whilst on the whole## we batted and bowled well## the Ballinger affliction of lazy fielding and dropped catches## some difficult## some simple## determined the result.

A great game of cricket and## satisfyingly## a triumph for timed games over 40/40## as admitted by AH over a beer in the Old Swan later. Although## upon reflection it was## admittedly## a generous declaration ( as told to skipper Hunting in no uncertain terms by that master tactician Sarah Maciver!) it would have been a dead game as a limited over game with AH never having been able to get close to our score.

Stand in captain Rix won the toss and invited Potten End to bat on a belter of a track. Misguided? Well that's what Mr Kerry would have done and we did have a lot of batting. However after 10 overs with the score on 84-0 the received wisdom was that there was no wisdom.

Cue Max (bat 'n bowl) Maciver and itinerant bowler Harry Rix.

Within 3 overs 4 wickets were taken (2 each) and 92-4 became 107-5## 118-6 and very quickly 169 all out in just 27 overs.

"Bat 'n Bowl" posted mightily impressive figures of 6-20 whilst Harry chipped in with 3-48 and a couple of catches and George Kingston marked his debut with a wicket and some excellent ground fielding.

 

So## having looked down the barrel at 250+ Ballinger now had 58 overs to reach our target at a very acceptable 3 an over.

Rix the older had no hesitation in asking Harry Bartlett and "Bat 'n Bowl" to open as we still had 45 minutes until tea. Two quality 14 year olds on a blameless track## lightning outfield and some fairly ordinary bowling equalled slaughter on an unparalleled scale. Bartlett set the scene with a pulled 6 in the first over and then accelerated. So much so that when we broke for tea at 4.15pm the score was 134-0 in 15 overs.

 

Tea gave everyone the chance to reflect on what was fast becoming a very strange match but to be honest the tea quickly became more important with everything from cheese straws to scones## jam and whipped cream courtesy of the wonderful talents of Heidi and Harry Petrie (great baking Harry!).

 

Play resumed and incredibly within 2 overs the remaining 38 runs required were acquired. It really was that type of match.

Both Harry and Max were rightly applauded for their high quality batting. Harry finishing on 93 and Max on 61 and frankly all one could do was congratulate them## they did everything right and not a thing wrong.

Time to look in record books perhaps. A win by 10 wickets with 31 overs remaining and an unbroken partnership of 172 must equal some sort of milestone?

Apologies for the several players who frankly had little to do but with a total match length of 44 overs and not a wicket lost it certainly was one of those days!

Another close and interesting match. Our first encounter of the season with bottom-of-the-league Chesham Bois## the earlier fixture having been rained off## this was the match that Ballinger had to win if they are to stand much chance of survival in the premier division. Fortuitously## a good start## in that yet again skipper Riley called wrongly## but found himself invited to bat first## which he would have done anyway had he won. However## evidently Chesham Bois had a fair idea that the pitch would misbehave - which indeed it did. Three Ballinger wickets were down by the 9th over## and a mere 28 on the board. A rescue mission was launched by Rollo and Jack Maciver## both batting sensibly. Together they put on 63 (the game's highest stand by far) ## but in the 24th over Rollo departed for a hard-hitting 41## rapidly followed by Jack for 27. Thereafter none of the remaining batsmen could survive the vagaries of the pitch## though a dogged last wicket partnership by Ian Maciver (17) and Jack Hankinson saw Ballinger crawl to a final total of 135## with 4.5 overs unused.

With plenty of time to get the runs## the odds were all in favour of Chesham Bois## and indeed ## although there was unsurprisingly a lot of playing and missing## Ballinger did not achieve a breakthrough until the 13th over## by which time the score was already 41. Nick Adams (4-39) was causing problems from the far end## but any loose balls were promptly dispatched to the boundary## and neither of the two young Jacks could work any magic from the pavilion end. However## wickets were falling - two in the 40's## two in the 70's## and 4 in the 90's## with Ian Maciver (4-27) getting us into what seemed likley to be a winning position with score at 98 for 8. Then it all went wrong. Two difficult catches went down## the score crept steadily upwards## and Ballinger were simply unable to break a ninth wicket partnership that eventually yielded 38 runs and saw Chesham Bois home by 2 wickets.

A very disappointing result## but too many of Ballinger's batsmen did not perform## and left the bowlers around 30 runs short of a defendable target. Also## Ballinger conceded 17 extras## as against the opposition's  4 - over-generous in such a low scoring match.

A visit to bottom of the table Prestwood should be an opportunity to 'fill your boots' as a batsman or make significant improvements to your bowling average.Unfortunately this doesn't seem to happen when we play them.

Having won the toss skipper Kerry was very happy to be able to choose to not bat first on what looked a very dodgy wicket.(dodgy only because we're being spoilt by the quality of the wickets at HQ.) He was then a bit non-plussed by only having 7 players to start the match with. 'keeper Harry Bartlett arrived in the nick of time and with Harri Doyle substituting for the missing 3 players off we went.

Of the missing three## two thought they were playing on Sunday and the other## having only been playing league cricket for the club for about five years## thought it was a 2pm start. Commendably the the two made it from Beaconsfield## home## changed and to the ground within 30mins of the start.

To the game. Evan Webster and Tom Sperring(0-27) opened for the Waggoners and both kept the Prestwood openers under control. In fact when Evan bowled Kinsman in the 10th over the skipper was a little peaved because it meant opening the door for Prestwood's Capeling. This is a player who should be competing at a higher level. He scores runs against us every time we play them and this was to be no exception. He opened his scoring with a straight six off Evan that  disappeared out of the ground and over the farm opposite. He then hit Tom for another enormous six.

The skipper decided that a change of pace and a bit of experience was needed. This meant the introduction of Max 'Bat and Bowl'Maciver and Phil LLoyd. He couldn't play Max and Phil bowled too tight a line to him## add some very defensive field placings and we finally slowed him down. Unfortunately Capeling(47) and opener Greaves were still ticking along at 5 an over. Greaves was run out by a brilliant bit of fielding by Phil LLoyd but this was topped by a fantastic catch by Monty Thompson to remove Capeling.

Alex Howe was then introduced into the attack and produced a couple of beauties to rest control back to Ballinger and it looked like 130 was going to be the hight of the home sides ambition. Unfortunately## once again we were confounded by some late order hitting by the Prestwood batters. Monty(1-31) and Evan(3-55) bore the brunt of this but it was good to see both Evan and Tom bowling decent spells at the death. 187 was probably 30 more than the home side should have reached.

It's taken me six paragraphs to describe the start of the game and our fielding efforts. The batting is somewhat more straight forward.Max and Harry put on 152 for the 1st wicket  with Max out in the 27th over for 65 followed by Harry in the 28th for 74. They were helped by some very generous fielders but frankly they are both too good for this level of cricket. They may find the next couple of matches a bit more testing.

This left 12 overs for us to pass the opposition score. A brief flurry from Phil Doyle followed by a professional display by Phil LLoyd(17*) and Nick Howe(12*) saw the Waggoners home with 5 overs to spare.

Another excellent win with once again the game played in the right way.

For once## fortune smiled on Ballinger. The cream of Knotty Green's bowlers had departed for a wedding in Italy## and Matt Riley had at last won the toss. Not that his decision to bat first## given Ballinger's recent batting performances## and a wicket soft on top from overnight and morning rain##was clear-cut. As it was## Ballinger were off to an exceptionally watchful start## with the scoreboard reading just 6 after 7 overs. Then Paul Humphreys launched into a series of huge 6's## doubtless influenced by his mammoth innings of the previous Sunday. But when in full flow and seeming likely to endanger the record books again## he checked a shot and offered a tame catch - out for 28. Matt## after facing an initial 26 dot balls## then got going and kept Ian Davies company until he was out for an increasingly confident 38## with the total on 74. Ian saw the 100 up## but was then the first victim of two Caught & Bowled dismissals off consecutive balls. Jack Maciver as usual was batting with increasing authority## but fell for 37. With the total now 130## 6 wickets down## and 34 overs gone## the scene was set for another below-par Ballinger score. Except that Andy Thompson## with a superlative 55 not out## and Ian Maciver (26 n.o) had other ideas. In the remaining 11 overs they put together an undefeated stand of 82## showing great enterprise with quick singles## and took Ballinger to a praiseworthy 212 - 6 at 45 overs.

Tea coincided with a heavy shower## but play soon got under way## and Knotty Green## after losing a key wicket to Jack Hankinson's second ball yorker## had reached 43 for 2 by the time more## and heavier## rain arrived. By the time the pitch had drained sufficiently to allow play to resume## 9 overs' play had been lost## and KG's attentions turned to achieving a winning draw based on run-rate## Messrs Duckworth/Lewis having not yet influenced the Mid-Bucks League law-makers.. They had advanced their total to 54 before man-of-the-match first change bowler Andy Thompson struck. 54 for 2 became 78 all out in the space of 9 overs## as the hapless KG batsmen were comprehensively destroyed by Thompson (5 for 20) and Paul Humphreys ( 3 for 9)## backed up by excellent fielding and catching. Skipper Riley## keeping wicket for the first time this season in a league match## was particularly pleased with his two catches and one miserly bye!

Perhaps too late to stave off relegation## but nevertheless a very satisfying result## and a great day for the Thompsons - ten year old Freddie## called up at the last minute## fielded splendidly at fine leg. Lots of jugs at the Old Swan afterwards rounded off a good day for BWCC.

BWCC 291-4 40 overs   The Lee CC 145 AO 39 overs

 

In sport there the odd occasions where a game## be it football or cricket etc## are so one sided that one could use words such as a ‘destruction’## or a ‘pasting’. Notable recent examples that spring to mind immediately would be the demolition of Germany in Berlin by the England football team in the run up to the 2002 world cup and the hammering handed out by Australia to American Samoa in the qualifiers for the same tournament. The score on this occasion was a scarcely believable 36-0!! Whilst Ballinger’s comprehensive victory over The Lee on the 8th August was not world record breaking it was certainly record breaking: highest first wicket partnership and biggest winning margin for starters. Anyway to the game… (the author of this report was not actually at the game so please allow for some poetic license!).

 

It was a fine day as the mighty men of Ballinger drove the short distance to the picturesque and pleasant ground which is home to The Lee. This was billed as a battle of the heavyweights and even had the usually reserved Daily Telegraph columnist Henry Winter salivating at the prospect of such cricketing giant’s battle out to the death. Ballinger captain Salisbury## did not comment as he arrived but was whisked off to the changing rooms away from all the hype of the following media circus. The steely expression that engrossed his face however said all that was needed; this was a big game for his experienced side. As the crowd filtered in## the team sheets were handed in and Ballinger lined up strongly with Riley making a return to the Sunday side along with Draper making his second (?) appearance of the season. Meanwhile the usual suspects of Hankinson’s## Kellock## Maciver and Humphreys made up an awe inspiring line up!

 

With the pitch freshly cut## painted and stumps grounded## play was ready to commence. The Lee won the first battle as they correctly called the coin toss and chose to have a bowl in what would be a 40 over win/lose shootout. Opening up for Ballinger were Riley and Draper. Both began slowly but as time went on both found there stride and Ballinger were rocketing along at a very healthy rate with Riley particularly punishing anything that was short and wide. Ballinger were soon past 100 with no real scares and then 150 was pasted too. With the pair serenely progressing on the record books were scrambled and as they edged closer to 200 the record for the first wicket partnership was getting even closer. Inevitably Ballinger did lose a wicket but not however after Riley and Draper wrote themselves into the annals of Ballinger Waggoners history with the highest first wicket partnership ever. It really was a pleasure to watch (for those there!) such fine cricket! The wicket that fell was that of Riley who creamed a cover drive over The Lee in field… or so he thought. Unfortunately the cover fielder leapt like a salmon 5ft of the ground and plucked it one handed. Amazing. Out for 86 hitting 11 fours and 2 sixes. (Please note I haven’t a clue if that is accurate## all I know is Matt was caught!). Anyway 212-1 soon 219-2 as Draper## who had brought his century in style by smashing the ball to the point boundary fell for a magnificent 107 hitting 19 fours and 1 six in the process. Enter Joe Hankinson and Jeremy Hunting. With overs running out Hankinson continued his fine form smashing the bowling all over the place with a very rapid 45 which included 8 fours and 1 six. When Joe fell Kellcok unfortunately could not join the party as he fell for 1 but Jeremy and Jack Maciver took Ballinger to the close without any further loss## with Ballinger finishing on a towering 291-4 off their allotted 40 overs.

 

Following another superb tea from The Lee## Ballinger may well have been excused for starting slowly but were right on the button straight away with the Jack duo bowling fast and straight. Jack Hankinson was his usual economic self whilst Jack Maciver provided a superb exhibition of fast bowling taking 5-20 of his 10 overs; it was no surprise then that he was mobbed by autograph hunters at the end of the game. Stuart MacGowan was also his steady self as he ripped through The Lee’s middle order with an expert spell of off spin bowling that claimed 3 wickets in a very economical 7 over spell. The other wicket taker was Salisbury who somehow managed to bore the batsmen into submission! Fallowfield-Smith## Kellock and Joe Hankinson also turned their arms over but to no avail. With 7 wickets being bowled the only catch fell to Paul Humphreys. Whilst I would love to say it involved diving 30 yards to his right and plucking it one handed## something tells it may have been a regulation slip catch! So whilst Ballinger’s bowling was exemplary## Morrison (45) and Jones (35) did put up some fighting resilience that was so lacking in The Lee’s batting but unfortunately their stand only delayed the inevitable and eventually The Lee were bowled out for 145 in 39 overs## meaning a winning margin of 146 runs## another club record.

 

From what I can see this was a thoroughly professional Ballinger performance against a side that was not at full strength. Two club records were broken and in Danny Draper and Jack Maciver Ballinger had 2 very creditable candidates for man of the match. Well played guys!

BWCC 187-10 37 overs    Cublington CC 130 AO 34.4 overs

After last week’s demolition of The Lee## Ballinger travelled to Cublington to play their second game of the season against the very friendly people of Cublington. As the team arrived## the ground superb despite the recent heavy rainfall but Ballinger had bigger concerns. Who was their11th man? Gradually the Ballinger rabble and somehow we had a full team.

 

Once the toss had been made Ballinger were put into bat and Paul Humphreys and Will Smith opened up. Unfortunately Paul departed early unluckily having played on. At this point the pitch was not playing too well and the ball was moving all over. Next man Tom Maw and Will began to rebuild for Ballinger. Gradually they took the score on although it did take 8 or so overs for Tom to get off the mark. However with the score on 40 Will edged Cublington’s overseas Australian to first slip and Ballinger were once again in trouble. Jeremy Hunting then joined Tom and both started to accumulate runs and soon enough the Ballinger 100 was up. Unfortunately with the score on 133 Tom got bored and tried to smash the ball out of the park and got bowled for a very patient 43## meanwhile Jeremy began to accelerate the Ballinger innings as wickets started to fall regularly at the other end. Eventually Jeremy fell for an excellent 61 and Ballinger subsided to 187 all out of 37 overs## 3 short of their allotted 40. Cublington’s stand out bowler was their overseas Westlands who took 4 wickets including a hat-trick.

 

In reply Cublington started very slowly due to some excellent bowling by the young Ballinger attack. Jack Hankinson recorded excellent figures## conceding only 5 runs on his 6.3 overs whilst taking 3 wickets. Mr Cricket Dom Birkby was even more economical## recording figures of 8-3-11-1. An excellent display from Nottingham University’s No. 1 Geographer. Whilst Jono Lacey also bowled well it was Joe Hankinson that ripped the heart out of Cublington’s innings including the prized wicket of Westlands. Although the Cublington lower order put up some creditable lower order resistance it was the superb bowling of Graham Salisbury and Tom Maw that did for Cublington who end on 130 all out. An excellent victory by 57 runs. The Ballinger machine rumbles on…
BWCC 186 AO   Aldenham CC 189-5
Longwick 216-5 46 overs    BWCC 144-6 43 overs
Aldbury Entertainers 76 AO BWCC 80-3 19 overs
BWCC 245-4 Ley Hill CC 152-9
BWCC 247-3 42 overs  St Albans 192-8 44 overs

There was a lot of damage arising from this match against Monks Risborough## mostly in the form of dented vehicles and dented bowling figures. Under overcast skies## stand-in skipper Davies performed a minor miracle (his only one of the day) by winning the toss## and with a strong batting line-up## decided to take first knock. There followed a heartwarming exhibition of cultured batting by openers Paul Humphreys and Richard O'Kelly. The score had rattled along at six an over until Richard was caught (in flagrant jug-avoidance) for 49## the partnership having yielded 129. Paul## batting with serene confidence## was stroking the ball effortlessly around the park## until## with his score on 96## made a complete mess of a straight one - 165 for 2. Meanwhile Rollo too was cashing in on a pitch which was actually not as easy (the batsmen claimed) as the run-rate made it appear. The score continued to mount at a most un-Ballinger rate## and Ian Davies (having narrowly avoided subs-collection duties) after much pondering declared the innings closed after 44 overs## on 281 for 6.

Past experience with the Monks Risborough approach to batting indicated that they were perfectly capable of a Pakistan (or England) style collapse## or blasting their way towards (or past) 300 with ease. Ballinger had an attack that was missing only Nick Adams## and so had every hope of success. Instead## they got wallopped all over the place## with only two bowlers achieving respectable figures - Andy Thompson## with another excellent 12 over spell taking 5 for 69## and Jack Hankinson (11 overs## 2 for 49). There were no dropped catches## the fielding was exemplary - but the opposition batsmen## notably R Shah (97) were simply too good## taking the aerial route to the boundary with depressing frequency## and reached their target with 7 wickets down## and 2.5 overs to spare.

A veritable run-fest## and Mr Kellock (DNB) was indeed proud of his pitch ! Most enjoyable## just a pity we didn't win.

An excellent performance from a young side## well supported by the three senior players.

The toss was won by stand in skipper Derek Richards who opted to put Frieth in to bat## following a steady drizzle which delayed the start of the game.

Tom Sperring tore into the Frieth opening batsmenwith a superb bowling display iin which only 26 runs were conceded from his seven overs. Phil Lloyd## introduced into the attack## following an early injury to Ben Carlin## provided the backbone to the team's bowling with two spells totalling 11 overs in which he claimed 1-32.

The initial burst from the seamers was then taken up by the young spinners## each of whom bowled superbly. Max maciver with 2-35 of 8 overs## Jake Cutter with 3-37 off 6 overs ans Rob Rose with 2-17 off 4 overs.

The outcome was that astrong and experienced Frieth side were restricted to 194-8 off 39 overs by the fine ballinger bowling performance## well supported by some fine fielding## Tom Sperring and Max Maciver in particular.

Ballinger## in reply## had an early wobble which saw the early removal of Max Maciver and Will Smith. Enter the stand in skipper with a defiant knock in support of a sublime innings from Rob McIntyre. The innings resumed on course until the score reached 59 when Richards fell.

Tom McIntyre was next to the crease and produced a superb innings. Both Rob and Tom took the match to Frieth and their partnership was a superb display from both players. Unfortunately Rob perished chasing runs and the later batsmen were unable to continue to match the required strike rate despite valiant attemts from Sebastian Richards and Phil Lloyd to support Tom McIntryre. In the end Tom McIntyre and Tom Sperring saw the match out to a draw with Ballinger finishing on 179 for 7.

On a personal note## many thanks to Phil Lloyd## who has probably played his last match for Ballinger. Phil's enthusiasm and support for the younger players will be sorely missed and all at the Club wish him well. 

All in all## a very enjoyable afternoon in a match which was played in exactly the right manner and many thanks to Frieth for their sporting performance.

CDCC – 187 all out. 

BWCC – 166-8

 

An unknown strength fixture following Little Gaddesden’s cancellation – skipper## Salisbury## was pleased to lose the toss so he had no decision to make! The visitors chose to bat on a pitch that had seen 550 plus runs scored on it the previous day ( notwithstanding some overnight rain).

 

Whilst having had to agree to a 40 over game to get the fixture## we agreed no limitation on number of overs per bowler (with the intention of bowling Dom Birkby in to the ground!)

 

Birkby opened the bowling (14-0-61-1) with McGowan (8-0-51-2) and both took early wickets as the openers perished. CDCC’s Nos. 3 and 4 batted sensibly albeit with some luck## O’Donohue eventually falling for 62## bowled by Max Maciver going for a big shot.

 

A turning point in their innings came when the CDCC’s No. 4 was run out for 40. The umpire gave it “not out” as he was standing in totally the wrong place! The batsman advised the umpire that he had’nt made his ground and walked off – so good to see the spirit of the game being upheld – this conduct being replicated in BWCC’s innings when Max Maciver walked when having been given “not out” caught behind – a show of some  maturity at Max’s age and particularly when on 0 at the time!

 

BWCC fielding for the first 30 overs was exemplary – unfortunately not so in the last 10 overs## when catches were dropped## meaning that CDCC reached 187 all out in 37 overs rather than a score of no more than 160 which would have been more representative of their efforts. Max Maciver was the pick of the bowlers and ended up with 5 wickets (##10.3-2-43-5) ##Will Smith assisting with 2 catches. Jake Cutter suffered from dropped catches in his late spell of 4-0-27- 0.

 

4.00pm  - tea not being ready## the decision was made to give BWCC 20 minutes gentle batting before tea.

4.30pm – BWCC score stands at 5-5 with the innings in disarray with 4 of the first 5 batsmen out for 0## with Will Smith looking on## bewildered## at the other end!

 

Whilst there was a suggestion from some quarters that “at least we would be in the pub early”## skipper## Salisbury## had very different ideas. The bowler who had done the damage## bowling gentle away swingers## had been the beneficiary of at least 2 soft dismissals and his figures flattered.

 

Smith W and Salisbury continued after tea very watchfully taking the score to 33 when Will was unluckily given out in the 9th over## caught at square  leg## off what looked suspiciously like a no ball full toss.

 

Skipper and vice skipper## Hunting## then had a mid square discussion## the upshot of which was that they decided that they really did’nt want the embarrassment of being thrashed by a side that## frankly## was certainly no better than BWCC.  Minds concentrated## they set about turning things round## initially just picking up quick singles and rotating the strike. Graham S was severe on anything short and wide and kept deep cover point busy all afternoon. Salisbury and Hunting put on 92 for the 7th wicket and were left with an achievable 8 runs an over to win off the last 10 overs. At this point## the skipper made his only mistake of the afternoon (other than a dropped catch!) by giving Hunting licence to start playing some shots. The inevitable ensued and Hunting was bowled for 36.

Nick Tegg (17) hit some lusty blows but we ended up 22 runs short of what would have been a fairly miraculous recovery## Graham having played a classic “captain’s innings” of 81*.

In short## a good game of cricket ( despite being limited overs!)  played in the right spirit.
