BWCC 291-4 40 overs   The Lee CC 145 AO 39 overs

In sport there the odd occasions where a game## be it football or cricket etc## are so one sided that one could use words such as a ‘destruction’## or a ‘pasting’. Notable recent examples that spring to mind immediately would be the demolition of Germany in Berlin by the England football team in the run up to the 2002 world cup and the hammering handed out by Australia to American Samoa in the qualifiers for the same tournament. The score on this occasion was a scarcely believable 36-0!! Whilst Ballinger’s comprehensive victory over The Lee on the 8th August was not world record breaking it was certainly record breaking: highest first wicket partnership and biggest winning margin for starters. Anyway to the game… (the author of this report was not actually at the game so please allow for some poetic license!).

It was a fine day as the mighty men of Ballinger drove the short distance to the picturesque and pleasant ground which is home to The Lee. This was billed as a battle of the heavyweights and even had the usually reserved Daily Telegraph columnist salivating at the prospect of such cricketing giant’s battle out to the death. Ballinger captain Salisbury## did not comment as he arrived but was whisked off to the changing rooms away from all the hype of the following media circus. The steely expression that engrossed his face however said all that was needed; this was a big game for his experienced side. As the crowd filtered in## the team sheets were handed and Ballinger lined up strongly with Riley making a return to the Sunday side along with Draper making his second (?) appearance of the season. Meanwhile the usual suspects of Hankinson’s## Kellock## Maciver and Humphreys made up an awe inspiring line up!

 

With the pitch freshly cut## painted and stumps grounded## play was ready to commence. The Lee won the first battle as they correctly the coin toss and chose to have a bowl in what would be a 40 over win/lose shootout. Opening up for Ballinger were Riley and Draper. Both began slowly but as time went on both found there stride and Ballinger were rocketing along at a very healthy rate with Riley particularly punishing anything that was short and wide. Ballinger were soon past 100 with no real scares and then 150 was pasted too. With the pair serenely progressing on the record books were scrambled and as they edged closer to 200 the record for the first wicket partnership was getting even closer. Inevitably Ballinger did lose a wicket but not however after Riley and Draper wrote themselves into the annals of Ballinger Waggoners history with the highest first wicket partnership ever. It really was a pleasure to watch (for those there!) such fine cricket! The wicket that fell was that of Riley who creamed a cover drive over The Lee in field… or so he thought. Unfortunately the cover fielder leapt like a salmon 5ft of the ground and plucked it one handed. Amazing. Out for 86 hitting 11 fours and 2 sixes. (Please note I haven’t a clue of that is accurate## all I know is Matt was caught!). Anyway 212-1 soon 219-2 as Draper## who had brought his century in style by smashing the ball to the point boundary fell for a magnificent 107 hitting 19 fours and 1 six in the process. Enter Joe Hankinson and Jeremy Hunting. With overs running out Hankinson continued his fine form smashing the bowling all over the place with a very rapid 45 which included 8 fours and 1 six. When Joe fell Kellcok unfortunately could not join the party as he fell for 1 but Jeremy and Jack Maciver took Ballinger to the close without any further loss of the wickets## with Ballinger finishing on a towering 291-4 off their allotted 40 overs. 

Following another superb tea from The Lee## Ballinger may well have been excused for starting slowly but were right on the button straight away with the Jack duo bowling fast and straight. Jack Hankinson was his usual economic self whilst Jack Maciver provided a superb exhibition of fast bowling taking 5-20 of his 10 overs; it was no surprise then that he was mobbed by autograph hunters at the end of the game. Stuart MacGowan was also his steady self as he ripped through The Lee’s middle order with an expert spell of off spin bowling that claimed 3 wickets in a very economical 7 over spell. The other wicket taker was Salisbury who somehow managed to bore the batsmen into submission! Fallowfield-Smith## Kellock and Joe Hankinson also turned their arms over but to no avail. With 7 wickets being bowled the only catch fell to Paul Humphreys. Whilst I would love to say it involved diving 30 yards to his right and plucking it one handed## something tells it may have been a regulation slip catch! So whilst Ballinger’s bowling was exemplary## Morrison (45) and Jones (35) did put up some fighting resilience that was so lacking in The Lee’s batting but unfortunately their stand only delayed the inevitable and eventually The Lee were bowled out for 145 in 39 overs## meaning a winning margin of 146 runs## another club record.

From what I can see this was a thoroughly professional Ballinger performance against a side that was not a full strength. Two club records were broken and in Danny Draper and Jack Maciver Ballinger had 2 very creditable candidates for man of the match. Well played guys!

BWCC 187-10 37 overs    Cublington CC 130 AO 34.4 overs

After last week’s demolition of The Lee## Ballinger travelled to Cublington to play their second game of the season against the very friendly people of Cublington. As the team arrived## the ground superb despite the recent heavy rainfall but Ballinger had bigger concerns. Who was their11th man? Gradually the Ballinger rabble and somehow we had a full team.

Once the toss had been made Ballinger were put into bat and Paul Humphreys and Will Smith opened up. Unfortunately Paul departed early unluckily having played on. At this point the pitch was not playing too well and the ball was moving all over. Next man Tom Maw and Will began to rebuild for Ballinger. Gradually they took the score on although it did take 8 or so overs for Tom to get off the mark. However with the score on 40 Will edged Cublington’s overseas Australian to first slip and Ballinger were once again in trouble. Jeremy Hunting then joined Tom and both started to accumulate runs and soon enough the Ballinger 100 was up. Unfortunately with the score on 133 Tom got bored and tried to smash the ball out of the park and got bowled for a very patient 43## meanwhile Jeremy began to accelerate the Ballinger innings as wickets started to fall regularly at the other end. Eventually Jeremy fell for an excellent 61 and Ballinger subsided to 187 all out of 37 overs## 3 short of their allotted 40. Cublington’s stand out bowler was their overseas Westlands who took 4 wickets including a hat-trick.

In reply Cublington started very slowly due to some excellent bowling by the young Ballinger attack. Jack Hankinson recorded excellent figures## conceding only 5 runs on his 6.3 overs whilst taking 3 wickets. Mr Cricket Dom Birkby was even more economical## recording figures of 8-3-11-1. An excellent display from Nottingham University’s No. 1 Geographer. Whilst Jono Lacey also bowled well it was Joe Hankinson that ripped the heart out of Cublington’s innings including the prized wicket of Westlands. Although the Cublington lower order put up some creditable lower order resistance it was the superb bowling of Graham Salisbury and Tom Maw that did for Cublington who end on 130 all out. An excellent victory by 57 runs. The Ballinger machine rumbles on…

This was a disappointing end to another excellent season for the 2s. Not only because the rain curtailed the game but the manner in which the team played wasn't to the standards set throughout the summer. In particular the bowling wasn't as good as we have come to expect. Some interesting umpiring plus some wayward bowling meant we bowled 22 wides and 7 no-balls. Basically we gave the visitors another 5 overs to bat.

Neave## Waddesdons opener scored an excellent 112 but he was very limited in the shots he could play and most were of the leg-side variety. Unfortunately on a slow pitch all the bowlers gave him plenty of opportunities to practice them. Alex Howe was probably the pick with 2-25 in his 7 overs. Evan Webster took another 4 wickets in what has been an excellent season for him## but even he had to agree that he wasn't quite at his best in this game.

Skipper Kerry won the toss and put Waddesdon in on what he thought was likely to be a difficult pitch to bat on. Unfortunately the fact that nearly 900 runs were scored on it last week should have been more of a guide as although slow it played very well. As mentioned above the Ballinger bowlers didn't make the visitors work too hard for their runs. A decent ball from Evan and a sharp catch by Kerry produced the first two wickets but Waddesdons 3rd wicket stand of over 100 took the game away from the home side.

260 was always likely to be too many for Ballingers young side but the visitors had been reading about the teams exploits over the last few weeks and weren't going to take any chances.

Tim Rix opened up with Max Dugdale and was looking forward to taking a final opportunity of the season to notch a decent score. Unfortunately the visitors umpire had other ideas. Max followed shortly but then an excellent stand between Sebastian Richards(43) and Ben Carlin (34*) which included some very fine shots plus some rather excentric running between the wickets. The demise of Sebastian brought in Ben Dugdale who only lasted a couple of balls before being replaced by the debutant Miles Dugdale. A well struck 4 and a scampered single ensured that Dugdale senior wasn't the lowest scorer in this family battle.

Alex Howe replaced Miles and he and Ben were at the crease when the heavens opened. The league rules state that the side batting lose and over for every 3 minutes they game is held up. As the side batting second we were already only going to get 40 overs as opposed to the visitors 45. There is no reduction in the total to chase so therefore at the end of the break we only had 11 overs to chase the total. An unlikely event so the stumps were drawn with the home side on 106-5.

It's been a really enjoyable season again with another crop of youngsters coming to the fore and another couple of dads coming out of the wood-work. I would like to thank all those who've helped out over the season especially Veronica Richards for organising the teas and all the ladies for doing the teas. Derek and Tim for taking over when events took me to other places and finally to the grounds team for producing such good pitches.

It is debatable what was more remarkable about this## BWCC's first match of the 2011 season at Aldenham.  Was it the weather? - hot and sunny - very unlike April## when we are used to anything from sleet## gales and general meteorological misery. Was it the fact that no-one can remember Ballinger playing a match on Easter Sunday? Or was it the unexpected outcome of the game?

Skipper Ian Davies won the toss## and our batsmen made a steady start with an opening partnership of 54 between Paul Humphreys (38) andWill Smith (18). Andy Thompson (30) carried on the good work## then Max Maciver blitzed an aggressive 37. Ian Davies took ther batting honours with an unbeaten 55## but Aldenham's bowlers kept the batsmen tied down towards the end## and a total of 227-5 when the declaration came looked a few runs short of comfortable.

And so it seemed## when Aldenham batted## Ballinger's first four bowlers all went wicketless (though errant line and length## plus a critical dropped catch## contributed to that)## and the first wicket did not fall until the score was 103## in only the 22nd over. Opening bat Monroe then mounted a savage attack## but with the total on 164 and only 34 overs gone## he unaccountably ran himself out for 92. This prompted one of the more remarkable collapses. Bastie took a hat-trick in an extraordinary spell of 5 - 21 (6 of which were no-balls!)## two more batsmen ran themselves out## and their 11th man was found to have gone home## as Aldenham sank from 164-1 to 183 all out.

An excellent way to start the season!

An excellent win for Ballinger by 79 runs gave the U10A's a great start to the season. Beautiful sunshine## although a little on the chilly side. Tractor mended and pitch marked in the nick of time.

An eager U10 team## captained by Monty won the toss and chose to bat first. A little reluctant to chase the singles at first## and scored 44 runs off the bat## benefiting from 51 extras and 9 byes given away by High Wycombe. Top run scorers: Henry K (9)## and Hugo E-H (8)## Monty W (8) and James B (8). Final score: 256

The boys bowled and fielded really well with some excellent wicket keeping from Hugo. The bowling was accurate## only giving away 16 in extras which was a good start for the first game of the season. The fielding was tight## the backing up excellent## so all the hard work in coaching and practising has really paid off. They never lost their concentration or determination in the field which really put the pressure on the HWCC batsmen## who only scored 19 off the bat and lost 10 wickets. Final score: 177

Top bowlers: James B (1 run## 3 wickets## 3 overs); Monty (3 runs## 2 wickets## 3 overs) and  Louis & Will both bowled 2 for 2 off 2.

So a really good win - well done boys! Keep it up.  (Wendy H)

Another sunny day## another win!

Pelicans## having won the toss## decided that they didn't fancy batting first on what looked like a Kellock belter## and Ballinger had cruised to an opening partnership of 50 in only 10 overs when Paul Humphreys went LBW for an impressive 43. When comments are made before an innings about the depth of the Ballinger batting## one can guess that the inevitable will ensue - as indeed it did. Six overs later the scoreboard read 64 for 5! Some sensible batting was called for## and was duly delivered by Jeremy Hunting## assisted first by Jamie Kellock## who was determined to prove that his pitch had nothing to do with the earlier clatter of wickets## and then by Ian Davies## with an accomplished 25. Jeremy went on to an extremely well-struck 67## then Bastie (29)and Jack Hankinson went after the bowling to post a final total of 210.

Pelicans could make little headway against an extremely accurate opening attack of Andy Thompson and Jack Hankinson. Wickets fell steadily## and Ian Davies joined the fray once Jack's allotted spell was done. Andy finished with 4 for 38 off 13 overs - impressive stuff - and Pelicans subsided to an all-out total of 143.

 

Gerry Hunting
Unfortunately the availability of only two U15s meant this match had to be conceded

In our first game of the season## Ballinger acquitted themselves well.  Chesham fielded a strong B team for this cup game and put on some good bowling.  The top 3## Freddie## Monty and Hamish all batted well albeit a little slowly.  Greg hit his first runs on debut. The highlight though was the Sam Peters (also on debut) and Henry Turrell## who came in with the score rate looking a little weak; between then## they put on 43 runs for the last 4 overs; Henry in particular scored a very fast 27 off 16 balls.

Ballinger's fielding was very strong; everyone contributed with some dynamic dives.  The ball spent a lot of time in the air with some good tight bowling but it never quite went to hand.  The team came off rightly satisfied with a good win## albeit in a match which we should always win.

A missed opportunity.  Chasing 119## we were 60 off 10 overs with only 1 wicket down.  From this position## Ballinger contrived to score only 31 runs from the last last 9 wickets; whilst disappointed with the result## I was happy with the team performance.  Going by form in the Division## Chesham are the side to beat and we were not fielding a full-strength team - missing 4 of our strongest players. 

Ballinger bowling in general was good.  I thinkChesham were surprised by the depth of our bowling as they played out the openners patiently expecting to be able to score freely after this. All of our bowlers caused them problems.  Hamish and Reece (on debut) are a good openning pair; Dom gave away just 10 runs and no extra's from his 4 overs## getting one of the two wickets. Greg had a useful spell and then Freddie and Monty arrived late and between them bowled 4 overs for just 10 runs.   Fielding let us down this time and the difference between the two sides was the extra's - Ballinger tally being 32 compared to Chesham's 6 - 12 of these extras were 4's behind the wickets. NB Toby kept pretty well taking some difficult leg side balls at pace well - we just need to give him a bit more fielding support behind the stumps.

Openning pair again did their job; Freddie (29) and Monty (17) make a good partnership taking every run available - if anything erring towards a little too much risk. Hamish came in and played a quick 22 pushing the run rate along.  Then on came County spinner## Sam Rance## giving a masterclass in line and length and Ballinger were suddenly 81 for 8. Playing spinners is definitely a skill which this team is lacking.  The only player who was able to cope with spin was Matt O'Kelly## who played a good rear-guard 10 not out and looked strong.
Rather annoyingly this game coincided with a cub camp## a Y5/Y6 disco and someones party. Therefore from a squad of 30 we couldn't raise a side.

We were almost at Burnham when the call came through that the ground was water logged. Not surprised considering the amount of rain overnight.

Think we need to get Teamer up and runing to save lots of calls and frustration

BWCC's 2011 league campaign started with a first-ever visit to Potten End## newly promoted to the MBL premier division. A little overnight rain perhaps influenced Ian Davies## successful with the coin## to field first## as the wicket looked as if it might play a few tricks.Not that the first Potten End wicket to fall - first ball## first over - had anything to do with the pitch.The batsman## surprised by a rank Nick Adams full-toss## swatted it straight to an equally surprised Danny Draper (making what we hope will be regular league appearances)## who clung on. There followed a rather extraordinary period in which the normally miserly Nick was given some rough treatment## whilst Andy Thompson opened with five consecutive maidens. With 82 on the board before the 4th wicket fell## Potten End were going along nicely. The introduction of Carlton Siddle changed all that## and 83-3 suddenly became 83-7## with Ballinger's oft-maligned fielders taking some smart catches. A stand of 43 for the 8th wicket hauled Potten End out of the mire## only for Rollo to enter the fray and show how easy bowling really is## with 2 wickets in 9 balls! Which must have been small consolation to Andy## whose analysis of 11 overs## 7 maidens## no wickets for 17 runs was a travesty for such fine## accurate bowling.

A target of 138 to win - should be easy?  Had Potten End's opening bowlers not both been 18 year olds## and thus restricted to 7 over spells by ECB regulations## things might have been very different. Paul Humphreys (0 in 6 balls) claimed that only a batsman as good as himself would have even got an edge to the ball that did him (such modesty!)## and Danny and Rollo struggled hard to raise the score to 25 before Danny went. Rollo followed with the score on 38## but with the enforced change in bowling## the pressure eased a little. Ian Davies batted well for 32## but the starring role went to Carlton## whose hard-hit 53 not out## coupled with his earlier 4 wickets for 31## capped a fine personal performance. Potten End rang the changes with their attack##but to no avail## as Ballinger emerged winners by 5 wickets.

A very welcome opening victory## enhanced by the 3 points gained by having an UMPIRE !! - thanks to Ian Hardy## destined to play for the 2nds## whose game had to be called off due to shortage of players## and who preferred to assist the club## rather than indulge in lawn-mowing## shopping## or any other alluring Saturday afternoon activity.

BWCC U10's won the toss again and chose to bat first. A much more confident batting side this week having worked hard the previous Saturday at calling and running between the wickets. BWCC scored 109 off the bat (although a few byes were accidentally included because I gave our scorer an old style score sheet which omitted a bye line !)

Some intelligent batting from several of the boys## and top run scorers Hugo (26) and Monty (20) who batted as the last pair## sealed a very decent score of 309.

They were awarded 36 extras in wides and noballs from Beaconsfield bowlers## but lost 6 wickets## which in effect cancelled each other out run-wise.

BWCC bowling and fielding wasn't quite as good as the week before (37 extras)## nonetheless they took 9 wickets: Monty## Charlie B## and James Arnold taking 2 wickets each## and a great catch from Simon C. With some good captaining and team work## they pulled their fielding together again towards the end of the match## keeping Beaconsfield's runs down to just 47 off the bat.

All in all another good match## and another very good win for Ballinger by 79 runs. Well done!

Oops! Having had 2 very convincing wins in the last couple of weeks## this match came as a bit of a disppointment to the boys. Electing to bat first## BWCC scored 62 runs off the bat## but lost a total of 12 wickets which inevitably cost them the game. The boys tried to keep the opposition's run-rate down## which they did quite reasonably for a while## but the last two pairs of batmen from GX proved too strong for us## the game ending in defeat for Ballinger. GX scored 98 off the bat## and lost 5 wickets.

Ballinger scored 62 off the bat:-

Top batsmen: Monty (22 for 0); Matthew Bellamy (13 for 1)

Bowlers: Will Hardman (2)## Monty## Theo & James B (1 wicket each)

An ultimately easy win to which everyone contributed well.  
Ballinger won the toss and batted first.  Joe Turrell and Zac Bischoff opened.  Joe was lbw early playing an uncharacteristic cross bat shot## but then Zac and Freddie Thompson played sensibly in a 30 run partnership.  

Unexpectedly## 3 quick wickets followed; but George Cooke joined Freddie and Ballinger then prospered again## passing the 100## with both batsmen retired after passing 30.  Angus Denison-Smith (22) and Monty Weatherall (18 not out) carried on the good work## and we closed on 151 off our 20 overs.  Overall## those who played straight preserved their wickets and scored runs## but those who played across the line got out.     


Opening the bowling for Ballinger## Fin Clark was in danger of ending the Chalfont challenge rather too quickly## with a double wicket maiden and then another wicket in his second over.  He bowled quick## full and straight and was just too good for them.  He had to be taken off.  But the others continued to take wickets## Ollie Hardman and Will Fennell with their medium pace and Monty Weatherall with his legspin## so that  wickets continued to fall steadily and Chalfont never looked like getting anywhere near our total.  

Taylor Levitt bowled some good offspin and was unlucky not to get a wicket.  Joe Turrell was finally allowed to bowl his excellent slow left arm at the end and was just too good for them## giving away a miserly one run off 2 overs.  Thompson and Cooke were not needed.  They ended at 48 for 8.

 Pick of the bowlers: Fin Clark with 4 overs## 2 maidens## 3 wickets for 2 runs.  The lesson for all:  bowl full and straight.

Most importantly it was a very good fielding performance## with all catches taken – including a wonderful reflex catch by Zac off a no-ball## and good tidy ground fielding throughout.  Marcus Tingey too was very tidy and enthusiastic behind the stumps.  We shall need those skills when we play stronger teams now that we have progressed.

Well done everyone.

With skipper Davies away (basking in Barcelona)## Ian Maciver## deputising## had little hesitation having won the toss in choosing to bat on a perfect wicket that looked full of runs. Matt Riley (on free loan from Eymet Club de Cricket## Dordogne) and Paul Humphreys gave Ballinger a good start## posting 91 by the 20th over## but thereafter none of the batsmen could really get on top of accurate bowling backed up by athletic fielding (regrettably to an endless chorus of "shabash##shabash"). Two uneccessary run-outs didn't help. Nick Adams came in early to clout 12 off 5 balls## and Carlton Siddle batted well (again) ## holding the tail togther. Carlton and Ian Maciver produced a flurry of runs (19) in the 44th over## to raise a total of 213 -9## which was satisfying## but on such a wicket## a far from unbeatable score.

Cadmore End were soon scoring well## but 4 wickets were down for 76## and Ballinger seemed to have the match in hand. However## their catching was fallible - 5 chances went down - and some loose bowling let Cadmore End back into the game and a partnership of 87 for the 5th wicket ensued. Ballinger were denied a run-out by their own umpire being badly positioned (but## being gentlemen## only reminded him of this half a dozen times thereafter). Ian Maciver then brought himself into the attack## and with the later Cadmore End batsmen unable to keep up with the run-rate## finished with 4 for 44## as BWCC wrapped up the match in the final over## a match which in truth they should have won much more convincingly.

For the second week running## two junior players were brought into the team## due to absence of seniors## and once again acquitted themselves really well in the the field - a credit to the club's junior section and their coaches.

Cadmore End is always an interesting place to visit for your first game of the season. It's unusual shaped ground plus the vagaries of the pitch can make a skippers life very interesting.

With the 1s having taken the only strike bowler in the squad skipper Kerry was left with a bit of a quandary as to what to do when he won the toss. Eventually the uncertainty as to how the pitch would behave was enough for him to choose to field.

Opening the bowling with an off spinner and a leg spinner doesn't often happen in any form of cricket but for the first 4 overs everything looked very comfortable for the Waggoners especially as there were only nine fielders on the pitch. Our 10th man arrived and was quickly in to the action.

Reece Tiley is a new U13 recruit for the club but the pace he was able to generate on this very slow pitch was impressive and bodes well for the future. He was first to draw blood with 2 wickets in only his 4th over for the 2s. Jake Cutter's leg spin had been moved to the pavilion end from where he bowled a pretty consistent line without any luck. The slowness of the pitch was making life difficult for Ballinger's bowlers and although turning lots## too easy for the batters. Cadmore's Dutton batted well for his 96* but there were plenty of classic village green shots from the rest of the Ends batsmen.

Ben Dugdale( 3-77) gave us a mixture of very good off-spin and "buffet" bowling## Tom McIntyre (2-47) bowled a really good spell of leg-spin at the death and Reece returned with another excellent spell ending with 3-47 off his 10 overs.

We had two other new members of the the club playing in the game. Daren Samet## who## I think## enjoyed his re-introduction into the game## and U14 Connor Underwood who was asked to play at the last minute and became the teams 11th man. He did an excellent job in the field including taking a very good catch.

Unfortunately the above can't hide the fact that Cadmore scored an impressive 242 -8

Ballinger's pursuit of this was led by the skipper who opened with Max Dugdale. As often the case## over the next 39 overs it was the boys that did the job rather than the adults. Apart from an excellent first innings of the season from Paul Branigan ( 32) the bulk of Ballinger's reply was scored by the boys. Max Dugdale with 22 led the way followed by brother Ben with 33 and an excellent 29* from Jake Cutter. 

It almost looked like we could hang on for a draw but with 6 overs left Connor was run out and we finished on 162 -10.

A long report for the first game but it was very enjoyable to get back on the pitch## the opposition were good value for their win as well as making it a pleasant afternoons cricket. They were also full of praise for Ballinger's juniors and for those interested yes it was a good tea.

Happy Days

The U12s first outing last night was the also the first of nine times that Ballinger will play The Lee at various ages including the senior sides.

Frequently the quality of cricket shown at these meetings is distorted by the need for the win over local rivals or## in the case of the boys last night## bragging rights at school the following day.

The Lee won the toss and elected to bat on what was a belter of a track. Tom Line and Max Hutt were soon into their stride punishing anything wayward but Will Arnold kept his line immaculately and his 4 overs cost a miserly 8 runs. Rob Farquhar was bowling well at the other end but the short boundary on the pavilion side meant anything remotely near the leg side was put away by The Lee openers.

Having put on over 60 for the 1st wicket the introduction of Jamie Kingston removed both the openers in consecutive overs. This changed the whole complex of the game. Skipper McIntyre had taken a bit of pasting in his first 2 overs but he was quickly back to get his revenge. Some smart fielding and some senseless running between the wickets meant The Waggoners kept the visitors down to 94- 7 in their 20 overs. Gethin Ross bowled well for his 4 overs and generally the fielding was OK with only 1 catch being dropped. Brandon Allen did another excellent job behind the stumps.

Brandon then opened the batting with his skipper and they patiently gave Ballinger a decent start. Ollie Brown bowled very well keeping one end tied up but Charlie Boyd had lost his radar and the extras were keeping the scoreboard ticking over. Max Hutt and Robbie Birkett bowled well keeping Ballinger behind the run rate but the introduction of Tom Line produced the first wicket enticing Brandon to hit to mid-off. Unfortunately for The Lee this brought in Edward Eaton-Hart who set about the Lee bowlers with gusto. His 30 came up in only 28 balls including 4 x fours. This also encouraged his skipper to open up and they both ended up retiring within a couple of overs.

Fortunately only 2 were required off the penultimate over and thanks to generosity of the Lee bowlers these were provided in extras as there was no guarantee that the batters would have managed it on their own.

Another cold evening being frustrated by players who should know better but## a win is a win.

Finally - something to ponder. If you put 5/6 of the boys from each team together you'd have had a very decent cricket team but## would they have had as much fun?

This was never going to be an easy game and unfortunately## it lived up that billing. 

High Wycombe were "awesome" and delivered a barrage of boundaries against our bowlers## who toiled away with little luck.  We had early success with Matt and Toby taking catches off James Mc and Seth - skipper turned to spin early and it got the result. however this brought in Saif## who plays for U15 county side and in 7 or 8 balls## scored 30 runs## 4 sixes## a 4 and two singles. HW were on 12 / over at one stage in the game.   The batting which followed Saif was also good and they finished on 186.  The figures are unkind on James Mc## who endured the worst of Saif's destructiveness and was bowling a reasonable line but dropping it a bit short.  Greg caused the most problems with his suprising speed and accuracy.   The fielding was not the best display with some of the boys letting their heads drop and making silly errors.  

Ballinger were never in the run chase## barely getting above 4 an over throughout the innings.  Almost everyone who batted got some runs but no one built an innings.  Hamish and Toby openned sensibly but got out trying to force the pace.  Brandon looked good and got out to a super ball.  Matt again looked confident before getting caught.  James Mc and Ollie Cooksey had a useful partnership of 20 at the end.

This was the closest we have come to beating Gerrards Cross## who feature a number of county players.  I was quite happy with Ballinger's performance.   

Gerrards Cross reached 100 with loss of only 3 wickets in the 12th over but we did not let our heads drop this time and restricted them to a more realistic target of 137.   It would have been considerably lower had we held our catches - 4 dropped in total; this really was the difference between the teams. Otherwise the fielding was very good and full of energy and commitment.  Pick of the bowlers were Freddie D-S with with 1-5 off 3 overs and Monty with 2-15 off 4 overs.  Sam Peters also claimed 2 wickets in two overs.   Brandon was excellent behind the stumps - a superb stumping and a catch. Andy Thomson also remarked that he probably should have given a run out to James Mc's incredible throw-down on the stumps from a fairly deep cover.

Monty went early from a good diving catch from GX.  Brandon looked in good nick but got run out.  Freddie saw off the openners but did not capitalise.  Hamish then stepped up and played a captains innings and really speeded up the run rate## retiring on 30. It was an important knock when we had lost some early wickets and were behind the chase.   Oscar supported with good hitting.  Greg lifted the team and gave some hope with some hard hitting## ending on 22 not out with 4 boundaries## supported by Sam Peters who scored 6 of 4 balls and Dom Brown.  We did not quite get there but against this bowling attack## it was very good to get 120 runs and the team should be proud.

The local derby match against The Lee took place on a fine evening although several players were away in Morocco. They missed a thrilling hard fought game of cricket. Max was lucky not to be out  on either of the first two balls but settled down into a good opening partnership with Maadi .  Max went on to top score with a good 38 with several thumping boundaries. Monty and Joe both made useful contributions in the middle order with Joe very effectively pushing  on near the end  with some aggressive calling and running . We were up against some very good bowling in the final overs  - especially Quinn whose Malinga-like yorker was very  difficult to defend## let alone score off. We reached a competitive 92-8.

Ballinger’s attack demolished The Lee’s much-hyped top order in the first four overs leaving them reeling at 16-3 -  two wickets for Maadi who was the pick of the bowlers and one for Greg. Joe was in the action straight away with a fine running catch in the deep in the first over and Max took an excellent catch behind the wicket. The Lee rebuilt with a good partnership against some tight bowling by Ben## Monty and Freddie. The pressure was building and the partnership was eventually broken by a run out: our whole team was  fielding superbly. But Young  cut loose and played a match winning innings which just took the game away from Ballinger with only two balls left. Disappointing to lose such a close match against local rivals but I was proud of our fine all-round team performance.

Bill Senior

On Tuesday Ballinger hosted Chalfont St.Peter on another chilly night on the green.

It's always difficult to decide who's made the major contributions in pairs cricket but one thing did stand out was the fielding.

Chalfont batted first and reached 265 but only lost 5 wickets. There was the usual quota of extras but they were kept in check by some tight bowling from the likes of Harri Doyle and Alex Beneke. All did well though.

When The Waggoners batted running berween the wickets was the main problem with 5 wickets falling to run outs. The final total of 284 was helped by the generosity of Chalfont's bowlers but James Gill gave the innings plenty of momentum with three fours in one over. Harri and Alex  also followed up their bowling with an excellent 23 runs in their four overs.

Kit Reynolds did a top job of leading the side and it was great to see so many parents supporting their team.

"All good things come to an end"## and Ballinger's fine start to the season was badly derailed at Knotty Green. A lost toss meant KG taking first knock on a fine sunny afternoon## and Ballinger's hopes of an early wicket were thwarted by some disappointingly inaccurate opening bowling - a total of 16 wides were conceded during the innings!The KG openers had amassed an untroubled 97 before the first wicket went down## but the scoring rate had fallen thanks to some tighter bowling## particularly by Ian Maciver## well supported by Jono Lacey. Carlton Siddle## doubtless furious with himself for having just dropped a sitter## then came on to take two wickets with successive deliveries## and suddenly KG were 149 for 5## in the 36th over## and Ballinger's prospects were starting to look rosy. However## their bowling## strong on paper## was weakened by both Andy Thompson and Ian Davies carrying injuries and thus unable to bowl## and KG then took control of the game with an unbroken century partnership for the 6th wicket in only 14 overs. Sixes flew out of the ground in all directions as the hapless bowlers toiled in vain. A final total of 253 for 5 was the outcome## and among the bowlers## only Ian Maciver's figures of 2 wickets for 31 in 12 overs will be recalled with pleasure.

BWCC's reply never looked very convincing from the start. Both openers Paul Humphreys and Richard O'Kelly were out by the time 29 was on the board. Rollo resisted with 24## and skipper Davies batted fluently for 40## as did Carlton (29)## but 119 for 3 became 127 for 8 as the middle order imploded. An early night in the bar beckoned## but Jono Lacey and Jack Hankinson had other ideas. With a judicious mixture of assault (mostly## but not exclusively## Jono) and watchful defence (mostly Jack)## a partnership of 58 was achieved for the 9th wicket. Then Jono perished going for one 6 too many## but with only 5 overs left an improbable draw seemed possible. Alas## Nick Adams playing in out-of-character defensive mode fell to a catch## with only 14 possible deliveries left in the match## leaving Ballinger 195 all out.

So## a respectable final total## but in reality Ballinger were outplayed by a stronger looking side.

Ballinger were well beaten on the day by a strong Beaconsfield side. The side bowled well but could not contain the Beaconsfield side. Pick of the bowlers were young Monty Thompson nad Harry Rix who returned 2 for 10 off his 2 overs.

What a frustrating afternoon for the Waggoners.

Having lost toss skipper Kerry was very surprised when his opposite number elected to bat on what was going to be a very slow wicket.

With a howling gale blowing from one end it was decided that bowling Reece Tiley into it wasn't going to be an option so## it was our two senior professional who led the attack. Evan Webster down the hill and Bastie Richards in to the wind. For 14 overs these two kept Haddenham on the rack. Only 34 runs were scored with Evan being ridiculously unlucky not get a wicket in his first spell of 0-14 off 7 overs.

Bastie faired a little better although his first wicket was a Fred Carno affair. A rubbish ball## a rubbish shot with the batter hitting it twice## once on the drive and the second time on his follow through. The whole episode was only saved by a brilliant catch by Tim Cutter. Bastie restored some order by bowling Haddenham's no 3 with with a jaffa.

At this stage Haddenham were 34 -2. Unfortunately it was getting wet and miserable and the bowlers were finding it hard to grip the ball. I'm not sure this wholly excused the 48 extras we gave away - "keeper Branigan senior was at pains to insure we noted that there were only 3 byes - but it did make it easier for Haddenham to use there favourite shot. 

The skipper wasn't sure he'd ever had 2 fielders at "cow corner" for all bar 10 overs of an innings.An 8-3 field would give a general idea of where the ball was going.

Jake bowled OK for his 6-2-21 but Evan was the pick when he returned and took 3-18 in his last spell.

206 - 9 was 60 more than the skipper wanted to chase but the Winning draw was only 183.1111 runs away.Haddenham opener Linke batted well for his 51 but frankly the hosts should have been out for around 140

Will Smith and Monty Thompson led off the chase and although a measured start it wasn't going to be quick enough for us to chase down 206. Monty's demise meant Bastie was able to mix a few lusty blows with some  elegant drives. Will was next to go but Paul Branigan was in a determined mood and was soon upping the pace.

He and Bastie put on 57 in only 8 overs before Paul was given out LBW. Best to ask him about it. Bastie then for some reason known only to him took a huge swipe and was bowled. Darren Samat and Jake Cutter were now together and they took the score past various batting point markers until it was realised we could reach the magic 184 for a winning draw.

Suddenly the field was spread## the umpires decisions being scrutinised## the scorers being carefully monitored and every run cheered and clapped - so we could keep warm.

11 off the last over was a tall order but when Jake hit the first ball for 4 the equation changed. A single## a two## another single## four off two balls## could they do it? well you know now that## sadly## the two Waggoners couldn't quite manage it## failing by 1.1 runs to beat the require target.

The difference between the extras given away by the two sides was 17 in favour of Haddenham. This would have put us in contention to win the game let alone the winning draw so it was a frustrating afternoon for the Waggoners.

Monday evening`s game was like playing on a North Sea oil rig. The boys didn`t seem to mind though and the visitors elected to bat first. A good start saw James Reid take the first wicket bowling Habeeb for 7. A superb batting performance by Matt Haumann, who went on to score 56 not out later, pushed Beaconsfield on to 71 before Captain James Fray tempted a catch taken by Dylan Shellard. Ballinger slowed down a poor middle order taking 5 more wickets for 39 runs.  Henry Turrell put in a solid 30 runs retired, Rufus SW batted to 14 before a tough LBW decision and Dan Adams with a useful 15 gave Ballinger 117 on 20 overs. A good performance by the aforementioned Matt H secured a victory for Beaconsfield on a fearfully cold night on the common. All down to a top batsman doing his job! JG

Last week's result was disappointing. This week's was downright depressing. The only success that came Ballinger's way was winning the toss. Their batsmen were then unable to cope with an accurate WESM attack. Too keen to chase runs on what they thought would be a good batting track## five of the first six were out to catches## and only Andy Thompson's hour-long knock of 23 showed what grit and determination could achieve. All out for 116 in only 33 overs was a pretty pathetic total## and one that was never going to worry WESM## who had knocked off 48 of them without loss by the tea interval. It only took them a further 11 overs to overhaul Ballinger's meagre target## a stroll in the park against a bowling attack that looked about as competent as the batsmen had.

Ballinger Under 17s won a thrilling match against Taplow. Batting first Will Smith and Sebastian Richards put on an opening partnership of 51 runs off just 6 overs before Sebastian was bowled for a well made 19. Harry Bartlett was bowled by a superb delivery but Will was then well supported by sensible middle order batting contributed by Jack Bull## Jamie Wise and Tom Edmonds.Will Smith's innings of 76 not out was as good a performance as any he has made for Ballinger and he is maturing into a fine batsman.

Taplow batted after the break and were immediately restricted in the search for runs by a superb opening spell from Hamish Sim## 3 overs yielding 1 wicket for just 14 runs. Jake Cutter opened with spin from the other end and his figures of 1 for 18 off 4 overs do not do full justice to a superb piece of bowling. The opening  bowlers were well supported with another fine display from Evan Webster and also from young Monty Thompson.

Taplow however were a formidable batting side and at 92 for 3 were edging ahead. Will turned to Harry Bartlett and Harry Rix to close the innings out and how well they bowled## showing real maturity in a difficult situation. Harry Bartlett returned figures of 3 wickets for 14 off 3 overs and Harry Rix had figures of 3 for 19 off 3 overs.

Ballinger 131 for 6 off 20 overs.

Taplow 125 for 8 off 20 overs

The match went to the last over with Ballinger winning by 6 runs. Well done to all the boys.

After a quick inspection of the track Skipper James Fray won the toss and put Wooburn in to bat. This proved to be a good decision as Ballinger proceeded to bowl the hosts out for 57 (16 from wides and no-balls!) Best figures from Manav Thaker who took 3 wickets for 2 runs in 2 overs and James Fray who took 3 wickets for 5 runs. Archie Gibbs also held on to a difficult high catch.

 

Ballinger started confidently but Matt O`Kelly was run out down to a great text-book under-arm throw on at the 14 run mark. A really effective partnership of 34 by Scott Bunce and Gethin Ross showed their elder team-mates how it should be done and all but finished them off. Skipper JF fancied a slog and paid the price being bowled out for a duck, leaving Seth Draper to finish Wooburn off in style. An easy win for our lads who showed their superior ability in all areas. Bring on Chesham!

Ballinger arrived at league leaders Holmer Green feeling that after last week's shambles things must surely improve. And improve they did. Ian Davies won the toss (he's getting good at it - maybe it's that knack that bankers have with money?) and perhaps apprehensive of the reputation of HG's pace attack on a hard## fast looking pitch## decided to field first. HG were soon scoring fast## boundaries flying across a lightning fast outfield. But the fates (and the umpires) were smiling on Ballinger. Wickets kept falling## sometimes fortuitously## sometimes brilliantly ( a catch by Danny Draper## a slick stumping by Richard O'Kelly). Almost unbelievably seven wickets were in the bag for a paltry 107## and only 22 overs gone. Could this be Ballinger's day? No## the HG tailenders decided. With sensible application## the eigth wicket pair put on 37## then the ninth wicket 61## as Ballinger fretted and fumed. The bowling was mostly steady## and the fielding## mostly## good## but the fates had evidently decided they had smiled on Ballinger for long enough. Still## a total of 213 should be easily attainable by Ballinger's power-packed batting line-up. Shouldn't it ??

All went well in the awkward one over Ballinger had to face before tea## as the whirlwind Steve Jermain opened with three consecutive wides at Andy Thompson. But ten minutes after the resumption## Andy aimed a slightly less than well executed hook## and departed caught. Meanwhile Richard O'Kelly looked in absolutely prime form## although Ian Davies looked rather the opposite.. Davies was clean bowled with total on 50. Richard and Paul Humphreys raised it to 65 before Paul## evidently also out of touch## decided to offer no shot## and saw his bails trimmed. Incredible as it is to relate## the scoreboard that had stood at 65 for 2## with 17 overs gone## was reduced to 67 all out in the space of 6 more overs## courtesy of change bowlers D Little and D King## who were simply too fast and too straight for Ballinger's hapless batsmen. Richard's superb knock of 52## with 6 extras## meant that the remaining 10 batsmen contributed precisely 9 runs between them. 7 batsmen were clean bowled## three got golden ducks - one of them## Jamie Kellock## having actually avoided being bowled first ball## wandered down the wicket in the process(possibly inspecting it with his groundsman's eye?)## and rather forgot that he needed to ground his bat before the wicketkeeper removed his bails.

All of which goes to show why Ballinger are likely to spend an anxious season in the lower reaches of the league## and why Holmer Green are deservedly setting the pace. Perhaps it is cruel that they achieved their victory with their most prolific batsman away on holiday... Nevermind## Ballinger's performance in the field was much more encouraging. As for the batsmen## nets anybody?

Following on from the excellent (losing performance to Gerrards Cross) and a reasonable performance against Chesham## on paper## this game looked like ours to lose.

Our side was missing our two openners who have been scoring well this season## but we have depth now in the squad and I felt that we should still be able to beat Great Kingshill.

We batted first## started quite well and then slowed to a smail's pace## scoring just 5 runs of 5 overs leaving with us only 25 off the first 9 overs.  The opposition bowling was very tight and there was some home advantage playing on a very bouncey all-weather pitch.

The top order (Hamish (15)## Brandon(14)## James Mc all tried to force the pace and got out accordingly).  Brandon's innings was patient but he struggled to find the gap.  Dom brown scored a quicker 12 off 12 balls and the run rate drifted up to 3 per over.  It was Reece's contribution of 26 from 16 balls and Matthew O'Kelly scoring 12 off just 4 balls (hitting the hardest four of the season) which meant that we able to score 44 runs off the last 5 overs. There was something for the the bowlers to have a go at but it was never going to be enough.

Our bowling and fielding was tight - Gt Kingshill on only 38 from the first 10 overs - but the wickets were not falling.  Reece was the pick of the bolwers with just 12 off his 4.  James Mc gave some hope bowling number 4 out for zero## quickly followed by William getting out their no.4 for just 3 runs.  The youngsters## Fred and Edward were very effective in the field but our score was never high enough and they reached it with some hard hitting from their number 5 Pistana with 10 balls to spare.

Reece - man of the match

If 48 hours is a long time in politics then so it  also is with cricket. Ballinger Under 17s returning fresh from their victory earlier in the week returned to the home ground to play Great Kingshill in the cup.

Great Kingshill won the toss and batted sensibly to score 120 runs for the loss of 7 wickets## well contained by Ballinger with all the bowlers contributing## and it was good to see Joe Hankinson back  leading the attack.

Highlights were the bowling of Monty Thompson## 2 wickets for 17 runs## Jake Cutter 1 wicket for 11 runs and Reece Tiley with 1 wicket for 12 runs## well supported by an excellent spell from Harry Rix## 0 for 17 off 4 overs## Geoerge Kingston  0 for 17 off 3 overs and Sebastian Richards 1 for 14 off 2 overs.

Ballinger approached the run chase in a strangely diffident manner losing 6 wickets for 12 runs as each batsman became pinned down by some excellent Great Kingshill bowling.

Enter Jake Cutter to join Jamie Wise as they led the Ballinger fight back before Jamie was out for 8. Harry Rix continued to support Jake before being bowled. Now George Kingston entered the fray to join Jake Cutter. Jake was now sending balls all round the pitch as he tore into the bowling attack and the partnership with George Kingston led Ballinger to needing 20 runs from the last 2 overs. Sadly Jake was out caught## having contributed a superb innings of 55 ## which showed real character.

George Kingston continued to play his shots## finishing on 18 not out but unfortunately the last two partnerships left Ballinger just 6 runs short of victory .The final score being  115 runs for the loss of 9 wickets## nonetheless a spirited fightback by the team.

Great Kingshill 120 for 7 off 20 overs

Ballinger 115 for 9 off 20 overs

Great Kingshill won by 5 runs.

Electing to bat first## Henry Turrell (30) and Matt O'Kelly (21) set the pace of the innings with a fine 49 run partnership.  Monty scored a good 30 retired albeit at a slower rate (40 balls).  U12 Edward Eaton-Hart contributed with 12 off 12 balls with Greg ratcheting up the pace with 12 of 9 balls to get us to a repectable 128.  Given that we were on 68 for 1 off 10 overs## I was hoping for Ballinger to post a huge score## still this was always going to be enough even without 3 of our usual bowlers.

James Mc (1-7 off 4 overs) and Monty Thompson (2-13) were the pick of the bowlers.  Hamish also bolwed tightly (1-14).  Fielding was in general very good with 3 run-outs and 2 catches.  The opposition never really managed to get close to the run rate required.

Onto round 3.

The highlight of this rather one-sided game was Reece Tiley's amazing spell of 5 wickets (all bowled) for 2 runs of just 2 overs. Had Monty (skipper) decided to let Reece continue## I have little doubt that we would have restricted the opposition to a much lower score than the 33 that they did manage to post.  Getting their top 3 out for just 4 runs surprised them - as I understand it from their coach## these 3 were used to scoring 30s.   Denison-Smith and Brown also contributed with 2 wickets a piece and the fielding was generally tight## although we gave away too many wides; extra's contributed 14 of the 33 runs.

Farnham Royal bowling was much more impressive than their batting but after losing a couple of early wickets## Greg and Toby saw us home with Greg scroring a reasonably quick 14 not out. 

Onto the quarter finals....against High Wycombe!

For the first time this summer Ballinger's selectors were called into play and their first move was to replace the skipper.

Paul Branigan took on the mantle for the day and managed to continue the good work of the previous incumbent by losing the toss. Much to his amazement the visitors put the Waagoners into bat.

For some reason Paul then handed over the setting of the batting order to the umpire - bad move.

When Tom McInyre and Monty Thompson strolled out to the middle there was some discussion as whether this was the youngest ever opening partnership to represent the club. They may have been young in years but their approach to the task was very mature.

For the first 20 overs they kept the rate at a very respectable 4 an over## against some very tight Prestwood bowling but## on another belter of a pitch## this was never going to be enough. After drinks they then put the 'pedal to the metal' and raced along at 7 an over until Monty was finally defeated for a well crafted 36 with the total on 161. As often is the case with one wicket comes two and Tom was out two overs later for a brilliant 95.

Bastie joined Kim Hughes with both looking to increase the run rate further. Both perished in the attempt but Max Dugdale had joined the fray and## from the off## set about the Prestwood bowlers with great gusto. With Bastie and then the skipper he helped add 89 in only 10 overs of which he scored a brilliant 66*.

The skipper## in conversation with that umpire again## had decided that a minimum of 240 by 42nd over was required so to reach 271 - 4 was riches indeed.

After an excellent tea it was the bowlers turn to show how it should be done. Unfortunately Tom Graham's warm up game wasn't ideal preperation for the cut and thrust of the MBL and after only 5 overs the skipper had to remove his main strike force from the attack. At the other end Evan wasn't fairing much better. There was a strong breeze blowing across the ground and the amount of wind resistance Evan currently sports was making it difficult for him to make any headway.

The combination of a left/right opening partnership for the visitors## some wayward bowling and a track that still refused to deteriorate meant much head scratching for the skipper. Whilst this was going on the visitors were quietly ticking along at near the required run rate to win the game.

Finally## Tom Sperring(2-34) in his first game of the season and Bastie( 1-30) gave the skipper a measure of control. Tom removed KInsman with a jaffa then Bastie had danger man Greeves(51) well caught behind by Max.

After that only Sanders(50) for the visitors offered any danger with the run rate slowly creeping towards the 10 an over mark. Jake Cutter did his best to keep Prestwood in the hunt but finally M of M Tom Mcintyre was brought into the attack and almost bowled the Waggoners to victory with 3 wickets in 5 overs. Prestwood finished on 222-8

A couple of early chances went begging but generally this was a good all-round performance by the team.

A lovely afternoon## an excellent track## two teams playing the game in the correct way## a proper umpire## a delicious tea and 21 points. Perfect

A comfortable win by 46 runs.
Ballinger batted first## and against some decent but not greatly testing bowling went about scoring a total of 117 for 4 that was clearly going to be too much for the opposition.  Although the Beaconsfield batting## like their bowling## proved workmanlike and effective## they never really threatened to reach their target## ending at 71 for 7.
Amongst the batters## Freddie Thompson topscored with 30 retired and he was ably assisted by Taylor Levitt and Angus Denison-Smith (both 19).  George Cooke (11*) and Rory Bland (18*) then carried on the good work## Rory playing some very well timed sweeps and clips off the legs to anything on or outside his legstump## picking up a series of boundaries.


It was clear after 8 overs of our openers## George Cooke and Fin Clark## that Beaconsfield were not going to score fast enough to mount a challenge## although their opening batsmen were technically competent and proved hard to dislodge## putting on 44 for the first wicket.  Will Fennell  and Ollie Hardman then took over## both bowling a good straight line.  Will showed his knack of picking up wickets (2 for 8 off 3 overs); and some very good Ballinger fielding coupled with some bad calls added 3 run outs.  

The main concern towards the end was a downpour that might snatch victory from us## and so our 2 spinners  (Joe Turrell and Freddie Thompson) were put on to bowl their overs as quickly as possible (slowed only by Marcus Tingey’s enthusiastic stumping attempts!).  Zachary Bischoff bowled the last over and picked up his first wicket of the season with an athletic one handed catch – typical of his general athleticism in the field.  In fact there was good fielding from everyone## with special mention to Rory Bland and Will Fennell in that department.


A good match played in a very good spirit.  Well done## boys.

Another game against Chesham in which we manage to get ourselves into a potentially winning position and lose it.  With Chesham on 62 for 6 off 12 overs## Ballinger were contemplating chasing down a manageable target.  Reece was once again the pick of the bowlers with 3 for 14 of his 4 overs.  Hamish (1-13) and Freddie (2-16) were also bowling well in support## but there were a lot of wides and byes.  Toby had a good day with the gloves## the bowlers were making life very difficult spraying the ball down the leg side coming off the slope and running down for several 4 byes; if you removed 20 byes / wides from the first 12 overs## we would have had Chesham on 42-6 off 12 overs and I suspect that might have created a very different result. Chesham went on to score 73 off their last 8 overs## which was a killer.

Chesham bowling was excellent - particularly from ex Ballinger boy## Theo reynolds who bowled on the stumps 85% of his balls - all on a length and Freddie and Monty struggled to get the ball away.  The run chase was never really on; our best position being 51-2 off 12 overs.  Freddie anchored the innings and although he might have appeared slow## he scored his 25 in 28 balls - respectable against this bowling attack.  We were let down by unneceesary run-outs - two from the non striker backing up too far and Monty lost his wicket wandering around the crease.  Matt looked again to be in fine form but got himself run-out as did Reece who started with intent.  The lower order played sensible cricket keeping the run-rate ticking along at around 5-6 / over.  Henry Turrell helped this cause by scoring 16 off 10 balls.  

As in the last game against Chesham## the big difference was extras## had we matched their tally## we would have been within 10 runs of their total and with that as a target## maybe the result would have been different.

Sincere apologies from the Chesham manager. The match didn`t appear on the Chesham fixture list. The first time this has happened to one of my teams## so in future it`s belt and braces with me confirming every match with my opposite number. This walkover leaves us top with 2 out of 2## so let`s make sure of a victory at Little Marlow next Monday 13th! Jimmy
Fortunately Chesham were unable to raise a team for this game as everyone would have been hanging around waiting for it to stop raining if they had.

For once## skipper Davies lost the toss## but was far from unhappy that Ley Hill opted to bat first on a wicket softened by overnight rain. Their openers started at a funereal pace (reminiscent of Ballinger in the past?) and had only 15 on the board when Jack Hankinson struck## scattering the stumps with the first and fourth balls of his 5th over. Worse was to follow for Ley Hill when Nick Adams## having narrowly failed to reach the rebound from a valiant caught & bowled attempt## then suffered the indignity of being hit for a towering 6## clung on to an even better caught & bowled off the last ball of his 7th over. 36 for 3## and Ballinger's tails were up. Alas## Messrs Lown and Clarke (57) had other ideas and put on 89 for the 4th wicket. Ballinger's team was## with one teenage exception## exclusively composed of over 40's (some significantly over!)## yet their fielding belied this statistic. Some scintillating catches were taken## notably by Andy Thompson and Ian Davies## as Ley Hill battled their way to a respectable final score of 208## all out off the first ball of the 45th over. Jack Hankinson (4 for 33 in his 9 overs) was the star bowler## with Andy Thompson ( 4 for 59 off 12) close behind.

Ballinger needed a good start. They didn't get one## as Matt Riley departed bowled in the second over. However## Richard O'Kelly was joined by Rollo McIntyre## and with both batsmen in top form from the previous weekend## the required run-rate was easily achieved. Rollo even had the temerity to smite the first ball he faced for 6. Unfortunately he perished LBW for 35 with the total on 62## whereupon although Richard continued in prime form giving a batting master-class## the other batsmen decided that a bit of hara-kiri was called for. Ian "Pietersen" Davies did his best to run himself and his partner out## and Paul Humphreys went one better## and succeeded. At 140 for 6## the match was now very much in the balance## with Richard perishing for a superb 74. Enter Messrs Hunting and Kellock## whose enterprising stand of 48 for the 7th wicket decisively swung the match in Ballinger's favour. But they both fell to catches## and with the total on 198## eleven runs were needed from the last two overs## and only two wickets left. Breathtaking stuff## but the cool head of Ian Maciver prevailed## and Ballinger eased home with three balls to spare!

Maximum points (at last!) for BWCC## but perhaps the best thing was the sight of such a closely contested match going to the wire. Congratulations to both teams.

The seconds made the short trip to Bellingdon on Saturday to play Ley Hill.

Skipper Kerry continued his consistent run of form with the toss by losing it once again. Once more he was surprised by the choice of the home skipper to bat. The 45/40 over split makes it a bit more of a tactical decision than the Waggoners skipper obviously appreciates.

The wicket was very well grassed so there should have been some movement for the seam bowlers so the skipper wasn't too concerned about bowling first. Unfortunately the toss was the least of his problems. Not reading his emails properly and a senior pro doing like wise meant starting with only 9 players. Within half an hour though we obviously had 12.

Evan Webster( 0-31) and Will Reid ( 2-33) opened up for the Waggoners and after their alotted 12 overs they had kept the score to a miserly 31 runs with Will taking 1 wicket from a good catch behind by Max Dugdale. Then it was time for the spin kings Rob Rose ( 1-51) and Bastie Richards ( 1-47). Rob struck first getting Ley Hill's No3 well caught by Will. Bastie was then unlucky to see the skipper drop his opposite number off an absolute dolly. Fortunately Kerry made up for it by catching the same player off a far more difficult chance. The boys both bowled well though Rob in particular started to tire towards the end and the skipper probably kept him on an over too long

The Hill opener Lyne was batting well but## to the visitors## it appeared very slowly so they were happy to keep him in. He was finally out in the 40th over for 86. He was brilliantly caught by Darren Samat on the square leg boundary off recently introduced Ben Dugdale ( 3-21). Joe Batt for the home side added some aggression in his well played innings of 40 but he was caught by Max off his brother. Rob Rose taking the last catch again off Ben.

The Hill finished on 187-7. It was difficult to work out how good a score that was on a slow wicket but even bounce.

The visitors innings got off to a disastrous start with Keith Turnball being bowled first ball. I know he wanted to get away promptly but that's ridiculous. Rob McIntyre now joined Max and they tiggled along at just around the 4 an over that would give Ballinger the winning draw.

Max(17) was first to go with the score on 47 with Rob (31) following 12 runs later. This brought Bastie and Paul Branigan together. Paul was soon into his stride and upped the run rate to match that required for a win. In 10 overs they added 65 before Bastie(15) was bowled going for one big hit too many. Darrren and Paul then added a rapid 29 before both were out within 4 runs of each other. Paul for an excellent 64 and Darren for a rapid 15 leaving 19 for the skipper and Ben Dugdale to score to claim the victory. They managed this without too much fuss with a couple of overs to spare.

A very enjoyable game as always played in the right way. The pinic supplied by Mr.Partington was excellent but I suggest when they come to our place we lock up the tea bags.

Ballinger won a really exciting game at Kingshill on Thursday night with the win coming off the final ball.

Kingshill batted first and the Waggoners struck early with Rob Farquhar claiming the first wicket. At the other end Will Arnold was bowling superbly without any luck. An excellent stand of 39 between Fountain and Webb seemed to have given Kingshill the initiative but the introduction of Jamie Kingston sooned changed that. His 3 for 10 in 4 overs put Ballinger frimly in control. A couple of wickets from Fred Sanders and with Will Arnold getting his just rewards with his second spell ending with 2-8 in his 4 overs meant the Waggoners were chasing a modest total.

Huge credit for keeping Kingshill to 82-9 in their 20 overs must go to Gethin Ross who did a brilliant job of keeping wicket and only conceded 6 byes.

Rob and Gethin opened up for the Waggoners but## unfortunately## Rob got a dose of his own treatment and was out in the first over. Sadly he was joined by Fred Peck and Fred Sanders in the same over. This meant Ballinger were 4 for 3 and in disarray.

Oli Moir joined Gethin and finally some order was restored. They added 29 with some excellent shots## interesting running between the wickets and some good fortune. When Gethin was out for 17## Oli then added 18 with Finn Hynes and 15 with Will Arnold. When Will was out it was obvous it was going to be a tight finish with only 17 needed off 4 overs but only Oli as a recognised batsman left. Louis Kelmsley came and went then John Collier strode to the wicket. With calm assurance he and Oli guided the visitors home. Although the coach felt that leaving it to the last ball was a bit unnecesary.

An enjoyable game played in the right spirit but not a good one for the coach's nerves.

Batting first Ballinger piled on the runs to make 131-4. Max opened the innings and once again played a big innings with 38. This included an excellent partnership of 57 for the second wicket with Ben (28) which was the foundation for a big score enabling the batsmen to be very attacking later in the innings. Josh Richardson made a quick-fire 21 batting at 4 that maintained the tempo. When Chalfont St Peter batted they found it hard to get going against some tight bowling and sharp fielding by Ballinger. The opening partnership was broken when Freddie swooped on the ball at midwicket## turned and threw sharply to Max for a run out - definitely the champagne moment. Mahmood's bowling was devastating with 3-2 off three overs including two maidens. Everyone else chipped in and a strong all round performance saw the U14s outplay Chalfont in all areas of the game.

Ballinger got a pasting at Chartridge on Wednesday from a very decent Chesham side.

Chesham batted first and on a cold night the bowling of Will Arnold was enough to warm the soul if not the body. Time and again he beat the bat with no luck. Finally he cleaned up fellow district player Milo Skelton. At the other end Rob Farquhar was proving less accurate with the left handed Jamie Franks causing him a few directional problems.

The introduction of Oli Moir led to some interesting cricket. Thanks to two really good catches by Rob and another by Fred Sanders## Oli reduced Chesham to 49-5. Unfortunately at the same time he was giving away wides at a unacceptable pace.

The introduction of spin helped Chesham get away with Manav and Fred both conceding 20 runs off their two overs. Add 27 extras to the the batting total and Chesham ended with a far to healthy 149 - 8. Once again Gethin did an excellent job behind the sticks conceding only 6 byes but 16 wides and 5 no balls is not good enough at this level. Pick of the bowlers was Will with 1-18 off his 4 overs.

Not sure what to say about the batting. Apart from Will and Oli## who both batted well## no other player got into double figures. Chesham have a strong bowling line up but felt we should have scored more than the 69 we finally managed.

It was a very cold evening and one I'll be pleased to forget

Rather annoyingly this match was rained off and it was against one the sides we would expect to beat.

 

Ho Humm. Mid-table obscurity beckons

Ballinger played Beaconsfield on Thursday and in the end won comfortably.

Batting first Ballinger set off at a break neck pace with Rory Bland and Jamie Fulcher running everything and smashing the ball to all parts. They scored 42 in only 3.2 overs before Rory was out for 15. Danny Simpson then continued the run fest with Jamie and after only 6 overs the Waggoners had 60 on the board. Then Jamie was out and the wheels fell off.

The next four batters all fell for ducks and it wasn't until Ben Westland entered the fray did Ballinger finally get the total their start deserved. Ben's 31* plus 47 extras helped take the home team up to 128.

Ballinger's bowling was steady with all the outfielders having a go whilst skipper Kit Reynolds performed heroics behind the stumps to ensure that not too many extras were given away. Unfortunately he couldn't help prevent the Waggoners donating 36 to the visitors score.

Fortunately 128 always looked beyong Beaconsfield and their final total of 90 - 10 was a fair reflection of Ballinger's dominance.

Ballinger's fielding was top draw with 2 very good run outs adding to some generally good ground fielding.

An enjoyable game played in the right spirit. Well done to all

Having suffered a defeat last week against Gerrards Cross## the boys were determined to reduce the number of wickets lost. We were struggling for numbers due to a clash with a paintballing party and were well aware of Chesham's high-scoring matches so far in the season## so we knew it was going to be tough. We were one player short in the end## due to a last minute illness.

The scoreboard started sliding backwards## losing 5 wickets in the first 6 overs against some very accurate bowling from Chesham. Unlike the last match## they didn't lose their heads this time## with some good performances## particularly from the last two pairs of batsmen. Charlie B and Louis began to pick up the run rate again## as the middle pair## and James A and Henry K sensibly reducing the number of wickets taken. The last pair (brothers Monty and Theo) scored some great runs and really put the pressure on the fielding side. The final score for BWCC batting: 244 (9 wickets)

Top batsmen: Monty 22## Theo 7## James Arnold 7 (no wickets lost)

Monty kept wicket for the match## with only 1 bye creeping past him## but quickly secured two quick stumpings (b. Theo) in one over to really reduce Chesham's run-rate. Great catch by Henry again at mid-off (b. Dylan); and accurate bowling from Henry K & James A earned them a wicket each. Chesham's final score 265 (6 wickets).

 

Although we lost by 21 runs## I was really pleased with the boys' performance at this match. Even though they were 1 man short in the field## they continued to work hard as a team## and kept Chesham's lead well below what they normally scored. Well done boys - I was really proud of you all.  (Wendy Hutson)

A bit of a disastrous half-term week trying to get a team together: as fast as I replaced unavailable players## someone else called off. Thinking I had at last reached the day of the match with a full team## we ended up two short at the last minute!

Ballinger batted first## with HWCC picking two of our mid-order batsmen to bat twice to make up the overs. Some erratic bowling from HWCC - they took 10 wickets## but gave away 44 runs in wides and no-balls. Top batsmen: Monty 26-0; Henry K 7-0. BWCC final score: 245 for 10

Our bowling and fielding started off better## with a guest appearance from Raphael W (age 6) who showed us all how well he can bowl already!! The fielding began to drift## with too many byes and a lack of back-up behind the wicket-keeper. HWCC's score continued upwards## and we could not take enough wickets to keep their score down. HWCC final score: 279 for 4. Top bowler: Henry K 2 wickets; James Bunce and Philip Sharkey taking the other 2.

Henry King captained for the first time this season.

Simon C and Matthew Barton opened the batting and kept the score over 200 runs for the first four overs (hooray!) Ballinger boys did a really good job to reduce the number of wickets they lost overall (only 3 this match) - well done## much better!! The number of runs continued to increase## albeit slowly## with Beaconsfield bowlers giving 50 away in extras. 

Top batsmen: Hugo 16 for 0; Simon C 5 for 0.

James A & James B opened the bowling really well. Hugo was back as wicket keeper with his usual excellent eye for the ball - only 1 bye.

BWCC bowlers were more accurate than their opponents## giving away only 24 in extras## and taking a total of 9 wickets - well done! Fielding was generally very good## with an amazing near-catch by Simon Carlin! Despite the roar of "catch" from the onlookers## no-one actually expected him to get near it## so as he managed to get a hand to it and stop the four## there was a well-deserved applause from both sides!

Top bowlers Charlie Barraclough 2 wickets for 6 (off 2); Simon Carlin 2 for 3 (off 3); Henry K 2 wickets for 8 runs off 3.

A worthy win by 58 runs - well done. (Wendy Hutson)

The weather gods were siding with Ballinger.  A game## scheduled for Wednesday which would have featured a full Wycombe side had to be rescheduled for Sunday## with Wycombe stripped of their county players.  Ballinger was also missing 6 first choice players but were able to put together a decent side## who delivered a convincing league win - at last. 

Freddie won the toss and elected to bowl.  Reece bowled with pace and accuracy and was unlucky not to take a wicket - finishing with just 7 runs off his 3 overs. The slow run rate## meant that Wycombe## who are used to scoring big## started taking risks - we missed a number of run out opportunities until Seth swooped onto the ball at close in square leg and ran out number 2.   The tight bowliing from Monty and Reece induced their danger man## Jack Whelan into attempting a number of risky shots## until he was caught well by Toby off Sam's first over.  It was a key wicket.  Just as their number 4 looked like he was going to strike us all around the ground## Sam followed this with a good CAB running 2/3rds of the way down the pitch.  Sam got their last dangerous looking batsman - clean bowled.  Freddie bowled a tight line and length## finishing with 3-12 off 4 overs. James Reid bowled tightly (1-2-1) and Ollie N-M succeeded in bagging two wickets for 4 runs of 9 balls## including a diving CAB - Monty## time to eat some humble pie after some of the pre-match jybes aimed at Ollie. 

A special word for the keeping from Toby which was first class - only 2 byes## took some really difficult balls and was energetic and active behind the stumps.  Also the bowling was much better.  Extras down to just 8.

Monty and Freddie openned and saw us home with a sensible approach to the low run rate required.  Wycombe bowling was tight and apart from a few poorly called run attempts## they both batted well.

Well done boys## - good performance which was really made by the very tight bowling and excellent keeping.

Monks Risborough had covered their wicket overnight## but there still looked enough in it for Ian Maciver to opt to bowl first. Nick Adams and Jack Hankinson opened proceedings steadily## and the scoring was slow## partially due to a wet outfield sporting a colourful crop of buttercups. Opening bat Amjad (52) must have thought it was his birthday as he profited from a succession of near misses when Ballinger fielders failed to hang on to (mostly) difficult catches. Sunshine gave way to a series of heavy showers - through which both sides bravely battled on. A superb diving catch by Rhodri Webster and a quick-thinking stumping by Richard O'Kelly redeemed Ballinger in the fielding department## and then Carlton Siddle## returning after a three week absence## showed how important he is to the side with a fine spell of bowling - 6 for 42 off 10 overs. However## Monks' total of 164 looked a competitive score## especially as a particularly heavy shower coinciding wiith the tea interval had spiced up the wicket.

Ballinger made a steady start through openers Richard O'Kelly and Rhodri Webster## and had put on 52 before Richard## trying to force the pace## was caught for 31. The showers returned## the temperature dropped## and the outfield became even slower. Where Monks' batsmen had scored threes## now similar shots were only going for two. Rollo McIntyre enlivened proceedings (as usual) but once he had gone for 24## wickets started to tumble as the batsmen tried ever harder to keep up with the necessary run rate. Rhodri went for a watchful 39## fifth out with the total on 112.## then as the "heavy guns" of Nick Adams and Jeremy Hunting both perished early in the cause of quick runs## it was left to Andy Thompson (15 not out) and Ian Maciver to shut up shop and secure a (losing) draw.
