By this time the pitch was starting to resemble a quagmire## the rain was pouring down again## and both teams were glad to get off the field. If only there had been a pavilion in which to shelter and change!

After putting Little Marlow into bat first## Waggoners struggled to contain Marlow openers Ali and Cox## who put on 59 between them. This gave the hosts a solid start and although Ballinger slowed them up## some steady batting took the home side to 144## a respectable score for 20 overs on a long boundary pitch. Highlights were a superb 3 over spell by Ollie and a couple of great catches by Sam.

Ballinger started disasterously## after the normally super-dependable Gethin Ross was bowled out for a duck after facing only 3 balls. Rob and Sam steadied the ship though putting together an 80 partnership which gave the B`s some hope## and at the half-way point they were only 7 runs behind the target average. Somewhat of a batting collapse followed though## and a tight field restricted our boys to a total of 120## on a long but pleasant evening.

Our man of the match - Sam Peters.

Having won the toss skipper James Macintyre elected to bat. Those wise old heads amongst us know that on sunny evenings on the Green always bat first. By the time the home side were trying to accelerate the run rate## the sun was right behind the bowlers arm making it very difficult to see where the ball was.

The Waggoners bowled well with some excellent fielding generating 4 run-outs. Unfortunately there were also some 'Fred Carno' moments with simple catches being missed and overthrows conceded. The visitors final total of 108 was probably 20 more than they should have got but a very manageable target.

James and Brandon set off in hot pursuit and were soon infront of the rate but the introduction of Josh King changed all that. Three wickets in two overs slowed the chase to a crawl and once Brandon went none of the Ballinger batters were able to get on top of some tight Cross bowling. Seven batsmen were bolwed giving an indication of how straight the visitors bowled.

80 - 10 was probably the rights score for us but if we had kept the opposition to 80/90 what might have happened then?

A really first class victory against very good opposition and an excellent all round performance.  That was both our league match and our cup quarter final.  So we are now in the semis …
 
It took some perseverance to get this game played at all due to the weather.  This was the third try.
 
We won the toss and batted.  George Cooke and  Freddie Thompson started well and then after George fell to a catch## Fin Clark and Freddie put on 68 for the 2nd wicket## both batting very well against the GX opener## Hamish Smart## who is one of the best Bucks U11 bowlers## and  then Fin in particular opening out against the 1st and 2nd change bowlers## with some very sweetly timed lofted drives back over the bowler’s head.  He showed that he can strike the ball very cleanly and has a lot of potential with bat as well as ball.  He retired on 30 with the total on 77 in the 14th over.   There was then a succession of wickets as the middle order did the right thing and tried to maximise over the last 6 overs.  Freddie was eventually out for 28 – again the foundation stone of the innings.  Zac Bischoff and Marcus Tingey did well at the end with some hard blows and well taken singles.  102 for 6 – a decent total against a good attack; but not out of reach by any means.     
 
Enter that man## George Cooke - the quickest bowler in both sides on the day and possibly the best.   He bowled one of the openers and then the GX number 3## taking 2 for 4 off his first 3 overs.  Freddie at the other end took 2 for 6 off his first 3## removing the GX numbers 4 and 5.  After 6 overs they were 10 for 4## with their 2 best batters gone.    The contrasting opening combination of speed and legspin had done the job.  GX never recovered.  Joe Turrell came on and took 2 for 11 off 3 with his left arm finger spin; and then 3 run outs and 2 wickets for Will Fennell finished them off.  There was also some very tight inswing from Angus Denison-Smith and very tidy legspin from Jamie Fulcher.   Ballinger throughout fielded very well## holding all but one catch## with some excellent ground fielding; and a great spirit out on the field.  It was a pleasure to be out there.
 
Stand out batsman – Fin Clark## bowler – Cookie## fielder – everyone (with special mention for Taylor behind the stumps and Rory Bland for one great stop at mid-off).
 
A great performance – one to be proud of.
 
Andy

Ballinger U 11A v Chesham A
Friday June 10th 2011
Ballinger lost by 3 wickets with 2 balls to spare.   A cracking game and a very tense finish.  11 young Ballinger men have much to be proud of.   They batted well against a strong attack containing 3 county bowlers## and then bowled and fielded with great skill and spirit and so nearly managed to defend a total that never looked quite big enough.
We won the toss and batted.  Freddie Thompson (15) and George Cooke (25) put on 38 for the first wicket against tight## penetrating bowling.   George was the backbone of the innings.  But after they went## nobody quite got going## although there were some useful runs from Joe Turrell## Angus Denison-Smith and Rory Bland and then from Taylor Levitt## Jamie Fulcher and Fin Clark at the end.   All batted well.  The bowling was of a high standard.  But 85 for 9 from our 20 overs did not look to be quite enough.
It was crucial that we bowled and fielded well; and the opening seam-spin combination of George Cooke and Freddie Thompson started well.  George worked up some good pace and bowled Chesham opener## Joe Rance## in the first over;  and after 6 overs  Chesham had been restricted to 20 for 1.  Fin Clark carried on George’s good work## bowling the other Chesham opener## Tom Petrie## to leave Chesham 26 for 2## with Ballinger building the pressure.   Joe Turrell then took over from Freddie and claimed another wicket## again bowled.  But at 57 for 3## Chesham had slightly got away## mainly thanks to some clean hitting from their number 3## Jamie Woodley.  Here the spirit of the Ballinger fielding was excellent.  They kept up the pressure and would not give up.  Angus Denison-Smith bowled 2 superbly tight overs for only 3 runs and then George came back and bowled a wicket maiden.    With Angus  taking a wicket in his last over## 81 for 3 had become 83 for 5; and Chesham were feeling the pressure.  In the last over Chesham still needed 2 runs with 2 new batsmen at the crease and the cream of the Chesham batting long gone.   Fin took a wicket with his first ball.  Was it to be victory at the last gasp?   No ....  Chesham squeezed a single and then scampered a bye with only 2 balls to go  ....... so close.
Pick of batters – George Cooke; pick of the bowlers – Angus Denison-Smith; and star fielder of the day – hard to pick##  but Taylor Levitt who did a very good job behind the stumps.
Overall## a great effort!  Quite rightly## the Ballinger boys’ heads stayed up the whole way## even in defeat.    A great game played in a highly competitive but very good spirit.
 
ANDY

Our first league match and a very comfortable victory## by 44 runs; despite missing a few of our regulars to holidays and a half term disco!  Joe Turrell won the toss for Ballinger and we batted first## scoring 120 from our 20 overs.  Freddie Thompson and Joe Turrell both contributed 30 retired## and after some quick fire runs from Angus Denison-Smith ## George Cooke batted very sensibly with controlled aggression for 21 not out## assisted by some lusty blows from Ben Westland## to give us a strong total.  
Once again our opening bowlers## George Cooke and Fin Clark## bowled fast## full and straight and took early wickets## and then## with a run out and wickets too for Angus and Will Fennell## Winchmore Hill were reeling at 15 for 7.  Joe then rightly chose to give everyone a bowl## providing good experience out in the middle## with Freddie Peck picking up a deserved wicket.  Winchmore Hill limped along to 76 for 8 off their 20 overs.
Another strong performance.  Well done!
Sadly a chance to beat one of the weaker sides was denied us by the weather.

As the Chairman and skipper had disappeared for a family fun weekend## Paul Branigan was drafted in to complete the formalities and in time honoured tradition lost the toss and Ballinger were offered first use of a still drying wicket.

Monty Thompson and Will Smith got off to a solid start against the league leader’s tidy opening attack before Monty perished.  Rob McIntyre joined Will at the crease and the run rate picked up with some fine attacking shots and good progress was made before both departed in quick succession. By this stage Will had reached his fourth fifty of the season. His Gilchrist-like departure drawing admiration from Wendover as the umpire’s finger remained in his pocket. This left two debutantes at the wicket ‘rusty’ Jon McKewan and Will ‘boycs’ Saunders. Both scored good runs after playing themselves in before Will## belying his nickname## perished for 29 in the pursuit of quick runs. A similar fate befell the skipper## who clearly felt it was too cold out in the middle and didn’t hang around thus allowing the spectators chance to see a  typical cavalier innings from Max Dugdale and then Basty Richards took Ballinger to maximum batting points before they too played one attacking shot too many. Mckewan finally paid the price for some near suicidal running when run out for 33 off the last ball of a rain restricted 44 overs. Ballinger had reached a useful score of 207 for 8 but against the best batting line up in the league there was a lot of work to be done.

The players came off for tea as the heavens opened and a cautious umpire led to a delayed restart leaving Wendover to get 164 off 35 overs for a winning draw or the full 208 for an outright victory.

Reece Tiley and Basty opened the attack and despite struggling with a wet surface Reece bowled very tidily and keeping the ball up to the batsmen completed a good six over spell. At the other end Basty claimed one of the openers and was unlucky not to get more as Patel  cut loose but evaded all attempts to catch him. At 88 for 1 off 12 Ballinger were just about to tighten the noose## through some promised fine bowling from Ben Dugdale and Evan Webster## but the weather Gods took a hand and further punishment was avoided.

12 points each a fair reward for an afternoon’s toil.

It's a while since Ballinger visited Kimble CC the venue for this game against new opponents Rivetts.

Despite (once again) losing the toss on a wet and wintry afternoon## stand-in skipper Hunting was not too unhappy to be put into bat on a pitch that looked almost unaffected by the overnight rain and the openers soon got to work. Paul Humphreys began in his usual## attacking style and after being promoted up the order## Fally supported him well. Some loose opening bowling allowed the BWCC batsmen to get settled and the score was ticking along nicely until the more accurate first change bowlers were brought into the attack## causing the run-rate to level out until Paul fell to a fine delivery in the 16th over after an opening partnership of 78. It was not long before we were two down as Joe Hankinson was outdone by the same ball just a few minutes later which brought Ian Davies to the crease. Ian was scoring in style and managed to find the boundaries with ease## despite the slow outfield. Upon the dismissal of Fally## Ian was joined by Bastie who began to increase the run-rate## including a straight six that would have cleared any boundary. These two batsmen took the score past 150 before succumbing to some good bowling by the Rivetts openers## re-entering the frame and Ballinger finished on a respectable 173 when called in by Hunting.

Ballinger came out keen (as ever) in the field and## with the weather clearing up## the omens looked promising as a good start followed.  With the Hankinson brothers opening the line## a wicket in just the second over from a well taken catch by the hands of Fally gave Joe his first wicket. Joe bowled very tightly for his first match of the season## finishing with figures of 6-4-1 including three maidens and Hankinson senior finishing with 7-0-29-0. With large boundaries and a good wicket it looked as if the spinners would do most of the damage and this prediction seemed correct as Stuart MacGowan took a wicket in his first over## caught in the covers## Jake Cutter proceeded to bowl from the other end## also taking a wicket in his first few balls.  These two continued to bowl the next twelve overs with few runs coming off the bat and two well taken catches from Jack Hankinson coming off Jake’s bowling. Rivets began to accelerate and runs were now coming more freely## nevertheless Stuart finished his spell with well-earned figures of 6-2-28-1. Jake continued on with Ben Dugdale from the other end who## despite a few loose opening balls## ensued to bowl well## restricting the imperious Smitter who surpassed his half century in no time. Ben was denied a wicket as a result of some sloppy fielding including a few dropped catches and not even the quick thinking of his brother behind the stumps could dismiss the batsmen## ending the day with 6-0-32-0. However Jake received a lot more luck; Jack Hankinson holding another catch off a top-edge and Bastie making no mistake with his more simple effort leaving him with figures of 12-0-63-5. Although BWCC were by far on top## with 30 needed off the last two overs## batting out for the draw seemed the sensible option as Rivetts ended their innings on 158 with 3 wickets in hand.

Both teams seemed worthy winners in a well fought game## however a draw seemed the correct result.

Skipper Davies## back on duty## for once failed to win the toss## and can't have been surprised when Downley invited Ballinger to bat first## as the pitch had endured a night's rain## and was therefore likely to be unpredictable. The start was unpromising## the first wicket falling at 15## when Rhodri Webster departed caught. Rollo joined Danny Draper## and they set about repairing the situation. A watchful partnership soon became a dominant one## with Danny (profiting from three dropped catches!) playing second fiddle to a rampant Rollo. They had put on 103 for the second wicket before a Downley fielder at last clung on to a Danny offering## and he departed for a valuable 40. Then came a dose of the Ballinger wobbles - not unknown when we have a strong-on-paper batting side. Richard O'Kelly and Matt Riley were gone in the blink of an eye## and suddenly the scoreboard read 130 for 4. Ian Davies joined Rollo## and they proceeded to put on 92 for the fifth wicket. The fact that Ian## batting well## managed to contribute a mere 18 of these illustrates the overwhelming dominance of Rollo## who mercilessly destroyed the Downley bowling on his way to superlative 145## including no fewer that 11 sixes and 11 fours! Magnificent stuff. We await the insurance claims....

A final total of 247 for 8 at the end of 45 overs looked good enough to win most matches## but we have had plenty of problems with Downley in the past. A cool cloudy afternoon had now given way to breezy sunshine## and the pitch## never the problem it threatened## was now even easier. Enter the man who has swung so many matches Ballinger's way over the years - Nick Adams. To bowl the prolific Downley captain Cox with his very first ball ( a full toss## but doubless planned as a canny surprise) was a huge bonus.. But in his third over he excelled himself## with two wickets## clean bowled## off the first two balls. The hat trick ball looked plumb LBW (as the batsman later admitted it probably was) but was given not out. The batsman's respite was short-lived## as Nick then took a blinding caught & bowled to make it a triple wicket maiden over## and. left Downley in utter disarray at 17 for 4. They recovered somewhat## but Ballinger were not to be denied. Nick took an even better catch## as Andy Thompson and Ian Maciver each bagged a couple of scalps## and Ian Davies wrapped up the innings with a wicket in the 36th over## to leave Downley 135 all out.

A thoroughly admirable victory## celebrated in customary style in the Old Swan afterwards## as the jugs kept appearing! Maximum points too - much needed## just a shame we lost out by not providing an umpire for the first time this season.

Simon Carlin captained today's match - a very exciting game played in brilliant sunshine for a change!! Having won the toss## he elected to field first.

The Ballinger boys## having generally had a very accurate season on the bowling front## let it slip badly in today's match. 52 runs were conceded in extras (oops!)## but Hugo did a stirling job as wicket-keeper## with only 2 byes. James Larard took 2 wickets and Henry King## Simon Carlin## James Arnold & Will Hardman each took 1 wicket. Energy on the field was also definitely lacking.

Having had a "few words" in the changing room## the boys took the criticism well## and lifted their game## knowing that they would lose their 2nd position in the Bucks league if they didn't.

The Waggoners batted steadily and well## and didn't let the first two wickets dampen their enthusiasm or fluster them. Each pair came out## ready to face some very good bowling from Chalfont St Giles## and I saw some of the best shots played this season!  Simon Carlin was top batsman today## scoring 23 ( 4 fours !!) - some classic shots## and continually looking for the gaps in the field. Charlie Barraclough scored 14## but lost a wicket.

The match still had all to play for as the last pair came in to bat - it could still easily go either way. Louis Thomson and Matthew Barton faced some fast and very accurate bowling - although no runs were scored off the bat## they took advantage of a couple of byes## and defended their wickets well## not risking anything against determinded Ch St G fielders.

BWCC finished on 275 (against 261)## so winning the match by 14 runs !!! Well done boys.

Keep your eye on the Bucks league tables - (update done## but not yet showing) Will we retain 2nd place in the league## or will Gerrards X snatch our position - still all to be played for in the final game!!  (Wendy Hutson)

We travelled to Chalfont St Peter on Thursday and had a very enjoyable evening considering the coach didn't have a team at 8.00am in the morning. His thanks goes out to all those mums who helped make it happen.

Chalfont batted first and when the skipper Kit was told Ballinger would have to take the field with only 10 players again## he was completely unconcerned and had already organised the bowling order etc.

I would like to say that the Waggoners were like a well oiled machine but that would be a bit of an exaggeration. 24 extras does give the batting side a bit of help but the boys fielded well and took most of the catches offered and the ones missed would have been 'top draw' if taken. A special mention must go to James Gill whos 3 overs cost 1 run plus a wicket and he took a good catch and almost took a blinder.

I could mention all the bowlers but look at the stats and you'll see that they all did well whilst keeping the home side down to 69 in their 20 overs

Simon Carlin and Ben Westland opened up for the Waggoners. Ben's innings was cruelly cut short when he played on but Simon was in imperious form. Charlie Barraclogh and Simon added 34 before Simon was out for a very well played 17. Charlie then added 22 with Ollie Hardman and## when Ollie was out for 8. watched the opposition bowl us home with a series of wides.

Well done to all but especially to Kit for running the game so well.

Ballinger travelled to Taplow unsure of what to expect. Would the wicket be fit for play? Would we actually have 11 players? Thankfully the answer to both was yes. Taplow won the toss and opted to bat first on what looked a tired pitch. Despite an excellent opening spell from Jack Hankinson and Nick Tegg (yes we were short of bowling) Taplow cruised to an opening stand of 50 before Max Dugdale swooped on a quick single and threw the stumps down. Wickets tumbled at regular intervals but first team player Mills compiled an excellent 94 which enabled Taplow to declare at 243-9 after 43 overs. Wickets were shared between Jack Hankinson (2-40)## Fally (1-43)## S Richards (2-43)## Graham Salisbury (1-17) and W Smith (2-6). Ballingers reply started badly when Humphreys and Bunce departed with on 9 on the board. Fally and Will put on 66 before Fally went. Will continued as partners came and went and would have scored more if the boundaries hadnt been ridiculously huge. He was eventually out for an excellent 63 caught whilst trying to hit his elusive straight six on the boundary edge. Wickets kept falling but skipper Salisbury and Nick held out for an honourable draw. Good game

Ballinger entertained local club Missenden Misfits on Sunday on a cold day at Ballinger common. Having won the toss Ballinger elected to bat and lost Humphreys for 17 and Smith for 6. Riley continued in his normal style and with Fally and Hunting helped Ballinger declare at 225-6 at tea. Matt had by then scored an imperious 124 and should have broken the club record for the highest individual score. The Misfits reply was soon dented when Cutter removed opener Partridge with a vicious leg spinner that Shane Warne would have been proud of. Unfortunately Misfits made their intentions clear that we would have to work hard to bowl them out. Enter the old timer Stuart McGowan. With all of his experience he whittled through the batting order to finish with figures of 6-40. He was ably supported by the latest spin bowler to come out of the colts section Monty Thompson## fresh from his gargantuan tea to keep his energy up. Monty bowled exceptionally## especially against the left handers and finished things off with figures of 3-40.

Longwick arrived at the common on Sunday to be greeted by a cold windy day. Longwick won the toss and put Ballinger into bat hoping the new ball would produce a cluster of wickets. Openers Humphreys and Smith obviously had read the same game plan and proceeded to put on 88 for the first wicket before Paul fell LBW for 55. Will soon followed when he nicked one behind for 21 and walked from the crease before the umpire had a chance to put his finger up. Matt by now was into his stride and with Kellock (16) and Hunting (59 No) put on 150 runs for the next two wickets. Matt eventually fell for 62 trying to up the run rate. Nick then scored a quick fire 18 to allow Ballinger to declare on 261-4 at tea. The Longwick team left the field thinking they were well an truly out of the game. They soon realised they werent. Jono removed the number 1 bat for 4 but the next four batsmen added 160 runs at a decent rate and soon they thought they were in the game. Enter Jack Hankinson. In 14 hostile overs Jack picked up 5 wickets## either bowled or LBW. By now Longwick had decided that a draw was the best option and the bowlers were rotated trying to get the last 4 batsmen out. Jamie## Jake and Monty ( who again bowled exceptionally well and should have picked up more than the one wicket he ended with) all had a go but in the end we couldnt dislodge the number 11 batsman. A good game and a draw was most probably a fair result.

Ballingers Sunday jugernaught travelled to Bourne end on Sunday hoping to keep the winning ways going. Having won the toss skipper Salisbury decided to bat first on what looked an interesting pitch. Initial thoughts were soon proved correct as openers Humphreys and Smith were soon either fending the ball off their noses or trying to keep balls out that rolled along the ground. They put on 43 before Will gloved one off another ball that bounced more than it should of and then Paul then departed to the opposite when a ball pitched half way down and rolled along the floor for 42. Jeremy hung around for a good 32 and had good partnerships with Jack Hankinson (22) and Stuart (25) which took Ballinger to 184-9 at tea. Bourne Ends reply started badly when Jack clean bowled Duncombe for 1## smashing the middle stump in the process## and then had his fellow opener caught behind for 20. Evan ably supported Jack from the other end and removed the number 3 for a duck before the spin twins of McGowan and Cutter came on to spin their web and proceeded to take the next 5 wickets. The wickets were all shared round with jack and Jake taking two each and Stuart and Evan 3 each bowling Bourne out for 120 A good game but not the sort of pitch we should play on too often##

Aldbury arrived on Sunday to a damp Ballinger and were surprised that upon losing the toss were asked to bowl. Nick was soon run out by Humphreys whilst attempting third run and pulled his calf in the process. Not a good start to his walking holiday in the alps!! Paul was joined by Rollo and between them added 139 runs before paul was lbw for 87. Rollo continued in his aggressive style and was soon sending the ball to all parts of Ballinger. After two quick wickets he was joined by Ben Dugdale who hit a good 26. Tea was taken with Ballinger scoring 294-6 (a new club record) and Rollo not out on 139 after a true exhibition of power batting Aldbury`s rely had reached 103-2 before the rain finally finished the game off. Stuart picking up the two wickets to fall

Ballinger win by 38 runs. A good win in our last league match## but not with quite the verve and excitement of Tuesday’s win at Gerrards X. You can’t do that every day. Marlow put Ballinger in on a damp grass strip## which was true but slower and lower than the boys might have been used to## playing as they do often on nippy astro pitches. That might have had something to do with the early departures of George Cooke and Fin Clark## both bowled. Ballinger were not used to being 12 for 2 after 2 and were not expecting it. But Freddie Thompson was as reliable as ever## clocking up his fourth retirement at not out 30 of the season so far. He has so far scored 210 runs in 8 matches at an average of 52.5 (4 not outs). He had good help from Taylor Levitt (12) and Joe Turrell (18) today## coming in at 4 and 5; but after that the Ballinger batting rather tailed off. All out for 106 off 19 overs was in the end a little disappointing against an attack which## after its opening bowlers had had their 4 overs each## was## to be honest## weak. Thankfully the Ballinger bowling and fielding display was excellent; and well led by Joe Turrell## who made intelligent bowling changes and field placings throughout. George Cooke as usual struck early to remove one opener## with the first of 2 catches by Taylor Levitt. Then the Marlow numbers 1 and 3 put together a well paced partnership of 29 which had them up with the required rate## despite good tight bowling from George and from Angus Denison-Smith. Joe then put himself on with Fin Clark at the other end and a gush of wickets followed - 3 for Turrell (2 bowled and one stumped by Freddie Thompson## moonlighting behind the stumps) and 2 for Clark. One Turrell wicket ball was described (by the bowler) as “turning like Shane Warne”. That was game over in effect. Jamie Fulcher (1 for 2 off 2) and Rory Bland (2 for 8 off 2## including another stumping) then started the mopping up operation. Fulcher’s wicket was courtesy of a stunning catch just behind square leg by George Cooke## who is rapidly turning into a very good fielder indeed. That was nearly but not quite bettered by Taylor Levitt’s diving catch off Bland in the next over. Very good fielding indeed all round## completed by a well taken run out to claim the last wicket. Stand out batting – Freddie## bowling – JoeTurrell## fielding – George Cooke. A very pleasing end to the league season. But it’s not all over - I shall be organising some friendlies over the summer; and we still have a cup semi-final. Andy

Games against Great Kingshill have always been tight but we have never quite found the winning formula.  Missing our two openners was a poor start - however so were Gt Kingshill so the teams were balanced.  Again## we lost the toss as we always seem to and batted first...again.  Posting our lowest total against this opposition of just 85## it seemed that history would repeat itself but not this time - Ballinger won quite convincingly but this was a game that ebbed and flowed and a result was never totally assured. 

The openning pair of Toby and Brandon started well with some good stroke play - keeping the run rate at around 5-6 and over. The loss of three quick wickets slowed proceedings down and the run rate dropped to under 4 an over.  Brandon continued to be the key run-maker with some well timed hitting of the ball.  The in-form Henry Turrell came in and scored 10 runs from just 7 balls before holing out.   Brandon was the next to go - fine innings - his 25 coming from just 19 balls. 

Greg (9) and James McIntyre (13) put on an 8th wicket partnership of 27 runs - critical to get the total to something which we could defend.  

Despite an early wicket by Hamish## the opposition were going well at 25-1 off the first 5. On come Will Arnold and James McIntyre and instantly turn the screw.  Will bowled with absolute precision## two maidens in a row - one being a double wicket maiden including getting the settled no.2.  Tight bowling was critical because their no 4. Freddie had blasted 19 runs off 11 balls in the previous encounter.  Frustrated on 5 from 13 balls## he went after James## miscued and Hamish caught it.  Pressure was the key element and these two bowlers had changed the game completely. Gt Kingsill were 32 for 6 off 10 but Ballinger still had a job to do.  

Their number 8 was going along fine - suddenly a target of 30 runs from 5 overs looked achievable when he was scoring at well over a run a ball.  Next in is Dom - again fantastic line and length - 1 wicket from 2 maidens and the point at which we won the match when Brandon## who had not made a single mistake all day including taking a very good run-out and no byes## did the fastest stumping I have seen taking the ball just next to the leg stump.  At this point the game was won and just left Greg who late in the season had discovered that he good off-spin the ball a foot bowled a peach to the get the last wicket. 

Well done## Ballinger## this was a very good victory - made by the bowlers and some excellent glove work...season ends with won 5## lost 5 - probably our best season## when we are always up against the likes of Wycombe## GX and Chesham.

Sadly the The Lee were unable to puit out a side for Saturday's game which is a shame as it was a lovely day. On the bright side we did get maximum points.

 

See Hawridge and Cholesbury report for the match that did take place

Having already won one game because The Lee couldn't put out a side we decided to see what could be achieved against replacement guests Hawridge and Cholesbury.

It was a beautiful day and the pitch looked good and with no points at stake skipper Kerry had no hesitation in electing to bat having won the toss at last.

Will Smith (33) and Max Dugdale(16) set off at 6 an over on another belter of a pitch but finally the H & C bowlers sorted out their line and length. In particular Akram who bowled 7-4-8-2 of controlled seam bowling. Azam was doing the same from the other end and soon frustration set in amongst the Waggoners batters. First to go was Max followed by Bastie then Will. New man Hameen Thacker (10) was pleased to survive his first ball but started to show glimpses of hidden talents.Stuart McGowan was making a guest appearance and was looking in no trouble until sold a dummy by Brandon Allen. whose father Steve (11) had also made his first appearance for the Waggoners. Steve was out caught and was shortly followed by Ben Dugdale. There was then a rare sighting of the skipper with his pads on but it didn't last long when he was bowled by a 'jaffa'. Another newcomer Michael Burden (9*) and Will Reid(10) took us past the hundred mark but 117 was never going to be enough on this pitch.

The sides enjoyed a long## leisurely tea interval## when they had chance to sample all the wonderful food provided by this weeks top victualler - Jan Kerry.

Will Reid and Michael Burden opened up for the home side and kept the H&C openers very quiet with Michael removing Drane in his second over for the club. Unfortunately this only introduced Mohammed who batted as though he was having a gentle stroll in the park. He was dropped twice on his way to 50 but was finally snared by Stuart courtesy of a very fine running catch by Bastie.

Unfortunately the score was 80 and Hawridge had released one of their batters to go home so confident were they. Stuart now caught and bowled the other opener Rutt who had batted 21 overs for his 27.

The rest of the visiting batsmen had been baiting the incumbents so as wickets fell it was now their chance to show how easy it was. They tried## Oh how they tried.

Hameen (4-7) was bowling very tidily from the other end## another tidy over from Stuart meant after 24 overs the visitors were 96 - 3. Then the wheels fell off. A double wicket maiden from Stuart##  a brilliant bit of bowling from Ben## another double wicket maiden from Stuart and suddenly the Waggoners have gone from despair to a glimpse of victory.

With only 13 required but with the last pair at the wicket## remember one has gone home early## Ben produces an unplayable delivery to win the game. 

Great fun. Stuart's contribution of 6-39 was invaluable but all the players kept going and really enjoyed the day.

Another local derby against a team we had narrowly beaten by two runs last year.  We won the toss and batted first.

Max and Hamish got Ballinger off to a flyer reaching 40 after 5 overs although neither went on to a big score after useful starts. Then our middle order collapsed badly with some very loose shots leaving us reeling with just 60-7 in the 11th over!  Fortunately  Henry and Reece came to the rescue and rebuilt with an excellent 40 run partnership for the eighth wicket  and then Dom chipped in a few more so that we finished with a competitive 121-8.

Ley Hill’s innings started slowly and the pressure built and build for the batters against some tight bowling from Hamish## Reece## Dom and Ben and good fielding early on. Max contributed a sharp catch behind the stumps. With Ley Hill at 58-4 after 13 overs needing 65 off 7 more overs## it seemed the match was in the bag for our lads.  But Ley Hill’s batsmen seized the initiative against our weaker bowlers and took advantage of the very short boundary against some loose deliveries. The pressure built for us then and we made a couple of misfields. They needed 3 to win off the last over from Reece: dot ball## dot## dot## dot..looking good and then…. a fraction shorter and cut away for four. Ley Hill were home with one ball left.It was so disappointing especially with such a tight margin and several small things that would have made the difference and got us over the line. The game was played with great spirit by both sides and had ebbed and flowed right through. Hopefully we will all learn to win these tight games.

Match report to be done - but we're through to the Bucks semi-final having retained our 2nd place in the S Bucks Div 1 league## and although finishing on equal points with GX## our net run rate was better!!! Well done (WH)

When one thinks of the Ballinger/ Hyde Heath rivalry words like ardour## intensity## vigour## zeal and vehemence come to mind## todays game had passion and enthusiasm in abundance and it turned out to be a thrilling game of cricket. On a pleasant day Ballinger journeyed across to the heath to play in the incredibly important local derby which feels more like an Old Firm game or a Merseyside Derby rather than a game of fun social village cricket between these two picturesque villages. At precisely 2 oclock battle commenced and the crowds (all of 4 spectators) were set## the players chosen and the pitch was ready. Ballinger were put into bat and what seemed a greenish looking pitch which played fairly inconsistently with a few balls keeping low (my excuse for missing a straight one). Unfortunately I didnt trouble the scorers so when Joe was out for a brisk 6## Ballinger were looking down the barrel at 14 for 2. However the tide was somewhat turned by a very good partnership between the experienced and effective Jeremy and Paul of 90 which set the standards for the rest of the team to follow. Jeremy was out for 26 meanwhile Paul looked in imperious form as he compiled a serene 81. The platform was set from some lower order hitting and Jono (12)## Basty (10)## Graham(33*) and Jake(11*) all chipped in with very useful contributions however Ballinger still looked 20 runs short finishing on 205 After an excellent tea which included copious amounts of Chicken wraps homemade flapjacks and succulent brownies. Ballinger entered the fray again with a vicious combination of Jack Sideshow Bob Hankinson and Evan Webster both equally determined to maintain the Waggoners honour and carry them through to victory. However the Heath had the better start with Haddock and Capper starting the proceedings strongly and putting Ballinger on the back foot from the start. Evan then bowled a ball which was nicked to a wide second slip## despite the batmens best efforts at feigning innocence## the umpire was very quick to send him on his way. This brought Shrimpton to the crease who never really looked as easy edging and flicking his way to a streaky 24 before being given out LBW to Joe Hankinson## a decision he didnt seem pleased with. The Heaths number 4 came and went quickly and tamely this brought the explosive Burgham to the crease who smacked us about last year. However Jake Cutter ( 12 overs## 4 wickets for 58) was not in awe of his reputation and proceeded to bamboozle him with his spin## bounce## turn and flight before getting him deservedly stumped for a tame 3. However Capper was still at the other end and he seemed to be taking the game away from the Waggoners but cometh the hour## cometh the man and Joe Hankinson produced one of his best balls of the season (an in-swinging Yorker) to remove Capper for a well-crafted and belligerent 81. The next wicket was so textbook and was so well bowled that I feel it deserved a paragraph for its description. The context was that Jake Cutter had just dropped a sitter of a catch against the Heath number 8 batsman who had just come to the crease. What then ensued will go down in Waggoners folklore## Cutter living up to his name and using all his experience and guile produced a ball which Shane Warne/Graham best leg-spinner in the club Salisbury would have been proud of## it pitched outside leg stump and hit the top of off stump leaving the bamboozled batsman to trudge off back to the pavilion for a blob. We were into their tail and when Jack Hankinson was brought back on that ever-so sweet victory looking within reach. However Jack couldnt quite get it right and despite bowling at the Heaths last pair neither he nor and Evan could quite break the deadlock. The last over was incredibly tense with 14 needed and 1 wicket left all three results were possible## however Jack bowled an efficient over but couldnt break the stone-walling of Richards and Stevens who both proved to be highly experienced and difficult to remove. The final result felt more like a loss then a draw but in hindsight it probably proved to be a fair reflection of an enjoyable and exciting match which turned out to be a brilliant advocate for timed cricket rather then this 40 over nonsense## bring on next years match!

The Lee won the toss and## perhaps defensively as it turned out## elected to bowl. Ballinger’s opening pair of Webster and O’Kelly started steadily against steady bowling## but Richard went for 12## and the strike rate instantly jumped## with the advent of Rollo## who hit 26 off 21 deliveries (4 fours## 1 six) – the “worm” on the ipad scoring software (as demonstrated to an incredulous Gerry Hunting after the match) shot up. He too was bowled by The Lee opener John Humphreys. Rhodri and Rollo had put on 36## but then came the meat of the Ballinger innings with a partnership of 86 between captain Ian Davies and Rhodri## before Ian departed for 49 (after having had a couple of lives). Paul Humphreys had no such luck## holing out on the boundary over the bowler’s head. Carlton Siddle (15) then put on 42 with Rhodri## who passed his fifty and then kicked on## before eventually he too holed out: an excellent innings## full of class - 78 off 97 balls with 10 fours. Thompson## Kellock and Maciver added another 30 between them with some swings (and the occasional miss)## to leave Ballinger on 226 for 7## a decent but not overwhelming total on a good track and fast outfield. This left the Lee needing 5 an over to win. It turned out to be well beyond them## since they were several batsmen light. The key for Ballinger was to remove their openers## John Swain and Warren Davis. Jack Hankinson got John Swain in the 7th over courtesy of a sharp catch in the slips from Ian Davies. But a 65 run partnership for the second wicket saw The Lee’s hopes rise## until it was ended by Carlton Siddle## who then went on to snap up another wicket## caught behind by Richard O'Kelly. However## so long as Warren Davis was at the crease## The Lee had a chance. He alternated watchful defence with cleanly hit straight drives and powerful slogs (“fetches” if one is being kind) to cow corner. Thankfully for Ballinger his innings of 70 was ended when he fell lbw to Thompson. Carlton then took 2 quick wickets and Ballinger were in the hunt for a win. But on Davis’s departure## The Lee had shut up shop – showing a truly disappointing lack of endeavor; and although skipper Ian Davies tried a variety of combinations of spin and seam## The Lee’s numbers 8 and 9 batted out with solid## if rather boring## defence. A winning draw## but ultimately not entirely satisfactory. Rhodri Webster was obviously the pick of batsmen; and Carlton Siddle was the pick of the bowlers with 12 overs 5 maidens 37 runs 5 wickets.

With the first half of the league season over## Ballinger were looking to consolidate their mid-table position by completing the double over bottom of the table Potten End. Somewhat surprisingly## Potten End## having won the toss (is Ian Davies losing his golden touch??) elected to bat first. Perhaps they had heard that BWCC were missing a number of key players## notably their first and second change bowling attack. What they obviously didn't know about was Ballinger's reserve strength! Nick Adams and Jack Hankinson gave Ballinger their customary accurate opening## and Potten End made slow progress on a flat wicket## with a very slow outfield affected by recent rains. Nick made the first breakthrough## with the total on 24## courtesy of a fine catch by Max Maciver## thankfully back in our ranks after a term's loan to Berkhamsted School. Another wicket fell at 31## this time a run-out resulting from some fine fielding - a feature of Ballinger's work on the daywas superlative ground fielding and throwing. The score had risen to 72 by the 22nd over## when drinks were taken. Due to a complete and regrettable absence of any Ballinger"supporters" in the pavilion## the opposition had to make the drinks themselves. What they found## or put in them## is open to conjecture## as immediately play resumed the wheels fell off the Potten End batting and the Great Maciver Show started. The combination of Ian's bowling and Max's catching proved totally devastating## as the next 8 wickets fell in the space of 19 overs for 39 runs. Jono Lacey and Jamie Kellock chipped in with a smart catch apiece## and Potten End finished with a distinctly sub-par total of 111. Ian's bowling figures of 8 for 16 in 11.1 overs were truly exceptional## but even though he didn't take a wicket## Max's spell of 12 overs for 36 played no small part in Ballinger's dominance.. Had it not been for Potten End opener Pickard - 10th man out for a studied 43 - doubless their fate would have been even worse.

So quickly had Ballinger bowled their overs that their batsmen had to face 11 overs before tea was due. In this time they lost Matthew Riley to a rather extraordinary dismissal## when the fielders all appealed for a catch## only for him to be given out LBW. Rhodri Webster was coping well with a more than adequate opening spell from the bowlers when he was undone by a sharp catch for a well-crafted 20. Max Maciver## who today could seemingly do little wrong## was joined by skipper Davies## and they had hoisted the score to 66 when the latter was caught for a fairly rapid 17. Max suffered the same fate soon after## but not before top-scoring with 29. In came Paul Humphreys to demonstrate an impeccable defensive technique for a while## before opening his shoulders## and it was a surprise when he perished LBW for 21## but by this time the total was 96 for 5## and sensible batting with masses of overs in hand would surely see Ballinger over the line. Will Smith provided exactly the sensible batting required## and Jamie Kellock applied the coup-de-grace with three thumping boundaries.

This was a very heartening display## especially in the field## and let us hope that it can be replicated in the next few matches against tougher opposition.

Ballinger won the toss and elected to bat against a spirited Stokenchurch team. A quick opening partnership of 32 was ended when Will Smith was out for 12. Max Maciver and Joe Hankinson put on an an excellent 78 run partnership before both fell at 110## Max having made an excellent 43 and great to see Joe coming back to form with a powerful 46. This partnership was followed by a slight wobble in the middle as the score moved from 110 for 1 to 115 for 5. Sebastian Richards with a powerful 6 in his 12 and Ben Dugdale with an excellent 28 not out put the innings back on track and the icing on the cake was provided by George Kingston with a classic 4 and massive 6 in his innings of 10 not out. Ballinger finished on 163 for the loss of 7 wickets from 20 overs.

Stokenchurch were always going to find the score reached by Ballinger hard to reach and their task was made even more difficult by a superb opening spell from Evan Webster of 4 overs## 2 of which were maidens and figures of 1 for 5. The remaining Ballinger bowlers returned excellent figures## with Jake Cutter getting 1 for 15 off 2 overs## Harry Rix with a fiery 3 for 19 off 4 overs and George Kingston with 2 for 12 off 2.2 overs.

Well done to will Smith for his captaincy and to all the boys.

Ballinger travelled to top of the table Potten End with a team sheet showing 8 changes from last weeks winning team.

Rob McIntyre was tasked with leading this disperate group and started with the usual losing of the toss. This meant Ballinger were given first use of what is always a sporting pitch.

32 overs later the game looked all over when the visitors were dismissed for 127. Even this target looked unlikely at one stage but some very lusty hitting from new boy John Martin(43) and a well crafted 23 from Ben Dugdale helped give some respectability to the total.

Unfortunately this also meant Potten End now had 53 overs to reach the target.

Ballinger took the field without high expectation but a determination not to let down their absent leader and do their best for Rob. 'We got him in this mess so we'd better get him out of it' was the approach.

What followed next can only be described as carnage. The Waggoners openers Mikey Burden 2-11 and Reece Tiley 2-22 soon had The End 25 -4. They were helped by some brilliant fielding from the skipper. Then Bastie 3-9 and Richard Burden 3-16 took over. Within under 19 overs Ballinger had destroyed the home sides title ambitions## bowling them out for just 60.

Some great fielding including 6 catches helped the cause. With a scoring umpire as well it was pretty well a perfect day for the Waggoners.

Having already lost fairly comprehensively to Knotty Green earlier in the year## Ballinger woulld have been apprehensive in facing the return fixture with a number of key players absent. In the event it was KG who were the more depleted## having arrived with only ten men## some of whom were eleventh hour selections. Stand-in skipper Riley won the toss## and on another rain-affected wicket opted to field first.

KG openers Hill and Widdowson seemed fairly untroubled by Ballinger's opening attack of Nick Adams and Jack Hankinson## posting a half-century stand for the first wicket## although Hill was missed in the slips. That was as good as it got for KG## as smart catching led to a breakthrough## with some good fortune when Nick## in dropping a sharp return catch## managed to deposit it straight onto the non-striking batsman's stumps as he backed up. Carlton Siddle## thoroughly disapproving of being carted for a six## struck back with the KG's captain's wicket courtesy of a good catch by Joe Hankinson. Nick finished his allotted spell with 3 for 37 off 12 overs## and then Andy Thompson created havoc with the tail## taking 3 for 8 in only 4.4 overs. KG had slumped from 50-0 to 98 all out## and only 33 overs gone.

Ballinger had to face 12 overs before tea## and Matt Riley and Danny Draper coped well against pace at one end and spin at the other## until in the last over before the break## Matt had the misfortune to get a fly in his eye just as the ball left the bowler's hand## neglected to play a shot## and was clean bowled## for a well-struck 22. Danny followed shortly after tea## commendably "walking" to a thin edge to the keeper. Joe Hankinson got a brute of a ball and was gone for a second-ball duck## and a familiar Ballinger wobble at 33-3 was on the board. But Jono Lacey## inspired perhaps by a fine aggressive knock in the earlier fixture## decided to repeat the experience## and mixed (nervous) defence with (profitable) attack## well supported by an extremely watchful and responsible Paul Humphreys. However## KG's Widdowson was bowling a very testing spell which## coupled with a daft run-out of Jamie Kellock induced a touch of headless chicken syndrome in the Ballinger dressing-room## as the tailenders## not expecting to bat## rushed to get ready. Having lost two wickets with only 2 runs needed for victory## surely Ballinger could not lose from this position??  No - they didn't## but really the game should have been wrapped up much more easily.

KG did well to stay in the game for as long as they did## and took their defeat in good part## joining us in the pub afterwards for some (rather early) beers.

A  particularly strong batting  performance by Ballinger set the base for a convincing victory against Chalfont St Peter after skipper Sebastian Richards had won the toss and elected to bat.

Harry Bartlett set the tone by taking 12 off the first over before perishing to a caught and bowled in the second over. This brought Joe Hankinson to the crease to partner Max Dugdale and they proceeded to plunder the Chalfont St Peter bowling attack in a partnership of over 100. Max Dugdale eventually falling for an excellent 57 which included four 6s and seven 4s.

The middle order batsmen## Sebastian Richards## Jack Bull## Jamie Wise## John Martin## Ben Dugdale and George Kingston contributed some lusty blows in support of Joe Hankinson. Joe batted through to finish on 88 not out and displayed real maturity in his inningswhich included five 6s and twelve 4s

Th eventual total of 211 runs for the loss of 7 wickets off 20 overs being one of the largest totals in recent years and well done to all the players.

Not to be outdone the bowlers tore into the opposition's batting. Evan Webster gave an excellent lesson to all aspiring bowlers at Ballinger pitching up to the batsmen and allowing time for the ball to swing. Evan was rewarded with superb figures of 5 wickets for 8 runs off his 4 overs.

Evan was well suported by Joe Hankinson in his opening spell. Harry Rix 2 wickets for 13 runs off his 3 overs and George Kingston 1 wicket for 19 runs off his 3 overs maintained the high standard of bowling before the opposition's inninings was finished by Ben Dugdale 1 for 26 and Harry Bartlett with 1 wicket for 4 runs off his over.

A superb performance from all the players## well captained by Sebastian Richards and an excellent end to the League Season. As always the players have been a credit to the club.

A nine wicket disaster in May on their own ground was a result that Ballinger were keen to avenge## and with a strong team available the omens were good - except that WESM were a close second in the league## and had won all four of their last games.

Ian Davies made a good start by winning the toss## and given the reputation of the Widmer End wicket## had no hesitation in asking them to take first knock. His decision looked more than justified when## by the end of the eighth over## Nick Adams and Jack Hankinson had WESM reeling on 12 for 6 wickets. The batsmen had little answer to their bowling## which exploited a pitch that more than lived up to its reputation## and they both ended up with 4 wickets apiece. The dismissal of the dangerous B Saeed to a smart slip catch by Paul Humphreys off Jack was perhaps the turning point in the game. Lewis and R Shah managed to drag the score  towards a semblance of respectability## aided by a couple of missed catches## but their final total of 66 all out in the 25th over left Ballinger with## surely## an easy target..

The pitch was## if anything## worsening and Ballinger suffered a disastrous start## losing Max Maciver LBW to a shooter first ball.Rollo followed soon after## caught off a flashing cut (edge?) to third man standing motionless on the boundary## then Paul Humphreys tried an unwise (on this wicket) attacking shot## and was caught off a skier. 14 for 3## and some commonsense application needed. Joe Hankinson joined Richard O'Kelly## and both played exceptionally well in a half-century partnership that took Ballinger to a winning total## without further loss## in the 19th over.

In some ways it was a pity that such a glorious sunny day should see only 44 overs of cricket## but another good win should encourage us for next week's encounter with league leaders Holmer Green.

Having been in third place two weeks ago the seconds suddenly found themselves third from bottom without having played a game.

This wasn't a problem to the skipper as he knew he had a decent batting side## they were playing on a very decent pitch and he was going to win the toss and bat.

Two out of three wasn't bad then as Ballinger set off in hot pusuit of the 250 plus that was going to be required. Some interesting shot selection## an umpiring decision that required DRS and a runout that was worthy of a Mr Bean episode left the home side in complete dissaray.

Paul Branigan(49) avoided buying a jug but with 'Blunter' Thompson helped steady the Waggoners paddle. They definitely didn't have the canoe yet. The skipper helped 'Blunter' add a few more precious runs but 147 was never going to be enough on what was now a decent batting track.

Unfortunately the skipper hadn't managed to lose the match ball which meant his bowlers were doomed to using a ball that looked vaguely like something the rabbit dragged in. Launching this projectile in the right direction might have helped the home sides cause but## with the exception of Alex Howe## this was beyond the wit off all.

Haddenham turned up with a few new players and were annoyingly noisy but frankly this was one of the 2s poorest performances. A change of tack from the skipper caused too many problems but he's learnt his lesson.

The sight of the victorious 1s back to support us was wonderful and so was Julie Thompson's tea.

If matches depended on the outcome of the first overs of each innings## Ballinger would have won this one hands down. Put in to bat by a Holmer Green side notably shorn of many familiar faces## Ballinger took 12 off a wild first over from the pacy D Little## courtesy of 2 no-balls##5 byes## 1 wide and a 4 by Paul Humphreys which ricochetted off Nick Adams' car into (or over) the hedge## never to be seen again. Much as we despise the MBL Kookaburra balls## this was an expensive loss## as the second new ball was therefore in use before the end of the first over!

There followed a thoroughly professional opening stand of 64 by Paul and Andy Thompson## broken when Paul was out for 27 to a smartly taken catch. By this time the scoring rate had slowed## and the arrival of Rollo at the crease would hopefully see this situation remedied. Alas## after a couple of trademark boundaries## he changed his mind in mid-shot and lofted the simplest of dollies## which was gratefully accepted. Ian Davies was greeted by a field designed to nullify his productive offside/third man areas## and became increasingly frustrated## taking nearly 3/4 hour over his 6 runs before being bowled## although admittedly Andy was taking much of the strike and accumulating steadily. The bowling was## perhaps unexpectedly## becoming more accurate## and the fielding was exceptionally athletic## so runs were hard to come by. Even Carlton Siddle found himself tied down## to his annoyance## as it became more and more apparent that Ballinger would need to accelerate if they were to post a competitive total. He was out with the score on 172## and two more wickets promptly fell - the rock-solid Andy took one chance too many and was run out going for a sharp second run## having made a valiant 61## and been twice hit on the helmet. Jamie Kellock followed## bowled for a golden (again## Jamie?)## and then Jeremy Hunting and Nick Adams tried in vain to locate the boundary## but could only gather singles. 187 for 6 at the end of the 45 overs was below par for a good track## especially as 50 of them (including 28 byes) were extras## but it remained to be seen what this Holmer Green side had in the way of batting.

Act 2  of the "first over" saga saw Nick Adams take 2 wickets## both bowled## so with the scoreboard reading 0 for 2 things were looking pretty good. Sadly neither of his victims was the prolific M Watt## nemesis of Ballinger bowlers often before## and Nick's next over cost 14 runs. Jack Hankinson got rid of the HG number four## but that was really as good as it got. Watt and Wallace made batting look like child's play## and the score mounted at an alarming rate. Carlton came in for some savage punishment but at least got rid of Wallace## caught for 50 by Ian Davies## whose shriek of triumph could have been heard in The Lee. Jeremy Hunting caught an absolute blinder - the first catch this season that he hasn't dropped (his own words)## but Watt continued on his merry way to score the winning runs and bring up his own century. A superlative innings## and only 33 overs used. Ballinger's fielding couldn't match their opposition's## but the the older members of the side certainly didn't disgrace themselves. It was simply that we weren't good enough## against a team that deserve to be league leaders and have a greater depth of players.

The holiday season hit Ballinger's availability list with a vengeance## and the Team Secretary endured a torrid week. The resultant XI that presented itself at Ley Hill looked somewhat short of bowling## but as skipper Ian Maciver lost the toss and was asked to bat first## this potential deficiency was put on hold## and it was the batsmen who had to stand up and be counted. Which they did## initially## very successfully. Another half-century opening stand between Richard O'Kelly and Andy Thompson saw them through to 65 before Andy departed for 22## a mixture of watchful defence and profitable hooked boundaries. Batting wasn't easy on a pitch where the ball would sometimes stop and rear up## and the next wicket fell almost immediately## with Max Maciver out. Meanwhile Richard was batting confidently## and with Paul Humphreys also going well at the other end## the score had reached 97 when## surprisingly## Richard was bowled when a 50 looked a certainty. Nigel Kerry## dragged unwillingly from his beloved 2's## followed in the blink of an eye## thereby unhappily gaining the honour of collecting the match fees. then Paul rather gave his wicket away with a skied catch. Jamie Kellock struck a few lusty blows before similarly holing out## and newcomer Gary Bunce looked ill at ease and soon perished LBW. That made it 116 for 7## with only 32 overs used. Jeremy Hunting was by this time hitting the ball hard## and Ian Maciver joined him in a useful stand until he too offered some catching practice. In came Monty Thompson to give an exhibition of stonewall defence to make his father proud. Jeremy continued to pepper the boundary until his luck too ran out##for an excellent 39##  and then last-man Nick Adams finished the 45 overs with some panache## to get Ballinger to a total of 179 for 9 .

The big question was now whether the Ballinger bowling attack was going to able to cope. Well## cope it did for a while## and very economically whilst Nick was operating. He struck in the 7th and 13th overs to take the first two wickets## and finished with impressive figures of 2 for 20 off his 12 overs## but runs were leaking badly at the other end. Nevertheless## thanks to a splendid display of wicketkeeping by Richard ( a catch and no less than three stumpings!)## coupled with Ian's wily  spin (4 for 43) Ballinger had Ley Hill struggling at 127 for 7 in the 30th over. Then the wheels rather fell off## as it took only another 8 overs for Ley Hill to smash their way past the Ballinger total.

Both teams were evidently weakened by holiday absences## but in the event it was Ley Hill's change bowlers who made the difference. It might have been a lot worse## yet with a little bit more luck## Ballinger could have sneaked home.

As a result of a little reported repercussion of last week’s riots the Seconds managed to cope with wholesale departures from both teams only due to the cancellation of the Spurs v Everton fixture. However the game that nearly never was saw three players make their Ballinger debuts and two more return home after prolonged absences## resulting in one of the stronger teams of the season.

Having completed the formality of losing the toss## stand in skipper Paul Branigan had to organise a batting line up filled with many talents. His son Andy returning to Ballinger from Ley Hill via Australia## opened with Basty who got an unlucky LBW decision in the first over  bringing debutante Anthony Leech to the wicket. He looked a useful addition but played back to a ball that kept a bit low and up went the finger again. At 8 for 2 things looked a bit tricky but Paul joined his son and they added 40 runs before an uncharacteristic swipe saw Andy fall to a good catch in the covers for 31. The second new recruit## David Kidde## also fresh off the plane from Australia## stamped his authority straight away with a classic cover drive and the 5 an over run rate soon ticked up to six. Paul departed to a good ball from Peterson for 33 but by then Ballinger were 111 for 4 off just 19 overs. Cue a middle order collapse as Daren Samat## then David (46) and young Matt Leech departed in short order leaving us at 134 for 7 but with nearly 20 overs left. This brought a second exile to the crease## Ollie Lowe## who had been held back by the skipper and not fed any red meat. Having not batted for a several years he started quietly but was never troubled. He set about the Ley Hill attack in a manner that can only be described as brutal## using the full range of shots particularly the straight drive and the pull. He was ably supported by Tom Branigan (18) run out by a direct hit## a third newbie Dave Weatherill (15) and finally Will Reid. In 14 overs Ballinger added 140 and## with a declaration imminent## Ollie reached his first ever ton with a six## and Ballinger immediately declared on 272 for 9 off 42 overs## the unbroken 10th wicket partnership of Lowe & Reid worth 65.

With a decent bowling attack Balliinger were hopeful of pulling off a victory and a fine opening spell from Matt Leech increased confidence. A father & son double act got the first wicket (good job you didn’t drop it Anthony !) and a stumping off the next ball left Matt on a hat trick but he had to wait till the next over to claim his third victim and he finished his 8 over spell with 3 for 7. By then Ley Hill had long given up hope of chasing the win but a stubborn father & son partnership from the Connollys used up 17 valuable overs and was only brought to an end by Ollie’s first ball a huge## quick inswinger that would have accounted for most batsmen. Another wicket for Ollie and a first for Anthony gave Ballinger hope but the last 10 overs saw an increasingly desperate attempt to get further wickets from a variety of bowlers to no avail. A winning draw was a little disappointing but testament again to the decent Ballinger wicket.

Ballinger arrived for this fixture in good spirits knowing that Will Hunting and Ollie Richards had made themselves available and were in the team for the first time this season. These spirits had taken a blow by 3.30pm as Ballinger having decided to bat had fallen to 85-6 and were still waiting on Ollie's arrival due to 'traffic congestion' in London and a suspected inability to find the M40.

Fortunately## Richards' did arrive in time to go in and bat at number 10 and formed part of the Ballinger fight-back that saw them recover to a total of 162 with Jeremy Hunting top scoring with 38.

In reply## Britwell Salome found themselves 69-3 leaving them with less than a hundred runs required from the final 20 overs. All of Ballinger's bowlers fought hard and this## coupled with a determined effort in the field (despite a total of 6 dropped catches)## left the game finely poised going in to the final over with Britwell Salome 7 wickets down and all 3 results still possible.

The duty fell upon Ian Maciver to bowl the last over## Max was determined not to let his dad walk away with better bowling figures than himself and mis-fielded early in the over giving Britwell Salome a crucial extra 3 runs. Maciver senior responded by taking another wicket and in the end it came down to Britwell Salome requiring 4 runs off the final ball for victory. Ballinger held their nerve in the field with just a single coming from the final ball and the match ended in a draw.

This was the first time Ballinger have played Britwell Salome and everyone was in agreement that it was a most enjoyable game of cricket## competitive throughout and played in the proper Sunday spirit.

Ballinger arrived at Downley with an under-strength 10 man team## to find a wicket badly affected by rain## and deemed unplayable until it had dried enough. Play got under way just over an hour late## with the match reduced to 36 overs a side. Put in to bat## Downley's openers found little to fear from the BWCC bowlers## handicapped by a slow wicket and a wet ball## and were showing signs of building a big score when the heavens opened to bring proceedings to a premature end after 17 overs. Very disappointing## but at least it kept us just ahead of Downley in the league table!

“Winning is a habit##” Vincent Lombardi

In history## 21st August has been a day of considerable violence and casualty. In 1863 the town of Lawrence in Kansas was savagely destroyed by Confederate guerillas## the ‘Quantrill’s Raiders’## in what is so imaginatively named the Lawrence Massacre. Furthermore## to add to this image of brutality it was in 1770 that James Cook forcibly conquered Eastern Australia for Great Britain naming it New South Wales. As a result## it was with some anxiety that the captains took to the pitch as the mighty Ballinger Sunday side rolled into the picteresque village of Cookham Dean and attempted to claim a small piece of Berkshire to add to the multiple scalps they have already taken this season.

The first act of this blood-thirsty drama was that of the toss. Many see the toss as ‘Much Ado About Nothing’## but for Ballinger and Captain Marvel Salisbury## this really was a tale of woe as The Waggoners were sent into the field to slave away in the afternoon sun. Whilst opposition to the disestablishment of the Church of England could be called antidisestablishmentarianism## Ballinger were certainly antilosingthetoss## however what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger. So with renewed vigour The Waggoners rose from the changing room like a Phoenix out of ashes and began the difficult task of trying to keep their unbeaten Sunday record intact. The comparison to the great Waggoner sides of yesteryear is inevitable and in front of Ballinger was a side that had them 5 wickets down for 5 runs last season so this was no walk in the park. We could not count our chickens and had to play each game as it comes if you like your clichés. 

Opening up for The Waggoners from the Pavilion End was Jack Hankinson and from the Big Tree End was crowd favourite Jono Lacey. Both started tightly and for the first few overs the run rate struggled to get above 3 an over as the tigerish Ballinger fielding yielded no easy runs with Jake Cutter being particularly mobile despite having a broken leg. Superb. Unfortunately for Ballinger## the opening Dean partnership looked comfortable and began to up the scoring rate as Hankinson and Lacey veered off line with Wells-Cole being particularly severe## driving gloriously over the top on more than one occassion. As the opening partnership reached the 30s## Ballinger introduced an idea so revolutionary that only two team mates knew about it. The concept is called ‘the tactical drop’. The idea is to intentionally drop a batsman to lure him into a false sense of security about the parlous nature of the teams catching and then when the next chance is offered snaffle it at the first attempt. Quite brilliant. So as Lacey and Hankinson were into their last overs## Jono offered a lovely juicy wide long hop to Dean opener Brooks who fired it straight at Will ‘gun show’ Smith. Unfortunately## having spent the past 936 days in the gym Will was too stiff to bend down and attempt the catch so took the bold decision to tactically drop it. 2 runs later this decision was vindicated as Jeremy Hunting took a stunning catch at third man as he sat down to have a picnic on the outfield. 

Unfortunately## this brought the dangerous Patel to the crease who along with the well set Wells-Cole steadily upped the run rate against Ballinger’s toiling opening bowlers. The breakthrough came when The Waggoner’s first change bowlers came on. From the Big Tree End was club professional Paul Humpreys and from the Pavilion End was Stuart McGowan. Slowly but surely## they brought the run rate down with Ballinger being particularly sharp in the field## with special mention to Jamie Kellock who gave a textbook performance behind the sticks as Paul delievered a variety of liquorice allsorts## a lot of pearlers but the occassional dross. Fortunately## it was more the former and both Paul and Stuart kept the Dean batsmen at bay with Stuart keeping an impeccable line and length. The frustration clearly set in as Patel tried to swipe Paul out of the ground one too many times and spooned a catch to Will ‘gun show’ Smith at cover who this time pocketted a neat catch away to his right hand side. Following Patel## was the key wicket of dangerman Wells-Cole who was undone by a beauty from Stuart. Having come down the track## the ball spun past the bat and Jamie## quick as a flash## took the bails and waved Wells-Cole on his way for a well made and chanceless 48. 

From here on in the quote “always expect the unexpected” by James Patterson is very apt as Ballinger really were about to see the ‘unexpected’. From a comfortable 75-1## Paul and Stuart tore through the rest of the Cookham Dean batting line-up like a hurricane tearing through a small wooden house. This even included another use of the ‘tactical drop’ concept## this time by Jono who dropped Dean’s big hitter Wilson on the boundary. This went unpunished however as only a few balls later Paul cleaned him up with a rather good delivery. Dean thus collapsed to a rather meagre 104 all out as Paul took 6-16 off 8.3 overs and Stuart played a very valuable supporting act taking 3-24 off 9. Whilst it maybe harsh to describe the Dean’s lower order performance as a floccinaucinihilipilification## Ballinger most definitely took advantage of the Dean’s collapse and as a result were only chasing 104 when earlier 200+ looked on the cards.

Folllowing an excellent tea which included a rocket salad## coleslaw and also scones## Ballinger opened up with Will and Basty. And my word what a start we had. To say that the capacity crowd were on the edge of their seats was an understatement as the opening pair rocketted towards the target## treating each and every Dean bowler with equal disdain and contempt. After 8 overs Ballinger had reached a staggering 11-0 and what followed was an exhibition of cricket in its purest form. Our good friend ‘Boycs’ would have loved it and as he## more than anyone else would tell you## crease occupation and not losing wickets is of paramount importance. To be fair to Will and Basty they did exactly this and took the sting out of the accurate opening Dean bowlers## Turner and Wells-Cole. Whilst Basty played second fiddle## it was Will who accelerated the scoring exhibiting his newly found strength## lofting a couple of lovely straight drives for 4 and it was with the inevitablility of a cow on a conveyor belt in an abattoir that Ballinger marched to victory. Soon the 50 partnership came up and it really was like watching Brazil## well maybe not## but Basty looked a picture of calm as slowly but surely Ballinger crawled towards their target. 

Unfortunately## hopes of a 10 wicket win were well and truely condemned to the rubbish bin as Basty was caught trying to hoick Brooks into next week## but unfortunately only ended up getting into a tangle and being caught for a very well- made 27. As he slumped off like a centipede with 98 missing legs## Tom Maw joined Will in the middle with the scores on 69-1. 5.4 overs and 38 runs later the game was over as Will reached 52* and Tom 19* which included 2 crowd pleasing sixes. As a result the Ballinger Sunday machine rumbles on with another win## with many pundits making comparisons to ‘The invincibles’ of Preston North End in 1888-9. Regardless of that## Ballinger once again gave a very professional and ruthless performance and whilst the paper’s have been critical of wonderkid Smith’s new fitness routine## the ‘steriod jerk’ certainly silenced his critics with yesterday’s performance.

So on the 38th birthday of Google’s co-founder Sergey Brin## it was Cookham Dean who were left searching after Ballinger inflicted a 9 wicket defeat on the home side. All in all## it was an excellent result for the away side played in very good spirit## with a very nice tea and at a lovely ground!

And finally## dear reader## I will leave you with a bit of Winston Churchill## who famously said that “these are not dark days: these are great days - the greatest days our country has ever lived.” Indeed## these are great days and would be even greater by continuing the winning ways at Wendover next Sunday.

Word of the day: pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis - a supposed lung disease.

Another toss lost and with both teams agreeing to play Ballinger had to bat in the rain on a wicket their groundsman admitted he didn’t like the look of!

Against  a bowling attack that wouldn’t have been out of place a couple of divisions higher## and with a lot of variable bounce## the Ballinger batsmen all dug in but found runs hard to come by. One by one they played themselves in and then perished when attempting to push the score along. Wickets fell at regular intervals with nobody managing to get on top of the bowling though Rob McIntyre reached 19 before a good leg side catch by the Wendover wicket keeper. However with everyone making a contribution Ballinger did manage to bat out the 45 overs but a total of 118 all out didn’t look quite enough## particularly as the weather had improved considerably.

With few runs to play with a good start was essential and tight bowling from David Kiddie and Tom McIntyre didn’t disappoint.  David bowled a good line and bowled an opening 7 over spell for 10 runs and claiming 3 wickets## whilst Tom bowled 12 overs of leg spin taking 2 wickets. David was replaced by Evan Webster who bowled a fine spell## his 7 overs costing only 9 runs whilst Matt Leech replaced Tom and claimed a couple of early wickets thanks to good catches from the Daves (Kiddie & Weatherill).  So having started with a target of less than 3 an over Wendover had been reduced to 76 for 7 with just 10 overs left. This brought Bridge to the wicket## who had earlier been the pick of their bowlers## and he now turned the game back towards Wendover with some aggressive batting. Although the ball was often in the air it never went to hand and Wendover eventually cruised to victory by 3 wickets with 4 overs to spare. However it was a good all round performance in testing conditions against strong opposition.

11 brave souls ventured into unknown waters with a match against the unfamiliar opponents of Abbots Langley. Jeremy lost the toss (dont ask where Graeme was) and the Waggoners were put into the field on a pleasant day with a nice but large ground. Some are born great## some achieve greatness and some have greatness thrust upon them and at roughly 2:05 with our usual opening bowler Jack Hankinson still driving to the game## greatness was thrust upon our overseas pro Matt Riley who bowled with such tenacity and skill he silenced his critics (me) and was probably the standout bowler with effulgent figures of (12 overs## 4 maidens## 48 runs and 3 wickets). In the meantime your humble correspondent dropped an unforgivable catch to let the opener off the mark. However in the process of my debacle on par with the titanics maiden voyage## I sustained an injury which would have felled any normal man however I managed to solider on through to pain## but 7 overs later my herculean effort could not be sustained and when the doctor said they would have to amputate if I didnt come off the field I succumbed to the pain## in reality my thumb was bruised and I made a fuss about it. However back to the interesting stuff## Alec Howe had a brilliant first and second spell and finished with very credible figures of (12 overs 41 runs and 3 wickets). The Langley number 3 batted superlatively and compiled an imperious 95 before unfortunately being caught in the deep. At 160 for 4 in the 33rd over things could have got messy but some inspired captaincy and bowling managed to peg the opponents back to a competitive score of 216 all out from their 45 overs credit to Jack Hankinson who bowled faster than the news of the world scandal unfolded and got 3 wickets in the process.

Now onto the important bit## Tea. Tea included a cornucopia of Sandwiches## a myriad of fruit## a horde of chicken drumsticks## a wealth of sausages and a plethora of ambrosial sweetness ranging from divine profiteroles to palatable cakes## in sincerity it was definitely the best away tea of the season.

Ballinger opened with our usual suspects and as usual numbers 3 and 4 were in early.
