Matt and Jeremy put on a partnership of 52 before Jeremy fell trying to loft the ball over the top## in the meantime light was closing in and the weather was deteriorating. However Matt had managed to get over his technical difficulties with his susceptibility to LBW and played nicely for an unbeaten 53. There isnt a lot else to say apart from just when the run-rate looked like it was getting out of hand the heavens opened and the game was declared a draw preventing Nick from coming out in his no expense spared Multi Axial Air Flow System helmet.

Overall a good game and perhaps we got fortunate but you never know## thankfully Ballingers Annus Mirabilis was saved and dare one mention an unbeaten season? In general a nice place to play with good facilities## apart from two thefts of a phone and a watch which leaves a sour taste in ones mouth but unfortunately cest la vie## for those who arent as talented at French as Ballingers own French resident## overseas pro and bowling all-rounder such is life.

(Note watch and phone were later found in the depths of owners bags)

Long Marston away is always a game that is looked forward to every year. Is it because of the pitch## the facilities or the general atmosphere at the ground?

 

Mostly it is because of the best tea in the area!!!

 

Having won the toss skipper hunting decided to bowl first and we were soon under the cosh as Wareham smashed us around. Jack bowled the other opener for 8 and then Jono had the number 3 LBW for 0. A generous decision.

 

Wareham was starting to look extremely dangerous## but on 49 smashed one straight up in the air## which was smartly taken by Max Maciver running at full tilt. Why the skipper hadn’t called for it## considering he was 10 yards away from the ball## we will never know. Experience we think!!

 

The spinners then entered the fray and slowly the run rate dried up as wickets fell at regular intervals.

 

Max bowled an impressive spell of 11 over’s for 4 wickets## and with Stuart taking 1 and Ian picking up 2 we managed to bowl out Long Marston for 197 in 36 over’s.

 

Tea was taken and 30 minutes later some very bloated openers arrived at the crease## having consumed vast quantities of sandwiches## cakes chicken wings and even a birthday cake## generously donated by a parent of a lad who wasn’t even playing!!!

 

Humphreys and Richards were made to work hard by the openers## even though one of them couldn’t find an end he liked and was heard to be asking the ground man to rotate the square in an attempt to find an end he liked.

 

Bastie was eventually dismissed for 2 in the 17 over## but the score had only reached 39 by this stage. Max came and went and when Paul found the only fielder on the leg side for a good 47 things were looking bleak.

 

Jeremy batted in his own imitable style and produced the shot of the day as he hit woodruff into the next field for an enormous six## but when he was caught for 31 the following band of supporters thought that our undefeated streak was about to end.

 

Nick and Stuart had other ideas. They added 43 for the 8th wicket before Nick and Stuart perished. This left the senior pro Ian Maciver and Ben Dugdale to negotiate the last 3 overs. Ben decided that Ian would be better standing at the other end whilst he took the responsibility for seeing us to the end which he did with some determined defence.

 

Game drawn and the Ballinger Sunday jugernaught is still undefeated## but we defiantly had the worse of this draw.

On a glorious Sunday Ballinger entertained Ashridge Coopers for the first time at the home of cricket.

On what looked a flat batting track skipper Salisbury had no hesitation having won the toss to bat first. Unfortunately Coopers had other ideas.

10 overs in and Ballinger were 37-5## down to a mixture of poor shots and some excellent bowling from Arnold who bowled 15 overs from the field end for 3-23.

Thankfully the change bowlers were not as accurate. Skip held the innings together with a belligerent 38 ably supported by spin king McGowan (25)## Jono (22) and Max Dugdale who produced an excellent 32. However 170 in 46 overs never seemed enough.

Jack Hankinson and Evan Webster hadnt read the script and coopers were soon eight down for 15 runs. Defence was then the order of the day and despite their best efforts the openers couldnt finish the game off. Even the spin of Riley and Smith couldnt entice an aggressive shot from the batsmen and it was left to golden arm Maw to finish the innings off for 22.

Good game and a nice opposition and definitely a team worth playing again.

On an overcast and rainy day Cublington arrived at the common unsure of how much cricket would be played.

Having won the toss skip hunting held a brief meeting of the senior players to decide what to do. The decision to bowl first was more down to the fact that we didnt want to field when it was cold and wet later!!!

Cublington started at a brisk pace and apart from jack removing one of the openers## caught by the ever impressive Brandon## the wickets couldnt be found. Two rain breaks didnt help the cause as the ball became impossible to hold and the batsmen took full toll on any loose balls. Stuart did manage to pitch one which bowled Middleton for 26.

By this stage the Cublington skipper suggested a 35 over game in an attempt to get a game in and jack finally found his range bowling Gordon-Stuart for an excellent 87 and Eatwell for 0. 189 on a wet pitch did look like a tall order.

Ballinger opened up with a brisk partnership of 58 in ten overs between Smith and Humphreys## before Will was stumped by the best keeper we will see for a long time for 13.

For once Paul heeded the advice given to him and kept hitting the ball straight and we were up with the run rate required. Wickets kept falling at the other end and when Paul holed out at long on (so much for hitting straight!!) the target looked a long way off.

Jack hadnt read the script though and an aggressive 35 enabled Ballinger to enter the last over needing 10 to win with the last pair of Hamish Sim and Ben Dugdale at the crease.

Cublington`s opening bowler was back on## but bowling spin. The field was up all he had to do was pitch the ball.

First ball## dot. Second ball was a waist high full toss which Hamish smashed to the boundary for 4.

6 to win.

The third ball produced a scampered single which left Ben on strike with 5 to win.

Fourth ball was another full toss## which unfortunately Ben hit to midwicket.

Things were getting tight and the players on the balcony didnt move as Howe ran in the bowl the fifth ball. Another full toss which Ben put into the car park for a 61!!!

An excellent 1 wicket win for the Waggoners.

An excellent game and credit must be given to the Cublington skipper who kept the game open all the way when he could have shut it out a lot earlier.

Today’s task - write a match report for a game that lasted only 25 overs.

Having decided to field first in pursuit of a morale boosting victory Paul duly lost the toss and the opposition then elected to bat anyway. They then revealed that they were two men short.

Will Reid and Evan Webster bowled very tightly –only one run came off the bat in the first 6 overs. It was in attempting to convert their second scoring shot that a 35 yard direct hit at the bowlers end from backward of point by Will Saunders resulted in the departure of Tomkins## always  the mainstay of any Prestwood innings. Having finally conceded a run in his 5th over Evan saw red and claimed two scalps in the next few balls## including a 33 ball duck for the other opener## and finished his 6 over spell with 2 for 5. Basty and debutante Matt Leech then took up the challenge and by the 15th over Prestwood were 4 wickets down at a run rate of less than one. Some aggressive batting saw the run rate rocket but a good catch from Monty Thompson off Basty (Monty’s loud shout narrowly avoiding a catastrophic collision with Ben Dugdale) and then two wickets in 2 balls from Matt cut off any chance of a revival. Matt then cleaned up the innings## finishing with 4 for 19## and Prestwood were all out for 44 off 18 overs.

‘Deadly’ Derek Richards and Ben ‘the bowler’ Dugdale began the Ballinger reply and were rarely troubled in knocking off the runs in just over 7 overs and the game finished at 3.15.

BWCC went into this## the last league match of the season## in confident mood##occupying a secure top-half place in the table. Opponents The Lee were correspondingly despondent## occupying the same relegation slot that Ballinger had last year. It was somewhat of a surprise therefore when## having won the toss## they chose to bat. What followed was a demonstration of top-quality seam bowling by Jack Hankinson who had the batsmen in all sorts of trouble## and accounted for the top four Lee batsmen## including the aggressive D Peens## three of them clean bowled. Conversely## at the other end## Andy Thompson was suffering a mauling from some crash-bang-wallop batting by batsmen who appeared to think this was a 20/20 match. The Lee had reached 96 before their 5th wicket fell## and by this time the bowlers were  Carlton Siddle and Ben Dugdale. Ben clean bowled top-scoring G Perry for 38 in only his second over## and went on to take 3 for 22 with his well flighted spin## whilst Carlton chipped in with three wickets at the other end## as The Lee crashed from 96 for 4 to 124 all out## with the clock showing only 2.58pm and a mere 26 overs elapsed. Ballinger's fielding and catching were mostly well up to the high standard they have set all season.

125 was hardly a target that a strong Ballinger batting line-up was going to find difficult## especially on yet another good Kellock track. And so it proved## as Richard O'Kelly and Joe Hankinson took the score to 47 in rapid time before the first wicket fell## when Richard ran himself out going for a sharp second run## doubtless hoping to speed up his (chanceless) contribution of 6 to the partnership.  Is he the new Riley??  At the other end Joe was mixing sublime driving with some productive edges## and keeping scoreboard operator Felix McIntyre busy while in the kitchen his mother agonized about when the tea interval was likely to occur. Husband Rollo arrived at the crease to smash a typically robust 20## including 2 sixes## before fatally testing the umpire's goodwill by heaving across the line. Joe perished## as a catch was at last accepted## for an exciting knock of 71## leaving it Paul Humphreys and Jamie Kellock to steer Ballinger serenely to their target## reached in a mere 25 overs## and the time only just half-past four.

Time for tea (delicious)## then off to The Lee to watch Nigel's 2's having a much less happy time of it. Disappointing that we didn't have a full-blooded challenge for the last match## but very encouraging that the day belonged to our youngsters## with a Hankinson bonanza## and excellent bowing by Ben Dugdale.

The last league game of the season as against one of the top sides in the league but hen Ballingers bolers had reduced them to 23-3 after 8 overs they looked anything but. Unfortunately hat the boys have discovered is that the better sides have strength in depth and an onslaught by Wycombe's Daniel took the visitors to 108 off their 20 overs.

108 isn't that tough an ask if the batters play properly but after an excellent opening stand beteen Brandon (22) and James Mac(13) the rest of the order subsided gently with no-one else getting into double figures. 80-10

This was a dissapointing end to what had been an enjoyable season but the difference between the Waggoners and table toppers Chesham and High Wycombe is marked. Maybe a different approach by the coach in bringing in better players from the younger age groups would have helped but that ould have penalised all the boys ho turned up for training each week.

I think it's going to be a busy winter.

Last game of the season and we're away to local rivals The Lee. With a decent side on the team sheet the skipper was quitely confident when he went out to toss up. An unusual looking pitch with lots of grass didn't deter him from batting first when the unexpected happened and he won the toss.

Max and Tom Mac opened up for the Waggoners and for 4 overs all looked completely serene with Tom especially looking in masterly form. Then the wheels fell off. All out for 116 with extras top scorer with 24.

116 was always going to be a difficult total to defend on a ground where 200 plus is par## but giving the home side 50 overs to score them in made it even worse.

The bowlers all did their best with Will Reid (6-0-16-0) being the pick but the Lee had a couple of wily old pros opening the batting and they weren't  split until the 30th over when the score was already 96.

Everyone fielded well but it was a shame to end another enjoyable season with a defeat. We also went from 3rd from top of the league## with a chance of getting promotion## to 3rd from bottom in to weeks.

It as great to see the 1s supporting us and it was a great evening afterwards. Roll on next year

‘I have a dream...’ Martin Luther King Jr.

In times long## long ago## Ballinger opened the Sunday season with a friendly against Aldenham. On that day## Sunday captain Salisbury had a dream. A dream so powerful that even many of the Ballinger stalwarts refused to believe. He dreamt of an unbeaten season## he dreamt of the Ballinger Sunday side of 2011 being written in the history books for eternity as one the finest teams to grace this planet. And so## on the 48th anniversary of Martin Luther King Junior’s infamous 'I Have a Dream' speech the story of Ballinger’s quest for immortality begins.

An eerie silence befell the dressing room. Usually## a team full of energy and razzmatazz## the Ballinger dressing room was reduced to quiet contemplation with each one thinking of the challenges that lay ahead. For the Waggoner warriors did not want to follow the same path as Portuguese leader Christovão da Gama who in 1542 was captured and executed by the Turks at the Battle of Wofla## but indeed they wanted to successfully defeat Wendover much like Theodoric## King of the Ostrogoths## who defeated Odoacer at the Battle of Isonzo in 489 allowing him passage into the northern Italian state of Piedmont. So on this big day a small prayer was offered far away in some unknown paradise to aid the Waggoner warriors in their attempt to keep their unbeaten season going:

 

Our father##
who art at Fortress Ballinger##
Cricket be our game##
When Wendover come##
It will be won##
On grass as it is on water.
Give us this day our daily beers##
And forgive us our celebrations##
As we forgive those who celebrate against us.
Lead us not into our own wickets##
But deliver us to victory.
For Ballinger is the kingdom##
For the maroon and the gold##
Forever and ever...

The air smelled sharp as new-cut wood## slicing low and sly around the angles of buildings and with it the coin was tossed and it was decided that Ballinger would take to the field first on a wicket that clearly had taken a pounding by the overnight rain. Time would tell if it indeed would cut like a trench from the Somme. However with a new cherry in the hand and breeze at their backs Ballinger were as eager as a child in a sweet shop to get the game under way. Did I mention Will got 7 A*s? So with crowd favorite Lacey unavailable## it was Alex Howe and Jack Hankinson who opened the bowling for Ballinger and both kept the Wendover batsmen at bay as both bowled tight and hostile spells. Half way through Alex’s spell came the first wicket. Unbelievable telepathic skills from the side’s Sri Lankan overseas player Paul Humphreys saw Tom Maw placed at short mid wicket and following an excellent delivery the ball was clipped straight into Tom’s hands. One wicket down## nine more to get and Ballinger could not have asked for a better start! Furthermore## with Ballinger tight in the field## runs were hard to come by## although C. Morley showed that considerable application was the only way to build a score on a pitch that had a similar coloring to that of sticky toffee pudding.

 

Soon enough the Waggoner’s rolled another Wendover batsman as Hankinson bowled Bhagarra and it was clear that Ballinger now had the bit between their teeth and looked hungry for more wickets## the kind of look you get from not eating for a while. However## as much as they huffed and puffed and tried to blow the house down## Walton and Morley (C) were creating a rather nice little partnership and as Ballinger’s change bowlers came on the scoring rate started to slowly rise. Unfortunately## little Jake Cutter bore the brunt of this as the lack of sun meant that he could not top up his tan and thus bowl well. However## Evan Webster at the other end did a good job stemming the runs although it was the aforementioned Cutter who made the breakthrough by having danger man Morley (C) caught by the now standing Jeremy Hunting at mid on for a well made and patient 50. This wicket seemed to open the floodgates somewhat and on the anniversary of British geologist William Smith’s death it was left to the previously mentioned Humphreys to gobble up the rest of the Wendover middle order## using an excellent and mind-boggling combination of swing and movement## much like californication which refers to the haphazard and mindless development of land that gobbled up most of Southern California during the 1970s.

This combined with an athletic fielding display## especially from team stalwarts Simon Denison-Smith and Jeremy Hunting## who belied their years and hurled themselves around the field like several species of African game with little respect for mind or body. Furthermore## this was coupled with another successful use of the ‘tactical drop’ concept## this time by Alex Howe. Unbelievably## this led to a very important wicket the very next ball! Good work! Ballinger’s standards in the field were as a result high and this was exemplified by two excellent diving catches by## firstly## Evan who judged a swirling high ball to perfection and secondly by Jake who despite his broken leg from last week## managed to fling himself to his left hand side like a salmon and pouch the ball. So at the end of 43 over’s Wendover declared on 126-8 off 43 over’s with Walton (P) excellently holding the lower order together. Anyhow## a score of 126## one would have thought## would not be enough especially given the star studded Ballinger batting line- up that the away side had at their disposal.

 

 After a superb tea and your correspondent subsequently putting on a stone of weight courtesy of the awesome mini cornish pasties## it was Will Smith and Freddie Denison-Smith that opened up for Ballinger. And much like last week Ballinger raced at the speed of light and an early finish was a distinct possibility with Ballinger rattling along to 6 off 6 over’s## as Smith was particularly brutal hitting two outstanding singles in a fine innings. Unfortunately## all fairy tales must come to an end though## and having hit two glorious singles## Challoner’s reject Smith tried to cart Wendover opener Siva into next year; unfortunately## the ball was straight and uprooted the middle stump. Very sad## I admit I shed a tear. Anyway## with Tom Maw replacing Will and Freddie looking technically very solid in both attack and defense## the Waggoner’s## slowly but surely## began to trundle towards the target set. Tom Maw began to open his shoulders and hit a couple of lusty blows and the score was at 31 when the next wicket fell with Freddie departing. However## cometh the hour## cometh the man. Next in was Paul Humphreys who following his exploits with the ball played a superbly paced innings that so nearly won the Waggoner Warriors the game. As the run rate increased## as both Tom and Paul ran well between the wickets## Wendover decided to bring on their change bowlers and what an impact they had.

At this point## I would like to preface what I am about to say by saying that the double bouncing delivery is one that many professional 20/20 cricketers try (and fail to master). Furthermore## Neil Pinner## an off-spinner who plays for Worcestershire's second XI argues "It just makes it so much harder for the batter to hit it out of the ground## which is what they are trying to do in Twenty20 cricket". So when Wendover captain Morley (C) brought Bhagarra on to the bowl from the Shrubbery End it can now be seen as a tactical master stroke## on par with dare I say Ottmar Hitzfeld’s tactical masterstroke as his Swiss side battered Spain into submission during World Cup of 2010. Anyway## a combination of a slow pitch and the ‘unusual’ bowling some Sky pundits have called ‘filth’## it did the job as Paul and Tom struggled to get it away## and furthermore led to the latter's wicket as he attempted to put the ball into oblivion## but only ended up missing the ball and being bowled for 21. The old adage of 'batsman misses bowler hits' is very apt here! Anyway## Paul was joined by Bastie who hung around for a while but the next wicket’s partnership was the game changer. Paul and Jeremy put on 50 for the 5th wicket and with 6 required off the last over## this really was a nail biter. A cool head was needed much like Old Oundleian## Will Jefferson who cruelly crushed Lancashire’s hopes in the 20/20 semi final the previous day with a professional and ruthless display of batting in the super over decider. Unfortunately## having taken Ballinger so close to the brink of victory that they were about to fall off## Paul was bowled in final over and despite the team’s best efforts a very tidy over from Siva kept the Waggoner’s cruelly at bay. In the end## Paul made a superb and pugnacious 54 whilst Jeremy ended on a hard fought 14 not out and Ballinger closed another ultimately successful day at the office on 123-6 off 40 over’s.

 

So there we have it## another game goes by and Ballinger still remain unbeaten! Those doubters who cast away Salisbury’s dream are beginning to eat their own words as there are now only 4 games to go to make it the perfect season. Overall## it was a rather tricky away day at Wendover who once again proved to be excellent hosts. An excellent close game## a great tea## friendly opposition playing in the glorious rolling hills of the Chilterns## what more could one want on a summer’s Sunday afternoon? Answers on a post card please.

After the game it soon emerged that Ballinger starlet and opening batsman## Will Smith## had been poached by an unknown rival funded by a foreign Saudi Arabian consortium. It is rumored that he has been whisked off to be looked after by the Worshipful Company of Grocers of the City of London at a school that has been described as “a popular## well-oiled## well-heeled co-educational boarding school which is riding high.” Whilst these rumors are unconfirmed## a tearful Jake Cutter gave the following interview to the Sky cameras present## "Will should have been playing for Oundle weeks ago. I rate Montague Cuthbert-Montgomery as a high-class first XI school batsman## but in one-day cricket I don't believe his game suits batting through. Will has real magic## he ticks every box## and he is a little professor of his industry."

The Ballinger Wagon rolls on to Chesham Bois next week as once again Ballinger look to keep the unbeaten run going. Best of luck guys!

BWCC v Jordans Taverners

                                  

On the tenth anniversary of 9/11 Ballinger’s juggernaut Sunday team travelled to Jordans Taverners with three games to go in this hopefully triumphant season.

 

Upon reaching the ground it soon became apparent that there had been a lot more rain in Seer Green than at the home of cricket.

For once this season skipper Salisbury lost the toss and we were in the field. More

bad news soon spread that this would be a 40 over game.

 

Openers Hankinson and Thompson opened up and soon found that the pitch was going to be easy paced (especially when pitched half way down). Jordans’ openers Sonnex and Mooton obviously knew how to bat on the pitch and as soon as there was any width they launched the bat with little disregard where the ball went. Luckily Mooton soon decided to test the skipper out and smashed one straight to him which was pouched with consummate ease. In fact it was a long hop from Jack which he calmly spooned to Graham but he would have you believe the latter. Soon after Graham turned to the spin pairing of McGowan and Max who soon had Jordans in all sorts of bother.

Max was at his wily best and decided early that the order of the day was to take the pitch out of the question and bowl full tosses!! Stuart bowled like he had all season and picked up 2-14 from his 8 over stint and Max ended with 4-49. Not his most fluent performance but the wickets are what counts. It was then left to Bastie and Ian Maciver to wrap the inning up and bowl Jordans out for 129 with 2 balls left of the 40 overs.

 

After an excellent tea held in the village hall## with the strange sight of grown men sitting in chairs meant for 4 year old children## openers Paul and Joe marched to the crease not sure how to play the indifferent pitch. Should they nudge and nurdle our way to victory or go for broke with a barrage of violent shots? They both decided a mixture of both would be the best tactic and after Joe put the left arm opener over his head second ball for a mighty 6 the game was on. Paul and Joe rotated the strike at will and mixed in boundaries that saw the score on 68 after 12 overs with very little alarm.

 

Jordan’s then switched tactics and bought on the experienced Yolland who## much like Max earlier decided full tosses were the order of the day. Four balls later both openers were in the pavilion caught at deep square leg and deep mid wicket!!

 

This was now straight up Rollo’s street so that after looking at a couple of balls he proceeded to smash anything all round the ground bringing up his 50 in 38 balls and the victory in the 21st over. Jamie was undefeated at the other end for an imperious 3 not out!!

 

Having knocked off the Jordans’ total## the majority of the Ballinger players retired to the Jolly Sportsman with their hosts. Rollo produced not just a jug but a bag of freshly-collected conkers## and the sporting competition resumed over a few pints of well-kept real ale. Max Maciver## being part of a generation deprived of conker fights at school as a result of the health and safety culture of the last 20 yrs## had to be educated in the dark arts of “death cracks”## “stringing” and “stampsies”. Jamie Kellock showed a particularly well –honed technique (surely a sign of a misspent youth). When we ran out of string## we were forced to turn to Bastie Richards’ abandoned cricket boots## with laces that proved well suited to the task (sorry## Veronica!)

Pretty annoying start to the season. A team## umpire and scorer and all we need is a pitch to play on. Sadly a 'drought' lasting a month has prevented any pitch preperation and with puddles still on the outfield it was a non-starter from Thursday onwards.

Hey-ho. Let's hope for some sunshine soon
First game of. Season rained off. Hope it's not a portent of things to come
Another one drowns in the deep end
This will have to be replayed

First the drought## then the rain and finally the first game of the season on May 11th on a very chilly evening - a rearranged league and cup double at Great Kingshill. Everyone would be rusty I was thinking until the second over when Max smashed a big six onto the road at the start of a brilliant attacking innings(45). He and Robert put on a big partnership of 60 for the first wicket in eight overs. Our other batsmen kept the momentum with notable contributions from Ben and Toby## taking Ballinger to a useful total of 134. Toby survived a bizarre incident at the start of his innings when the ball looped down out of the sky## nicked his bat## then on to the keeper's helmet## then deflected and finally caught at slip...but it was a no ball(and apparently you can't be caught if the ball has hit a fielder's helmet).

Hamish and Reece opened up with a fast## furious and fierce opening spell. Both are a several mph faster than last year and both openers were soon back in the pavilion. GK had a useful partnership for the third wicket but were gradually falling behind the required run rate. Ben eventually got the breakthrough with first of two stumpings by Max. Joe and Josh bowled well at the end and each picked up a wicket or two. Fielding a bit rusty at times## but a good team performance and a match played in good spirits. Good to be playing at last and a very good start to the season.

 

BS

First the drought## then the rain and finally the first match of the season on May 11th. And a very cold evening it was for the double header league and cup tie with Great Kinsghill.

I thought everyone would be rusty until Max smashed a big six onto the road in the second over. He played a great innings (45) in an excellent opening partnership with Robert to put on 60 in eight overs. Other batters kept up the momentum and there were notable attacking contributions from Ben (25) and Toby.  There was a bizarre incident at the start of Toby’s innings when he nicked a very high full toss towards the keeper – it glanced of his helmet and deflected to slip who caught the ball and appealed. But it is was a no-ball as it was too high and apparently you can’t be out if the ball has hit a fielder’s helmet. 134 was a useful score to have on the board.

Hamish and Reece opened up fast## fierce and furious from both ends extracting a lot of bounce. Both have added a few mph over the winter! And the openers were soon back in the pavilion. GK’s batsmen had a good partnership going for the third wicket but eventually Ben broke through with one of his teasing flighted off spinners and the  stumping was well taken by Max.  The pressure on the batsmen was mounting as they were falling behind the required rate against the (generally) tight bowling. Josh and Joe both bowled well near the end and each got a wicket or two. Hamish and Reece came back for the last overs to finish things off. The fielding was rusty at times but a very good all-round performance saw Ballinger through winning by 19 runs. Great start to the season.

First match of the season## and the artificial pitch was ready just in time. Opening batsmen Simon C (Captain) and Hugo E-H set the tone with some really good batting. Hugo demonstrated some classy shots## scoring 2 fours on a slow outfield and retired at 30 (not out) - a very good start to the season! Simon achieved 11 off the bat## and will run faster next time when he has the correct underwear on!!! James Bunce and Henry King batted at 3 and 4## unfortunately both were bowled out for 0 by some excellent bowling from the opposition. Matthew Barton and Harry Petrie batted at 5 and 6## bringing the game back into control## and playing some intelligent shots. Mattie's steady batting continued with Matthew Gate and Theo Weatherall (at 8). Theo kept his head under pressure and stopped the team from losing any more wickets.

Hugo E-H kept wicket very well - only a couple of byes. Some great bowling from Simon Carlin (4 wickets). James A bowled very tightly in 3 overs (the wickets will come next time!); Matthew Barton took two good wickets despite bowling off the wrong foot## and Harry Petrie## Matthew Gate and Louis Barton each took a wicket. Henry "the hands" King bowled and caught one## (the only wicket maiden of the match) before taking another 2 stunning catches. Some great fielding by Louis Thomson## and also from star reserve: Louis Barton (aged 8!!)  

Well done boys - you're through to the next round of the Cup against High Wycome. WH

It's Friday afternoon and skipper Hamish Sim is having his first experience of the problems of trying to gather a team together for a match. Ballinger are playing Gerrards Cross at home and we know in advance that they are going to be short of some of their top players. An opportunity then to sneak an early win in what is going to be a difficult season.

Firstly a rugby presentation evening takes away several players## a match between two schools sides has reduced his options further## and then 2 players call in sick during the day.

Finally the Waggoners take to the pitch with just 8. The skipper has lost the toss and GX have decided to bat. Hamish opens the bowling having carefuly placed his meagre resources. 3 on each side then. He's also decided that he needs to set the standard for all. His first ball would have removed Andrew Strauss let only Johnny O'Regan. It was a jaffa. Then with his 4th ball he removed GX's other opener. End of 1st over 1 for 2.

Will Arnold opened from the other end and was a bit profiligate giving away 2 runs. Another tight over from Hamish## A wicket from Will in his next over## Reece Tiley has arrived like the cavalry and takes a wicket in his first over## Will then takes 2 in in 2## Greg McManus gets 1 in his first## so## at the end of the 10th over GX are 18-8. At the end of the 14th they are 36-9.

Unbelievable stuff from the Waggoners. Great fielding as well was backing up this top effort from the bowlers. Will Arnold's figures were 4-4-4 with Hamish 2-6 in his 4 overs.

How GX then got to to 72 is difficult to understand. A lack of bowlers - see rugby presentation## school match etc - was the problem with the skipper running out of options and the last 2 GX  batters recognising there were no devils in the pitch and played properly. 72 was probably a par score on a slow pitch with a very slow outfield.

The home side opened with Brandon Allen and Greg McManus who tickled along nicely for the first 7 overs before a rush of blood led to Brandon being stumped. The skipper and Greg then added 19 for the next wicket before Hamish was bowled with the total on 37.

 If the Waggoners had removed GX's last batter when they should have they would have won the game by now.

Toby Lyons## Henry Turrel and Reece Tiley all helped Greg add a few## but by now it was pitch dark and drizziling. Ossie Glenister helped Greg add another 10 before being part of Greg's run out. Now it was down to Ossie## Will Arnold and James Reid to get the Waggoners over the line. Sadly they couldn't quite manage it with the home side all out with 2 balls to go just 3 runs short. An excellent innings from Greg deserved a win.

Could 1 more player have made the difference - YES.

Should the game have been stopped - YES -but both sides thought they could win so carrying on was the right decision.

A long match report but it was good game in difficult conditions.Both sides made lots of noise in the field but the game was played in the right spirit.

BWCC ventured onto a cricket field for the first time in 2012's sodden spring## with a team mainly rich in years and experience## and facing a Ley Hill side that had been skittled for only 58 the previous week## might have fancied their chances of denting their morale still further.

The home side having won the toss took first knock## and must have feared the worst when Carlton Siddle struck with the third ball of his opening over## courtesy of a blinding slip catch by Matt Riley. With 12 overs gone the total had reached a mere 22## and Carlton and Nick Adams were keeping tight control. However## C Peterson was starting to hit the ball hard and## profitting from a missed chance behind the stumps## was in dominant form## and his partnership with the adhesive Lown had put on 114 for the second wicket before Peterson was out for 76 in the 29th over.Three more wickets went down## as Ballinger's bowlers regained their ascendency## and with the total on 137-5 in the 34th over## prospects were favourable. Enter Messrs Jone and Cartledge who proceeded to give a remarkable demonstration of the potential of the cross-batted agricultural approach## and the fielders watched helplessly as the sixes flew over their heads## the road## and the golf course.. 95 runs accrued from this carnage and changed the face of the game## before a few late wickets added a touch more respectability to a final total of 248-8## with Andy Thompson emerging with the best bowling figures of 4 for 59.

Ballinger's reply was encouraging## and the openers Matt Riley and Paul Humphreys batted steadily## with Paul doing most of the scoring before he was bowled for 30. Jeremy Hunting perished in no time## but Carlton and Jamie Kellock looked in good nick before both were victims of totally unneccessary run-outs which effectively cost Ballinger any chance of winning the game. This is not the place to apportion blame (is it??)## so let us merely applaud Matt's powers of concentration in posting a well-crafted 50. At the 34 over mark## Ballinger were only 2 runs behind the comparable Ley Hill score with the same number of wickets down. However## well though Andy Thompson and a (remarkably) watchful Nick Adans batted## supported by skipper Ian Maciver## there was no way they were going to match the pyrotechnics of the Ley Hill middle order## and attention switched to salvaging a draw## which to their credit they duly achieved## finishing on 183-7.

Our reward in league points was virtually the same as we had gathered in each of the two previous rain cancelled fixtures## but at least our season was under way.

Wow - that was a cracking start to the season. A lovely grass pitch had just been prepared at Holmer Green## after 3 weeks of rain and re-arranging matches. Chilly but dry!

Theo Weatherall & Harry Petrie opened the batting in style## putting on 20 runs between them in the first 4 overs (10 each). The loss of a wicket (a decent ball to be out to) was cancelled out by the extras from Holmer Green. Hannah Bates scored a beautiful boundary but both she & Elise Farquhar waited in vain during 4 overs for something else to score off (22 extras!). Raphael Weatherall & Georgina Kellok shared a similar experience: Raphael scored a classy boundary## but then lost a wicket. Marcus Coulter & Jamie McMullan batted as the fourth pair## scoring 2 runs each (and 18 extras) - Marcus lost a wicket## but didn't make the same mistake twice (well done both boys for their first game for Ballinger!). Finally Will Hardman and Will Jones came in to bat as the final pair## snatching several quick singles without loss and really putting the pressure on the Holmer Green fielders. Final score: 300 runs for 3 wickets (breakdown: 38 runs; 80 extras conceded by HGrn## 3 wickets x -6)

Will Hardman (Captain) did a fantastic job setting the field## and raising the game with an increasingly attacking field. Theo W was an awesome Wicketkeeper## who was forced to deal with some very variable bowling - well done! A few catches were missed## but Ballinger picked themselves up and 3 stunning catches were eventually taken by Will Jones## Will Hardman and Jamie McMullan (whose full somersault and safe hands brought huge applause from everyone!) Raphael bowled a maiden over## and Harry P bowled a wicket maiden - excellent. (Harry had definitely had 3 shredded wheat that morning!!) Harry P: 4 for 1 off 3; Will Hardman: 7 for 2 off 3; Will Jones & Raphael both had 4 for 0 off 2; Hannah 5 for 0 off 2; Elise 7 for 0 off 2; and a huge smile from Georgina when she took a wicket (caught) 13 for 1 off 2. Some excellent fielding from everyone - a particularly impressive start from Marcus Coulter## Jamie McMullan and Will Jones. Final Score: 250 (for 4 wickets). Breakdown: 26 runs conceded; 46 extras from Ballinger; 4 wickets taken.

Well done kids - great fun! (WH)

With all the boys on both sides knowing each other from their various schools this was always going to be a keenly contested match but once more Ballinger started a match with only 8 players on the pitch. 2 more arrived at the end of the 1st over and finally Toby Lyons arrived to take over the gloves from a very releaved Monty Thompson.

Hamish Sim was quickly into his stride and a briliant catch by Henry Turrell gave him his 1st wicket. With Reece Tiley on top form at the other end runs were hard to get. Chesham's batters were taking some excellent quick singles which led to some interesting field placings.

Will Arnold came onto replace Hamish and once again proved the virtue of line and length giving away just 5 runs in his 4 overs whilst taking 1 wicket. Greg McManus was on at the other end and quickly removed Chesham's No3. Tom Mckinley now joined Alex Goodman for the home side and these tewo batted very sensibly mixing aggression with good running between the wickets. They took Chesham's total to 102. It was difficult to decide whether this was a par score because the outfield was quite slow but the wicket was very true.

It was soon obvious that the Waggoners were going to struggle against some tight## but not particularly penetrative## bowling from Chesham. The run rate quickly climbed to 7 an over as Ballinger failed to copy the efforts of the hosts in looking for singles. Greg McManus was then bowled by a straight ball from Sam Rance's first ball## Monty and Toby then contrived to run out Toby## Henry Turrell was looking in good 'nick' and had started to bring the run rate down before he fell foul of another mix up with Monty. The skipper then failed to lead by example## holing out to his first ball##Dom Brown produced some lusty blows which started to bring the gane back to the visitors.It even gave them a small glimmer of hope## but his departure left the Waggoners with just too much to do over the last 3 overs and they finished 10 runs short.

Once more this was a game we should have won. Some very strange field placings and an inability to manage a run chase were two of the more obvious causes of the defeat.

On a different note the game was played in an excellent spirit and at last in beautiful sunshine.

U12s - Ballinger A v Chesham

A great win!  Well done everyone.

Ballinger batted first and scored 96 -2 off 20 overs (George Cooke  retired 30## Louis Prideaux 29## Freddie Thompson 26 not out).  A very solid start from openers Cooke and Prideaux.   Cooke’s was a very classy innings## as he scored quickly but with genuine cricket shots.  Prideaux played a supporting role and then opened out after Cooke retired - a very good first innings for Ballinger A from Louis.   Thompson guided Ballinger home to a strong score over the last 10 overs## with some nimble footwork and well-judged but daring running.

Ballinger put the squeeze on Chesham from the start with some excellent ground fielding.  Zac Bischoff (who had a promising A team wicket-keeping debut) completed an athletic run out of one opener## and that may have caused the other opener to embark on a overambitious single a few balls later## causing his downfall as Max Leane threw down the stumps with great speed – top fielding.  With lots of encouragement for each other## and great team spirit## Ballinger kept the pressure up for the remainder of the innings## and Chesham were always playing catch up.  Some very good bowling from Thompson## Joe Turrell and Leane in the middle of the innings in particular left Chesham with  too much to do at the end## and they never looked like getting there## particularly with Cooke coming back to bowl at the death.  88-7 at the end.

Well done## lads!

A cloudless sunlit Ballinger cricket ground was the setting for BWCC's first (actual) home game of the season## against newly promoted Bradenham. The visitors opted to take first knock## and from the very first ball their opening batsman Rafiq launched a violent assault on the bowling## being particularly severe on Nick Adams## whose first two overs went for 23. One feared that unless he was soon got rid of the match might shortly be all over## but Nick had his revenge in his third over## thanks to a splendid catch by his fellow opener Carlton Siddle## who had been keeping the other end under tight control. The wicket fell with the total on 30## of which Rafiq had made 28 in 12 balls.

The match now settled down to an even contest ## and skipper Maciver rotated his bowlers in short spells## whilst the No 3 bat Ghafoor proceeded steadily to a useful 59 before being bowled by Carlton. Meanwhile young Evan Webster bowled an excellent spell## taking 2-27 in his six overs## and a young newcomer Josh Badrick contributed an economical four overs for 9 runs.. With the scoring rate coming under increasing pressure## the Bradenham batsmen tried hard to speed things up## but only R Ilyas## with a rapid 33 not out containing three 6's achieved much success. Andy Thomson was the only bowler to bowl his full allotment of 12 overs## and although wicketless conceded a miserly 28 runs. Conversely## Nick who suffered so badly from the earlier onslaught was unfortunate enough to come under the cosh from Ilyas## and although he bagged two wickets they came at a price of almost 9 an over - very un-Nick like! A final total of 204 for 8 on what looked like a very good batting track (take a bow## Jamie) looked a very achievable target.

Paul Humphreys and Richard O'Kelly set about this target in fine style## with Paul particularly aggressive## until he was surprisingly## bowled for 36.Thereafter it was basically the Richard O'Kelly show. Wickets fell at 85## 101## and 119## and it was not until Carlton joined him that the match looked Ballinger's for the taking. Carlton fell LBW for an excellent 29## leaving Andy Thompson to partner Richard past the target## with four overs to spare.. Richard finished on 103 not out## a magnificent and perfectly paced innings.

Maximum points for Ballinger## enhanced by the very welcome arrival of Roger Webster## who agreed to umpire for the remainder of the game## thus gaining us three points which we hadn't counted on. The game was played in an excellent spirit## too## an added bonus.

At last the Waggoners 2nd X1 got on the field of play and what a beautiful day and ground to start on. Bradenham is one of the prettier grounds we play on and all though slightly quirky with it's slopes the views are wonderful.

Skipper Kerry started the day in fine form by losing the toss but Bradenham chose to bat anyway. This saved him the embarrasment of having to ask them to bat on what was going to be a very hot day.

Ballinger's side consisted of three adults and then eight boys with an average age of 13. Not ideal and Bradenham obviously thought this was going to be a stroll in the park.

Ballinger's boys had other ideas and after a couple of wayward overs Dom Brown and Tom Petrie settled into their stride and kept the Bradenham openers under the cosh. After the first 10 overs the score was just 30 with Dom having taken the teams first wicket of the season. 

First change introduced seasoned professional Bastie Richards. Last year wasn't one of Bastie's best and the skipper was a little worried. He needn't of been. Bastie quickly slipped into a good rhythm. By the end of his spell Bastie had the excellent figures of 4-49 including a hat-trick. At the other end James Fray had started his first spell in adult cricket and again held his line well but he topped his bowling efforts by taking the most stunning catch off his own bowling.

Enter Freddie Thompson. With his first ball in adult cricket Freddie produced a beautifully flighted leg spinner which Bradenham's Mottram chipped to short mid-wicket. At this point something amazing happened. Paul Branigan leapt salmon like to his left to take a fantastic catch.

With some excellent fielding and top bowling The Waggoners had reduced the home side to 139-9 with just 8 overs to go. Unfortunately the heat and number of overs began to take it's toll on the fielders and over these last few overs Braddenham's final wicket racked up another 60 runs. Very annoying.

Ballinger opened up with Peter Petrie and Bastie but Bastie was soon back in the hutch after a silly run-out. Peter was then joined by his son Tom. I'm sure Ballinger have had father/son batting partnerships before but one involving a 12 years old batting at 3? These two added 82 for the 2nd wicket before both fell in quick succession. Paul Branigan and the skipper were both undone by shooters and it looked like an early finish.

 Enter Harry Glenister. Fresh from a rowing training session Harry regarded the wielding of a bat as much easier fair and set about the Bradenham bowlers with great gusto. With Dom Brown they added a rapid 29 for the 6th wicket and suddenly the Bradenham fielders were panicking as Harry brought the winning draw within reach. Sadly it wasn't to be and the Waggoners finished 12 runs short of the target.

A really enjoyable game played in the right spirit and great effort by all of Ballinger's juniors. Bradenham were fulsome in their praise for the boys.

A good game## tight bowling from Chalfont kept score down to 103 which didn’t look enough. Chalfont got off to a good start but our boys tightened up and made it difficult for them. Accurate bowling throughout kept the pressure on and an excellent spell from Ben## aided by the setting sun behind him turned the tide. Good spell of accurate bowling from Will and a solid spell from Rob Farquhar saw us home. Chalfont 73-8 after their 20 overs. Game played in good spirit and all the boys played their part## well captained by Ben.

A very strong all-round batting performance saw Ballinger amass 160-5 off 20 overs. This was led by a great innings from Ben who made 51(retired). Lack of bowlers was our undoing after the good batting performance. Ben was also pick of the bowlers and gave us a glimmer of hope after their openers put on 78 runs in quick time## taking 3 wickets in 1 over## highlighted by a magnificent single handed catch by Dom at mid on that nearly took his arm out of it’s socket. Ben awarded Man of the Match by Ley Hill.

The Ley Hill v BWCC Challenge Trophy was supplied by our hosts for this and future fixtures and we look forward to the opportunity of getting it off them.

A great game## played in good spirit on a fabulous day. Credit to Ben who said he would have swopped his first 50 and overall personal performance for a team win.

Played in a fantastic spirit on a beautiful sunny evening at Shardeloes## our team of Under8s##9s and 10s put on a great display of cricket to win this friendly 12-a-side game at Amersham.

Georgina## captaining the side for the first time## rallied her enthusiastic troops and ably placed her fielders. Harry##Will## Nic and Philip opened up with some aggressive bowling## though Theo's excellent keeping skills were required. It wasn't until Georgina's second over that we got an all important wicket## bowled## swiftly followed up by Raphael with another wicket. With Louis## Finn and Oliver## all Ballinger bowling debutants## keeping up the pressure## the cool headed Marcus then bowled a double wicket maiden to knock their team off their stride. Harry## Philip## Will and Georgina then managed to restrict Amersham to only one run off their last four overs. Marcus 8 for 2 off 2. Georgina 8 for 1 off 3. Raphy 12 for 1 off 2. Philip 7 for 1 off 3.

Will and Nic opened the innings with great gusto## rapidly putting 29 runs on the board with some powerful offside shots from Nic. With all the more experienced batsman pairing with a younger player## Ballinger steadily accumulated their total## but were restrained by some very fine bowling at the end of the innings. Harry and Oliver kept cool heads to see Ballinger home.

The whole team should be very proud of their performance## but in particular those boys playing their first game. The old-timers were fantastic in their support of the whole team too. Well done all of you## and thank you for making this match manager very proud indeed.

Team; Georgina Kellock (Capt)## Will Hardman## Nic Blagg## Louis Barton## Harry Petrie## Theo Weatherall## Raphael Weatherall## Philip Sharkey## Finn Henry## Oliver Webb## Marcus Coulter (and a cameo fielding performance from Kit Sharkey)

Once more the U14s had to start a game with only 8 players but this time Hamish won the toss and batted so it didn't look so bad## especially as the opposition were in the same boat.

Brandon Allen and Greg McManus opened up for the Waggoners and were looking pretty secure until Brandon tried a somewhat risky shot and paid the penalty. The skipper then joined Greg and things were looking very promising with both beginning to play some powerful shots. Sadly the curse of Chesham returned and the visitors were gifted a wicket courtesy of Greg being run out.

Dom Brown then entered the fray and immediately set about the Beaconsfield bowlers. He and Hamish (29) put on 62 in 10 overs before Hamish departed to a similar shot to Brandon's.

Reece Tiley joined Dom and immediately tried to prove that he could run faster between the wickets than Dom. He could - just. They added 27 in 4 overs. When Reece departed Sam Peters helped Dom add another 10 runs over the last few balls enabling the Waggoners to finish on 119-4. Dom Brown finished with an excellent 43*

Ballinger may have their batting faults but they are a pretty decent bowling and fielding side and it didn't take long for this to show.

Reece cleaned up Beaconsfield opener Matt Harman and then Sam Peters with a brilliant throw ran out Connor Jones. Chris Kay and Calum Rennie then put on a very useful stand of 33 for the visitors but they were already in the 13th over. Chris was run out by that man Sam Peters and then Calum was run out by James Fray.

Aidan and Calum had dragged the visitors score up to 76 and Then Tom Devoy helped add another 10 before the overs ran out with the visitors nearly 30 runs short.

This was a convincing win for Ballinger with MofM Dom Brown providing not only the top score but also miserly figures of 4 overs 13 runs. All the bowlers were on form and being backed up by a tight fielding side## led by a good 'keeper and all marshaled well by the skipper meant the team finally got the result it deserved.

Hopefully the next game will involve all the U14 players who have yet to be involved with the team.

On a beautiful Sunday morning at Ballinger our unbeaten U10s arrived to take on Knotty Green in our second league fixture## with a mixture of old hands and new on display.

 

Captaining the team for the first time## Philip won the toss and put KG into bat. Will Hardman (vice-capt) took the gloves for the first half of the innings. Nic and Philip opened with some tight aggressive bowling. They immediately put the opposition under pressure## and grabbed three wickets## putting KG firmly on the back foot. This included a very smart run out by Jamie. Their second batting pair was a good deal stronger however## and put on a solid 28 runs off the bat. All of our bowlers tried hard with the bowling## but possibly in an effort to gain speed over accuracy## were a little expensive with extras. Nic looked quite comfortable with the gloves for the second half of the innings. With KG’s strongest batsman coming in again## as part of their last pair because they had only fielded 9 players## KG were able to climb to a very respectable total of 272. This was despite some very sharp work from Finn taking two wickets in the last over## including a run out of the over eager non-striking batsman!

 

Ballinger opened with a combination of Nic and Will## which had proved to be a strong partnership the previous match. Once again## they got us off to a good start## but slipped up by giving away a wicket. This proved to be the pattern for the next few pairs## good positive batting let down by unfortunate loss of wickets. By the time our last pair came in## we had lost five wickets. However## all three combinations of Finn and Oliver## Elise and Marcus and Jamie and Harvey## looked very nervous to start with and gradually grew in confidence. Both umpires were really impressed with the way you all improved in your four over’s## so I hope they can all build on that in their next matches for Ballinger. Philip and Will J came in as the last pair. Needing to get 21 runs to win## the pressure steadily grew and a little bit of panic set in. Albeit from some good straight bowling## the loss of a further five wickets in those last four overs## was enough to ruin the score. The loss by 29 runs did not really represent the cricket match.

 

All of the boys and Elise should be extremely proud of their efforts## and we will all mark this one down as a good experience for all.

 

An enormous thank you to Jayne Coulter for bravely taking on the scoring role again## and doing a very fine job.

 

Team: Philip Sharkey (Capt)## Nic Blagg## Will Hardman## Oliver Webb## Will Jones## Harvey Wilson (debut)## Jamie McMullan## Marcus Coulter## Elise Farquhar## Finn Henry

A fixture against bottom-of-the-table Knotty Green presented a welcome opportunity for Ballinger to bank some valuable league points## and with stand-in skipper Carlton Siddle (has Ian Davies emigrated??) winning the toss## Ballinger's bowlers were given first outing against their apparently out-of-form opponents. All went well for a while## and with four wickets captured for only 46 by the 15th over## Knotty Green appeared to be following the form book.. However## their left-handed No 3 bat D Williams was definitely not suffering from lack of form## and profitting from a culpable dropped catch before he was off the mark## proceeded to give a batting master-class in taking advantage of some increasingly loose Ballinger bowling. Other half-chances went begging## and then a belligerent knock by M Kumar## scoring 55 at No 8 saw the scoreboard fairly rattle along (metaphorically## that is## because Knotty Green are now the proud owners of an imposing new electronic scoreboard)## with all the bowlers## except Carlton## taking punishment. Williams should have cruised to his ton## but some uncooperative partners saw him stranded on 99 not out at the close## when Knotty Green had amassed 233 for 8.

Ballinger were quickly off to a good start## Matt Riley and the in-form Richard O'Kelly scoring freely## with 46 on the board before Matt exhibited splendid sportsmanship by walking to a catch at the wicket## which the umpire and eleven fielders all deemed to be not out. Rollo## making one of his rare (just-in-time) appearances for the side then joined Richard## and they were in little trouble until Richard was caught for a well-hit 40 out of 81 for the second wicket. By this time the bowlers were getting considerable lift off the wicket at the pavilion end - something Ballinger's bowlers had failed to extract - and the slip cordon steadily multiplied. Max Maciver## Paul Humphreys and Jamie Kellock all smacked some resounding boundaries## but in between a lot of fresh air passed between bat and ball. Meanwhile Rollo## having painstakingly passed his 50## a signal normally with him for a violent assault on tiring bowlers## unaccountably decided to perfect his defensive technique and eschew any attempt to keep up with the run-rate. Nick Adams was promoted to produce one of his famed blitzes## but barely got going## and by the time Carlton arrived at the wicket in the 42nd over a losing draw looked more than likely. However## the Knotty Green skipper decided to toss the ball to a new (and presumably untried) member of his team## with catastrophic (for him) results## as Carlton smashed 21 off 12 balls## and Rollo at last came to the party## finishing undefeated on 80 not out## as Ballinger passed their target with three balls to spare.

Nail-biting stuff## but Ballinger made it unnecessarily hard work for themselves.

After being put in## Freddie Thompson and George Cooke batted superbly in a big half century opening stand for Ballinger before Freddie had to retire for an excellent 30 while George made an impressive 25. The middle order accumulated a few but also lost wickets steadily including a poor run out. Apart from that Ballinger's running and calling had been very good. Ollie Moir(15 NO) and Jamie Kingston(16NO) came together at the end and really kicked on in the last two overs including 20 off the last over with Jamie thumping three successive fours and Ollie joining the fun. 110-6 looked to be a useful total## though not easy to defend with a very short boundary near the car park.

Beaconsfield were tied down at the start by some tight bowling by Ballinger  (George Cooke## Freddie Thompson## Jamie Kingston and Joe Turrell) and looked to be out of the game midway through their innings at 39-4. But their middle and lower order counterattacked nicely and they got back in the game as the pressure mounted on the bowlers and fielders. They had a good 5th wicket partnership going until Rob Farquhar made the breakthrough with two wickets in two balls. Beaconsfield's lower order kept on and even though they kept losing wickets edged closer to Ballinger's score. With the last pair batting there were six to win off the last over from Ollie Glenister (who had already picked up a couple of wickets). Three scored off the first three balls## then a dot ball## three to win off two balls.....then a crazy attempted run by the number 11 and well taken run out.

Ballinger had scraped home to win a nail-biter by 2 runs. It shouldn't have been so close. The game was played in a good spirit by both sides.

We knew this was going to be a tough match – Chesham’s U11A team include 5 or 6 county players## and were all U11’s. Having won the toss## Henry King (captain) elected to field first. Opening bowlers Simon Carlin and James Arnold delivered some very fast bowling## but the Chesham batsmen settled in and used the boys’ speed together with a fast outfield to score several fours## and a lot of quick singles## putting the Ballinger fielders under pressure and forcing errors. Hugo Eaton-Hart (WK) certainly had his work cut out for him## and there were a few byes from Simon’s overs. James Bunce and Harri Doyle also bowled very well## but both batsmen retired at 30## much to our disappointment. An injury on the field (James Arnold) forced Henry to change the bowling order## eventually rewarded when the first wicket fell in the 9th over## clean bowled by Harry Petrie## but Chesham had already scored 69 runs. With spirits lifted## our fielding improved and the opposition’s run rate slowed as a result## before a great catch was taken by Harry P in the 14th over (bowled by Henry K). Despite good bowling from Will Hardman and Matthew Barton## before bringing the other fast bowlers back on## further wickets just would not come. Another Chesham batsman retired at 30## and the final score after 20 overs was 151: a huge number to chase!

Opening batsmen Simon Carlin and Hugo Eaton-Hart knew they had a huge task ahead of them## but they proceeded to frustrate the Chesham bowlers with some excellent batting## and finding the gaps for several fours. Despite this## the run rate was much slower## and quick singles were hard to take## mainly due to the pace and accuracy of the county bowlers. My umpiring was tested when a fast ball popped up from Simon’s bat## and he quickly toed it away to defend his wicket. Eleven rather surprised Chesham fielders looked at me in appeal – but Not Out. Again## the first wicket fell in the 9th over (an unfortunately over-optimistic call by Simon## which resulted in him being stumped). Ballinger’s score was 39 (30 behind). Hugo E-H was out caught## as was Harri Doyle (at 3) and James Bunce (at 4). Matthew Barton (at 5) was bowled## and it looked as though our batting was about to collapse. However## Henry King (at 6) calmly took back control of the game## despite Chesham’s best efforts## and produced several fours. Theo Weatherall (at 7) joined him at the crease## knowing that his older brother Monty (now at Chesham) was desperate to claim his wicket! The battle of the brothers lasted 3 overs: Theo held his own## and kept his head despite the banter on the field## playing defensive strokes and not letting the pressure get to him. Even though he only scored one run## he denied his brother (spinner) and two other county bowlers a much-wanted wicket – Theo definitely won the final battle## even though we didn’t win the war!

Well done boys – you played really well## and both Nigel and I were very pleased. You were a much younger team## and had only had 1 match 2 weeks before## whereas Chesham had had 3 that week. Half their team are county players – but you earned their respect today!

Final Score: Chesham 151 for 2; Ballinger 64 for 5

Little Marlow batted first on a very soft and slightly damp wicket. Their batsmen all struggled to score and wickets fell steadily throughout the innings against a spirited Ballinger team. Our lads were queueing up to bowl and the game provided an opportunity to try out a few irregular bowlers. Having said that Ben was again the pick of the bowlers  with 3-5 off 4 overs but it was great to see Jes## Ollie## Toby and Freddie all picking up wickets; but there were a disappointing number of wides conceded from the occasional bowlers so that is something to work on. Max had a great game behind the stumps with three stumpings and two run-outs. LM were restricted to a meager 60 all out which was never going to be a severe challenge. Our experimental opening partnership gave a coupe of lads a chance to play a good innings## but the experiment failed. After that the Dugdales got stuck in to the bowling; Max seemed to be in a hurry to get things done with another couple of huge sixes and Ballinger cantered home in 9.5 overs. Both sides played the game in really good spirits and although a one-sided affair it was great to see everyone get a chance to contribute.

Cup games arranged during half term are always difficult to get out a full strength team## however## we had some very good players. After some heavy rain yesterday and during the night## and yet more forecast for the rest of the week## we persuaded HWCC to go ahead and play!

Henry King captained## won the toss & elected to field first. Some excellent bowling from openers Simon Carlin & Harry Petrie. Will Hardman bowled very economically at 4## and Charlie B bowled a maiden over in his 2nd over. Simon## Harry P## Dylan & Will Hardman each took one wicket (bowled)## plus 2 runouts from Simon's overs. A couple of near runouts## and a couple of nearly caughts ... but the fielding was generally better today. HWCC finished on 91 for 6.

HWCC only needed to bowl line and length today## and to keep their heads in the field. Simon scored 17 (he'd already lost several lives before finally being caught!). Hugo scored 25## and looked as though he would have to retire## but decided he would tempt fate with a kami-kazi run .... and was indeed run out. Henry K scored a decent 7 before being bowled## but the run rate slowed right down## and HWCC began to gain confidence. Charlie B (at 5) and Theo (at 6) faced some accurate bowling## but there was still a lot to do. The score was 59 at the end of the 10th over## and still only 69 at the end of the 16th over - only 10 runs scored in 6 overs!! A quick shower interrupted play for a few minutes## and after an opportune team-talk## Theo & Charlie knew they needed to really increase the run rate. 

There was a bit of confusion with the rain interruption and the scoreboard: how many overs left? and how many needed to win? .... and for one moment## we thought we had another over to go## and just 3 needed to win; in which case the game would have been ours! Alas the scoreboard was wrong## and despite really upping their game## BWCC were just 3 runs short of the target!

Never mind boys## every game is a lesson in itself## and it was good to get some cricket played!

When skipper Kerry lost the toss again there was no surprise when Ballinger were asked to bat.

Having arranged his batting order to suit the demands of the 2ndX1 super stars and## as usual sacrifised him self on the alter of an easy life## he wandered out onto the balcony to watch the start of proceedings.

It took a couple of overs before he and the rest of the team on the sidelines realised that the vistors only had 8 players. There was immediately much muttering about how low down the order various batters were.

They needn't have worried as their team mates earlier in the order felt sorry for them and decided to either hit the ball to one of only 6 outfielders## get their pads in the way or pull muscles that hadn't been used for 20 years.

Peter Petrie ( (34) and Bastie( 23) made full use of the wide open spaces then Ben Dugdale and Paul Branigan added 82 for the 5th wicket before both were LBW in quick succession. They were followed by an unbroken stand of 99 between Daren Samat( 56*) and Reece Tiley (33*). Both batted very well against some mixed bowling.

After an excellent tea Ballinger set about the job of taking 7 wickets.

Reece got the home side off to a good start with a wicket in his first over and it soon becam apparent that the visitors weren't going to delay the envitable too long.

Tom Petrie took a wicket in his third over then Ben ( 3-7) and Reece ( 3-9) finished things off.

With a scoring umpire on both sides meant maximum points for Ballinger. Nice to get a win but slightly unsatisfying.

U10 beat Chesham in a pairs game this morning. Ballinger finished on 321 for 2 wickets## Chesham just 203 for 10 wickets = BWCC win by a massive 118 runs!!!!  Full match report to follow when Umps has recovered from all the excitement !!  (WH)

A very exciting match away against Beaconsfield## resulting in a Ballinger win by 19 runs. Some real star performances - full match report to follow when Umps has recovered from all the excitement (and 2 matches in 1 day!!!). Scores: BWCC 90 (for 8 wickets); Beaconsfield 72 for 10 (9 wickets & 1 retired).  

Top batsmen:  Theo W 17; Charlie Barraclough 13

Top bowlers: Harry Petrie 2 wickets for 4 runs off 4 (incl 2 wicket maiden overs; Dylan (hat-trick) Ellis 3 wickets for 3 runs off 1 !!!

(WH 10.6.2012)

Ballinger won the toss and chose to bat but tight bowling made it very difficult to score and wickets fell as our lads attempted to get the scoreboard moving. Dom played a great innings and held the team together but 84 was never going to be enough. Their opening pair set about this sub par total with Saif Zaib looking to finish the game in quick time. He was dropped on 15 and then made us suffer. Our bowlers found it difficult against quality opposition and the pressure told with some eratic bowling that was severely punished. The boys stuck to their task in what was always going to be a losing battle. Special mention to Henry Turrell who stepped in at the last minute and opened our innings and facing their best bowlers put in a good display.

The game was played in a good spirit and gave our boys the opportunity to see the standard required at this higher level.

Cricket - boring? predictable? Not this match !!  It proved that however obviously a team is staring defeat in the face## fortunes can change in dramatic fashion. In this case it also demonstrated that having youngsters in the side can compensate for the failings of their elders!

Up against Holmer Green## league champions last season## and vying for the leadership this season## prospects did not look too rosy when## after being sent in to bat first on a wicket that had miraculously survived the week's downpours## Paul Humphreys was back in the hutch with only 10 on the board. Andy Thompson was joined by by Max Maciver## and they slowly set about repairing the damage## to such good effect that with both batting increasingly fluently their partnership had yielded 96 before Andy was bowled for an excellent 46. Max went on to a vitally important 56## made over two hours## but at the other end the batting fell steadily apart. Ian Davies## fresh from his international travels## departed to a catch behind## Will Smith went LBW first ball (his day was to come on the morrow!!)and Jeremy Hunting perished second ball to a full toss. Carlton## as usual## batted positively but was left high and dry##  though there were a few lusty blows from Jamie Kellock## Ian Maciver and Nick Adams## before the overs ran out with a total of 180 for 8 on the board.

Past experience## and the current batting form of Holmer Green's openers Kevin King and M Watt indicated that early wickets would be vital. Great joy then## as Watt launched the fifth ball of Carlton's first over skywards with skipper Davies waiting expectantly right underneath it. Joy rapidly transformed to grief## as the ball thudded through (round?) his hands to the turf## upon which Davies buried his face in aforesaid turf in misery - and possibly to avoid looking at his team-mates. This would be the only opportunity to get rid of Watt## who rubbed salt into the wound by plundering 26 of Nick's third over. But the Gods pitied Ballinger## and up went another skyer off Carlton's fourth over## this time with Jeremy on hand to clutch it - which he did## only for a subsequent juggling act see the ball once more on the turf. The Gods by now had had enough; the score raced up to 125 without loss## only 15 overs gone## and Ballinger were looking very unhappy bunnies.

Desperate Davies now tossed the ball to Evan Webster and Max Maciver. There followed one of the more remarkable collapses seen on the Ballinger ground for many a year. Watt was clean bowled by Max for 98## 82 of which had come from boundaries in 43 balls## when it looked a cast-iron certainty that he would cruise undefeated past his 100 and see off the winning target with ease. King soldiered on but increasingly defensively## whilst Max wrought havoc at the other end. Evan took 1 for 12 in his very tidy 6 overs## whilst Max narrowly missed the all-time Ballinger bowling record in taking 9 for 21 in a staggering exhitition of spin bowling## as Holmer Green lost 10 wickets for 27 runs in the space of 16 overs.

So the Gods had finally decided to show Ballinger that if the oldies couldn't do the job## the young ones certainly can! Incidentally## there was also an excellent display of keeping by Will Smith behind the stumps. Joy## and for some## profound relief## as Ballinger left the field## and a sporting## if utterly bemused reaction by the Holmer Green players. Not that they went to the pub.....

Horrid weather closing in rapidly at 5.30pm. Agreed with GX to play 10 overs each side and then review the weather/pitch conditions/light. We allowed GX to bat first because several of their players still hadn't arrived by 6.10pm.

Playing for the first time on grass (to avoid the lake now surrounding the pavilion!!) Simon Carlin & James Arnold opened the bowling with their usual exciting pace and really kept the GX batsmen on the back foot. Theo W kept wicket superbly## and the changeover in the field was quick## maintaining the pressure on the batsmen and keeping the run rate down. Ballinger were rewarded with 5 good wickets in the first four overs## and GX crumpled under the onslaught. (A great catch by Harrie Petrie## and two great catches by Charlie B.... who nearly caught a 3rd as well.) 

The rain started## but Harry Petrie continued the excellent bowling## and kept both batsmen from scoring any runs in his 2 overs (a few extras only due to very slippery conditions for a pace bowler). Henry K took the 6th wicket in the 10th over## before we all took cover from the rain for 5 minutes.

GX score: 33 for 6 wickets## in 10 overs

Simon and Charlie opened the batting. Simon scored an impressive boundary off the first ball## and the opposition's faces fell. He and Charlie took a little while to get in sync## and certainly faced some very fast & accurate bowling from GX. Both boys were bowled (better than being caught)## but were out to very good balls - no shame there. Theo batted at 3## settling in at the crease quickly and comfortably## before pushing the run rate back up again and scoring a very impressive 14## not out. Henry K didn't face many balls because the match was won on the last ball of the 8th over.

Stumps and bails collected## and a mad dash for cover and tea!!

BWCC score: 35 for 2 wickets## (8 overs)

WELL DONE TO ALL THE BOYS - YOU LOOKED AND PLAYED LIKE A CRICKET TEAM !!  (WH 14.06.2012)

A strong all-round batting display saw Ballinger pile on 158. Max and Robert got us off to a flying start -this was one of Robert's best innings yet and he smashed a six through the covers into the carpark in the second over to get things moving. Then Will Reid played played a superb innings for 39  off 21 balls with the ball flying around and Ben also batted superbly. Both were out to run outs which should not have happened although there was some excellent fielding and direct hits by GK fielders. These and some tight GK bowling slowed the momentum for  few overs in the middle of the innings. However Hamish continued the onslaught later in the innings with a quick-fire 31no off 15 balls. 158-6 was going to be a challenging total for GK to chase.

Our bowling was really good with accurate and tight bowling from eight different bowlers. Of particular note were Will and Reece who tied GK down from the start## Rob Farquhar and Will Arnold were both accurate and economical## and Jess Thomas and Joe Shepherd who both took wickets at the end with Joe taking 3 wickets in the final over. Our strong team bowling performance and good ground fielding made it hard for GK to score apart from Joe Thomas who scored an impressive half century but who didn't find enough support. Our strong all-round performance played in great spirit was only marred by some dropped catches so more practise is required as this will be much more important in closer matches. As it was Ballinger won by a big 52 run margin.

With the pitch wet after yet another sodden week## Carlton Siddle## leading the side again## in the absence of both Captain and Vice-Captain## decided to field first ## a decision that looked to have  paid off when J Cox## a regular destroyer of Ballinger bowling## was caught by Jamie Kellock behind the stumps for only 10. His fellow opener (father## S Cox) then batted so tentatively against an accurate attack on an unreliable wicket## that the scoreboard barely crept along## as wickets fell steadily. Nick Adams recovered from his traumas of the previous week to bowl 6 maidens in taking 3 for 22 in his 12 overs## well supported by Evan Webster (3 for 42 in 10)## and a fine## economical spell by Paul Humphreys (welcome back to the ranks of the bowlers## Paul!) who conceded only 17 runs from his 12 overs. Cox (snr) having reached double figures in the 27th over (!)## was eventually out for 26## but an irritating partnership of 25 for the eigth wicket saw league leaders Downley post 135 for 8 after 45 over.

Normally such a target would be well within Ballinger's capabilities## but the weather## very windy all afternoon## deteriorated with some heavy rain at the tea interval## and continued thereafter with frequent showers. Although this would handicap the bowlers## it also greatly slowed down the outfield## which had only been partly mown due to an equipment breakdown. Taking their cue from the Downley batsmen## Matt Riley and Paul Humphreys batted even more cautiously (12 on the board after 10 overs!)## then Paul was bowled with the total on 21## triggering a collapse## with few batsmen having much success in coping with the spin of D Willans. Only Matt batted with any confidence in top-scoring with 28. When 9 wickets were down for 70 with 9 overs still remaining## Ballinger appeared doomed.
