But## as usual## Carlton batted with true Yorkshire grit## and was impressively supported by 11th man Evan ## who batted out 29 deliveries for his 1 not out## and it was a damp and disgruntled Downley side who left the field somewhat short of the 25 points that had looked to be theirs.

As a result## Ballinger remain by the skin of their teeth the only unbeaten side in the premier division## but have slipped to 5th place.

Ballinger batted first and soon started to pile on the runs in a dominating 69 run opening partnership between Henry and Monty. Henry played a splendid aggressive innings hammering the ball round the ground and reaching 50 before  he retired while Monty was rather more measured in his 22. Then Greg came in and also played an excellent innings for 40 continuing the batting momentum. Freddie provided good support running lots of good quick singles to rotate the strike. The other batsmen were unlucky to miss out. 142-5 was clearly a good score against demoralized opponents.

Reece bowled a marvelous opening spell and clean bowled three of the top order LM batsmen. It wasn't easy at the other end against Hamish who was unlucky not to take any wickets with his bowling## although he captained well and took a great run out with a  long bullet throw after a chase to the long on boundary. Greg## Dominic## James and Matt all bowled well and picked up wickets as LM collapsed in a very weak batting display.  The last pair hung on to deny Ballinger the last wicket with LM finsihing on 61-9. Our lads were very excited and upbeat and fielded very well too. Team spirit was strong and it was hard to fault the allround performance.

A very young team from Ballinger with only 4 U11's due to school trips## but some up and coming stars proved their value as part of the squad today.

Ballinger batted first with Hugo E-H and James Bunce (Captn) opening. The Winchmore Hill bowlers proved to be fast and accurate with a double-wicket maiden in the first over: 1 catch## and 1 LBW. The WH fielders and bowlers continued to keep our batsmen in the crease## and punished anyone who didn't keep the ball on the ground with some great catching.

BWCC 35 all out (17 overs) - highest scorer again = Hugo E-Hart

Slightly disheartened## but encouraged to go out and reply with some great fielding and bowling## the BWCC boys started really well with some awesome bowling from Harry Petrie (2 for 1 off 2) including a caught and bowled## plus a great first over from James Bunce. Matthew Barton bowled two really good overs with his new slower action (just 4 runs conceded in 2 overs). Winchmore's score was only 19 by the end of the 7th over (just 6 runs ahead of ours)## but they hadn't lost as many wickets.

In Overs 8 to 10## the Winchmore Hill batsmen suddenly found their stride## and started to score boundaries. Matthew Gate's Over reeled them back in for a moment## but they weren't to be deterred## finishing easily on 37 by the end of the 10th over with 7 wickets in hand.

A very good game of cricket - and a nice club to lose to. Everyone fielded well and contributed tonight - some excellent wicket-keeping from Hugo (no byes at all!)## and only 4 extras in total from our bowlers - very impressive!!!! (WH 18.6.2012)

As usual a bit of controversy when we play GX. This was a game that should never have been played because of the weather but as always once you start it's difficult to stop.

GX won the toss and put the Waggoners in what was gong to be an interesting pitch. Tom Petrie and Freddie Thompson opened up for the visitors and were picking off singles quite comfortably and quickly added 20 before both fell trying to force the pace. James McIntyre was joined by Will Arnold and Will set about the GX attack with great glee. He and James added 41 for the 3rd wicket of which Will scored a brilliant 33*. There was then a scamble over the last two overs to try and reach a decent score which 74 was probably 10 short.

The rain hen got worse and it was quite aparent tha Ballinger would struggle holding the ball but both teams wanted to play so off we went.

A couple of early wickets## 1 each from Tom P and Will## got the Waggoners in the hunt but as the ball became more and more difficult to hold## a couple of catches went down and it all got a bit messy. GX had a match winner in big hitting Chris Daniels who put on 50 with Nial McCarthy and took the game out of Ballinger's reach. The home side got home with a couple of overs to spare.

The boys enjoyed themselves which is more than can be said for a certain umpire.

AGGGGGHHHH

 

This is getting very frustrating. Although the pitch could probably have been used the outfied was just too wet again.

I think we need a new drainage system rather than pavilion.

2 games in 7 weeks. Very frustrating

Firstly it was worth noting that the sun was shining for our visit to Chalfont St.Peter.

Batting first the home side were always going to be underpressure from The Waggoners opening attack. With Will Arnold once more displaying his consumate control over line## length and late swing and George Cooke giving nothing away at the other end Chalfont were 4 down by the end of the 5th over with the score on 7. Whiting then helped Crossley add 36 for 5th wicket with Crossley continuing until retiring for a well played 33.

Ballinger eventually removed the rest of the Chalfont order but not until the last ball of 20th over by which time they'd reached 73. There was some good fielding with a couple of good catches from the visitors.

Tom P and George set off after the target and looked in complete control until George spooned one to mid-on. Fred Sanders was then out first ball and Tom gave some more catching practice. By this time however Gethin Ross was in full flow and was despatching the Chalfont bowlers to all parts of the ground. He retired on 32 off just 21 balls. After his departure Ollie Fretton was run out## Will Arnold's innings was 'after the Lord Mayors show' so it was left to Rob Farquhar to smite the 6 that won the game.

A good result and an all-round competent display by the boys. Even the umpire was happy because he was warm and dry.

1.15pm. Two problems. Skipper Davies hasn't turned up in time to toss up (but then he does live on the other side of London). Selector Humphreys has "done a Kerry" and assembled a jury rather than a cricket XI. That said## it looked a very capable jury## and it was soon reduced to eleven when Ian Maciver volunteered to fill the umpiring vacancy## thus guaranteeing Ballinger at least 3 league points. Such was the strength of the batting line-up that Ballinger elected to bat first on yet another rain affected wicket.The creme de la creme of BWCC batting prowess then proceeded to resemble more a sagging souffle as the scoreboard lurched from 6 for 4 wickets by the 5th over to 22 for 6 by the 10th. Only Richard O'Kelly appeared to have any idea how to handle Cadmore End's excellent openers## and an on-going batting disaster zone suddenly nose-dived towards the tragic as Richard attempted to  despatch a long hop from the first-change bowler's second ball into Blackthorn Lane## only to see his stumps scattered. The look of mortification on his face said it all. 31 for 7## and surely no way back from this one?  Would this be Ballinger's lowest ever league score??  Oh## such pessimism......  For two of our doughtiest defenders in the form of Jamie Kellock and Evan Webster now started a dogged partnership that eventually yielded 64 runs for the 8th wicket## and broke the bowlers' grip on the game## as they inched the total towards a measure of respectability. Evan fell for an invaluable 20## but Ben Dugdale then joined the indomitable Kellock## and they hauled the final score up to 128 as the final wicket fell in the 45th over. Jamie finished on 56 not out## surely one of his best ever league performances.

Inspired by these batting heroics## Ballinger took to the field enthused## and in no time had two Cadmore End wickets down## courtesy of of a slick stumping by Richard O'Kelly and a lightning slip catch by Paul Humphreys. 7 for 2## and could the improbable happen? Alas## at 65 for 2## and only 18 overs gone## the answer looked to be "no". However## Cadmore's No 3 batsman made a serious mistake when he lofted the second ball of Carlton Siddle's second over out of the ground. Carlton doesn't like being hit for six! With a wicket in his 3rd over## and two more in his 4th## he transformed the Cadmore innings into a shambles at 73 for 6. The batsmen now tried to regroup## and desperate defence yielded a mere 22 runs in the following 18 overs## during which Carlton bagged a fourth wicket. At 99 for 8## sensing that the target was actually within range## they now upped the tempo## but were dramatically undone when the No 11 ran himself out with only 15 more runs needed## and four overs left. Carlton finished with 4 for 23 off his 12 overs## and Evan built on his recent excellent performances with 2 for 8 off 6 overs.

A match of remarkable twists and turns saw Ballinger not only preserve their unbeaten record## but take maximum points from a match which had looked utterly lost at 2.05pm!

At last a game of cricket.

The 2s travelled to the wilderness of Cadmore End with some joy in their hearts as they had a ridulous batting line up. There were a few concerns about the strength of the bowling but it wouldn't matter as we could chase down any score Cadmore offered.

This was the basis of the tactics worked out by skipper Branigan in conjunction with his  CinC the day before. It was only left to the skipper to manage the menial task of winning the toss.

So it was plan B then. Score a huge total on yet another Cadmore batter friendly pitch and then bowl the home side out.

It appears that none of the Ballinger batsmen were privy to the tactic as they happily played round straight balls## ran themselves out## gave simple catching practice to the fielders or even allowed the fielders to demonstrate an athelitiscm in taking a catch not often seen in this parish.

Only an ill Peter Petrie(25) and David Kiddie(19) managed double figures## with Dom Brown helping Peter add 33 for the 8th wicket## as the Waggoners were bowled out for just 84.

The CinC had told the troops that anything around 100+ would be a difficult target. Having let the home side get to 80 the lack of depth in their batting began to show and 4 wickets fell as they struggled to get the last 5 runs. Another 20 runs would have been too many for them.

There was some interesting bowling with Dave the pick but Dom did an excellent job as well. James Fray fielded really well and managed to remove the End's top scorer but it was Bastie's 3-10 which stands out. Mainly because he hadn't got a clue where the ball was going so the batsmen had no chance.

The bowlers were backed up by an excellent display behind the sticks from Max Dugdale. This almost made up for his first ball duck.

Once again we left Cadmore End with a sense of frustration. We should have won

Chalfont St Peter 115- 4; Ballinger U15s 108-8

We made a very good start in the field restricting Chalfont to 51-3 in 13th over. Our early bowling by Will## Hamish and Ben was economical although not very accurate and got some early breakthroughs. But then it all fell apart as Chalfont's No4 (Reif) took to the attack against some poor bowling by most of our other bowlers and slack fielding that included a concoction of no balls and wides## overthrows and three dropped catches. Two well taken run outs by Max and Ben's catch were scant consolation. Chalfont had gained the momentum and put 115-4 on the board. 

Our run chase started very slowly against some very good bowling## which was directed on the stumps. It wasn't easy batting and bounce was variable but several of the top order were out to straight balls that hit or were going to hit the stumps. Dom was unlucky though as he got a pea-roller. We fell behind and lost key wickets. Will Reid led a fightback with a splendid innings over 18 overs and looked like he could win the game. He was ably supported by Dom## Hamish & Josh## each of who scored 14. The game went to last over but there was too much to do and the game finally slipped away when Will was run out on second ball of the last over## and three more wickets followed## rather than the few runs left to win.

This was a disappointing loss for U15 against a team we had beaten easily earlier in the season. Narrow 7 run margin makes it harder as there were many obvious ways that number of runs could have been saved with more accurate bowling## better fielding or shot selection. We have to learn to play as a team and keep it tight when put under pressure.
Regrettably Burnham could not raise a side.

For one week the 1st IX were free of the steely gaze of the President## who## as well as scoring and writing the usual pithy and frank match reports## is known to offer the troops the odd motivational comment## to spur them on during the hours of play (though they may sound occasionally more like despairing gasps).  And## parted from their mentor (guru?)## the 1st XI duly lost their unbeaten record.  Monks Risborough always have a significant home advantage## with the steeply sloping outfield and equally steeply undulating run-ups causing problems for opposition fielders and bowlers.  But that is no excuse.  In short## Ballinger bowled well and possibly batted as well (or badly) as Monks## but Monks held nearly all their catches and Ballinger shelled too many of theirs.

On a very grassy wicket## Ballinger were happy to be bowling first.   Nick Adams generated plenty of zip but no luck and Andy Thompson plugged away for 12 overs eventually extracting 4 wickets.  Both suffered dropped catches; and## rather than being 84 for 4 after 24 overs## Monks should probably have been  7 down.  Thankfully## some big inswingers from Evan Webster and then later on Ian Maciver’s slow left arm kept the runs in check and produced some wickets as Ballinger began at last to hold their catches.  The turning point in the fielding  came when skipper Ian Davies showed the way by clinging onto a skier in the 24th over## to his obvious delight after 2 less successful weeks in the catching department.  A flurry of wickets after the 35th over## for Maciver and also David Kiddie## saw Monks bundled out for only 142 in 40 overs## Ian Maciver finishing with the striking figures of 4-3-4-3.  Job well done## one might have thought!  50 overs to get 143 runs with 10 wickets to play with …… sounds easy doesn’t it?

First## to be fair## Monks bowled pretty well.  They know their game and they stick to it.  Second## they caught their catches## including 2 very good diving efforts in the covers.  Third## the grassy pitch was still “doing a bit”.  But that is where the excuses end.  Opener Thompson ground out a laborious 28 from more than 30 overs## and was 8th out; while others came and went## as Ballinger lost wickets steadily at the rate of one every  4 overs or so throughout the afternoon (5 falling lbw).  Ian Maciver played some crisp shots for 19 not out at the end## coming in slightly incongruously at number 10## and## with batting that deep## Ballinger hoped even then for another improbable victory## but this time it was not to be## as the last wicket fell with Ballinger 35 short and still another 7.3 overs to be bowled.

Once the smoke had cleared on the battlefield it was difficult to decide whether this was the thrashing the score indicates## a collection of missed chances or what might have been if we'd had 11 fit players on the pitch at the end of the match.

Unbeknown to the CinC he had lost one his key players before the start of the match hence his confusion when finding 12 players at the ground. It turned out that his able lieutenant had changed the well rehearsed plans of the previous day and insured a substitue was in place. The injured party had been press-ganged into scoring## thus giving us max umpire/scorer points. - brilliant. This man should be in charge. 

The CinC was also a bit bemused when he won the toss and had a choice to make. Having decided to field he could have done with his bowlers making some early inroads into the Hills batting## but the visitors were getting there revenge for some crafty team selection carried out by the Wagoners last year.

A slim line Lewis Thompson opend up for Ley Hill and he an his fellow opener Lynes added 55 for the 1st wicket in just 10 overs. Lewis was in imperious form smashing Ballingers bowlers to all parts of the green and when Lynes fell to Ben Dugdale's 4th ball## his contribution to the partnership was 3.

The rest of the fielding and bowling display should be glossed over but it must be mentioned that we dropped a few catches. An easy one by Josh Badrick at mid-on and even easier one by Bastie Richards at 1st slip. The fact that both ended up in A&E as a result of their errors was probably punishment enough. At least in Bastie's case he kept his eye on the ball. So by the end of the innings we had a full hand of Petries on the field doing stirling jobs as subs.

The Hill declared on 236 -5 in 40 overs with only Alex Howe and Joe Hankinson coming out with much credit for their bowling

On an easy paced pitch Ballinger should have been able to put up a decent response and having been given a generous 45 overs to score the runs we should have made a better fist of it than we did.

It wasn't to be and with the three senior pros amassing 17 between them it was too tall a task for the boys. It was good to see Joe Hankinson back in his whites and his patient innings may well be the precursor to better things

Hamish Sim and Alex almost batted out the overs and it was quite interesting watching Ley Hill's bowlers getting a bit concerned towards the end but## frankly## we weren't at the races and the visitors deserved their victory.

 As always it was a pleasant game only marred by Basties injury and I'd like to thank the Thompson family for their help with getting him to A&E.

An excellent tea to thanks to Debbie and Fiona

In a brief interruption in the never-ending rain we managed to fit in a rare game of cricket against U15s archrivals Ley Hill in a top of table clash. It  was inevitably a damp and soft pitch.

Once again Max and Robert got us off to a really strong start. this time  putting on 55 for the first wicket in 8 overs. Max played a superb knock for 51 off 30 balls punishing the wayward short-pitched early bowling from Ley Hill's attack. Robert (16) provided vital and solid support at the other end in another fine partnership. But then there was a collapse as the top order were out cheaply as it was hard to get going on such a slow pitch and LH tightened up the bowling and held their catches. Reece and Dom consolidated with another good partnership that took the total to 127-7. Given LH had chased down 160 in the earlier encountered we expected a good response.

Will and Reece opened the bowling this time and put the batting side under pressure from the start with fast and accurate bowling. Reece's first ball was a superb unplayable fast inswinging yorker which dispatched LH's best batsman. The top order batsmen dug in and hung on although they found it hard scoring.  Then Robert picked up the ball in the deep and hurled in a magnificent long throw to hit the stumps and run out the No.2. Brilliant fielding that lifted the whole Ballinger team. A procession of wickets started including three more run outs: the first another superb pickup and throw to the keeper Max by Toby## then another direct hit by Robert who's fielding was red hot and the third by Max. Robert also held a really good catch and Kenny joined in with a good caught and bowled. LH were demolished and all out for 50! We won the challenge cup LH had put up after a series of close encounters - but it wasn't close this time. Ballinger were on top of their game and showed remarkable spirit. Robert edged it over Max for Man-of-the Match. The boys moved top of the table although sadly it was the last league game of the season and others have games in hand.

Defeat at the hands of a better team is acceptable. If you lose by playing badly## you've only yourselves to blame. So## this much-changed## ring -rusty (blame the weather!) Ballinger side must be wondering quite how things went wrong in this home fixture against Ley Hill. Loose opening bowling gave Ley Hill a rapid start## but Nick Adams and Jack Hankinson soon got their act together## backed up by excellent work in the field. Wickets fell steadily## and change bowlers Max Maciver and David Kiddie maintained the pressure## to the extent that when the 9th wicket fell## Ley Hill had only 98 on the board in 33 overs. Simulaneously their No 11 arrived at the ground## hurled himself out of his van## and managed to reach the crease just in time (?) to beat a "timed-out" dismissal.. This proved to be one of the tipping points in the match## as the last wicket pair then proceeded to show all their preceding batsmen how to make runs## and took the total up to 142## with 42 overs used.

Still## 48 overs to score 143 on a decent track## with boundaries even shorter than usual## due to the area in front of the pavilion having been officially designated "swamp" and excluded from the field of play## should be easily done. Openers Max Maciver and Sam Phillips got Ballinger away to a slow but steady start## and had 36 on the board before Sam perished LBW. Rollo then entered the fray## and soon had the score moving. At 99 for 3## and only 30 overs gone## Ballinger were cruising. At the same stage Ley Hill had lost 9 wickets! However## Ley Hill's Sri-Lankan (ex Hawridge & Cholesbury) spinner Daluwatte was causing all sorts of problems## and courtesy of a clutch of LBW decicisions where the DRS system## had it been available## might have come in really useful## Ballinger then completely disintegrated## losing 7 wickets for 9 runs## ending with a paltry total of 108. Rollo had looked as if he could have won the game in a canter## and it was unfortunate that his LBW was the most controversial. Daluwatte was the main destroyer## with 6 for 22## but the later batsman had little excuse for their abject performance.

Never mind## "summer" arrived at long last## the tea was excellent - take a bow## the Thompsons - but we'd rather you were playing## Andy!

A combination of a sunny afternoon and the National Trust ambiance of Bradenham's pretty ground## which our 1sts had not visited for many a year## gave all present hope that a good game of cricket would ensue - which## in the end## it did. Opting to bat first## Ballinger's top order batsmen looked unlikely to make it a prolonged contest## hell-bent as they were on giving catching practice to Bradenham's fielders. Rollo McIntyre looked likely to produce one of his blistering match-winning assaults## only to join the suicide brigade when he had made a rapid 31. With the score 78 when the 6th wicket fell## in the 21st over## a competitive total looked improbable.  An ideal challenge then to Andy "Bulldog" Thompson## who dug in and defied the bowlers for more than an hour. In this he was more than ably supported by young Xavier Owen## making his debut for the 1sts. His elegant correct style of batting was a delight to watch. Together they added 55 for the 7th wicket## and after Andy was out for a priceless 40## Ian Maciver (only playing because he was deemed marginally less crocked than the limping Jamie Kellock) launched a late assault on the bowling## blasting an undefeated 31 off 18 balls. Xavier finished on 37 not out## with the 9th wicket having added 47 runs before the innings closed on 187 for 8.

In reply## Bradenham were soon in trouble## losing their first two wickets for only 15## with one of them gifted by a comical run-out when the No 3 batsman overbalanced trying to regain his crease. Two stunning catches by Xavier enabled Jack Hankinson to grab a couple of scalps## but thereafter the batsmen became increasingly dominant## being particularly severe on Max Maciver.. However## not for the first time this season## Ewan Webster produced a steady and profitable spell## taking 4 for 21 in his 7 overs. With Bradenham's score on 132 for 7## and only 27 overs gone## the match had definitely swung Ballinger's way. Ian Maciver## conceding only 6 runs off 5 overs## and David Kiddie with 17 off 7 overs## applied such a stranglehold that nine overs later the total had only reached 140. Skipper Davies then## fatally as it turned out## changed the bowling## A spate of wides## and some sensible batting by Bradenham's No 9 and 10 saw them home in an exciting finish## with three balls to spare.

So## another match ##from which we should at very worst emerged with a winning draw## cost us valuable points which might well be vital towards the end of the season when we have to face some of the stronger teams.

Sunshine and no puddles at Balllinger. This is a first for this season. This was also the 2s first match for 4 weeks following two games rained off and a blank week.

Skipper Kerry was quietly content with the hand dealt to him by his selection supremo even if there were only 2 players over 18. It looked a reasonably balanced side so when he lost the toss again and was asked to bat he wasn't too concerned.

The pitch looked another belter especially as it had had it's final preperation that morning from the groundsman's latest recruit.

Max and Monty opened up against some wayward Bradenham bowling and it was difficult to see where the boys were going to score their runs. Eventually Monty reached too far forward and offered some gentle catching practice## Bastie arrived at the crease in a flurry of gloves pads and whirling bats## but his late arrival meant he hadn't been watching and he'd missed that the ball was keeping very low. This meant he missed the first straight ball and was on the way back to the pavilion. Max finally managed to reach one of the endless leg side wides and hit it straight to the fielder## Paul Branigan played on to another shooter## Ben Dugdale was caught brilliantly at point## Jake Cutter got an interesting LBW decision## Dom Brown has gone off injured having been hit by a line drive from the skipper whilst at the non-strikers end ( he didn't get much sympathy)the Skipper fell to another good catch at extra cover##and the innings is in disarray.

Then the cavalry arrived in the form of Will Reid(61) and Will Arnold ( 12). These two put on 60 using a mixture of judicious shot selection## some interesting running between the wickets and some good## old fashioned## slogging. Eventually Will A got run out but he was replaced by Dom Brown( 72*) who was detremined to make up for lost time. He and Will R added another 56 before Will was caught and then Josh Badrick (11)helped Dom add another 49 to take the Waggoners to the unbelivable heights of 219 - 9 off 42 overs at which point the skipper declared - Disbelief alround.

After a fantastic tea form Fiona Brown the Waggoners took to the field with great purpose. Will Reid opened up and bowled a tidy first over. Josh then had to bowl at the visitors skipper. This gentleman came in at 7 when we played them away so we felt that they weren't going to be that strong. Unfortunately kerry had forgotten what yhe did to us that day which was basically to smash the ball out of the ground at every opportunity. Opening the batting didn't cramp his style in any way and he proceeded to plant Josh into the car-park on a regular basis.

Bradenham were cruising. The introduction of debutant Will Arnold had the immediate effect of slowing things down and so did Ben Dugdale from the other end and Ben struck immediately having the skipper caught 2nd ball. Finally the Waggoners had a measure of control but a couple of dropped chances and some interesting wide calling meant they couldn't get the visitors far enough behind the run rate to try and buy a wicket. Ben produced a brilliant bit of fileding to run out the other opener but now they introduced a batter whose favourite shot was the chinese cut. This game was going to the wire.

Ben took a really good catch off Dom Brown## Will Arnold was now bowling really tightly and the pressure was mounting on both teams. Finally Will A got his reward when the Bradenham danger man hit a catch to the skipper who## even at his age## would have been upset to drop.

Now the charge was on for the Waggoners## could they get the last few wickets before overs or runs ran out. It was close with Will taking 3 wickets in an over but there just wasn't quite enough left for either side to grab the win.

A really enjoyable## exciting game and some points on the board at last. The skipper could hear some mutterings from the crowd about the declaration but his timing was perfect.

Great fun - well played everyone.
Yet another victim of the "summer"

Revenge is sweet. So thought Holmer Green## smarting no doubt from their remarkable debacle earlier in the season## and facing once again their destroyer on that occasion## Max Maciver. But in truth## this match deserved to be billed as The Men (HG) versus The Boys (BWCC)## such was the composition of the Ballinger side## probably the youngest ever to have represented the Firsts.

Losing the toss condemned them to a hot afternoon (what a rarity) in the field against the league leaders## but the opening attack of Hamish Sim and Evan Webster started well and contained the powerful HG openers K King and M Watt. However## it was Jack Hankinson who drew first blood## when Ian Davies scooped up a superb diving catch at slip to dismiss King## with the total on 69## and 15 overs gone. Unfortunately that brought to the crease a hitherto unknown (to Ballinger) batsman## by name Hiram Shallow## known to his team mates as Piggy## a dreadlocked Carribbean## who proceeded to scatter the bowling and the fielders to all parts of the field in compiling a violently struck 82 off 16 overs. He and Watt (61) had added 92 for the second wicket before he became Hamish's well deserved victim## thanks to an absolutely blinding catch by Xavier Owen## who shortly afterwards repeated the act in at last getting rid of Watt## who had been badly dropped much earlier. The frenetic pace then quietened down## but only one more wicket fell as HG cruised comfortably to 238 for 4 before declaring with 40 overs gone.

50 overs to score to 239 on a good wicket would probably have seriously taxed a full-strength BWCC line-up## but with Joe Hankinson having injured himself in the field## this batting order looked unlikely to cope for long with the best bowling attack in the league. Hope really rested on openers Max Maciver and Andy Thompson## but all too soon Andy was back in the hutch after unluckily playing on## defending a lifting delivery from the pacy D Little. Ian Davies## whose batting form this year (what little we have seen of him ) could reasonably be described as disastrous## then decided that attack was the best policy## and got the scoreboard moving with some risky boundaries## before settling down to watchful defence. Max mis-hooked## dollied a catch## and departed for 18## with the total on 51## whereupon Xavier Owen joined Ian## and was soon playing confidently## in a watchful but authoritative innings. Ian was## unexpectedly## bowled for a well made 41## with the total on 80## and with his departure any real hope of winning became remote## so it was a question of whether the remaining batsmen had the guts to stick in there for a draw. Fortunately Monty Thompson was intent on showing his father that the famed Thompson cussedness was alive and well## and proceeded to defy the bowling for exactly an hour in making an invaluable 14. Xavier also exceeded an hour at the crease for his excellent 24## and thereafter runs became academic as HG crowded the batsmen## using their full range of fast bowlers to intimidate "our boys". Evan Webster## not for the first time## was resolute## but with two overs left and the last pair (both Hankinsons) at the wicket## the tension was such that few of the many spectators could tear themselves away to watch the Olympics in the bar.

And so the draw was achieved## and high praise is due to the tenacity and application of those responsible - one wonders if some of Ballinger's absent senior players would have been so steadfast in the circumstances.
This is becoming a bit tedious. When we finally get the right weather## a proper team and first use of a lovely strip the opposition cant get a side out. Hopeless

The weather forecast was dire##but at least this match got under way. Ian Maciver ## leading a very inexperienced young Ballinger side## won the toss and invited Cadmore End to bat first. Some excellent bowling by Alex Howe rendered the Cadmore openers almost strokeless## and in his opening 7 overs spell## 5 were maidens## at a cost of 3 runs and one wicket## courtesy of a superb diving catch by Max Maciver## who repeated the performance with another fine effort## this time in the slips## off Will Reid## who also bowled extremely well. Rain interrupted proceedings twice## meanwhile Max bowled a mean spell of 12 overs## 5 of them maidens## taking 2 for 21. Cadmore End had subsided to 39 for 6 in the 22nd over before some late-order aggression saw them reach 111 for 9 in 38 overs## before the heavens opened to the accompaniment of thunder and lightning. The wicket was soon awash## tea was taken## but with the rain still falling steadily## play was abandoned at 4.30.

A ver disappointing way to end a game which Ballinger stood a good chance of winning## and which yet again showed how well served the Club is by its young cricketers## who bowled and fielded excellently.

It was a beautiful day and the skipper had arrived early at The Lee's pretty ground. It was a tranquil scene but both captains had troubled looks. Sure enough when the toss was made both had to reveal they were a player short. Game on

 

As usual Kerry lost the toss and his motley crew## shorn by the 1s of 4 of its compliment## were asked to bat. Now on some grounds this is a problem but not here. 

 

Boosted by the return of Derek Richards## and with an unusual quota of adults in the side## the skipper was confident of a big score. Derek and Max Dugdale were looking confident against The Lee's opening attack but it wasn't long before the experience of big John Humpries was too much for Max. Daren Samat fresh from his summer break also look at odds against this seasoned pro and went quickly but## new boy McCloughlan wasn't to be intimidated and soon took the attack to the home side. Derek fell for a well crafted 22 and he was pleased to be back and so were we.

 

Losing studs as fast as he was scoring runs## Ian changed the pace of the game. When he lost his mentor## Paul Branigan## he realised that he was going to be batting with the skipper. What he didn't know was that Kerry and Humphries had spent the last 20 years trying to get the better of each other and there was no way that the Ballinger captain was going to get out to his rival. Therefore spent the next couple of overs batting from the other end.

 

 

Timing is the most important thing in captaincy and coming in to bat when the openers are just about to finish is a perfect example. Kerry took advantage of the generosity of the change bowlers## as did Ian## to help move the score along until a rush of blood from Ian and an interesting lbw decision for Nigel meant we needed the tail end to wag a bit and another debutant Charlie Barker## Tom Petrie and Josh Badrick helped get the score up to 174.

 

As always we were treated to a delightful tea over which there was much discussion about teams scratching.

 

The problem for the Waggoners was could they defend 174 on such a good wicket.

 

Josh Badrick and Dom Brown opened up for the visitors but it was quickly evident that Josh's pace was going to be used against him by the wiley old pros opening for The Lee. Tom Petrie gave the skipper a bit more control but the introduction of Ian M completely changed the game.  

 

Dom Brown had removed one opener with a "jaffa"## Tom the number 3 but from then on it was the Ian McCloughlan show. Backed up by some smart fielding from Charlie Barker and the skipper## table topping The Lee were bundled out for just 139.

 

It always helps if one of your opponents has to leave early for work## for which I have paid my dues in the applicable pub## but this was a good performance by the side.

 

In a season disrupted by the weather and teams scratching it was great to be involved in a proper game of cricket.

Another frustrating day at the office.

Plus sides for the 2s were the return of Reece Tiley## Freddie T's wicket keeping## Tom P's bowling and Toby Lyons' fielding.

Gordon and Rob Farqhuar can bowl and Ian McClaughlan needs new boots. Phil White will be stiff tomorrow and the skipper won't be doing teas again in a hurry.

Well done the umpires

Ballinger U12A v Chesham U12

Friendly

28 August 2012

Won by 6 wickets

A good win and a pleasing end to the season.  Chesham chose to bat but made heavy weather of it## at 9 for 2 after 4 overs## against accurate bowling from openers Ollie Hardman (1 for 5) and Fin Clark.  In the middle of the innings## spin from Taylor Levitt (1 for 7)## Jamie Fulcher (0 for 4) and Joe Turrell (1 for 7) kept up the pressure and runs remained hard to come by with Chesham passing 50 only after 13 overs.  Skipper Tom Petrie set some intelligent fields and managed to keep Chesham’s stronger batsmen off strike.  Keeper for the day Freddie Thompson stood up to all but Fin and so kept the Chesham batters in the crease## restricting their strokeplay.   Tom (2 for 5) came on himself at the end and with Max Leane gave away only 15 runs off the last 5 overs.  There was some rustiness in the bowling and fielding## but it was basically a very strong performance## which successfully strangled the Chesham batting.  Fin was the pick of the bowlers with 1 for 11 from his 4 overs and some genuinely hostile pace and bounce – including one very sharp and well-directed bouncer.  I suspect Fin may become a bit of a handful for batters as he grows older.    

74 to win was not challenging and Louis Prideaux and Angus Denison-Smith laid the foundations with an opening stand of 28 off 6.4 overs## playing each ball on its merit and thus sensibly mixing defence and attack.  Freddie and Tom carried on the good work## Tom hitting a waist high full toss for a huge 6 into the side of my car!  Victory came from the 1st ball of the nineteenth over but had not been in doubt for most of the innings.  Well done!   I am already looking forward to having a very strong squad which can play some entertaining and muscular cricket next year ….

Andy

From the Ballinger perspective the best feature of this## the last league game of the season## was the weather - glorious sunshine. Very ironic## after a record six matches washed away (a third of our fixtures) - the worst for any club in the division. As for the cricket## it would be good to report that Ballinger finished in fine form. Alas## they didn't!

Ten man Monks Risborough won the toss and took first knock. Their progress was steady## but Nick Adams## back from his hols## nicked a couple of wickets. However## a 65 run stand for the third wicket saw the bowlers taking increasing punishment## and although Max Maciver took three wickets the run rate kept accelerating. Maciver senior tidied things up towards the end## but by the time Monks ran out of batsmen they had 166 on the board## in only 37 overs## leaving BWCC 53 overs in which to win.

Andy Thompson and Richard O'Kelly negotiated the 8 overs before tea with supreme and almost Riley-esque care## so all looked a safe bet for a successful resumption## and so it proved as they calmly took the score up to 55## against a hostile## if occasionally wide-of-the wicket## attack. Then Andy was bowled## but no worries## surely## with our quality top-order batting line up? Wrong.... Max Maciver and Will Smith survived three balls between them## and the clatter of wickets must surely have been heard as far away as Bellingdon where the Two's were playing. 55-0 became 67-4## and worse was to come as the dependable O'Kelly was triggered in debatable circumstances (but no complaints## really## as Ballinger didn't even have an umpire for the match). Monty Thompson then characteristically managed to hang around for 22 balls in making a defiant 2## and Ian Maciver did what he could to save the sinking ship with an excellent 23 not out## but the innings died a slow and painful death on 109## in the 45th over. Significantly## the highest scorer was extras## with 27!!

"Naturally we would have easily won all the 6 cancelled matches## especially as they were mostly against theweaker teams##so our rather iffy final league position is of course highly misleading" (Probable extract from the Captain's report for the Season ??)

A plea to those carryinginjuries - we need you fit and well for next year## so please book your surgeons nice and early. And to those whose appearances have been rather sporadic## please use you holiday entitlements up in search of winter sun.

On a lovely afternoon for cricket Ballinger entertained Missenden Misfits in a game that really lived up to its pretty match billing. A tense and epic contest went to the wire as the away side just scrapped home after Ballinger had looked to have wrestled back the imitative after the Misfits had dominated the opening stages of the match.

 

With the sun out and pitch looking excellent## Ballinger won the toss and chose to have a bat on what looked like a peach of a strip. Opening up for the home side was Jamie (5) and Nick (21) who saw off the opening Missenden bowlers with consummate ease as Nick especially looking at home spraying the ball to the boundary at regular intervals. Unfortunately Jamie played at one to many and got caught. Enter financial wonder kid Fally (13) who also looked in good touch## although he missed a straight one just as he looked set to get the scoreboard going. Paul (23) and Tom (17) both added valuable contributions although both can be guilty of not cashing in when they both made decent starts. Thanks to some lower order hitting from Jono (22) and steady support from Stu (12) Ballinger made there way to 177AO at tea which one had to admit looked to be an average score at best## although what was to come may or may not disprove this!

 

After an exceptional teas from the Cutter’s## Ballinger set about there task of removing 10 Missenden batsmen and thus winning the game. Easy. Well## easy it was not. Following Monty Thompson’s rather controversial run out earlier in the afternoon there was a bit of bite out there in the Ballinger cauldron as Hamish and Jono tour in to bowl against the unfortunate Missenden. Fortunately for the away side the openers held off this initial outburst gradually looked more and more comfortable with Tossell in particular scoring exclusively in boundaries. When he was bowled for 28 Missenden’s Lyne and Partridge knuckled down and efficiently began metaphorically chipping away at the target. As Missenden slowly but surely eased there way to the target## Partridge was given out LBW and Ballinger had a sniff. This became more than sniff as Stu and Paul blew away the Missenden middle order making then look very much like Misfits. And so as the game went into the final over## Missenden were 7 down needed only 6 runs. The best Ballinger could do was to claim an honourable draw or even a tie and this looked like becoming reality as the home side really tightened the screw on Missenden restricting them to only 2 runs off the first 5 balls. Unfortunately the last ball of the match however was dispatched to the boundary by the unlikely figure of Lloyd and Missenden had won an excellent match by 3 wickets off the last ball.

 

So yes we lost but this match was what Sunday cricket was all about! A nice day## god opposition## a close finish all in time to retire to the pub! Long may it continue!

After walking through the wedding party and hacking their way through the knee high outfield to the Bellingdon  pavilion## the seconds spent the first 15 minutes getting used to the unusual yellowy orange ball in the sky. The die was cast when the stand in skipper won the toss and chose to bat on what always looked a low scoring wicket. 

Fresh from his big score last Sunday Max set about the Ley Hill opening attack but soon lost opening partner Tom Mac before perishing himself bringing together what was the mainstay of the Ballinger innings Rob Mac and Iain. They gradually batted us back into the match before Iain fell to the wily Peterson for 18. Ben and the skipper barely troubled the scorer before returning to the hutch. This brought Steve – back from his 7 week mini break holiday - to the wicket and he helped steady the ship. For some strange reason Rob Mac was applauded for reaching 49 and took that as his cue to depart forthwith. Solid performances from the lower order in particular Freddie helped us accumulate  138 off 43.2 overs## leaving Josh left high and dry for another not out. The score looked reasonable if maybe a few short of a par score.

Will and Dom opened the Ballinger attack and by the time they had finished their spells it was clear that Ley Hill were going to struggle to get anywhere near our total as their combined 11 overs cost a mere 16 runs and they had removed both openers – Will clean bowling Walter and then catching Jones at point. Josh then claimed another wicket courtesy of a catch from Ben whilst Freddie was turning the ball sideways from the Wedding Party end. When he removed Peterson due to a replica catch by Will## Ley Hill were 55-4 off 25 overs with little or no chance of winning the game and it became a question of trying to winkle them out. The skipper brought back the opening  bowlers and Will claimed three more wickets ## a superb slip catch from Steve and two from Iain at shortish mid off – one of which he juggled with like a first night waiter kept us in the hunt. Several difficult chances went begging that might have sealed the game but Ley Hill held on for a losing draw at 101-7

A very satisfactory end to what has been a very damp and disappointing season. Lets hope for better weather next year !

Ballinger won by 9 wkts with 11 overs to spare. An emphatic win. Not really a contest. On a very good## fast track## Ballinger openers Cooke and Livingstone generated good pace and took a wicket apiece. Then Thompson’s legspin took 4 wickets for 3 runs in 2 overs## and at 37 for 6 it was pretty much game over. Leane’s and Fennel’s accurate medium pace reduced Marlow to 49 for 8## a wicket each. A 9th wicket partnership of 23 saw Marlow inch towards respectability but then Turrell took 2 wickets for 1 run in 7 balls and finished the innings off. The fielding was generally pretty good## with 2 diving low catches for Thompson. Turrell opened with Denison-Smith## putting on 34 together## before Denison-Smith was caught for 12## setting the stage for Levitt to come in and hit 26 not out off 10 balls## combining brutish wallops with some very well-timed cricket shots. Turrell finished with a classy 24 not out at a run a ball. A very convincing win. They will not all be that easy!

Starting the season against league favourites High Wycombe was always going to be a challenge## especially with many players missing. The visitors  put on an impressive 178 with a strong batting performance. Hamish and Dom were best able to curtail the runs against the top batsmen.  Will and George bowled pretty well at times. However much our bowling was erratic and there were too many wides - our bowlers need to try and stay calm and develop tactics against very attacking batsmen. Ballinger's reply started with some resolute defense by Hamish and Matt against some fast bowling## plus useful knocks by Greg and Tom. Hamish played an excellent captain's innings for 48 batting through until the 17th over. That over was devastating with a team hatrick for the opponents against some mystifying left arm spin in pretty bad light. It was nearly dark by the time our innings closed on 105-7. As ever Ballinger played with good spirit and there were several good performances## including some U13s## all against a very strong team.

BWCC  94-3   HWCC  60 all out

A complete team effort; Will's grandfather umpiring (thank you Keith) and an assortment of helpers setting up this match (thank you Andy T## Bee and Sally)## we were able to get our first league match of the season underway. 

Shrugging of a short heavy shower## and finishing in virtual darkness## the boys achieved a resounding early season league victory.  

The opening pair of Philip and Harry established a very strong foundation to the innings## which Theo took on handsomely## batting with great aplomb. Running at nearly six runs per over for the first half of the innnings## we thought we might be a little low when we finished at 94.

However## the opening pair of Will and Harry immediately put High Wycombe on the back foot. The rain came and the light began to fade## and the opposition did not look up for the challenge against some good accurate bowling and some energetic fielding. In fact## the pressure was not let off at all## and the whole team should be commended. Marcus## Philip## Luke and Nik waded in with some wickets. There were also some really important tight accurate overs from Ben Tomlin## Harvey Wilson and Tom Vicary. To allow only one of their batsmen get into double figures was very telling. 

Huge thank you to Harvey## Nik## Harry## Theo## Tom and Ben for playing up an age group. 

All told## we were all very proud of your efforts boys. Well done.

The 2s first fixture under the new rules was always going to be interesting.

Skipper Kerry got off to a good start by wining the toss. What to do? As usual he chose to field first.

A useful opening attack of Will Reid and Hamish Sim appeared to be keeping the Lacey Green openers quiet but## although the wicket was playing much better than it looked it had an odd slope to it## which meant the bowlers were struggling to keep the right line. Therefore the Green were being helped by a few extras.

Will struck first with a "jaffa" and then Sam Peters took his first wicket in senior cricket## thanks to a juggling catch at slip by Steve Conway. Dom Brown then got in on the act  and suddenly The Green were 69 -3. Craker then joined opener Janes to put on nearly 80 in just 7 overs. This was achieved with any interesting array of shots. Not many you'd find in any coaching manual. Craker was finaly run out by Ben Dugdale who was also now bowling. There was some debate as to whether this was Ben's worst spell of bowling but somehow## as always## he contrived to take 4 wickets. One thanks to a briliant catch by Will. The skipper wasn't complaining.

Will took 2 more wickets including the opener Janes and The Green had been bowled out in just 35 overs.

The standard of the Wagoners fielding was excellent with particular praise going to Oliie Cooksey who was outstanding.

The father and son combination of Tom and Peter Petrie opened up for Ballinger and were ticking along nicely before Tom missed a straight one. Hamish joined Peter determined to show there's more to his game than just a fast bowler. He did this very well in an excellent stand of 52 before holing out to a good catch in the deep.

Steve came and went followed by Peter and it looked all down hill for the Wagoners. Then that boy Cooksie joined the fray and in combination with James Fray## Dom Brown(21)## Sam and Will added another 84 runs taking us to 156 before being bowled with just 4 bals left. It was great to watch.

With the draw now out of the equation Balinger were looking for as many bonus points as possible and Ollie kept ticking them off. We ended up with 14 bonus points only 6 behind the maximum for the winners. 

An enjoyable afternoon spoilt by Lacey Greens insistance that we didnt have a scorer## although Miles was producing yet another master peice from the middle## deducting us a point and making us pay £5 for the privilege. Hey ho

“Ballinger came a very clear second in this opening contest of the League season.  169 was not enough batting first on another very true Ballinger wicket (a credit to groundsman J Kellock as ever); and Monks Risborough knocked them off with 16 overs and 9 wickets to spare.   They had some luck and were a little flattered by those stats## but not much.  After the early loss of in-form O’Kelly## McIntyre (63)## assisted by Thompson and then Davies## put Ballinger into a decent position after 20 overs## but with those 3 out## the middle order collapsed.  Maciver## assisted by new-addition Adeel Iqbal##  guided Ballinger to respectability## but no more.  Monks set off as if chasing 270 not 170## and it was only spinners Maciver and Davies who restored some control## but all too little## too late.  Some catches went down at the end## when it really was all over## which added to the general impression of disarray.  Some “big guns” being available next week should help on the batting front## but in the field we need to get more of the basics right – line and length and taking our catches.  Much room for improvement ...... “

The curtain raiser to the BWCC 2013 season saw 11 prime athletes pitch up at Aldenham CC on a cold## dark and windy afternoon. Ballinger won the toss and opted to field (Skipper Davies openly admitting his decision was based purely on not wanting to field at 7pm when even colder and darker!).

Adams and Brown opened the bowling and produced a fine display of seam bowling with Brown taking a wicket and Adams two during a controlled spell that blunted the Aldenham top order attack. At 40 for 3 Ballinger were on top and looking good to restrict the total. New recruits Sandip Das and Adeel Iqbal bowled shortly after and produced tidy spells to further control the run rate - both players have been out of the game of late but encouragingly produced performances that will yield wickets in weeks to come. The Aldenham middle order rallied in the middle of the inning and C. Munroe scored a controlled 61 to take the score past the hundred mark however Ballinger spinners## Maciver## Davies and Dugdale soon turned the screw and bowled Aldenham out for 145 just before tea. Davies taking 3-15 as the pick of the bowlers.

In reply R. O'Kelly came up with a patient and controlled innings to lead Ballinger to victory - his 69 runs resulting in a match winning performance. O'Kelly was ably supported by Adeel who scored 28 and contributions from the rest of the lower order saw Ballinger home with plenty of time and 3 wickets to spare.

1 from 1 - a great start to the season but lets hope the weather improves !

At the last minute and after some kind of vaguely team democratic process## Michael stepped up to the leadership position and duly lost the toss.

Ley Hill elected to bat and started strongly getting to 49 after 8 overs and we started thinking good score coming up! In the next few overs we took 4 wickets with only a few runs added to their score. With some very impressive bowling we held them back in the last 12 overs to 23 runs for them to reach a target of 72. Very smart team fielding## and field positioning by Michael Everett.

Our innings started with a heart-stopping wobble as we lost three early wickets in the first four overs for 20 runs. Then James Bunce put his head down and## joined by Henry King## they put on a sterling match winning partnership to see us finish off with 73 for the loss of 3.

If I was to pick a man of the match it would have been a three way draw with James top scoring on 29 (n.o.)## Henry King 23 (n.o.) and Ben Westland with fantastic figures of 3 wickets for 3 runs in 3 overs and 0 maidens.

An impressive start to the season.

Regards
Dave

P.S. don't be getting any ideas about Buncy and Henry!!!

Against Kingshill's A## this was always going to be a tough fixture and the 44 runs they put on after the only 4 overs gave us a flavour of how difficult it would be.  The Kingshill openner is county standard and was able to use the predictable bounce of the astro to smash fours off the best of balls.  Harry Doyle was the outstanding bowler with figures of 3 for 17 of 4 overs## a superb caught and bowled and another good pressure catch.   Even after the openners had retired## it was clear that Kingshill had depth. However## Ballinger never let their heads drop## remained focused and in general the fielding was energetic and accurate.  Kingshill reached 91 for 2 off the first 10 overs and had 200 in their sights.  However## they found run scoring tougher in the second 10 overs; with everyone continuting to the bowling; James Arnold's spell of 1 for 11 was useful contribution.

Harry and Marcus started sensibly and both looked solid against some fast and accurate bowling.  They saw off the openners and started to relax and play their strokes when Harry fell for 9.  Will and Marcus continued the resistance but Will was bowled with a beauty and Marcus fairly shortly afterwards trying to push on with the score## top scoring on 11.  The middle order and tail never really fired and Ballinger collapsed to a total of 42.  I was not unhappy with any of the dismissals; they were all generally out to good and fast bowling - playing sensible shots.  This was an A team that was just too good against our mix of U13s and U12s.

You always know that it's going to be a cold day in the field at Ballinger when the scorers move inside the pavilion. As this happened in about the third over of the day we all knew we were in for a miserable day.

The skipper won the toss again but was confused by the team sheet which had the names of 6## yes I repeat 6 adults on it. Now in uncharted waters he took the safe option## as always## and offered the visitors first dance on a new strip. Again something the 2s didn't recognise.

Ballingers opening bowlers Rob Farquhar and Dom Brown did a reasonable job of keeping the openers down to 50 by the end of their spells. It was difficult to know what was going to be a decent score as the pitch## for obvious reasons## was a bit slow but the outfield was very fast.

Ballingers luckiest cricketer(BLC)## Ian McCloughlin## then took over from Rob and struck mmediatley with an unplayable long hop which was hit straight to the fielder for a gentle catch. He then had the Hill skiper caught off the back of his bat and then persuaded the umpire that his third victim was plumb. With Gordon Farquhar now nipping in with help from a good catch by Rob McIntyre## the Waggoners had reduced Ley Hill to 105 - 7.

Matt O'Kelly( 1-24) was now doing a sterling job bowling into the wind but It has been the failing of the home side for a couple of years that once we get the opposition down we can't seem to finish them off. This time we let an experienced campaigner Ivan Veal settle in and then take the Hill score along to 176 before we finished them off(Petrie 2-9) for 180 in 37 overs.   

After an excellent tea there was a certain reluctance from all parties to leave the warmth of the pavilion but finally the opposition and Ballingers openers were pushed out into the elements.

Tom Petrie and BLC opened up for the home side and Tom was soon showing us what a class act he is adding 69 with BLC before departing for 23. Unfortuantely for the Hill BLC(51) was continuing on his merry way. Rob McIntuyre perished for a rapid 12##new man Kris McKenzie batted as though he hadnt played for 20 years## then disaster struck. A lucky twisting of Dave Peterson's ankle meant that he was taken off and Dastardy Dennis Mcarthy(6-18) was brought on. Chaos in the Ballinger camp. a Comfortable 98-3 became a very unpromising 101 -7.

Skipper Kerry(34) and Matt O'Kelly(18) settled the ship and slowly inched the Waggoners closer and closer to the target. Unfortunately a couple of good overs from the visitors meant that with 2 overs to go 16 were required. A wild swipe from Kerry ended his chance for glory. Rob Farquhar and Matt added another 4 before Matt was caught. A big hit from Rob meant the target was down to 7 with 3 balls to go. A dot ball and then Matt## acting as a runner for the injured Gordon Farquhar## was run out. 

 

A really enjoyable game despite the weather

After their humiliation the previous week## Ballinger badly needed redemption away at Cadmore End. The weather forecast was unfavourable## and there were showers just before play was due to start. A lost toss saw openers Matt Riley(welcome back!) and Andy Thompson having to bat carefully on a pitch that saw the ball both lifting and swinging.. Andy perished rapidly## as did his replacement## skipper Ian Davies. 15 for 2 and Cadmore End well on top. The rot was firmly stopped by the unhurried Riley and the aggressive Carlton Siddle## also making his first appearance of the season. Cadmore End's skipper switched his bowlers around at great speed## but to no avail## as the runs mounted.The 50 partnership had just been reached when Carlton departed## caught## for an invaluable 31. Rollo (who had eventually located the ground after a mega-tour of the Chilterns) came in## hit a 6 into the (very) nearby graveyard## and by the time play resumed after a lengthy search for the ball## his concentration was sufficiently affected for him to misjudge the next ball## and offer a tame catch. 91 for 4## and 24 overs already gone. Next in was young Hamish Sim## who played himself in carefully## displaying some immaculate defensive strokes. This added to the pressure on Matt to keep the scoreboard moving## and he responded in fine style. Hamish sacrificed his wicket to a run out## having batted well## then in came Jono Lacey for his first knock since last "summer". With Matt now attacking the bowling with even more violence## and Jono occasionally connecting with impressive effect## the score had reached 174 when Jono fell to a catch off the last ball of the allotted 40 overs## but not before the drama of seeing whether Matt could reach a well-deserved ton.He could have been caught off the penultimate ball of the over## but the chance was spilled on the boundary## and he could only manage a single to end on a tantalising 99 not out. A superlative and finely judged innings.

Cadmore End in reply got off to the worst of starts## losing their opener to the very first ball of the innings## bowled by Nick Adams## who was soon revelling in a pitch that was very different from the Ballinger track that had seen their bowlers suffer so badly the week before. With Hamish bowling fast from the other end## the batsmen had few answers until their number five hit a quick-fire 18## comprising three sixes off Hamish ##who had the last laugh## getting him caught off the final ball of his spell. Nick signed off with a masterly analysis of 5 for 20 (thanks Nick## we enjoyed the jug!!)##then Ian Maciver supplied the coup de grace as Cadmore End reeled to defeat in the 24th over for a wretched total of 64 all out.

Well played Ballinger## just the way to bounce back.

BWCC 257 20 overs

CSGCC 241 20 overs

 

Orlando (C) won the toss and elected to put Chalfont into bat.The first wickets fell in the 4th and 5th overs## with some spectacular bowling from Oliver Webb (2 wkts) and David Steinhauer (2wkts).

When not bowling all the boys worked the field to keep the opposition run rate to a minimum. The bowlers were again rewarded with more wickets in the 11th and 12th overs bowled by Harvey and Jamie respectively.  Orlando took the last wicket of the innings in the 15th over. 

After a brief interlude and some furious crisp and cake consumption the boys retook the field.

Archie and Orlando opened the batting and started the innings## followed by Tim and Jamie who managed to get the first fours on the scoreboard.  A solid performance from the middle order## including another couple of fours from Ben and David## left the result looking like a formality.  However## a late display of form from the Chalfont bowlers meant there was all to play for in the last few overs.

Tom and Oliver suffered a couple of early wickets in their pairing but remained poised and focused on ramping up the run rate to give the Waggoners their win.

A big thank you to all the parents who turned their boys out on Sunday morning but particularly to Megan for providing a much appreciated match tea and to Ian for his scoring prowess.

Match Report

 

Ballinger’s U14 traveled to a bleak Beaconsfield on Wednesday for their first league game of the season.

Beaconsfield won the toss and inserted the visitors. Ollie Fretton and Gethin Ross opened up for the Waggoenrs and had obviously been feeding on a raw diet of IPL as they flayed around at anything in their half of the pitch This led to some interesting shot selection and execution.

The fun didn’t last for long with Ollie departing with the score on 11. Rob Farquhar followed without troubling the scorer, Gethin shortly after and at 14-3 the Wagoners were in trouble.

Skipper Will Arnold(38) and  Scott Bunce(23) now steadied  the ship and slowly but surely built a stand of 54 before Scott was run out, Harry McMullan and James Bunce came and went but both helped the skipper add valuable runs. Michael Everett(9) helped Will add another 19 before he then  Harri Doyle and finally Will perished in the chase for a few more runs.

97 looked below par on a decent pitch but the weather was, by this time, foul and the outfield getting slower

Will and Rob started well for the Waggoners  with Will in particular  bowling  with pace and accuracy but it was  the introduction of Scott that started to give Ballinger some hope. He bowled 4 overs of high quality seam bowling fully deserving his 2-10. He was helped by a very good catch by Gethin behind the stumps.

Will now had the difficult task of getting enough overs out of the rest of the team to try and keep Beaconsfield under control. Harry McMullan took his first wicket, likewise James Bunce and Harri  bowled well to but, the Beaconsfield batters had just enough savvy to win the game. Getting over the line with just 3 balls to spare.

It was a great effort by the Ballinger boys.  The U14 “squad” is now down to just 7 players if all available so we’re going to need lots of help from the U13s and U12s and if those who come in do as well as those who played last night everything will be fine

Having spent the day at Lords watching a fairly dismal England performance## it was a relief to be back in Ballinger and seeing a team on top of their game!  This was a comprehensive victory against a reasonably high quality competition. 

Batting first## we had an initial wobble with Marcus out 3rd ball.  Kit and Angus seemed to steady the innings but after reaching the boundary with a cracking shot## the Capitain (Kit) was also soon  back into the pavillion.  Rory and Angus then pushed the score along quite quickly with some smart running between the wickets until Rory tried to lift a straight one over the memorial hall and was clean bowled on 9.  Angus retired on 31 and the middle order took up the baton well - pushing the score along with Michael (9)## Ollie (8 n.o.)and Henry (5 n.o..) all scoring well with some decent stroke play; Ben added a typically cameo cracking 4 before holing out to mid off.  100 seemed like a decent score.

Hawridge set off at a terrific pace in reply - 8 off the first over## at 13 of the second## they were well in the chase.   However line & length and some excellent fielding won the day.  The wickets did not fall but the runs dried up.  From 13 off 2 overs## Hawridge were at 18 after 6 overs!   Between them Will (playing 2 years young)## James A## Ben## Sharky and Marcus had only 20 runs scored off their combined 14 overs.  Sharky looked particularly menacing## causing their top scorer some real difficulties and was unfortunate not to collect some scalps.  At the other end## Michael was doing a good job with the gloves## letting through just 6 byes and taking a sharp stumping which should have been given out if the umpire (me) had been watching.   Ballinger fielding was sharp and energetic; lots of positive and encouraging banter kept the spiritis up in artic conditions.  A very good and assured performance from Ballinger Bs - more of the same please against Chesham next week.  Thank you again to Tim for being 12th man and being an excellent addition to the fielding side.

Put in to bat by Waddesdon## Ballinger's openers Matt Riley and Richard O'Kelly## both in good form## were quickly into their stride## and with over a hundred on the board without loss## a sizeable total looked on the cards. But shortly after both completing excellent half centuries they departed## caught## and then the rot set in as wickets tumbled. As usual## Ian Maciver led the resistance## and was undefeated on 17## when the overs ran out## leaving Ballinger with a total of 162 for seven. Credit must be given to the Waddesdon change bowlers## who exerted an increasing stranglehold on the batsmen## and for their ground fielding - though certainly not for their catching## as a hat-full of chances went begging.

Following a superlative tea## the Waddesdon innings followed a remarkably similar path to Ballinger's. with their openers scoring freely. However## their opening stand amounted to only 50## before Ballinger got among the wickets## aided by some splendid catching. Notable were a fine one by Andy Thompson grasping a skyer that looked to be over his shoulder## and a vital one by Ian Davies who clung onto a stratospheric offering by Waddesdon's opener## who was threatening to take the game away from Ballinger. An easy win looked in prospect as Ian Maciver (3 for 14 in 10 overs) and Carlton Siddle were in control. However## an unexpected last wicket partnership developed## as Carlton's bowling was seized on## yielding a rapid succession of boundaries## and the Ballinger supporters began to doubt their men. Unjustifiably## as it turned out## as the bowlers wrapped up the innings## with Carlton taking 5 for 50## leaving Ballinger winners by 20 runs.

An excellent game## especially for the spirit in which it was played## by both teams.

On a very cold windy##  evening Chalfont St peter turned up wanting to play cricket. As a horizontal drizzle had started it was agreed to play 10 overs each. The Woggonetts batted first and posted 215## not a massive total to defend.

 

We fielded really well## kept the bowling tightand kept a constant flow of wickets. with Chalfont St peter needed 2 to win off the last ball the Waggonetts kept their nerve and in their first game in the league recorded a win.

Being put in to bat first we slowly accumulated runs and posted a score of 235. It was likely this was not going to be enough. In spite of valiantly playing on in the rain## the game had to be abandoned when the sky was lit up by lightening.

Short on the Ballinger line up by two players## Louis Barton (nine) stepped up to the mark to make his debut in the under twelve’s!

With ten players the game commenced with Ballinger in to bat.

First pair were Simon Carlin and Matthew Barton## who built up a respectable score of 45## Simon retiring at 33 runs.

With excellent performances by the remaining team members## Ballinger finished on 86 for 5 off 20. Great batting contributions from Hugo## Henry and James T## to name a few.

Following a motivational speech in the changing rooms by the Manager Dave C## the boys went into field## with the challenge firmly in mind. It was agreed that we really needed a score closer to 100 to feel safe. It was always going to be a close match as High Wycombe are always strong opponents.

Charlie Barraclough took the new role of wicket keeper## and did a great job.

Great bowling by Henry## James and Simon in particular## but some excellent batting on the part of the home side.

It was then## with failing light that the Wycombe Boys improved on the 86 runs with two overs to go.

Slippery ground## freezing temperatures (first time several of us have donned gloves in May!) and a shortage of players- Not a bad effort by the Waggoners.

This was never going to be an easy game for us.

The boys were up for it though and went into the match with a positive attitude. After electing to bat we made it to the 20th over and scored 76 runs. Our highest against Chesham A for some time.

Despite some good bowling## spirited fielding and the gods disrupting play for a heavy shower Chesham reached our target in 11 overs.

All round good team performance by the Waggoners## depsite the result.

Now that this game is out of the way we can concentrate on getting our winning streak back.

Good news- a full team and dry weather. Captained by James Bunce## Ballinger won the toss and opted to bat.

Marlow made it difficult with some excellent bowling and fielding. A notable display by “Buncie” who retired at 31 (1 six and 3  fours).  After 20 overs Ballinger were 73 for 7 and looking like a bit of a struggle ahead.

Marlow started shakily and with excellent bowling and fielding by Ballinger## kept the visitors on the back foot. Once again a great display of bowling by James Bunce with 3 for 3 off 2. Matt Barton took two wickets and a catch with further catches by Harry Doyle## Ben Tomlin## James Arnold and Louis Thomson (fantastic diving catch). Good wicket keeping again by Charlie Barraclough with two stumpings. Excellent fielding by the Ballinger team restricted Marlow to 32 all out after 13 overs.

First win of the season- well done lads!

Man of the Match- as an excellent captain## batsman and bowler on the day- James Bunce was voted the “Man of the Match”.

Ballinger U13 A v High Wycombe

21 May 2013

Lost by 12 runs.

A spirited performance from a depleted team (only completed when I confirmed my 11th man at 8 AM on the morning of the match) with everyone contributing and some very good individual performances. Well done.

HW batted first and Ballinger bowled and fielded very well to restrict them to 86 for 6## not a formidable total at all## on a good wicket and fast outfield. Ballinger opened with Harry Livingstone’s left arm swing and Freddie Thompson’s wrist spin and had HW 0 for 1 off 2 overs## new county player Moore caught and bowled Thompson. Harry bowed very well with good pace on a quick wicket – 4 overs for only 11 runs. He then took a really excellent running and diving catch in the deep to dismiss the other opener off Jamie Fulcher (bravely bowling with a damaged quad). But## despite some good pace from Fin Clark (including a well directed bouncer at the HW skipper) HW then built up a partnership until Sharky Iqbal safely took a catch off Thompson in his second spell putting HW at 55 for 3 off 14. Angus Denison-Smith ## bowling very tightly## bowled the new bat - 56 for 4. Ollie Hardman then carried on the good tight medium pace from the same end and picked up a wicket in the 17th over - 66 for 5. Michael Everett pouched a catch off Sharky in the next – 70 for 6 – but HW got away slightly in the last over to finish on 86.

New man## James Lewis## looked good but perished to an almighty swing which would have cleared the railway line had he connected! Livingstone and Taylor Levitt fell to some good quick inswing bowling## leaving Freddie Thompson## assisted by James Gill to build a response. Thompson holed out in the 9th over## leaving Ballinger at 32 for 4## still in touch but with more wickets down than we’d have liked. Watchful defence punctuated by lusty blows over mid-off took Jamie Fulcher into double figures## but he was then part of a steady loss of 3 more wickets; so that in the 15th over we were 44 for 7## needing another 43 to win. A tall order perhaps## but we had saved some of the best to last in the form of Fin Clark and Angus Denison-Smith## and the other side had bowled out all their best bowlers and had to resort to 2 weaker bowlers for the last 4 overs. Fin and Angus nearly did it for us## both picking the balls to hit and hitting them crisply. But both in the end went aerial once too often and picked the wrong fielders; and Ballinger’s late charge faltered at the last hurdle – all out 12 short with an over left.

But great credit to all those who turned out## despite illness## injury and exams## including some who have so far been playing for our B team and one new to the club. On that performance## we certainly have strength in depth. Man of the Match: Jamie Fulcher## for indomitable spirit in overcoming the most obstacles in order to play – exams## illness and injury all in one day.

We had an unusual  side as many U15/14/13 players were away. The visitors batted first and scored heavily.   We didn't bowl especially well with too many full tosses and wides## although Hamish was threatening and economical as ever. Chesham's batters took full advantage## especially on the side of the very short boundary## reaching 172-6. A few dropped catches didn't help curtail the runs or run-rate. When Ballinger batted it seemed more difficult## maintly due to more accurate bowling but also with the dazzling sun dipping down. Matt O'Kelly was the standout batsman with a very good 30## showing an array of orthodox shots all round the wicket. Everyone struggled to up the run rate and wickets kept falling at regular intervals as a consequence and we were all out for 81. Disappointing to lose so heavily## but hopefully a learning experience for those who don't always get a chance to bat or bowl and for James (U12) who got a chance to play.

Ballinger U13A v Gerrards Cross

23 May 2013-05-23

Won by 78 runs

An emphatic victory.  Ballinger started well and got better and never let GX into the game.  After the early loss of Taylor “Slugger” Levitt## Freddie Thompson was joined by U12 Henry King## and they put on a partnership of 57 off 34 balls## before Henry fell for a superb 28## including a 6 over extra cover off U13 County opening bowler## Hamish Smart.  Tom Petrie carried on the good work with Freddie until Freddie retired for 30 and Tom fell for a rapid 21 – 106 for 3 after 14.  Fin Clark (22 not out) with Harry Livingstone and then Angus Denison-Smith kept piling on the runs## leaving Ballinger on 141 for 5 off 20 overs.  A commanding total after some excellent attacking batting## and generally very good aggressive running between the wickets.
