Ballinger opened with Max Leane’s nippy seam bowling and Sharky Iqbal’s deceptive wrist-spin.  Max bowled one GX opener in the first over and Sharky the other in the second over## with an awesome googly## hitting the very top of off stump.  Max picked up the GX number 3 caught by keeper## Taylor Levitt## next over## leaving GX at 11 for 3 off 3 overs.  Sharky then bowled the number  4 and Max then got another - 26 for 5 after 7 overs.  And that was pretty much that.  The GX skipper then played aggressively for 30 retired## supported by his sister (county U15 girls## allowed to play in boys’ matches 2 years down under ECB rules)  until she was bowled by Angus Denison-Smith.  All too little too late.  James Bunce## another U12 playing up## bowled 2 very tidy overs and then in his third he wrapped up the innings with another catch behind for Taylor.  Game over.   Excellent catching and ground fielding## as usual from Ballinger.  Max Leane## best bowling figures – 3 for 14.  Man of the match:  Henry King for an excellent attacking innings playing a year up.  He might have had the “champagne moment” too for that 6; but that in fact goes to Sharky Iqbal (another U12) for that superb googly.  Well done everyone.

Andy

Our first match of the season hosting High Wycombe. The Captain Oliver Webb won the toss and put HW in to bat. Wickets were taken by Max Foden-Ellis##Oliver Webb##Max Conway and a 3 wicket haul by Rafi Weatherall. There was also some very tight bowling by Curan Biring## Louis Barton## assisted by sharp fielding from Ollie Norton##Casper Jack##Matthew Jones and Toby Rynn. The side kept HW pinned down for almost all of the 20 overs leaving a score of 227 to beat.

The opening pair of Oliver Webb and Max foden-Ellis put on a very solid 20 between them## the next best partnership came in the form of Rafi Weatherall and Max Conway who put on 13 between them. The rest of the batting side performed well against some mixed bowling## with excellent backing up throughout most of the game.

The team finished with a great score of 255## winning the match in some style with Rafi scoring 9 off the last over.

The scorecard really speaks for itself on this encounter. A great innings from Ian Davies## supported early on by Basty with his carefully constructed 21 allowing Ian to keep the score moving along at a reasonable rate. A youthful middle order collapse looked to endanger not only Ian's ton but the possibilty of posting a challenging target. Up stepped the captain for the day Ben Dugdale with 9 overs remaning and he looked to take on the bowling from the outset. A quickfire 40 and 75 run partnership with the irrepresable Ian took Ballinger to what looked like a competitive 200.

Bourne End took to the middle and Ben with inspired captaincy chose to open with Alex and Stuart## pace and spin. Alex keeping the batsmen under pressure at one end and Stuart rattling through their top order at the other. With relative inexperienced bowling options Bourne End managed to get a foothold in the game. Some erratic bowling and fielding gave the oposition momentum and belief that never looked likely. Back came Alex and Stuart to steady the ship but Bourne End were still in with a shout. A good spell of bowling by Ian complemented his masterful batting performance but it was left to the captain to bowl the last over with 13 runs required. Nerves held and victory was secured on a warm and sunny day.

Ballinger at its best.....everyone in the team bowled and contributed to a thoroughly convincing win. Thank you to Theo## Harvey## Max## Henry## Kyle and Will for playing up for the Under11s. You were all fantastic.

Philip## Theo and William (Captain) in particular## put on a very steady start with Harvey and Will Jones. I was thrilled to see how eager the rest of the squad were to get out for a bat. William spectacularly signed off with a six. An innings score of 84 looked like it might be a little low## but that was before we saw the fielding and bowling display. 

The team bounded onto the field## Philip and William giving good direction to their fielders. William## Philip and Will J then bowled some accurate overs picking up four wickets and putting Beaconsfield on the back foot at 26 for 3. Marcus then bowled accurately followed by Will Statham and Kyle who were representing the U11s for the first time. Will## Harvey## Kyle and Henry took over the bowling and supported the team effort fantastically. They all improved as their over went on## and will be brilliant next time they bowl (next overs). Charlotte delivered two good tight overs## and kept the pressure on the other team to score.

A brilliant run out from Marcus (at one stump) then broke a stubborn low scoring partnership. The opposition then found it really difficult to score of our attack## and all the bowlers should be proud of this. The last four overs saw some strong return bowling from Philip and William H## with four more wickets being taken## culminating in a fine last ball of the day delivery from Philip to take out the off stump.  

The real difference was made by some enthusiastic and accurate fielding. Catches were held and returns to the keeper were accurate## but Harvey's work in the big outfield was really impressive.

All in all## a really enjoyable game of cricket to watch and all of the boys should be very proud of their victory.

A sunny day at home ## Beaconsfield lost the toss and our Captain Oliver Webb chose to field. There were so many outstanding performances with excellent tight bowling throughout the match. With us only giving away 8 leg byes##1 bye## and 16 wides. We took 8 wickets compared to Beaconsfield taking only one of ours. Wickets taken by Oliver 3## Tom 2## and 1 each for Toby## Max Fe and Raphi. We kept Beaconsfield down to 246 runs.

Our batsmen started well and that continued throughout the entire innings## our pairs each put on the following Oliver and Max Fe 31## Louis and Freddie Bateson 16## Tim and Casper 34## Toby and Tom 11 and Raphi and Max C 31.  Our top individual scores were Oliver 15## Max C 13 and Raphi 12. The boys never looked back and never looked like losing the match in any of their overs ## leaving them with an outstanding score of 317 for only one wicket.

The fielding was outstanding with several close run outs and great work by the whole team especially Tim Hayes## Max Fe and Toby.

So another comprehensive win by Oliver and the boys##we have a break next weekend  and face Chesham on the 16th Away##

Sun## a light breeze .... it was almost warm. Longwick brought a strong## entirely adult## team## to face Ballinger’s blend of youth and experience; won the toss and decided to bat. George Cooke and Dom Brown took the new ball and an early wicket each## before George pulled up with a sore ankle (recovering from a bad sprain 10 days ago) after 2 overs. Skipper Andy Thompson and then James Fray took over from George## while Dom completed an excellent spell at the other end. But Longwick put together a powerful 3rd wicket partnership## assisted by a regular diet of full tosses from various Ballinger spinners. Offspinners Monty Thompson and Stuart MacGowan picked up a wicket each but Longwick were scoring too quickly. So skipper Andy Thompson came back and plugged up one end## ending up with 3 for 13 off 10 overs. Longwick could and should have declared as they passed 200 but chose to bat until 4.30 and 237 for 7 - too many to chase seriously in an hour and 20 overs## at more than 6.5 runs an over## with 5 under 16s in the team. Matt Riley and Nick Tegg started briskly and Monty Thompson (60 not out) then carried on the good work with Matt (46)## but there was never a serious run chase or a serious risk of Ballinger losing 10 wickets. A lost opportunity to set up a proper game of cricket## but all very pleasant in the sun ......

A Win

At last the 2s got their first win under their belt and they did it the hard way.

Skipper Kerry won the toss again and having taken one look at a very wet wicket decided that as they prepared it the home team could use it first.

As expected it was very slow but Ballinger's double Will attack made sure they kept the ball upto the bat and gave Prestwod's openers few chances to score. Will Reid bowled particularly well without success. Will Arnold was his normal economical self and eventually got his reward.

At this point Kerry introduced his secret weapon. Matt O'Kelly. Prestwood had no idea how to cope with his double bouncing long-hops and with the aid of 2 very good catches and one very good ball ended his spell with figures of 3-10. New boy Fin Clarke was now into his stride and again was hitting the right length to bowl on this slow pitch. A good catch in the slips by Steve Conway gave him his first wicket in adult cricket.

The 2 Wills now returned to finish off the Prestwood innings with the help of another good catch By Steve and one by Paul Branigan and an excellent run-out by Finn. Prestwood 87-10

87 didnt seem many but it had taken the hosts 38 overs to get them and the skipper was concerned. Especially as he and Peter Petrie were now on the injured list. 

Ben Dugdale opened up with Tom Petrie and they cautiously moved the total to 20 before Ben holed out## Matt came and went## Paul should have wacked it instead of giving catching practice## Tom then made the mistake of running on a miss-field and Ollie Cooksey was all at sea.

36 -5 and Ballinger reeling.

Will Reid and Steve Conway finally gave the inings some impetus before Steve was out to a chest high full toss - No Ball cried the crowd. The double Will act then took the score to 65 before Will R missed a straight one. Finn then got a first ball. Suddenly Ballinger 65-8.

This cant be happening. The skipper then hobbles out to join Will A and is given a very comprehensive breakdown of what's happening by Will. Skipper's response - no quick singles.

Will then gets out to a very good catch so 17 still needed when Peter gets to the crease. So we have a knackered knee at one end and knackered back at the other. On receiving his second ball Peter calls for a quick single before realising that neither he nor the skipper would make it. It has to be done in 4s. A couple of excellent blows from Peter and one lusty blow from the skipper get the Waggoners close. One more very dodgy single and then a couple of wides finally get the visitors over the line.

A ridiculous game of cricket but very enjoyable and played in excellent spirit and finally with the sun shining.

Ballinger batted first and put on a useful 100-4. It was very much an innings of two halves as our batsmen struggled upfront against some very accurate bowling with the score only 23-3 after 10 overs. Then Henry## Hamish and Monty mounted an impressive fightback to add 77 off the next 10 overs and build a useful total## including 35 off the last three overs. That showed how an innings and game can change quickly. Great Kingshill got off to a flier when they batted and we quickly lost heart. Monty came on to take the pace off the ball and made a breakthrough but the game ran away quickly not helped by a couple of crucial dropped catches(one very hard) and drooping heads in the field. Disappointing as it should have been a close contest.

Batting first## Skipper## Kit## set his team a target of 120.  James Gill and Marcus set off after this target with great energy and some very smart running between the wickets against a strong bowling attack.  James Gill looked like he would go on to score 30 but fell to a direct hit run-out for 14.  Henry King hit 5 boundaries including a 6 to get his 30.  Ollie's innings (his best ever) was a master class in stroke play## with a perfect on drive; he also retired at 30## leaving Hugo and Simon to see out the innings - 10 from the last over took our score to just 2 shy of the skippers target:  118.

This looked defendable and even more so when Will clean bowled their openner with an off cutter on the first ball.  After this## Ballinger were ruthless taking a wicket in each of the first 4 overs## with both Ben (2-4) and Will (2-1) bowling excellent line and length.  On comes Captain Kit and takes two in two balls - both bowled and Chenies are on their knees.  James continued to keep up the wicket / over routine and Kit finished them off with another two in his second over.  Kit's figures of 4-3 of 2 overs meant we wrapped up the game after just 7 overs.

Such a huge victory surprised me. Chenies were strong on the bowling but Ballinger picked the right balls to hit and blocked the good ones.  But it was Ballinger's accurate bowling which made the difference.  Well done.

Ballinger u17 took to the field for their opening game of the seaon in this league and cup ' double header'. When I say u17## it was actually 1 u17## 4 u16## 4 u15 and 2 u14. Captain Alex Howe won the toss and decided to bat on what looked a good wicket on a beautiful sunny evening. Our top order came and went in fairly quick time without troubling the scoreboard too much against a very good Cublington bowling attack. Ben Dugdale steadied the ship with a solid 32. Will Reid never really got going## which brought to the middle Alex Howe and Kenny Holt with work to do in setting any sort of defendable total. Alex scored a quickfire 17 but it was Kenny who took up the challenge. Obviously benefitting from his work in the nets he crafted a fine 33 not out and put on 48 with Alex taking Ballinger to a respectable 121 for 6.

Cublington took to the middle and looked comfortable against Ballingers opening attack of Hamish Sim and Will Arnold who both bowled well without success. Alex Howe took over from Hamish and hit the mark straight away but it was Will Reid at the other end who changed the balance of power. A fantastic spell of bowling taking 4 wickets in 4 overs for 6 runs really put the opposition on the back foot. On came Rob Farquhar who came under attack from  Cublingtion needing to up the run rate but managed to pick up a valuable wicket. Inspired captaincy then brought James Fray into the attack at a crucial time## taking a wicket with his first delivery## followed in his next over with two more## a fine catch from Ben Dugdale## rounded off with a brilliant caught and bowled## he finished with 3 wickets for 8 runs off 2 overs. This brought Cublingtons innings to an end as they were a man down still needing 22 runs off 2 overs.

A great performance## everyone playing their part. either with bat## ball or in the field.

BWCC   108-9     Knottty Green 113-2

A brave effort from our team## but we probably let them get away with too many boundaries.

Firstly a big thank you to Mathew Jones who once again played up two years for our Under11s. Mathew's bowling and fielding were bang on the  money. Congratulations also to Nicau for a really good first game for Ballinger.

Having lost four batsman very cheaply## Theo and Elise led a very strong fightback. Both batted with great ability## punishing the bad balls heavily and getting our innings back on track. Theo's retirement then allowed Luke and Will to come in and keep the scoreboard ticking over. Marcus and Mathew were very unlucky to get out very quickly## which left Theo and Charlotte to see us home to the 20 over mark. Theo's innings of 42 not out was littered with good shots and positivity. Well done Theo.

Defending the total did not appear to be too daunting## but our fielding really let us down. Normally accurate and sharp## we let too many boundaries get through## and allowed the opposition to build momentum. Our experienced cricketers need to be a bit more alert on placement and technique with our fielders. Learn to adapt to situations if you see a weakness. Elise was the pick of our bowlers with some really accurate overs. 

Plenty to improve on## particularly for the senior players in the team## but well done to ALL of you the kids for a really good try.

Sharkey

Chalfont St Giles v Ballinger U13A

7 June 2013

Won by 43 runs

GSG won the toss and chose to bowl – just what we wanted.   Ballinger had a slightly dicey start## with Harry Livingstone caught and George Cooke run out (not his fault – and the saying “never run on a misfield” has some basis).  But Joe Turrell is developing into an excellent 20 over opener – careful for a couple of overs but still pushing singles and putting away bad balls for 4## but then rapidly accelerating.  His excellent 31 retired was the foundation of the innings.  He was ably assisted by Zach Bischoff## with 17 in the same style## and then Will Fennell with a confident 12.  After Joe retired Tom Petrie carried on where he left off## finishing with 20 not out; while first Fin Clark and then Angus Denison-Smith blazed away at the other end.  Angus hit the last ball of the innings for 4 to finish 17 not out## with Ballinger on 133 for 5.  CSG did not have a strong attack but it was still a very good batting performance.

CSG never really mounted a challenge## always being way off the required rate and seemingly not prepared to take risks to try to keep up.  CSG finished rather tamely on 90 for 3## despite some slightly mixed Ballinger bowling.  Angus and Fin started well## and Taylor Levitt bowled some off-breaks surprisingly well considering that he had pulled a glute at the Beacon sportsday that afternoon (I’ve heard of playing a match “on one leg”## but not playing a match “on one buttock”).  Max Leane came on 3rd change and picked up the first wicket and then in fading light on quite a quick wicket George Cooke and Harry Livingstone revved up the pace and took a wicket apiece## with Cookie in particular generating some serious pace for a 13 year old.  Zach kept well## particularly to Cooke and Livingstone.  Fin skippered well## coping with the injuries to Taylor and later Max (who took one on the knee after  12 overs)## but he never came under any pressure from the CSG batters.

Man of the match:  Taylor Levitt for turning out and giving it his all despite being injured in the afternoon.

Champagne moment:  Angus whacking the last ball of the Ballinger innings over the bowler’s head for 4. 

Well done.

Andy

The captain David won the toss and elected to bat.  Ballinger scored steadily in the first four overs putting on an impressive 16 runs.  Then the initiative was taken by Wycombe## with 3 wickets falling in the following 4 overs.  The middle order batsmen continued to score steadily## gradually increasing their runs until again Wycombe turned on the pressure## claiming another 3 wickets as the Ballinger innings raced toward 20 overs.  The final 2 batsmen entered the crease with only 18 runs on the scoreboard.  With a real desire to win and some aggressive strokes and powerful running between the wickets## the final two batsmen scored 19 runs.  Ballingers total 237.

 

 

Wycombe’s performance was almost a mirror image of Ballinger. Some early high scoring was reduced in the middle order with 5 wickets being taken by Ballinger. By the 14th over## Wycombe were only 16 behind.  Ballingers’ score didn’t seem like it would be enough  and with Wycombe playing a tight game it was all to play for.  Runs were added to the scoreboard only to be reduced again as Ballinger took wickets.

 

4 overs left 222 on the scoreboard

3 overs left 225 scored

2 overs left 226 scored

 

Entering the last over Wycombe were 6 behind.  No runs off the first ball## 2 from the second. One from the 4th and 5th balls………………………..needing 3 to win.  An excellent bowl from the captain## a good strike from the batsman## tight if not a little frantic fielding…………One run.

 

 

Ballinger won by 1 run.

A fine day for cricket. Hooray!  

Sent in to bat Ballinger posted a respectable 115 off their 20 overs with the loss of only 5 wickets. Notable scores by James Bunce (22) and Harry Doyle (retired 30) and supported by Harry Petrie (13no).

Amersham were set a challenging target and with the light fading## and the Ballinger umpire freezing## they were all out within 15 overs for 39 (16 extras). Very good fielding by the U12 team certainly helped keep this score down for which the Ballinger manager was very grateful as he was rather cold! 

A fine win by 43 runs!

Fot the third week running skipper Davies lost the toss## and Ballinger were asked to bat on a slow## low sticky wicket amidst the picturesque backdrop of the Chiltern Hills and Bradenham Manor.Thompson and O'Kelly provided a cautious but solid start to the innings before Thompson perished on 18. Rollo McIntyre fell soon after## to bring Davies to the crease with the score at 28 for 2. After consolidating their position## the pair set about picking off the Bradenham attack## and looked to be in a position to post a competitive total before Davies fell## bowled by Ali for 28 with the score on 85. Bradenham's left arm spinner entered the attack and proceeded to run through the Ballinger batsmen## incuding the prized wicket of O'Kelly on 30## and a late order hat trick to finish off the tail. Ballinger ended up on 137 all out.

In response the new ball pair of Adams and Siddle looked threatening from the outset## the pitch proving to be equally challenging for the home side## and the Bradenham batsmen looked vulnerable from the outset. Adams struck early with two wickets## and Siddle one from the other end. Unfortunately the clear difference between the two sides lay in the field## with Ballinger putting down at least five clear cut chances that would surely have sealed a win should they have been taken Instead No 3 Gafor went on to score 60 and win the game comfortably for Bradenham. Things could and should have been so very different## and this is a lesson Ballinger must learn in order to avoid a relegation battle for the rest of the season.

(Report supplied by Ian Davies)

So## here it was## the match we were all waiting for! The weather was bright and sunny## the conditions perfect to watch a quality game of cricket.

With the welcome return of James “Larry” Larard the team was at full strength- and boy did we need it.

On this occasion## the team was led by James Bunce.

Winning the toss## Ballinger chose to bat first. First pair on- Henry and Hugo## and what a start.

With a number of fours and sixes## Henry retired at 32. Then came Harry Doyle who## despite a broken toe## also “slogged” his way to retirement.  Then there was Simon Carlin who again## “sprayed the ball” all over the pitch and ended retired on a score of 31. Other batsmen of note included Matt Barton who managed three 4s before the final ball.

Ballinger finished on a very healthy 172 runs.

Chesham were now in to bat and the fielding was highlighted by excellent tight team work . Good precise and tight bowling meant that the opposition were prevented from capitalising. Of particular note was Charlie whose demonstrated excellent wicket keeping.

Louis Thompson made a glorious catch## followed by a further two impressive failed diving attempts .

Final score 102 to Chesham- 172 to Ballinger.

A truly excellent performance by everyone in the team.

After winning the toss## catpain Evan Webster decided to bat on an overcast evening with the ground still wet from the afternoon showers. The opening pair of Max Dugdale and Tom McIntyre made a cautious start against some excellent bowling## Max lucky to remain at the crease after being dropped early on. They gradually got to grips with the Gt Kingshill attack and put on 56 before Max was caught going for yet another big hit but not before he'd hit a huge 6 into the pub car park## this after his helmet being smashed the ball before## something he obviously took offense to. His 32 of 21 balls set the innings up nicely. Jake Cutter was next in and a mix up whether to run a quick single saw Tom McIntyre run out the next ball. In came Ben Dugdale with Jake on strike for the 1st ball of the next over only to hear the 'death rattle' as the bails took to the air## a team hat-trick and things now not looking so good. Up stepped Henry Turrell to the crease and looked composed from the start. A partnership of 34 of 5 overs put the innings back on track before Henry was caught for 18. Alex Howe was next up and he and Ben put on a further 35 off 5 overs before Ben was caught trying to up the rate. In came Hamish for the remaining 2 overs and hit a quickfire 14 off 7 balls taking Ballinger to 141 for 5 with Alex unbeaten on 14.

Gt Kingshill had a lot to do and lost their first wicket to a great catch from Ben Dugdale off the bowling of Alex Howe without a run being scored. They were soon 2 down with Will Reid claiming the other opener with only 9 runs on the board. In came Jack Tebb for the visitors and looked to halt the slide. He went on to make an excellent 69## losing partners along the way with wickets from all the bowlers at crucial times and he finally fell to a great delivery from Evan Webster. With the score on 115 for 9 with 3 overs remaining## Hamish Sim finished off the innings with his best delivery of the day.

Game over## another 21 run victory## with contributions from everyone. Some sloppy fielding along the way needs to be improved but another pleasing performance on the whole.

On the warmest day of the season## Ballinger won the toss and elected to field. All started well## with Evan picking up one of the openers when the score was on 15. Carlton##supporting well from the other end## picked up the next two in quick succession## and at this stage Potten End were struggling at 38 for 3. Carlton bowled out his 10 overs## and after 20 the score was 52 for 3. Maciver then picked up a wicket## but then followed it up with two poor overs and was severely punished by the hard-hittng Hawkridge. This completely changed the tempo of the innings. The skipper then came on and picked up the wicket of Lee who batted patiently for 65. Evan then returned to finish his spell## picking up 4 wickets and finishing with the impressive figures of 5 for 28. Generally the the fielding and catching were good.

Ballinger found themselves chasing 172## and never really got going## largely due to an impressive spell by Guerney. Riley went with the score on 18 to a ball that nipped back## Ian followed in the same over to one that kept low. With Carlton going after a brief cameo## and Jamie becoming Guerney's fourth wicket## Ballinger were struggling at 49 for 4. Andy Branigan (batting on one leg) and Jono Lacey then put on 41 until both fell in quick succession. Three more wickets fell quickly with no real addition to the score## and it was then left to Rob Grosse and Evan to give the score some kind of respectability## putting on 31 for the last wicket. Ballinger were all out for 135## losing the match by 135 runs.

In truth## a lost opportunity. Whilst we gave them 30 runs too many## overall it was a poor performance with the bat. Six batsmen being bowled on this wicket summed it up.

(Report supplied by Ian Davies)

Ballinger suffered their third consecutive league defeat## away to Ley Hill. On paper## a disaster - but not all was doom and gloom## by any means.

Having lost the toss## skipper for the day Carlton Siddle led a very young looking Ballinger side out to field## deprived of most of their seasoned regulars through injury or non-availability (holidays?)## on a welcome sunny afternoon. The unfamiliar looking opening attack consisted of Will Reid and Rob Grosse## and they did an excellent job in keeping the Ley Hill batsmen quiet. Will struck first## courtesy of a multi-juggling catch by Fally## but another wicket was not to fall until the score had reached 134## with R Clarke hitting the short boundaries hard and often. One of the few benefits of being short of our "seasoned regulars" is that the ground fielding is prone to improve## and this was certainly the case here. Fally took another stunning catch## and generally Ballinger looked pretty efficient as the bowlers toiled on a good batting track. A couple of run-outs at the bitter end saw the scoreboard register 5 wickets down for a final total of 207.

With an inexperienced batting line up 208 was always going to be a tough target## and so it proved. The score-board was always well up with the required run rate## with Jono Lacey hitting a powerful 21## but wickets fell all too frequently. Coming in at no. 3## Andy Thompson batted in his customary dogged way to anchor the innings## and started to find the boundary with increasing frequency## including one delightful 6## and his partnership with Carlton (30) looked as if it might win the day for Ballinger## but it was not to be## and when he was shown the dreaded umpiring digit - more than somewhat unjustly some thought - he departed## having made a fine 63## with the total on 157 for 7. The game was really now up## but a spirited last wicket partnership between Ben Dugdale and Will Reid kept us in the match until the 36th over## 31 short of the target.

A loss against another team struggling in the league was definitely not what we wanted## but to employ the well-known sporting cliche## there were a lot of positives to take from the match.

The difference between the sides was height## bat size and age. A big bat on a fast outfield makes quite an impact.  Ballinger's U13Bs are an increasingly confident unit in the field. We bowled more accurately## took more wickets and were tighter and more energetic in the field than the opposition but lacked the big willow to find the boundary as often as they did (6 fewer to be precise).  

Skipper## Ben## elected to field and openners (Will Fennell and Will Harman) were unlucky not to get wickets.  Their length often forcing air shots which did not quite go to hand.  Ben and Ollie also bowled tightly earning 3 wickets in their 4 overs and keeping Ballinger hoping to contain Wooburn.  Ben again managing a CAB## which seems to be his signature wicket.  Max Conway playing no less than 4 years young had a terrific spell of 1-6## our most economical bowler despite bowling off a wicket 2m longer than he is used to. He was also a courageous and effective fielder.  Josh Brown seemed to be in the hot seat for fielding and grew in confidence through the match## collecting the ball quickly and with accurate returns eventually leading to one of our run-outs.  Marcus## also playing up had a useful spell culminating in a very quick stumping by Michael. Michael's glove work goes from strength to strength - only letting through one bye is the best performance I have witnessed at this age group.  He took a smart stumping which he has been threatening to do all season and was sharp on the run-outs.  

Wooburn's target of 130 was always going to be tough and we never quite got onto the chase.  The highlight of our batting was Hugo's 31 retired.  Hugo has hinted at this kind of innings for some time - some good aggressive stroke play combined with respectful defensive shots to some good bowling.  Ben supported with 15 and Ollie had a cameo 9 off about 6 balls at the end of the innings.  I would like to see Ollie put his hand up to open in the next game. 

Man of the match to Hugo for a great innings.  Champagne moment to James Gill for an amazing one handed catch to a ball that was skied over his head.

BWCC 90 for 7   vs Chiltern Girls 90 for 8

Wow## yet another very exciting and competitive game. What an exciting finish to the game too. Well done to both teams.

Ballinger batsmen Harry and Philip made a solid opening stand against some accurate bowling. However with Philip departing## there followed a small collapse with Will## Luke## Marcus and David all going cheaply. Harry then retired with a very good 33. Nicau## Ben## Jamie and Henry then saw the 20 overs comfortably through## and contributed some very valuable runs## including a cracking four through the off-side from Jamie. Yeah! 

We knew that 90 was a defendable target## but it would require some accurate bowling and fielding. We started off like this## with some good tight overs from all of our bowlers. Though Harry and Philip bowled agressively and well## the pick of the bunch were David## Max (yr4)## Ben and Will. These four all took useful wickets and swung the game towards the boys. The Chiltern Girls middle order of Hannah and Charlie## then gave a brilliant demonstration in calling and running## and set real panic into the fielding side. Overthrows## fumbles and dropped catches ensued. The boys then countered with some excellent run outs. This led to 7 runs required off the final over. Four byes....this was Hollywood stuff....one needed off the last ball....another bye.....and a DRAW. Agony and ecstasy.

Super stuff with no less than 16 Ballinger CC members involved on the night. Thank you Roger and Keith Barker for umpiring so proficiently.

Sharks

Our skipper for the day Finn Henry won the toss and put the confident Chesham side in to bat. we took a wicket in each of the three first overs which put Chesham under quite some pressure. Finn directed his field with total confidence and rearranged his bowlers to maintain the pressure with Tim Hayes now putting himself forward as one of our strike bowlers and it wasnt until the 10th over before Chesham were in positive territory## this only lasted for three overs after which their score continued its downward spiral. All of the boys bowled really well and this week i have listed all of their efforts as they really warrant publication. The last two overs we took a further two wickets and this left us with a total of 179 to chase.

All of our pairs did a fantastic job with Max C stepping into Olivers opening role with Max Fe## they finished their session with us on 220##Casper and Freddie then took over and moved us up to 236## Matthew and Tom V held their own against some strong bowling and left their creases with us on 234## Tim and Thomas B had Chesham running all over the place and left Raphi and Finn with 231 to take over and they decided not to use the boundary## but istead gave Chesham some intensive fielding practice and finished on 238.

Next Week Gerrards Cross at Home

Of all the grounds in the MBL Premier Division where you would least like to play cricket (or umpire or score!)on a cold## wet##windy day## Haddenham would probably get most peoples' vote. Remarkably it was the only ground in the division which saw a result## all the other matches being abandoned to the weather.

Ian Davies## returning to lead a greatly strengthened side## performed his customary ritual of losing the toss## whereupon Ballinger were invited to bat first. With rain looking imminent from the outset## it was difficult for the batsmen to decide whether to play as if it were a 40 over innings## or maybe a 20 overs one. Either way opener Riley didn't have to make a decision as he departed in the first over## swiftly followed by Rollo## both adjudged LBW. However## Richard O'Kelly was in fine form from the start## and with Ian Davies giving good support## the score was looking distinctly healthier when the rains came. Play resumed briefly## but the heavens then opened in earnest## with the score on 42 for 2## and 8 overs gone.

After a lengthy break and an early tea## during which most of the team revealed their prowess on the darts board or the pool table## the clouds parted## albeit reluctantly## and the match resumed ## shortened to 29 overs each side. Ballinger now faced trying to make a decent total in the 21 overs left to them## and the third wicket partnership continued to thrive until Richard## having just completed a hard-hitting 50 was## surprisingly## bowled. with the total on 72. Meanwhile Ian## who one assumes must have implied to the Haddenham fielders that it was his birthday## continued to profit from dropped catches (three!) until his luck ran out## but not before he had hit a priceless 40## including one mighty six.. The rest of the innings then rather disintegrated## with three run-outs## as the batsmen strove to get a defendable target on the board. 129 for 9 was the outcome## substantially less than had at one time seemed likely.

Ballinger's bowlers did not have to wait long for success## Nick Adams striking in his second over## and evidently finding the pitch greatly to his satisfaction.. However## Haddenham were accumulating their runs quite rapidly## and had reached 92 for 4## within easy reach of their target## by the 16th over. Evan Webster swung the match by bowling the hard-hitting Burniston## Nick having already disposed of the dangerous Bharath for 41.Nick completed his 10 overs with the superlative figures of 6 for 32## and Evan finished with 3 for 27## as Haddenham subsided from 92 for 4 to 109 all out## leaving Ballinger victorious by 17 runs.

This was a gratifying performance## after a run of defeats## moving Ballinger a welcome couple of places up the league table## and a triumph for all concerned in the match## considering the miserable weather conditions.

Reduced to 15 overs a side## due to the late finish of the Beacon v DCGS match in the afternoon.  Ballinger 92 for 6. Superb opening platform from Joe Turrell (retired for 30## continuing recent top form as opening bat) and Fin Clark (run out for 21); and then some lusty hitting at the end from George Cooke (20 not out).  Tight bowling from Freddie Thompson## Tom Petrie## Fin and George## and generally good ground fielding## kept Chesham behind the rate.  With 3 overs to go they had 28 to get. Harry Livingstone and Max Leane bowled 2 tight overs## leaving Chesham 18 to get off the last over## bowled by Harry.  Excellent clean striking from Chesham's Nouman Aslam left them with 4 to win off the last ball## despite all Ballinger men being on the fence.  But Harry kept his head## as did George on the boundary## keeping Chesham down to 2 runs## leaving them 1 short## on 91 for 4.  A very exciting game of cricket## played to a very high standard## in an excellent competitive spirit.

Captain Matt Riley won the toss and decided to bat on an overcast afternoon with a light drizzle falling. He was probably questioning his decision 3 balls later as an uplayable delivery nipped back of the wicket and clipped his bails. Max Dugdale was next in looking to build on his recent improvement in form. Basty found it difficult to get going and it was left to Max to move the innings on. He made an excellent 52## including five fours and 3 sixes## the partnership putting on 75 in 16 overs before Max took on the bowling once to often. 75 for 2 quickly became 85 for 5 before Steve Conway and Tom McIntyre put on a useful 38 of 10 overs before Tom holed out to a good catch at mid wicket. The weather was improving but unfortunately not the batting. Steve Conway pulled up lame and the decision was to either put him down or get him a runner. Ben came out as his ' body double' and the three of them put on another 10 runs before Steve fell to a good delivery. Tea was fast approaching and Ballinger managed to get to 159 before George Cook was run out with 1 ball remaining.

The sun was now shining and the wicket drying quickly. After an excellent tea Missenden took to the middle on what looked a much better wicket. Captain Riley decided to go for youthwith anopening attack of George Cook and Freddie Thompson## pace and spin. They both bowled really well without any luck as the openers put on 72 for the first wicket. 72 for 1 was soon 81 for 2 but the problem of youth and bowling spin meant that Ballinger were rattling through the overs. 21 gone and the clock stricking 6pm gave Missenden 20 overs to get 78 runs with wickets in hand. However## excellent bowling kept the run rate down. It came down to the last 2 overs with 9 runs needed. It was down to Ben Dugdale to bowl the crucial penultimate over and he kept his nerve## conceding only 2 runs and taking a key wicket. Over to Stuart McGowan## a wicket with his first ball and 7 still needed. Unfortunately## Chris Kaye## who had opened was still there to guide Missendenover the linewith 1 ball to spare.

Ballinger lose by 5 wickets## but a thoroughly enjoyable game## played in great spirit on what turned out to be a beautiful afternoon.

This will be a short as the match was. 21 overs instead of 40.

With no Ballinger batsman making double figures on a decent track against an average bowling attack it's difficult to know what to say. 48 was never going to be enough and Marlow made very short work of reaching their target.

 

Hey Ho off to The Lee next

The least said about this game the better. Over confidence and complacency can often come back to haunt you and this game was no exception. Asked to bowl Ballinger soon had Aylesbury in trouble  at 19 for 3 off 7 overs. Enter complacency and the score becomes 67 for 4 off 14 overs. Introduce over confidence and a little arrogance and the score finishes on 117 for 6.

Over confidence and arrogance take to the middle and soon it is 11 for 3 off 3 overs. Harry Bartlett who for technical reasons is represented on the score card as Josh Badrick realises that this might not be quite as easy as imagined and anchors the innings with partnerships of 17 with Kenny Holt and 49 with Jake Cutter taking the score to 77 for 5 off 13 overs before falling to a good delivery. Jake Cutter is batting well at this time and is joined at the crease by Ben Dugdale with 41 runs still needed off 7 overs with the Aylesbury team in confident mood. Tight bowling kept the run rate down an Ballinger needed 23 off the last 3 overs with the Aylesbury opening bowling attack back in action. Backs to the wall and defeat a real possibility in a game that should never have been in doubt see Jake and Ben hit 9 off over 17## 14 off over 18 and 12 off over 19## Jake finishing the game with a huge 6 into the nearby tennis courts.

Victory from the jaws of defeat## all of their own making with lack of focus## sloppy fielding## bowling and batting. Hopefully## lessons learned.

Ballinger U13A v Dinton

20 June

At home

Lost by 4 wkts

This was a shame really.  We had a very much weakened team out due to all the Beacon yr 8 boys being in a school play## but I felt that our team## made up of some of the best U12 players supporting a selection of the remaining U13s## had enough firepower to beat bottom of the division Dinton.  It seems that we played a bit below par and Dinton played very much above.  The result was that Ballinger managed only 87 all out## and Dinton chased it down with 4 wkts and over 3 overs to spare.

Only Henry King really mastered the attack.  His excellent 31 retired was the cornerstone of the Ballinger innings.  He defended the straight ones solidly and hit anything wide## or over-pitched## very hard## finding the boundary 7 times.  A model innings.  But around him wickets tumbled and they carried on after he retired.  Matthew Barton showed excellent application and a good eye to accumulate 11## but all others remained in single figures.  7 out of the 9 wickets to fall were bowled## suggesting poor defensive technique or over-ambitious shot selection (unfortunately they were all seen by me only from square leg so I cannot be 100% sure which in each case).  It also showed that Dinton were bowling reasonably straight.  Ballinger were all out in the 17th

over. 

It is notoriously said to be a  “crime” not to use all one’s overs batting first in a limited overs game ….

Sadly## Ballinger did not bowl straight enough## giving the Dinton batters too much width and not testing their defence as much as they tested ours.  We took wickets steadily but runs came just as steadily## despite some mostly good ground fielding (especially by Hugo Baker down at third man).  A very good knock of 32 from their captain coming in at 5 saw them all but home.  Ballinger had## too late## got through all the real Dinton batters and were into the tail## but the last few runs were inexpertly garnered through edges## byes and wides and suddenly it was all over.

Positives?  Lots.  Henry’s skilled and confident batting.  Matthew’s application.  James Arnold’s excellent spell of  2 for 16 off 4 overs.  Ollie Hardman also proved very hard to get away## with none for 7 off 2 overs.  Fin Clark is growing into the captaincy role and will be good at it.  Mike Everett had a hard time behind the stumps on a fast and skiddy astro pitch## but## with some coaching## will be a good keeper.

Man of the match:  Henry King

Champagne moment:   James Arnold taking a wicket## bowled## with his first ball.

Andy

Another overcast day at Ballinger with our Guests eager to get started## their skipper lost the toss and our captain Thomas Berens put them in to bat. Thomas had to utilise two of our Under 7 boys## his younger brother Charlie and Max Hayes whist two of our players arrived a little late. Both Charlie and Max saved runs with Max almost making an extremely difficult high catch and Charlie bowling the 5th over## which he only went for 4 runs which was the 4th tightest over of the innings## so he is going to be a great asset for the club along with Max as they move into the U9 team in the next two years## so a big thank you to both of them.

Gerrards Cross took off at an extraordinary rate and our bowlers only managed to take five of their wickets one for Louis## one for Casper and three for Finn.

The team were not as sharp as usual in the field and this played into Gerrards Crosses hands with their energy between the wickets## we saw great fielding by Casper Jack##Oliver Webb and Raphi Weatherall.We then all witnessed what must be the catch of the season## a high jumping ##diving##one handed catch by Tim Hayes fielding at point## it was quite extraordinary and really lifted the team.

Gerrards Cross finished with a score of 286## quite a target for any side to reach.

Thomas sent in our openers Oliver and Tim who put on 22 with Tim hitting two consecutive 4's on a long boundary and Oliver stealing singles at every opportunity without losing a wicket taking us to 222## in came Max Fe and Finn Henry who put on a net 24 taking us to 246 and at the same time making Gerrards Cross start to panic as the target looked very much in sight## in came the next pair Raphi Weatherall and Tom Vicary who put on 17 taking us to 263##the skipper Thomas decided to switch pairs putting in Casper Jack and Louis Barton who continued with the pressure with both boys playing lovely shots off their legs and adding a further 12 runs to the total## so we only needed a net 12 from the last pair Max Conway and Thomas Berens## the boys had their game plan and had reached their target by the end of the 18th over and then played some great defensive strokes to guard their score and finish the match on 291 and beating what was an excellent opposition.

Well done to all of the boys and support from the parents especially Fiona and Danielle who made the cakes and Tina and Graham for all of their help in the clubhouse looking after everyone.

We have our last match next sunday against Marlow which will again be a great test for the boys.

Following the disappointment of the game against Dinton on Thursday## Ballinger came to Beaconsfield with purpose.  Ballinger never looked like a team missing their 3 County players.  It was a ruthless and very confident performance.

Harry Livingstone won the toss and elected to bat.  On a very slow outfield## they set themselves a target of 120.  Joe Turrell and Henry King navigated the first 5 overs of the Beaconsfield openers.  They found it tough to find the middle but kept the score ticking over with some excellent running between the wickets.  Henry was bowled by a superb delivery in the 6th for a useful 9.  Joe was joined by skipper Harry Livingstone and they continued with very good running## picking off the bad balls with some excellent stroke play.  Both retired on 30.    As did Taylor Levitt who played a good array of strong hits but happy to defend the good ones.    Zac Bischoff's 10 at the end of the innings - off around 7 balls helped Ballinger to get well beyond their target and finish on 128 for 3.  The outfield was very slow and the boundary long; on a different ground## this could easily have been 140/150 run innings.

Ballinger entered the field with some confidence and rightly so.  Fin Clarke and Will Fennell opened taking a couple of wickets each and leaving Beaconsfield on 22 for 4 of 7.  But the best was yet to come.  Sharkey Iqbal's spell of 2 wickets for 5 runs off 4 overs was stunning.  His first was a sharp stumping which turned a foot;  the Beaconsfield batmen just could not cope with his flight and length.  Balls were not quite going to hand until he earned his second innings - a simple catch to Mid-Wicket (Taylor).    Angus Denison-Smith## Harry Livingstone and Harry Doyle all bowled straight - with Harry just 1 run off his two overs.  Joe Turrell had just one over and could have taken a wicket on 5 of his 6 balls - he took two.  Taylor Leviitt took the final over and was denied the final wicket because my line of sight for a smart stumping taken by Zac was obscured by a fielder.    Ballinger were very tight in the field - giving nothing away.  Fin's sharp throw in to get a run out was the champagne moment. 

Well done - a terrific performance.

Skipper Davies## apparently still intoxicated by a combination of the Lions' victory plus the after effects of the Golf Day Dinner## and having actually won the toss ( a rare event)## threw caution to the winds and elected to bat on a rain-affected pitch## even though his batting line-up lacked a little in depth. Thereafter## things went sharply downhill for him## and the team. After 14 overs the scoreboard registered 4 wickets down for a mere 16 runs## nine of which were wides! This abysmal performance was the result of excellent fast bowling by Little (whose 10 overs cost 11 runs)## and Germain who ended up with 5 for 19## combined with a death wish by our star batsmen Rollo (caught first ball) and Davies (caught 4th ball). Opener Jamie Kellock despatched Germain for an imperious cover driven boundary in his first over## before registering 36 consecutive dot balls in the book## and lasting an hour at the crease in an impressive defensive effort. The arrival of Carlton Siddle arrested the impending debacle## and he saw the total reach 45 before he was bowled## and 21 overs gone. However## there followed a 67 run partnership for the 7th wicket between Fally and Adeel Iqbal. Both unsurprisingly started nervously but they grew in confidence## Fally scoring mainly in powerful boundaries## while Adeel showed some delightful cut shots and placed the ball well. Fally departed## bowled## having top-scored with 39## with the total on 112## and Adeel (30) a couple of runs later. Normal service now resumed and the innings collapsed to leave Holmer Green a pretty tame target of 119.

Ballinger's bowlers started well. Will Reid gained a contentious LBW decision in his first over against the prolific Watt## and Nick Adams struck soon afterwards to see Holmer Green 17 for 2. That## though## was as good as it got## as the batsmen were soon scoring freely. A couple of sharp chances went down## which didn't help## and the pitch seemed to have quietened down. Max Dugdale took a smart stumping chance in an encouraging display behind the stumps## and Carlton picked up a couple of late wickets to lend a modicum of respectability to the scoreboard## but in truth this was a disappointing effort against a clearly better side.

Ballinger lose by 8 wickets but what might have been? Ballinger lost the toss and were asked to bat on a sunny evening on what looked a decent wicket. Max Dugdale soon set about the Dinton attack and put on 53 for the first wicket in the sixth over. Hamish Sim joined Max at the crease and the pace didn't let up## the pair putting on 76 in 9 overs before Max fell on 89## caught at deep mid wicket going for yet another big hit. The score on 131 for 2 after 15 overs. Then the collapse losing 6 wickets and only adding a further 23 runs. Was this going to be enough?

Captain Evan Webster decided to mix pace with spin as the opening attack with Jake Cutter bowling with the sun behind him. It's a fine line when trying to flight the ball to a good length and some over pitched deliveries were severely treated. Monty Thompson suffered the same fate and Dinton were soon up with the required rate with wickets in hand. After 15 overs they were on 133 for 2## 2 runs ahead of Ballinger at that stage of the game. Their opening bat was now closing in on his 100 and set about the Ballinger bowling and finished the game off with 3 overs remaining## unbeaten on 110## a great innings.

Lessons to be learned ..... must finish off the innings when in a great position ....... must bowl better line and length when defending a decent total ...... must be sharper in the field and not gift runs to the opposition.

Sunday 2nd X1 versus Kimble (Away. Under leaden skies## a very brisk wind straight down the ground## then some sun….and then it rained). Result - match abandoned. Likely result – victory.
 
When the rains came at 6.45 they required a smidgeon over a 100 from 14 overs with 7 wickets left – one good player in## and one man (who was not going to pinch a quick single) just arrived at the crease. So what odds would you think that would be? We would have won 7 times out of 10## maybe higher?
 
So## well done## guys## especially so since we had a very youthful team. As for the batting## we topped 200 for the first time in a game I have played this season. And with only the loss of four wickets and with every batsmen who was out making a meaningful contribution## nice runs therefore from Bastie and Max D## then Hamish## then with increasing belligerence from Jake Cutter and Tom Mac. Champagne moment was Cutter’s drive through mid-off on the up with the ball travelling along the floor at speed across the boundary. Only very good players can hit that shot.
 
As for the bowling## I was enormously proud that our first four bowlers had an average age of less than 15. And whilst we did not take a clatter of wickets## of the balls that went in the air nothing made for a straightforward chance## and we had kept them in pretty firm check## with one key wicket just taken….and then it rained.
 
So really good job.
 
NB Of course## the flip side to a good batting performance is that a number did not bat at all eg Ben D. I am sorry. A lot of you are better than where you go in the line up but I try hard to share things around as best I know how. Catch you all soon

A big hand to the parents for a fantastic response to get a full side out in just 36 hours.

First time skipper## Oliver## set his team a target of 120 runs and almost all the batsmen delivered; the run rate built steadily and at 56 for 3 of the first 10 overs## we were on target…but the wickets did fall steadily…Harri Doyle was the pick of them with 28 not out## ably supported by Joshua Brown who stopped the flow of wickets and picked off useful singles. Their partnership of 37 steered us to a defendable 125.

Chesham set off at a good pace. Ballinger’s bowling induced quite a few catching opportunities but none taken apart from a crucial catch taken by Joshua off Sharky’s bowling to get out their main run scorer. Halfway through## Chesham were on 59 for 2 and in the chase. The crucial spell came from Ollie## who had the good sense to bowl himself all 4 overs despite a lot of pressure from team mates; his figures of 1 for 8 off 4 overs was the really the difference between the two sides and despite some cracking boundaries in the final over## Chesham finished short by 10 runs.

Matthew Barton offered to keep wicket and did so very well improving through the innings which was critical to keep the run rate down.    

This was a very good team performance and my first ever experience of managing a game in which we beat Chesham…a moment to savour!

Playing against the division leaders## Holmer Green's A team was never going to be easy.  Doing so when half the team was playing at least 3 if not 4 years up was daunting.

Oliver elected to bat.  Disastrous start.  At 5 for 5 off two overs## and only 2 U13s left## it looked like we would be struggling to get into double figures!  The U10 and U9 boys did a sterling job to make our score look less appalling.  Max and Henry showed that just by staying in the runs happen from byes## wides and no balls and Jamie McMullan and Ben Tomlin put on a 14 run last wicket partnership to take us up to 35. 

We were never going to win this game but as with all U13B games## it was good to see Ballinger remain focused in the field and enjoy themselves.  Joshua Brown in particular doing an excellent job at Mid Off## stopping several hard drives from getting to the Boundary. Oliver was the pick of the bowlers picking off a couple of their better batsmen## which on another day## defending a better total## might have made a game of it.  Nic Blagg bowled very straight and did well to adjust to the length and took a well deserved wicket as well. Once again Michael was very effective behind the stumps - no byes at all.

Sun at last and Marlow won the toss and put Tim Hayes and his team in to bat and we were met with a team of boys who without exception could all bowl## we started off slowly and by the end of the 8th over we were sitting on 192## then Matthew and Max Fe started to steady the ship and moved us up to 207 off 12## BWCC U9 are now in uncharted territory## and then the gale started with the partnership of Tim Hayes and our usual opener Oliver Webb who took us to 252## with Tim scoring 29 off 19 balls which included a monster 6## sadly Oliver only faced 5 balls## then our usual tail end pair of Raphi and Max C scored 26 but unusually lost 3 wickets leaving us with a respectable 260.

Marlow in to bat with a line-up that included Andrew Straus's son## surely they can't all bat## oh yes they can. We seemed to be very unlucky in the field ## but I am sure the very short boundary had a pert to play. They were plodding along with us taking our usual one or two wickets per pair and then on came Matthew Jones who took 3 yes 3 wickets from his first 3 balls ## Marlow were in shock## then Sebastian steamed in but didn’t manage to break through and then Matthew Jones bowled his second over and took another wicket## yes he bowled two overs ## 4 wickets for 8 runs [net -16]. Our other bowlers did their duty ## but sadly it wasn’t to be and they finished 9 runs ahead of us## but a score to be proud of and if## yes if so many other things had gone our way we could have won## but a great learning curve for the team.

The boys all showed amazing commitment and as always some acrobatic fielding combined with excellent bowling from the whole team.

So we have won the League and to make sure it wasn’t just several lucky matches we play a final game on the 14th of July which will be hosted at Beaconsfield CC along with finals of U10##U11##U12##U13##U14 and U15 on the same day## so there should be an amazing atmosphere. I would like to spend an hour with the boys before the match to work on our tactics and field positioning.

Our match will be against either Beaconsfield CC U9A or Marlow CC U9A

Ballinger's season reached a new low at home against Downley.Thrashed by 10 wickets - it doesn't come much worse!

Put in to bat## our top order batsmen had no answer to the Ali brothers' bowling. Richard O'Kelly could consider himself unlucky to fall victim to a brilliant slip catch## but Rollo and Ian Davies were victims of their own impatience. Carlton came in with the score on 35 for 4## and aided by another good knock by Fally## the pair managed to put on 29 for the 5th wicket. That that was the highest stand of the innings says it all. Carlton battled away## desperately trying to keep the scoreboard moving## whilst dealing in his own special way with the excessively vocal Downley fielders## but apart from a defiant knock by Ben Dugdale## the innings sagged to a miserable 102 for 9 when the overs ran out## with Carlton undefeated on 42. 

There was never any likelihood that such a total would present much of challenge to the Downley batsmen## especially with some key bowlers missing. As it turned out## the Downley openers strolled to victory in a mere 18 overs## without Ballinger ever looking like taking a wicket. What a waste of a lovely sunny evening!

Next week we face Monks Risborough again - in the first match of the season they beat us by 9 wickets on our own wicket. We are now firmly in the relegation zone## so a big improvement all round## please!

What a way to end the (competitive part of the) season! A game that ebbed and flowed.

Ollie put Chalfont into bat and at 7 for 3 off 15 balls## I was beginning to get concerned that our final match might be a little too easy.  I need not have worried!  Our first wicket was taken off Rory's first ball of the innings (3-11 off 3.5) - caught by the substitute fielder provided by the opposition. Other than Rory## the wickets were shared around..as were the extras## no less than 30 of Chalfont's 88 runs. Henry King took two good catches and two wickets.  James Arnold's 1-6 off two overs was also an excellent spell and deserved to have at least one more over.  Michael took a good stumping and was generally good with the gloves## dealing with the wayward bowling of his team mates.

88 should have been a relatively easy target but Ballinger were determined to give their parents (great turn out - thank you) an exciting game.  We lost two wickets in the first over - shades of the game against Holmer Green.  Henry King and Ben Westland then settled down and starting building a partnership.  At 36 for 2 off 5 overs## the match swung back to Ballinger.  Then Ben "I got bored" Westland tried to drive a straight one and Rory immediately followed him back into the pavilion.  Mr reliable## Henry King## fell for 23 after a good knock##  43-5.  Kit's cameo 6 runs off 2 balls gave fleeting hope before we lost him## James Gill (who had provided some doughty resistance) and Ollie Hardman.  The top 8 had all been bowled!  A win from 56 for 8 from Joshua Brown and Matthew Barton seemed too big an ask## but this was by far the most mature partnership of the innings.  They blocked the straight ones## ran and called sensibly and kept finding the boundary.  Two overs into the partnership and we needed just 13 to win with plenty of overs.  12 more balls and only 3 runs kept us on the edge of our seats and then suddenly it was 4 to win.  Joshua smacked a boundary and he and Matthew had won the game for Ballinger. 

It was not our best performance although definitely the most exciting.  Congratulations to Matthew (19) and Joshua (10) for keeping their heads and following the instructions of their coach to "hit the wide ones## block the straight ones".  Henry King also had a terrific game with bat## ball and in the field.  Champagne moment - I think it had to be Joshua's 4 to win the game## although Michael's sharp stumping was a close second. 

 

That ends the season for competitive leagues games.  Won 5## lost 4 is a good result in a division which has 8 A sides and only 2 B sides.  The highlight was our performance against Chesham.   The boys have played competitive cricket with great spirit## lots of encouragement and hardly any criticism of each other## very supportive of the youngsters when they played.  It's been a pleasure to see them develop into a decent unit who enjoy playing as a team.  We will try to arrange some friendlies in July / August.

Having been put in to bat by High Wycombe it was important to get off to a solid start in what was going to be a difficult encounter. Unfortunately the first ball of the innings## unplayable## skittled Max Dugdale's stumps. The quality of the High Wycombe bowling made it impossible to gain any momentum and Ballinger were soon 15 for 2 off 5 overs. Change of bowlers did not lessen the quality and Ballinger found themselves 49 for 7 off 13 overs. Dom Brown and Will Reid put on a gallant 33 before Dom fell to another great delivery. Ballinger finishing on 91 for 9 off their 20 overs.

High Wycombe obviously thought this would not be a problem to chase down and sent in some lower order batsmen to open their innings. However## excellent bowling from Alex Howe## Will Reid and Will Arnold held the visitors to 31 for 1 off 9 overs. Dom Brown joined the attack and HW found themselves 42 for 2 off 12 overs. In came the big guns in an effort to get the innings back on track. On came Ben Dugdale to bowl over 17 with the score on 84## 2 runs and a sharp stumping by Max took the score to 86 for 3## 6 runs needed in 3 overs. A couple of big hits in the next over gave High Wycombe a deserved victory but much closer than they ever imagined.

A great effort by the boys with special mention to Evan Webster for his great catch and heroics in the field. Leading by example and backed up by the rest of the team.

This fixture was rearranged from late May when it had been washed out. 

On a beautiful sunny evening at Widmer End## we lost the toss and GKCC chose to bat. Will immediately had them on the back foot with two wickets in the first over## but to their credit they gradually rebuilt their innnings. As we rotated our bowlers## we were far too generous with wides## and allowed their total to creep up to 85 runs. Some notable bowling from Orlando## David## Harry and Will was slightly undone by the extras column of the others.

When we began our innings## it looked an achievable target. Philip stroking two beautiful shots in the first over## but then succumbing to a straight one on the last ball of the over. Harry and Will began some consolidation## but gave their wickets too easily again. Boys## if it is straight on the stumps## you need to give the ball more respect. We then began to struggle until Marcus and Henry began to stop the wickets and rebuild## but they were now up against a climbing run rate. Boundaries became a rarity and shots to well placed fielders deterred us from taking singles. GKCC bowling was overall much straighter## so the extras column did not come to our aid either.

All in all## I think we were all disappointed not have given a better account of ourselves.

Well done boys and girls## let's go out with a bang on Sunday at Chalfont St Giles.

JS

Captain Ben Dugdale won the toss and chose to bat on what looked a good wicket on this beautiful sunny day. It was obviously too hot for several of the top order who decided to gift their wickets and retire to the shelter of the clubhouse. It was left to Stuart Clark and Iain McLoughlin to try and get the innings back on track. The pair put on 73 before the heat got to Stuart who hit across the line to a straight delivery. In came Oli Cooksey and a 23 run partnership with Iain took the score to 111 before Iain nicked one to the keeper## a solid innings of 59. Phil White## who for technical reasons appears as Sam Phillips on the score card## never got started and was out LBW. The score now at 116 for 7 after 32 overs and things not looking good. In came Dom Brown## back after injury## and he set about the Lacey Green bowling. A partnership of 66 with James Fray and finishing on 54 not out took the Ballinger total to a respectable 183 for 7 off their 40 overs. It still looked on the light side given the conditions but at least a total to defend.

Lacey Green took up the challenge and good bowling from the youthful Ballinger attack made it diifficult for the visitors who were 40 for 3 off 10 overs. A partnership of 50 for the next wicket took the score to 90 for 4 off 18 with their number 3 bat established at the crease. Ballinger had limited bowling options with James Fray not feeling well and unable to bowl and the captain having to juggle his youthful team. Another good partneship of 56 for the next wicket took LG to 148 for 5 off 28## well ahead of the rate## wickets in hand and their number 3 still in control. Some erratic bowling made it all too easy and LG chased down the required total with 9 overs remaining.

A deserved victory on a very hot day## spoilt in part by the attitude of certain players and officials......let's put it down to the weather.

Another lost match for Ballinger## but in an exceptionally low scoring game they came within a whisker of snatching victory. Acting skipper Ian Maciver## having bucked the usual trend by winning the toss## opted to field first. Nick Adams and Will Reid were soon into their stride## with Nick securing the first of his four wickets when Monks Risborough had reached 12 in the 5th over. Evan Webster then entered the attack## starting with two consecutive wicket-maiden overs. By the end of his spell he had taken 5 for 20 as the wickets tumbled## and at 59 for 9 Monks Risborough were looking done for. However## their 10th wicket partnership then proceeded to put on 29 priceless runs by dint of intelligent batting and a match-turning negative decision by their umpire for a smart piece of O'Kelly stumping off Hamish Sim's bowling. Both Hamish and Adeel Iqbal bowled well towards the end## but when Adeel bowled his namesake Iqbal to wrap up the innings in the 35th over## the final total of 88 looked## surely## hardly a mountain to climb. But the fact that it was so low was heavily influenced by the extremely slow outfield which restricted boundary scoring to the extent that the total was realistically worth nearer 130.

Ballinger had to face 5 overs before tea## during which they rapidly lost Nick## promoted by the skipper to give him greater batting time## for a duck. As a past winner## albeit lost in the mists of time## of the club batting prize## Nick's time will surely come again! After tea## Richard and Rollo proceeded encouragingly well## and the match was beginning to look safe until Rollo perished to a blinding catch in the deep## which on most other days would have gone to ground. 30 for 2 rapidly became 57 for 8 as a succession of batsmen failed to cope with hostile bowling on a somewhat unpredictable pitch and a cacophony of noise from the fielding side## who## sensing an unlikely win became more than a little over-excited (well## by BWCC's sedate and gentlemanly standards## anyway). Standing firm amidst the carnage was Jamie Kellock## coming in at No 6## batting for nigh on an hour for his excellent 17 before falling to a catch by the keeper (- and he walked## instantly). An equally obdurate partner was Evan## who complemented his splendid bowling performance by also resisting for nearly an hour## and remaining unbeaten with 15. Partnered at the end by Will Reid## the pair looked as if they might emulate the Monks Risborough 10th wicket stand## but with 3 overs left## and only 4 runs required for victory## Will directed an otherwise admirable hook-shot straight at square leg## who gleefully held it## and was mobbed by his team mates in a scene reminiscent of the Lions' supporters in Sydney## or indeed the crowd on "Murray Mount".

Compared with last week's wretched display this was a really good performance## especially by the young players in the team## who all contributed well## and it also gave Rob McIntyre his first experience of 1st XI League cricket## which appeared to leave both him and James quite unfazed.Also impressive was the shrewd handling of the field-placings. "Years of experience" (- I Maciver)

This beautiful sunny Sunday was overshadowed with the awful news that one of the Hyde Heath team due to play in this match had died suddenly in the week## having played the previous Sunday. At the age of 46 he leaves a wife and daughter. There was a minutes silence before the game in his memory.

Captain Nick Tegg won the toss and decided to bat on what looked a superb wicket. The game understandably got off to a subdued start with both teams coming to terms with the situation. Nick Tegg was the first to go with the score on 29 with Max Dugdale at the other end looking in good form## stroking the ball about in controlled fashion. Basty was next in but never got going and was bowled without troubling the scorer. Monty Thompson was next to join Max and both looked very confident before Max fell to another great delivery. In came Hamish who also looked to appreciate the conditions. Monty was the fourth wicket to fall to another great delivery## all four batsmen bowled by Foster with his controlled left arm swing. Toby Lyons## making his Sunday debut## out without scoring. Ballinger now 86 for 5 off 23 overs and in need of inspiration. In came Jake Cutter who took up the challenge going on to make 43 off 32 deliveries before mistiming a full toss straight back to the bowler. Dom Brown and Matt OKelly went cheaply and it was left to Ben Dugdale and Alex Howe to get Ballinger to a respectable 187 for 9## putting on 49 off the final 8 overs.

After a pleasant but rather expensive tea Hyde Heath took to the middle in confident mood with the opening pair looking to take on the Ballinger bowling. With the score on 33 off 6 overs Dom Brown deceived the left handed Haddock and the whole of the Ballinger team with a wonderful slower delivery out of the back of his hand## one to live in Ballinger folk lore. Unfortunately## this momment of magic did not manage to slow the scoring and Hyde Heath raced to 112 off 18 overs before Monty Thompson deceived the opening bat and Max Dugdale taking a very sharp stumping. With the score on 121 off 20 overs it was the same combination## Monty deceiving the bat and Max quick to remove the bails. Hyde Heath now needing 67 runs from the remaining 18 0vers. Wickets from Jake Cutter and 2 from Ben Dugdale kept things interesting but with wickets to spare Hyde Heath managed to chase down the required runs with 4 overs remaining.

A great game## played in great spirit under a cloudless sky but under the darkest of circumstances. Credit to all involved.

Captain Evan Webster won yet another toss and chose to bat on what looked a good wicket on yet another beautiful sunny evening. What could possibly go wrong? Well at 15 for 3 off 6 overs it appeared to be the batting. Good opening bowling on an unpredictable wicket had Jake## Max and Hamish back in the pavilion in quick time. Ben Dugdale and Alex Howe resumed their Sunday unbeaten partnership and put on 34 off 5 overs before Alex was trapped LBW. Kenny Holt didn't stay long which brought Toby Lyons to the middle in his first appearance for the under 17's. He put on 17 runs in partnership with Dom Brown and a further 19 with Will Reid and finished on 23 not out off 24 deliveries## taking Ballinger to 110 for 7 off their 20 overs. Not bad considering but was it going to be enough?

CSP took to the middle in confident mood but excellent bowling from Alex Howe and Will Reid soon put an end to that. CSP found themselves on 7 for 4 off 5 overs. Rob Farquhar and Hamish Sim were next on and the quality of the bowling remained at a high level not giving the opposition any easy runs. The next wicket fell at 48## a great delivery from Hamish## the next at 48## another great delivery from Hamish and the next at 48## a good catch from Evan Webster off Will Reid's final over. Ben Dugdale and Dom Brown joined the party and both took wickets. Ben tempting the batsmen out of his crease for Max to remove his bails. CPS finishing on 70 for 9 off their 20 overs.

Great effort by the boys## good to have batting ability through the order and with the excellent bowling options available we're always in with a shout. On to Ley Hill for the league decider.

A beautiful sunny evening## the league title still a poosibility## captain Evan Webster winning the toss yet again and deciding to bat## thinks we're looking good and the boys in confident mood. Max Dugdale cautiously looks at the first delivery## then middles the second## cover dives and puts out his right hand and miraculously holds on to the ball. Max walks off in disbelief and on comes Hamish Sim much earlier then hoped. He and Jake Cutter get the innings back on track before Jake has a moment of madness and calls for a run that was never on. Ben Dugdale up next with the score on 41 for 2 off 6 overs. Another decent partnership develops before Hamish holes out to mid off 76 for 3 off 14. In comes Dom Brown## out goes Ben Dugdale holing out to the same shot as Hamish. Will Reid to the middle with Ballinger in need of salvation. Over 16 sums up the game so far: . W 1nb-1 . W W 1wd 1wd . 3 wickets## 4 byes## 1 run. Ballinger 85 for 6 soon becomes 88 for 7 off 17. Will does his bet to inject some life into the innings and finishes on 16 not out off 12 balls with Kenny Holt falling to the last ball of the innings. Ballinger 108 for 7 off 20 overs. Surely not enough even with our bowling options.

Ley Hill take control early and push the score to 52 for the first wicket off 8 overs## a sharp stumping by Max of Jake Cutters leg spin. Another quick wicket## the dangerous Joe Batt## well caught by Connor Underwood of the bowling of Ben Dugdale offers some light but this is short lived with some erratic bowling and fielding allowing the opposition to get to 96 off 14 overs before James Fray takes a good catch off Evan Webster's wicket maiden over. Sadly too little too late as Ley Hill reach the required total with 4 overs remaining.

No league title## no longer the holders of The Ley Hill Challenge Cup## not this season anyway. We'll be back!!!!

On a scorching hot afternoon Richard O'Kelly was asked by his team mates to toss up## since Ian Maciver had failed to make the 1.15 deadline. Cadmore End's skipper called correctly## thus condemning Ballinger to an arduous stint in the field## where## unlike the previous week at Monks Risborough## the outfield was lightning fast and bumpy## and the pitch another Kellock gem.

With a near full-strength side for a change## the extra maturity in years and experience was somewhat offset by an occasional lack of athletic fielding on the boundaries## redeemed by superlative work from Will Reid whose chasing and diving were admirable## plus the usual excellent fielding by Jono Lacey. An injury to Evan Webster meant that after taking a wicket in his first over## he had to come off## after his three overs had cost 25 runs. Nick Adams was his customary economical self## his ten overs yielding a mere 35## with one wicket## and had several other half chances flash through the slips. A partnership of 69 for the 4th wicket was broken by Carlton Siddle when he bowled J Ahmed for 56## but the scoreboard could barely keep pace when M Luqman scored 31 off 12 balls## including 4 sixes## largely at the expense of the luckless Andy Thompson## and the run rate rose to 6 an over. Ian Maciver weighed in with four wickets towards the end## albeit expensive ones## and Cadmore End assisted with three run-outs## gratefully accepted. Richard kept a clean sheet behind the stumps## with no byes## and was visibly furious with himself when missing a sharp stumping chance. A final total of 229 meant that certain Ballinger batsmen might have to forget recent poor form## and take advantage of the friendly pitch and fast outfield.

Such expectations often mean that the batsmen chance their arms all too early## but Matt Riley and Richard## as the in-form batsmen this season## set about their task in exemplary manner. After a circumspect start both were soon scoring freely## and so confident were they## against an increasingly silent and dispirited fielding side (the start of the Ramadan fast perhaps contributing) that it started to look as if Ballinger might achieve a ten wicket victory. But with the stand worth a mighty 172## Richard was caught for a superlative 85## and in the 35th over and the total 197## Matt followed## only 12 short of a deserved ton.
