The big question was now whether the asking rate could be maintained. Rollo went on the attack immediately## and was unlucky (yet again!) to be held in the deep for a quick-fire 17## whereupon there followed a clatter of wickets as 204 for 2 became 215 for 6## the fielding side recovered their voices## and finger nails began to be chewed in the pavilion.To the rescue came the cool head of Andy Thompson## who finished with a blaze of boundaries## to see Ballinger home with an over to spare (- it appears## as the scorers## affected by excitement and unaccustomed heat## had by this time temporarily lost the plot!).

An exciting end to a good match## and a result desperately needed if we are to avoid the spectre of relegation. Every point will be vital## so if anyone could volunteer to umpire in the next two matches before Dick Beard returns to these shores## that would be worth 6 points!

This was Ballinger's first visit to Ley Hill 3rds new home at Barn Meadow in Old Amersham and what a day to pick. The temperatures up in the 30s## children are cooling off in the river## the pitch looks good and the skipper manages to lose the toss. Not a happy team did he lead out onto the vast acres.

Dom Brown and George Cooke opened up for the Waggoners and George in particular was quickly into his stride but the first wicket fell to a brilliant bit of fielding by Sam Peters when he ran out one of the Hill's openers. George then cleaned up the other. Then it was time for change and on came Sam to replace George and Tom Petrie to replace Dom. Sam struck in his first over and then Tom had danger man Petrie dropped off his first ball. How costly would that prove as he was going along really well. Not a problem for Sam though when he removed his middle stump next over.

The home team were scoring at about 4 an over but it was difficult to work out what a decent score was gong to be as the pitch wasnt quite as quick as it first looked.

Tom got his reward in the next over## then it was all change with Tom going to 'keeper and Freddie Thompson coming on to bowl with Ben Dugdale at the other end. Ben took a wicket with his second ball and Freddie in his second over. Chris Jones had now started to strike the ball well for the Hill and looked like he could take the game away from the Waggoners but a liitle teaser from Ben was too much tempatation and he fell for a well struck 32.

With the score on 104## 8 down and still 13 overs to go Ballinger were thinking about an early tea and lots of overs to use but two of the Hill's youngsters soon changed that plan. James Woodley and Max Lee added an excellent 33 runs before the returning Dom managed to get Jamie to hole out to Freddie. George was now back on and quickly removed the last man.

We bowled and fielded well and. although we had been refreshed by drinks every 10 overs everyone did really well not to wilt under the blazing sun. 

Derek Richards and Tom opened up for the Waggoners with the comforting words from the skipper that "they havent got anyone quick". Unfortunately he hadn't come across the Petrie twins before. They were both quick and hostile. Derek and Tom did brilliantly to survive and slowly but surely Derek found his timing and the pair added a very handy 32 runs before Derek perished caught behind. Bastie didnt last long## Steve Conway looked a million dollars for 8 balls then Mat O'Kelly joined Tom and they patienty put on 29 for the 4th wicket. Tom fell in the 29th over for only 19 but## by occupying the crease and helping others keep the score board ticking over he'd done a brilliant job.

By now we'd all realised that this wasnt the easiest pitch to bat on and the Hill bowlers were making sure that it was as hard as possible.

Dom Brown got away with a very easy drop catch only to try and repeat it 2 balls later with a different result. This brought Ben to the crease and his rapid 25 off 16 balls changed the game completely. Annoyingly he got out with still 22 required and 7 overs left ( By now we were very grateful for the extra 2 overs we got for bowling the Hill out). Sam Peters hadn't troubled the scorers and Matt had finally gone for a well played 20. Skipper regarded this as his best innings for the club so far. Freddie and George added another 8 before Freddie was briliantly caught by Max Lee the Hil's 'keeper. This meant that the skipper had to don his pads and join George.

14 required 5 overs left. George patiently working the singles whilst the skipper is trying to work out how to bat. 4 overs 11 required## 3 overs 10 required## 2 overs 9 required##  last over 7 required. Wily old pro Peterson to bowl it to George. Dot ball## wide## dot ball## a single and now there are 100 years of experience facing each other. Who is going to crack. A straight ball and the skipper finds the middle of his bat and manages to hit it for 4. The scores are tied. A very lenient umpire doesnt give the next ball as wide down the leg side. This is it## last ball.

The skipper cant believe it when the ball is so wide outside the offstump he cant reach it and the Waggoners have won a realy good game of cricket.

A great day and well done to both teams for coping so well with the heat. As always played in the right spirit.

We finally managed to play this rearranged game on a sun-drenched evening (July 15th) at the picturesque Cookham Dean ground.

Ballinger batted first and were tied down to 30-2 in the first eight overs against some tight bowling. From then on## Dominic and Hamish started smashing the ball all round the ground with Dom playing the aggressor and Hamish the anchor as both scored excellent 50's. Toby## Sam and Rob also joined in the batting fun as the boys reached a commanding total of 162## their highest score of the season.

Cookham Dean started well and looked like they would mount a challenge. Their runrate was averaging eight per over off the first eight overs. Then Ballinger seized control with some tight bowling## wickets and committed fielding. Dom's and Rob's bowling was excellent and accurate as they clean bowled five of the top order with Dom making the early breakthroughs. Dylan and Scott also picked up wickets## and then James and Harry both enjoyed a chance to bowl the final overs as Ballinger closed in on an impressive win. Matt's keeping was impressive despite the variable bounce## while Sam took an excellent catch in the deep and ground fielding was excellent on a super-fast pitch and outfield.

I really like the intensity## commitment  and team spirit Ballinger showed in the field. Dom captained well and played an all-round Man of the Match performance. It was pleasing to end a tough league season on a high with a good victory where everyone got a chance to contribute.
Phoenix OBs withdraw from the league enabling MBL to cause further chaos
This game was cancelled due to cock-up caused by MBL

This game was played on 22nd June and it has taken until 17th July to write the match report.

That's how annoyed I was with our performance.

There were no positives to take from the game except it finished early.

A slight break in the weather and a choice of two great strips, everything was set for an enjoyable game against one of the division’s more affable teams. Our team once again gutted to augment the holidaying first team, and with skipper Kerry very much looking forward to a trip to Colchester it was a much changed side with lots of known unknowns in it. Lulled by the overhead cloud cover, stand in Skipper Branigan won the toss and, envisaging a leisurely afternoon in the cool conditions, stuck Waddesdon in.

First over completed, a peach of a ball from Rob Farquhar moving back through the gate and Waddesdon 5 for 1, what’s not to like?  Hmm. Two fairly wayward opening 4 over spells completed, the sun beating down, the oppo on 67 without further loss and the frustrated Kerry whispering advice from the scorers hutch it suddenly didn’t seem quite so pretty! A measure of control was needed, so a change of pace was called for – quicker at one end courtesy of Sam Peters whilst from the Pavilion End Monty Thompson weaved his off spin. A couple of very difficult chances went begging, whilst a faint nick of Sam was snaffled by Freddie Thompson behind the stumps but ignored by batsman and umpire alike. The 15th over saw an end to the second wicket partnership as the scenario was repeated and the roar from the Ballinger fielders proved too much to ignore this time, but by now they had reached 96 of the first 15 overs. Monty continued to restrict the score, whilst Sam was replaced by James Fray at the Football Stadium end. Drinks – thankfully! 124 for 2 off the first 20, Monty’s spell nearly finished and bowling options limited. The Skipper had a few things to sort out. The athletic Steve Conway was summoned and sent to the Pavilion to emerge Prior-like in pads and gloves – increasing the bowling attack by one even if Waddesdon were to be deprived of Conway’s magic with ball !

A crucial passage of play then ensued with James finding a better line and length, a despairing diving chance was spilled by the skip, who was relieved and reprieved 2 balls later thanks to a fine catch out on the mid wicket boundary by Sam, and the dangerous looking Grantham was back in the hutch. By the 30th over, they were down to well below six an over but still only 3 wickets down. Time for the leg spin of the younger Thompson. Runs continued to accrue but now all of a sudden wickets started to tumble too. The highlight was an outstanding catch in the deep from Nick Peters capping off a fine fielding display on his debut. Sam dismissed Edwards for 80 with a surprise full bunger which he mysteriously declined to smack to the boundary and Ballinger could suddenly smell wickets. Thompson ran through the tail with a ruthlessness one expects from a cricketer bearing that name, and soon had 4 wickets to his name. Showing the trust in his older brother, that one likes to see from the youngest, he directed Monty to the long on boundary and told him to prepare himself. Two spilled catches later, followed by a run out of their last man – Andy would be proud of the brazenness of the family jug avoidance! 232 all out of 39.5 overs – a mighty score but it might have been a lot more and on that track there was always a chance.

A fine tea from Veronica saw the Ballinger team in better spirits (well maybe not Monty who already feared the family dinner table as Freddie retold the story for the nth time).

Ballinger needed a solid platform and so turned to the dependable Derek Richards as opening partner to Monty. A surprisingly brisk start set the right tempo before Derek perished with the score on 24 . Monty was joined by Basty and the runs continued to flow (boundaries mainly as neither seemed too keen on that tiresome chore of actually running between the wickets). Basty was back in the Pavilion with score on 57 but at least we were scoring freely. Out strode Nick Peters, on debut, could his batting match his earlier fielding? At the other end Monty was piling on the pain and had soon accumulated 50 – maybe he’d have some ammunition for that dreaded family get together after all. What followed could only be called a dismantling of the Waddesdon attack that used 7 bowlers in an attempt to shore things up. By drinks we were well ahead of the required rate as the batsmen hit the ball to all parts of the ground, Monty mainly through the covers and straight down the ground, whist Nick was more mid wicket and third man!

Monty spent a while in the nervous nineties before finally reaching a fine century, his first, before generously deciding to give someone else a chance and departing for 101, with the game in the bag. Steve Conway joined Nick, who by this stage had reached his 50, and Ballinger cruised to victory by 7 wickets with 5 overs to spare – an unlikely looking scenario at drinks half way through the Waddesdon innings.

Thanks to Jamie for preparing another belter – the same strip that Cadmore had scored 229 on the previous week only to have that chased down by our Firsts in an uncannily similar game and approaching 1000 runs in 150 overs.  A fine all round display and a victory that all could share the credit for as we stuck at it under difficult conditions in the field. A fine all round display from Monty and Nick were the pick and a final thanks to Andy who did the decent thing and turned up at the Swan to buy the beer!

Captain Richard OKelly took his team of youth## experience## inexperience and the unknown to Cublington on another beautiful sunny afternoon. After winning the toss he sent his troops in to bat. Nick Tegg ( experience ) and Max Dugdale ( youth ) opened for Ballinger and got off to a great start before Nick fell with the score on 62. In came Basty Richards ( youthful experience ) and he and Max added 74 before Max was stumped going for another big hit## Ballinger 136 for 2 off 25. Ben Dugdale up next ( youth ) out goes Basty with the score on 145. In comes David Cooke ( unknown experience ) and he and Ben add another 34 before David's bails are removed. To the crease Dom Brown ( youth ) another 12 runs added before Ben is out after making a solid 25. Matthew OKelly ( youth ) next in## Dom Brown next out## Ballinger 206 for 6 off 39 overs. Stuart Fray ( unknown experience )##runs himself out## in comes James to try and restore family pride only to be bowled first ball## a peach of a delivery from Cublingtons best bowler. In comes George Cooke ( youth ) with 2 balls ramaining and falling to the last ball of the innings. Ballinger finishing on 207 for 9 off their 40 overs. Still unused in the shade of the pavillion Richard OKelly ( experience hampered by injury ). Not a bad total but looked a little under par given the conditions.

After an enjoyable tea and welcome shade Cublington took up the challenge in confident mood and pushed the score to 36 off 5 overs before losing their first wicket. Captain OKelly having to carefully manage his youthfull bowling options with the various age restrictions. Another quick wicket## again falling to Dom Brown with the score on 40 looked promising for Ballinger. A partnership of 76 for the next wicket took Cublington to 116 for off 19 overs## a great catch by the captain off Ben's bowling but the opposition now well ahead of the required rate. Captain OKelly continued to juggle his attack but some big hitting and dropped catches kept the opposition in control. Wickets continued to fall but Cublington managed to chase down the required runs with 4 overs remaining.

An enjoyable game## played in a good spirit on a lovely day. A good team effort highlighted by a great batting performance from Max and excellent bowling from George.

Firstly a huge thank you to James Bateson for being Umpire all day and all of the parents and children who came and supported their sons and brothers. I also apologise in advance if I missed out any special mentions as there were so many outstanding performances and I believe that we could have won the tournament with any combination of players in the squad which is a great reflection on the players and  BWCC.

 

SQUAD

 

Freddie Bateson U8

Charlie Berens U7

Thomas Berens

Max Conway - Captain

Max Hayes U7

Tim Hayes

Casper Jack

Matthew Jones

Sebastian Phillips

Archie Tatum

Raphi Weatherall U8

Oliver Webb

 

I arrived at an overcast Tring a few minutes late and missed the managers briefing## it was at this point I realised that I had clearly misunderstood how serious this competition was going to be as I walked past Harpenden’s team who were sitting in a semi-circle being spoken to by their team manager## their team coach also supported by the team psychologist## physio and 11 plus tutors. The other 14 clubs were in similar huddles to Harpenden or were in the nets being barked at by athletic looking chaps in Nike tracksuits with COACH on their backs.

 

I had Ballinger boys set up camp on the square between pitches 1 and 2 where I thought we were going to play our matches and they had a game of Kwik cricket in full swing whilst I arranged where we were going to have the planned picnic and the Ballinger dads worked out how long it would take to get to the bar and back from where our base was and how many pints it would be possible to carry if they were using the flimsy plastic cups without a tray## so we were all set.

 

I had understood this was meant to be a family fun day and had selected a 12 boy squad of 8 under 9’s## 2 Under 8’s and 2 under 7’s  and I was going to make sure that all of the boys had games as that is what I had promised## so we now needed to be slightly tactical and see if we could win the first game.

 

MATCH 1

Our first match was against Harpenden## our captain Max Conway put them in to bat## Oliver ## Archie## Max and Raphi all took wickets and kept them to 219 for 4##  our openers then came in Oliver and Thomas who got us to 217 after the first 2 overs## Tim and Sebastian took us to 230## Archie and Freddie moved us up to 236 and then Raphi and Max finished us off on 249 with us losing only 1 wicket. We were in business and the boys were fielding exceptionally well all guarding their territories and communicating like professionals.

 

MATCH 2

Our second match was against Berkhamstead A and we were put in to bat## our openers Oliver and Thomas took us up to 227 off the first two overs with Oliver striking two sixes and Thomas stealing some wonderful singles## Tim and Sebastian came out and again caused Berkhamstead lots of problem as the big hitting pair found both found the boundary and were clearly trying to win the £10 bet to land a ball in Matthew Webb’s open top car next to an old side screen on the square## they moved us to 241## Archie and Matthew took us up to 260 with Archie narrowly missing the £10 prize with his wonderful six## Raphi and Max finished the innings taking us up to 276 for the loss of just one wicket.

Oliver and Archie bowled the first two overs leaving Berkhamstead on 204## Thomas and Sebastian held them to 214 at the end of the fourth over## Tim and Matthew finished them going backwards as two wickets were taken in Matthews over leaving them on 212## Max then bowled a maiden and Raphi let them finish on 214. I was now thinking we can get through to the semi-finals as we have beaten these sides quite convincingly.

 

MATCH 3

The Sun is now beating down on us. Time to bring on our two 7 year olds against Tring## we were put in to bat and we opened with Oliver and Max Hayes [U7]## Oliver hit three fours## a six and a single and Max Hayes faced 3 balls in his first ever match## dot ball to settle in ## then he hits a four and finishes off with a single## quite something and they left the crease with the team on 233 off two overs. Freddie our talented eight year old again found the boundary twice and Charlie Berens our other U7 stole two classy singles with lightening running between the stumps## we were now on 254 from 4 overs## Matthew and Casper score off every ball in their first over with Casper hitting two fours and a single ## they walked off leaving us on 279## in come Raphi and Max who as a pair put the opposition into panic with their desire to score off every ball## they took us up to 302 from the 8 overs which was the highest total from the tournament.

Tring come in to bat Freddie takes a wicket then Raphi bowls a maiden ## so Tring are going backwards and are on 196 after two overs## Max Hayes U7 takes a wicket with his second ball and Casper bowls and Tring are on 210 after 4 overs## Charlie our next U7 comes to bowl and not to be outdone he also takes a wicket as does Matthew with a superb catch by Casper## they are on 215 after 6## Max C and Oliver keep them down to 222 ## So we are through to the Semi-Finals.

 

Semi-Finals

 

It felt like an England v Germany game## lots of polite hello’s ## but they were there to win## our boys hadn’t had a break now for almost three hours## so they took on some fluids and Max put Chesham in to bat## Oliver Webb opened  five dot balls and the last ball a wide## gosh Chesham don’t like this## Archie lines up takes aim and first ball a wicket## a run and then another wicket## oh dear Chesham are on 198 after two overs and their scorer begins twitching next to me## Thomas comes on again very tight bowling with only a no-ball in the over## Tim  has his over and Chesham are on 205 from 4 overs Freddie and Sebastian bowl with Sebastian taking a great wicket## they are on 214 from six overs## we know we have them as their best batsman takes to field## Max C takes 3 wickets in his over one of which was an amazing catch by Raphi and then Raphi finishes them off with another one## so we have to chase 211.

 

We take to the field our solid openers Oliver and Thomas knowing what is needed## they take us to 201 as we lost a rare wicket## Tim and Sebastian take to the crease ## Tim under instructions to defend## first ball Tim plays a forward defensive## he has clearly been paying attention## next ball he steals a single## next ball he hits a four and then another one## both off his legs## they walk off leaving us on a solid 209## we need a net three runs to get through to the final## Archie and Freddie come in and Archie is on fire playing a variety of quality shots supported by Freddie who was in total control backing up from the other end## a great pair who left us t runs ahead on 213## so Raphi and Max come in for the last two overs ## we take five runs off over number 7 so we are on 218 as Chesham’s fast bowler appears bowling to Raphi who thinks this is great fun as he is much slower than his brothers## dot dot and a single and Max calmly defends the last three balls and we finish on 219 and into the Final.

 

FINAL

 

The boys are now looking quite frazzled so more fluids and biscuits are administered and we put Langleybury in to bat. Oliver opens the bowling and first ball a wicket and they are going backwards on the scoreboard## Archie comes on to bowl and we take another one ## they are on 202 after two overs## Thomas bowls five dot balls and so does Tim and they are now on 207 after four overs## Sebastian and Matthew next to bowl and Sebastian takes two wickets sending them tumbling backwards and they finish on 208 after six overs Max and Raphi now on and Raphi bowls a maiden to finish the session leaving us 218 to chase.

 

Oliver and Thomas open up again Oliver finding the boundary twice and both stealing quick singles ## we are on 217 after two overs and the Langleybury scorer is no longer communicating with me. In comes Tim and Sebastian## Tim hits three fours and a six and the two boys stride off with us on 232## Archie and Matthew come in and Archie again scores off nearly all of the balls with two singles ## two fours and his final attempt to win this £10 with a superb six## so we are on 240 after six overs as Raphi and Max come in## both boys again finding the boundary and finishing on 253## another convincing win and us winning the tournament.

 

 

Regards

 

 

Steve

The heatwave relented for Ballinger's visit to the attractive National Trust surroudings at Waddesdon## and having (unusually) won the toss## Ian Davies## back with us after his hols## decided to take first knock. With current form batsmen Matt Riley and Richard O'Kelly both in the side again## this seemed a sensible choice. A slow steady start was to be expected## but the scoring rate accelerated encouragingly## as they took the total to 57 before Matt went## caught in the 18th over. However## Richard was scoring freely and the score had reached 85 when## soon after he tweaked a hamstring responding to a call for a very sharp single## he too holed out## for a well struck 56. By this time the Waddesdon bowlers were starting to cause problems## notably Atteek who persuaded umpire Miles Dugdale## nobly officiating at both ends (as well as ensuring both scorers were doing their jobs properly) to give two LBW's## including skipper Davies first ball. Ouch## its a long way to come from South London for that! As usual## Carlton could be relied on to shepherd the wobbly middle-order## as 85 for 2 became 124 for 6## and when he was out for a fine 40## the total was 140 for 7##and only two overs left .  Two towering 6's from the new Nick Adams bat then put a much better look to the board as the innings closed on 162 for 7.

In contrast to the Ballinger start## Waddesdon were immediately in trouble## with both Nick and Carlton gaining LBW's. That was as good as it got## though## and Waddesdon were well up with the required run-rate by the time the third wicket fell on 66## with the departure of the hard-hitting Bird (LBW## again) for 45## the first of Andy Thompson's three victims. The middle-order## like Ballinger's## lost their way## and at 96 for 6 in the 24th over## a victory looked likely. Alas## Waddesdon's number seven## Zagram## who had previously conceded 26 runs off his three overs## decided to get his own back. He launched a blistering assault on the bowling## taking 20 off Carlton's last over (plus two byes!)## and completely swung the game in Waddesdon's favour. At 160 for 6## and only 3 required for victory## Zagram drove a ball boundary-wards## and sauntered down the pitch## convinced that it would be a four  In some frenzied confusion## in the end it was only one run. He therefore deprived himself of a 50## as he was bowled by Nick immediately afterwards for 49## and with a run out at the other end## suddenly there was a gleam of hope for Ballinger. However## it was too late## and Waddesdon eased home by two wickets## and five overs to spare. Chief wicket-taker was Andy Thompson## with 3 for 50## but a word of praise for Ian Davies## who bowled a very tidy spell of 9 overs## taking 1 for 31## thereby justifying his lengthy journey!

A pleasant match## well contested## against sociable opponents. As usual## Ballinger's youngsters## this time the Dugdales## Dom Brown## and Matt O'Kelly all acquitted themselves well in the field. Where would we be without them?
<html />

Belsize Village Cricket Club## the Currymen## were Sundays visitors to the mildly moist acres of Ballinger. Captain Stuart McGowan won the toss and against Ballinger tradition chose to field on a wicket that he thought could be unpredictable after the heavy rain of the previous evening. How right he was. Some decent bowling and unpredictable bounce made it difficult for VCC who struggled all through their innings. Wickets fell constantly with the Currymen finding the Ballinger attack and wicket too hot for their liking. Afternoon tea was looking more likely to be a late lunch as they limped to 101 all out off 29 overs with the clock not yet reaching 3.45pm.

Ballinger in to bat until tea at 4.30pm## Max obviously deciding to try and finish the game before and launching the first ball to cover for a well taken catch. Fally## apparently playing to the same script## hit the next ball## with a similar shot## to the same fielder## 0 for 2 off 2 balls . Two Bombay Ducks. Steve Carter in next and the Currymen with renewed hope. Good bowling from VCC## also helped by some unpredicatble bounce continued to challenge Steve and Basty with Steve falling on 17 trying to hit across a straight one. In came Monty to try and see Ballinger through until tea without any further mishap only to be caught 2 balls later with VCC crowding the bat. 17 for 4 off 7 overs## now things were getting very hot for Ballinger. Ben to the middle and he and Basty managed to avoid further bloodshed before tea.

After a welcome break and excellent tea provided by Veronica Richards## Ben and Basty took up the challenge with the viisitors in confident mood and sensing an unexpected upset. Ben and Basty had other ideas and batted the next 20 overs sensibly## adding 76 before Ben was bowled after making an excellent 40. With the score now 93 for 5 in came Alex with Ballinger only needing 9 to win and the clock not yet at 6.15pm. He and Basty saw the team home in the 30th over but not without a scare or two along the way. Basty finishing on 40 not out.

An enjoyable game## played in great spirit with the weather staying kind throughout. A disapponted VCC off to the Swan to drown their sorrows## followed by a curry at the New Akash before their journey back to North London.

It was supposed to rain. From 6am Saturday## said the Met Office## and it would be torrential. With this apocalyptic forecast## the captains went out to toss up## under a hot sunny sky## with no sign of what might be beyond the horizon. Latest indications## via numerous smart phones now suggested rain at 4 - or possibly 6pm. So## what to do? Ian Davies## having won the toss## and with a vastly changed side at his disposal## including 6 juniors## decided to be brave## and batted first## A lot would depend on Richard O'Kelly maintaining his run of form## and Andy Thompson who opened with him. It was a shock then## when the first to go with the total only 14 was Richard## caught behind off a fine edge. Next in was Rob McIntyre## making only his second appearance for the Firsts. Not that one would have guessed## by the way he batted## with calm assurance. Andy## meanwhile after a quiet start was opening up with a string of boundaries## until he too got a thin edge## but this time undetected by the umpire## who sent him on his way LBW. In came Will Smith##holder of the club record highest score##for his first appearance of the season. He and Rob soon had the scoreboard speeding along## and reached 105 by the 21st over when Rob perished to one of those catches which are plucked from the sky when a boundary looks certain## for an excellent 32. Ian Davies## desperately in need of runs## now came to the crease. He was batting increasingly confidently## and with Will playing some delightful shots## it seemed that a 200+ total was in prospect## when Ian called Will for a risky single## onlyto seeWill run out by a direct hit. He had made 34## and was making batting look easy. Spinner Hafiz then accounted for Monty and Fally in the same over## while Ian struggled successfully to keep the score moving. Dom Brown and newcomer Theo Reynolds did well to add a few## and then Ian ##hitting outas he had to## was caught for a valliant 23## and the innings closed soon after## 168 all out in the 38th over.

Tea was taken with the skies starting to darken. The immediate question was whether Bradenham would manage to get 20 overs batting. Therafter##if the rain came## the result would be determined by run rate. It was inevitable therefore that they would seek to set a fast scoring rate from the off. There was nothing wrong with the rate## but their wickets soon started falling. Ian started things## trying out his spin as opener## and struck in the 4th over## courtesy of a fine stumping by Richard. Dom came on to replace him and although having difficulty finding his direction## took two quick wickets## one another fine piece of work by Richard who took a tumbling catch. With Bradenham 70 for 5 in the 14th over## Ballinger now had victory in sight-they thought - providing the rain kept away. But the next wicket did not go down until 100 was on the board## and then a seventh wicket stand of 55 due mostly to some big hitting by Sherazee (43) finally turned the game Bradenham's way. A couple more wickets fell## but with 42 overs at their disposal the batsmen could take it easy## and as it was they only needed 30 overs to pass the Ballinger score. All the Ballinger bowlers acquitted themselves well## with Dom taking 4 for 41 and Alex Howe 2 for 32. The fielding was excellent. All that was wrong was that Ballinger needed another 40 runs! And conceding 14 wides perhaps didn't help.

The rain did arrive. Around 7pm. And yes## it was torrential!

We're doomed Mr. Mainwairing## we're doomed was the cry coming form all the phone holding meteroligists. With this thought in mind the skipper went to the wicket with the Bradenham captain certain in his course of actions. Unfortuantely he lost the toss again.

The hosts skipper had no doubt about his plan either and the Waggoners were inserted with the intention of the home team to bowl us out quickly and then knock off the runs before armaggedon arrived.

 

Bastie and Tom opened up for the visitors and although it was slow progress they didnt look in any trouble from the bowlers but the pitch was interesting. After about 30 mins without mishap and the batting order settled our No5 had to depart to collect the missing member of the team. Not sure would have happened if we'd been fielding.

No sooner had he left the ground than Bastie - having looked very comfortable## got a leading edge. Matt O'Kelly was removed by a brilliant catch at slip## Steve Conway was run out by a rediculous peice of fielding## Tom finally fell to another catch and the skipper was changing the batting order so frequently that everyone was padded up but not sure when they were going in## and we're still two players short.

The skipper has to enter the fray at 6 which is oxygen country for him. Being bowled a straight one wasn't fair and certainly wasn'twhat he needed. Max Dugdale had now arrived was changed and straight into action and we though he and brother Ben might dig us out of the trench we were now in. Sadly Ben also missed a straight one## Freddie Thompson now strides to the crease and at 49 - 6 Bradenham's skippers plan was obviously working as they'd only bowled 24 overs.Freddie and Max set about doing a bit of a repair job before Max fell trying to thump a scouser back to Liverpool. Freddie kept plugging away and then Paul Branigan missed a straight one - anyone notice a theme here - and in comes Sam Phillips. He and Freddie then hustled the score along to 100 before Sam was caught and finally Fin Clark and Freddie bated out the last couple of overs taking us to 114

A respectable score considering where we were.

The skipper had a master plan. He was going to open with Freddie and Ben with the old ball. Frankly for the first 9 overs the Braddenham batters didnt have a clue how to play either Freddie's legspin or Ben's Off-spin. Ben took a wicket in his first over and suddenly the Wagoners were on their toes.

Unfortunatelyly with such a small total the required run rate of 2.8 was just too easy to maintain. Regardless of the efforts of the Ballinger bowlers## including a fine spell from Sam Phillips## and some outstanding catching by Bastie and Sam it was all too easy for the home side and they cruised home with 16 overs to spare.

We missed one very difficult chance which was the Braddenham opener who scored an unbeaten 59. If that had been taken who knows as we pretty confident they didnt have much left.

The rain## well it arrived an hour later whilst we're sat in the pub with the 1s nursing our collective wounds and did it rain - too late

A pleasant sunny afternoon greeted Ballinger at the equally pleasant Potten End ground## and skipper for the day Ian Maciver started proceedings by losing the toss## with the home side taking first knock. They were soon in trouble## with both Nick Adams and Andy Thompson quick to strike## and wickets fell regularly## with only Gurney defying the bowlers and keeping his side in the game. The total had reached 84 for 5 in the 25th over when a heavy and protracted shower sent the players off## and an early tea was taken## with loss of 4 overs from each team's 40 overs. Potten End's run rate was already quite good## thanks to their excellent judgement of quick singles## and following the break they tried to raise the tempo still more. The result was the rapid loss of wickets## including the prize one of Gurney (50)## so that they had slumped to 99 for 9 before a last wicket stand of 26## spearheaded by the aggressive Davis (26 not out) took them to 125 before the final wicket went down in the 35th over. Ballinger had looked very impressive in the field## with Jono Lacey and Hamish Sim saving plenty of runs## and Max Dugdale giving a sharp display behind the stumps. Andy ( 4 for 19) just pipped Nick (4 for 21) in the bowling honours department.

Ever keen to experiment## Ian sent the Thompsons## father and son## out to open the Ballinger reply.Neither found the going easy##against fast and short-pitched bowling## and just as they seemed to be weathering the storm## Andy was adjudged run out## having failed to ground his bat in completing a single. He was not convinced of the justice of this decision## but that's cricket## Andy! DRS where art thou? In came Rollo## desperately searching for some runs this season## only to depart caught at the wicket 3rd ball. 13 for 2 and 9 overs gone - not good. The arrival of Rob McIntyre immediately steadied the ship## not for the first time## and he was going well when another run out incident befell the team. He had## immediately prior to this## aggravated a knee injury## and when faced with Monty three quarters of the way down the pitch for a non-existent run## gamely sacrificed his own wicket. Next in was Jono Lacey## who wasted little time in boosting the slow scoring rate## and with Monty batting in Riley-esque mode at the other end## the total had reached 65 when Jono departed for a well-struck 18. Monty## by now joined by Jamie Kellock## was starting to hit the ball really well## and the score had reached 108 when he fell undeservedly one short of his 50. Quick runs still being a neccessity## next in was go-to hitter Nick## and this time he obliged with a rapid 12## leaving Max to see Ballinger home with a couple of lusty blows## and three overs to spare.

Having lost to Potten End earlier in the season## this was welcome revenge## and the points gained lifted us to the top half of the league table## an unaccustomed pleasure! We should not get carried away## as the remaining fixtures are difficult## particularly the final two. It was good to see Dick Beard in the white coat ##back from his Florida holiday - well most of us thought so!

Amersham on the Hill was the venue for this 40 over encounter. Amersham won the toss and chose to bat on what looked a good wicket. Their 1st X1 openers## looking to find some form in the Sundays## put the Ballinger attack under immediate pressure with some great stroke play and powerful hitting. On a small ground with a fast outfield the score escalated## 85 off 10 and the bowlers not quite knowing what to do. 129 off 14 before the 1st wicket## Jake tempting the bat down the wicket and Fally swiftly removing the bails. Jake claimed his second wicket with the score on 156## a good catch taken by David Cooke. Unfortunately the opener was still in and going strong## closing in on his ton. On 197 off 22 overs he retired unbeaten on 102. The runs continued to flow with the occasional pause with the fall of a wicket## Amersham getting to 322 with 3 balls remaining but deciding that was enough carnage for the day and the possibility they would run out of balls. But would it be enough!!!!!

After an excellent tea and much soul searching## a beleaguered Ballinger took to the middle in pursuit of the impossible. Basty and Monty opened only to find their 1st X1 bowlers were also looking to regain some form. Basty was the first to go with the score on 10## Jake to the middle. Monty next to go with the score on 26. Sam Cooke## alias George for scorecard purposes## next up. The pair then proceed to put on 139 off 20 overs## Jake the main run scorer but Sam playing his part before being bowled after making an excellent 37. Jake closing in on his maiden century is joined by Toby Lyons who unfortunately gets the best delivery of the day and gloves his first ball to the keeper. Fally next to join Jake with Ballinger still trying to chase down the impossible. Jake passes the magic 100 before exhaustion takes its toll and he's bowled off his pads from not a great delivery. Fally is joined by Ben with the pair looking to up the rate with the score on 175 for 6 off 28. Ben out## well caught going for a cover drive. In comes David Cooke with Fally on the charge. David next to go with the score on 203 off 31 overs. Tom Petrie to the middle and the boys still giving it a go. Fally finally falling after making a swift 32 off 23 deliveries. Alex Howe joins the fray and makes an even quicker 32 off 17 deliveries before skying one. Ballinger all out for 275 in the final over.

A great game## played in good spirit. A strong Amersham side always in control but a spirited Ballinger gave it their best.

At 1.15pm when the skipper went out to toss up the visitors only had 6 men and how tempting it was to bat first. The arrival of a car which disgorged 4 players was enough to change his mind when he actually won the toss for a change.

When drinks were taken Cadmore were on just 80 off 20 overs which## on another excellent pitch and very fast outfield## meant the skipper was feeling rather the pleased with himself. Tom Petrie in particular and Sam Peters as well had kept a reasonable line although a few too many wides were being conceded. Tom had removed one opener with the help of a smart catch by ‘keeper Freddie Thompson and then Ben Dugdale## who’d replaced Tom removed danger man Dutton.

Unfortunately drinks meant a change of ‘keeper and a change of approach by Cadmore. Carnage ensued with the visitors accelerating form 80 to 262 in just 20 overs. No bowler was unscathed but Freddie was probably the unluckiest with several deliveries just missing the stumps. He did get his reward with 4 wickets but the damage had been done. 43 extras was not a pretty sight in the score book

A slightly disgruntled team ambled off for tea.

A torn hamstring to ‘new’ boy Richard Devas meant a rethink in the batting order but  Peter Petrie was happy to step up to the plate and he and Bastie set off in pursuit of the impossible target. Soon both were playing some delightful shots with Bastie in particular reeling off a selection of wonderful drives. The moans from the sidelines were now becoming cheers of encouragement as the pair kept the run rate within sight. Peter fell when the score was 70 so Bastie was joined by the newly promoted Ben who announced his arrival with a well struck 4. These two continued to almost keep up with the run rate and batting points were being accrued with alacrity. Bastie was finally out for an excellent 56 but Ben was now into his stride. Steve Conway made a brief visit to the crease before complaining of a pulled hamstring as well. This meant the arrival of a runner in the shape of Sam Peters. To say the speed of the running between the wickets increased is like saying Usain Bolt is quick. Ben and Sam were scampering singles## turning 1s into 2s and even 2s into 3s. Great to watch and soon had the Cadmore fielders in disarray.

Steve decided## with the encouragement of the umpire## to leave the field and let Ian McCloughlin have a go. He did but needed more chalk. Paul Branigan now joined Ben who had already smashed his way past 50. Paul played some delightful late cuts and guides helping Ben add another 20 before he guided one onto his stumps. Ben was finally caught for a really good 77 justifying his skipper’s confidence in him.

The final bonus point was passed as the game came to its inevitable conclusion. 220 would have been a sensible score to chase but it was great to see the batters doing their best to chase down the target.17 points was a decent reward for everyone’s efforts.

A lovely day## decent opposition and a great tea. What more could we ask for?

For once Ballinger fielded an almost unchanged side## against visitors bottom of the table Ley Hill## with Ian Davies back## and for once winning the toss. Taking the field first## Ballinger were immediately gifted two wickets## with messrs Lown and Clarke## who had both taken 60's off us in June## back in the hutch thanks to ill-advised run selection and excellent Ballinger fielding## and the total only 10. Dreams of further quick wickets were soon shattered by the arrival of S Daluwatte## who after having been missed in the slips before he had scored then gave a lovely exhibition of straight driving and was looking to rapidly put Ley Hill out of sight when to his## and everyone's## surprise he was bowled by the persevering Andy Thompson. Cue shrieks of joy## especially from our Captain## who was having a good day## taking two smart slip catches during the innings. Ley Hill continued to bat well## but though the  total mounted quickly## wickets continued to fall## and at 99 for 6 in the 21st over## things were looking promising. However## a stand between Kemp and Cartledge had yielded 42 before Max Dugdale## standing up to Nick Adams## took a smart catch## to cap a generally excellent display behind the stumps. Nick promptly took another wicket with his very next ball## but  a last wicket partnership added a tantalising further 22 runs## before Ian Maciver finished matters off## and the innings closed on 170## made in only 34 overs.

Ballinger had to endure ten minutes batting before tea could be taken. Ley Hill opened with Duluwatte bowling off spin## with silly-mid on and silly-mid off both under the batsmen's noses. The ploy paid handsome dividends## with Monty and Rollo both clean bowled## so that Ballinger left the field on 4 for 2 after three overs. After an excellent Webster tea## Ballinger's woes rapidly deepened## with Jono also bowled by Daluwatte. 4 for 3## and the prospect of a massive batting disaster looked a possibility. But not to Andy## batting with his customary calm## and now joined by Ian Davies## determined to put a poor season behind him. Together they defended doggedly## and Ley Hill captain Ottaway then made a bowling change that perhaps changed the outcome of the match## by resting Daluwatte## who had taken 3 for 5 in 6 overs. Andy and Ian were able to move up several gears## and had added an invaluable 71 for the fourth wicket## when Andy fell LBW for 33. Ian perished shortly afterwards## then Max also attracted the umpire's disapproving finger## and at 92 for 7 Ballinger looked doomed## especially as the wicket was by now starting to misbehave - to the chagrin of Jamie who was undone by a sharply lifting delivery.  There followed a quite remarkable partnership between Hamish Sim and Ian Maciver. Hamish batted with total confidence## scoring all round the wicket with some delightful shots## whilst at the other end Ian mainly took on the role of defying the wiles of Daluwatte## in his second spell## determined not to be undone by a fellow spinner!. Thanks to Ley Hill having used only 34 overs in their innings## Ballinger now had the luxury of 46 overs to bat## so time was on their side. Daluwatte conceded only two more runs off his remaining four overs## but crucially he could not get a wicket. Gradually the prospect of defeat started to recede## and the unbelievable prospect of a win replaced it. Hamish was by now in comlete control of the bowling## and Ian was taking toll of any loose deliveries. Also massively aiding Ballinger's quest was Mr Extras## with the amazing total of 46 (the match's top scorer!)## including 24 byes and 15 no-balls. With three overs to spare Ballinger cruised home## with Hamish undefeated on 40## and Ian likewise on 20## having put on an unbroken 79 for the eigth wicket.

A thoroughly excellent game of cricket## with the result in doubt almost to the end## and played by both sides in good spirit.

The Lee won the toss and chose to bat on yet another good wicket and sunny day. A wise choice as their openers put on 80 off 15 overs before losing their first wicket## LBW to Andy Thompson. In came Morgan## their star turn## who survived an early scare## a very close LBW shout## again from Andy Thompson who looked questioningly at the umpires lack of finger movement. As Morgan then went on to make 92 off 60 balls the umpire shall remain annonymous. The score escalated to 136 for 3 off 26 overs with The Lee seemingly in control. Captain Thompson throws the ball to McGowan## 3 dot balls## a sharp stumping from Max## caught and bowled## hat trick ball with the fielders crowding the new batsmen## bowled## a hat trick maiden## 136 for 6 off 27 overs. Unfortunately ## Morgan is still at the crease and scoring freely## the unamed umpire still questioning his earlier decision. He finally falls to a good catch from the captain off the bowling of Alex Howe with the score on 203. The Lee add another 15 runs for the loss of 1 wicket in the remaining overs before tea## taking them to 218 for 8 off 39 overs.

After an excellent tea provided by Barbara Dugdale the captain maintained the Dugdale theme and put Max and Ben in to open the innings. Max survived a couple of dodgy moments as the pair put on 39 before Ben caught a top edge and was out. Max was next to fall with the score on 56 off 10 overs. Ballinger well up with the rate and The Lee in no hurry to get the ball back to the bowler. Ballinger took advantage of some generous bowling but gave wickets away## Jake 12 off 5## Ian 29 off 19## Fally 39 off 24## the score now 145 for 5 off 20 overs. Ballinger now requiring 74 off the remaining 15 overs. Given the conditions this should have been a stroll but the middle order couldn't get the ball away against some indifferent bowling. Wickets continued to fall and the introduction of Morgan and Line to the attack made things more difficult. The unamed umpire made another dubious decision giving Stuart McGowan LBW with the game still in the balance## 201 for 9. 18 runs required## 14 balls remaining the captain now joined by Will Arnold. Morgan to bowl to Thompson . . 6 2 1  . . 9 off the over## 9 needed off the last over with the captain on strike. Boakes to bowl## 2 dot balls## pressure on## the captain launches the ball to deep mid wiicket## will it carry? Around runs Morgan## who else## to take a great catch on the boundary. All out for 210.

An exciting game## Morgan definately man of the match with his 92 runs## 2 wickets and 3 catches. A brave effort by The Waggoners but a game they should have won. The unamed umpire still trying to come to terms with error of his ways.

Captain Matt Riley took another youthful Sunday side to the sunny## rural retreat of Britwell Salome. Britwell won the toss and chose to bat. On a sloping wicket the Ballinger openers found it difficult to find line and length## highlighted by 13 wides in a final total of 21 extras. When the bowlers managed to find the strip the Britwell openers found it difficult to get the ball away but patiently stuck to their task and pushed the score to 53 off 16 overs before losing their first wicket. By this time captain Riley had turned to the spin of Ben Dugdale who got the breakthrough with a great delivery. Ben went on to bowl an excellent spell of 18 overs with control and variation keeping Britwell constantly under pressure. At the other end captain Riley rotated his bowling options and Ballinger rattled through their overs## whilst managing to keep the run rate below 4 an over. With the score on 185 for 6 off 49 overs and the clock on 4.30pm Britwell decided to take 1 more over. The batsmen on strike## looking like he'd been recruited from The New York Yankees## set about Ben's last over and clubbed a further 26 runs to take the score to 211 for 6 off 50 overs. Not something Ben deserved after his afternoon exploits.

After a pleasant tea Riley and Smith took to the middle with the prospect of a maximum of 40 overs to chase down the required total. From the start they both set about the Britwell bowling with controlled batting. Will first to reach his 50 with Matt not far behind## the score reaching 124 off 23 overs before Matt mistimed and was caught. In came Basty who was deceived by the unusual action and delivery of Prior and was duly stumped. Ben was next in and he and Will pushed the score to 150 off 27 overs before Will was caught at long on going for another big. Disappointed but an excellent innings of 80 off 72 balls. Hamish joined Ben at the crease with Ballinger up with the rate## seemingly in control and batting to come. Then came the Ballinger middle order collapse. Ben next to go## again caught at long on## going for a big hit. A good knock of 30 off 29 balls. The score now 187 for 5 off 34 overs. Ballinger needing 25 off 6 overs with 5 wickets remaining. In the next 3 overs Ballinger lost 4 wickets## Steve Carter caught## Dom Brown run out without facing a ball## Alex Howe caught and Connor Underwood stumped first ball. Final pair at the crease James Fray and Toby Lyons with 17 needed off the final 16 balls. James played a few good shots but realising it would be too risky the pair saw out the remaining deliveries for a well earned draw.

A great game## played in good spirit## an excellent advert for timed cricket.

Ballinger’s 2nd X1 visited Hawridge and Cholesbury on Saturday. Hawridge have been out of league cricket for a while and it’s good to see them back in the MBL

The skipper was a bit worried that at 1.15pm he still only had 6 players and when he went out to toss up he was slightly concerned as how## when he won the toss## he was going to field first. All irrelevant of course as he lost the toss and the Waggoners were asked to bat.

The skipper had also planned to open the batting but one look at the wicket encouraged him to think of the team and drop down the order to when they might need him most.

Therefore who to send in with Tom Petrie? Given the amount of ear bending he’d received from him there was only one option and that was to send in Ben Dugdale.

Tale-ender to opener in two weeks## could he cope?

Well Ben and Tom set of carefully against some decent bowling. They were always looking for singles and Ben’s speed between the wickets was really helping push Tom along as well. At drinks (20 overs) The Waggoners were in the unusual position of not having lost a wicket with 68 on the board. Not enough but a good base. Ben then started to unfurl some excellent drives and cuts## pushed even harder to turn singles into twos and with the occasional ‘slog’ dragged the score up to 132 before he was finally out for a really good 85. Dom Brown was now promoted up the order to keep the pace going and poor Tom was confronted with an even quicker version of Ben. These two added another 25 before Tom was out for a very well crafted maiden 50.

Dom was then helped by Steve Conway## David Cooke## Steve Carter and Paul Branigan to pull the visitors total up to a very respectable 192.

An excellent tea as always## which the skipper was reluctant to leave behind## especially as it had just started raining. Unfortunately his team mates and the opposition were keen to play.

Ballinger’s juniors were now to witness a master class in batting from one of the host’s long serving Sri Lankans. Rifai was a difficult enough bat to bowl against when he was in the Premier league and the skipper had Premier league bowlers at his command but now he had an attack whose average age was 15. As expected carnage followed.

Dom and Adeel opened up for Ballinger and they soon learnt that anything short## slightly wide## too full was just swatted away. Then when they did get the ball in the right place Reefer would play an elegant drive or a glance. After just 5 overs the score was on 50.

The skipper needed some control so turned to Ben and Will Arnold. Finally the flood stopped and he had chance to catch his breath. A smart bit of fielding by Tom ran out one opener but Drane was quickly into his stride and it was looking a bit ominous for the visitors. Then Will removed Drane thanks to a good catch by Tom## Dom was now back into the attack and we finally had the bit of luck we needed when Rifai missed a straight## shin high full toss and he was on his way. Low full tosses were now the order of the day as Dom now had Rupasinghe well caught low down by Steve Carter off one## and bowled Thomas with another.

We’d broken the back of the home side’s batting but was it going to be too late. Hawridge had gone from 113-1 to 135 – 8 but Matt Rutt was still struggling on having been hit on the knee earlier in the game. Rutt and Reading added another 45## in the rain## before Adeel who had just returned to the action had Reading bowled with another low full toss. Then the important wicket of Rutt again bowled by Adeel.

180-9 with 9 overs to go. 187 – 9 with 6 overs to go. ‘Hang on a minute’ was the cry from the middle. They haven’t just scored 7 runs. Thank goodness for Miles keeping track## not scoring of course## just keeping track of the score. 182-9 it should be.

Then its 185 -9 with 3 overs to go. This was going to be tight then Adeel bowled a very good straight ball to Hawridge’s injured last man and their umpire had the difficult decision to give him out LBW.

We’d won. Well done team.

A miserable day for weather but a really enjoyable day’s cricket. Thanks to H&C for not arguing when the score was disputed and allowing common sense to prevail.

Match abandoned after one over## after Ian Davies## leading a seriously youthful side (plus Derek Richards making his 1st X! debut !) had asked a strong looking Holmer Green side to bat first## hardly surprisingly. Within 20 minutes of the teams leaving the field the pitch was awash.

On a warm cloudless afternoon at Downley## Ballinger could afford to relax in the knowledge that relegation was no longer an issue## and with a side restored to something approaching their strongest## they might be able to give a decent performance against their opponents## who would have been clear league winners had they not been docked points for fielding a non-registered player against the ultimate winners## Monks Risborough.

Downley opted to bat first## and made a careful start. Hamish Sim struck to take the first wicket thanks to an excellent catch by Monty Thompson (who shone with his ground fielding## too)## but therafter the bowlers took an increasing hammering## and the second wicket was not to fall until the total had reached 101## with only 17 overs gone.  By this time Adeel Iqbal was starting to bowl well## and he and Ian Maciver pegged back the scoring rate## to the extent that Downley found themselves 135 for 5 in the 25th over. Then Downley regained control## with opener Priestley narrowly missing a well-deserved ton when he was sixth out for 96## bowled by Adeel. Andy Thompson paid the price of being the "death" bowler## going for 18 in his final over## and Downley closed on 225 for 7.

This should have been a perfectly reasonable target## but with Downley opening their bowling with two spinners## using the old ball## Ballinger then proceeded to give one of their more abject performances of the season## set in train by Matt Riley## well ahead in the batting averages## running himself out for a duck. Disaster then followed disaster. Richard O'Kelly looked to be well on top## when he was unexpectedly bowled## having made 25 out of a total of 30## and thereafter only Hamish(22) and Max Dugdale showed any tenacity## but with the run rate barely over two an over## any chance of making the requisite score had long since vanished## and the innings petered out limply in the 32nd over## all out for a paltry 89. 

As we had been thrashed in the earlier fixture by 10 wickets## it would have been a good way to end the season by showing that we were really not that bad. In this we failed## dismally. Never mind## the beers went down as well as usual## and hopefully those who went on to the curry night enjoyed themselves even more!

It's another beautiful day at Ballinger and, sadly, the last league of the summer. Where has the season gone?

Today we were hosting Widmer End, which due to the vagueries (interpret that how you will) of the MBL ‘s fixture planners, was the only time we were to play them. How can you come to a satisfactory conclusion to a league when we played all of the teams above us twice and all bar one of the clubs below us once. 

To the game. Skipper loses toss – again. Worst season ever, but, Widmer chose to bat. Not sure what the wicket is going to do so not too concerned about that and we have, for the second week running an excellent bowling attack.

Dom Brown opened up with Will Arnold at the other end. Dom is quick but a bit erratic and anything off line is keeping very low. In the right places its coming through with pace and bounce so Steve Conway behind the stumps is going to have an interesting afternoon.

Will is his normal accurate self but the Widmer openers have obviously been watching too much 20/20 and with no thought to the aesthetic side of batting swished and swatted at anything in their half of the pitch. This is incredibly annoying as they managed to put on 66 without playing a proper cricket shot.

Tom Petrie had now replaced Will and in his 3rd over finally got the break through the bowlers deserved. In his next over he also removed the other opener. This should have meant a more sensible approach to batting but none of it, each new batsman continued in the same vein. It’s almost impossible to set a field when you don’t know where the ball is going to be hit.

James Fray now bowled a spell of quick aggressive bowling and with Ben Dugdale now on at the other end the Balinger bowlers were slowly working there way through the visitors line up. A good ball from Ian McCloughlin, some well flighted off spin from Ben another tight spell from Will and suddenly the visitors were all out.

The bowlers were supported by some good catches by Steve, James and Nigel plus excellent ground fielding all round including a brilliant run out by Ben.

A total of 151 looked a bit below par

After another excellent tea thanks to Fiona Conway the skipper had to sort out the batting order.

Following their success last time out he decided to send out Ben and Tom again. The bowling didn’t look anything special and neither looked in any trouble so the skipper went back to the tea. At which point Tom had that most frustrating bit of bad luck when the ball roled back onto his stumps. David Cooke then joined Ben and these two tickled along for a few overs before David tried successfully to just reach a wide and dolly a catch, Ian McCloughlin then helped Ben add just over 20 before giving some more catching practice. Steve came and went but in the meantime a huge moment of controversy. Did Ben snick a catch behind or not? The opposition thought so and were determined to make the rest of his stay as unpleasant as possible.

Paul Branigan was now at the crease and in a typically unselfish approach proceeded to blunt his way  to 2 off 27 balls, whilst Ben was taking full advantage of his good fortune. At 109 for 4 the skipper was quietly confident and had set off on another stroll round the ground. Unfortunately by the time he had reached the safety of the pavilion again the Waggoners  batting line up was in disarray. In 6 overs we lost 5 wickets for 14 runs.

This meant the side’s two senior pros ( or invalids) had to don the pads and try to rescue the game. Fortunately there were plenty of overs left and it didn’t take long for Peter Petrie to find his range and the visitors were also running out of bowlers. This enabled the skipper and Peter to guide The Waggoners home with Peter finishing with a flourish hitting a 6 to win the game.

Despite the fuss over Ben it was an enjoyable game and it was good to see how well Ballinger held up in the field when the ball was flying all round the place. A few weeks ago the bowlers would have lost control and we could have easily been chasing 200+

It was also great to play against a team that come to the pub so all the on field problems can be solved over a pint.

A really enjoyable season thanks in no short measure to the weather.

A few thank yous:

To Paul for somehow getting out a team each week. I’m not sure how many realise the difficulty of getting 33 players on the pitch each week but it’s almost an artform.

To Miles for umpiring. It makes a huge difference to the captain not having to worry about  sending someone out to do the job. Miles was also our top point scorer.

To Max Conway for becoming the apprentice scorer and earning us a few more points.

To Jamie Kellock for producing excellent pitches each week.

And finally to all the tea ladies. It’s great to know that when ever we play at home we’re going to get a feast.

Another sunny Sunday afternoon## Ballinger winning the toss and choosing to bat on what looked yet another great wicket. Matt Riley and Stuart Clark enjoying the conditions and some generous bowling and taking the score quickly to 13 before Matt## continuing his excellent weekend form## forgets to hit a straight one. O'Kelly junior joins Stuart at the crease and so began the S. Clark batting masterclass. The pair put on 101 in the next 20 overs## Stuart the main contributor but a solid 22 from Matthew. Steve Carter next in to join the maestro and a further 36 runs added before Steve hears the rattle of his stumps## Ballinger 150 for 3 off 28 overs. Max Dugdale next in and eager for runs## Stuart now scoring freely. the pair proceed to put on 108 runs in 11 overs## Max riding his luck a few times but playing some big shots highlighted by a flat 6 back over the bowlers head and clearing the hedge. Captain Thompson then deciding to end the carnage and generously declaring the innings with Ballinger on 258 for 3 off 39 overs## Max not out 60 off 35 balls and Stuart 146 off 118 balls in what was a flawless display. Perhaps the captain should have batted a few more overs????

A superb innings was complemented with an equally superb tea provided by Azra Iqbal. Wendover took to the middle with a big target to chase but time and overs in their favour. Captain Thompson opted for spin from both ends and was rewarded with 2 early wickets from the bowling of Freddie Thompson. The visitors 12 for 2 off 2 overs. Robinson## the opening bat was looking dangerous and hitting some big shots and a partnership of 53 off the next 6 overs sent alarm bells ringing. He launched an enormous blow off Freddie out towards the deep mid wicket boundary## around ran Ben Dugdale## brilliantly judging the flight of the ball and taking a stunning catch## Robinson looking on in disbelief## a game changer. Ballinger now back in control and some good bowling from Fin Clark and Sam Peters kept the pressure on. Wickets continued to fall with Wendover on 125 for 6 off 24 overs as the clock struck 6pm. 133 runs required## 4 wickets to take off the remaining 20 overs. Their captain Seabrook now at the crease and deciding a draw was the only option. A solid partnership developed putting on 43 runs for the eigth wicket## taking Wendover to 173 with 9 overs remaining. Seabrook now trying to batten down the hatches and keep the strike whenever possible. The ninth wicket falls## bowled Ben Dugdale## 7 overs left. Overs go by## 195 for 9## 2 overs left## the captain calls on the man he can trust the most to finish the job## himself!!! Dot ball## dot ball## wicket## brilliant captaincy## the result never in doubt## the early declaration inspired.

An exciting game## played in the true spirit of timed cricket.

Our first early match of the season.

High Wycombe opened the batting and scored steadily to get their 109 runs. Not a great target## but fading light towards the end of our innings meant we were chasing an achievable 15 runs in the last two overs.  In the end we lost by just 10 runs.

Notable performances by Henry King (batting)##  Harri Doyle (batting and bowling) and James Arnold## Miles Devereux and Simon Carlin (all bowling). 

A good effort all round## considering we have not had a practice session yet!

Away to Holmer Green for the opening League match## with seemingly half of the members away or otherwise occupied## did not bode well for Ballinger. Holmer Green won the toss## and predictably decided to bowl first## on a damp wicket. Against an accurate attack## Ballinger were soon in trouble## losing the vital wicket of Richard O'Kelly in only the fourth over. Andy Thompson was soon displaying his customary doggedness## and with Rollo McIntyre they had ground their way to 34 in the 17th over## before Rollo fell to a good catch. This opened the floodgates## and wickets crashed rapidly to the pacy Weerakoon and spinner Gumb## and when Thompson went for a splendid## defiant 25 after nearly two hours at the crease## the total was only 53 for 7. That immediately became 53 for 8## and the end seemed nigh. However## some lusty blows from newcomer Andy Rowe helped the scoreboard reach a pathetic final tally of 69 all out## in 35 overs.

There was time for four overs before tea## and with Nick Adams' first over going for 10## the prospect of a very early end to the match was in sight. However## Nick quickly found his rhythm## and bowled Watt in his second over## and with Will Reid bowling well at the other end## tea was taken with HG on 13 for 1. Weerakoon rapidly showed that he was no mean batsman as well as a bowler## and looked to be taking the game well out of reach## as the total climbed to 45 with only 3 wickets down. But Nick## who had already claimed the prolific Kevin King LBW## then sent back Weerakoon the same way. The innings then fell apart in much the same way as Ballinger's had done## with Andy Thompson producing a mean spell of bowling## taking 3 for 10## complementing his fine batting earlier. At the other end Evan Webster went even better## destroying the HG innings with figures of 4 overs## 4 maidens## 3 wickets## 0 runs. Ballinger's fielding was exceptional throughout## but the game still seemed lost when HG's skipper S Adams took them to within 5 runs from winning## then scooped a shot to square leg. The nearest fielder##Will Reid## pulled off an astonishing diving catch to hold the ball an inch from the turf## and suddenly Ballinger had won a remarkable victory. An unexpected## but highly enjoyable start to the season!

Early season spring sunshine## beautiful Chiltern views and a blend of youth and experience taking the field – the best of Ballinger cricket.  Ballinger won the toss and## as is customary on Sundays## elected to bat.  Ballinger lost David Cooke (the senior partner in one of 3 father-son combos in the Ballinger team) early## but his opening partner## Richard O’Kelly## thrived## with his usual mixture of care and aggression.  He was well supported by Jamie Kellock and then 14-year-old Joe Turrell## playing his first adult match (and displaying great calmness and maturity in the process). Joe departed from a well-made 16## and Richard finally fell for 64## leaving Ballinger still relatively well-placed on 112 for 4.  However## there then followed a small clatter of wickets## with Steve Conway probably about as plumb LBW as it is possible to get## and Freddie Thompson run out by a duly apologetic Paul Branigan.  Rusty batting and rusty calling at the start of the season## I fear.  Thankfully## Paul was joined by George Cooke (the third 14-year-old in the team)## and between them they put on useful runs## George finishing with a composed 24.  As tea loomed (local rules compelling tea at 4.30 regardless of the state of the innings!) Ballinger closed with a respectable## but not overwhelming## 177 for 9 off 45 overs.

We would have to bowl well## and field well## to win – always a challenge in these early-season matches!  George Cooke and Matt O’Kelly opened the bowling## both finding some good rhythm and largely sticking to a good line and length## removing one of the openers each. Then came the crucial partnership of the game## between the Pelicans numbers 3 and 4## Bailey and Patel## clearly their strongest two batsmen.  Both punished bad balls## and both were served up a few.  As the Pelicans 100 came up## with only 2 wickets down## the skipper turned to Freddie Thompson’s legspin to try to conjure a wicket.  In fact initially he delivered much-needed control## bowling an excellent line and length and keeping the Pelicans batsmen anchored in the crease for fear of stumping. That also allowed Andy Thompson to switch ends and coming down the hill bowl a rather better length with a bit more zip## resulting in the removal of the 2 main Pelican batters - and suddenly the game was opened up.  The scoring rate slowed## Freddie claimed a wicket and Ballinger looked very much in the hunt.  But tension remained and another partnership developed## bringing Pelicans to within 20 runs of victory.   However## Freddie Thompson then bowled one of the last main threats behind his legs## and Joe Turrell claimed his first wicket for the Ballinger Sunday team## in a cameo performance with his slow left arm; and we were set for the tightest of finishes.   Although the scoring rate slowed to a trickle## the overs were not really an issue ….. and the Pelicans had one strong batsmen left …. until he was removed by a thrilling piece of fielding from Matt O’Kelly in the deep## combining with his father behind the stumps to complete an excellent run out.  Ballinger felt that the momentum had swung their way and in a gripping last few overs (involving dropped catches## a crucial collision between batter and keeper## but luckily no diplomatic incident) George Cooke and Andy Thompson came back into the attack to claim one of the last 2 wickets each## completing an excellent victory by a mere 2 runs.  As Dr Who would put it## definitely squeaky-bum time! 

 

The bowlers were supported by some surprisingly good fielding for so early in the season## with particular mention due to Ian McLoughlin## who seemed by the end of the afternoon to have done more fielding than the other 10 players put together## including an excellent catch out of the sun and some truly heroic athletic attempts.   All in all## a great team effort.

On a gloomy day  with poor light Chesham wnet in to bat first.  They scored a fair 103 with superb bowling and fielding by BWCC. A really good display in the field by the whole team with Ballinger taking six Chesham wickets## not done that before!!

Then it was our turn to bat and the wheels fell off.  We struggled to get 37 runs off the bat and where eventually all out for 49.  Having said that all batsmen managed to stay in for several balls and none of the team lost there wickets through any fault of their own. We were simply facing ferocious bowling by some very good Chesham players. All the team stood up well to most of their spinners## but very accurate bowling by the faster bowlers was our undoing.

An encouraging effort against a really strong team who were visibly worried after their innings! Unfortunately our batting did not shape up.

Ballinger finally won a toss and went in to bat on a reasonable wicket with good light. Once again## however## our batting failed us with the first 5 wickets falling for less than 15 runs. Only Hugo and Matthew saved some face by putting on 23 runs between them (Matthew top scored with 15). Ballinger finished with 58 runs and a challenge ahead of them. Winchmore did have some good bowlers who managed to keep us on the back foot throughout and had us all out within 17 overs.

Winchmore innings started slowly with our bowlers pinning them back with some excellent bowling and an early wicket. Then## despite continued good bowling## Winchmore started steadily putting on the runs.  Our fielding and bowling were really excellent## with only two wides as the only extras recorded against us.  The fielding and team support was noticably very good with every ball being chased down very hard and bowlers being encouraged by their team mates.

Unfortunately we had not set them a high enough target and they reached this within 12 overs.  Had they had a higher score to beat we would certainly have been able to win this game.

We lost the toss and were put in to bat which on this sunny eveing suited our team as we knew the last few overs of the match could be challenging to bat in. Our openers Oliver and Archie were faced with some strong bowling from some very tall boys## they took us to 207## Thomas and Casper then followed and put on and then took off some runs## with no boundaries to be had we were still on 206 after 8 overs## Sebastian and Kuran moved us up to 226 after 12 and then Max C and Max FE brought us along to 244 afetr 16## our two great U9 players Raphi and on his debut for the U10A Edward led us to a respectable 270 from 20.

Bledlow came in to bat and did not hold back## Oliver very smartly mixed up the bowling and wickets were taken by Oliver## Archie 3## Edward## Kuran## Max Fe and Casper## which shows the depth of our bowling attack.

A great start to the season and despite playing agains some very large and powerful boys we delivered a well deserved result.

Really Well done

Despite the downpours and the poor forecast## Ballinger 2nds managed to get their season underway at Aylesbury Town 2nds on Saturday## in a slightly shortened 36 over game. The opening spells from Will Arnold and newcomer Andy Rowe were very tight and restricted the same Aylesbury openers who had destroyed the Ley Hill bowling last week. They were subsequently backed up by the rest of the bowling attack with 2 wickets apiece for Josh Badrick and Matt O'Kelly## one for Ben Dugdale and some tight bowling from Fin Clark. A good fielding performance from the Ballinger youngsters restricted the opposition to 138 for 5## which## although a low total## would still require some application as## given the conditions## boundaries would be hard to come by. 

Stu Clark and Max Dugdale got our reply off to a flier as they kept their eyes on the strike rate given the strong possibility the game would be brought to a halt by more rain. However when they both perished the innings lost some momentum## as they were quickly followed by Ben and Iain McCloughlin. Further wickets followed as the total crept up as did the required run rate. An injection of urgency from Will Arnold and Paul Branigan took Ballinger to within 9 runs of victory but when they departed## the tail just fell short of completing the job## with Andy Rowe run out off the last ball## a mere 4 runs short of the opposition.

It was good to get a game in on a day when most games fell foul of the weather and the 14 points accrued at least meant no ground was lost to those who didn't play. It has hopefully knocked the rust of a few of us so bring on Bourne End !
