Finally## our first outing for the Waggonette B team [we need a better name - anyone?]; 24 hours earlier and the match would have been a wash out.  This was however the perfect May evening for a game.  The girls started in the field.  Charlotte Rynn opened## surprising the opposition openers with her accuracy and length.  Nikki followed with similar accuracy and a little more pace - hitting the stumps on her second ball.  Farnham Royal were 2 for 1.  The Farnham Royal batsmen dug in and the girls were able to be see a well-crafted innings from their number 3## who went onto to retire at 20.   Both Ellie's and Isabel's spells were accurate and deserved a scalp each.  Elodie also bowled a tight spell at the end of the innings## when the batsmen were looking to make runs; with only 2 scored off her over## she really should have had a chance to bowl again.  In the field the girls impressed us all.  They were a tight fielding unit.  Charlotte C and Nikki attacked the ball and were unlucky not to get some run outs.  Elena and Milly let nothing go past and were quick on the return## cutting off a number of runs.  Poppy was very reliable with the gloves## only letting through one bye (which impressed her brothers) and nearly taking an opportunistic stumping.  The champagne moment was Ellie## who having stopped a hard driven ball on its way to the boundary with a perfect display of the long barrier (much to the pride of the coach)## then propelled the ball back## hitting the stumps from side on to create a video replay moment for a run-out (just in).   This enthusiastic and committed performance in the field restricted a decent batting attack to 68.    

 
Livvy and Elena opened the batting.  Elena was unlucky to receive the perfect ball so early on in## which brought in Charlotte R.  Livvy and Charlotte were solid and kept the score line ticking along; they were able to block the good balls and took all of their chances for runs.   A middle order collapse threatened to lose all of our wickets before the end of our overs.  Running between the wickets was aggressive - with the girls looking to take their chances.  This did lead to a couple of run-outs## but I prefer to see them erring on the side of taking a risk.  It’s the only way to learn whether there is a run on.   Just as we thought we might run out of batsmen## in came the Hersey girls (both playing their first ever games of cricket) to steady the ship.  Elodie was unlucky to be run out## very nearly making her ground.   Daisy continued to bat and showed that she has a good eye for the ball and was remarkably composed against some quickish balls - she saw us home and to a commendable 33 total.  Against a good bowling attack## it was a noteworthy achievement for the girls to bat their full number of overs.
 
The girls were enthusiastic throughout and they should feel proud.  Farnham Royal had some very good players and probably should be playing in Division 2 not 4 however## the girls ensured that it was a competitive game of cricket.  This was all played out under the watchful eye of Nigel Kerry (our head coach) who commented to me after the game "I am really pleased with what I have seen today - the girls were focused and particularly impressive in the field".    

 

 

Go Waggonettes!

A warm sunny day greeted  Premier Division new boys Bourne End at Ballinger. They lost the toss## and Ballinger skipper Ian Davies elected to take first knock. Against tight bowling and athletic fielding## openers Richard O'Kelly and Andy Thompson had taken the total confidently to 43 before Richard departed## the first of three LBW decisions to befall Ballinger. 43 for 1 had become 58 for 4 five overs later## as the middle order imploded in a not unfamiliar way## before skipper Davies joined Andy. Looking extremely vulnerable## in his first knock of the season## he managed to hang in there## as Andy's innings blossomed## and the pair had put on an invaluable 58 togther before Ian's luck ran out. Andy perished soon after## for a superlative 74## including two fine 6's.Thereafter## the innings subsided meekly and depressingly to 140 for 9## when the overs ran out.

Nick Adams opened the Ballinger attack## and struck with his very first ball. And that was just about the only happy thing to report## as Bourne End's batsmen subjected the bowlers to a withering assault. Catches went down - 5 in all - and the ground fielding was markedly inferior to Bourne End's.  In a mere 20 overs Bourne End reached their target (with a towering 6) and the BWCC team photo of a cheerful looking side taken as soon as the game was over was to celebrate the Club President (and scorer)'s 80th Birthday## certainly not their own performance!

So serious was the situation deemed to be that plans for some net practice were decided on for the coming week -  but that was after several pints. Will it happen???

Another toss won and on a scorching hot day## a Scoop 6 ticket in the pocket## and only Arsenal in the cup final to watch at  5pm## the decision to bat first was fairly straightforward. First problem was the absence of Mr Kerry - going to extreme lengths not to open the batting by driving backwards and forwards along the A41 until 1.30. Step forward the father/son Clark combo. Off to a solid start Stuart despatched the opening attack## seemingly at will. After Fin's departure he and Ben took the score past fifty. Wickets fell at regular intervals after that## but not before Stuart completed a good looking fifty. Steve Carter having his first knock of the year was joined by fellow seasonal debutant Nigel and they steadied the ship adding 45 at a decent strike rate. Nigel was replaced by the skipper and he and Steve stepped up the pace to a run a ball. With wickets in hand the Kamikaze Kid put paid to an obviously tiring Carter before he and 'gloves' Conway engineered (after one or two practice runs) another run out a few balls later. A couple more wickets fell in the final over but not before Ballinger reached 188 on a far from perfect wicket.

Our opening bowlers did a fine job with Fin striking in the first over and he picked up two more to finish a decent spell. Andy Rowe finally got his reward after another longish opening spell and notched his first victims for Ballinger. Matt O'Kelly bagged himself two more for the season whilst MOM Carter## having already taken two catches volleyed the ball to Rob Mac who seeing the non striker stranded pinged it to Ben to complete a good bit of team cricket. Ben then duly wrapped up the match in the next over.

A really enjoyable all round team performance with contributions from everyone with bat##ball and in the field.
Report to follow

Our U10B amazing victory ## their first game of the season captained by the only U10 player Finn Henry ## he led 9 of our U9 players in this match. Bill Senior very kindly stepped in to manage the boys at the fixture and as you can see from the result we took 26 wickets in 20 overs## Bill said the boys caught everything and i mean everything## so once again our Ballinger skills training combined with our players skills and enthusiasm once again paid off. Clearly all of the boys took wickets ## the leading wicket takers were Edward Best taking 6 from his 3 overs and Harvey taking 4 from his 2 overs.

Our batsmen were also quite amazing## with the two highest scorers being Edward O scoring 19 and Freddie scoring 14 ## both of them not losing their wickets.

I have never seen a result like this## so well done to

Finn## Victor## Toby##James##Edward B## Harvey##David##Freddie##Edward O and Noah

A big thank you to Steve Best for stepping up and scoring

Ballinger won the toss and put Chalfont in to bat. The weather being kind and the pitch very good## this was a good decision.

Ballinger bowling## once again## did the trick with some very impressive work from James Arnold (3 for 10 off 4 overs!!!). Although there were several wides## a few no balls and some fielding was not as sharp as previous games## we still held St Giles to 103## while taking a useful 7 wickets. 25 extras!!!

And then it was our turn to bat## needing 104 to win. Understandably nervous## the opening batsmen held on## not scoring many runs but wearing down Chalfonts' better bowlers. This allowed the middle order to face a mix of bowling (still very neat and tight bowling with only 9 extras given away) and allowed them to settle and to start steadily chasing the runs.  There was a tense point in the match with the required run rate nearing 8 per over with 6 overs to go. But with good solid batting performances by Harri Doyle (29) and Simon Carlin (31## retired) who were well supported by Miles Deveraux and Hugo Eaton-Hart (12 each) We reached the target in fading light with two ball to spare.  Great team support for most of our innings was certainly a help## as was the encouragement by some parents!

A good game with a very good result. Well done boys.

For first game in the season starting in sunshine but ominous black clouds in the distance. The Waggonettes batted first and posted a creditable score of 73 for 4 with main contribution from Hannah.

We concluded our innings in the heavy drizzle and retook the field with the end of the match very much in doubt. each time the drizzle became heavier it would then slacken a little. Our good bowling and tight fielding brought sparse reward and the openers played through and got to the total in almost 18 overs.

Although a loss I was impressed by the magority of our batting and although we took no wickets we were tight in the field with some excellent bowling. A really encouraging performance to start the season with.

finally some sunshine and a friendly reception from Marlow who very kindly switched the fixture to their ground [Thanks Nigel Kerry and Nigel Ashton]. Saturday afternoon and i am down 2 players## thankfully Raphi came to the rescue of the U9 side ## but we were down a player due to illness. so with 9 players and a young man called Harry who nervously joined us from what he thought was going to be his Sunday morning coaching## so we have a side ## 3 U9 and 7 U10. Our Skipper Thomas Berens wins the toss and puts Marlow in to bat. Tom Vicary## Kuran ## and Harry## finish the first 4 overs with a run out and a catch and them on 203## over 8 and Noah Henry bowls out one of their strong batsmen. Edward O'Doherty then bowls his second Maiden over and Thomas B takes another wicket. After 12 overs they are on 208 for 4## four more wickets fall 2 for Thomas and 2 for Harry## including a stumping and a caught behind. Thomas B then takes his place behind the stumps and Max C takes 2 wickets and Daniel puts another W on the scoresheet. they finish on 197.

Daniel Batman opens the batting and keeps the ship steady for the first 4 overs## Edward and Max Fe come in keeping the pressure on Marlow with some quick running taking us to 213 for 3## Casper and Kuran start applying the pressure with quick singles and a earth shaking 4 from Casper## they left the field with us on 235 for 3## Tom and Noah seemed to run for their lives and Tom kept his nerve and defended and left the field with the team on 236 for 4 ## In come the Skipper and Max C## both vying for strike## Max hitting two boundaries a 3 and 3 singles from 9 balls ## the pair took the score up to 266 for 4 a convincing victory.

The boys excelled in the field and always looked in control##

After the wet weather on Saturday saw both matches cancelled## all players were relieved to see fresh## sunny conditions drying out the sodden square enough to allow a full game to be played.   Bourne End won the toss and decided to bat.  Opening bowlers Hamish Sim and George Cooke remove the openers rapidly## one of them to a blinding one-handed full-length diving catch by David Cooke – rolling back the years!  But there then followed the key stand in the match between Hill and Bourne End skipper## Akhtar## scoring 85 and 44 respectively.  Both Hamish and offspinner Monty Thompson were part of good contests between bat and ball with Akhtar## before Monty## having first tied him up## then bowled him - a crucial wicket## without which Bourne End could have got away completely.  However## Hill persisted## with Ballinger proceeding steadily to remove all his support at the other end## first through Stuart McGowan’s off spin (2 for 42) and then with Hamish and George coming back.  Both young men (16 and 14 respectively) bowled with good pace and generally tight lines to end with 4 for 43 and 3 for 39 respectively.  The bowlers were well supported in the field with James Fray and Basty Richards standing out## as well as Monty’s excellent catch on the boundary which eventually dismissed Hill. Freddie Thompson## not a regular keeper## turned in a very agile and effective performance behind the stumps.

195 all out## however## was a very competitive total on a damp pitch and## to be frank## Ballinger never really threatened to overtake it. Matt Riley (22) made a good solid start at the top of the innings## but without any support and as the last 20 overs began at 6.30 Ballinger still needed over 140 with 6 wickets in hand.  Despite a good stand and some clean striking from Monty (36*) and Hamish (19) coming in at seven and eight## Ballinger never really mounted a challenge.  However## we looked safe enough until Hamish fell## after which there was a sudden clatter of wickets with a hat-trick to finish the game off with Ballinger a long way short.  To be fair## the pitch became even more difficult during the Ballinger innings with many deliveries simply dying.  But it was a good match played in a very good spirit## which demonstrated the value of playing win – lose – draw time cricket## rather than limited overs cricket## on a Sunday.  And everyone was just glad to get a game in!

 

 

AT

At last the U12s were able to get a match underway at GX on Tues 13th May. A good mixture of U12 girls and boys## and a sprinkling of U11s looked like a strong enough line up. 

Faced with a rather unique eight straight overs of left arm over the wicket bowling## our batsmen struggled to fire on all cylinders. Faced with the early loss of Harry and Hannah## Philip held his end up well## though he sttruggled to put away the bad balls. Theo and Samuel hd no such trouble## but were not able to sustain it very long. The rest of the batsman were not confident in their shots and therefore struggled to get the score beyond 56.

Harry and Hannah opened the bowling with some good tight overs and kept their batsman honest. However## they picked up the bad balls off Samuel and Philip which let the pressure off. Accuracy not pace## were the order of the day. The rest of the bowlers kept things tight## but we were always going to struggle to defend the low total. 

Let's try and bat more confidently next match and give ourselves a chance with the ball. 

Team: Sharkey## Petrie## Bates## Weatherall## Kellock## Colville## Love## Coulter## Jones## Steinhauer## Mills

Well done kids.

Sharkey

Sadly High Wycombe couldnt raise a side for this match and have given us the points. This leaves us still unbeaten and at the top of the Division. As we have the ground we are having a friendly match with guest players from Chesham and also our U11 and U9 sides. Hope to have some fun this evening as long as the weather is on our side.

 

Steve
The rainy season has arrived. Probably just in time to save the U13s from another beating

Ballinger's resplendent new scoreboard (courtesy of Kerry Joinery & Artwork) made its debut## but the three shiny hooks for BWCC's total proved excessive## as for the second time this season their struggling batsmen failed to break 70.

After a very wet week## the boundary had to be modified to exclude a swamp near the white hut## but in spite of its tempting proximity## none of Ballinger's batsmen took advantage. Instead they seemed primarily occupied with giving Haddenham catching practice. Two wickets went in only the second over as O'Kelly and Thompson (M) lasted 5 balls between them## gifting mistimed dollies to the grateful fielders. Sanity then prevailed## as Andy Thompson was joined by skipper Davies## and for an hour they defied an accurate attack## backed up by athletic fielding## whilst slowly but surely hoisting the total to 41 in the 17th over. Four overs later 41 for 2 had become 41 for 6## with Andy caught behind for a typical gritty 12## and Ian following the next over## playing no shot to a delivery that cut back to bowl him## for a valiant 19. Max Dugdale and Jamie Kellock went within the space of another nine balls## neither of them troubling the scorers. Dom Brown and Nick Adams contributed some lusty blows during their (very) brief innings## whilst Adeel Iqbal (at number 7)showed that it was perfectly possible to defend## batting for 41 balls before being last man out for 6## with only 30 overs used. Haddenham produced several remarkable catches ##to hasten Ballinger's demise## but## all told## it was a wretched effort.

 Ballinger took the field in the hope that as 69 had proved a winning total against Holmer Green## perhaps lightning might strike twice. This looked extremely unlikely as Haddenham sped to 18 in only 3 overs## and this had become 33 by the 6th over## when the fielding side were glad to head for the pavilion to enjoy a splendid tea## courtesy of Mr & Mrs Kerry - definitely a Kerry day## but perhaps not much competition?  Two wickets had in fact fallen during the pre-tea session## one a smart run-out## and the other the result of some impressive spin bowling by Monty Thompson## who had opened the bowling - an enterprising initiative. Father Andy now joined the fray## and was soon causing difficulties## taking 2 more wickets## as Haddenham started to wobble. Keeper O'Kelly then produced an excellent piece of stumping off Monty## and suddenly the curse of the forties seemed to be striking again as Haddenham slumped from 40 for 2 to 41 for 5. Will Reid and Evan Webster were given a miserly one over each in which to try pull off the improbable## but although both obliged with a wicket## Haddenham ended by cruising home with three wickets in hand## and only 17 overs gone.

With the match done and dusted by 5.00pm## it was left to those with memories of long ago to recall when 5.00pm was the mid point of a cricket match. Ah## well.

Some stories are best told briefly## and this is one. The Longwick outfield had clearly not been cut for a couple of weeks and would have fed a good-sized herd of Friesians for at least that long. It was## to be honest## a rather disappointing venue on the day## particularly since the square itself was very well cared for. Disappointing too was the Ballinger attack## nearly all of whom went for more than six an over in a 40 over limited overs game## allowing Longwick to compile a commanding total of 245 for 6## largely based on a score of 131 by their number three## Thornton - although many would have said that he could have been given out LBW at least 3 times before he had got into double figures. Ballinger just bowled too many bad balls## allowing him to slog the ball hard and high over the dense jungle that passed for an outfield for six (10 in all). We were really short of a couple of experienced bowlers on the day; although the youngsters pressed into service did their best and stuck at the task## showing great character.

That left a very big task. Ballinger made a decent start## based around some good crisp hitting## comprising proper cricket shots## from Rob McIntyre (25) and eldest son Tom (55). Many which would have gone for 4 on a cut outfield gained just 1. Tom was later joined by younger brother James (24)## but when both were out in relatively quick succession## the Ballinger challenge faded## with a series of batsmen getting out heroically trying to push the scoring rate up to the spiralling levels required (including a trio of Bunces Gary## Scott and James). The McIntyre family scored more than 100 of Ballingers eventual total of 139 all out. It was at least a lovely sunny day at last.

AT

Although we lost to undoubtedly the strongest team in the league## there was a great deal to celebrate about the Ballinger performance: the return of Max Leane to Ballinger Colts Cricket## an excellent fielding performance## a very good run chase that ran out of steam only in the last 2 overs and most of all the superb strength of Ballinger girls’ cricket as demonstrated by Hannah Bates and Georgina Kellock who between them made up our 11th man (Hannah to field## Georgina to bat) when we had a late dropout through injury.

Chesham won the toss and elected to bat and## despite some good tight bowling and excellent fielding (Marcus Tingey particularly tidy behind the stumps)## amassed a formidable total of 129 for 5## centred around an excellent 50 (retired) from Nouman Aslam## with some very clean hitting.  Max Leane (2-23) and Fin Clark (1-18) bowled good opening spells## followed by the “spin twins” of Joe Turrell (1-38) and Freddie Thompson (0-25) (no opportunity for cliché will be missed in these reports!); but the pick of the bowlers was 12-year-old Hannah Bates## parachuted in at the last minute## who bowled 4 overs for 25 runs## all at the end of the innings when Chesham were pushing for quick runs with wickets in hand. She only bowled one genuinely bad ball out of 24## was apparently entirely unfazed by playing against boys who were two years older than her and was a genuinely fantastic advert for Ballinger girls’ cricket (Roger Webster## you should be very proud!).

Ballinger set off at a good rate through Turrell and Thompson## keeping up with the rate until the 13th over when the first wicket fell## with Joe unfortunately run out for an excellent 47.  But Thompson carried on the good work supported in particular by some clean hitting from Tingey (16) coming in at number 4.  But when Marcus was out in the 17th over Ballinger still needed 26 off just over three overs## which was only really do-able with batsmen blazing at both ends and it was extremely hard for new batsmen to come in against an excellent attack of largely county bowlers in the dying overs.  Charlie Barraclough## Fin Clark and Michael Everett made a valiant attempt## but once Freddie was out attempting a giant swing over mid-wicket at the end of the 18th over## the game was up.

Last year in the league we beat Chesham and went on to win the title county-wide. However## with a much smaller squad## in many ways today’s effort was even better than that. Well done to everyone; and apologies to those who did not get a proper opportunity with the bat – you will be at the top of the order on Friday v Holmer Green.  Man of the match: Hannah Bates. Champagne moment: Joe Turrell’s huge 6.

On a gloomy overcast day the umpires decided on an 18 over match.

Marlow won the toss and went in to bat with their opening bat and 4th man in both retiring on 30 each we thought we may have our work cut out for us. As it turned out our bowling and fielding was## once again superb## on the whole. There was great team spirit which certainly helped the bowlers. Not sure if any batsmen were actually intimidated as they seemed to take the chirping in good humour. Marlow were held to 85 after their 18 overs. Valuable wickets taken by Bunce## Arnold and Petrie all of whom helped restrict the runs by some  very good bowling.

So## Ballinger in to bat with a reachable target of 86. We got off to a cracking start with both Harry Petrie and Matthew Barton piling on the runs to both finish (retired) on 32 and 31 respectively.  A good solid start and we were off to potentially a great win.  And then the wheels fell off## big time. The next 5 batsmen were all skittled out by some good bowling and very good fielding (three catches!!) for 9 runs between them## until Louis put his head down and scored the winning runs with one over to spare.

A good win in the end## but some tense moments during the batting collapse and some dogged determination by James Tomlin and Louis Thompson to finish the game off for us.

An excellent win by Ballinger having not played togehter for a few weeks. We won the toss and decided to bat. Tilly and Hannah soon had the scoreboard ticking over at over 6 runs an over. They took the score to 76 for no wicket off 12 overs when Tilly had to retire and then Hannah was out next over; 32 and 27 respectively## a brilliant opening partnership.We did not really quite kick on from here. there was now a regular fall of wickets making 99 for 9 off our 20 overs. Rachel unlucky to be out a great catch and Hattie being bowled by a great ball. The tail really tried for all the extra runs with graet running and some sacrificing of wickets for runs.

5 tight opening overs from Charlotte and Georgina meant Marlow were soon behind the rate being 22 for 1 off 5. Marlow now had their big hitter and had almost doubled their score in 2 overs## 43 for 1 off 7. Hannah and Hattie brought a little more control once their 3 had retired## with Hattie bowling consequitive maidens. Rachel## Flora and Sophie all kept their nerve and bowled some tight overs. With the score on 84 for 6 with 2 overs to go the match could go either way. The openers ; Charlotte and Georgina came back on and only 3 runs were scored in the final 2 overs## so a well deserved victory.

The good bowling was backed up by some excellent fielding. The highlight being stops from Hannah and Charlotte of absolute screamers## but they got therir hands to them and stopped a 4 apiece.

A beautiful evening as we arrive at Cookham's bustling clubhouse## there must have been over 100 people having sundowners as their children were being coached. Our team led by Skipper Louis Barton walk over to the pitch and we are met by a very friendly manager and boys## i suddenly realise looking at the opposition that we must have had a spell cast upon us as we drove through Great Missende past Roald Dahl's house## was i now the Willy Wonka of cricket and are all my players Umpa Lumpa's ## in some cases almost two feet smaller than the opposition?  Louis gets his wish and Ballinger field first## let the magic begin and believe me there was magic from our team of six year 5's and this was the first match this season for three of them and four year 4's.

Louis immediately took control and set an excellent field## we saw some outstanding fielding from Edward Best##James Best and Ollie Norton## great fielding from the rest of the boys## who are now programmed for long barriers. Wickets went to Edward Odoherty 2## Tom##Toby##James and Louis and Cookham just couldnt get away from us## maidens from James and Toby## they were on 225 by the end of over 17## then Max C took off his keepers gloves and hit the stumps 5 times for just 5 runs leaving them on just 207.

Drinks then straight back on the field## Toby [2 fours] and James Best taking us to 216## Louis and Matthew very solid in the middle with Matthew also finding the boundary and leaving us on 229## Ollie and Tom [two fours] took us to a commanding 245## Edward O[two fours] and Edward Best toiok us up to 261 and then our last pair## Max and Kuran added a further 39 runs from their 4 overs taking us to 290.

We did lose 5 wickts through the match three being run outs ## one bowled and one caught at deep midwicket## but we never once looked out of control. A great victory## played in great spirit by a team of talented players. Well done Ballinger##this means we are top of Division 1 and Division 2

A sunny evening## a dry wicket and outfield## was this a dream or was it really happening. We were playing cricket## happy days## would it matter who wins## of course it would## especially against our old foe from Ley Hill.

Ballinger won the toss and chose to bat## Max and Monty to the crease## Monty on his way back to the pavillion in the 1st over after Max called a run that was never on. Hamish joined Max in the middle and the pair looked solid until Max decided to try and launch the ball into orbit## missing it completely and losing his off stump. Ben next up and again the pair looked solid unjtil Ben tried to launch the ball into orbit## missing it completely and losing his middle stump## obviously a family trait. Harry McMullan next up making his U17 debut## falling to a good delivery. Ballinger 33 for 4 in the eigth over## the sun not shining so brightly. Matthew OKelly in next with Ballingerr in need of inspiration. He and Hamish putting on 50 runs in the next 6 overs before Hamish was caught on the boundary looking to push the score on. Ballinger now 83 for 5 and back in the game. Dom Brown joining Matthew and the pair putting on a further 26 runs before Dom runs himself out. 109 for 6 with 2overs left. Connor Underwood to the middle and he and Matthew adding 13 runs finishing the innings on 122 for 6. Was this going to be enough?

Ley Hill took to the middle with their openers looking to push the score on and making 122 look well below par. Some agressive and accurate bowling from the Ballinger attack was rewarded when Sam Peters took the 1st wicket## Will Price trying to launch the ball into orbit## missing it completely and losing his middle stump## seemingly trying to outdo the Dugdale's. Hamish taking the next wicket with Ley Hill 21 for 2 off 5 overs. Jamie Woodley now joining Joe Batt at the crease and the pair adding 20 runs in the next 4 overs with a promising partnership developing. Ben Dugdale now bowling to Joe Batt who smashes the ball back down the wicket## Ben throwing himself at the ball## managing to deflect it onto the stumps with Jamie out of his ground. A fortunate but valuable wicket. Excellent bowling from Ballinger made it difficult for Ley Hill before James Fray took the importnad wicket of Joe Batt who tried to launch tha ball into orbit## missing it completely and losing his middle stump. A theme seeming to develop here. Ley Hill now 70 for 4 off 15 overs. Ballinger continued to make it difficult to score and further wickets fell to Monty and Hamish before the Ley Hill innings closed on 102 for 7.

Ballinger winning by 20 runs thanks to an excellent bowling and fielding effort by all the team.

Ballinger went from one extreme to the other in five days## playing the strongest team we shall play this year## Chesham## on Monday## and what I suspect will be the weakest team we shall face on Friday. Holmer Green won the toss and decided to bat and after six overs from the Ballinger openers## Fin Clark (0-1) and Max Leane (3-3)## the result of the game was already very obvious## with Holmer Green at only 7## with 3 wickets down.   The seventh over saw 2 more wickets for Freddie Thompson## including a stumping by Marcus Tingey; after which Ballinger took their foot off the bowling pedal## and used the innings effectively as some bowling practice## with everyone## apart from those designated to open the batting## having a bowl.  That was useful## with some good contributions from Simon Carlin## Ben Westland## Henry King and Josh Brown.  Josh in particular bowled impressively accurately.  Holmer Green wickets continued to fall## with 1 for Joe Turrell## 1 for Ben Westland## 1 for Henry King and 1 more for Thompson.  Meanwhile runs came only very slowly.  They were all out in the final over  for 51.

Michael Everett and Hugo Baker opened the innings for Ballinger and they did well to put away some reasonably rapid but very loose bowling## including several wides and over-waist-height no balls (two of which were put away for four with excellent hook shots from the Ballinger openers).  Hugo fell for 7 with the score on 21 and then Michael for 10 with the score on 30## leaving Marcus Tingey and Simon Carlin to finish the innings off with a flurry of boundaries – after 8.1 overs.

It was all far too easy really## but all good fun for the Ballinger boys## on a lovely sunny evening## with a large Holmer Green crowd watching from the bar!  It is hard to choose a man of the match really## since that should be someone whose outstanding performance had the biggest influence on the outcome of the match.  On that basis## however## it is Max Leane## whose spell of 3 for 3## removing the Holmer Green top order## made the result obvious even sooner than it might have been. Champagne moment: Hugo Baker’s hooking a very high and fast full toss all along the ground for four.

Well done everyone.

Andy

It didn't look promising at 10am when junior training was cancelled due to a wet outfield and there was a thunderstorm forecast. It didn't look promising at 2pm as## after winning the toss and inserting Ley Hill## they had raced to 50 without loss off the first eight overs. So a decision to take pace of the ball seemed the right one## although there was some surprise as the job fell to ex-quickie James McIntyre who hadn't bowled leg spin in a match at any level. Two wickets in his first over helped settle the nerves and with the help of Matt the brakes were gently applied to Ley Hill's runaway train. Searching around the team for another bowler the skipper alighted on one N.Kerry who was looking forward to another dreamy afternoon in the Ballinger sunshine. Lets make him sweat - although off three paces there wasn't much chance of that ! The barnacle-like opener was soon on his way back to the hutch bamboozled by the Kerry bag of tricks. The real story unfolded at the other end as young James completed a five timer for just 29 runs off his 10 overs with only 16 coming off the bat. Two tight spells from Matt which cost just 24 runs and a better second spell from Andy helped tighten the noose. Ballinger's third secret weapon ## McIntyre senior - looking to all intents and purposes like Jade Dernbach - sans tatoos - wrapped up the innings. The outfield cricket was excellent including a fine diving catch from 'pads' Conway.

Our opening pair## average age 38## though one was nearly five times as old as the other ! Marcus Tingey## making his Senior bow## had kept very tidily and been deprived of a catch despite the edge being heard by some HS2 surveyors down the road ! He looked very comfortable before scooping one## bringing 'Jade' McIntyre to the crease. The two 'bowlers' showed another side to their games and took the score along to 70 before Nigel departed just 4 short of his fifty. Steve Carter continued the good work until he too fell with the score on 105. A mid order collapse ensued before the McIntyre combo steadied the ship. However Rob's departure led to another clatter of wickets so that when Andy joined the skipper as the last pair 26 runs were still needed off the last four overs. Recognising a chance at redemption for some ordinairy bowling Andy lashed the Ley Hill attack to all parts of the ground (well one really !) and Ballinger got home with 3 balls to spare. 

A hugely enjoyable game (and victory) with some notable performances amongst a fine team display. I'm sure many will look back on this game as the highlight of the season even if there are some aching bones around this morning.

A sunny## pleasant afternoon's cricket seemed a far from likely prospect in view of a forecast of thunder## lightning and heavy rain all morning. In the event## the rain was short-lived## and an efficient Ley Hill ground staff had covered the wicket## so that play could start on time## under blue skies.

Trusting that their pitch would be a good one## Ley Hill took first knock## and openers Lown and Peterson were proceeding smoothly## until the latter was bowled by Nick Adams## who then accounted for Clarke the very next ball## undone by a full toss. This brought the dangerous Daluwatte to the crease## and he was soon scoring freely.  Nick yorked Lown. to make it 43 for 3##finishing an excellent spell with 3 for 27## but Ballinger had to wait until the 20th over before Ian Davies pulled off a spectacular catch on the boundary to account for the hard-hitting Thompson## off Ian Maciver's spin. At 90 for 4## and only 22 overs gone## Ley Hill were now looking well placed for a commanding total## but in the space of the next six overs they lost their next 5 wickets for only 9 runs. We saw the unusual sight of three hat-trick chances as both Ian Maciver and Will Reid joined Nick in taking wickets with consecutive balls. Richard O'Kelly took a smart  catch behind the stumps## and was cruelly denied a fine stumping effort. When the persevering Daluwatte fell LBW to Will for a well earned 36## the score was 105 for 9## and the end seemed nigh.  Messrs Morris and Ottaway had other ideas though## and spent the next eight overs carefully## and occasionally aggressively## hoisting the total to 140 before Morris chanced his arm once too often## and Ian Davies gratefully grasped another skier. Ian Maciver ended with figures of 3 for 36## and special praise for Will Reid## with 3 for 19 off a hostile 7 overs.

With five overs to bat before tea## Ballinger needed a safe start## but in only the second over Richard O'Kelly edged to the keeper## and left Matt Riley## making his first Saturday appearance this season## and Andy Thompson to survive until the break. This they did## but the scoreboard had only reached 25 with ten overs gone## when Andy edged## fatally## to the slips. Meanwhile Matt was batting confidently## and it was a surprise when he fell LBW for a well struck 23## giving Ottaway his third wicket. Max Dugdale continued his luckless season## also LBW## and it was 62 for 4. The in-form Ian Davies now joined Rollo McIntyre## and both of them batted splendidly## having to contend with a variety of accurate spin bowling## and gradually the total mounted## with every opportunity taken for quick singles. Rollo contributed his usual array of big hits## but his was a thoroughly responsible knock - the sight of him playing out maiden overs was a rare one!. With the total on 118## and victory now seeming a distinct possibility## Ian was bowled by the ever impressive Daluwatte for an invaluable 19## which brought Carlton in to join Rollo. Carlton smashed three consecutive balls from Ottaway for four## in an over which cost 14 runs## and Ballinger were virtually home and dry. Rollo finished unbeaten on 61## including 10 fours and two sixes -  a wonderful return to the form of which we know he is capable.

This was an all-round excellent performance by Ballinger## words which have not been aired for a while!
report to follow

A warm humid sunny day turns into a grey muggy evening with occasional showers## our opposition arrive early and my phone continues to receive text messages as boys are travelling from athletic events in Eton are caught up in traffic## slowly but surely they start to appear from the hedge ## very kindly Beaconsfield allow us to bat allowing the rest of the team to arrive. This is our first real challenge and it become quite clear fro the off that they have been practicing and have new members.

Oliver and Archie open against some quality bowling and put on a very respectable 18## Raphi and Kuran take us up to 236 and Matthew and Louis on to 262 ## so far we have only lost 2 wickets [one of which was a borderline call by myself]## Sebastian and Max FE push us along to 274## so it looks like we could hit 300## but Thomas and Max only manage to get us to 288 as Max C decided to try new and innovative ways of being dismissed including a dilshan which was caught by a very shocked boy at 3rd man [we shall be working on not giving away your wicket at the weekend]. 288 with our bowling attack was a big ask for any team to reach.
Our opening attack was accurate## fierce and in some instances very fast. we were giving nothing away in terms of runs ## but a few byes and a couple of wides allowed them to reach 213 after 12 overs## wickets fell to Thomas## Matthew##Louis ##Archie##Sebastian [Wicket Maiden]##Max FE [3 wickets] and Oliver. By the 16th over they were on 216## the last two batsmen came in with nothing to lose and with Oliver and Raphi bowling the last four overs there could be runs and wickets with the batsmen edging and running every ball Ballinger style. They put on some brave runs which took them to a more respectable 247.
A solid win for Ballinger against a decent opposition in some challenging conditions. Sebastian Phillips deserves a mention for textbook leg spin and Oliver managed his team and bowling order extremely well which  clearly added to the result## our fielding was good## but we have been better and we need to support the team by being sharper## as this again is worth runs to us.
A fun match with a fun and friendly opposition## such a good experience for everyone. WELL DONE!!!!!!!!
Our Next U10A fixture is this Sunday morning away against Amersham -

The only good thing about losing## as such## is that one tends to learn more from defeat than from victory.  There can sometimes be other good things about specific defeats## such as good individual performances. Both points apply to this match.

Chalfont St Giles is a very high-scoring ground.  The track is very good indeed to bat on## the boundaries are short and the outfield slopes away from the track on most sides.   It can be difficult to bowl on and certainly difficult to keep the runs down.  A friend of mine who coaches at Chalfont said to me between the innings that the Ballinger total of 134 for 3 was “daunting”.  For the reasons just mentioned## I disagreed with him.  On most grounds## that would be a winning total## but not on this one.  It may seem an odd thing to say with 134 off 20 overs## but the reality is that our defeat was caused by not scoring as many runs as we should have.  The main lesson is that when setting a total you should strive to grab every run that you can.  Although batting very well## the Ballinger batsmen throughout## and especially towards the end## were guilty of missing out on singles and in particular missing out on turning ones into twos## which could have given Ballinger an extra 10 runs at least – which would have meant victory.

That said## the Ballinger batting effort was a very good one. Having lost Freddie Thompson early after a breezy start## Matthew Barton batted extremely well for 18 before being run out## to get the Ballinger innings off to a fast start.  He showed a good sense of urgency and was very much not the stodgy opener.  The backbone of the innings was Fin Clark’s 50 (retired)## which included some skilful leg glances and strong hits over the top.  An impressive## balanced and well-paced innings.  He was assisted in a stand of 70 by Simon Carlin## who scored a very good 23. He is a very able cricketer who I hope is gaining the confidence in his own abilities which his coaches already have.  Hugo Eaton-Hart joined in at the end with a lusty 13 not out## striking the ball hard from the start – exactly what is required when coming in at the end of an innings.  The only criticism I would make of the Ballinger batters is the one identified above – not enough urgency in the running throughout.

The Chalfont innings started very slowly with only 27 scored off the first 8 overs## bowled by Freddie Thompson and Hannah Bates.  Having bowled extremely well against Chesham last week## Hannah turned in another excellent performance for an U 12 girl bowling in an U14 boys match## with figures of none for 10 off 4 overs.  Really top bowling.  However## at that stage## needing 106 off 12 overs## the Chalfont batsmen set about getting them with plenty of aggression and some skill## particularly after their opener had been well caught by Miles Devereux off Will Hardman in the 12th over.  The remaining Chalfont opener## Drage## and their number 3## Bright## both scored 50s (retired); with the Ballinger bowling for the remaining 12 overs going for an average of nearly 9 an over## with none of the 6 further bowlers used being spared.  It was tough## as a number of younger bowlers## playing up in what was a depleted XI did their very best against some muscular batting on an excellent track.  Sadly## the quality of the fielding dipped a little and Ballinger voices became fewer and further between as the fielding side began to feel a gathering sense that## despite scoring all those runs## they could actually lose.  Chastening stuff.

Man of the match: the Fin Clark for his excellent half-century.  Champagne moment: Hugo Eaton- Hart’s first boundary from only his third ball as he launched an immediate and selfless assault on the Chalfont bowling in the final overs of the first innings.

Andy

Skipper Charlotte put the opposition into bat## feeling more comfortable with a chase than setting a target.   Lucy stepped in last minute for one absentee## so we fielded a full side and the girls seemed confident in the field.  The pick of the bowling was Nicky## who once again delivered the first wicket…and the second - leaving Stokenchurch somewhat reeling at 16 for 2.  However## the opposition Skipper settled the innings and the runs started to flow.  Nevertheless## there was some good effort in the field.  The younger girls## Annie## Milly and Daisy## fielding at 3rd Man## Long stop## and fine leg were onto the ball quickly## stopping quite a few runs.  Laura was particularly impressive in the field - putting her body on the line more than once.  Ellie again bowled tightly.  Lucy bowled well and surprised with some pace in her 3rd over.  Elodie really should have taken her second over as her left arm action bamboozled the opposition but in her modesty and generosity felt that others should have a chance.   Olivia bowled the most amazing ball of the day## pitching outside leg and hitting the top of leg stump to finally get their immovable opener.   Poppy once again impressed with gloves - earning individual praise from the opposition coach## himself a wicket keeper.  The opposition scored a mighty 119## which was always going to be a tough ask for our inexperienced team.
 
Stokenchurch bowling proved to be much more challenging than Farnham Royal - both quicker and more accurate.  Scoring runs off the bat was challenging## nevertheless## the girls do need to learn to be more aggressive with calling and taking runs.  Wickets came quite quickly initially## however the middle order led by Ellie and Elodie steadied the ship.  Lucy was impressive with her stroke play and Ellie alert to the run opportunities.  Again a flurry of wickets in the 9th over threatened an early collapse but Poppy and Milly proved resilient## blocking the good balls and eeking out runs.  Milly as one of the youngest was particularly impressive.  Poppy was out## caught well by the wicket keeper off the glove.    A rear guard action by Milly and Annie meant that the Wagonnettes survived 19 overs (3 more than against Farnham Royal)## which was impressive against this attack and led to a final score of 52## our highest yet.   
 
The girls should feel proud - they have taken on a tough opposition and delivered a decent result.
Winning Report To Follow

Big black clouds assembled on the horizon as the players arrived.  However## the enthusiasm of the girls and wafts of sizzling BBQ soon saw them off. 

Skipper this time was Poppy## who once again won the toss and put her side into the field.   Charlotte R## who had been looking menacing in warm up## was no less so in her first over - narrowly missing the stumps on more than one occasion.  She was ably supported by Isabel at the other end - Isabel's second over was particularly high quality.  First change were Laura and Charlotte C## who were unfortunate to be bowling against the their skipper and best batsman Alex## who now had his eye in.  Both girls often bowled very good line and length## but Alex was able to use his feet well and scored freely.   The two youngsters## Annie and Daisy decided that they would bowl one over each for this match…and then enjoyed it so much that they requested to bowl a second! They both justified it - Daisy was very accurate and Annie got one of only 3 wickets## taken in the innings.   Olivia was probably my pick of the bowlers and extremely unlucky not to get a wicket.  On comes Elodie## and proves to herself that she does after all deserve to bowl her two overs by taking the first wicket.   Eva and Ellie wrapped up the bowling well.  Ellie taking the third wicket with an excellent catch by wicket keeper## Poppy.   The fielding was generally very good - Laura again did not let anything through.  Charlotte R worked hard and has an excellent throw.  Eva at Point was solid.  I would have liked to see more use of the Long Barrier## which they all demonstrate well in practice and then seem to forget when it comes to the matches.  Just as important was the noise level on the field in this game - there was much more energy and encouragement from the girls to each other - it's great to see the spirit of the team developing.

Time to bat…Ellie and Isabel were the pick of the batters with some good firm hits## taking good runs.  Charlotte C was very unlucky to fall so quickly## her bat grazing the bails as she swung round.  Poppy survived some tricky balls## connecting well and scored her first ever run off the bat.   The middle order of Laura## Elodie## Eva## Annie and Charlotte R were unlucky to come up against some superb bowling.  Daisy and Olivia provided some brief resistance at the end - both scoring runs with Olivia hitting a memorable shot "over the top".  Although our score in reply to their 131 was our lowest yet this season## this was probably our best batting display.   That sounds like an oxymoron but two aspects of the Waggonette batting innings need to be considered.   Firstly## the opposition bowled just one wide - something of a record in any division## let alone division 4.  The Wooburn bowling was both accurate but good length which was very challenging## Secondly## the hit rate was much higher.  I estimate that the girls connected with the ball about 4 times more than they did on Wednesday and they scored double the number of runs off the bat## because they connected more often and were more aggressive with the running - particularly Isabel.  

 

It is thoroughly enjoyable to coach a side like the Waggonette Bs## who are able to take so much from a losing cause - they are all enthusiastic and keen; they are beginning to find the confidence to express this enthusiasm in the field and in their batting.  On on!

It was back down to earth with a bump for the Seconds this week## as a depleted team travelled to league leaders ##Waddesdon. Another new opening pair combined the experienced Nigel with new found opener Matt. Nigel's early departure## set the tone for the afternoon as a rather puzzled Matt watched his partners return## one by one to the hutch. What was so difficult ? Sure the track was slow and wet and the outfield cavernous but Matt continued to make it look easy. No-one could stay with him## as we all found novel ways to get out. He reached his 50 with six wickets down and when he finally perished to an outstanding catch he was the 9th wicket down.

With conditions improving as the wicket dried out Ballinger needed a decent start - Reece Tiley## returning after 2 years out through injury## duly served a wicket up in the first over. A fine spell from the other end from Will Arnold backed up him up and after 12 overs Waddesdon were struggling at 19-1. However we were always a bowler light and despite another tight spell from Matt## the string of part time bowlers were pushed around the park without too much difficulty although there was a promising debut from Will Russell. The youthful (for the most part !) Ballinger team received a harsh lesson in running between the wickets from Cadmore refugee Spike who showed whats possible as we struggled to stem the quick singles. It only served to highlight the missed runs in the Ballinger innings. By the time the skipper belatedly brought back his main bowlers the bird had flown and Waddesdon cruised to 136 -1.

A disappointing end to what had promised at one time to be a good performance. However it was decent weather in a peaceful setting## even if we had only Matt's 50## the first of many hopefully ## to savour

On the face of it## to lose narrowly to league leaders Waddesdon might be construed as encouraging. The reality was that Waddesdon were missing five of their regular side## as became evident when## opting to field first## they put down a hatful of catches## which## if held## would have put Ballinger in trouble. As it was## Ballinger put on 71 for their first wicket## without either opener looking really comfortable## against a steady attack. Matt Riley was first to depart## edging to the keeper for a somewhat fortunate 20. Andy Thompson followed three overs later## leg before## soon after reaching an excellent half century## and efforts to up the scoring rate proved difficult especially against Adnam## whose 10 overs cost only 17 runs##- 9 of which were no balls! Carlton soon left## also LBW## making it 104 for 3## with 33 overs gone. Rollo## however## was going well## continuing his form from the previous week## and making the most of the few scoring opportunities on offer. The Waddesdon captain then made a game-altering bowling change by bringing himslf on. With Nick Adams having been promoted to accelerate the run-rate## the combination was electrifying. The last 7 overs of the innings went for 75## 46 of them off the hapless skipper's 3 overs. Rollo finshed unbeaten on 42 including 3 sixes and## and Nick on 27 (2 sixes). A 40-over total of 179 was by far Ballinger's highest of the season##and hopes were high for victory. 

The Waddesdon openers looked to be in little trouble## and scored relatively freely## but a change of bowling earned the first wicket with the total on 45## when Carlton struck in his first over. The next change had the same outcome## when skipper Ian Maciver's first over was a wicket maiden## to make it 67 for 2## and only 14 overs bowled.There followed a lengthy partnership between the aggressive opener Atkinson and Irwin## which looked to be tilting the march Waddesdon's way until Irwin was run out from a direct hit by boundary fielder dead-eye Matt Riley## as he had the nerve to take a second run. Ian Maciver was by now keeping the batsmen almost scoreless (after 8 overs he had conceded a mere 5 runs and taken 3 wickets!)## but runs at the other end kept the scoreboard moving. Ballinger's fielding was## on the whole## rather sloppy## but there followed two exceptions: a superb catch by Will Reid## hurling himself full-length on the boundary## and another good run-out## this time from a fine return by Rollo.  Nick returned to the attack and took a wicket## as did Evan Webster## but still the runs kept coming. Eight wickets were down## the batsmen were grabbing every chance to steal singles## and the match could go either way. And so it continued## amidst great tension## until one run was needed off the final ball of the 40th and final over. It was successfully run## and Ballinger were left to rue the 33 extras conceded## which in the end had cost them the game.

Overcast at shardaloes ## but a very warm and friendly welcome from the Amersham players. Our Captain Sebastian won the toss and chose to field. Thomas B's first over was a double wicket maiden and Amershams woes continued from there on. More wickets fell to Matthew[2]## Edward##Louis##Max and Sebastian [3] and a fine wicket maiden to Finn Henry. Some excellent run outs by Louis and Archie and Hannah. We also had the pleasure of having Hannah Bates one of our great girl players who bowled on the stumps every ball. amersham never really managed to get going and we only gave away 9 extras## some may say 9 too many## but at this level of the game it is still better than most othe rteams## but an area still to work on. Amersham Finished on 200. 

I expected our side to get to around 280 and from the start we never looked like doing anything apart from continuing to command the field. Finn and Edward took us up to 220## Matthew and Louis up to 228## Tim and Seb pushed us further on to 255## Max and Hanna moved us on to 268 and Thomas and Archie finished the innings off on 293. I lost the bet of ending on 280## but we dont always get it right.

Well done to all of the boys and special thanks to Hannahs parents and Hannah and also to Nick and tim Hayes for stepping in at the last moment.

Under leaden skies and a breeze sufficient for the scorers to move inside## I mused that the Great Missenden Misfits were not aptly named. Rather they were a very competent side both initially with ball## and in the field where even their older ones were all prepared to dive around## and with bat. So it is with particular pleasure that I record a big win – we scored almost 200 and they scored only slightly over 100.

Our innings was built firmly on a stand of real verve of about 100 between Tom McIntyre (73) and Hamish (56)## the latter doing particularly well to keep the momentum going when he lost his marginally more senior partner## who had inter alia hit a peach of an on-drive and these days seems capable of really taking the attack to the opposition. Indeed I thought the quality of Tom and Hamish’s leg-side shots was of a very high-order – Max too in a brief cameo.

And fortified with a fine tea from Veronica## we then showed equal verve in our bowling and fielding. How nice it is for a captain to have some venom in his opening bowlers; immediately Hamish and Dom (3 wickets) were at and through their top order and then the old stagers in Andy Rowe and Stuart MacGowan (the latter with a niggardly## miserly spell) worked their way through the middle and lower middle order## leaving only a man called  Kaye## P and Harris – a veritable giant. Well## AR accounted for the former to universal acclamation (KP having personal characteristics in common with a better known cricketer of the same initials) and then Matt  O’Kelly held his line and nerve to have Goliath caught safely by Tom M at a wide-ish long on.

And so it came to pass that the Missenden men were humbled by the boys of Ballinger## not least because the fielding had involved a good deal of athleticism (all catches caught## little or nothing given away cheaply on the ground). 

Plaudits as ever to Miles for doing everything. Respect for their man who “walked” and their umpire who gave (as he should) a front foot LBW. Privilege to have skippered you guys. And## boys## you are not supposed to start a sentence with an “and”.

Rob McIntyre
Batting first we made 154 for 4 in 20 overs and restricted Chesham to 84

We drew Charlsbury Oxfordshire away and had to be up early to get there for a 9.30 start !! Charlsbury batted first and we got them all out for 79. The runs were knocked off with no loss of wickets by Tilly and Hannah in 11.5 overs.

On yet another sunny evening the home team won the toss and put Ballinger in to bat on what looked a decent track. Early indications confirmed as much as Max and Monty put on 41 runs in 6 overs before Monty was caught off a thick edge to the keeper. Hamish joined Max in the middle and they put on 17 quick runs before Max fell to a great delivery## Ballinger 58 for 2 off 8 overs. Ben was next up and he and Hamish set about the Ley Hill attack## helped by some erratic bowling and loose fielding the pair put on 85 runs in 12 overs before Ben is unluckily run out. Matt joined Hamish for the remaining 5 balls with Hamish in touching distance of his 50. Another 7 runs were added with Hamish finishing on 52 not out## a great innings. Ballinger 150 for 3 off their 20 overs.

Although a decent total Ley Hill were in confident mood with their openers Joe Batt and Will Price looking to take on the Ballinger attack. Both looked to be in good nick before Batt had his stumps re-arranged by a great delivery from Will Reid. Callum Wilson next to the crease and he and Price continued to take on the Ballinger bowling. The score 51 for 1 off 6 overs and Ley Hill up with the required rate before the dangerous Price## trying to hit Hamish down the ground## was well caught by Matt O'Kelly. 51 for 2 soon becomes 57 for 3 as Wilson has his stumps re-arranged this time by Hamish. With Ley Hills big hitters back in the pavilion it was up to Matt Burr to try and salvage something for the home side. Ley Hill now 58 for 4 off 10 overs. Captain Ben Dugdale feeling the game was now in control varied his bowling options. Ley hill putting on a further 19 runs off 4 overs before the next wicket## 77 for 5 off 14 overs. A further 34 runs in the next 5 overs take the home side to 111 before wicket 6 tumbles with 1 over remaining. Will Reid to do the honours## 2 dot balls## wicket## wicket## hat trick a strong possibility## the fielders surround the incoming bat Brandon Tuberville but he manages to keep out the next 2 deliveries and Ley Hill finish on 111 for 8 off their 20 overs.

A convincing performance by Ballinger both with bat and ball. Man of the Match undoubtably Hamish but everyone played their part. Great bowling from Will Reid was nearly overshadowed by his brilliant 2 handed catch leaping up to take a ball that looked well beyond his reach.

A very satisfying victory## built on some sound cricket in all departments.  I said in the last report## on the Chalfont St Giles game## that one usually learns more from defeat than from  victory.  We seemed today to have learned a lot from last week’s defeat and we put nearly everything which was wrong on that occasion## right on this.

Ballinger won the toss and decided to bat and openers Thompson and Turrell set off like a train scoring 21 of the first two overs## but unfortunately both departed## Thompson to a shooter and Turrell to a slightly over-ambitious shot spooned to extra cover.  Things could have gone wrong at that point## but enter Marcus Tingey## who top scored with 20 and formed the backbone of the innings.  He was sensible in defence but very quick to be aggressive## eg hitting his ball for 4.  A very pleasing knock.  He was well supported by Carlin## Eaton-Hart## Devereux (who glided three fours in one over down to third man) and Everett.  Leane## Westland## Brown (who timed the ball very nicely) and Barton carried on the good work at the end of the innings## until Ballinger were all out after 19.4 overs for 104. I mentioned everyone there## since everyone batted with the right mix of defence to the really good balls and aggression for anything else; and everyone this week was quick to look for singles and quick to turn 1s into 2s wherever possible.

My opposite number at the break thought that our total was a good one.  I was not quite sure it would be enough## since much would depend on how we bowled and fielded.  I need not have worried.  We bowled extremely straight and fielded very efficiently indeed.  Bowling straight is crucial in limited overs matches at this level.  A teammate of mine on Saturdays continually shouts the mantra “no width” to our bowlers## quite rightly## since if you bowl straight you inhibit the batsman’s ability to score runs without taking undue risks and in particular you confine the batsman to hitting straight unless he is prepared to take the big risk of playing across the line.  All of our bowlers – Thompson (1 for 13 off 4)## Leane (2 for 14 off 3)## Westland (2 for 13 off 4)## Turrell (0 for 16 off 4)## Tingey (3 for 14 off 2) and Carlin (1 for 8 off 2) turned in tidy performances and tidy figures## since all bowled very straight.  Leane was rewarded with the scalps of both openers## LBW to a straight one which kept low and caught behind off a faint edge.  Westland replaced him and took a wicket with his first ball## much to everyone’s joy.  He added another.  And then Marcus Tingey took over## performing the same trick of taking a wicket with his first ball## followed by two more in the same over to finish off the Gerrards X challenge.  Meanwhile## at the other end## Turrell had bowled 4 very steady overs## keeping the pressure up## as Gerrards X fell further and further behind the required rate of five and over.  In limited overs cricket the bowlers who create the pressure by restricting the runs don’t always take the wickets.  Often the wickets which their pressure has created are taken by others.  It is a team effort.  There were no serious errors in the field.  Everyone got down and fielded everything that came to them tidily.  Particular mention is due to those fielding on the boundaries## including Carlin## Eaton-Hart and Leane## all of whom took and returned several shots which were hit to them very hard## without making a single error.  Very tidy cricket.  In short - ultimately## a lot of straight bowling and good fielding created pressure on the Gerrards Cross batsmen and so wickets tumbled and Ballinger won.

Man of the match:  clearly Marcus Tingey## who top scored and also took the most wickets (having also kept pretty well for 8 overs before handing the gloves to Thompson).   Champagne moment: Ben Westland taking a wicket with his first ball (made even better knowing with hindsight that he then carried on and bowled 4 very good overs on the trot).

A very good win – well done everyone!

Andy

David won the toss and elected to bat.  Amersham immediately got underway## bombarding the opening batsmen with fast## accurate deliveries. Archie and Max defended well and as their confidence grew they started to accumulate runs.  The first BW wicket fell in the 3rd over.  The innings were punctuated with 4s## scored by David## Oliver and Harvey.  All the batsmen played excellent strokes## showing real development and confidence## particularly further down the batting order;  Angus## Jake## Felix## LJ and Tom steadily increased the score. Some risky singles in some cases narrowly avoided run-outs with Usain-Bolt-esque dashes between the wickets.  Some sliding in of the bat was closely followed by sliding in of the batsman.

Innings total of 54 all out in 19 overs

Oliver opened the bowling account for Ballinger with some well-pitched and challenging deliveries.  He was duly rewarded on the 4th ball of the first over with the leg stump of Amersham’s opening batsman.  On the very next ball the delivery was edged straight into the hands of our star Ballinger wicket keeper Max; As a result## Batsman number two was on his way to the pavilion.  Now the boys were fired:  With encouragement from the rest of the team## Oliver’s final ball of the over was misread and Batsman No. 3 was out plumb LBW.

 

Overs Two to Six were brilliantly fielded by Ballinger with the team displaying good communication## excellent fielding discipline and real purpose.  Felix and Jake ran a tight ship## defending point and cover positions;   Angus## Harvey and Archie managed the on-side## while Tom patrolled the outfield in deep extra cover.  Over No. 7 was a maiden (Archie)## followed by another wicket in the 8th; a collaboration between Harvey (bowing) and Max (catching).  Another wicket ball from Archie in the 9th followed fast and the remaining four overs passed without incident while Amersham approached the Ballinger target.  The game finished in the Thirteenth over:  Amersham 56 for 5 in 13 overs.

Playing 9 man Prestwood should have been a straightforward assignment## but not for the first time the Seconds made hard work of it at times. The opposition won the toss and unsurprisingly opted to take first knock## and fuelled by an aggressive innings from Spur they raced to 49 without loss off the first 7 overs. A wicket maiden from Fin slowed things down## but the real turning point came with a farcical run out at the start of the 14th over## that saw the end of Spur for 50## Fin with an accurate throw leaving him stranded. Ballinger were then able to tighten the screw through Ben and Andy. Wickets fell at regular intervals in a fine spell of bowling from Andy Rowe who took his fifth and sixth wickets with consecutive balls and then looked forlornly as no more Prestwood batsmen emerged from the pavillion.

Back out to bat with 40 minutes before tea## we made a bit of a mess of it as the openers decided they wanted to enjoy their tea without having to worry about the Prestwood bowling attack. A fine tea## courtesy of Fiona who's contribution at that stage exceeded that of her eldest son## was quickly followed by the return of Marcus & Steve 'dude' Carter to the hutch. 34 for 4. Time to go on the attack we felt. Ben and Dom - who clearly wanted to take some measure of revenge - quickly took the score past 100 before Ben went for a big swing. When he opened his eyes his stumps had been rearranged. Fin joined Dom##who raced to his 50 and finished the match with a six.

A reasonable performance and a satisfying result. An outstanding spell from Andy backed up by Fin and Josh in particular## and responsible innings from Dom and Ben saw us home comfortably in the end.

England humiliated in the World Cup; smashed by the All Blacks; McIlroy missed the cut.....could life get any worse for Wendover CC## without a win in the league so far? Could Ballinger grab some easy points to boost their own shaky league position? Read on...

Ian Davies returning## more sun-tanned than ever## to lead his men## won the toss and decided to give his bowlers first go. They did not disappoint him. Opener Patel## surviving a snick to the keeper off Will Reid's first ball## which only the umpire failed to detect## took root in a display of astonishing immobility## falling for a duck after facing 33 dot balls## in the 14th over##  with the total on 19! His fellow opener went next over## for  a more respectable 17## although he too had at one time faced 35 balls in scoring 1. Nick Adams conceded only one run off his first 5 overs## and though finishing wicket-less## his 10 over spell cost just 10 runs. Ian Maciver had come on to replace Will Reid in the 14th over;  the Wendover batsmen found him virtually unplayable## and his figures of 5 for 15 in his 10 overs were proof of a superb spell of spin bowling. With half their overs gone Wendover had only 26 runs on the board## with three wickets down## so the fact that their second 20 overs yielded a further 84 was proof that their later batsmen were determined to make a game of it.

However## a target of 111 on what had proved to be a pitch with no demons in it was evidently one that Ballinger could tackle with confidence. Unfortunately for Andy Thompson## already suffering from some unkind late-order abuse of his bowling## the pitch now decided to deal him a grubber## castling him for a confident 7. This was an ideal opportunity for fellow opener Richard O'Kelly to bat himself back into form## which is exactly what he did## whilst Rollo continued with his own fine form## and the pair of them gave a delightful batting exhibition## looking to have won the game## when both departed bowled## unexpectedly## leaving the match to be won amid a flurry of extras## with 12 overs to spare.

A thoroughly excellent all-round display by Ballinger. Well done indeed!

Almost snatched victory from the jaws of defeat. 

Some good hitting from Harry## Sam and Will set us up with a defendable total## particularly with rain threatenign and and looking failry gloomy. 

We lost narrowly and learnt a very valuable lesson. Keep pressure on the opposition all of the time## you never know when/if they might fall over. Ballinger were looking at losing this game quickly until Charlotte put seeds of doubt into their minds with some accurate building. Charlotte brought the pressure on## and CSG lost four wickets in seven balls. Unfortunately## it was a little too late. 

Game management. Think about your fielding positions and keeping the other team under pressure. Fast bowling is not always the answer## but field placings and enthusiastic play are pretty much always going to change the game.

Well done everyone. Another day and we might have won this one. 

 

Sharks

Ballinger Waggoners v High Wycombe 15/06/14

 

Ballinger Waggoners 311 for 3 wickets

High Wycombe 260 for 11 wickets

 

A cloudy Sunday morning saw High Wycombe win the toss and decided to field first.

Freddie and James opened the innings and put on a sound 22 run partnership## this set the tone to the other Ballinger batsmen to accumulate runs with the loss of 3 wickets against some strong bowling from High Wycombe. All the batsmen showed great maturity in putting away the bad ball and defending potential wicket taking balls (using the forward defensive stroke which had been practiced on Saturday). The end of the innings saw Daniel and Toby R coming in and hitting some powerful shots. Ballinger posted a target of 311.

 

A good bowling and fielding display saw Ballinger take 11 wickets in High Wycombe innings and this decided the outcome of the match. Three of these wickets were due to run outs and as usual all the lads are very sharp in the field and are constantly trying to run out batsmen at every opportunity. High Wycombe had loaded their big hitters towards the end of the innings so a special mention to Noah who bowled the last over against two well set batsmen and he bowled quick and straight.  High Wycombe amassed a total of 260.

 

After the Marlow match this game was played in a Great Spirit and High Wycombe enjoyed the match so much they would like to organise some friendly matches later in the month or in July.

 

I didn’t have a chance to say thank you to parents who organised the drinks and snacks for the lads this is always much appreciated.

 

The boys once again all played well and all have great talent## they were captained very well by Freddie who made some crucial decisions at critical times.

 

Key performances

 

Bowling

Joe 2 wickets for 13 runs

Daniel 1 wicket for 2 runs

Tom 1 wicket for 12 runs

Toby M 1 wicket 11 runs

Edward 1 wicket for 12 runs

James 1 wicket for 15 runs

 

Batting

Toby R 14 runs

Tom   11 runs

Freddie 9 runs

Noah 6 runs

Mathew 5 runs

Another excellent game with lots of rivalry between teams and classmates. Our boys batted first and put on 249 against a good Chesham A attack. We only lost seven wickets which was impressive. Finn(12)## Sebastian(16) and Tim were the top scorers and all batted very well. There was also some good defense by Toby## Leo and Louis who all defended well and avoided getting out. Bwcc 249-7.
The Ballinger attack kept taking wickets which meant that Chesham fell behind the required rate. The bowling was mostly accurate but a few too many wides. catching and fielding were good. Sebastian captained well and was busy in the field. The game was in the balance and was getting tense. Chesham needed 20 off last two overs with their strongest batters in last. They scored 13 off 19th over which making the target 7 off the last.However Sebastian bowled a really good last over and  the game went to the last ball. it was a dot ball and Ballinger held their nerve to win by 2 runs. chesham 247-11.

 

Well done Ballinger. It's good to win tight games like this.

 

Bill Senior

Max Dugdale's maiden century for Ballinger was the highlight of this enjoyable days cricket. Ballinger winning the toss and captain Will Smith deciding to bat## then opting for youth to open the innings with Hamish and Max. Hamish unluckily going early## misjudging the pace of the ball on to the bat and catching a thick edge for an easy catch. Danny Draper joining Max in the middle with the pair adding 95 runs before Danny was caught## Ballinger 95 for 2 off 16 overs. Will Smith next to the crease with Max now established after some early scares. Max and Will putting on 121 runs in the next 16 overs before Max edges to the keeper looking to push the score along but not before hitting Rivetts best bowler Bilal for 25 in one over## closing in on his century with tea fast approaching. It was a very well crafted 112 including 13 fours and 4 sixes in a total of 92 balls faced. Will was next to go falling 3 short of his 50 in a solid innings that took a while to get started. Further wickets fell as Ballinger tried to push the score along in the final 15 minutes before tea## Ballinger finishing on 249 for 7 off 38 overs.

After an enjoyable tea provided by Graham## Rivetts took up the challenge. They were quick out the blocks scoring 36 in 5 overs before the first wicket## followed by wickets 2 and 3 in quick succession## the score now 38 for 3 after 6 overs. A further 27 runs were added before wicket 4## Rivetts 65 for 4 off 10 overs with Ballinger seemingly in controi. Ateeq## still in the middle and scoring freely was joined by captain Quasim with the pair adding 82 runs off the next 15 overs## the score 147 for 5 off 25 overs with 11 overs remaining. Wicket 6 fell 2 balls later but Ateeq was still scoring freely and now joined by Bilal## seemingly recovered from his mauling by Max earlier in the day. The pair adding 27 runs before the important wicket of Ateeq## out for 83## caught by Hamish of the as ever economical bowling of Stuart McGowan. With the score on 175 for 7 with 8 overs to go Bilal looked to take a more cautious approach. Ballinger looked to attack the other end and were rewared with wicket 8. Bilal looked solid as Ballinger continued to try and attack the weaker end but were without success until the final over## bowled by Hamish## with Bilal LBW off the first ball. 5 balls remaining## 1 wicket needed## bats 10 and 11 at the crease with Hamish giving it all he had. Rivetts managed to survive and earned a hard fought draw.

A great game## Ballinger with some wayward bowling at times and a few dropped catches had their chances to win the game but credit to Rivetts for initially trying to chase down a challenging total before eventually playing out for the draw.

Ballinger Girls were in the unusual situation of fielding first. Charlotte and Hattie opened the bowling and had Burnham 17 for 3 off 6. Burnham then had what looked like an unlikely partnership in 10 overs to take them to 81 before tha fall of the next wicket at 16 overs. From here Burnham continued to score and amassed 106 runs .

Although a big score## the boundaries were small and everyone knew how easy it could be with Georgina scoring 10 in the first over. This soon became 30 well crafted runs and then retired. Hannah continued getting runs even if her calling was not as crisp as usual. Hannah run out for 25 and the Tillty soon back on the boundary. Charlotte scored 14 runs but was also run out. At 87 for 3 off 13 overs everyone knew the win was just 2 overs away. The runs however dried up Jane was out for 0## Sophie survived 12 balls for her 1 before she was bowled. The winning runs were eventually scored by Lucy a very cleanly hit 4 off the first ball she faced. With 3 balls to spare Ballinger had held their nerve and just got home. A massive congratulations to Hattie for organising the tail as she had done on Sunday when she was involved in a lst wicket partnership of over 40 out of her teams total of 100.

A good performance by the U17's## winning the toss and chosing to bat Ballinger got off to the worst possible start with Monty running himself out this time in the first over. Hamish in next with Max carrying on where he left off on Sunday and the pair putting on 44 in the next 6 overs. Max getting to 30 in quick time before being stumped. Ben joining Hamish in the middle and both continuing to take on the Cublington attack## adding a further 32 in 4 overs before Ben is caught## Ballinger 77 for 3 off 10 overs. Things looking good for Ballinger but how quickly that can change## Dom and Connor come and go in quick time## Ballinger 95 for 5 off 13 overs.
