Toby Lyons now joining Hamish with Ballinger hoping for another decent partnership. Hamish departs with the score still on 95 and things not looking so promising. Matt O'Kelly up next and he and Toby add a quick 16 in the next 2 overs before Matt has his stumps re-arranged. Toby looking in good nick is joined by Josh Richardson## making his U17 re-appearance## doesn't stay long with Ballinger now on 115 for 8 off 16 overs. Will Reid up next and finds it hard getting bat on ball. Fortunately at the other end Toby is playing beautifully and the pair take the score to 148 without any further mishaps## Toby finishing on 24 not out and giving Ballinger a total to defend on a good batting track and fast outfield.

Cublington took to the middle with Ballinger knowing they had to make a good start and so they did with Will Reid## Hamish## Dom and Will Arnold all making it difficult for the opposition. Pressure mounted and wickets fell and Cublington finding themselves 55 for 5 off 12 covers. Ben## Monty and Josh joined the party with the final score ending on 99 for 5 off their 20 overs. It was an excellent display by the four front line bowlers backed up by some great fielding and a team in positive mood with lots of encouragement throughout making it even more difficult for Cublington.

Hopefully they can take all that was good in this game to the cup meeting with Gerrards Cross next Tuesday.

The weather finally on our side as this was our 4th attempt to play the fixture against a very good side. First to arrive at the ground was Andrew Strauss who was great signing the boys bats and doing selfies and pictures with all the boys. This set the warm tone for what turned out to be a very competetive but friendly game.

Whilst Marlow warmed up with the ex England Captain our boys started arriving from school trips and matches in Northwood##speedily delivered by Nick HAyes and Nick Tatum. 

We batted first and Oliver and Tim put us on 229## Archie and Seb up to 257 after 8 overs## Raphi and Max FE pushed us up to 294 from 12 overs## we still hadnt lost a wicket and Marlow were at a complete loss what to do. Finn and Kuran faced some very accurtate bowling and we held on 292## then in came Max C and Thoimas B who drove the total up to 334## our highest ever score.

I thought that 260 would win this match## but the boys had other ideas.

Our bowling was suoerb## everyone bowled a good line and lenght and Oliver managed his bowlers like a veteran captain. Oliver threw a ball in from at least 40 yards for a direct strike running out Sam Strauss and so Marlows woes began## Kurans first ball bowled Sam Strauss ## then Finn took a wicket and Max stumped another. 12 overs gone and they are on 237## more tight bowling and by over 17 they were on 257## 4 overs to go and then Sebastin takes an amazing catch followed by 2 more catches taken by Finn## Raphi and Oliver finished proceedings with them still on 257.

Oliver 23   Archie 10   Seb  13   Raphi  14  Max FE 16

Max C 20

Wickets

Finn 3   Raphi 2 Kuran 1  Oliver 1

Samuel won the toss on debut as Captain and put GK into bat. Philip and David opened with some good tight overs## but did not look like displacing their solid openers. As we entered the 5-10 overs their opener began to take it away from Ballinger## and though William and Samuel were able to take some wickets## the GK batsmen had accelerated the score considerably. The innings total of 135 did not feel like a correct total for the bowling that we had sent down. Ballinger felt that they could try to chase down the total if they kept their wickets. 

The early loss of Philip to some very fast bowling from their captain and the subsequent restraint that put on our batsmen stopped our momentum. Their wk took a couple of knocks to the helmet## so Philip went on as sub fielder. Over the next few overs Philip then took two good catches at midwicket## but in doing so## cut short Theo and Will in their prime. Samuel continued bravely and retired at 30. From there## the less experience batsmen simply had too much to do. We reached 86 for 9## but were left feeling that it could and should have been closer. 

A game of cricket played in the very best spirit## well done boys.

Sharks

The team looked very flat this Monday rvening## which affected the fielding and bowling and also a pretty lacklustre run chase. The boys have got to learn to support each other.......it is a team game. The HW batsman raced off to a flying start and both retired at 30. Ballinger did well to claw back the rest of the batsman and claim seven wickets## in the end## the 45+ of extras we conceded meant that an evening run chase of 124 was just too much.

Another very solid batting performance from Samuel underpinned the innings## but a combination of a low sun in the eyes and some poor shot selection meant we did not reach the heights. 

Let's bring back some enthusiasm and energy into our last two games of the season.

Sharks

I cannot say more than pointing out there were 82 dot balls in our innings. Their out fied cricket was good## but not that good. Calling## running## pressurising the fielder .......this is all part of cricket
Wicket with his first ball but after slipping up in his second over## Fin brought the game to an early end.
We lost!!!!!
A tense but exciting win

We could have filled a pond with the amount of ducks we had today## but our annual Beaconsfield 12 a side friendly and they arrived straight from training with 11 motivated boys## our Finn won the toss and chose to bat first. We were fielding a team of five of our great U9 players and the other 7 from our U10 squad. Playing normal rules with boys retiring on 30 ## well Beaconsfield had clearly been working on their bowling and our wickets started to fall at too rapid a rate## we limped into the 20th over with Max Conway on 39 and Daniel Battman supporting him with some confident batting both walked off not out. Our second highest scorer behind Max was Extras followed by Thomas on 5. 

79## we have not much of a chance the crowd thought## anyway we loaded our players with juice and some very yummy cup cakes and we took to the field## controlled and guided by a very precise captain Finn Henry## he had a plan and he was going to put it into action## which he did. 

Tight and accurate bowling from Thomas## Finn and Kuran kept the run rate right down and then as he planned he gace all of the boys a bown## the first breakthrough came to Edward Best with his spin## then the flood gates started with most of the boys taking wickets and giving almost nothing away. Max FE was almost unplayable for their batsmen## Louis Barton caused all sorts of problems for them and Leo##Noah##Daniel and Tobywere never phased by their openers.

Beaconsfield just couldnt get runs passed out superb fielders performing textbook stops## noticeably Noah Henry## James Best. Great catches from Daniel and possibly catch of the season when second ball from Finn to a fierce looking batsman was edged## it clipped Max behind the stumps and Thoimas Berens at first slip dived to take it.

Beaconsfield never looked like ever reaching their target and Finn's field placement was genius and never allowed them to ever get started.

A big thanks you as well to all the parents## but especially Freddie Hancock who kindly played for Beaconsfield## he was an outstanding sportsman all day.  

Note to self - defensive stroke training for boys

Steve

A late change of venue kindly provided by Beaconsfield CC and a warm summers evening## so everything in place for our last league fixture.

Oliver won the toss and chose to field## and Knotty Green to to the beautifully prepared pitch. Our opening bowlers allowed them to get to 220 after the first four overs and KG appeared fairly optimistic## could they be the giant killers## sadly for them matters started to get worse as Ballinger moved up a gear## wicket maiden from Thomas## wicket maiden from Archie## then an amazing high backward diving catch from Archie at Long Off from Thomas's second maiden over## Sebastian's gps accurate bowling led to a superb direct hit run out from Archie ## it was over 10 and they were down to 202## Finn came on and his first maiden over 3 wickets  fall## a great catch from Tim a run out by Max and then middle stump is bowled## down to 189## they managed to recover a little after over 13 and we took no further wickets## they finished on 221 following more tight bowling from Tim## Seb##Matthew##Leo and Oliver. Thomas handled the last over which was his final maiden.

Ballinger came in to bat after taking on fluids## Archie and Thomas finished their four overs on 227## so we had already beaten the target## Knotty then put on their best stint putting Matthew and Leo under some pressure## sadly this was the session where we lost our only wickets of the match## but the boys did well and Matthew punished the last bowler with a great four off his legs## leaving us on 218. Knotty felt there was hope## sadly they didn't realise what was awaiting them## Finn and Kuran came in both boys finding the boundary with ease Finn adding 18 [from 13] and Kuran 20 [from 11] taking us up to 256## Knotty then hoped that was the end of our batsmen[one of the boys asked me if they could all bat##i smiled and said “Oh Yes”## he replied with “Oh Dear”]## in came a highly charged Sebastian and Max## Seb put on 22 [from 14] and Max 11 [from 10] leaving us on 289## then came in the really big guns## some very slow wide bowling prevented sixes galore## but Oliver scored 24 [from 13] and Tim scored 19 [from 12] leaving us on 332## 111 ahead of Knotty Green.

What strikes me about our team is not the fact that they keep winning ## but that they just all play so well as a side ## knowing each others strengths and weaknesses## with the pairs knowing how their partner bats to the captain Oliver bowling his players at the right time to get the best results. 

Unbeaten in the league and on to the finals day on the 20th July.

What appears a convincing win for Gerrards Cross could have been a different story if not for a dropped catch at a crucial point in the game.

Although not at full strength Gerrards Cross was always going to be a tough encounter. Winning the toss and chosing to bat GX found themselves 44 for 3 off 8 overs with three of their top four batsmen back in the pavilion. Ben Lane batting at three still there and looking to push the innings on. In the tenth over with the score on 56## with Lane on 19## he skies the ball## two fielders close in## one calls## but the ball slips agonisingly through his fingers. I highlight this incident because Ben Lane then goes on to score 109 not out off 51 balls## including 11 fours and 7 sixes## plundering the Ballinger bowling. GX finishing on 191 for 4 off their 20 overs.

A bruised Ballinger take to the middle needing nearly 10 runs an over. A good start essential to make any challenge but sadly not to be with Ballingers top three back in the pavilion with the score on 9 off 3 overs. Ben Dugdale and Dom Brown manage to put on a 73 run partnership and take the score to 82 in the 15th over before Ben is caught. With a slightly more respecatable score on the board Ballinger then try and push the score along## further wickets fall and Ballinger finish on 120 for 8.

An enjoyable game## played in good spirit on a sunny evening. GX through to the next round## Ballinger live to fight another day. What might have been we'll never know but as the saying goes ' catches win matches'.

WAGONETTE B’s vs STOKE COMMON : 2ND July 2014

 

 

Our last league game and by some margin our best performance.  On the bowling front## all girls bowled a much better line and length.    The opening spells of Nicky and Charlotte Rynn (who bowled off a short run up because of an injury) were unlucky not to take scalps.  If the field placing (me) had been a bit more aggressive## Nicky would have had a wicket on her second ball.  Isabel took the first wicket and her accuracy pegged back the batters## reducing the run rate.  Ellie was again consistent.  Charlotte C's accurate loopy balls proved a challenge for the batters.   Laura struggled a little with her line in the first over but the balls that were on the stumps were difficult to play and she should be pleased that she kept the run rate down to just 8 off her 2 overs - well below the average at the time.  Livvy bowled tightly and deserved her wicket - beautifully flighted and with some bounce.  Annie's bowling has improved immensely this season and this was definitely her best spell - it was both accurate and good length and good batsmen struggled.  Lucy and Millie finished off the innings well - both again not giving away many wides and Millie taking our third wicket - plumb LBW.  Thankfully she (and Poppy) remembered to appeal!  

In the field## the girls generally stopped everything that came their way.  Laura has become a specialist mid-off and the batsmen learned not to take runs from her - she will be nursing a few bruises today as she put her body on the line time and again.  Lucy seemed to get a lot of the action and dealt with it well.  In general the girls were committed when the ball was coming to them but I would like to see them up this to a more aggressive and dynamic display to stop the balls wide of them.  Poppy once again kept the byes down - just 3 compared to the oppositions 8.

Containing a fine batting team to just 99 runs was a result but the best was yet to come. 

The girls have found batting tough this season - struggling to get bat on ball## moving their feet.  In this innings## they looked like a different team.  Every single girl connected with the ball this time and not only that## they were moving their feet and playing with a straight bat.  Livy and Nicky started well but both out Caught and Bowled for 2 each.  The middle order collapse - Charlotte C## Ellie## Laura and Poppy - does not tell the story that all four of them had a decent amount of time at the crease during which they ran byes and they were all playing good looking strokes which kept finding fielders.  On a different day## they would have all got runs.  Charlotte R (with Nicky as a runner) had her best innings of the season and scored the first ever 4 for the team - looked like she was going to score a lot of runs but was then bowled by a ball which pitched a foot outside off stump - Charlotte Edwards (current England Captain) would have struggled with that one.  Just as it looked like## Ballinger might run out of steam## in comes Isabel and gave a master class in stroke play## including hitting probably the best shot of the day (from both sides)## a perfectly executed front foot cover drive for four.  Millie did a sterling job at the other end## scoring singles and giving Isabel the opportunity to get our top score of the season - 13.   Lucy scored her first ever run in a league game and Annie was unlucky to get a tall bowler with a lot of bounce - but she still connected!  I am not sure what has happened since the last game but I can only assume that the Mums and Dads have been out in the garden helping them with technique - it was a huge improvement.  They should all feel very proud.  54 equals our best score of the season but this time over 5 times more runs came off the bat! 

Once again## we were lucky to have a very sporting opposition.  Both the Stoke Green boys and coaches were fantastic and supportive - I think everyone enjoyed themselves.

On a beautiful Friday evening Ballinger Girls opened the batting with Tilly and Georgina. Tilly was soon retired on 32 and Georgina went on and scored 18. This brought Hannah and Hattie to the wicket and Hannah was also soon retired on 31 and Hattie also made 18 which left Jane and Charlotte to face the last few balla. A commanding total of 135 for 2.

At the beginning of their innings the scoreboard kept pace with the run rate. Georgina was bowling good line and length as was Hannah. First change had Charlotte who wasn't bowling at her best but got a wicket. Hattie took over from Georgina and then the wickets started to tumble. Chalfont St Peter had no answer to Hatties nagggingly accurate left arm bowling. Jane took a good catch for Hatties first wicket## bowled the next ball## so on to a hat trick. It didn't happen but the 3rd wicket came on the 4th ball. Hattie continued## took another wicket and was bowled through her 4 overs to see if she could get a 5th. She could and a 6th next ball. Hat trick ball again. But again not converted. Hattie was carried off by her team mates when Chalfont St Peter were bowled out for 79 with Hattie having figures of 6 for 6 off 4 overs. 

A great batting disply topped off by Hatties bowling.
Knotty Green were allowed in to the league at last minute and we didnt have time to sort out a team so game was agreed to be called 'Rained Off'

Another rainy Saturday morning after a sunny week## and a sense of deja-vu. The difference this week was that the rain had been much lighter## so after a heavy shower had delayed the start of proceedings##the game got under way with little time lost## and Ballinger opting to bowl first on a wicket that would prove to be a tricky one## due to the ends having been covered## but not so the middle. Holmer Green's openers immediately started to chance their arms against Nick Adams and Will Reid## the latter particularly having cause to think the Fate was against him## as the ball flew regularly to the boundary## edged over or between the slip cordon. The total had sped to 56 in the 11th over when keeper Max Dugdale grasped the first of two excellent catches## the second following at 79 in the 17th over. By this time Carlton Siddle had come on## and immediately applied a stranglehold which## try as they could## the HG batsmen simply couldn't break. Max## standing up to the bowling##also shackled the batsmen## and Ian Maciver## replacing Nick## was immediately into his stride and keeping the batsmen guessing. From the 20th over the next 16 overs yielded only 32 runs## while 2 wickets fell## so that with only 4 overs left the total was a mere 121 for 5## and Ballinger's tails were up. Unfortunately Kevin King## long-time destroyer of Ballinger hopes## now entered the fray## and the last 4 overs went for 49 costly runs## so that HG finished on a respectable 170 for 6.

Sadly## Ballinger's reply never got past first base## with none of the first four batsmen able to cope with a ball lifting sharply off the pitch## and whereas the HG batsmen edged to the boundary## Ballinger's edged straight to the keeper## who pouched 5 catches in the innings. Coming together at 25 for 4## Carlton and Jamie Kellock steadied the ship for a while## managing to put on 23 for the 5th wicket## but Carlton was then bowled by Weeracoon's second delivery## and Jamie who had been judiciously mixing vigilant defence with some flashing off-drives## then decided on a spot of hara-kiri## and ran himself needlessly out. That his 17 was the top score (save for Extras 20 !) says it all of the remaining batting## which subsided to a dispiriting all out 85.

To lose## having scored only 50% of the required target## must be counted as a pretty miserable defeat## but Lady Luck was certainly not favouring Ballinger## with the number of near chances## and a couple of very hard dropped catches. Overall the fielding was excellent ## and Max's keeping superlative## conceding no byes on a difficult wicket. Carlton's bowling performance of 10 overs## 1 wicket for 5 runs was surely deserving of a far better fate than the batsmen were able to deliver!

So it’s another calm## quiet day in the life of the Waggoners 2nd X1. 

The Skipper is relaxing in the wilds of a northern country and has left his replacement an 'X1' plus a 12th man.  So far so good but by 9.15am on Saturday this 12 is reduced to 10 as illness infects 2 members of the squad.


Now the replacement is aware that taking an U16 team plus him and Steve Carter to top of the table Knotty Green isn't an ideal way to spend a Saturday afternoon but surely the weather will intervene.

Sadly the rain stayed away## the Green had covered their wicket and they were keen. The replacement lost the toss and Ballinger were condemned to batting first on what was going to be an interesting wicket.


Matt O'kelly and Freddie Thompson were first up for the Waggoners. Matt lasted 3 balls## Steve Carter a few more## Charlie Barraclough## on debut## three more## Harry Livingstone## also in his first adult game## managed two balls. A total of one from the four of them. Reece was in and he and Freddie finally gave some substance to Ballinger’s innings by putting on nearly 40 before Freddie was out caught## for the 2nd time according to the home side## for a well played 33.


12th man Henry King now made his debut and he nervelessly helped Reece add another 25 before Reece departed for 23. Henry then had to watch as Nigel and James departed without worrying the scorer and with last man Harry at the wicket he tried for one more big hit. It always helps to watch the ball you're trying to hit out of  the ground but Hey Ho he'd scored 20% of Ballinger’s 94 so who was complaining.

 

30 minutes to tea so out we go. Reece to open up with Harry L in support. Reece's first over is a bit off but nothing to worry about. Harry's first is on the money but Knotty's opener has decided to finish the game before tea. Harry has other ideas and removes his middle stump. Then Reece starts his second over and by the end of it the opposition is 35-1. The ball is lost## it rains and finally before the 4th over is started tea is taken.


Over tea the replacement discusses possible changes with senior members of the team and it’s agreed that Freddie will come on in place of Harry and Harry will switch ends. Suddenly its a different game. Knotty have no idea how to play Freddie and Harry is still on the mark. He bowls the home teams No3## T.Patel## and then has No 4## L.Patel caught by 'keeper## Steve Carter. Freddie now has another Patel out LBW and the hosts are 40 - 4. James Fray is now on to replace Harry and bowls quickly and accurately keeping the runs down and the pressure on. Finally Khan takes a huge swipe## up goes the ball and when it comes down Nigel is ready for the catch. His shout of 'Mine' may have been a bit unnecessary as his nearest team mates seemed to have moved further away as the ball decended.


52-5 but the opener still there. He has no idea how to play Freddie and neither has their next batter who is soon on his way back to the pavilion. Six down and they aren't scoring any runs but the Waggoners are running out of bowling options. Their skipper and the opener## two wily old pros## are beginning to take the game away. Drinks are taken with the score on 78 - 6.

Another discussion between the think tank. More spin with Henry King or seam with Matt O'Kelly. The tank decides on Henry so he's on with Harry back. Henry's 1st over not good but could have got a wicket. Every run now important and Freddie letting one straight through his legs got a 'double teapot' from the whole team.

Harry still in full flow from the other end gives 'keeper Carter the opportunity he's be waiting for all match. A full length diving catch to finally remove the opener.

87-7

Charlie has been grazing in the outfield all afternoon but suddenly finds himself in the spotlight when Sandeep Patel choses to launch Henry towards the long on boundary. Charlie decides that if he lies down it will make it much easier to take the catch. Who are we to argue when he came up with ball in hand and a new technique added to the ECB coaching manual.

89-8

A confident push from the Greens No10 concerns the skipper and so does a sneaky couple of runs past 'Gloves' Carter as the home side take the score to 93.


Its Harry's last over. 

 

Play and a miss

 

Play and a miss

 

Play and a miss

 

Bowled 93 -9

 

Bowled 93-10

 

It would be admirable if the replacement could claim that the Waggoners behaved in an appropriate manner for the next few minutes but.....

Strange game but really impressed with the way the boys stuck together. Very happy with efforts of U13s Henry and Charlie## excited by the arrival of Harry## 6-23 on debut cant be bad. James bowled and fielded brilliantly and Freddie is begining to show real maturity in his play both with bat and ball. All the bowlers were backed up by some brilliant fielding. Well done to 'Gloves Carter who probably cant walk today.

It was a great team effort.

A lovely tea and well done to KG for getting covers on and off to make sure the game could be played.

Ballinger’s team of teenagers## leavened with a trio of men in their 40s comprehensively outplayed Hyde Heath’s team of men in their 20s and 30s.  It was a pleasure to captain a team of skilled and athletic young cricketers who know how to play the game well and enjoy themselves at the same time.

Ballinger won the toss and decided to bat## despite there still being plenty of dampness in a pitch which had been very wet and difficult to bat on the day before.  However## after some early misbehaviour## the pitch settled down. Ballinger’s total of 204 for 6 from 41 overs was built largely around 3 very skilful but very different innings.  James McIntyre## coming in at number 3## built the foundations of the Ballinger total with a careful but stylish 51 off 90 balls## assisted in particular by Ben Dugdale at number 5.  Ben was fourth man out at Nelson (111) after 25.3 overs.  Toby Lyons initially supported James well and then accelerated towards the end of the innings to score a focussed 40 not out off 45 balls.  After James was fifth man out at 153 after 34 overs## Monty Thompson joined Toby and scored a bludgeoning 31 off 26 balls to contribute to a nicely-timed acceleration in the last 10 overs of the Ballinger innings to produce a challenging but eminently gettable total.

 

Hyde Heath gave the impression of being just a little bit too confident in their ability to overhaul it. Ballinger opened with a pace and spin combination in the form of Hamish Sim and Stuart McGowan; and Hamish struck in the third over as opener Haddock unwisely left a ball that pitched on off stump and hit off stump.  Hyde Heath showed intent from the start but lost another wicket to Hamish on 25## as a catch was spooned to James McIntyre at a deliberately straight extra cover.   There then followed a threatening partnership of 48 for the third wicket## which was ended by an excellent piece of fielding on the boundary from Hamish## sending in a fast flat throw to Stuart at the bowler’s end  – typical of Ballinger’s excellent fielding throughout the afternoon.  There then followed a clatter of wickets at 74## 82## 91## 97 and 106## as Hyde Heath continued to pursue the total but without the ability to cope with the accurate offspin of Stuart McGowan from one end and the equally accurate legspin from Freddie Thompson at the other.  Stuart ended with 3 for 44  and Freddie 3 for 26.  Both were assisted by excellent close catching - including a sharp catch by keeper Max Dugdale and 2 superb one handed diving catches at slip by one of Ballinger’s athletic old pros## Rob McIntyre.   After the ninth wicket fell at 121 in the 28th over## Hyde Heath gave up the chase and Ballinger were left with 13 overs to take the last wicket.  Nearly everything had gone right in the first 28 overs## but there Ballinger’s luck turned …..  Number 9 Rauf batted with some skill to end up not out 38## while number 11## and Hyde Heath skipper## Samuels essentially played French cricket to great effect for 13 overs## to deny Ballinger the win that they deserved.  Seven bowlers were used in the last 13 overs in an attempt to dislodge them. With hindsight the skipper should have persisted with the spin of Freddie and Stuart for longer## as the quicker bowlers went past the bat frequently but failed actually to hit the stumps and the less penetrating seamers bowled admirably straight but could not do enough to get through the Hyde Heath defences.  It was a shame not to win## but that was not allowed to mar an excellent performance in all departments by a very young team.

Ballinger won the toss and chose to bat in this top of the table clash.

Max and Monty got off to a decent start putting on 27 runs in the 4th over before Monty## tempted outside his off stump## nicked one to the keeper. Toby in next and 19 runs added before Toby's bails are removed. Ben next up to join his brother with plenty of banter from the opposition## Ben on his way back to the pavilion 2 balls later after trying to launch one back over the bowler to be caught on the boundary## Ballinger 46 for 3 off 9 overs. Matt to the middle to join Max and the pair looking to push the rate along. Max## now timing the ball well## middles one back down the ground to be brilliantly caught by Fraser Percival diving high and wide and holding on to the ball in what looked a certain six## Ballinger 65 for 4 off 12. Dom Brown now moved up the order to try and gain some momentum. He and Matt adding another 40 runs in 6 overs before Matt has his stumps re-arranged. Kenny to the middle with 2 overs remaining and his brief to get Dom on strike. Another 25 runs added before Kenny is run out with 1 ball remaining. Ballinger finishing on 130 for 6 off their 20 overs## with Dom 44 not out off 29 balls.

A decent total to defend but important Ballinger get off to a good start and what a start it was. Will Reid's first ball unplayable and clatters the stumps of a bemused Henry Quinn. The next four deliveries not bad either## followed by another rocket that has Eddie Mason LBW## The Lee 0 for 2 off 1 over. Freddie DS bowling from the other end giving nothing away to a shell shocked opposition. Will on for his second over and removes Tom Houghton## bowled off his pads## The Lee 4 for 3 off 3 overs. Jamie Line in next## questioning the legality of Will's action## only to be caught by Will off Freddie DS## not a happy bunny as he returns to the pavilion## the Lee 8 for 4 off 4. Freddie T now to bowl and excellent spell to add to The Lee's troubles. Will Young and Tom Line put up some resistance but wickets fall at regular intervals. The clouds darken and rain begins to fall but not in time as The Lee finish on 68 all out## with Josh Richardson taking the final wicket in the 19th over.

Another great perfomance by the team and a game played in good spirirt.

Ballinger slipped a little further down the greasy pole of relegation on Saturday when they lost badly to fellow strugglers Monks Risborough. Influenced perhaps by the relative batting strength of his side compared with his bowling line up## acting skipper Andy Thompson chose to take first knock## on a hot sunny afternoon## a decision regretted by the third over## by which time BWCC had lost both openers Matt Riley (unluckily deflecting a wide ball onto his stumps) and Richard O'Kelly (castled by near unplayable delivery)## both victims of the accurate J Iqbal.  Rollo McIntyre and Andy Thompson set about repairing the damage## with Rollo looking again in fine form. But with the total on 37## both fell in the 11th over## with Monty Thomson perishing soon after## LBW without opening his account## and the scoreboard reading 45 for 5. Enter Max Dugdale and Dom Brown## two youngsters without any batting form in the 1sts to date## and who evidently had the same idea## namely to justify selection - which they did in an emphatic way.  The pair had put on 46 for the 6th wicket before Dom fell## LBW for an excellent 22## and Max's classy knock came to an end after batting exactly an hour for an invaluable 28.Fortunate indeed that he eventually managed to locate the ground## after an abortive visit to the middle of Aylesbury!  That made it 104 for 7## and the remaining wickets went down within 6 more overs## to leave Ballinger with a highly vulnerable score of 127. Had the Monks' fielding and catching been better## it might well have been less!

Monks started their innings just as badly as Ballinger. with Nick Adams grabbing a couple of quick scalps## and Will Reid joining in with one## so that with the score standing at 16 for 3 prospects for a favourable outcome were good. First change bowler Andy Thompson struck in his first over## but by that time the total was already 55## and thereafter the bowlers could find no way of stopping H Amjad (50) and B Khan (38) who cruised undefeated to their target in only the 26th over. Had Ballinger had their two missing regular bowlers available## the result might well have been closer## but there is no denying that Monks Risborough played the better cricket.

Home to Aylesbury who had beaten us by one run at the start of the season returned to meet a much younger side## with David and Steve pushing the average age only just into the high teens. Many of the boys have been with the club since they were single digits and as we were to see had been through the BWCC system being coached by Nigel## Bill## Roger and the team.

Ben in charge whilst Paul was away in Scotland calculating the odds on 13.10 donkey derby at Gallowshields. Ben decided we would bat first and with a target in his mind of 200 we set off on the challenged.

Sadly the third most senior player Basty was caught from his second edge to the keeper## then David steadied the ship with Matt O## David playing like an old pro and Matt looking as though he was going to get a quick fifty## but Aylesbury were good in the field and their opening bowlers had other plans for us with Matt and David both being caught on 23 and 28## Ben and Toby then came in and really pushed the run rate on from 3 to 5 ## the skipper bowled for 36 and Toby caught on 42## Steve did some backing up and then walked off again victim to an LBW## James followed shortly afterwards on 4 but Freddie and Will continued to pile on the runs Freddie not out on 25 and Will on 11. A defendable score of 189

With guidance from the Umpire who really needed to get away by 18.30 to watch a re run celebrity masterplumber we took to the field with a strong bowling line up## so Ben put on the gloves to control matters from behind the stumps.

I had the pleasure of being at first slip to watch our bowlers excel in their art with Will and Finn opening and the wickets just kept coming with the first scalp in the 3rd over to Will## then number two to Finn in the 4th and then two more to Finn in the 10th over## they were on 36 for 4. Ben then brought on Harry Livingstone who bowled as well as the openers also swinging the ball and giving almost no runs away and with Freddie at the other end bowling some unplayable leg spin Aylesburys troubles just continued with Harry and Freddie taking wickets in overs 14##15 and two in 16## so Aylesbury are now on 66 for 8 from 16 overs## The 20th over saw basty take out one of their former openers and then the last wicket was picked off by Freddie and the were all out for 71 from 22 overs.

As one of the older two in the side i was so proud of the way the side batted bowled and fielded giving almost nothing away to a decent Aylesbury side ## a great win for Ben and the team. A big thank you as well to Miles for being a great umpire and to Fiona for putting on a fine spread.

Steve

Our penultimate U10B fixture and a struggle to put a side out due to cub camps## holidays and various school discos [if they are still called that].

I was using up my U10A player allowance so we had a good cross section of players including Toby from U9 and Max Hayes from the U8 squad.

With Thomas Berens in charge we took to the field to bowl## the manager Glynnis was scoring and directing from the club house with no tannoy required and a trainee umpire joined me to facilitate proceedings##from the fist over i was beginning to worry as the Winchmore boys and girls froze in front of the stumps ## most of them asking for middle and then placing their feet firmly on the mark## but that didnt really help much as the wickets kept coming for Oliver ## Max Hayes## two in a maiden for Matthew [great catch by Tom]## three in another maiden for Oliver ## one for Tom then Toby and another for Max Hayes## maiden overs all over the place## our only minor error was a dropped high catch by Toby at extra cover which he collected and threw to the keepers end and ran their player out## what great skill. Thomas bowled Max Hayes for 3 overs which was a great reflection on how well he had bowled  his previous two overs. They finished their innings on 177. They had only scored 10 runs from the bat.

Glynnis told me that her side were still learning and that we were too good ## i wasn't quite sure how to respond and in hindsight we should have fielded an U9 side if they had been available. 

In to bat we went## I told the other umpire that i would be very lenient on the calling of wides and no balls. The boundary was huge so i hoped that would keep our score back

Our first pair took us to 225## psir two including Max Hayes who middled a shortish ball for 4 [this was an adult boundary]## Toby had his best innings this year playing with utter confidence and a straight bat## we were on 252 then Sebastian and Kuran pushed us to 272 and the last pair on to 296.

A very comfortable win for the team## against a really nice team of boys and girls who played with great spirit.

having won the toss and deciding to field Knotty Green were 12 off 2 and it looked like it was going to be a long evening. Both Charlotte and Hattie then bowled some excellent overs backed up by ever improving fielding. At first change Nicky came on got the only wicket. Gracie was turning the ball but is till looking for consistency. Tilly and Flora completed the bowling with Knotty Green getting to 97 for 2 in their 20 overs. A challenging but not insurmountable total. 

Tilly looked in good form and struck 6 4s before she had to retire. Hattie unfortunatly stood on her wicket! with contributions from Osobel (6)## Charlotte (6)## Flora (2); Gracie and Charlotte knowling we needed 16 off 4 overs (inspite of what the scoreboard said). This became 10 off 2## then 6 off 1. Charlottte hit the 2nd ball for 4 with screams of delight from the spectators (paticularly her mum). 2 needed and 2 singles taken off 3 balls. The total achieved with 1 ball to spare. An excellent game of cricket played in good spirit## Well done to everyone who played## You all contributed brilliantly.

Ballinger won by 7 wickets.  Ballinger won the toss and put Aylesbury into bat## and immediately the Ballinger openers## Will Reid (4 overs## 1 for 10) and Will Arnold## were too good for them.  Likewise Freddie Thompson's legspin (3 overs 1 for 5).  Captain Ben Dugdale then used a range of bowlers to get everyone into the gane## fearing a low Aylesbury score## with mixed results. Aylesbury closed on 104 for 3 off their 20 overs.  That total never presented too much of a challenge## with Ballinger up with or close to the rate for the first 8 overs## and then accelerating slightly to finish it off in 16 overs.  Max Dugdale and Dom Brown started well until Dom lashed at one and spooned to mid on.  Matt O'Kelly was bowled by a good one just as he was getting going. But then Max was joined by Ben## who with 33* saw his team home## even after Max's departure for 33## ably assisted then by Toby Lyons## who played some aggressive but classical cricket shots for his 21*.  A well-paced chase and an easy win.

Ballinger's first ever visit to Bourne End for a league match was viewed with some trepidation## given the two clubs' relative positions in the league table## but with a strong team available we at least should surely do better than the hammering we received from them earlier in the season.  The pitch had been covered to protect it from the recent downpours## so when the home side opted to bat first## it might be assumed that the pitch would be a good one. In fact## a completely wrong assumption## as from the very first delivery Will Reid and Nick Adams had the ball flying viciously at and over the batsmen's heads. Presumably Bourne End were used to dealing with this## as they tended either to hit and miss## or flay the ball to the boundary. Three wickets were down for 49 by the 14th over## with  Nick keeping the lid on things with a good 10 over spell## taking 3 for 20. First change Evan Webster came in for some harsh punishment## but then Ian Maciver came on to bowl and he and Andy Thompson grabbed 3 quick wickets## so that Bourne End were 83 for 6 in the 25th over## and a manageable target looked in prospect. Unfortunately## it appeared that Bourne End tail## following the trend in the current Test series## batted rather better than their predecessors. Another wicket fell on 116 (31 overs)## but the total then raced to 159 before the final wicket was secured in the 39th over.

With their two first choice openers available## Ballinger needed a good opening partnership to set them on their way. Just like England. And just like for England## it didn't happen. Richard O'Kelly went first## victim of a fine diving slip catch. Rollo fenced  at yet another sharply rising ball## and went for 0. 23 for 2  soon became 44 for 5## as Matt (for a patient 12 in 50 balls)## Monty Thompson and Will Smith departed. The rot looked terminal## but Max Dugdale had obviously taken note of Bourne End's batting technique on such a wicket## and produced a superlative display of stroke-making## while Andy Thomson dug in at the other end. Their stand was worth 36 when Andy fell. caught and bowled. Max then hoisted a huge hit into the deep and was unlucky to select a fielder who could actually catch## out for a stimulating 43. The Ballinger tail then bucked the current trend## and subsided limply## but not before gathering a second batting point## which might come in handy## looking at their league position.

Ballinger were indebted to Jamie Kellock for standing in as umpire. Having had a long## close up view of the wicket (doubless for longer than had he had to bat on it)## he must feel gratified that his square at Ballinger is so very different!

Congratulations to everyone for making the trip to Newport## I thought you all deserved a drink when you got there and a drink and biscuit would have gone down well between innings or indeed at the end of the match. It seems I was the lucky one## eventually being bought a cup of tea once everyone had gone!!
Having won the toss and deciding to bat the score cruised to 22 off 2 overs## an excellent score well in excess of our 158 against Chesham seemed on the cards. This however didn't happen as the Newport bowlers tightened up their lines and brought back the run rate. Tilly and Hannah continued to put away the bad ball and were on 36 when Hannah was bowled for 13 in the 5th over. Hattie came to the crease and played very sensibly looking to keep her wicket. The bowling got better and we were not able to rotate the strike. 51 for 1 off 10. With wickets in hand## shots needed to be played and Hattie was bowled for 10 and Tilly ran out for an excellent 35. Elise and Rachel then scampered some much needed runs at the end to take our score to a creditable 87 for 3
The 2 Newport openers## both U15 England Women Development Players## knocked off the runs in 15 overs. The opening 5 overs of bowling was excellent by Hannah and Elise and this was backed up by an beautifully set field which made the batters really work hard for their runs. The first change bowlers of Hattie and Charlotte both preformed very well going for just 3 an over and brought back a bit of control. The fielding throughout was exemplary; Charlotte sweeping the boundary## Elise and Hattie patrolling the offside## Gracie and Flora stopping everything on the legside and Rachel covering behind. Newport were not to be denied and took 15 overs to reach their target
I was really proud of how you all performed## looking like a fantastic team in the field with great support for each other. We didn't win but you can smile knowing that you are between the 5th and 8th best girls team in Britain; or may be even higher if Newport go on to win. Well done and thank you## particularly the drivers. How we managed to arrive in convoy I don't quite know.

After a lot of shilly shallying which resulted in the loss of 4 overs per side the game finally got underway around 2pm but the skipper lost what might have proved to be a decisive toss and we were inserted on a still drying wicket. Our regular opening pair  of Stuart and Matt got the innings off to a very solid start notching 64 at 4 an over before Stuart departed for 46## once again dodging the traditional jug buying ceremony. Despite losing three quick wickets (or not quick enough in the case of Basty's run out !) Ben and Dom took up the cudgels and battered the Bourne End attack## recording their 18th (or was that pub talk ?) 50 run partnership together this season. When they both perished in the cause of quick runs## Freddie T ##Will and Fin scampered some very useful runs including several byes to their increasinglly frustrated wicket keeper. A score of 171 looked likely to be enough so we all enjoyed an excellent tea provided by Fiona.

A good start was needed and Fin and Will duly provided one reducing the opposition to 17 for 3 after 10 overs. Job done surely ? However in the long established tradition of Bourne End they were going to go down swinging and everyone gets lucky once in a while. 63 runs were added in the next 5 overs despite the loss of 2 more wickets and by drinks they were exactly half way to their target with half the innings gone. With the two Freddies operating in tandem and Dom now behind the stumps## to the disappointment of messrs Rashid and Haseeb## a measure of control was restored although several crucial catches were dropped. This enabled them to keep the required rate just below a run a ball and with most overs containing a 'four ball' the total nudged up. A good catch from Stuart in the penultimate over left the final pair needing 6 from the final over. A loose first delivery and yet another dropped chance ensured we snatched defeat from the jaws of victory !

A good game played in a great spirit and one we never really looked like losing until it finished. We batted and bowled (for the most part) very well but in the end our fielding didn't match up. Thx to Pads Conway for scoring and Miles for umpiring as ever.

Finals night

Ballinger batted first in the Semi against Wendover and had to defend a very small target of 45. Thanks to some exccellent bowling we triumphed by a couple of runs. In the final we faced Cheshams Asian stars masquerading as Hyde Heath## watched by a largely partisan HH crowd - ballinger where were you all ?. Despite a wicket maiden for our first over we set a target of 44 off 5 overs and again bowled tightly much to the diasappointment of the HH team (who were in the crowd !). The proxy HH team squeaked home in a tight finish - no trophy just the moral high ground !

Mondays report

Group games

Having restricted Coleshill to 54 off their 5 overs things looked bleak as our batsmen picked out fielders in the cavernous Shardloes outfield. As our injured skipper limped ## nay hobbled## to the crease 6 runs were required off the last 2 balls. Son Matt## gave Dad the strike as his runner made it safely to the other end. A four would not be enough as Ballinger had lost 4 wickets in the run chase. Richard heaved the disconsolate Coleshill bowler over deepish mid wicket for 6 and set up a knock out match with Prestwood## who also squeaked home against Coleshill in the second match.

The Prestwood match went much more to plan - chasing down 54## despite losing Max first ball. Ben and Rollo mixed aggresion with some sensible batting and cruised home with more than an over to spare.

Wendover on a cloudy Sunday morning## Wendover winning the toss and putting Ballinger in to bat on a moist wicket. Seemingly a good call as Ballinger found themselves 21 for 4 off 5 overs against some very good opening bowling## the clouds now looking even darker. Max still at the crease and now joined by Hamish with a re-building partnership desperately needed. The pair not only re-build but extend and put on 105 runs in the next 13 overs and take the score to 126 before Hamish is caught looking for another big hit## the score now a respectable 126 for 5 off 18 overs. Max continuing to punish the Wendover bowlers who must have regretted several dropped catches during his innings. Ballinger finishing on 149 for 7 with Max unbeaten on 79## a captains innings.

Having posted a challenging total Ballinger looked to make things difficult for the opposition. Fin Clarke and Will Arnold opening the attack and giving nothing away. Sam Peters and Dom Brown picking up were they left off. Excellent bowling and scoreboard pressure adding to Wendovers woes with a couple of panicky run outs making a difficult situation impossible. Wickets fell at regular intervals and Wendover collapsed to 40 all out off 12 overs. Sam Peters the pick of the bowlers with 5 for 9 off 2.2 overs..

Max's batting and Sam's bowling the highlights of the morning but congratulations to all the team for a great win. Ballinger 5 wins from 5 and the sun starting to break through.

For technical reasons Sam Cooke is down as his brother George on the scorecard.

This week the Sunday XI ventured north of Aylesbury to the small but picturesque village of Cublington. Losing the toss and fielding on a large ground with an excellent wicket and a lack of bowlers could have been a recipe for disaster. However we stuck at the task well and managed to restrict Cublington to a score of 208 for 6 from their 40 overs. The wickets were shared between three bowlers each with two wickets; James Mcintrye## Rob Farquar and Basty who has the happy knack of picking up important wickets## crucially dismissing the dangerous Carter for 42. Credit must also go to the part time bowlers Marcus and Tom who managed to restrict the Cublington run rate even towards the backend of their innings.

After an excellent tea and a spot of drizzle Ballinger opened up confidently with the father and son pairing of Rob and Tom Mcintrye. However despite a good start both openers managed to find novel ways of getting out## Tom chipped a ball which had bounced three times straight to cover and Rob got into a mix up with Danny over calling an easy single. Danny and I then attempted to get the run chase back on track by being watchful but still looking to pick up singles and punish the bad deliveries. We were able to put on a partnership of 88 and at 120-2 with 16 overs left## Ballinger fancied their chances of pulling off an unlikely victory. However both Danny and I were out in consecutive overs triggering a lower-middle order collapse. With the loss of wickets## our run rate stalled and despite Max Dugdales explosive striking and excellent batting he couldn’t haul the team over the line by himself. In the end Cublington’s score of 208 was 20 runs above par and to have won the game we needed one of the top 5 batsmen to go on and score 70+ rather than 3 of us scoring 40.

 Nevertheless it was an enjoyable game played in good spirit against friendly but skilled opposition. We look forward to hosting Cublington in September when we can hopefully have a few more frontline bowlers in the side. 

For technical reasons Rob Farquhar appears as James Fray on the scorecard

Will Smith

With 13 players unavailable and 6 changes to Sunday's side a new look Ballinger took on Chenies & Latimer in the final league game of the season. Captain Ben Dugdale won the toss again## 5 out of 6 for the season## and opted to bat. Max and Matt got off to a good start and put on 22 for the first wicket in the fourth over. Matt'a departure brought Kenny to the crease for an outing at 3 after much negociating throughout the season. Max telling Kenny to take his time obviously had no effect## with Kenny holing out to mid on after 4 deliveries. Ben joined Max in the middle and they put on 50 runs before Max mistimed one to mid off## Ballinger 88 for 3 off 11 overs## a very healthy run rate. Hamish in next and he and Ben take the score to 110 before Ben is bowled by a ball that kept very low. Marcus Tingey## making his u17 debut## having a brief spell at the crease## Ballinger 112 for 5 off 15 overs. Will Arnold now joining Hamish and the pair adding a further 39 runs in the last 5 overs## with Hamish doing most of the damage## finishing on 39 not out## Ballinger 151 for 5.

Having set a challinging total the captain decided to mix up his bowling options with various degrees of success. Rob Farquhar## flown in from Hungary for this game got Ballinger off to a good start with a wicket in his first over. C & L added 38 runs before losing their second wicket## Will Arnold doing the damage. It was Will again 3 runs later## C & L 45 for 3 off 8 overs and again 2 runs later## 47 for 4 off 10. Max Dugdale now on and bowling some interesting variation## gave C & L some restbite and they managed to push the score  to 72 before Hamish claimed a further 2 wickets in his third over with a variation of leg spin## off spin and no spin. C & L 72 for 7 off 13. Further bowling changes allowed C & L to take the score to 125 for 7 after 19 overs## 26 runs needed in the final over to win. Hamish on for the last over## reverting back to his usual action and taking the final 3 wickets only conceding a bye## C & L all out for 126. Hamish finishing with 6 for 8 off his 4 overs.

Ballinger securing the league with 6 wins out of 6. A squad of 24 players from u17 to u14 used throughout the season## all playing their part in some excellent cricket. 834 runs scored with the loss of 32 wickets conceding 548 runs and taking 46 wickets. Very impressive and things looking good for the future of Ballinger cricket.

 

Miles Dugdale

A youthful Ballinger team were invited to the Hawridge Presidents' Day six a side and we're looking to improve on last year's Semi Final place. Drawn in a group with Hawridge's Sunday team and a team from their sponsors##Shami## good runs from Max ##Andy & hamish saw us safely through to a semi final match against last year's winners from another sponsor Phil Wright. In a tight finish Ballinger got through to the final where they were rematched with the Shami six. Batting first for the first time in the competition a total of 45 never quite looked enough and we had to settle for the runners up.

Taking a strong side to Cadmore is not always a guarantee of success however they have made great strides with their wicket - although the outfield remains interesting ! With the skipper held up behind the corporation dustcart## stand in Stuart called tails to the chagrin of his teammates and BWCC duly took to the field in blistering heat. The only problem for the newly arrived Branners was how to deploy his pack of hungry bowlers. The ball was thrown to Evan##who had wisely ducked the Ballinger road that Jamie had prepared in order to get some first team runs. He and usual opener Fin were miserly conceding just 17 runs between them off their opening spells. 'Pads' was however getting redder in the face as he familiarised himself with the unique Cadmore slopes. Drinks at 13 overs and no wickets down## time for Harry and Tom to have a crack. By the time drinks were taken again at 26 overs## Cadmore were 74-6## the wickets shared between them plus a fantastic run out from Stuart with the Dude (now behind the stumps) finishing the job off. In trying to repeat the feat a few overs later a now highly excitable Dude beat Stuart's accurate throw to the stumps ! Another short spell of magic from Freddie confused the remaining batsmen and our opening pair were recalled to mop up the by now bemused Cadmore tail##a fine slip catch from Pads being the highlight - he really doesn't need those gloves !

Our regular openers took to the field after an early tea and by drinks at 13 overs the game was all but over. Stuart## determined not to have to bat for too long## finally got the 50 he'd been avoiding all season ably supported by Matt. By 5pm hands were being shaken and the pub was the next objective.

Thanks to Dick for helping us out this week and Max Conway for resuming the pencil duties.

Unsuccessful at the toss## Ballinger's under-strength bowling line up had to endure the hottest Saturday of the summer## facing the usually high scoring Downley## on a pitch perfecly made for batting. So when Nick Adams accounted for both openers## one of them superbly caught by a flying Danny Draper## and only 30 on the board in the seventh over## hopes were high. However## the next wicket was not to fall until 97## and by this time Downley's number three R Ali## after a watchful start## was giving a superlative batting exhibition## excelling at the late cut## and with R Ullah (42) put on 105 for the 4th wicket## by which time the total was 205## and still 4 overs left for the hapless bowlers to suffer. Ali was bowled by persevering skipper Ian Davies for a magnificent 105## whereupon J Cox proceded to flog 25 off a mere 12 deliveries## to set Ballinger a mountainous target of 256 - their previous best this season being 179 -4!

With a good batting track and a strong batting side## there was every hope that at last we might see their full potential unleashed.  Attack was to be the order of the day## and Danny Draper## making his debut in the league side this season smashed a couple of fours off the first over - then promptly was dismissed LBW by umpire Dugdale## rapidly followed by Andy Thompson getting a top edge to fine leg off his first aggressive shot. 10 for 2 by the 4th over was not in line with team orders## but Rollo McIntyre and Ian Davies got their heads down well and rebuilt the innings so effectively that having reached a half century partnership## it was a surprise when Ian was bowled by an excellent delivery## having made 23. Richard O'Kelly kept the board moving with a quick 18## but was then caught by the keeper## as was Rollo who by this time was scoring freely## and the Ballinger run rate well ahead of Downley's. It accelerated even further with the advent of Will Smith at the crease## as he smashed two mighty sixes## before sallying fatally down the pitch## wafting at thin air## and be being stumped by a mile.This was a real waste of an opportunity## as he and Max Dugdale had been making batting look easy## and they had ample time in which to set up victory. Max## who after a tentative start## was increasing in confidence with every ball## also struck two sixes in a fine 31## before he too perished LBW. That made it 159 for 7## with 10 overs left. At the 30 over mark## Downley had been 149 but the difference was that they had only lost 3 wickets. Monty Thompson came in to bat sensibly## taking any runs available## and finishing unbeaten on 29## but there was no-one left to keep the requisite momentum up## and the innings ambled along to finish on 194 for 9## when the overs ran out.

By no means a demoralising defeat## and perhaps with some of our missing bowlers available the target might have been lower.  Perhaps## but all the bowlers did as well as could be expected## and Richard O'Kelly might have cut down on the byes had he been fully fit. "Perhaps" and "Might "will not help in the relegation struggle## though!

Winning the toss and batting on a beautiful day## flat track## lighting quick outfield and a strong batting line-up Ballinger were expecting a total of at least 240. However the best laid plans of mice and men often go awry## and none of the top 5 batsmen showed any application and Ballinger were struggling at 110-8 in the 25th over with only Reece Tiley batting properly for a stylish 41. It was now left down to Will Arnold and David Livingstone (on debut) to see if they could at least make Ballinger’s score respectable. They proceed to play ‘clever cricket’ by running very quick singles## and being watchful and circumspect to balls outside the off stump while thrashing anything short and wide to the boundary. In short they showed skill and application far above their positions in the batting order.  Gradually Ballinger’s score began to creep up## thanks to an excellent 48 not out by Will ably supported by David. We ended up on 197 from our 40 overs which was 50 more runs than we could have hoped for at 110-8 but ultimately 20 runs below par on such a quick outfield.

After a first-rate tea and quick warm up Ballinger went out into the field confident in a strong bowling attack and youthful fielding side. The opening pair of Will Arnold and Harry Livingstone both adroitly managed to control a swinging ball with devastating effect taking 3 wickets in the first few overs. Rob Farquhar came on first change and managed to maintain the pressure by bowling accurately and keeping the run rate down. However despite this promising start the Chearsley Captain## Ricketts## was beginning to find the boundary regularly and he was well supported by their number 6 batsman who was adept at finding the gaps and rotating the strike. These two played incredibly well and their 140 run partnership won the game for Chearsley## in particular credit to Ricketts who was very unlucky to finish on 97 not out.

 

Despite losing a close match it was nevertheless an enjoyable day playing on a nice ground with great weather against friendly opposition.

Will Smith

Having had both Saturdays matches rained off it was a relief to arrive at Amersham with clear blue skies## and an even bigger relief to lose the toss and be asked to bat on a small ground with a very quick outfield! Openers Matt R (39) and Matt O’Kelly (24) started brightly## both capitalizing on anything back of a length and in particular playing the late cut (or outside edge?) through gully/third man with great skill.  Despite the excellent start and 50 partnership both openers managed to get themselves out to short and wide deliveries## Riley by giving catching practise to cover and Matt edging one behind to the keeper. I carried on my season long habit or getting in and then getting out cheaply by spooning a catch to midwicket. By now Max was beginning to look more assured at the crease despite a streaky start and was well accompanied by Toby (21) and Ben (28) whom he shared consecutive 50 partnerships with. Unfortunately Max was run out going in an effort to retain the strike and get to 99. Nevertheless Max played exceptionally well; he combines a bludgeoning and aggressive batting style with outstanding selectivity and normally very good running between the wickets. The tail failed to wag as it had in previous games and we actually ended up being bowled out in the final over. However we finished on an imposing total of 282 from our 40 overs## the only black mark against an otherwise excellent batting performance being 3 run outs!

It made a nice change for the Ballinger opening bowlers and skipper to have a lot of runs to play with and consequently we could bowl and have fields set to take wickets rather than limit runs. This suited Alex who bowled excellently to take 3 wickets for few runs in his first spell## he was backed up by Dom who was a little erratic but still managed to pick up a wicket. Stuart came on first change and bowled miserly; squeezing the Amersham batsman and causing the required run rate to rocket upwards of 10 an over. The scoreboard pressure proved too much for Amersham and Stuart claimed 4 wickets while Monty chipped in with two to wrap things up for Ballinger at 18:30 in the 25th over!

In short this was the best performance the Sunday XI have had this season and made skippering the side easy and enjoyable## hopefully a sign of things to come over the rest of the season!

 

Will Smith

Barn Meadow was the venue for this fixture## aptly named judging by the condition of the pitch. Captain Stuart Clark winning the toss and chosing to field## not knowing what the strip was likely to do. With a youthful bowling attack and an unpredictable strip Ballinger were soon in control. Fin Clark taking the first wicket in the third over## Dom Brown the second in the fourth## Dom again in the sixth followed by Fin in the seventh## Ley Hill 29 for 4 after some tight bowling## some loose shots and some good catches from Freddie DS## Tom Petrie and Toby Lyons. It was Dom again in the twelth over## keeper Ben Dugdale taking the catch. Andy Rowe and Freddie Thompson taking over from Fin and Dom. Freddie bowling great line and length and getting plenty of turn on an unhelpful pitch kept Ley Hill under pressure. Wickets continued to fall with Freddie the main danger## taking 5 wickets in his 5.3 overs## 2 bowled## 2 stumpings from Ben and a catch from Tom Petrie and only conceding 6 runs. A stunned Ley Hill all out for 60 with their captain commenting he thought they had a strong batting side.

Ballinger took to the middle with Stuart Clark and Matt O'Kelly. Batting wasn't easy and Matt was first to go with the score on 13 in the third over. Even Stuart was struggling to get any rhythm and he was also deceived by a ball that stood up and could only glove it to the keeper. Ballinger 28 for 2 in the tenth over. Tom Petrie and Toby Lyons were now at the crease and both took their time to settle. Some tight bowling from Ley Hill made things difficult but the pair batted sensibly and took the score to 62 in the nineteenth over## Tom not out on 36## securing the win and the points for Ballinger.

Time is fast running out for Ballinger if they are to stand any chance of avoiding relegation. On an ideal day for cricket ## with a pitch unaffected by overnight rain## thanks to our new cover## they produced another disappointing performance## allowing Ley Hill to avenge their defeat earlier in the season.

Having won the toss## Ley Hill unsurprisingly opted to bat first## but initially things looked bright for the home team## when Alex Howe struck with the very first ball of his spell## courtesy of an athletic diving catch at gully by Will Smith. This was followed by Will Reid's successful LBW shout against the number 3 bat## Ford. That made it 20 for 2## with 7 overs gone## but thereafter it was all downhill as a lengthy partnership of 82 developed between opener J Lown and O Runswick. Both started cautiously## but they steadily mastered Ballinger's (mostly!) youthful attack## and when Runswick eventually fell to the persevering Carlton Siddle he had made 56## and the total had reached 103## in the 28th over. That meant that the bowlers now had to contend with the talented S Daluwatte. With Lown now scoring freely with shots his own team said they had never seen from him before## the score was rocketting along. Lown was at last bowled by Will Reid for a valuable 65## and Daluwatte raced on to 48 not out## as Ley Hill finished on 206 for 4.

Any half-decent side would reckon on pursuing 207 on such a good wicket. Indeed Ballinger started as though they were well up to the task. Danny Draper and Andy Thompson set a cracking pace## aided it must be said by a flurry of extras## and had 43 on the board in 10 overs before Danny's patience got the better of him and was caught by the keeper for 9.Will Smith now joined Andy who was batting so well that he looked as if he might win the match single-handed. But having reached a fine 44## he top-edged a catch. 69 for 2 became 78 for 3 when Ian Davies' brief knock ended. The patient Will Smith and Carlton had seen the score to 103 when Carlton somehow found himself LBW## at which point the wheels well and truly fell off - a not uncommon Ballinger scenario. Two more wickets fell without addition to the total## and a further two at 127. Ballinger's only realistic hope was now to reach 158## at which point they could claim bonus points for scoring 75% of their opponents' total. Thanks to some adventurous running and hard hitting  this target was reached (- just!)## a credit to those mainly involved - Will Arnold## Will Reid and Evan Webster whose towering 6 saw us reach the necessary score## whereupon the final wicket went down.

With both teams starting the game within the top four## this fixture had the potential to significantly influence where cricket is played next season. 

Waddesdon won the toss and## perhaps surprisingly## elected to bowl on a dry flat track and short## fast outfield. From the outset the senior members of the Ballinger team felt that anything short of 200 would be below par batting first. Initial progress was steady## with 50 being reached in the 8th over without loss. The first wicket fell at 64 when Matt got one that stuck in the pitch and was caught for 15. Runs continued to flow until a breakdown in communication resulted in the stand-in-skipper being run out on 49. Rumours of jug avoidance may abound## but are greatly exaggerated. Despite being at the crease during the mix up## James McIntyre put this behind him and set about building an excellent innings## including some superb footwork to the slow bowlers## together with the shot of the day - an exquisite on-drive for four. While the Ballinger total continued to accumulate## wickets were falling at regular intervals## culminating in the close of the innings in the 37th over with the total on 189## thanks to a series of valuable cameos (Rob Mc 18; Basty 17; Fin 13). At tea the general feeling in the dressing room was that this was 20 or 30 runs short.

Both of Ballinger's opening bowlers (Fin and Evan) set about the task in hand with pace and hostility. However## despite their efforts## the early breakthrough that was required did not materialise until the 9th over. From this point onwards## two things happened: Firstly## the Waddesdon batsmen decided that they were not prepared to graft for the runs that were required## and that attempting to hit boundaries was the order of the day; secondly## the youngsters of Ballinger proved the old adage that 'catches win matches'. Seven catches in total brought the Waddesdon innings to a close## including two sensational efforts from James Mc and Freddie. These spectacular efforts were swiftly followed by two difficult chances being snaffled by Evan and Basty## with the game being finally wrapped up by a smart (juggling) caught and bowled by Fin. All four bowlers maintained a good line and length and were rewarded for their efforts.

While it was overheard from the visitors that the difference between the two sides was the fielding## the reality was that Ballinger were the better side in all three areas## and were deserving winners.

 

Stu Clark

On a sticky wicket## overcast conditions and Ballinger being asked to bat this match had all the pre-requisite ingredients for another one of our many batting collapses this season. However this was not to be## as the batsman (bar myself) showed application## fortitude and skill we haven’t really produced all season.  Our innings was built around partnerships and contributions of 20’s and 30’s with no one going on to make a big score## but due to the nature of the pitch you were never really ‘in’. Andy was probably the pick of the batsmen with a well crafted 39## playing the hook and pull shot with great aplomb## however he was unluckily given out LBW despite suggestions of an inside edge. Andy was well supported by Richard (30) and Ian Davis (28) who both played well and managed to keep the scoreboard ticking along## this was despite a massive boundary with an uncut outfield which ensured plenty of 2’s and 3’s. The scene was well set at 113-4 for some lower ordering hitting## which was duly provided by Jono (16)## Ian McIver (9*) and Will Arnold (17*). We were also quite fortunate to be on the receiving end of 37 extras## including 15 no balls## which bought our score up to 194## which was probably 20 runs above par given the conditions.

                It made a nice change for the bowlers to have some runs to play with and for the batsman to be under some scoreboard pressure right from the start. The scoreboard pressure was immediately apparent as two of Waddesdon’s best batsmen were out early trying to hit Will Reid over the top. After this excellent start by Ballinger the Waddesdon innings never really got going as Ballinger were able to pick up wickets at regular intervals and restrict the Waddesdon scoring. Despite some wearisome resistance by the 10th wicket pair## Ballinger were able to wrap things up and bowl them out for 99 in the 37th over. It was an excellent bowlingand fielding performance by everyone## but in particular credit to the niggardly Ian Maciver who picked up 4-17 and Will Reid who took 4-25.

                This comprehensive victory was fully deserved as we outplayed Waddesdon in all facets of the game. Now we just need to maintain this level of performance over the last two matches against Wendover and Bradenham in what will be relegation deciding matches.

 

Will Smith

Excitement had been building all week for the cricket loving supporters of Ballinger in advance of the visit of Britwell Salome from across the border in Oxfordshire.  On a sun drenched Sunday in the middle of August there is no finer place to be for the village folk of Ballinger.

However## with heavy local showers in the surrounding villages on the morning of the game everyone arrived at the ground wondering just how wet it would be.  To the surprise of all## the ground was dry and the pitch was hard.   Although the sun was out at times## there was a cold wind which did not make it much fun for the spectators. 

Skipper Will Smith had his carefully selected team of youth and experience ready to take on the Britwell juggernaut.  He wins the toss and chooses to bat.  Having done his homework on Britwell the first part of his  master plan was in place.  As the fielders take to the field they are all wearing Widmer End shirts and caps!  Britwell had cancelled late in the week and Widmer End had agreed to the game at short notice.    

The opening bowlers of Widmer End kept it tight.  Hamish got a nasty ball which saw him dismissed for just 2.  Will joined Matt O’Kelly at the crease but was dismissed for 19## trying to force the run rate.  Matt continued to blunt the opening bowlers and was eventually dismissed for a dogged 36.  Richard O’Kelly (48) and Marcus Tingey (42 not out) picked up the run rate to enable Ballinger to declare on 178 for 6 at tea.  Both Toby Lyons (11) and Nick Tegg (5) perished going for quick runs at the end## although Nick’s dismissal was probably due to him needing to get back to the pavilion to sort out the teas!

Dom Brown opened the bowling for Ballinger but had trouble controlling the swinging ball.  One of the spectators did comment that they had not seen that much swing at Ballinger since a Frank Sinatra tribute act in the Village Hall in 2010!

Harry Livingstone bowled from the other end## taking the first 3 wickets for just 8 runs from his 6 excellent overs.  Fin Clark bowled well without reward.  He did rush through one of his overs## so as to make sure we got an extra over in before the start of the final 20 overs.  This turned out to be vitally important as you are about to find out.

Stuart McGowan toiled away at one end taking the next 5 wickets.  With 8 wickets down## Ballinger knew they needed those last 2 wickets.  The Ballinger spectators have already seen their bowlers fail to dismiss the opposition’s number 11 batsman twice this season## so having to settle for draws.  Surely it was not going to happen again?

With 5 overs left## all 3 results were possible.  Hamish took the 9th wicket leaving 3 overs to get the last man.  Going into the final over## Widmer End needed  14 runs for victory.  With the number 11 batsman on strike this seemed unlikely.  Stuart had 6 balls to get that final wicket.  Every fielder was around the bat.  The first 5 balls were seen off.  All down to the final ball.  Stuart released the ball.  The line was good## the flight was good## the batsman was drawn forward## there was late dip## the batsman could not get to the pitch of the ball## it turned## it beat the bat and clattered into the stumps. 

There were jubilant scenes on the pitch and among the watching spectators.  The cheers would have been heard by the people of The Lee and South Heath## while sitting in their back gardens next to their patio heaters.  The cricket loving folk of Ballinger wandered home talking about dramatic late victories they had seen. Edgbaston 2005## Ballinger 2014.....

This was an excellent friendly game of cricket## played in the right way by both teams.

Ballinger went in to this must-win fixture shorn of the greater part of their first eleven squad## so a casual spectator (if we have any) would be forgiven for thinking he had turned up to watch the high flying Seconds in action. Wendover won the toss## and possibly because they knew that they were certainties for relegation## decided to bat first. With 20 on the board after only 3 overs## they must have been confident that it was to be their day. Although Nick Adams went wicketless in his first spell## Will Arnold was bowling particularly well## and struck in his third over to make it 24 for 1. A stubborn stand then ensued## but the scoring rate steadily diminished## and the next wicket went to an on-song Evan Webster with the total on 60## and he quickly followed with two more victims.  Ian Maciver tied up the batsmen at the other end## then clean bowled Wendover's best batsman## the left handed N Morley for 37. Nick## scenting cheap wickets in a second spell## duly delivered##with two in his first over in consecutive deliveries. His hat-trick ball was## alas## a high full toss.... The Wendover innings was by now in ruins. A superb throw by Matt O'Kelly (thereby fully redeeming a dropped dolly!) saw his father complete a valuable run-out## and Will Arnold wrapped up the tail end with two more scalps## finishing a fine performance with 3 for 14. Ballinger's few oldies were given a lesson in fielding by the youngsters whose efforts were first class.

With a target of only 97## would Ballinger's batsmen be up to the task? The answer was a resounding yes! Openers Richard O'Kelly and James McIntyre never looked to be in any trouble as they kept the scoreboard ticking steadily## concentrating on punishing any loose bowling## but avoiding any unneccessary risks. Repeated bowling changes by Wendover were unavailing## and it was only when the target was in sight that they both lost a little concentration and were caught. James went first## having made a stylish 28##with some sumptuous stroke play## and Richard followed soon after having reached a match winning 50. Their partnership of 81 was by some way Ballinger's best of the season. An 8 wicket victory left a number of batsmen frustrated in the pavilion## but the batting display in this match## coupled with the all round solidity in last week's performance showed clearly why the team have been flirting for so long with relegation - their inconsistent batsmen have simply been letting them down.

The final game of the season was upon us## and the Seconds had only tasted defeat once since a wet Saturday in early June over at Waddesdon. Up against Widmer End IIs who were languishing in the bottom half of the league## the skipper had already decided to have a bat when on losing the toss -again - we were inserted by the oppo. A solid start from the regular opening pair Stuart and Matt saw the score into the 30s before Matt departed and James Mac joined Stu in what was to prove the key partnership of the match. By the time Stuart was caught out at Cow## for 66 the score had passed a hundred off 22 overs.
