Ben joined James and looked to push the score along as the lads occasionally looked for a quick single or two. With a plethora of talent still in the hutch Ben fell to the wily Hobbs and was soon joined by the skipper who failed to make his first visit to the crease for a couple of months a lengthy one ! Andy ##back from Oz## had also not wielded a bat in anger for a considerable time but made better use of the opportunity and pushed the run rate up. By now James had reached his fifty and was also beginning to accelerate## finally reaching 81 when the innings closed - the highest score in the league by any Ballinger batsman this season.

Widmer started badly with Fin's box of allsorts claiming 3 wickets whilst Tom's more orthodox approach at the other end went unrewarded. A switch to spin brought more wickets as both Ben and Freddie made further inroads into the opposition batting. By the time Matt came on to clean up what was left## the only thing on both teams minds was to get to the Swan as fast as possible.

Another overwhelming win for the 2s rounded up the season nicely and we must just wait to see if it will be enough for the team to get promoted and face some new opposition next season.

Thanks to all who played this year and to in particular to Nigel and Stuart who skippered in my absence (and often in my presence !) and to Miles for all those umpiring points as well as all those who conjured up teas for us all.

Safe at last from relegation worries## Ballinger's visit to the picturesque surroundings at Bradenham gave them an opportunity to go one better## and climb to mid-table respectability. A chance they took with a vengeance## as Bradenham## opting to bat first## found themselves utterly webstered. This new cricketing term refers to the devastating swing bowling produced by Evan Webster## who if his first over goes well## can well prove unplayable. The total stood at 39 for 2 when he came on to bowl## the early breakthroughs caused by a successful LBW shout from Nick Adams## and a suicidal second run attempt which alert fielding capitalised on. Enter Evan. His fourth ball went for a boundary## the next was exit the batsman## bowled. Only two singles were conceded by him for the rest of the innings## during which he claimed another 5 hapless victims## remarkably all of them clean bowled## or inside edged. Meanwhile Will Arnold claimed the wicket of the dogged opener Hoddle## without whose 31 runs Bradenham would have been facing utter disaster. Monty Thompson chipped in to spoil Evan's chances of entering Ballinger bowling history## and when Evan took the final wicket## his figures read 6.4 overs - 3 maidens - 6 wickets for 6 runs ! A superb performance.

With the clock standing at only ten past three## Ballinger's batsmen went out to see whether they could finish the job before tea. Well## most of them. Matt Riley## having despatched the fourth ball of the innings to the boundary## then realised that this was truly unseemly aggression on his part## and settled down to his proper role## nicking singles off the last ball of an over whenever possible. No such inhibitions affected Richard O'Kelly (20) and Rollo McIntyre (17)## but in a match where remarkably not a single catch was taken## both departed ## bowled. Tea was deferred## and Matt and Danny Draper saw Ballinger steadily home## with Matt suddenly casting off the shackles## and hoisting the winning runs with a six!

Game over at half past four## time for a pleasant tea with pleasant opposition## then off to Ballinger to watch the Seconds triumph in their match.  A truly enjoyable way to end the season.

It is always a huge pleasure to play cricket at Long Marston. It is fantastic ground with an excellent wicket## at which minor county games are played.  Ballinger elected to bat first – you can’t sensibly do anything else on a “road” like that.  Opener Basty Richards fell early## but then his partner## Matt O’Kelly## and Nick Tegg built up a steady partnership.  The run rate was however getting a little pedestrian and so Nick rightly tried to push it on## but perished in the process. The stage was set perfectly for Rollo McIntyre## who came in and## as ever## moved the scoring along with some big and sweetly timed shots## before he was eventually out for 71.  After Matt fell for a very diligent 37 off 31 overs## the scoring was taken on by Will Smith## Rob McIntyre (56*) and at the end Andy Thompson (33*)## with Ballinger 259 for 6 declared off 46 overs -  about 200 of those scored off the last 26.

 

One had the feeling that even a target of 260 might not be enough on a very good pitch and fast outfield## and so it proved.  Ballinger kept the old ball (we were playing with 2 new balls) and opened with Freddie Thompson and James McIntyre both bowling leg breaks. The game might have been very different if Freddie (or the skipper) had answered Rollo’s question of “do you want me first or second slip?” differently. Rollo ended up at second and Freddie’s first ball was edged through first. The Long Marston opener went on to blast 101 retired off 18 overs## by which point Long Marston effectively had it in the bag.  After 5 overs of spin## Ballinger had reverted to the new ball and the more regular opening seam attack of Nick Adams and Alex Howe.  Nick in particular bowled his usual tight lines and came away with the creditable figures of 1 for 65 off 13. Freddie came back to bowl another spell and ended with 2 for 65 off 10.  But it was all really a matter of just trying to delay the inevitable and attain respectability.  To Ballinger’s credit## we did do that## slowing the scoring## taking some wickets and remaining committed and effective in the field.  The reality is that on that track we needed 300 off 45 overs and then a bit of luck!

Batting first by agreement## Ballinger initially seemed to be facing really quite an impressive opening attack for a Sunday## with Matt Riley and Jamie Kellock dismissed relatively early## followed a little later by Danny Draper (after a battling 22## including a 6 which nearly took out one of the pavilion windows) and Kenny Holt## before the Jordans Taverners opening bowlers had finished their work. However## Will Smith## coming in at number 4## having seen off the last of the openers## then plundered a really excellent 119 against the remaining bowlers## batting with skill## confidence and## latterly## audacity - a truly excellent innings## peppered with sixes and improvisation.  Will was ably supported by some lusty blows from Steve Conway and Steve Carter and then## after Will was finally out## from David Livingstone in the last few overs## before## in his capacity as skipper## Will declared at 230 for 6 after only 41 overs## having used considerably less than half of the likely available time - a confident declaration to match the confidence of his innings.

 

It also proved a well-judged declaration## as Jordans never really looked as if they were genuinely trying to overhaul Ballinger’s total and in the end only just hung on## with 9 wickets down## after 47 overs.  The declaration was also## in one sense## bold## since even at the outset Ballinger were a little short of bowlers## with Nick Adams## Andy Thompson and Matt O’Kelly## to be supplemented by David Livingstone having his first bowl of the season. Unfortunately## after only 5 overs## David damaged his knee diving in the covers## restricting the bowling attack even further.  Luckily the two old warhorses## Adams and Thompson## bowled 17 and 18 overs respectively and Matt O’Kelly turned in an accurate and penetrating spell## picking up 1 for 23.  But the bowling highlight and provider of the champagne moment was Matt Riley’s occasional off spin## which claimed a wicket with his very first ball## as a long hop loosener was slapped conveniently to mid-off.  Matt then bought another wicket## but his purchasing power then expired as the Jordans number 9## Murphy## tucked into some juicy full tosses## whacking them over the fielders at long on and cow corner for a series of sixes## to produce the only moment in the game when Jordans looked as if they might just go for a win.  Thankfully Thompson was brought back and bowled Murphy## leaving the final pair to hang on for the last few overs and secure a draw.  A very good Ballinger performance.  The other contenders for champagne moment were Kenny Holt’s 2 calmly taken catches at mid-on  ….  Kenny seemed as pleased and surprised as everyone else!

The fixture computer served up a tough opening game in a higher division for the 2s. Early season absences compunded the problems with none of our top ten bowlers and only one of our top ten batsmen from last year's averages available. To then run up against Salid Ali whose predeliction for despatching any good length balls way over the boundary was## to say the least## unfortunate. After the first six overs went for 63 runs we were in deep trouble. A change of pace with debutant Graham Jones replacing Will brought a little respite and when Andy finally bowled Ali off his pads the pain started to ease. A tremendous piece of fielding from Matt (finished of by Pads Conway) saw the other ambling opener on his way back to the hutch. Andy & Graham and some decent fielding had gradually swung the game back towards us## to such an extent that Lacey Green were reduced to 101-7. However## we became increasingly frustrated as a partnership between another big hitter and a youngster added 82 runs despite some tight bowling from Matt. He eventually got the breakthrough and wrapped up the innings with an excellent c&b## rounding off a top fielding display. New boys Philip## Harry & Charlie saved at least 20 runs in the field## keeping up the traditional top notch fielding from Ballinger's youngsters.

After an excellent tea provided by Lizzy we needed a decent start but unfortunately Matt fell c&b and was quickly followed by Will. At the other end Ben looked very comfortable after a 4 year absence and was accumulating runs at a good rate. He was backed up by Charlie who looked very much at home in senior cricket. The running between the wickets was excellent but proved Ben's downfall when a momentary hesitation left him inches short. The opposition then summoned one man demolition merchant Ali into the attack who## in an accurate spell of bowling## claimed a couple of quick wickets - Charlie & Andy## whilst Harry & Phil perished at the other end. At 58-7 and only four old men left## 26 overs seemed a lot of time to fill ! The skipper dropped anchor whilst Peter (a last minute replacement) kept the score ticking over - despite being in pain every time he hit the ball. The skipper went with the score in the nineties and Graham followed shortly after## once again Ali doing the damage. Pads - well rested after his exertions behind the stumps joined Peter with 15 overs still left and they started to worry the oppo as the score passed 100 then 125 and the run rate started to pick up. However one risk too many from Steve finally saw the gallant effort fall short.

Many thanks to Dave Carlin who stepped in to umpire## securing the Seconds first points of the new season## to Max for scoring and for Peter for stepping in at the last minute. A game played in a decent spirit and a respectable## if disappointing. start to the new season.

Paul Branigan

Monks Risborough - so often the graveyard Ballinger hopes.  In recent memory our record away at Monks Risborough has been woeful.  Sadly## that pattern continued as the Ballinger 1st XI played its first league match this season on a cold Spring Chiltern hillside.  In fact## it may be unusual local conditions created by the severe slopes and the always slightly underprepared wickets which contribute to this poor record.  However## Ballinger’s problems this time were largely created in our own heads and by some excellent Monks Risborough bowling.

Ballinger’s bowling and fielding was actually pretty impressive for a first outing## perhaps reflecting the good attendance at winter training and at the first outdoor session on Friday.  Openers## Nick Adams and Will Reid dropped right onto a good line and length and were rewarded with 4 for 28 and 1 for 13 respectively.  New skipper## Ian Maciver## turned to Rollo McIntyre as first change to replace Will## and Rollo showed a Botham-esque ability to take wickets with balls that could not fairly be described as wicket taking deliveries## ending up with 4 for 33 off 5 overs.  When Carlton Siddle took the last wicket with his first ball## Ballinger were pretty pleased with having dismissed the home side for only 84 off 20.1 overs.  But for a series of huge blows from number 8 K Ahmed## finishing with 32 not out## the score could have been a lot lower; particularly as he was dropped on nought. Luckily the offending fieldsman was also the bowler## otherwise the bowler might have got his hair drier out.

Chasing that low total## Ballinger started well enough## but after Richard O’Kelly was run out## it was downhill all the way.  The opening bowlers were seen off## but it was the first and second change bowlers who did all the damage## taking 3 for 19 and## amazingly## 5 for 0 off six overs## with another run out (Rollo) contributing to the collapse to 40 all out.  The pitch was not great## but it was fear of the pitch rather than the pitch itself which did the damage.  Only Ian Davies## who got a shooter## could blame the pitch itself.  There are both technical and mental lessons to be learned.

 

The best that can be said about this performance with the bat is perhaps that we have got it out of the way early in the season## and on one of the rare occasions when our President and scorer## Gerry Hunting## was not there to witness the debacle.  One feels that Gerry would not have been amused.

This is the first competitive match of the season and before i report i do have to mention that we had to disappoint one of our squad as the county decided that all U11 fixtures should be played under Barrington rules## so we had to reduce to ten players for this fixture## not something we enjoyed as all the players are chomping at the bit to play.

Marlow are are very strong and friendly club and our first opponents in this county knock out## luckily the ground was in great shape thanks to our great groundsman Jamie. Marlow lost the toss and our skipper Sebastian wisely chose to bat first.Oliver started proceedings## a dot ball## a 4 and then the first 6 of the season## backed up by the talented Raphi who wasn’t seeing too much of the action as Oliver continued to find the boundary## Raphi placed some great shots for a few singles taking us up to 219 after 4 overs. Archie and Max followed up with a flurry of singles and twos with Max also finding the boundary## leaving the square with us on 246 from 8 overs## Casper found the rope on two occasions helped by Finn who was placing the balls in the gaps with quite some precision## 265 from 12 overs . Thomas and Kuran took their place with some great strokes from Thomas and Kuran taking four singles as well as finding the rope on two occasions## could he be yet another Ballinger all rounder? 276 from 16 and Sebastian and Tim come in to pile on the pressure## flying between the wickets stealing singles which Sebastian took 8 along with two boundaries## Tim only faced a few most of which were fairly wide not allowing him to work his magic.  294 from the 20 overs## a few little mistakes which were to be expected this early in the season.
A very quick turnaround and cakes and sandwiches provided by Melanie Phillips and the family being devoured we take to the field with what has to be one of the strongest bowling sides one could choose and the first over Thomas has a two wicket maiden and a slick run out## Casper bowler like a pro only giving two runs away ## Tim takes two more with no runs and by the end of the fourth over Marlow are on 189## Thomas then takes two more wickets for one run and Sebastian and finn give almost nothing away## then Sebastian gets a run out for only one run in his over and Archie hits the stumps twice from some tidy seam bowling. Kuran comes in and takes 3 for 3 off his two overs and Marlow are on 179 after 13 over and think that must be the end of the Ballinger bowlers## then on come Oliver and Raphi ## Raphi’s first over is a wicket maiden followed by five dots and a four## Oliver continued to be unplayable for the batsmen ## but challenging for our fielders behind the stumps on a couple of occasions ## Thomas bowled a maiden in the 19th over followed by Sebastian taking a wicket the very last ball of the match.
The players ooze confidence and show tremendous team work## the banter between overs is great with Oliver telling his teammates exactly how it is ## very funny to watch and then back to business as they take their positions. A great result with all of the players adding so much to all of the phases of the game## so lessons to be taken away as well so that we reduce the small errors when we take on stronger opposition.Marlow we great opponents and all of the players played with great spirit.
Once again thank to Melanie for laying on a super tea and looking after the clubhouse after the game and to Nick Tatum for helping me tidy and lock up afterwards## it is really appreciated.
Steve

Our first U11B league match and as we promised we gave our U10 squad the opportunity to play up a year and in this match the entire side was U10 ## due to year six disco’s## football## scout camps etc## anyway these things happen. the weather had been very kind and the ground was in great condition## however it was going to be a cloudy and chilly affair  with winds from the east.

Hawridge lost the toss and our skipper Raphia chose to field with eight of the boys who had just finished playing school matches## so little warm up was required. From the first over i could sense what was to come as Toby bowled a wicket maiden followed by a further wicket from Edward O’Doherty’s first over shortly followed by another from his second
## Hawridge are 188 from 4 overs## James and Victor bowled with great accuracy and Hawridge were on 195 after 8 overs## Harvey and Edward Batchelor [on his debut for BWCC] again gave nothing away and Harvey took a great wicket## the end of over 12 and they wren on 198## still not getting into positive territory## they must have been hoping that was the end of our bowlers## but then on came Edward Best and the skipper Raphi## Edward takes two wickets in his first over and Raphi takes one in his second## over 16 and they are still going backwards on 190## Freddie ##Toby and Victor finished off the proceedings with toby taking a further wicket and leaving the visitors in positive territory in the last over 206 for 8. Hawridge had been kept under pressure from the boys from accurate bowling## virtually no extras and strong fielding and filed placement.
Ballinger come in to bat with not too much to do## but this is cricket and anything can happen## Edward Batchelor and new player to the club open with Victor and they have their own plan and Edward hits a mighty six ## the long way i might add## well backed up by Victor## and we have passed the Hawridge total by the end of the first over## Edward and Victor don’t lose a wicket and leave the square with BWCC on 223 after 4 overs. Toby and Harvey come in and continue doing damage to the oppositions score## Harvey finding the boundary as well as scoring from every ball that he faced ## they left the square pushing the score up to 251## next in Edward O’D and Edward Best## both boys found the boundary with apparent ease and Edward Best a wonderful demonstration of how to play a cover drive## they wandered back to the pavilion without losing a wicket on 272 from 12 overs. Haw ridge must have been wondering if this would continue and in came Freddie with James Best and again both boys found the distant boundary with perfectly times strokes## making it all look effortless## again without losing a wicket they took the side up to 303 from 16 overs## it was now getting very dark so on came the high visibility ball along with Jack and Raphi ## the boys over enthusiasm created two run outs## but this was offset by Jack and Raphia running excellent two’s from well placed shots and both boys finding the boundary as well as the second six of the season with a strong strike down the ground by Raphi. It was all over and the boys walked off with a majestic 326.
Well done to all of the players and a big thank you to Emma##Jess and Lara for providing a wonderful tea for the players and spectators.

Forecasters have made a bit of a mess of things lately## so after last week's abysmal batting show anyone predicting Ballinger's highest total since July 2013 would have got very good odds.

The ground looked a picture - well done Jamie## and all those who helped at last month's working party. Put in to bat## on a pitch that proved to be a a little on the slow side (particularly for those used to winter nets)## openers Richard O'Kelly and Danny Draper took a little time adjusting## but Richard (commanding a Riley-esqe share of the strike) was soon into his stride## and the scoring rate steadily mounted## as the boundaries flowed. Danny's bat now started to locate the ball more profitably## but frustratingly his best shots sped unerringly to a fielder. Target number one was to beat last week's all out 40## and this was achieved in the 13th over. Regular Bradenham bowling changes had no success## and the century partnership looked a certainty until Richard miscued## out for a very attractive 56. Rollo was next in## and## misreading the pitch## was lucky to profit from an easy dropped catch. Hitherto the Bradenham fielding had looked very sharp## so this was an unexpected bonus## from which Rollo took full advantage. Cars and buildings around the ground now started to suffer## as he opted for the aerial route. Danny went## caught for a well crafted 52## Jono Lacey perished## bowled## and in came Ian Davies to show us that whatever else he had learned from his recent Carribean sojourn## sloth between the wickets was not on his agenda## as previously spurned singles were now chanced with alacrity and unsettled the fielding side. He did not last that long## but certainly upped the tempo## as did Andy Thompson## so that with 40 overs up## BWCC had reached the dizzy heights of 222 for 6## with Rollo on 79 not out - a masterly display.

Danny contniued his successful day by providing us with a massive tea## berfore Bradenham commenced their daunting reply. Their openers looked solid## and although some half chances (and one easy one) went begging## Will Reid and Nick Adams went unrewarded until the latter at last struck. Will Arnold joined the attack## bowling a fine## accurate spell## but he too had his share of bad luck. The fast bowlers having done all the hard work in keeping the batsmen in check## on came the spinners to claim the glory. Skipper Ian Maciver bagged a wicket in his first over## and another in his second## as Bradenham slumped from 75 for 1 to 127 all out## Ian claiming 5 for 33## and Ian Davies 3 for 12. There were some star performances in the field - two swift stumpings by Richard## a great effort by Will Reid managing not to topple over the boundary as he clung onto a skyer## and an Adams special##his arm at full stretch## the ball appearing in his hand as all looked towards the boundary. A mention to for what might have been the catch of the season (century?) by Jamie Kellock## leaping salmon-like to pull down a drive from high over his head## only for it elude him as it fell to earth.

An excellent performance## and an enjoyable game all round against spirited and sporting opposition. And a particular word of thanks to scorer Liz Thompson## thrust into the firing line for the second week running.The score book is impeccable!

This was a game of two pitches.

 

When we arrived at the ground the sun was shinning and the white clouds were floating gently across the sky driven by a steady breeze. Imagine the captain’s horror when he saw the pitch. It was soaking wet. This meant the toss was going to be crucial as who ever won it was going to get the better pitch to bat on as it dried out.

Sadly stand in skipper Kerry's tossing abilities failed him once again.

 

Ben Carlin and Matt O'Kelly opened up for the Waggoners and it was immediately apparent that getting the ball off the square was going to be a problem. WESM knew what they were doing when they opened with a "dibbly dobber" up the hill and into the wind. No pace at all on the ball. Poor Ben and Matt tried everything they knew to get the ball away and even when they did get it off the square the damp## long outfield stopped it. 

 

After 10 overs the score was on 16 and Matt finally lost patience and lifted his head and was bowled. Ben followed in the next over trying something similar.

Ben Dugdale and Charlie Barraclough were now at the crease and Ben## who is now almost a senior professional in this team## decided to take a few chances along with some excellent shots and good running between the wicket he and Charlie dragged the score upto 45 at the half-way stage. 

120 was the skippers target but Charlie## having looked very comfortable## lofted one and was caught## Ben was then talked out by Widmers best bowler## Shah## who went on to take 5 wickets in all. 

 

The tail didn’t wag unfortunately and by the time the skipper came to the crease it was obvious the strip was beginning to play much better. Not good news. 95 all out was probably 20 less than we should have got.

 

7 overs were possible before tea so the Waggoners went into the field enthusiastically but it was clear from the off that the wicket had changed. Suddenly there was bounce and carry with Finn Clark getting the ball through at good pace even though it was up the hill. The same thing applied to Andy down the hill. The only problem was that anything slightly short just stood up waiting to be hit and Widmer’s openers did just that. Having said that the fielding was excellent and the outfield still slow so there were only 26 runs on the board at tea.

 

After an excellent tea the skipper changed tack and brought Ben D on up the hill and immediately things became more difficult for the batters. Matt O’Kelly was on down the hill and beating the openers for pace. A break through was needed and Ben delivered. I don’t think a description of the actual ball is required but it got a wicket.

 

Charlie B then took a really good catch and we had another point. Could this be the turning point? Sadly not as the number of runs we had to play with were too few. The skipper decided to give debutant Miles Devereaux a bowl from the top end so we would have spin at both ends. Miles immediately dropped onto the spot and proved very difficult to get away. A very confident LBW appeal## when the opener decided to play “French cricket” was turned down only for Miles to bamboozle him 2 balls later.  Sadly this was all in vain as Widmer cruised past our total in only 24th over.

 

A disappointing match only in that the toss decided the game. Widmer are an enjoyable team to play against so it was a pleasant afternoon and the skipper enjoyed a bit of banter with the opposition in the pub. Not something I suspect will happen often this summer.

Ballinger U10 debuts for James Batchelor [U9] ## James Garner## Josh Mandeville [U9]##Harry Sutaria and Charlie Ward against our good friends from Wendover. Wendover won the toss and put us in to bat on this clear but chilly evening## clearly they hadn’t been told about the Ballinger setting sun. Our skipper Toby clearly had a plan and opened up with Matthew W and Charlie W and what a great start with both boys placing the ball well for singles and two’s and running extras when the opportunity presented itself## they took the team up to 221 without loss. James Garner faced some accurate bowling along with Harry and both boys picked up singles and James G found the boundary ## the first of the match## sadly losing one wicket in their pair they however returned to the pavilion after having pushed the total up to a very respectable 233. James Batchelor and Jack dominated in the middle with eight singles and Jack twice finding the boundary## really putting the pressure on the visitors they strode off leaving the team on 255 from 12 overs## Tom and Josh faced two of the better bowlers and played very well and didn’t lose their wickets and they pushed the score further upwards to 260 from 16 overs## a good score from the side## however Freddie and Toby had decided to really put the pressure on and with Freddie hard to take off strike and with every possible extra being run Freddie hit six fours from the spell and the skipper Toby stealing singles and extras on an industrial scale## both boys backing each other up like true professionals. The pair scored 56 from their four overs with only one small error which allowed Wendover to take their second wicket## back to the pavillion with the team on 310 for 2 ## a commanding score.

Both teams ran in for cakes and drinks very kindly organised by Jessica Ward [a huge thank you] and BWCC took to the field. Toby opened the attack four dot balls## a four and then an in swinging yorker whose next point of contact was middle stump## so Wendover in negative territory## then James Batchelor masterminded a super run out with Josh and a clean bowled for only two in his first over and Wendover move back to 188## Tom also bowls neatly and is rewarded by a catch from his first over## the visitors are in all sorts of trouble.James Garner gives only a few extras but no runs from his first over and James B bowls five more dot balls and only gives away a single.Charlies debut over is excellent with no extras given away in either of his two overs## Harry bowls well and is rewarded by an excellent catch by Toby in mid wicket## Josh follows in the Ballinger tradition of tight bowling with several dot balls## Freddie now bowling into the setting sun takes a wicket with the last ball of his first over and the match is finished off by tom## James and Toby with very little being given away. Wendover finished on 259 for 7 ## Ballinger never looked like they were out of the driving seat from the first ball that was bowled## with solid fielding ## strong and sensible batting and tight bowling. Well Done
Steve

Away Match 11th May Chalfont St Giles

A sunny afternoon in Chalfont saw the home team win the toss and put Ballinger into bat.  The opening pair started well with some good strokes and solid strikes.  Chalfont took an early wicket with Jack being bowled.  Rory battled on in partnership with Max retiring on 30 from a well-placed four. Max then joined forces with Henry to make a very respectable 42## Henry being bowled just 1 short of the retirement maximum.  Ballinger then suffered a small mid order collapse before a stabilising partnership between Jake and Archie saw out the 20 overs.

Ballinger 118 for 7## off 20 overs

After a short break for light refreshments Ballinger took the field.  Chalfont put in a solid start with the first pair making 59 off 14 overs## with a comparable run rate making the match look like a close run thing.  Over 15 saw Jake take three wickets## and a high catch taken by Jack.  Over 16 saw another batsman take a walk## an edge being expertly caught my wicket keeper Max.

Overs 17-19 saw Chalfont making worryingly steady progress towards the Ballinger total.  The final over saw all the drama## with Henry taking two wickets## leaving the home side requiring six from the last two deliveries.  Ball five was struck into open space running through the outfield for four runs…so alll down to the last ball.  The crack of leather on willow had the home team cheering….Ballinger fielders were quick to react Tom and Orlando patrolling the outfield and the ball was quickly returned to the bowler’s end for one vital run.

Ballinger 118 for 7 off 20 overs

Chalfont St Giles 117 for 6 off 20 overs

 

A very spirited but friendly game….a big thank you to Chalfont for hosting us.

When groundsman Jamie Kellock asked if it was OK to use the same batting strip again he should have asked the bowlers permission as 443 runs were scored in the ensuing 80 overs. Having won the toss## the skipper spotted that the unathletic looking Wendover side had only 10 men and cruelly prescribed 150 minutes in the heat of the day for them. Stu## making his seasonal bow## took full advantage## despite some tight bowling from the opening attack. The early loss of Ben no1## bought Ben no 2 to the wicket## who curbed his attacking instincts## dropping anchor and taking 20 balls to get off the mark. He eventually perished for 31 of an 85 run partnership. A clatter of wickets reduced BWCC to 140 for 5 but Stu still unbeaten on 85## with 10 overs left. He and the skipper added 67 from the next 9 overs before a clearly inebriated Clark mistook Paul for Usain Bolt and ran him out for a useful 31. Clearly contrite he rounded off his and Ballinger's innings with three consecutive sixes - which were to prove invaluable - in an unbeaten 145. Wendover started well in reply despite Fin taking a wicket in his first over. Both he and Will took some tap from Merrell## sulking in the twos## who hit boundaries to all parts of the ground when challenged to do so by an unusually vocal Stu Clark. A change of pace was required and the ball was thrown to Ben and Miles. However by the time the third wicket fell at 132 in the 22nd over## the oppo were on track for an unlikely win. The two spinners gradually slowed up the runs as we starved Merrell of the strike. When he was dropped on the boundary things looked bleak. However he was eventually well caught by Will on the Cow Corner boundary (much to Stu's delight) for a fine 78. Ben & Miles completed their match winning ten over spells and fin and Philip## bowling his first senior spell## combined to wrap up the Wendover innings just 21 runs short of their target. Whilst at first glance this match seemed a cricketing and verbal duel between two batsmen who should have been playing for their first teams## there was a fine supporting cast. The BWCC youngsters## in particular 11yo Max Conway## subbing for a very poorly Ben Carlin## and Philip saw lots of action in the field and saved a lot of runs. The bowling attack## notably Miles## refused to back down in the face of some aggressive batting and eventually emerged on top. A slick stumping from the Dude merits a mention## and a big thank you to Fiona for an excellent tea and to Miles for officiating once again. The laurels however belong to Stuart for his batting masterclass.

And we are off!

Fantastic win from the girls' first outing - playing away at Farnham Common and it was a nail-biter!  Bowling accuracy and great fielding was the difference.

 

Lucy Adams lost the toss but fortunately the opposition decided to bat first.  The opening bowlers of Merryn and Lucy Bannister were impressively accurate and unlucky not to take a scalp or two.  Laura was our first wicket taker of the season## with a perfectly flighted ball hitting middle stump.   Mimie bowling at the other end kept the runs down.  The Farnham middle order discovered the short boundary but resilience in the field held back a tide of runs with two excellently executed runs outs.    Isabel had the stop of the day - hit extremely hard - what seemed like a certain four was calmly gathered with one hand on the boundary.  Lucy B also collected one very quickly on the boundary and followed up with an accurate throw to achieve an excellent run-out.  Our youngest player## Millie bowled with authority restricting a pair who were trying to break loose to just 3 runs off her 2 overs.  Francesca had an equally tight spell.  Lucy Adams was excellent and energetic behind the stumps - taking one sharp stumping## 3 run outs and should have been awarded another stumping if the umpire (me) had been paying attention.   

 

A target of (2)68 was definitely gettable.  Our openers Isabel and Lucy A played some good shots but succumbed to some excellent bowling - leaving the score where it started after their 4 overs.  Merryn and Laura progressed the score well to 213## only losing one wicket.  Francesca and Millie's innings was the one which put Ballinger into contention.  Helped by some wayward bowling by the opposition.  This pair played sensibly## with some good shots including a well-timed 4 by Francesca and importantly kept out the good balls leaving us needing just 20 runs from the last 8 overs.    Lucy Bannister and Mimie had the task of seeing us home - needing 18 from their 4 overs.    They played sensibly## taking their runs well.  Going into the last over## we were ahead of the target and needed to just keep our wicket to win.  Farnham Common had been hiding their fastest bowler to the end with Lucy fending off a quick full-toss on the first ball.  With two balls to go## it looked as if we had the match in the bag when a second fast full toss claimed a wicket; this reduced our total to just 270.   Farnham were still in the game…the crowd were on their feet…the umpires fidgeted nervously (unsubjectively of course!)…Farnham could scent an opportunity..but the last ball went wide to provide us with a 4 run victory. 

 

Many congratulations to the girls - great to see them start with such a competitive performance.

Away to Farnham Royal and a beautiful sunny Sunday morning## Max FE our skipper in charge and Farnham selected to bat.

Our opening attack of Kuran and Raphi made a breakthrough in the second over with a clean bowled by Raphi## this was followed by Max C and Noah who all kept the run rate down with FR on 211 at the end of the first four overs## Jack behind the stumps keeping everything neat and tidy especially with the quicker balls. Leo ##Toby and Louis all bowled maidens from their first overs with Toby Mandeville bowling a wicket maiden in his U11 debut. Wickets also came from Will Nettlefield’s over with a good run out## along with another run out from Louis second over## Max Fe kept his overs very tight giving nothing for their best bat to play with## Kuran and Raphi both finished up with a wicket each in the last two overs## leaving us with a score of 242 to beat.
Max Fe had chosen his pairs well and he put out Max C and Kuran to start the proceedings##in their usual style running on virtually every ball and Max finding the boundary## they were looking good## Kuran found a thick edge and was caught by the back stop## Max then tried to send the ball into space with the last ball of their pair## sadly the bat had different  plans and he was bowled. 210 after 4 overs## Toby and Louis started well## sadly Louis lost his wicket twice## but he bounced back to the Louis of old and played two full tosses down to the leg side boundary## Toby looked totally comfortable and always in command playing into space for singles and two’s and also rewarded with a quality boundary. 223 from 8 overs and they llet the square with us now well ahead of the required run rate. Jack and Noah came in and on we were not disappointed ## Jack had the lions share of the strike but backed up like a king by Noah## Noah scoring off the few balls he faced with a super strike into mid wicket for two## Jack punished their bowlers finding the boundary on three occasions## they piled on the pressure and left the middle with us ahead of the required score with us on 249 from 12 overs. Leo and our skipper Max FE came in  and sadly Leo lost his wicket## but this didn’t put the pair off## Max FE hit a four from his first ball and they began to clawback their position and then Max FE played like a true pro when their strongest bowler came on. without any prompting he defended then took a single when he chose## this was the end for FR as they were running out of overs## Leo and Max FE put on 14 leaving us on 263 from 16 overs and well in control. Our last pair Will and Raphi  were not content to just to stop at that point and it was going to be a battle as to who would be on strike## Will attacked the ball scoring off nearly every ball as well as Raphi## it was becoming a run fest## Will finding the boundary twice and by the end of over 19 we were on 293 and then Raphi decided to push it even further hitting their big fours and finishing the innings with a six. 319 from the twenty overs.
The boys fielded in the Ballinger style of not giving anything away## backing up and talking to each other. The FR manager commended our boys on their great spirit.

Confident after last week's batting success## skipper Maciver chose to bat first## away against Knotty Green## newly restored to the premier division. Openers Matt Riley and Danny Draper found runs hard to come by## especially against the accurate M Widdowson. First change bowler T Patel struck first though## bowling Matt for 11. With Danny now getting into his stride## and Rollo continuing his rich vein of form## it was a surprise when Danny fell to blinding catch at cover off a shot that looked a four from the moment the ball left the bat. That made it 56 for 2## in the 18th over## and Andy Thompson's second ball dismissal saw the scoreboard register a potentially wobbly 56 for 3. Never fear## Ian Davies now arrived## and gave the now imperious Rollo magnificent support## to the extent that the pair put on 104 for the 4th wicket. Ian may have been the junior partner in the stand## but his alacrity between the wickets## turning singles into twos## was vital. Rollo## after a spate of sixes## chanced his arm once too often## and was bowled for superb 77## with only 2 overs remaining. Ian fell for a gutsy 28## in the final over## as the innings closed on 171 for 6. 

The Knotty Green innings got off to a shaky start## with Nick Adams striking first## and then Will Reid  taking two in his 4th over## one of them to a miraculous diving catch by Andy Thompson. From 18 for 3## Knotty Green recovered somewhat## and took the score to 43 before  Ian Maciver## on as first change## took a wicket in his first over. The game looked as if it might swing away from Ballinger when C Goodwin## after a very quiet start## suddenly unleashed a volley of 6's ( five of them in his 41) and it was a relief when Andy T had him## bowled. That made it 113 for 6## and ten overs left to make 59. The remaining batsmen were not up to the challenge## and they were all out for 143## with 4  overs left.       

Will Reid was the pick of the bowlers## bowing at a good pace downhill. His 4 wickets only cost him 26 - 10 of which were no balls and wides!

Ian Davies## standing in behind the stumps## kept a clean sheet## and Ballinger's fielding## whilst not faultless## looked efficient.

Winning the toss and electing to bat on a pitch which was clearly considerably drier than it was when the second XI played at Widmer End a week ago## Ballinger piled up a formidable total of 223 all out## with the last wicket falling neatly in the last over before tea.  The total was built around an excellent innings of 93 by Graham Salisbury## who played with controlled aggression## putting away the bad balls effectively## and looking in little difficulty.  He was finally caught on the boundary selflessly pushing the total on as the innings came to an end.  An excellent knock.  He was well supported by Freddie Thompson coming in at No. 3## with 22## and David Livingstone at No. 6 with 24.  Quickfire cameos at the end from Monty Thompson and Nick Tegg rounded off a very solid batting performance. 

 

The Widmer End openers started positively## until Tom Petrie claimed a deserved wicket LBW.  While numbers two and three were together## putting on a 50 partnership## it looked as if the home team might have a serious dart at the Ballinger total.  Monty Thompson then claimed a couple of wickets in short order## with his attacking offspin## slowing the Widmer End charge at 86 for three.  No 4## Parsons## looked capable of pushing on but was pegged back for several overs and never quite got going.  Widmer End’s last chance to launch an assault on the target ended in the 30th over when Stuart McGowan came back and bowled Parsons with his first delivery of his new spell## to leave Widmer Ended 118 for 4## with only 12 overs left.  Ballinger managed to take 4r more Widmer End wickets## but couldn’t grab the last two## with the Widmer End innings fizzling out at 146 for 8.  A dominant performance but a shame we couldn’t quite claim the win.

Having lost the toss## Ballinger found themslves bowling first on what looked a perfect strip. In the event## a bowler's graveyard was a better description. Last year's league champions set off at a cracking pace against a weakened bowling line up## lacking a pace bowler. To make matters worse the outfield was lightning fast## although as the innings progressed that mattered little## as the batsmen increasingly chose the aerial route. Although the scoring rate was fast## there was some success for the bowlers## and would have been more had some chances not been put down. Andy Thompson held a fine catch on the boundary## and a clutch of LBW's contributed to Bourne End being 213 for 7## with 32 overs gone## so Ballinger were certainly still in the game at this stage## with spinner Monty Thompson having taken two wickets in his first over at a cost of 4 runs. His next three overs cost 49! Similarly## Nick Adams## coming on for his second spell## had respectable figures of 1 for 42 off 9 overs.His last over went for 32.... The cause of this destruction was M Shah## who after a watchful start produced a batting masterclass## making a fine 102 before being bowled by Ian Davies## with seven 6's and 10 4's in a fifty ball innings. Bourne End's final total was 337 for 9 - a record score against the club!

After savouring an excellent tea courtesy of Jan Kerry## Ballinger set about the monumental and probably unlikely job of scoring 338. Any chance of making an interesting game was immediately scotched by the Bourne End skipper setting a run saving defensive field from the very first over## together with the early loss of Rollo McIntyre## very unfortunate to be adjudged LBW## as he was the in-form big hitter most likely to keep up with the requisite scoring rate. Danny Draper batted beautifully for a well deserved 53## and there were useful contributions from Matt Riley (21) Ian Davies (26) and Jonno Lacey (21)## but the target was increasingly out of range. Monty Thompson  did his  best with a very aggressive 54## and was undefeated when the overs ran out## with Ballinger short of their target by 117!

Arguments against the concept of "win/lose" league matches are strengthened by this type of match situation. The real winner of the day was Jamie Kellock in producing such an ideal batting surface. We just need a ground twice as large to complement it!

On Sunday Ballinger took a trip out to the lovely part of the county that is Bledlow Ridge

The team had elected Dan Battman as captain and he immediately lost the toss. An afliction well known by other Ballinger captains.

Fortunately  the hosts elected to field which meant Dan got his wish with The Waggoners having first knock.

A pair of Edwards opened up for Ballinger and put on an excellent 46. Edward O'Doherty was the victim of a freak dismisal when he was caught off a delivery bowled whilst he was still asking the umpire for a guard.

Cyrus and Toby then rattled up 35 with some great shots plus some brilliant running between the wickets. Toby in particular was very positive.

Harry and Tom W didnt lose a wicket but their indecision when running singles was a reminder to the coach to practice it again in training next week. They also came across Bledlows best bowler in 9 years old Molly.

Noah and Matthew were again a bit uncertain with their singles but Matt made up for this with some great hitting adding another 32 between them.

Harvey and the skipper finished off the innings with another good stand of 26 but with Dan being bowled by the excelent Molly## Definitely no disgrace there.

325 is a formidable total to chase down and Ballinger's bowlers and fielders## well marshalled by Dan## were in no mood to let Bledlow get anywhere near it. The two Edwards set the tone but all the bowlers did well although the coach was suprised to discover that the Waggoners had conceded the same numbers of exytras as the hosts. 

A special mention must go to Noah who took 5 for 2.

We have two wicketkeepers in this age group but neither were available so the team were indebited to Toby who did a brilliant job behind the stumps with only 5 byes bieng conceded.

 

A good win at a pleasant ground with hospitable hosts.

On an overcast afternoon Ballinger arrived at a ground more suited to an episode of Countryfile - badger markings across the outfield and nesting bees hovering above and below the surface of the square. The result being a meadow-like outfield and trampoline-like strip.  

Having lost the toss## Ballinger were inserted on a track that proved bouncy and slow.  The opening pair of Clark (S) and Thompson (F) made a steady start## although boundaries were hard to come by due to the slow outfield.  Clark departed for 17 to one that nipped back down the hill## and Andy Branigan was trapped in a similar manner six overs later## having looked extremely comfortable for his 15.  Meanwhile## at the other end Freddie was coming to terms with the pace of the track and outfield. He was joined by Toby## and together they built an excellent partnership - combining some fabulous boundaries and smart running between the wickets.  The partnership ending with Fred being run out## trying to push the score on## for an excellent 57.  Toby continued to add to his tally## and was ably assisted by an aggressive cameo from Ben (23); a brief flurry from Steve Carter (15)## and a late boundary from Dom (6). Shot of the day - Toby with a superb## classical cover drive up the hill## through the long grass## on his way to an excellent 60.  A total of 205 was above the skipper's expectations at halfway## however with a short boundary on one side## and rumours of some big hitters and darkening skies overhead..... 

Fin and Dom shared the new ball## and immediately restricted the Hampden batsmen to less than 2.5 per over for the first ten overs.  During this period there were changes to personnel at the crease thanks to a run out (Dugdale); a retired hurt## and a wicket from Dom - efficiently removing a single bail by brushing the outside of Ali's off stump.  Due to age restrictions## both opening bowlers were withdrawn from the attack## to be replaced by the spin-twins Thompson and Dugdale. By this time the Hampden skipper had been joined at the crease by Bashir## who had the look of a man in a hurry. Both batsmen struggled to deal with the spin being achieved at both end## however anything loose was being aggressively dispatched.  While Freddie struggled on manfully with a thigh injury## the onslaught from Bashir eventually became too much for the spinners.  In order to change the pace of the game## Fin was brought back into the attack sooner than planned## and skipper Branigan took the ball at the other end.  This partnership proved to be the undoing of Hampden.  Fin's four overs at the death costing a meagre 11 runs## however the real damage was being done that the opposite end.  Having being brought into the attack to relieve Freddie from his toils## and to provide some left-arm variation## the skipper 'tore' into the Hampden batting.  Simply by putting the ball in the right areas and sticking to the old adage## "if they miss## you hit"## Branners mopped up a total of six Hampden wickets at a cost of 33 runs from his six overs. 

Important to mention the general efficiency of the Ballinger fielding - catches from Andy## Dom and Ben. A stumping from the Dude; and a high pressure catch from Nigel to dismiss the ominous Bashir.  A fabulous all-round team win for Ballinger.  Special mentions for Freddie and Toby for their excellent## mature innings; and (obviously) congratulations to the skipper on a spell that would have made Derek Underwood proud....... 

 

Stuart Clark

An efficient and convincing win by 100 runs against a weak Wendover side.  Ballinger dominated from the start.  Batting first## Richard O’Kelly (44) and Max Dugdale (50) started quickly## putting away a series of loose balls very effectively.  The middle order of Rob McIntyre (44) and David Livingstone (47) carried on in similar vein.  Some timely slogging at the end left Ballinger with 232 for 8 declared off only 38 overs## in less than 2 ½ hours## leaving us with 1 ½ hours and 20 overs to bowl Wendover out.   It took only 34.5 overs in fact## when the last Wendover wicket fell at 132## with 18 overs to spare.  Attacking fields were set from the start.  Matt O’Kelly opened with a very effective spell## ending with 1 for 23## bowling straight and on a good length.  Stuart McGowan’s offpsin (2 for 22) opened at the other end.  Theo Reynolds’ 2 year break from cricket didn’t show as he slipped into a good line and length with 1 for 20## knocking over the one Wendover batter to make any headway (with 52).  Freddie Thompson’s legspin (4 for 48) disposed of the middle order## who really didn’t know what to do with it## Max Dugdale executing 2 neat stumpings.  Monty Thompson’s (increasingly fast and flat) offspin nabbed a couple of the last 2 wickets … and off we went for an early trip to the pub.

Ballinger won the toss and decided to field first. Opening bowlers Max Hayes and Josh Field took 4 wickets for a handfull of runs and this was followed but good bowling from the rest of the team with special mention to James Batchelor spin bowling that had Beaconsfield batsmen thrashing at thin air. Fielding was good and resulted in 4 catches and 2 run outs. Beaconsfield amassed a total of 258 for 6 which at the time was probably 30 runs short of a good target.

Ballinger batting was rusty and unlucky but on the positive side James Batchelor and James West were are only not out batsman. The rest of the team were unlucky in finding the same beaconsfield fielder who could catch (Alex)and perhaps were a little to aggresive to the straight ball.

The team was captained well by Leo Wilson and their conduct on the field was superb and i know the lads are looking forward to playing them again to gain revenge for a bit of sledging by their wicket keeper.

So in summary we know it was our batting that let this result slip so on the plus side we know what we have to improve on.

Nearly forgot thank you for the cakes## biscuits and teas Beaconsfield wanted me to pass on their thanks to everyone who cooked and helped.

The Ballinger wicket was is great shape and had managed to absorb the rain and hail that had been sent its way in the afternoon## with some broken cloud and a chilly wind Toby and his team were put in to bat by Cheshams Captain Charlie.

Edward Batchelor took strike and calmly sent four of the first deliveries to the boundary ## his partner Cyrus then took strike and quickly between the wickets with Edward they continued to keep the scoreboard turning over at quite a rate with the pair scoring off every single ball bar one. Total 240 for 0 as they left the square.

Harvey Ward found the boundary three times as well as Matthew Warren who placed a slightly shorter ball between the fielders## Harvey and Matthew put on another 40 between them ## BWCC on 280 for ) after 8 overs.

Raphi and Victor took their place in the middle and Raphi hit his first four deliveries for four each time and some good fielding from Chesham ran the boys out## our first wicket to fall and that was followed by a yorker outside off which Raphi's bat and shoe directed towards his stumps. Victor and Raphi again scored from every single del;ivery bar the wickets## they pushed the team up to 314 for 2 from 12 overs## this was looking like it could be 400 from the innings at this rate.

The Best boys continued to pile on the pressure with 10 from their first over## then sadly a run out slowed them down and then straight back to business with a lesson in finding gaps in the field and they pushed the team up to 334## a massive score in any barrington fixture.

Freddie and Toby came in next and Chesham must have been thinking that not all of the boys can possibly bat## well the misery was about to be compounded as Freddie and Toby caused panic in the field ## again scoring from every ball bar the fall of Toby's stumps## if they didnt find the boundary then they would run ## and just like pairs one and two they also put on a further 40 runs taking the side to 374 for 4.

The Ballinger Mums had provided cakes and crisps and drinks for everyone and the doughnuts were consumed in record time## a big thanks you for this as we know how well received they are.

The umpires defrosted their hands in the warm water from the clubhouse and back to the field.

There were a couple of short shower bursts but the show was going to go on.

I couldnt see how any side could get near this apart from New Zealand## and so the bowling began and Raphi opened and second ball there was a lightening run out by Toby## snd sadly one of the openers took a knock to his arm and had to retire## he was clapped off by the Ballinger players and Raphi apologised and wished him well like a true gent## i have since been in contact with the manager and the boy has fully recovered.

The pain continued for Chesham with nothing being given away by Edward Batchelor## or James Best. Then Edward Batchelor clean bowls the captain last ball of their pair. 205 for 2 from 4 overs.

The pressure continued with great catches by Matthew Warren and Edward Batchelor## a speedy stumping for Freddie from a Victor Grant ball that had tempted the batsman towards the bowlers end## 210 for 5 from 8 overs.

Wickets then fall for Edward Best and Cyrus## tight bowling and lots of dot balls## Chesham are still over 150 runs behind our total. Harvey as usual giving the batsmen very few opportunities to score runs with lots of dots going in the scorebook and Toby sees reward in his forst over with a super run out by Victor. Matthew continues the good Ballinger work from his two overs and then Raphi and Toby finish off the innings with three wickets each bringing Cheshams total down to 228 for 13 from 20 overs.

Chesham were very friendly opposition and our players clearly were some way ahead in terms of all aspects of the game## fielding## batting ## bowling and teamwork.

This really is a very special squad of players and it was a delight to be able to facilitate the match. 

I apologise for waiting a couple of days to post the match report## but i have only just regained feeling back in my hands after what was not the warmest eveing on the Ballinger square.

 

Steve

Another sunny day in Ballinger as we welcomed unbeaten league leaders##Frieth## to the home of cricket. Despite Will & Tom being plundered by the Firsts and top batsman Stu unavailable##the 2s were still able to field a strong side and blood 'new boy' Steve (another distinguishing nickname required ?) Best. Having won the toss the skipper inserted the oppo on what looked like another flat## batting track. Openers Fin & Matt initially struggled to hit their straps but Fin finally found a good rhythm and Matt claimed a wicket due to a nonchalantly taken catch at mid off by debutant Steve. Despite this## it was clear that we needed to take pace of the ball as Frieth were ticking along at more than five an over. Miles took the second wicket in a short spell but Ben D - little Ben ? - also struggled initially to find a good length. The drinks break came at a good time and Freddie## who had already started to slow the run rate## claimed opener Tanveer in the first post drinks over## the Dude obliging## snaffling the catch behind the stumps. Ben was now finding his line and length and conceded only 21 runs from his last six overs## notwithstanding two mammoth sixes## and he and Freddie slowed Frieth down## despite them having seven wickets in hand. An unusually disappointing fielding display was stopping Ballinger taking a firm grip on the game and despite two run outs## Frieth were able to chance their arm in the final overs and a total of 206 - 6 looked a par score and possibly up to 20 runs more than they would have got had the fielding been up to its usual high standard.

After consuming a fine tea provided by the Dude (and Lizzy!)## Ben C - Big Ben - opened with Matt## having been asked to build a solid platform from which the rest of the team could attack. They did just that## starting slowly but gradually ticking up the run rate. Matt## who had found it difficult to pick up the openers## despite one very fine drive through extra cover## perished in the 15th over with the score on 45. Big Ben was joined by Nigel## finally getting a bat this season## and the pair upped the run rate before Nigel had to limp off## having damaged his hamstring. Little Ben joined his namesake and the run rate continued to climb - but so did the asking rate which was up to 8 an over by the time Big Ben departed for a 72 - a good mix of patience and aggression. We then lost wickets at regular intervals as a succession of batsmen attempted to match the required rate and when Pads departed## BWCC required 34 from 16 balls - a tall order. A six from Fin## off his second ball gave a hint of what was to come## but with no boundaries in the 39th over and the Dude departing off the final ball## it didn't look good. 17 to win off the last over and a ninth wicket pairing of Fin and Miles## who between them had only faced a handfull of balls between them this season (such is the strength of 2s batting !). Nigel was frantically strapping on his pads over his jeans and his recently showered and gelled torso. A four and a six from the first two balls produced a great deal of excitement from the pavilion but a single from the third ball brought Miles on strike. He cannily squeezed the fourth ball backward of point for three runs which left Fin needing three from the last 2 balls. A wide eased the pressure and with all the fielders now in the ring Fin drove the penultimate ball down the ground. 

A great win## with good performances from the Bens & Freddie and another top Clark performance (who needs Dad !). Thx to Miles & Dave for officiating. Three wins on the bounce - bring on Knotty Green.

Having won the toss## Holmer Green opted to take first knock## and opening bat Joe Gumb (49) was soon scoring readily## being especially hard on Will Arnold. At the other end Nick Adams was economical## but went## unusually## wicketless. Instead## first change Ian Davies accounted for the first five Holmer Green batsmen## in an impressive 10 over spell of spin bowling## for only 38 runs. In an attack heavily dependent on the day on spin bowing## skipper Ian Maciver also kept the batsmen in check## but he too## also unusually## failed to take a wicket. However## the third spinner## Monty Thompson## after bagging a wicket off his first ball (thanks to a tricky catch by his father) then paid heavily for his next three## and Holmer Green's tail enders were allowed to score too many easy runs## resulting in a challenging total of 185. Richard O'Kelly caught the eye with a couple of smart stumpings.

Opening the Ballinger reply## he also looked good## and in little trouble against Holmer Green's  experienced and dangerous opening bowlers## whilst Danny Draper## admittedly with precious little of the strike## struggled at the other end. First change bowler Salter immediately slowed the scoring rate## and dealt Ballinger hopes a blow by bowling Richard in his third over for 29## with the total 37. New batsman Andy Thompson was rapidly into his stride## and with Danny now locating the middle of the bat## prospects for a win looked good. 99 runs were on the board when Danny fell for 35. The next three wickets added a measly three to the score## and 102 for 5## with 28 overs gone saw Ballinger in trouble## with Andy out for an excellent 27. Ian Davies and Monty Thompson had barely troubled the scorers## but Jono Lacey battled hard for his 19## and debutant Matt Petrie looked assured before perishing LBW for 9. When they were out in quick succession## the only target left for Ballinger to pursue was 139 (75% of the opponents' score) and this they did by the skin of their teeth!

I thought Windsor Rugby Club in January was cold until last night umpiring on the Ballinger square. Oliver our skipper wanted to bat first and his wish was granted when he lost the toss and Knotty Green put us in to bat.

Freddie and Archie set us off to a great start against some accurate bowling and both boys finding the boundary and taking us up to 224 from their stint in the middle. Edward Batchelor our other U10 partnered with Kuran and both boys found the boundary on three occasions each and drove our score up to 257 from 8 overs with neither of them losing their wicket.

Finn and Casper came in as our third pair and against some more accuarte bowling got off to a good start## Casper finding the boundary with a 4 and then a mighty 6 but their opening bowlers found gaps assisted by the gusting wind and managed to bowl out Casper## but not until he had added lots of runs## Finn also rewarded with a boundary they headed back to the shelter of the pavillion on 267## a very respectable total.

Max and Thomas settled in but only after Max mistimed his first delivery and let the ball hit the three wooden poles behind him## mistake out of the way and the usual flurry of singles from the pair along with two 6's from thomas## the boys strode back with the team on 292 from 16.

Last in were Oliver and Tim and Oliver hit a top edge which was well taken deep in the covers## the boys didnt find the boundary as often as usual## with Oliver finding the gap twice## they played well and pushed us well past 300 and left the field with the side on a very respectable 314 for 6 from 20 overs.

Knotty Green had taken quite some time to bowl their overs and it was looking like we were going to really overrun## so quickly out and on to the field.

Oliver and Edward took the first four overs and were giving very little away## but wickets were not coming## but KG were only on 212 after 4 overs## so they still needed 103 to win## not easy with our bowling attack.Thomas picked up a wicket in his first over with his good line and length## Kuran only went for 1 run from his first over ## so pressure was mounting## Thomas and Freddies next overs were not so pretty and mistakes in the field were giving KG a glimmer of hope. More tight bowling from Archie and Tim started to rein in on the KG optomism and Casper struck with an inswinger that knocked off the bails followed by another middle stump for him from his last ball## so two wickets to Casper## Finns over was rewarded as well by a great catch by Freddie from his second ball## three wickets in the spell and KG are on 234 after 12 overs.

The cold seemed to be causing us some catching challenges and we were missing some simple run out opportunities which normally would be sucessful. Tims second over resulted in one Bye and smart fielding by Finn thrown straight to Max who dispatched the bails for a run out## Freddie bowled a tight over replicated by Kuran who had been delivering unplayable pace and bounce## finn was then again rewarded by a catch by Tim at first slip## KG are on 231 from 16 overs.

Dot ball bowling by Archie in the last spell followed by another wicket from a Casper ball caught by Oliver## Thomas provides a further catch for Casper in Mid Wicket and the pain for KG continues## Kuran bowls the last over## 5 dot balls and a single and the match ends with KG on 237 for 8 from 20.

Thanks to the mums and dads who braved the cold and for helping tidy up afterwards. We finished much later than i like to ## so i again apologise.

There are several lessons to be learnt from last night and we have to make sure that we stop making basic errors## stronger teams will punish them and we need to make sure that whilst having fun we also play as a diciplined unit.

Sunny morning and i have finally thawed out.

 

Steve

It is unfortunately the lot of any successful side## that others will look on and covet it's stars. One immediately thinks of the Chesham United team from the 1968 Amateur Cup Final or more recently Bale##Modric## Carrick## Berbatov just a few names that spring to mind who have been plundered from more talented teams by those with more sway. So after three successive victories it was little wonder that the likes of Stuart & Fin Clark found themselves in the first team this weekend. A more general player shortage exacerbated the situation and the 2s turned up shorn of many of its regular bowling options and looking a shadow of the side that beat Frieth the week before. Once again winning the toss the skipper opted to chase## believing it would be hard to defend any total below 250. It's probably best to gloss over what happened next. Suffice to say that despite an improved fielding display the bowlers## and there were seven of them## never got to grips with the sloping Knotty Green wicket. Only little Ben went for less than a run a ball. There were some highlights though. Newbie Andy Berry took a great catch## on the run in the deep to dismiss Raza for 108 off just 54 balls & also claimed a run out with a slick piece of work at extra cover. Byeless keeping from the Dude on a difficult wicket to keep on was also creditworthy (in contrast there were 19 in our reply). Both Bens bowled well## 13yo Phil claimed his first senior wicket and the skipper added another to his season's tally. Never down hearted ( not sure that's true -ed ) the skipper rallied his troops over tea convinced Ballinger could make a good fist of the batting. The Bens had bowled 20 overs but gamely stuck their hands up to open. They started spiritedly before Big Ben departed to the Greens opening chucker. Wickets fell regularly at one end after that## but Little Ben remained there at drinks## looking set on 41 of our 81-4## and having been joined by Nigel. Disaster struck first ball on the resumption and with it all hopes of an unlikely victory as the skip's batting targets were revised downwards. However Nigel and Pads combined for a fifty partnership that saw us past the halfway target. Nigel unfortunately had to retire for the second successive week when## having battled with a rib injury throughout## it was that hamstring that laid him low again. He was quickly joined by Pads whose carefree innings was terminated by the Miles finger. Andy Rowe## watched by fiancée and his new born## batted with typical verve and secured us maximum batting points whilst the skipper held up an end. When they departed it was left to another debutant Scott Devereux and young Phil to ensure we weren't bowled out. Thanks to Miles ## who once again had to umpire both ends## and in particular to Scott & Andy for enabling us to field a full team. Next week Downley will face the backlash !

Neither side went into this match fielding a full strength side. The outcome indicates that visitors Ley Hill have far greater resources to call on than Ballinger.

The home side won the toss  and opted to take first use of a pitch tailor-made for batting. Their start was disastrous. Stuart Clark## on his overdue first team debut## played down the wrong line to a straight ball## and without further addition to the total## Rollo McIntyre## having driven a confident shot to mid-off and called "no"## stood still without realising he was an inch outside the crease. A swift return to the keeper saw him on his way. 7 for 2 in the second over!  Andy Thompson and Ian Davies then set about a serious rescue task## to great effect. They had put on a fifty partnership against the opening pace attack in fluent style## aided by a spate of no-balls from P Ottaway## at five an over## when S Daluwatta and S Dasanayaka took over## with the result that the runs dried up## and Ian then fell## caught## for a valuable 20 off Dasanayaka's first over. David Livingstone. also on first team debut## went in his second over. Carlton Siddle now joined Andy. They repaired the damage## but batting was now a struggle## with bowlers well on top. To get the scoreboard moving risks had to be taken. Only three short of what would have been an excellent fifty## Andy was caught on the boundary## and then Carlton going for a quick second run found that he was not as fast as he had once been. That made it 120 for 6## with only six overs left## and the innings petered miserably out for 136## a total around 100 runs short of competitive on such a good pitch.

And so it proved. Ley Hill openers B Ford and C Petersen were never remotely troubled## apart from one or two half-chances. Skipper Maciver switched his bowlers regularly## but without success. Both batsmen had scored fifties in impressive style## and a ten wicket defeat appeared inevitable until Andy Thompson scooped up a diving low catch## to send back Ford## off Dom Brown## with only three runs left to win.

The difference in class between the sides showed clearly why Ley Hill deservedly are unbeaten league leaders. Quite apart from their batting## their ground fielding and throwing showed Ballinger's up in a bad light - the age profile doubless a major factor! 

Thanks are due to Ian Maciver who managed to provide and organize teas## with significantly greater success than willing his team to victory! Also to Liz Thompson for once again coming to the rescue as scorer.

A complete team performance by our eager U9s.

Ballinger chose to bat so that we could provide two spare fielders to the visitors. James and Josh put on a very strong platform of 47 runs## followed by Maxim and William Curry adding a solid 20 together (net of a run out by our loaned fielder - Josh Field - nice!). Charlie and Skipper Kit then came in and pushed us onto a nice round 300. This coach was enjoying watching the good calling and watchful batting against the GX best two bowlers. Noah and Joe then added a further 27 runs## with some wonderful power hitting from Noah in particula-##and then Elliot and Thomas eased the total up to 348 (net of a last ball bowled-out of Elliot). So a very handsome total indeed## helped by 25wides from the oppposition## but a credit to our discliplined batting. Losing only two wickets was really impressive.

We knew that accurate bowling would guarantee the win## but I was really proud with the way all of the bowlers and fielders applied themselves. We chatted about keeping the wides down and fielding energetically (not giving overthrows and pressuring the batsman). Kit marshalled his bowlers and fieldsmen efficiently## and what was heartening was hearing all of the players encouraging each other. That is a sign of good team - boys. Charlie opened with some accurate fast bowling and Joe held up the other end very tightly. Two wickets in these overs## meant GX did not get off to a flier. The rest of the bowlers all followed suit; Josh## Thomas## Noah## Maxim and Elliot gave the batsmen nothing to hit and even kept the extras down. William Curry (not in list above because late to get added to register) bowled two really impressive overs with 2ov 2w for 3runs. James and Kit then bowled four overs## completely strangling their two best batsmen (batting again). The visitors could only make (net) three runs from these four overs. 

It was a complete performance. Well led by Kit## the team all played for each other and had fun## as did I. Well done all of you. 

Sharkey 7.6.15

Sunshine at last and in the abscence of our Cup Captain Sebastian## Max stepped up to take the helm.

I wanted to use this game as an opportunity for the boys to work on tactics## field placement and keeping the pressure on for 20 overs and the boys all excelled themselves with Max managing the field well and putting them under pressure.

I think the statiscics speak for themselves## we clearly were a completely different class to our opposition who were brave at everystage of the proceedings and it probably isnt fair to disect the game in too much detail## however i must point out this is one of the biggest score differences i have seen over the last few seasons.

The side also had four of our U10 squad## many of whom are becoming regulars in our U11 side.

I saw commitment from the boys when we were put in to bat## a head never went down when we occasionally lost a wicket## usually because of a batting error rather than strong bowling. Particularly strong batting from Victor and Jack who were placing the ball all over the ground and also Tim who i havent seen smile quite so much whilst he found the middle of his bat several times. The other boys also delivered some excellent strokes against difficult bowling which on many occasions struggles to find the strikers end.

With so much depth in the side all of the boys scored losts of runs and in true ballinger style they stole singles and two's at every opportunity## good exaplles being Toby##Will##Casper##Raphi and Max.

I wish i could show their strike rates as well as it clearly shows a side playing as one - Great Teamwork.

We left the field on 344 - Our boys could have relaxed## but Max kept banging the drum and made sure that every over was going to count.

Please do take a moment to look at the bowling statistics - i will try and put it in a bit more perspective for those who werent there -

Runs Scored from batsmen off the 120 balls - 14   Extras 24 

The boys did not give anything away right to the end## in fact there were only 3 rund scored from the last four overs.

Everyone bowled a good line and length and our spinners Victor and Will were super creating catching opportunities. Casper's first ball was knocked up for Max to catch## Finn took two other great catches## then Victor picked one up in Mid Wicket## Raphi's quick fielding and great throw into Jack gave us a run out. Raphi just bowled straight with a good line and length and was rewarded with three maidens with one wicket.

Max decided that Jack should keep wicket and his decision was clearly a good one## Jack was solid behind the stumps picking up any wayward leg side balls and pinging the stumps at any sign of the batsman being out of his crease## we clearly have a talented keeper and batsmen in Jack who is new this year to the club.

What impressed me today was the way the boys focussed on every ball and kept the pressure on right to the end## it is so important that they continue to learn and develop as circketers and understand the tactics involved. 

Well done to the parents for making sure the boys were punctual## and thanks again to the players who behaved as true gentlemen.

 

Steve

Ballinger batted first on a a sunny evening and it felt like summer had arrived at last.

Our opening pair went all out from the start. Unfortunately it didn't pay off as the boys lost five wickets in their four overs. Edward O'D went for all-out attack but had taken too many risks too early. At the other end Edward Batchelor scored a useful 16## including a cracking straight drive. The next pair## Charlie and Matthew## steadied the innings but we were only on 199 after the first eight overs which seemed below par. Then Victor and Jack came in and got the scoreboard moving. Victor played an excellent innings and was joint top-scorer with 20## including four boundaries.
