Next in were James and Harvey who kept things moving forward.  Raphi and Toby were our last pair - they really put the pressure on the opposition with some impressive batting and running. They added 15 in their first over## including three consecutive boundaries by Raph(as he joint top-scored). Their four overs added a total of 40 without losing any wickets and taking Ballinger to an innings total of 278. It looked to be a competitive score.

in the break the boys and match officials were treated to a lovely tea and some delicious scones and cookies. Thank you Nicky.

Ballinger put GK under pressure from the start with a combination of accurate fast bowling and very good fielding. Edward O'D got the first wicket in the second over## and from then on GK lost wickets at regular intervals. Edward B## Victor## Toby ## James and Raph all took wickets. Raph was the pick of the bowlers  with 4-4 off his three overs## including two consecutive Bowled in the last over. Toby was a very mature and able captain throughout.

Ballinger's fielding was excellent too and put Great Kingshill under even more pressure leading to seven run-outs. Jack's wicket keeping was super and was one reason for this. The ground fielding was excellent . Our boys took some good catches too## led by Harvey who took two catches. 

As a result GK's innings limped along and never really got going. They briefly got ahead of 200 with their fourth pair## but they slumped back as their last pair were torn apart by Toby and Raphi's excellent bowling and the team's fielding. Great Kingshill finished on 179 having lost 17 wickets in total. We had won by 99runs after an impressive all-round performance.

The sun was shining on what looked like another Ballinger road prepared by Jamie.

 

Ballinger won the toss and elected to bat## hoping to amass a large total in order to put the opposition on the back foot. Max Dugdale (104* off a mere 55 balls) and Rob McIntyre (58 retired off 49 balls) set the tone of the innings within the first 5 overs with 49 runs coming from them. Rob later retired due to having cycled 90 miles the day before## leaving Max to continue the big hitting. It was at 150 runs when the first wicket fell of David Livingstone (5)## who hit the ball to a fielder calling for a sharp single## unfortunately only to be sent back and left high and dry by Max Dugdale.  Paul Branigan (33 off 45 balls) did not miss the opportunity to score some runs. Max reached his ton a few balls before drinks and was persuaded to retire and not go for the record held by Will Smith. Andy Rowe was next to cash in with a few well timed shots piercing the mid wicket boundary to speedily get him to 34 of 22 balls## to later lose his wicket to a very good caught and bowled. Hamish (12* off 6) and Matt (3* off 2) came in to finish the innings off before the customary declaration before what was a wonderful tea from Debbie Sim. This left Ballinger with 264 for 3 of only 31 overs (bowled at leisurely pace).

 

Ballinger took to the field with about an hour to go until 6 (when we would have 20 overs left). We decided to open with the new recruit Clive Starr## with Stuart McGowan’s offspin in order to bowl as many overs as we could before 6. It was a steady start for BBC Bushmen. The first wicket came in first change## Matt O’Kelly’s second over when what looked to be their key batsman nicked off to Max behind the stumps. Matt got his next ball to jag back to crash into the batsman’s stumps## sending him back for a duck.  He continued to bowl with excellent accuracy.  Stuart later picked up another wicket (off a full toss – often a wicket-taking ball!) caught## to a good sliding catch by Hamish Sim (showing the wonders of a youthful side). Miles Devereux was brought into the attack and got the ball turning into the batsman causing them some issues## but unfortunately didn’t pick up a wicket. Monty Thompson## Hamish and Matt came into the bowling attack to try and get the remaining 6 wickets that were needed to win the match. A very attacking field was set with everyone around the bat or in the slips. There was an amazing catch made by Rob off Matt’s bowling at silly mid off## diving to his left like an athletic youthful teenage boy. But unfortunately our best efforts with the ball and supremely attacking fielding were not enough to get the remaining wickets## resulting in a draw - with BBC Bushmen 84 for 8 - 180 runs short. 

 

However a rare achievement for a Ballinger side was accomplished - we did not drop a single catch!

 

 

Monty Thompson

A chilly start to the evening and a side made up of five U10## four U11 and one U9. Supported by several parents without whom none of this would ever happen## having said that if they had known what the weather was going to do i think they would have brought the cars next to the boundary with engines running.

Our Skipper Louis and the boys were put in to bat and we seemed to struggle to get going against their accurate opening bowlers whom pushed the boys back behind 200 ## not something our sides experience very often## but credit to Joe and Jai their opening bowlers who were very accurate. Harvey and Freddie did their best against them and the Casper and Daniel began to steady the ship## but again they faced very tight bowling## but they both found the boundary and the pressure started to swing back in our favour and they proudly walked back with us in positive territory on 209. 

The bowling again remained very strong and Matthew along with our skipper Louis kept the ship steady and were the last boys to lose a wicket with a run out## but they had pushed us up to 218 from 12 overs## Edward and young Charlie took to the middle and really started to push the score forwards giving us some hope of a defendable total with Edward finding the boundary and Charlie scoring four singles amoungst his contribution## clearly another future star## the boys left the square with us on 251 from 16 overs## not bad at all. Kuran and James marched on and again faced the openers## and they again batted well and pushed us to a very respectable 278 from the 20 overs.

Our bowlers started well with Kuran opening with Daniel## Daniel took a great wicket bowling their skipper out first ball. Louis moved the bowlers around and we kept their score down## however wickets were not forthcoming and despite amazing fielding from Matthew## Harvey and James we were not being given the run outs despite great speed from Freddie behind the stumps.

We kept them to 257 from 9 overs and then Casper bowled a maiden and they seemed to start to feel the pressure## we only gave away another 16 runs over the next six overs so we were level at over 15 but with no wickets falling we had a big job to do and as the tempreature dropped to minus 7 celcius and the light began to leave us Jai their opening bowler came to the crease and found the boundary four times and also hit a six## so with strong hearts the boys battled on and despite losing the match played the best they could in difficult conditions against a strong side.

Once again thanks to all of the parents especially Nicky for wizzing accross Berks and Bucks to get Freddie to the ground and to Lara for helping us by letting Charlie step up at the last minute## he now no longer needs to step up as he showed he is more than capable playing at this level.

 

kindest

 

Steve

Cup fever hits Ballinger. A team of teenagers + wily old Richard## Stu & the Dude took on the might of Holmer Green and sent them packing with a bloody nose. In what must rank as one of the best performances by a Ballinger senior side## the 2s with the help of ROK beat a HG side containing not only several of their first team but also amongst the League's best batsman & bowler ( Watt & Jermain).

Starting briskly Richard and Monty had taken the score past 50 off 6 overs before both perished to the bowling of Jermain. Stu quickly followed but Max & Freddie set about rebuilding the innings until Max made it 4 down at the halfway stage with the score an impressive 77. A repeat of that would see BWCC safely home. However wickets continued to fall at regular intervals despite cameos from Ben & the Dude. Jermain was brought back into the attack and we were all out for a par score of 126 with a valuable 17 balls still remaining.

Will & Freddie opened the bowling and a direct hit from the boundary by Matt ?## despatched opener Little. However Watt continued to keep the score around the required rate helped by Purkayasta until the latter was also run out after a mix up. Rickett & Watt batted sensibly## taking the score into the 80s with 7 overs left## so a little over a run a ball was needed and HG now looked favourites. However quick wickets from Fin & Matt unsettled them although Watt still remained. The crucial moment came with the score on 104 when Watt drove Matt down the ground for what looked like six runs but was well taken on the boundary by Dom. Jermain hit Matt for six off his first ball to leave them just 15 short but then fell LBW next ball. The 15 they required off the last over ## bowled by Dom## never looked likely and as they tried three times to take 2 runs to fielders on the boundary - and lost three times victory was ours## much to the delight of the shivering Ballinger supporters on the boundary.

A real team effort## well orchestrated by Stu. Don't miss the Quarter Final at Ballinger on 23rd June versus Bourne End 2nds !

Rory won the toss and elected to bat.  He and Jack formed the opening pair and started a good confident innings on behalf of the Ballinger U12 boys.  Jack was bowled early by a deceptive ball which turned in## catching the batsman out and the bails fell.  Harry as batsman three join Rory and the pair were both retired at 33 and 32 respectively## both marking the end of their innings with fours.  Max achieved a very quick and respectable 21 runs before miscommunication led to a run out.  Batsmen five and six## Henry and Ben took us nicely through the remaining overs## bringing the Ballenger score to 153.

Rory took the first Chalfont St Peter wicket in over two as the clouds rolled in and the sky started to darken. The visitors dug in and played some excellent cricket; Good shot placement and intelligent batting put the match at even footings.  Over seven saw an inspiring performance from Harry who took four wickets.  The umpires took some time at the end of Harry’s over to discuss the progressive onset of bad weather but the decision was made to continue.

Ben took another wicket in over eight.  The next three overs were bowled as the rain began to fall. Harvey and Jake bowled an over each with good line and pitches leading to 3 runs from the two overs.  What turned out to be the last over was a maiden from Archie## as dark skies and rain called an end to the match.

The Ballinger U12s had played a disciplined## tight and cohesive match## showing genuine teamwork and support## fine performance.

Noteworthy other than those mentioned above were Henry’s keeping and some light-footed and impressive long barrier stops on the boundary from Jamie…He even got his knee down!

Ballinger 153 for 4 from 20 overs

Chalfont St Peter 63 for 6 from 12 overs

Ballinger Win

Beautiful day saw the under 9 's play our first tournament of the season.

Our first game was against Redbourne - we won the toss and batted first and amasses 72 in 8 overs with the highlight the partnership between Josh and William snooks battering 28 in two overs. The bowling was just as good with Leo Wilson bowling his leggies and starting us off with a maiden over##Redbourne struggled to 27 off 8 overs with all the bowlers bowling tidy and tight.

Second game against Old Albanians saw them bat first and once again struggled to 27 off 8 overs. Highlight of the bowling was William Yarroll taking 2 wickets in his over## but all players bowled well. Chasing we got off to a steady start with the run rate with Josh## Max and William S upping the run rate at the end of the innings (very proffesional). Yhe boys totalled 45.

Semi final meant playing the big hitting Tring who batted first and certainly went after our bowling but the lads kept plugging away and the highlight was Josh last over## only conceeding 3 runs and with Max lightening reactions stumped Trings top batsman who must have been given permission from England to guest for Tring. Tring total was 79 runs.

The boys batted well and totalled 47 runs and in my opinion it was the best we batted with only 2 wickets given away funnily enough the first and last ball of the innings. Will Yarroll hitting an unbeaten 19 inthe middle of our inning was the highlight along with Max's first ball attempt at a six that went miles in the sky and was just caught on the boundary edge that shot silenced the crowd.

The lads were brilliant and a couple of coaches came up to me during the tournament to say how they were impressed with the way the lads played.
Washed out## despite everyone's best efforts.

It was a bright but bitterly cold night at Ballinger on Tuesday when the Waggoners were hosts to the boys from Chalfont St. Peter. Actually the game was due to be played away but when their manager confirmed the fixture he thought it was away and just by chance the ground was available. Sometimes you do get lucky.

 

Toby M and Dan are in charge tonight and had laid their plans carefully during their maths lesson. The first part of the plan went well when Toby won the toss and put CSP into bat.

 

Spin from both ends is an unusual way to start a game but Edward B and James didn’t disappoint with Edward getting 1 wicket. Edward also combined with Freddie to complete an excellent run out. The skipper had decided on the 1 over spell route much favoured in T20 these days thus not giving the batsmen chance to settle. Unfortunately this also confuses the scorers and umpires.

 

Dan and Teague were next up with Dan his normal economical self and debutant Teague getting an early lesson in the cost of bowling wide.  Toby and Harry bowled well with Harry getting an excellent bowled. A double dose of Tom’s kept CSP under the cosh with Tom W getting 1 wicket. Noah then charged in from football end a cleaned up 2 CSP with his quick## accurate bowling. Teague’s back and bowls much better and CSP are chasing a score## which means more rum outs courtesy of Edward and Harry. Dan gets a wicket in his next over## so does Tom W## Noah’s back and cleans up their best batter and Dan finishes with a maiden.  6 run outs shows a high standard of fielding

 

CSP have finished on 226 

 

Tom W and James are first up for The Waggoners and with sensible defence## and running between the wickets## get the home side in the positive. Harry and Teague are not so lucky with Harry out twice but we’re still in the positive. Teague’s debut ends without him being dismissed so good start. Noah and Tom R are next up with Noah setting about the CSP bowling with gusto. Unfortunately as fast as he was scoring Tom was getting out but they managed to get the score up to 234 so we’re now in front. This of course means nothing in “pairs cricket” but the skipper has loaded the back end of the innings with his big hitters. He and Dan are up next and with some excellent running between the wickets get the score up to 257 with just an unlucky run out of Toby. Freddie and Edward are last pair and Freddie is in top form. 23 off 16 balls and with some well-taken runs the pair add 43 taking the home side to a very impressive 300.

 

It was another good all-round performance from the boys with some excellent fielding on what was a difficult night to be standing in the outfield. Well-set fields by Toby and Dan## good ‘keeping by Freddie and a generally good standard of bowling contributed to keeping CSP down to 226. We need to work on keeping number of wides down.

 

The batting was fine with all the boys playing to their strengths. If they’re not a strong batter then singles and defending their wicket is absolutely key in this form of cricket.  Well done the skipper for getting his batting order right.

 

For me these evenings are simple as all I have to do is arrange the toss## provide a ball then stand back and watch from the umpire’s chair. 

 

Thanks to Lara and all others who helped with food and providing an endless supply of tea to keep the supporters warm. Thanks also to all those who turned up to watch. It is appreciated to hear the boys receiving a round of applause when they do something well regardless of which side they are on.

C & L have been put in the wrong league and may of their players were experiencing "hard-ball" cricket for the first time. Therefore coming up against a decent Ballinger side wasnt what they needed for their first game. 

The boys were clinical but made sure they played the game in the right spirit which was good to see.

The stats are shown but they will distort the end of season figures

Toby R ran the game like clock work.

 

A gentle opener for the boys with tougher games to come

Downley appeared to have escaped the overnight downpours elsewhere (including Ballinger) and after a half hour delay## waiting for sporadic drizzle to peter out## Ballinger## having lost the toss## took the field. The bowlers soon found the ball taking on the characteristics of a bar of soap## and the fielders slithered about on the soaking grass## regularly ending up on their back-sides. Faced with such handicaps## they did well to keep the scoring rate modest. The first wicket fell to Will Arnold in his fifth over## clean bowled## and next over it was Nick Adams' turn## winning an LBW shout against the dangerous Priestley. Even the prolific J Cox was unchacteristically quiet## and the run rate proceeded at an unspectacular 3 runs an over. Evan Webster took over from Will## and kept up the pressure## so that by drinks at 21 overs## Ballinger could congratulate themselves on a job well done## under trying conditions## with the total 61 for 3. Thereafter## unsurprisingly## the batsmen## notably Cox## upped the rate## and it was with great joy that Evan held on to a boundary catch to dismiss Cox for 49. But further success eluded the bowlers while Martin and Stone put on a fifty partnership for the 7th wicket## which ended with both of them smartly stumped by Richard O'Kelly (completing a trio of stumpings - did I miss the jug???). Ian Davies bowled another pleasing 10 over spell## with 3 for 45## with both Nick and Will chipping in with two apiece. 

Given the strength of Ballinger's batting line up on the day## a target of 180 was definitely on. Openers Matt Riley and Danny Draper appeared to have been paying close attention to the new-look England approach## and boundaries started to flow at a remarkable rate## with neither batsman appearing to have any difficulty. It came as a surprise when Danny risked playing across the line## and perished LBW##with the total 48 in only the sixth over.  Worse was to follow. 48 for 1 was soon 60 for 4## Matt (30) caught behind off a lifter## Richard mesmerised second ball by the sight of a hookable "gift" delivery## and Ian Davies caught for only 2. Rollo McIntyre and Jono Lacey steadied the ship## and managed to keep the scoreboard ticking over nicely## but at 91## Rollo was caught for a well made 32## including two trademark sixes## and with his departure one felt that Ballinger's hopes were subsiding fast. Jono nicked one to the keeper soon after## having batted well for 16## but Nick and Ian Maciver clung on to see the score reach 135## but when Nick went for a brave 15## the end was nigh. All out 144 represented a seriously disappointing performance after such a good start. This was a match that was eminently winnable## even though we had by far the worst of the conditions.

It was a pleasant reminder of the "old days" in village cricket## when a number of the Downley players joined us in the pub after the match## for a few pints.

Freezing cold on Tuesday now I’m going to get electrocuted during a thunderstorm. The lot of a cricket umpire is not often fun.

 

Firstly we have to negotiate with the groundsman who has a direct line to the BBC weather centre and is convinced we wont get a game in so removing the covers is an action of great folly. Having finally overcome that hurdle now it’s about explaining to the opposition that reducing the game to 15 overs per side is a good idea and we might actually finish before Armageddon arrives.

 

At last we get under way and Edward Best is in charge tonight. Once again the captain wins the toss (they need to give the senior captains a bit of advice) and puts GX into bat. 

 

Harvey and James B open up and are on the spot straight away with Harvey getting 1 for 0 in his 2 overs. Pretty impressive stuff.  James B executes a sharp run out and GX are 2 in the negative at the end of 1st pair.

 

Edward is completely unconcerned by the reduction in overs and has his fielders and bowlers ready at every change.

 

Cyrus and Matt are next up and bowl pretty well although Matt gives away 9 wides before confusing the batsman with a straight fast one. So at the end of 6th over GX are still behind the rate.

 

Then the skipper goes for a double dose of Edwards with spin from one end and the fiery Ed Batchelor from the other. The skipper gets bashed around a bit but fiery Ted is not to be resisted and takes 2 for 1 in his 2 overs including an excellent catch by Jack behind the stumps.

 

Ollie## Toby M and debutant James Batchelor all have one over to finish the innings and do an excellent job for their skipper with James B taking 1 wicket with a Shane Warne quality delivery.

 

GX close on 229

 

Tea proves a problem as its so good we cant get then boys out of the pavilion. This umpire is now looking apprehensively at the sky which is looking black on the horizon.

 

James B and Cyrus open up and Cyrus is out 1st ball. He and James recover and with some good running edge the score into the positive. Jack and the skipper are in and Jack unfurls some sumptuous shots with Edward giving him as much of the strike as possible.  The Waggoners are now in front of the GX total.

Fiery Ted is now at the crease with Ollie and they rattle along adding 22 for their pair.## with Ted striking 4 excellent 4s. Toby M and young James are the next pair and again push the score along with both playing a couple of excellent shots for 4. Harvey and Matt are the final pair and cause a bit of chaos with their running between the wickets and Harvey clubs a couple of 4s to help The Waggoners finish on a very comfortable 293.

 

The sun is out and is shining on a very happy umpire.

 

Thanks again to all the parents who helped with the excellent tea and gave their support

The sun finally broke through and our combined cup and league fixture was about to commence with Oliver at the helm who chose to bat first on the Beaconsfield astro strip which is well known for its bounce. Archie and Sebastian opened up and managed to take four quick runs off good staright bowling## we then lost three wickets from the next twelve balls with a bowled##catch and a run out and we were into a strange area of negative runs## not somewhere the boys visit very often## Archie found the boundary and Seb was cut off twice at the boundary but managed to run two's##but nine from their last over pushed us back to par.

Next in Oliver and Tim who should start pushing us northbound## another run out and dot balls and then finally a boundary## another difficult over and Tim has his off stump nicked by the round red thing## into over three and we are back under the 200 mark and the boys are starting to read the ball better and with eight from over seven and ten from their last over they leave the square with us on 216.

Finn and Will take their positions and and taking their time they dont lose a wicket and take sensible singles and then they both find the boundary. Putting the ship back on course we move forward to 234 from twelve overs and the Beaconsfield bowling doesn't seem to be letting up with excellent fielding from their boys.

Kuran and Toby take to the square and a direct hit from a fielder caught Kuran short on what looked like an easy single ## but the boys kept their heads up and shoulders back and Toby played straight and was rewarded with four singles and a two## Kuran found the boundary and the pair took the score up to 252## starting to be defendable.

Thomas and Max took their places and Thomas played carefully and then struck out with a six a followed by a four## Thomas sadly lost his off stump fom a decent inswinger and Max finished off the proceedings with a four## the boys pushing us on to 269 for 8.

I could sense that our side were gelling even better than last year and this was about to be witnessed by the spectators.

Oliver opened the bowling five dots and a single with swinging quick good length balls## Kuran took the second over and was delivering at a very awkward height and at quite a speed and was rewarded by a great catch by Thomes. Oliver's second over changed the shape of the match with him only going for one run and the loss of three wickets## the first an amazing pick up by Finn  at deep in the Gulley with a direct hit at the stumps## this was followed by Oliver smashing th stumps and another run out by Max. Beaconsfield were iin all sorts of trouble on 185 after three overs## Will Nettlefield was played well off the batsmans legs and then the boy was caught## the wickets just kept coming## Thomas came on and dot balls a two and a nick off the legs in the air and Max caught around the leg side with two other fielders homing in should he have not been in position.

Archie rewarded second ball by a catch by Sebastian## BEaconsfields strong batsmen find the boundary a couple of times and Thomas and Will go for a few extras. Some amazing fielding by Tim stopping boundaries and Sebastian was a fraction of a second from making the most amazing diving catch.

Totally committed in the field and under the constand direction of Oliver ## with all of the boys making sure there were no gaps in the field.

Tim was rewarded first ball with a fine edge straight into Max's gloves and Finn rewarded with a straight bowled from his first over. Beaconsfield are on 210 from 12 overs and Olivers side are clearly in total control. Toby's fiorst over is a wicket maiden followed by another wicket for Sebastianand Beaconsfield are going backwards being on 199 after 14 overs## Toby's next over he gives only two runs away and Sebastin bowls a maiden## they are on 201 from 16. Archie switched ends for his second over and wasnt finding the lift he had from the other end but he tried to adjust## Kuran then bowled four dots a single and hit the stumps and Oliver hit middle stump two balls on the trot furtehr adding to Beaconsfields problems. Kuran finished off the proceedings with them only reaching 207 for 14 from their 20 overs.

Well done to all of the boys## through to the next round of the cup and back up the league table.

Thanks again to the parents for all of the support .

 

Steve

Sunshine and a lovely grass strip## Beaconsfield chose to Bat and Toby opened up the bowling ## followed by James## and straight away we could see that Extras were going to be the star of the show with Beaconsfield not doing too much with the ball## a tidy over from Edward Batchelor gave Ballinger a small piece of relief and whilst our bowling was very respectable we were not being blessed with too many wicket opportunities despite quite a few edges. Beaconsfield continued to tick along adding four or five an over then the second breakthrough for Noah in over 10 from a catch at square leg taken by Harvey## with the hosts on 246## then a wicket for Harvey and an unplayable ball from Edward best claimed a wicket## finally pressure being applied and a slow down on the run rate## moving into over 14 and they are on 249 for 5 . Wides from a few of the boys and not the sharpest fielding was punished by the Beaconsfield batsmen who remained alert with clear calling and with no other wickets until overs 19 and 20 for Toby and Edward## a superb pick up by Noah in the field ## speedily dispatched to Edward Batchelor gave us a well deserved run out## however Beaconsfield by now had pushed their total up to 297## a big score on this wicket with such large boundaries## again extras had been the star of the show.

Toby put in Edward Batchelor and Noah## who unphased by the Beaconsfield openers played with the upmost confidence and scored eleven from their first over## nine from the second##ten from the third and seven from their last one## we were well ahead of the game on 237 when the pair left the square. All that was needed was patience and no risk taking.

Jack and Victor were faced with tight bowling and excellent fielding which resulted in two well administered run outs## so they were taking the runs off as quickly as they were adding them and the side remained on 237 after eight overs## a target still achievable. Harvey and Daniel were again pinned down by straight careful bowling and sadly played around a couple of inswingers and they left the square on 219.

James and Edward Best took up their position and James played a text book cover drive for 4  and also found gaps for singles and two's but luck was not with them and a run out and a couple of catches undid their hard work## pushing the total to 222 from 16.

Unphased as all Ballinger players Toby and Freddie walked out and asked me how many runs they needed from each ball 3.16 to be precise to win and proceeded to try and achieve it. Sadly Beaconsfield had work out their plan and set a defensive field. As happens when just in and trying to send the ball skywards one can miss time it## notwithstanding that the boys facing a great left arm slow medium found the bondary and lots of other runs## putting on 39 but sadly losing 36 with the loss of 6 wickets leaving the side on 225 from 20 overs.

The match was played with good spirit and whilst the end result is not very flattering i can say with some experience that in a rematch it could go the other way. Hopefully the end of season play off with give the boys the opportunity to demonstrate my opinion.

Great moments form all of the boys and a huge thankyou to the huge support from all of the parents.

 

Steve

As Esther Williams sang "What a difference a day makes" [yes i did google it] seems an apt song for yesterday## completely different body language and heads held high [except when batting].

Will Nettlefield in his first role as skipper and a side of two U11 and eight U10.

Jacob the Gt Kingshill captain [who sadly was very badly hurt last year in this fixture] chose to field.

First ball first over and the bails fly off. oops## but that was really the only nervous ball out of the 120 that were presented.

Will and Edward Batchelor settled in and pushed the score to 211 from their spell with Great K bowling a decent line and length. Noah and Daniel came in and a young bowler called Tahil delivered a maiden with very difficult lenght balls which Noah defended like a master## Daniel and Noah then picked up their pace and took tidy singles and both located the boundary## all going to plan and then a close run out## but we were still moving on up and the pair returned to the pavillion on 221.

Edward O'D and Edward Best further put on the pressure with good running between the wickets with Edward O going at quite a pace between the stumps## Edward B played particularly well off his legs finding some nice gaps in a well place field. The boys pushed the score up to 245 and James B and Max FE came in ## Max defending the straight difficult balls and punishing the less accurate ones## again with great running## calling and backing up. James B hit three fours ## one being a text book effortless cover drive## without a loss of a wicket they pushed the side up to 273 from 16 overs.

Jack and Toby faced the opening bowlers for their spell and as quick as they were putting the runs on they were having them taken away## none the less Jack found the distant boundary and took lots of singles with Toby who played with a nice straight bat## holding the score the boys finished on 271 for 7 from the 20 overs## a very defendable total on this wicket.

Teas and biscuits provided very kindly by the mums and after Edward O'Doherty ate his own body weight in custard creams we proceeded back out into the field.

The boys knew what to do and Will set about sticking to his plan## a blistering run out second ball from a great pick up dispatched to Jack at the stumps from Toby's second delivery applied immediate pressure. Tidy bowling was to follow from Edward O' and Will then Edward Batchelor struct the stumps and Gt Kingshill were on 205 from 4 overs. Daniel bowled straight and accurate ## Noah hit the stumps from his fourth ball following two dots## Edward Best went for a single and then Toby fired a pick up to Jack and another run out from Toby's second over. Max FE sent down five dot balls and then a no ball and Kingshill are on 205 from 8 overs## their mountain was getting higher.

A Maiden from James Best added to their woes along with few runs being given from the boys second overs## but no further wickets were to fall between over number seven and the 18th over## however strong fielding and superb keeping kept the score well away from our total. A delightful Caught and Bowled for Daniel## a straight bowled for Will## closely followed by another chance for Will## sadly he had to dance around the batsman and didnt quite hold on to the catch and in the last over from Edward Batchelor a great caught behind from a find edge by Jack.

Great Kinghshill managed to get to 238 for 7 from their 20 overs and with a fairly matched side we held them back with sensible batting## strong accurate bowling and committed fielding.

Well done to Will and the boys and a thank you to the Great Kingshill coach Chris who was full of encouragement to his boys.

 

Steve

A sunny evening at a beautiful ground saw Ballinger play a rearranged home match away at Amersham. James Batchelor won the toss and decided to field. All the bowlers bowled well but the highlight was our aggresive throwing which netted 6 run outs. Max hayes was on form behind the stumps claiming his usual stumping. Our catching could have been sharper but its something to work on. I cant really single out any star performers with the ball because all the lads bowled well and restricted Amersham to 236 for the loss of 10 wickets.

After a drink of squash please note no cakes (so far we are winning the league on teas and cakes) Ballinger opened the batting with James West and Joe Yalden providing a steady start with no major problems. Enter the two big hitters in James Batchelor and Josh Mandeville who put an impressive 48 run partnership with James hitting a powerful flat six off his last ball. This allowed the next partnership of Charlie and Max to just punish the bad ball##Harbin and Kinura followed suit with Harbin after an early scare soon finding his form with some impressive boundaries. Finally Josh Field and Noah facing Amersham best bowlers played with great maturity seeing Ballinger home in comfort.

A very enjoyable match to umpire well done to all players.

All the bowlers bowled well but the highlight was our aggresive throwing which netted 6 run outs. Max hayes was on form behind the stumps claiming his usual stumping. I cant really single out any star performers with the ball because all the lads bowled well and restricted Amersham to 236 for the loss of 10 wickets.

Finally Josh Field and Noah facing Amersham best bowlers played with great maturity seeing Ballinger home in comfort.

A good toss to win on a drying wicket so Ballinger were in trouble from the start## which was compounded when Big Ben was caught at slip in the first over. Little Ben repeated the shot two balls later## the ball just failing to carry##but then settled down with Andy to build a platform . Ben fell with the score on 41 but Matt then joined Andy and the pair were still together at drinks with the score on 85## and a target of 200 seemed achievable - a decent score given the conditions. However wickets began to fall at regular intervals after the break curtailing attempts to increase the run rate. Andy stayed defiant at one end until the burden of batting with his old man became too much to bear and he departed for a well crafted 61. Useful runs were added at the end along with a useful 10 wides in the final over which gained Ballinger maximum batting points## but left us shy of what was likely to be required.

The rain at tea time 'freshened up' the wicket and breathed hope into the Ballinger fielders. An early breakthrough from Matt## when Miles held on to a trcky catch at mid off## meant a decent start and after three maiden overs## he had 0-1. However runs continued to flow too freely at the other end and Phoenix were managing 5 an over by the time Little Ben claimed their second wicket at 71. The third wicket stand## which saw both batsmen reach 50## was finally brought to and end when after some great work by Matt ## the Dude completed a run out. By now Phoenix had reached 138 and had ample number of overs left to complete the formalities. However Ballinger would not go down without a fight and wickets from the skipper## two from new boy Simon and two more from Matt made Phoenix battle all the way. Matt's 3 for 30 off 9 overs and Simon's 2 for 12 off 5 overs were particularly noteworthy and had the skipper realised the talent he had at his disposal a little earlier## or one or two difficult chances not been spilled## we might not have gone down to a narrow defeat.

Thanks to Jan & Nigel for an excellent tea & scoring respectively (the right way round methinks) and Miles for umpiring once again. Despite the defeat it was good to get a game in after last week's disappointing wash out. A trip to Aylesbury awaits us next week.

Waddesdon decided to bat first in a game that was always going to be affected by rain. Indeed## the drizzle started soon after the start## and continued on and off## with increasing intensity## but play was only interrupted by one short break## in the eleventh over. The bowlers had to contend with a ball that grew ever heavier and soggier## so it was to their great credit that by the nineteenth over they had reduced Waddesdon to a shaky looking 66 for 6. In the absence of Nick Adams## who had failed to read the clear email instructions of the Team Secretary (and indeed possibly due to the lamentable lack of a fixture card this season?) and had gone to Ballinger## the opening over was bowled by Joe Hankinson## who struggled to find line and length bowling downhill. Nick arrived## grumpy even by his standards## in time to bowl the second over## and cheered up when it proved to be a maiden. Happier still when this second was a wicket maiden## courtesy of a blinding slip catch by Matt Riley. Grumpy again though when he was told he had to re-park his car## blocking someone in...

Meanwhile Evan Webster had replaced Joe## and was soon bowling exceptionally well## and also pulled off a fine catch## giving Nick his second victim. Evan's 7 over spell of 4 for 20## two of them clean bowled## was most impressive. Unfortunately for Ballinger## their serene progress was badly held up when Waddesdon's No 7 Chaudry and 8 Irwin decided it was time to start batting sensibly## and put on 72 for the seventh wicket . The fielders did not help themselves by dropping several chances## although given the conditions perhaps that was unsurprising. Eventually## skipper Maciver could stand it no more## and brought himself on to wrap up the innings with 4 for 12 in 3.2 overs## by which time the scoreboard read 165 all out## in the 39th over.

No sooner had the players reached the pavilion than the heavens opened## the thunder rolled## and half an hour later the pitch looked like a lake. Which was a shame## since the Waddesdon total looked in reach## given the strength of the Ballinger batting line-up. But we thought that last week too!!

Home against an unbeaten Marlow## and Marlow lost the toss and our skipper Toby chose to put Marlow in to bat## with our regular keepers unavailable Toby threw on the gloves and set to field. 

Toby was ultra organised and was in control of the team from the start and with Edward O and James Bathcelor opening nothing was being given away and Marlow were on 210 after 4 overs but hadnt lost a wicket## giles and Teague both changed this with Teague finding middle stump and then James Garner recovering the ball at gulley and sending an accurate throw to Toby leading to a great run out. Marlow are now 216 from 8 overs with the loss of two wickets.

Wicket maidens for Finlay and James G started to put the Marlow boys under immense pressure along with a maiden from Noah## this included a great run out facilitated by Tom##Marlow were now down to 208 for 4 from 12 overs.

Another maiden for Noah and Tom and Finlay both bowling five dots and a wide each and then Guy Jarvis in his first match bowled a wicket maiden## so Marlow remained on 208 for 5 from 16 overs.

Tom's second over came with two wickets ## both hitting off stump## Guy then bowled five dots and a single and Edward O and Noah finished the session off with continued pressure and Marlow finished on 207 for 7 from 20 overs.

Following the consumption of vast quantities of squash and biscuits and flapjacks the side were briefed and we opened with James G and Guy## James found the boundary and the boys didnt lose their wickets and pushed us up to 219## already 12 ahead of our target## but this is barrington rules so anything can happen.

Tigue and Tom faced some accurate bowling which was hard to get away and managed to defend it well and then two catches a run out and a stright bowled and we were back to 201 ## Tom and Tigue had managed some swift singles during their spell. Marlow's confidence now boosted they felt a victory was now possible.

Giles and Finlay defended well and managed to hold our position which is what had been asked of them## we were now on 200 for 6 from 12 overs.

Toby and James Batchelor took to the square and Toby found the boundary and James played three wonderful drives which all went for four## the boys didnt lose their wickets during their spell and pushed the up to 235 from 16 overs.

Edward O and Noah took to the square and both found the boundary and added a further 29 rund from overs 17/18/19 ## Marlows quality leg spinner came on for the last over and tempted Edward with a great ball that found his off stump## never detered the boys run four more singles and finish the innings on 262 for 7 from 20

A very convincing win against an unbeaten side## great fielding## very few extras and sensible play from all of the boys. 

Well done to the skipper for making my role easy## congratulations again to Guy on his debut and wicket maiden.

Thanks again to Louise and Mark for arranging the teas and for ensuring the clubhouse was shipshape when we left.

 

Steve

Having lost the toss on another sunny Ballinger evening## the skipper tossed the ball to Fin who promptly demolished the stumps twice in the first over. When sub fielder Hamish caught the other opener in front of the pavilion off Matt## Bourne End were reduced to 6 for 3 off the first 2 overs ! The rebuilding of the innings was further set back when their skipper collapsed in a heap as his knee gave way - a feat that he was to repeat several times during his three trips to the crease. By the time Will Reid and Freddie Thompson were asked to bowl## the opposition were trying hard to post a defendable score but by the time these two had finished their innings was in tatters - All Out for 110 in 17 overs.

Stu & Monty opened the innings and by just rotating the strike and picking off the bad balls##the score rattled along at a run a ball## and they always looked comfortable. Monty edged one on to his pads and the umpire's finger was up before the fielders could appeal. Debate raged as to whether the noise was louder or quieter than than the edged catch to Steve in their innings given as a wide !

It mattered not## as Andy joined Stu and the runs were knocked off with nearly five overs to spare. Thanks to Richard for umpiring (he wasn't the deaf one !) and for the good support on the night. Well skippered Stu and another really impressive team performance. The SemiFinal awaits on July 7th.

Sunshine at our beautiful ground and our league fixture against an unbeaten Gerrards X## with Oliver away Sebastian took the helm and we were put in to bat.

Opening with Raphi and Edward Batchelor we thought we would get off to a flying start## but GX opened up with two excellent bowlers who gave literally nothing away## the boys pushed us forward to 214 from their four overs with Edward finding the boundary## not a bad start then Finn and Casper took to the square## again super bowling from GX but Finn managed three 4's in one over and Casper backed up superbly and scored a two and a single from the few balls he faced## 233 from 8 overs and we are looking in pretty good shape.

Tim and Seb came in and scored runs from every ball bar three in their spell and in the very warm conditions welcomed the water break when GX changed their keeper over## taking every opportunity in a very calculated way they put GX under immense pressure and without losing a wicket drove the score up to 278 from 12 overs## all we needed to do now was protect our wickets and play the bad balls.

Thomas and Kuran faced some more accurate bowling but with the loss of three wickets left the square with us back two runs on 276.Archie and MAx strolled in and managed to score from every ball bar two## which sadly were wickets## none the less Archie kept the ball low for three great fours and Max with luck on his side was dropped from a leg side glance## but he too found the boundary. The pair pushed us up to 303 for 7 from 20 overs.

Refreshments and cakes very kindly provided by Edward's mum Caroline and with a very respectable score one would have thought the rest would be a stroll in the park## however this was a very different side to the GX from last year.

Opening with Finn and Edward GX attacked from the very start with their U10 player finding the boundary with ease## a breakthrough catch from Finn's second over eased the pressure## but GX were on 234 from 4 overs## the match was far from over.

Charlie Berens came on to replace Finn who had to head home and Raphi and Thomas came in for their spell## GX happily taking singles and the Raphi takes off stump for his first wicket and then two consecutive run outs for Thomas ## one of which he dealt the fatal stumping## some dot balls and then Thomas bowls the batsman from a slower yorker## GX pushed back to 232 from 8 overs.

Tight bowling and a catch from Caspers first over followed by Casper hitting the stumps and a wicket also for Tim and GX are only on 238 from 12 overs. Seb and Kuran begin their spell and Seb gives very little away## and first ball of his second over is nicked by the batsman into the hand of Charlie who is fielding at fly slip## Seb then hits the stumps followed by a shorter ball from Kuran which is caught by Archie at mid off.GX are on 244 from 16 overs## so a difficult game for them to win ## but the last pair didnt give up and we were punished by three no ball 4's ## but Archie hit the stumps and then two catches ## another for Archie at mid off and one for Max behind the stumps. 

GX managed to push up to 260 and whilst a convincing win it was the toughest opposition so far this year and should we have been sharper in the field we could have held them back a further 30 runs or so.

Big thank you again to Caroline for the match teas and looking after the clubhouse and also to the parents and boys for helping me tidy up afterwards## again i apologise for the late finish.

 

kindest

 

Steve

It seems customary to start with a comment on the weather so here goes:  Not great.

Winchmore Hill won the toss and elected to put Ballinger into bat. 

Our opening pair Jack and Rory started with real purpose## Jack hitting a 4 off his first strike.  The duo continued in this fashion## Jack retiring on 32 having also achieved the game’s only six.  Harry joined Rory until Rory was bowled out## just four short of the magic 30.  Harry retired on 32 finishing on a well-placed four through midwicket. Henry was next in and saw out the innings## partnering with Ben and Harvey## eventually concluding with Jake.

Ballinger 155 for 5 off 20 overs

Winchmore Hill’s opening batsmen were clapped on and rose to the daunting task of facing Harry## who was taking the first over. Henry (WK) set himself almost at long stop and waited for Harry to fire his first six balls down the crease.  The game was underway with a maiden over.

Rory and Harry kept constant pressure on the batsmen keeping the run rate down.  The first wicket came in the fifth ball of the fifth over## Harry dismissing the batsman for 1 run.

Jack and Jake were the next bowling partnership;  Good communication and excellent fielding from their team mates again kept pressure on the batsman.   Jack provided both a catch and wicket in the seventh and ninth overs respectively.

As the team gained momentum## confidence grew and the gathered (and by now## freezing)## parents   were witness to a solid and cohesive team performance.

Harvey and Ben took a wicket each and a maiden by John in the closing stages of the game galvanised Winchmore Hill into what would become the last stand of the innings:  Jamie stepped to the crease##  and with six law-of- physics-defying bowls## two wickets fell.  I’m unsure who was more surprised## the batsmen who were defeated by the angles achieved after the pitch## Jamie who seemed to serve up a plethora of unreadable balls## myself## ideally positioned behind the stumps to witness the spectacle## or his team mates who shared in Jamie’s elation.

What a way to finish the Ballinger innings and the game.

 

Ballinger 155 for 5 off 20 overs Winchmore Hill 73 for 7 off 20 overs

Although it was another lost toss -its just an urban myth that the skipper hasn't won one all season. Nonetheless we were inserted & had to make the best of it. Although it was a young side it contained a decent line up of BWCC's finest and more experienced junior cricketers most of them with at least 3 campaigns behind them. Marcus & Big Ben led the way against a tight Aylesbury opening attack and a side that had won its last three matches. The pair took the score along to 39 in the 12th over before Ben took a chance too many. Tom then joined Marcus and the run rate began to tick up but Marcus##who had rotated the strike superbly## walked down the wicket and was stumped. It was a feature of our innings that it took a while for most batsmen to find their feet but all eventually got in and started to score well## only to perish soon after. Tom was run out after a mix up with Ben## new boy Kamal looked set and was beginning to really hit his straps when he perished and the same was true of Duggers (Little Ben to regular readers) and Miles. However the score kept rolling along and the skipper pushed things along at the end with help from Matt and a score of 193 for 9 would have been worth at least 225 back at Ballinger such was the size and length of grass of the outfield.

The new ball was entrusted to Matt & Duggers and both found a good line and length right from the start. Whilst Ben strangled the batting from one end## Matt was removing them at the other - as Tom & Big ben shared four catches off his bowling - his venomous short ball accounting for two of them! When Duggers held on to a fiercely hit cover drive## Matt had his fivefor. Tom then clean bowled their sixth wicket with the score on 71 and the game seemed close to a conclusion but there were still 24 overs left and with our opening bowlers taking a well earned break## Aylesbury's 7th wicket pair began to rebuild. No further inroads were made as the score began to climb and they remained in touch with a run a ball needed. Those present then witnessed a spectacular catch from Tom at cow corner## who having initially misjudged the flight of the ball turned his back and began to run back towards the boundary. He then caught the ball ## arm outstrectched above his head## one handed in the back of his hand whilst running away ! An incredulous batsman ( and 2 umpires and 10 other fielders ) watched in amazement - but the dangerous Ferguson was on his way back to the hutch. Matt & Ben were then recalled and wrapped up the rest of the Aylesbury innings without too much resistance.

A really satisfying team performance after a winless month## with most getting some runs and time in the middle## eight catches## another good spell behind the stumps from The Dude##a top notch fielding display & all topped off with Matt's 7 for 55. Once again thanks to Miles for umpiring. Lacey Green next up## and Captain Kerry will be looking for a similar effort from his legion.

Visitors Aylesbury Town were doubtless overjoyed to win the toss on a sunny afternoon and a pitch that looked a batsman's paradise. But they were one down with only 6 on the board when Nick Adams saw Will Smith## keeping wicket ##take a good catch in his second over. Alas## that was soon forgotten## as the batsmen almost immediately started thrashing the bowling to all points. Acting skipper Andy Thompson tried to stem the flow with frequent bowling changes## but to little avail. Evan Webster## having seen his first delivery despatched for six did well to clean bowl Aylesbury's other opener for 26 in the same over## but by this time they had 102 on the board## with only 16 overs gone. Quick running## taking singles where there should not have been any## plus a badly dropped catch all added up to an increasingly bad day for Ballinger## but just when a total not far short of 300 looked on the cards## Carlton Siddle had the rampant S Ashraf caught for 89## and suddenly the game changed as he and Ian Davies started to get a firm grip on the scoring rate## catches were held and wickets started to fall. Will caught the eye with a couple of smart stumpings## and Aylesbury were now struggling to post a competitive total. Both Ian and Carlton ended up with four well-earned wickets apiece## as the innings closed on 206## with five overs going begging.

Even with a much changed side## this target## on such a good wicket## should have been well within Ballinger's range. Yet within three overs they had lost two key batsmen. Danny Draper fell LBW to only his second ball## and Stuart Clark## after a sumptuous cover boundary followed by a towering 6## was well caught - an all too brief cameo. This poor start was rapidly put right as Will Smith and Joe Hankinson started to tear into the opening bowlers## but Will's stay was all too brief when he was caught in the slips for a rapid 18. Joe was now joined by Andy Thompson## and the scoring rate dipped considerably with the arrival of first change bowler W Mohammed##who had Andy fighting to connect with his away swingers. But it was Joe who was to be his first victim## clean bowled off by a superb delivery## having posted a most impressive and hard hitting 46. Jono Lacey had no answer to the same bowler## and it was now Ian Davies who joined his skipper in what was starting to look a difficult bid to win. Andy## after his early struggles## was just starting to score more freely when he was caught for 21. 117 for 6## but still 15 overs left## and our hopes lay with Ian## batting freely but circumspectly and Carlton. Together they took the total to 146## when Carlton edged to the keeper. Ian departed nine runs later for a patient 22## whereupon the innings rapidly disintegrated## 159 all out.

Thanks are due to Jamie Kellock who stood in as umpire most efficiently## and to Nick Adams whose provision of a much appreciated tea took him a lot longer than his stay at the wicket! By and large## the bowlers came out of this match far better than the batsmen. There thoughts in the pub afterwards that perhaps we should ask Jamie to stop preparing batsmen- friendly strips and start helping the bowlers!

It was pouring with rain at 5 but that moved off by six so we managed to play this top of table clash. Ollie was stuck in traffic so we were lucky to have Matthew keen to play instead and Charlie to be sub fielder for the opponents. Freddie won the toss and chose to bat.

Ed Batchelor and Leo opened but got off to an unlucky start as Ed was runout by a direct hit on the second ball. They recovered well and took the score to 211.   Louis and Will came in next and showed some solid defence against some accurate bowling taking us to 224. The middle order of Toby and Harvey and then Josh and Mathhew all tried to get the score board moving but kept losing wickets at regular intervals## mostly bowled or run out.  Freddie and Ed O'D were the last pair and played very positively towards the end. This included a fantastic pull for six into car park by Freddie followed by a four off a no ball. But he and Ed  O'd both got carried away losing three wickets. We finished on 258 but it was disappointing we had lost 11 wickets. 

Tea was provided by Jess which was much appreciated by everyone. Thanks

It was always gping to be a hard score to defend. We started really well with the two Eds bowling fast and accurate. They each took a wicket and pegged back Wendover's openers to 200. Wendover's second pair got the scoreboard moving and they slowly pulled ahead from then on. Our boys bowled fair enough without taking wickets. Edward B pick of bowlers and I was pleased how accurately Toby## Josh and Leo bowled. Wendover's fourth pair took them ahead and they finished on 295.
Sadly KG couldn't organise a side or a date so we have claimed the points
C St Giles couldnt get a team out for either of the dates offered so we claimed a wlakover

This re-arranged fixture was moved from Ballinger to Amersham just so it could be played but it isnt really a hard-ship visiting Shardeloes on a lovely evening.

The boys were ready to rock and roll early and tonight's skipper## Noah## had laid his plans carefully. Having lost the toss he was pleased when Amersham chose to bat. He opened the bowling with James B so a seam and spin combination. This was effective when Noah took a wicket with his 3rd ball. James bowled a maiden from tghe other end. Noah though was going down the 20/20 route of not allowing the batters to settle and immediately changed bowlers at both ends

Guy and Tom R took over and conceded just 8 runs between them in 4 overs## with each getting a wicket in their second over. Thus Amersham were only on 193 at the end of over 6. Noah rang the changes again by bringing on Tom W from one end and debutant Kit Sharker from the other.Once more this was an inspired bowling chjange with the boys conceding just 9 runs between them and Kit proving a real handful for both batters and Dan behind the stumps. A wicket with the 1st ball of his 2nd over was just reward.

Very warm conditions and once all of the parents eventually found the ground hidden behind the thick lush hedgerows we were asked to field first.[so much for sat nav]

Edward started off in a friendly and generous manner allowing a couple of byes and then as his generosity began to wane and with his fourth ball he smashed the top of off stump## Harvey followed from the other end and again gave very little away. four from his first and then just a single from his second over## Ollie Norton joined him with five dot balls and an extra## chenies on 207 from 4 overs.

Tom bowled nice and straight and was hit for four from a short of a length ball and then was rewarded by razor sharp fielding from Edward which delivered a super run out. Victor was blessed with a catch from a top edge first ball## with Victor turning it with aparent ease## then three unplayable dot balls from a confused batsman## the spinners mandatory boundary and then middle stump from a gracefully floated ball## two wickets in his first over.

Noah came on with his great line and length bowling which gave him five dot balls followed by Ollies second over which the batsman only managed one single from## Chenies are on 206 from 8 overs.

Skipper Max now came on with his left arm over action and only gave them an extra and dot balls## followed by Leo's great length bowling which went 5 dots and a wide## BWCC again giving nothing away in the field. Victor on for his second spell and its a wicket first ball with the turn baffling the batsman.

Dylan in his first match of the season was thrown the ball by the skipper and bowling his first competetive over this year went dot## straight bowled##dot##straight bowled##dot dot## so a double wicket maiden and cheers from all his fellow players and the third pair leave the square with chenies on 197 from 12 overs.

Second spells for Leo ## with him going for just one bye##Tom hits the stumps with his third ball## much to his delight## Noah gives nothing away again and his rewarded by a catch at deep midwicket by skipper Max who eventually held on to the ball like a winning lottery ticket## Dylans second over he goes for just three runs and then a nother wicket in the form of caught and bowled## what a day for him## Chenies now on 192 from 16 overs.

No more wickets were to fall for us as Toby now out of the keeping position which had been taken by Victor## bowled two decent overs along with Max and Edward## walking from the field for refreshments with Chenies on 212 from 20 overs.

Fully refreshed Edward and Ollie opened the batting and Edward playing well against some slow and low bowling he managed four boundaries from his stint with Ollie## the pair didnt have much to hit at but pushed us into positive territory despite a wicket and run out so we were on 207 after 4 overs## just 5 short of our target . Harvey faced all six balls of his first over and scored 12 from it then Noah came into action as well and the pair pushed the team on to 239 with four boundaries for Harvey and one for Noah## we were well in front.

Dylan and Tom with instructions from the skipper not to lose their wickets played perfectly ## defending and taking safe singles## not losing their wickets they pushed us on to a commanding 247 from 12 overs##winning a match is often about playing the situation you are in and Dyland and Tom did exactly that -well done.

Leo and Max came in with the same thoughts in mind and with Max able to punish two wayward balls to the boundary and further growing the lead to 260 from 16 overs.

Victor and Toby came in and didnt lose a wicket and both boys found the boundary rope with a particularly well timed and seemingly effortless drive by Victor## the boys added a further 21 runs from their spell and walked off the square finishing off a very convincing win.

The fielding was a good as i had witnessed all season with the boys always in the right fielding positions## leaving very few gaps if any.

Well done to Max and the boys## a big thank you as well to Victor who stepped in a Matthew unfortunatly had to withdraw at the last minute due to illness and we wish him better.

 

Steve

A hot summers night at Ballinger and several dehydrated boys arrive straight from school matches. an important fixture as we continue our rise to the top of the table.

Wycombe chose to bat and Tim and Oliver open proceedings ## not many chances from the first four overs## but a tidy maiden for Tim## Oliver finding pace and length but most balls well outside off and the temptation not being taken by the HW openers## HW finish on a respectable 220 from the first four overs.

Oliver brings on the spinners and what a great decision from the skipper. Will getting a run out from the first ball## three dot balls and then a caught and bowled and next ball a floater into the safe hands of Sebastian## HW down to 204## Sebastian is turning the ball and they cant get near it and last ball of the over it goes around his bat and hist the stumps## Will then bowls dots and a single and Seb bowls five dots and a single## so HW are 203 from 8 overs.

Max and Kuran take the next spell and Kuran takes the stumps out with his extra pace ball## followed by a shorter ball straight to Oliver. Max bowls nine dots and gives a a four and a no ball## the pair keeping HW down to 215 from 12 overs.

Edward## Archie and Finn come on and give almost nothing away ## a great run out Will throwing in to Finn from Finn's bowling and Archie bowling with great accuracy rewarded with a hit on middle stump. HW 223 from 16 overs.

Edward and Finn add to the dot balls with their second spells and then Oliver sends the spinners back on to finish the innings## a stumping at lightening speed from Jack followed by an Oliver Webb run out## Seb takes the last over and again quicker than Bruce Lee ## Jack removes the bails again## so HW reach 233 from 20 overs for 11 wickets. 

The boys consume the jam doghnuts and juice and then Seb and Tim open## putting HW under immediate pressure with their desire to score from every opportunity## but there was an element of care and the pair proudly walked back to the pavillion with Tim finding the boundary twice with the side on 227## we need 7 more runs to win.

Archie and Max take their place and get 12 from the first over## Archie smashing two well timed fours## target met. Max fell to a very tidy leg break then he managed to strike a full toss to the boundary## Archie followed suit and the boys walked back with the side on 249.

Edward and Will knowing we want a large score differential continue with the climb and score well from each over## Edward running well and driving his fours with his usual grace## Will determined to score from the last ball charged the spinner and was caught with the popping crease some way behind him## great spirit and big smiles from both boys as they leave the square on 272.

Finn and Kuran take their positions and off they go## Finn hitting six fours accompanied by Kuran who also hit three of them## the boys didnt put a foot wrong and drove the score up to 316 from 16 overs.

Oliver and Jack both found the boundary each on two occasions## both boys playing some wonderful shots around the ground and continuing to push our margin up. The boys finished with the side on 339 from 20 overs some 106 runs ahead.

Thanks to all of the boys and the parents## especially Matthew Webb who helped throughout and at the end of the game with the boys and the clubhouse and also to Caroline who very kindly looked after the cups and plates and the dishwasher## it is really appreciated.

It was a long day for a lot of the boys and the club really appreciates their commitment.

 

Steve

A hot sunny evening in High Wycombe saw Ballinger complete a comfortble victory over High Wycombe. William S captained his first game and started off by losing the toss and batted first to be honest with the under 9s this season it doesnt really matter wether they bat first or second.

Max H and Harbin B started powerfully putting on 33 with the loss of 2 wickets both cracking some powerful boundaries.Charlie W and Noah L calmly amassed 21 without losing any wickets## this was just what the team needed.Enter captain Snooks and debutant Tommy T who balsted 40 off their 4 overs with the loss of 5 wickets## this was the most entertaining partnership of the night with both lads attacking every ball with their stroke play and running between the wickets ( a scorers nightmare). Next in James B and Ary P who put on 29 for the loss of 1 wicket## special mention  for Ary who took a bit of sledging from his High Wycombe school mates. Josh F and Josh M finished off the innings with 29 for the loss of 2 wickets against Wycombes 2 best bowlers. So we posted a solid 293/10.

 

Ballinger bowling and fielding was the highlight of the night. Yes we may give away some overthrows but they are so aggresive in the field and always try for the run out and once again claimed 3 run outs.

Ary P took revenge for sledging## taking 2 wickets for 9 runs. Max H took 1 wicket and then displayed his skills behind the stumps. Josh M bowled without luck taking 1 wicket for 7 runs. Harbin bowled quick conceeding 11 runs but had Wycombes batsmen jumping around. Charlie W solid bowling was rewarded with 1 wicket for 11 runs. James B leg spinning is outstanding once again should have taken more than 1 wicket.Noah solid bowling conceeding only 6 runs but he pulled off the catch of the season on the boundary. Tommy T bowling was excellent and caused panic with Wycombes batsmen resulting in 2 run outs. Captain Snooks strong bowling only conceeding 10 runs and finally Josh F claiming 2 wickets for 4 runs. Wycombe total was 236 for 11 wickets. A superb team performance and after the game the lads voted Tommy Threlfall man of the match on his debut for his bowling and batting.

Kingshill won the toss and elected to put Ballinger into bat.  The usual opening combination of Jack and Rory faced an initial onslaught from some talented Kingshill bowlers.   A dropped catch from Kingshill only offered a short reprieve and before long## Ballinger was suffering from early loss of wickets## heightening the pressure of the next pair to make a significant score.  Harry and David rose to the challenge and kicked off Ballinger’s quest to pile on runs## in the limed time afforded to them.  Harry made his maximum## finishing with a four and retiring on 32.  David battled stoically through partnerships with Harvey and Henry until being given out LBW.

 

Ballinger 120 for 8 from 20 overs.

 

Team talk over tea around run rates and fielding meant Ballinger took the field knowing they would need to run a tight ship to defend their total. Fantastic bowling from Jack and Harry as well as two athletic catches from Rory left the teams even-pegging at the halfway point. David took another wicket and Jake## two more off the next five overs.  The teams were still evenly matched; Ballinger had their sights on tight bowling and exact fielding## while Kingshill continued to make quick singles## chipping away at the Ballinger total.  Finally## it came down to the last over; Kingshill needed 4 from the last six balls. Two singles from the first two balls## one of which could have easily been a four## saved by a diving stop from Jake.  The next delivery## compounded by the stress## went wide and was run…….2 runs.  A disappointing anti-climax  to what had been a hard fought match from both teams.

 

 

Great Kingshill 121 for 8 from 19.3 overs

Another magnificent batting pitch## on a fine sunny day. Not a good toss to lose## but alas we did. Knowing Monks Risborough's reputation for rapid scoring it therefore came as a welcome surprise that after nine overs they had a mere 13 runs on the board for the loss of 3 wickets## with the opening attack of Nick Adams and Andy Thompson exerting a virtual stranglehold on the batsmen. Notable in this opening phase of the game was Ballinger's fine fielding. Richard O'Kelly pulled off a superlative diving catch behind the stumps## and Freddie Thompson an equally fine one on the boundary. Would this last? Answer - an emphatic No. Nick conceded 26 off two overs as the boundaries started to flow## although Andy continued to keep the other end tight. Skipper Maciver brought himself on## to see if some spin would change things## but without success. Instead## it was spin from the other end## when Freddie Thompson came on to replace Dad## that was to produce wickets## although inevitably at some cost. Joe Hankinson replaced the skipper## and immediately picked up a wicket## thanks to yet another wonderful catch## this time by Freddie Denison-Smith## and finished a good spell with another off the final ball of the innings. Freddie Thompson's spell of 4 for 50 off 9 overs was highly encouraging## and with Andy's 3 for 20 off 10 it could be said that the Thompsons were having a good day. (But see later!!)

For the second week running it looked as if Ballinger had an excellent chance of overhauling what was really a quite modest target of 184## given the conditions. Matt Riley (especially!) and Danny Draper gave us a confident and rapid start## putting 59 on the board## before Danny missed one from first change bowler Bukhari and was bowled for a solid 18. Bukhari also accounted for Matt## whose tame dismissal caught and bowled for 40 was in stark contrast to his earlier aggressive stroke play. However## the writing was already on the wall## as not long before Danny was out he had faced an over of spin from the second change bowler## Fiaz## on which he could barely lay bat on ball. The trouble started when Richard O'Kelly## seemingly in no trouble at all## was victim of a fine catch## off Fiaz with the total on 82. Whereupon the traditional Ballinger mid-order collapse set in. Collapse is rather an understatement. Annihilation perhaps? 82 for 3 became 92 for 7. This included a Fiaz hat trick## accounting for Joe (caught). Andy T (golden duck- neat slip catch to a good ball)## and Monty T (golden duck## deciding most inadvisedly to pad up## and paying the penalty). So## no## the Thompson family batting was not up to their bowling! Sanity returned via an excellent stand between Ian Maciver and Freddie Denison-Smith which put on 43 for the 8th wicket## and showed that the game could still be won. But## sadly## Freddie who had batted stylishly## albeit mostly on the defensive## was dismissed by another caught & bowled## followed by Ian## LBW amid scenes of near hysteria by some of the fielders## for a valiant 20## whereupon the innings gently subsided to 140 all out## just enough to secure the 75% bonus points (we trust!). A feature of the innings was the Monks Risborough fielding. They held some quite spectacular (even improbable) catches## yet their ground fielding was sloppy in the extreme - a massive contrast to Ballinger's. 

So## yet another story of a game that got away. Time for a win ???

We were playing away on Sunday morning at Marlow’s busy ground by the River Thames. Unfortunately one of the lad’s had an accident so we were only nine players.

Edward and James Batchelor opened the innings.  James## an under -9##  had an unlucky start as the keeper took a difficult catch running backwards. After that the brothers put together a really good partnership. Edward scored freely with five boundaries in a commanding 27 no## our top scorer. James played a supporting role but also cracked a boundary in the last over.  A great start## 232 after four overs.

Dan and Jack came in next. Marlow’s top bowlers were on. Sam## one of the fastest I’ve seen at this level and a wily legspinner. It was a stern test for Dan and Jack and they both defended really well against excellent bowling although each was out once## Dan bowled and Jack stumped.  In between they cumulated a few runs and took score to 241. Mathew and Harvey were in next. Both played  quite well although there was hesitation and a mad run-out. Edward O’D and Jack batting again were the fourth pair. Ed was on the charge from the start and was bowled early on. His lofted drive later in the innings was quite a shot even though it didn’t quite reach the longest boundary. Meanwhile Jack played a great innings of 14.

Our final pair were Toby (with 14) and Freddie(10). They played another excellent partnership against strong bowling. The only drawback came when Freddie was deceived and stumped off the leggie in the final over. We had finished on 293 after an excellent allround batting performance.

We would need to bowl and field well as we were one fielder short. I wasn’t to be disappointed and everything went well …at least for the first 19 overs. The standard of bowling and fielding were very high. Toby rotated the bowlers cleverly. Everyone’s bowling was accurate although the first pair defended well. Wickets started to fall from the fifth over onwards. Against their second pair Ed O’d bowled a wicket maiden Jack got a sharp caught and bowled and Mathew got a wicket first ball.  The third pair were undone by the Batchelor brothers. Ed’s bowling was really accurate all day as he took 3-7 off three overs - pick of our bowlers. James got a first wicket in this age group as Jack took another excellent catch at mid-off.

Marlow’s last pair came in with the score on 228## needing 65 to win.  Their leading batsmen came in: Sam and George.  Sam was impressive## a very attacking batter and his dad a former England captain held in awe by our team. Toby and Ed initially kept things under control and Toby got Sam out caught in the penultimate over.  At the start of the last over Marlow were on 251## 42 short## and Ed O’D  was keen to bowl.  But Sam was on the charge## cracking boundaries around the ground and unsettled  our bowler. It was nerve-racking with four fours and a couple of no-balls going for 27 runs.  What a crazy over !

Fortunately we were in such a good position from our excellent all-round performance that the last over didn’t alter the result. We had won by 14 runs. Phew## what a relief! Well done boys.  It was super to see everyone contributing##  such a good squad and playing with good team spirit.

When Captain Kerry left Ballinger on Saturday he was slightly confused when he saw 4 of his players heading off in the opposite direction. No amount of waving or horn tooting could change them from their route. This was the start of a very strange afternoon.

On arriving at Lacey Green scouts were sent out to look for the missing quartet to no avail. Eventually a call elicited the information that they didn’t know where they were but they would be at the ground in 15mins.
By now the skipper had been forced into joining his opposite number on a trip to the square to carry out the rather pointless ritual of tossing a coin. Why bother when you know you’re going to lose - again. Sure enough with the toss lost The Green elect to bat. Who wouldn’t when you know your opponents have only got 7 players. As we amble back to the pavilion he asks if we would mind taking part in a short memorial service for a mate of one his team. Not believing his luck Captain Kerry obliges with the 7 players he has. Another few minutes wasted. Surely the boys would be here soon. 
 At about 1.50pm we finally have to take to the pitch. Finn is given the dubious honour of bowling the first over. The Green is one of the bigger grounds we play on so trying to cover lots of space with just 5 outfielders was going to be a bit of a problem. The rather portly gentleman on strike rather liked the idea of so few fielders and swung lustily at Finn’s first ball and it duly raced to the boundary. He did this 4 times more during the over achieving a 50% strike rate. Dom is on at the other end and manages to bowl a tight enough line to only concede a couple of wides and then the rest of the troops turn up. A relieved captain waved them on only to be told that Miles had forgotten half his kit. Now this isn’t what a frazzled skipper wants to hear. Miles has to field in shorts and finds himself running from fine leg to fine leg.
Finn pins the other opener whilst Dom gets the same treatment from said portly gentleman. So after 4 overs the score is 24. The next 16 overs are completely bizarre as Finn and Dom complete 5 over spells for 11 & 13 respectively## Simon bowls 5 overs for 11 and takes 2 wickets courtesy of a brilliant catch by Tom P## which## I’m assured was nowhere near as good as his catch last week.
