Tom is swinging the ball around all over the place making life very difficult for the batsmen and we arrive at drinks with the score on just 51
Everything continues in the same vein for a while after drinks but the slightly rotund opener has now gone which means that 3s are no longer being turned into singles and bat is being put to ball with good effect. The next 17 overs produce 140 runs  Big Ben has taken over from his little brother and does a good job for 5 overs before he gets carted to all parts. Miles has 2 overs of which the first is a maiden## then the batsmen line him and take 16 off his next. Finn comes back and concedes 12 off his first over## 1 good shot## 1 complete miss hit and a snick that rolled gently down to 3rd man where Miles did an immaculate long barrier and let the ball roll through his legs and over the boundary. I’m not sure if a captain can do a "double teapot’ and explode at the same time but….
Dom is now on for Ben and bowls an excellent over only for Finn’s bowling analysis to be completely destroyed at the other end when The Green’s danger man## Deepak## smashes him for 20 off his last over. Dom gets a wicket in the next and Tom P gets Deepak in his come back over but now the Green are throwing their bat at anything remotely within reach and Dom gives them plenty of opportunity with 2 half-trackers which are duly spanked for 6 conceding 15 off his last over.
Where did it all go wrong. 56-4 after 23 overs then 194-9 at 40. We didn’t bowl badly and the fielding held up. 
 Hey Ho off to an excellent tea.
On the way to the ground and whilst fielding at 1st slip Marcus had been bending the skippers ear about how well he was batting and when Big Ben announced at tea he’d hurt his back it was to Marcus the skipper turned to open with Tom. Tom lasted 5 balls so Marcus was joined by Bastie and## against some good bowling## on an interesting pitch## they hurried the score up to 59 before Bastie was too early on a drive as was easily caught. Kamal played one sumptuous shot to fine leg before deciding to mis a full-toss. Toby was given out stumped by one of his own team mates without troubling the scorer but all the while Marcus is driving and pulling and rushing between the wickets. He’s now been in stands of 59## 17## 20 and now the important one where Dom scores a rapid 20## and helps Marcus add 42 before sacrificing himself to preserve his openers wicket. Miles comes and goes## Ben likewise and now the skipper is padded up but sensibly he’s sent in Finn to help Marcus and with some brilliant stroke play from them both plus some excellent running between the wickets they slowly close on The Greens score. 
With scores tied Marcus finishes the job with a beautiful straight drive and The Waggoners are home with 3 wickets and an over to spare.
This was a brilliant innings of 117 no from Marcus. His maiden 50 for the Club and his first ever 100 and he’s only 15. Lets hope there’s plenty more where they came from.
Before the game started both Miles Dugdale and the skipper were concerned about how the game would be played following a very unpleasant match here 2 years ago. We shouldn’t have worried. The game was played in an excellent spirit and we were well looked after.

A slightly overcast evening with a cool breeze## Oliver won the toss and he had already decided that he was going to bat and give Chesham something to chase. 

Oliver and Tim faced Cheshams opening bowlers and Oliver immediately started to find the boundary hitting 5 fours with Tim following suit from the other end## both being careful. Oliver lost his wicket to an awful pea roller ## not something we see very often and Tim kept a clean sheet defending some accurate bowling## the boys pushed us up to 224 from 4 overs.

Max and Thomas were presented with more decent bowling and a decent leg spinner## Max as usual couldnt resist the temptation of swinging at the turning ball and then he relaxed and moved to a straight bat method## Max taking singles and Thomas playing a wonderful set of drives for the boundary## the boys pushed us up to 249 from 8 overs## 300 runs seeming achievable.

Finn and Archie faced some more leg spin from the 3rd over from the chesham boy which claimed a scalp## however the other bowlers were a little less challenging and both Finn and Archie found the boundary and played sensible shot. 263 from 12 overs and still on track.

Luke on his debut found the boundary from his third delivery ##well supported by Kuran. One little hick up with the boys having a slow dance in the middle of the strip led to a run out## however Kuran powered one to the boundary as his penance.270 from 16 overs and looking like a decent total for us to defend.

Raphi and Seb took the last spot and they clearly wanted to give us an extra margin with Raphi retaining most of the strike from which he struck five fours and a six ## with the boys also running eleven singles and a two## the boys looked like they could have stayed out for 40 overs never mind 4## they left us with a very decent 306 from 20 overs for the loss of 5 wickets.

Match teas were very kindly provided by Grace and Fiona which i was told were delicious## my supper was eagerly consumed by the ballinger boys and i was told that my piri pirir chicken was delicious.

A confident Ballinger side took to the square and Oliver set a well balance field for the first few overs tempting the batsmen to play the ball## Kuran struck the stumps with a ball going at warp factor six and with only the odd single and a four being taken from Kuran## Luke bowled a great line and length every ball and went for a few singles and a few byes## but he mainly bowled dot balls## putting the pressure on the nervous Chesham players. Chesham were 214 from 4 overs.

The second pair were a strong pair and Oliver set his field really well## changing it for each bat [as one should do]## Thomas bowled a good length ball that they struggled to get away and Oliver came in and gave a couple of extras## but sent in a shorter slower ball that went high over to Tim at point## the next over and Thomas struck the wicket## so the pair left the square on 233 from 8 overs and their hill was becoming steeper.

Finn and Tim bowled at the third pair and they scored only seven runs from the bat along with Tim and Finn bowling 15 dot balls## the pressure on the batsmen building at a pace and only one more potentially dangerous bat to come in. Chesham were 248 fropm 12 overs.

Sebastian with his field set wonderfully by Oliver delivered a few allowable singles and then a run out which struck the stumps with a direct hit by Tim at point with their batsman a good yard out## Archie came on and bowled perfect line and length at a medium pace for which he was rewarded with the first maiden of the match## Sebastian's second over was rewarded first ball with a shorter ball which the batsman struck straight at the uber safe hands of Raphi at mid wicket.more dot balls and the the pair walked back to the pavillion with Chesham on 245 from 16 overs.

Raphi bowled over 17 and gave only two singles and a leg bye## Thomas took over 18 and a wide and then another catch pushed their score backwards## Raphi in over 19 against attacking batting as we would expect delivered a further wicket leaving the visitors on 249 from 19 overs. Oliver bowling at his best and still irritated at the pee rollers then bowled a double wicket maiden. Chesham finished on 237 for 9 from 20 overs.

A well deserved win from a team that performed in every aspect of the game and a delight to watch in action. This is a side that are learning from their mistakes which demonstrates great maturity.

Well done to all of the players and this means they have finished top of the league.

Thanks as well to all of the parents for making sure the ground and clubhouse were tidy.

 

Steve

Knotty Green in to bat first and Finn took out their number two bats stumps for a golden duck from his fith ball## the next pair settled in and added some 28 runs before a shorter slower delivery from Matt was sent skywards only to be intercepted by a locomotive speed run and catch from Monty## KG settled down again for a while pushing up to sixty runs## held back by some quite superb fielding ## especially from Stuart and also Joe who made a right handed diving catch [sadly it had kissed the ground from the bat] that Brendan McCullem would have been proud of. The partnership was then broken with them on 60 from another great catch by Monty from the tight bowling of Dom## this was followed two balls later with a run out of their number four bat## so with them now on 60 for four from 9 overs.

They managed to add another 15 runs before Dom struck the wickets again and then two balls later off Freddies somewhat unplayable leg spin the ball is dispatched into Dom's safe hands## KGCC are in all sorts of trouble on 75 for 6 from 11 overs.

KGCC managed to add on a few more mainly through no balls and wides then Joe was rewarded with a nick into Steve's gloves behind the stumps## in comes the KGCC skipper who sees the score up to 100 and then he is faced with the up pointed finger of Dick following a yorker length ball on to his pads## their number ten bat then comes in ## takes his guard and Dom immediately bowls him out## they are still on 100 for 9 from 15 overs.

The last pair managed to hang on for a further three and a bit overs before Matt takes out number eleven with a tidy caught and bowled. KGCC had scored 89 from the bat plus 25 extras## 114 from 19 overs- all out

Stuart and Monty opened and set off at a pace pushing the total along with aparent ease## reaching 40 from just six overs## then with a change of bowler Monty was given out LBW## the finger appeared up quicker than the appeal. Stuart then joined in the middle by Freddie and following a lull for two or three balls the push again continued with both players driving the total up to 78 in the 11th over when Freddie was caught. 

Joe joined Stuart in the middle and there was to be no lull with the pair again driving the score closer to the target## the pair pushed up to 93 when Joe was bowled by their left arm spinner.

we were 93 for 3 from 14 overs and with just twenty two needed Kamal joined Stuart and the pair steadily moved towards the total reaching it with a four from the middle of Stuart's bat in the 18th over.

Well done to the side and clearly the support of the club chairman and president gave the extra moral boost to secure this fine victory.

Big thank you to Dick for umpiring.

Sadly no extra points for having a scorer.

 

Steve

Ollie our skipper on this fine and somewhat chilly evening was asked to field first## with four late changes to the side he meticulously altered his bowling order and never once had to refer to the manager despite the late changes.

Opening with Raphi an edge to Max at first slip took the first wicket and with Edward O at the other end no runs were scored from the bat in the first four overs## only a few extras to the Lee batsmen## Raphi bowling a maiden his second over.

With Freddie behind the stumps for the fist spell Jack came on to try his hand at bowling along with Max## both boys bowling with some skill and giving very little away and then JAck in his last over straight bowled their number three and then after a single was rewarded by his last ball finding its way into Raphi's hands. The Lee were now on 211 from 8 overs.

With Jack now behind the stumps and Freddie with the ball their number five bat stood and tried to hit Freddies wicked leg breaks which were turning as if the seam was made by Dunlop. James Batchelor performed with similar skill and was rewarded with a catch by Raphi## along with 4 dots and only a single from his debut U11 over## James second over then produced five dots and a single## great performance from a year 3 boy. Freddie also had 5 dots and a wide from his second over## the Lee were on 213 from 12 overs.

The skipper Ollie gave very little away from his two overs and accompanied by Edward Batchelor who bowled 9 dot balls ##a single##a bye and a no ball## thus piling on the pressure with them on 229 from 16 overs.

Cyrus started off his first over with a wicket maiden accompanied by a wicket for Kuran who was bowling from a 3 step run up## so the Lee finished leaving us with a target of 229.

Crisps##Nuggets and Bourbon's were very kindly provided again by Caroline## who also looked after all the spectators so once again a big big thank you.

Freddie and Cyrus opened the batting and despite a difficult first over Freddie then switched to boundary mode along with Cyrus both hitting four fours each and passing the Lee's total in the fourth over. So they returned to the pavillion with us on 240.

James and Ollie took to the square and James immediately started pushing the ball around along with Ollie and they both found the boundary and only allowed four dot balls in their partnership## they pushed the score up to 271 from 8 overs## the only thing that could possibly change the course of events now would be if it started snowing.

Kuran and Edward B came to the crease and Kuran was run out twice by some superb fielding that resulted in direct hits## notwithstanding this the boys both pushed the ball into gaps and also to the boundary and continued to push the score up 281 from 12 overs.

Jack and Edward O didnt have much to hit as there was a demonstration on bowling wides## but the balls that came within range were pushed for singles and two's and they pair demonstrated great running between the wicket and awareness stealing extra runs from overthrows## neither boy lost their wicket. BWCC now on 310 from 16 overs.

Raphi and Max finished off the proceedings with Raphi taking a couple of boundaries along with the constant flow of singles and two's with Max. The boys didnt lose their wickets and finished with the side on 336 for 4 from 20 overs.

 

Well done to the boys and again a huge thank you to Carloine and the parents## the clubhouse was once again immaculate.

 

Steve

An afternoon in the sun at the picturesque Bradenham ground is one of the season's highlights## especially as BWCC tend to win. Yet again our skipper lost the toss## but with a well balanced side available this week## there should be no problems. As indeed there weren't; only three quarters of an an hour into the match## Bradenham were 27 for 4## and reeling under the onslaught of a fired up Will Reid and the wily accuracy of Nick Adams. Will suffered two missed slip catches off his very first over## and by the time his seven overs opening spell ended## he had conceded a mere 14 runs## but had seen Nick grab all the wickets at the other end. But Lady Luck was not going to favour Ballinger today. Chasing a ball in the field## Carlton Siddle pulled up lame## and was thus unable to fulfil his role as first or second change bowler. The skipper therefore tossed the ball to Freddie Thompson## just at the time when the burly left-handed Ghafoor## after a quiet start## decided to impose his presence on the match. Poor Freddie went for 48 in his 3 overs## including 7 sixes## before the skipper had mercy on him. Ian himself was also suffering heavy punishment by this time. The scoreboard raced along## as Ballinger did not help themselves## grassing three opportunities to halt Ghafoor and the by now equally aggressive Kiani. Salvation appeared in the form of a passing motorist who took grievous exception to the ball rocketing into the side of his car## and was unimpressed by shouts of " It's your own fault for driving across behing the bowler's arm"  etc## etc.- mostly by the Bradenham players naturally## certainly not Ballinger's! But the slaughter resumed. Ghafoor was eventually bowled by Joe Hankinson for 112## an innings which included 10 sixes and 9 fours. Joe also claimed the scalp of Kiani## stumped by Richard O'Kelly for 95 ( a mere 8 sixes and 7 fours). But not before the final straw in a miserable afternoon's fielding## when Andy Thompson's calf seized completely up while bowling his fourth over## and he had to be carried from the field## to play no further part in the game. Bradenham's sixth wicket put on 136. Their next highest stand was 33!

A target of 257 would have taxed a full-strength batting line -up## let alone Ballinger's seriously diminished one. But evidently no such thoughts were in the minds of Danny Draper and Richard O'Kelly as they made a rapid and confident start. Danny cleverly managed to place his aerial shots so that they landed just over the fielders' heads## and with Richard hitting the ball with his usual power## and taking few risks## the total passed 100 in the 19th over## well up with the requisite run-rate. Danny went first## bowled## for an attractive 41## with the total on 113## and Richard followed quickly for an excellent 69.  Those familiar with Ballinger's middle order batting need read no further. Rollo was batting in very restrained mode when## afflicted by the "Shane Watson" syndrome (i.e: propensity to death by LBW) inevitably took a risk and paid for it. Will Smith came and went## first ball## rapidly followed by Joe Hankinson. Nick Adams played sensibly## batting for half an hour for 16## but the run rate was now out of sight## and the aim had now to be achieving 75% target bonus. We failed in this## too## in spite of a nice cameo from Will Reid. Carlton came in at No 10## with a runner## but lasted only 3 balls ## and Andy could not bat. (The stats above show "retired" as there is no provision for "Absent hurt" - action NK/webmaster please!)

Many more batting failures like this## and Ballinger's place in the Premier Division may be drawing to a close!

The lads performed another professional performance today. As usual with all our captains this season Captain Mandeville called wrong and Ballinger were asked to bat

Ary  and Max put on a steady partnership of 15 runs with Ary stroking some lovely offside shots. Next in Max H and Will S hit a lively 33 run partnership with Max H hitting some impressive boundaries and Will S judging the single well. Harbin B and Thomas R put on a steady 23 run partnership unfortunately Harbin having his usual run out episode. James B and Captain Mandeville hit an impresive 42 runs both hitting big sixes into the crowd. And finally Josh F and Charlie W completing the innings with a 36 run partnership. Setting a total of 334 runs for 6 wickets

Chesham in response could only manage 227 runs for 11 wickets with all the lads bowling well. Once again good play in the field saw 4 run outs and 4 catches taken. The best bowling  performance was Harbin B bowling 2 wickets for 1 run at the end of the innings.

No man of the match was nominated because this was a very good TEAM performance.

On another hot## dry afternoon at Ballinger the stand-in skipper was relieved to be batting## despite losing the toss. With another 'road' prepared by the stand-in groundsman; a short dry outfield and a strong batting line up## a score of 200 plus was surely in order? Widmer End's opening bowler## Overmeyer## provided a brisk start to the game; extracting enough bounce from the track to keep the bowlers interested. Any early width was punished by the openers## who initially looked comfortable. Opening from the Village Hall end## Wyatt set about a ten over spell of dropping the ball on a decent line and length## without really doing much with the ball. Monty was extremely unlucky to play-on while sweeping - the ball only just having enough momentum to dislodge one bail by the time it eventually reached the furniture. Clark perished soon after## trying to hook one that was too short and too wide to play at that early in the innings. Jono joined Basty at the crease and took a liking to Wyatt; dispatching him twice to distant parts of Ballinger Common## before being trapped LBW to a ball hitting him high on the thigh (with a bruise to prove it). At 34 for 3 off eight## what BWCC needed was someone to dig in and occupy the crease; while still dispatching the none-too-rare bad deliveries - enter Toby Lyons. At 20 overs (65 for 6) the stand in skipper was simply hoping to achieve a score that would be even vaguely defendable - surely 120 was too much to ask for? While others perished around him## Toby continued to accumulate runs steadily while wickets fell at regular intervals at the other end. The tail then wagged. Fin adding 7; Will 14 and an excellent hard-hitting 24 from Evan; combined with a superbly constructed innings of 51 from Toby## took BWCC to a previously unimaginable 149. Despite turning the innings around## a score of below 150 still looked eminently gettable## given the track and conditions. Surely? An excellent tea courtesy of Caroline lifted the spirits and off we went. Fin and Evan started well; both extracting enough pace and bounce to make wickets look like a real possibility - Fin rearranging Afridi's stumps in the third over. Evan bowling tidily from the football ground end. Saffid joined Hobbs at the crease## and a partnership of 51 then seemed to be taking the game away from BWCC. Despite the steady progress being made towards the target## many of Widmer's runs were coming via a lofted route - this served to keep Ballinger in the game with a chance surely going to hand soon? Another partnership (31 runs between Hobbs and Shahzad) followed leaving the score on 102 for 3 off after 17 overs. Only 48 needed. By this stage the openers had been replaced by Will and Monty## and due to the patience and persistence of the Ballinger bowlers and fielder## the game started to change. Bowling to a 7/2 field## Will proceeded to bowl one of the best spells seen at Ballinger for some time. Line and length## and enough movement away from the bat to keep the slips interested## Will proceeded to collect 5 Widmer wickets for 24 runs off 7 overs. A truly game-changing performance. The real frustration being that he had to be withdrawn from the attack due to bowling restrictions. Never mind - Matt had been loosening up for at least 15 overs. Cometh the hour....... At the other end Monty plugged away with a spell of tight attacking spin bowling## picking up a couple of wickets for his toils. By the 24th over Widmer had reached 125 but with nine wickets down; the last pair now in and only looking to nudge their way to 150. All of sudden the game had changed - 25 runs seemed like a mountain to climb and the momentum was with Ballinger. Nonetheless## due to some stubborn batting and a few loose deliveries## Widmer found their way to 139 for 9 at the start of the 32 over. Having spent the previous few overs striking a balance of containment and attack## the stand in skipper elected for the latter with full force. Matt started the over with a single## bringing the less dangerous of Widmer's batsmen on strike. Further fielders were brought in to search for the final wicket and Matt sent down a short of a length delivery on leg stump which was fended off toward Toby at forward short leg. Toby appeared to react slowly## but then calmly stepped forward and snaffled the ball a couple of inches above the turf. Widmer End all out for 140. A fabulous win for Ballinger## who were patient and persevered even when the game looked well beyond them. Honours evenly shared between Toby (for batting with great control and giving us something to defend); and Will Arnold for a fabulous spell that changed the second innings. The Dude was once again very tidy behind the stumps and took his catches well. Many thanks to Roger for officiating## and Nigel for scoring and preparing the track (and generally pottering) so well. Stuart

A rare event indeed at Ballinger## as skipper Maciver returned from the toss with a smile on his face## and the home batsmen smiled likewise## at the long awaited treat of batting first on the famous batting paradise. The smiles were short-lived. Matt Riley## apparently deciding that immediate all-out attack was called for## ballooned a catch to mid-off in the third over. 13 for 1 became 13 for 2## as Rollo guided his first ball into the grateful hands of slip. Eight runs later## Will Smith was unlucky##and the only person on the field. alas including the umpire## who thought he hadn't nicked one down the leg side to the keeper. For once it was now Ballinger's oft-maligned middle order which was called on to repair the damage. Ian Davies dug in for 23 dot balls## before starting to go on the offensive## whilst Joe Hankinson was striking the ball to great effect at the other end. Together they had raised the total to 51## when Ian fell to another catch by the keeper. Jono Lacey's stay at the wicket was all too brief (58 for 5) but Monty Thompson came in to give a demonstration of Thompson grit (his father watching helplessly from the pavilion## last week's torn calf apparently sporting a Dali-esque tattoo## but to the relief of all## actually a medical device!). With Ballinger's batting resources badly stretched by injury and unavailability## it was essential that this pair stuck it out## but just as the total neared 100 Joe edged fatally to slip## out for a valiant and at times aggressive 42## with one splendid 6. Thereafter## it was rapidly downhiil## and the innings whimpered to a sad end - a pathetic total of 121. Had Knotty Green held all their catches things might have been even worse##

Having batted for only 35 overs## Ballinger then had three overs before tea in which to dent the Knotty Green confidence.The tea score of 24 without loss indicates their success.  A welcome break for sustenance provided by the Thompsons sent the fielding side out again## to try and do better. They failed## spectacularly. The same opening attack## which had so dominated the early batsmen last week## was simply toyed with by J Patel. Will Reid was the pick## and managed to concede only 4 an over## but Nick Adams' three overs cost 33. A swift change to spin brought no relief whatsoever##as Ian Davies and Ian Maciver were both put to the sword. It was only when the score had reached "nelson" that Will Arnold## in his one and only over took two wickets## both clean bowled! Patel was unbeaten on 82## including 18 fours and 1 six. The match was all over at ten to five## Knotty Green taking 12 overs and three balls to usher Ballinger ever closer to the league trap door. Abysmal.

The good news was that most of their players came along to the Swan for an early drink with us. Good for them.

Stony Stratford elected to bat on a blustery day at Great Horwood. James Best and Edward Batchelor opened the bowling## and both kept it tight## despite the wind## with the added bonus of an early wicket in Edward's 2nd over. A net score of 211 after 4 overs represented a very good result with 2 good batsmen at the crease. Noah Henry and Victor Grant then came on to bowl the 2nd set of 4## also keeping it very tight## despite the hurricane which really was making bowling very difficult. By the end of the 8th## Stony S had moved to a net score of only 225 with a loss of 1 more wicket. Cyrus Hassan and Matthew Warren came on for the next set of 4## bowling very tidily## but both suffered a little bit of the long handle from 2 strong boys## who took their score to 256. Then the Waggonners played their trump card## bringing on Luke Hopcroft and Harvey Ward both coming in off their (very) long runs taking 3 wickets in their 4 overs## thus reducing Stony's score to net 250. The final 4 were bowled by a combination of Edward and James Best and Edward Batchelor## who between them kept the Stony total to 268. A target well within reach. 

Edward Batchelor and Matthew opened the batting. Edward proceeded to plunder 4 fours## including a straight drive for a 2 bounce boundary## which had one balding overweight scorer nodding in appreciation. A net score of 17 after 4 was a good start. Cyrus and James then came in## and decided to take the attack to the Stony bowlers## and proceeded to smash 29 runs in their 4 without losing a wicket. Magnificent hitting. Things were looking bleak for the men from the north. 

Harvey and Luke were up next and continued to belt the ball to all corners## Luke in particular playing some delightful shots square of the wicket. After 12 overs## Ballinger were 287 and in charge. Noah and Freddie walked out for their 4 overs## and continued to dominate the bowling## and apart from one farcical run out where both boys ended up at the same end## they both batted very nicely## with some handsome stroke play from both boys## as Ballinger advanced to 317 after 16. Finally Victor and Edward B marched in for the last 4## and Stony## somewhat demoralised at this stage## allowed them to apply the coup de gras and take the score to 321 at the end of the 20th. 

A thumping win for the Waggoners.Thanks to Joe for umpiring and to the weathermen for keeping the rain at bay. On to the final!

A warm sunny day at Wendover - a first for me as I had always thought it was twinned with Manchester - saw Ballinger in the field hunting another win. Fin & Andy bowled a good variety - certainly enough to confuse the Wendover top order and reduce them to 41-5 as the fielders enjoyed some catching practice. Tight spells from Ben and Tom kept the 2s in the ascendancy whilst Freddie took wickets at the other end. Just six overs remained with Wendover languishing on 122 for 8## so the skipper## still euphoric after his catch## decided to feed them some runs to ensure more of his lads would get a bat. Once they had enough (177) he finally recalled Tom back into the attack and he promptly took the 2 remaining wickets with his first two deliveries.

The Ballinger reply started badly as the Bens were both back in the pavilion with the score only just into double figures. Tom & Kamal patiently rebuilt the innings## ever watchful on a tricky wicket## before both started to push the score along nicely## Kamal eventually departing for 32. Alex## playing his first game of the season## and still recovering from a dislocated shoulder## joined Tom and in another 50+ partnership took us within striking distance of the target before Alex too perished. Brief cameos from Pads and Andy and the loss of Tom left Freddie and Fin to get us over the line with three overs and three wickets to spare## Freddie's 28 coming at a run a ball.

Another good win & team effort so the Seconds Steam Train rolls on down the line## Hampden are next in line for the juggernaut. Thanks due again to Miles for umpiring.

Ballinger in the shape of  skipper## Monty Thompson## won the toss and elected to bat## in the usual Sunday fashion. The opening father and son partnership of Rob and James McIntyre got us off to a slow and steady start## however this was largely due to the low## slow and unreliable strip.  James perished for 5## caught. Will and Rob began to rebuild the innings. Runs began to flow in until Will was given out to a questionable LBW by Max Dugdale! Rob soldiered through on what was a tough pitch while the wickets of Salisbury## Tegg and Kellock fell for the total of 12 runs. Freddie Thompson and Rob pressed on until Rob was caught for 87 and Freddie was caught for 22. Hamish and Fin finished the innings off## both standing on 6 not out. This left Ballinger on 192 for 9.

 

 

After tea Hamish and Freddie openned up with the old ball. Hamish took the 2 key wickets of the two opening batsmen## Freddie added to this by taking their number 3 batsman. Hamish ended his spell with figures of 3 overs## 4 runs and 2 wickets## with Stuart MacGowan coming on to replace him. Freddie bowled a beautiful ball that apparently took the outside edge of their number 7 batsmen. He was quite rightly given out by Miles## only to then stand there in disbelief and appeal.  Perhaps over-generously## even in the spirit of Sunday matches## he was called back## due to the good position that we were in.  Frankly## everyone knew that he was out## but we didn’t want to create an “incident”.  Nonetheless##the batsman’s attempt to joke his way out of it were met with stony silence and sarcastic laughter from the close fielders. Unfortunately he went on to score their only standout score of 46## to be caught off Monty’s Bowling at deep cow corner by Hamish. Fin picked up the last real batsman## effectively to end the game. The entertainment was not over## however## with Monty chasing hard to get under a high catch to finish the game## only to fall over – inexplicably – at the last moment## with the ball eventually landing inches from his head as he sprawled on the ground.  He blamed his tumble on “a hump” in the apparently bowling-green-flat outfield. An over later Fin finished the game by bowling the last batsman out## with Finn finishing 6.5 overs## 1 maiden## 19 runs and 3 wickets. We had won the game convincingly by 101 runs. 

 

Monty Thompson (Ed Andy)

We won the toss for the 3rd week in a row and elected to bat## on what was a good## true pitch that had pace and bounce at Kimble CC.  Max and Monty opened up and got off to a flyer## with 40 runs being put on  in 5 overs. It was in the 6th over when we had what is known as a Ballinger collapse. With two wickets coming in the over## a further wicket in the next over and another in the 9th over with 0 runs being added to the total. Toby and Marcus then begun to rebuild the innings with Toby (22) getting run out in the 20th over. Marcus carried on and scored a gutsy and excellent 48 off 62 balls## standing out as the star batsman with many well-timed shots pinging off the middle of the bat. Stuart and Will added vital runs to the total with 34 runs and allowed us to bat out the 40 overs.

 

 

The tea left us with rather hot mouths and full stomachs with a wonderful curry. We started off well with a wicket coming off in the second over## with their key batsman taking on Toby at long on to find out that he can catch. Will and Fin proved to be useful opening bowlers taking 2 key wickets for few runs in the opening overs. Fin ended with figures of 3 wickets## 8 overs for 27 runs and Will ended with  2 wickets## 8 overs for 25 runs. Wickets steadily fell up to the 21st over when they were 74 for 5.  Then there was a strong partnership until the 34th over when the next wicket fell at 148 when Will came back on to bowl his last over. Events in his first over repeated themselves with Toby taking another good catch at wide mid on. The game became tight with the Rivetts needing 34 runs off the last 6 overs. Fin## Matt## Monty and Dom had the challenge of bowling the last 6 overs with Rivetts needing less than a run a ball. The next two overs went for 5 and 6 runs. Fin was to bowl the 37th over – producing a much needed wicket maiden. The 38th over was bowled by Monty and went for 5 runs with the wicket of their last real batsman who was stumped by Max behind the stumps. Dom bowled the 39th over with 9 runs coming from it leaving them needing 9 runs off the last over. Only 7 runs were conceded with Monty bowling ‘Piggy pace’  - quicker balls fired a foot outside off stump - and Ballinger had won a close highly competitive match by 2 runs. 

 

Monty Thompson (Ed Andy)

The sun was out for the final of our 3 local derbys; Missenden## The Lee and Hyde Heath. The Sunday XI before the game was on a flier of a season with no losses to their prestigious name. The pitch looked good for batsmen and the outfield was rapid - if the infield was beaten then the batsman could expect 4 runs. The game format was to be time## which suited our 4 man bowling line up. The toss seemed to be a bad one to loose## but to our surprise we were put into bat.

 

‘Run a Ball Riley’ and Rob McIntyre were to open. After a close LBW call on his first ball Matt set us off to a flyer with 4’s being hit all around the field. However this quickly ended in the 4th over with Matt being caught and bowled## leaving us 31 for 1. This brought Marcus Tingey to the crease## fresh from scoring a ton the day before. Marcus played a few risky shots for 4 before he was bowled for 12. Rob stemmed the flow of wickets the innings with Toby## but this was at the cost of a slower run rate. As both batsmen begun to pick the run rate up after the period of consolidation## Toby was stumped for 27. Graham was next in and looked aggressive from the beginning.  He and Rob ran many a well-judged single## even though Rob was still recovering from a bike ride the week before from Lands End to John O’Groats!. Rob was eventually caught for 68 when he also like Toby was trying to push the run rate higher. David Livingstone and Graham were left to finish the innings off in aggressive style. Graham hit the ball to all areas of the park and even played an excellent late cut## which was too fine for 3rd man. David seemed to take a disliking to the ball## brutally clubbing it for multiple 6’s and 4’s.  238 for 4 off 42 overs.

 

 

After tea and a short heavy rain shower## Harry Livingstone opened the bowling. He got us off to a good start with very few runs coming from his first few overs. Monty’s offspin at the other end was effective against the lefthander but less so against the right hander and Freddie Thompson took over. Meantime Harry picked up the first wicket of the left-handed batsman## who chipped a full toss to Rob at mid on. From Freddie’s first ball he seemed to cause the remaining opening batsman problems. However from now till the last 15 overs proved to be a difficult period for Ballinger in the field. The opening batsman and their number 3 tucked into the bowling## even good balls disappearing for 6 off the number 3’s bat into the tree tops. We were staring at defeat. It was not until around the 30th over when Freddie induced a miss hit slog from the number 3 to have him caught by a stunning diving catch by Rob on the boundary. Things began to look up as we quickly learnt that Hyde Heath only had 3 real batsmen.  Numbers 1-3 scored 177 runs while 4-11 scored only 33 runs.  Do the maths – we won! Freddie persisted from the same end## with the help from Harry and Monty from the other. A barrage of wickets fell in the last 10 overs as a result of tight bowling and restricting the strike of the opening batsman who stood on over 100 runs. There were run outs from risky runs in attempts to get the better batsman on strike.  And when their opening batsman was caught## suddenly we were unexpectedly in a winning position; we needed 3 wickets off 4 overs with 38 runs to play with. With a run out and 1 person being bowled this left us with 1 wicket needed off the last 2 overs. Freddie took the 2nd last over – a maiden – they were now blocking. Harry came on to bowl the last over. With the field all in he was bowling against a seasoned blocker. However he kept it pitched up and produced a catch off the penultimate ball to provide us with a hat trick of wins in the local derbys!

An away match at local rivals The Lee is always a pleasure due to the ground’s idyllic setting## good wicket and friendly opposition. This trip was made even more satisfying when a youthful Ballinger side (Basty was the second oldest player at 21!) comfortably defeated our opponents## whose line-up looked suspiciously like it contained a ringer or two.  

                Upon winning the toss and batting we quickly found ourselves 5 for 2 in the 4th over. The skipper then decided the best form of defence was attack and proceeded to take advantage of the small boundaries to compile a rapid fifty. However Toby showed a lot more application and in partnership of 79 they began to rebuild the innings. Once Will was out Toby began to show more aggression and survived a succession of partners before departing in the 35th over for an excellent 78 scored at nearly a run a ball. The platform had been set for some lower order aggression and Ben Dugdale provided the impetus with a belligerent 43* off 29 balls. In the end Ballinger compiled 249 off their 40 overs a mighty achievement considering the disastrous start

 

                Tea was a veritable feast containing scones## hot sausages## chicken nuggets and a delicious homemade Victoria sponge! Perhaps the copious amount of food consumed by the Ballinger fielders explains why the Lee were able to get off to a flyer and smash 14 off the first over. Nevertheless Matt and Harry## who were opening the bowling## managed to keep the Lee in check by bowling tight lines and waiting for the batsmen to make a mistake. Their patience was duly rewards as both the Lee openers were out in their 20’s## A Morgan holed out to deep cover and A Harris was out lbw attempting to hit across the line.  However the Lee steadily rebuilt through the Swain father and son partnership and at 100-2 with well set batsman our total seemed within reach. However Chris Cooke playing his first ever game for Ballinger managed to break the partnership and opened the proverbial floodgates## as the Lee lower order capitulated. Pick of the bowlers were Harry Livingstone who deserved a wicket or two and Ben Dugdale who grabbed 3 for 22 in 6 overs. Overall a really entertaining game played in good spirits against affable opponents. 

 

Will Smith

Successful with the toss for the second week running## Ian Maciver decided not to repeat last week's miserable outing by his batsmen## and to risk trusting his bowlers## ignoring their performance earlier in the season when they conceded 337 against the same opponents.They did not let him down## as Bourne End started very watchfully against Will Reid and Nick Adams## and as soon as they tried to up their scoring rate## wickets started to fall. The pitch was playing much better than on our last visit## and Ballinger's success was entirely due to accurate bowling## backed up by fine fielding. Will took two outstanding catches## one off his own bowling## and an even better one at full tilt on the boundary. Evan Webster held another good one## and this was a (rare) day when not a single chance went begging. Nick finished with 4 wickets for 24 off his 10 overs## and Ian Maciver ran him close with 3 for 23 off 9. Evan chipped in with a couple## and Bourne End found themselves all back in the hutch for a paltry 87## a total that Ballinger - even at their worst - must surely beat with ease.....?

Seven overs preceded tea. By the sixth ball of the innings the scoreboard read 0 for 2. Matt Riley## LBW off his 5th ball## Richard O'Kelly bowled by his first. Will Smith and Max Dugdale (making a very welcome return to action) saw us through confidently enough until the interval## at 23  for 2. That total had grown to 30 before Max edged fatally to the keeper. Still## no reason to panic ....Then Monty Thompson drove a ball hard back at the bowler. He thought that he had driven it into the pitch before the catch was claimed## but after some debate the umpires decided otherwise## so 36 for 4. Jamie Kellock came in to steady the ship## and give some support to Will Smith## who was batting with growing aggression. But with the total 50## Will was bowled for an excellent 23. In came Freddie Denison-Smith## and he and Jamie had little trouble in raising the total to 72## when a totally unneccesary attempt to steal a second run led to Jamie being run out## and as things turned out##  this was to deal a fatal blow. as 72 for 5 became 76 all out !  Freddie was caught for a stylish 18## and the skipper## batting at number 7## faced only two balls whilst helplessly watching four wickets go down in space of 6 balls at the other end## the match ending with a hat-trick## all clean bowled.

Well done to the young players in the team. It was the oldies who were mostly to blame for this most pathetic of batting efforts. It is a pity that league rules do not allow for any club to have both its 1st and 2nd teams in the same division. A contest between BWCC 1 v BWCC 2 might be hard to call!

As usual## (stand-in) Captain Clark lost the toss on a surprisingly dry Ballinger track. However## he got the result he had hoped for as Ballinger were put in to bat. The skipper opened with 'Big Ben' and they put on 59 before BB perished to 
a tidy inswinger. Basty joined the Captain at the crease and they added 86## when the skipper went (caught at cow corner) for an aggressive 91 (more jug avoidance ? - ed) having ridden his luck for 23 overs## and courtesy of some generous bowling. Basty and Toby continued the good work until Basty was stumped for 38 after an attacking innings. Nigel came in at 5 and was joined by Freddie after Toby fell## bowled for 19. Freddie hit a nice shot for 4 and added a single before getting caught off a top edge. Tom Petrie## batting lower than usual and was required to play an uncharacteristically attacking innings## which he did. Tom and Nigel added 51 runs for the final wicket in the space of 5 overs## with Tom playing 3 'switch-hits' and a 'ramp' shot (earning a 'look' from his batting partner in the process)## finishing on 44 not out. Nigel batted more conventionally## and at the end of the innings was 30 not out. A pleasure to watch## though if he doesn't get out soon he won't have an average ! Ballinger finished on 251-5 after their 40 overs and headed for tea confident of being able to defend their score in the second innings. Fin and Matt opened the bowling## the first over from Fin starting in typically hostile fashion (fast beamer!)## with a run-out coming later in the over. Matt used more orthodox methods to take a wicket with his second ball## bowling their number 3 batsman for a duck with a full## in-swinging delivery. The scoreboard pressure continued to build (as Steve 'the Dude' continually reminded the batsmen) and Fin took a wicket with the most dangerous 2nd XI delivery## the low full-toss. The openers both finished their spells after 6 overs## with Tom coming on from the Village Hall End and starting with a maiden. Freddie came on from the Football Ground End and completely confused the Hampden batsmen with his leg-spin. Tom completed his 5 over spell with figures of 1-8 with two maidens and some clever slower balls. He was replaced by Ben Carlin bowling his off-spin## who started with a wicket maiden## followed by another maiden in his second over. Freddie completed an excellent spell with figures of 2-18 off 8 overs## conceding only 8 runs off his first 7 overs. Charlie Barraclough took over from Fred and bowled 3 overs 2-27. The skipper then brought the openers back on to try and dismiss the final two batsmen. Fin ended the innings with a short ball which was lofted to Tom at cow corner. A fabulous all round performance## with all parties contributing with bat or ball (or gloves). Many thanks to Dick for officiating at both ends; to the O'Kellys for a fine tea## 
and to Mrs Thompson for scoring - the neatest the seconds' score book has been all
season!!
Fin Clark
Rain## Rain go away

Winning the toss on a damp wicket with a waterlogged outfield and the promise of further rain## the skipper had little hesitation inserting new opponents High Wycombe with the hope of getting early wickets. Ballinger had the luxury of opening the bowling with Hamish and Will Arnold## fresh off a five wicket haul from the day before. However both bowlers struggled with their rhythm due to incessant rain-breaks and the slipperiness of the ball. The High Wycombe batsmen were less than sympathetic as despite a shortened innings due to the unrelenting rain and time spent looking for lost balls## they managed to post 235 for 9 off 32 overs. No one actually bowled badly but it’s always difficult to contain a batting side at Ballinger when they are trying to smash every ball out the park. The Wycombe innings contained 16 sixes## highlighting the dangers of bowling spin at such a small ground like Ballinger!

 

                After a delightful tea courtesy of Veronica## Ballinger began the daunting chase with Richard O’Kelly and Freddie Thompson batting circumspectly. However the watchful start quickly turned into a shambles## after Freddie’s unlucky dismissal opened the floodgates and the Ballinger batting line-up capitulated in a manner similar to England’s top order. Dignity was only restored by Basty who batted well for 30 and Monty as they ensured defeat was by fewer than a hundred runs. Credit to High Wycombe for bowling aggressively and to their fielding which was superb. All in all a match to forget as nothing quite went right for Ballinger against a talented and youthful Wycombe XI## perhaps the greatest achievement of the match was in actually getting a game in despite the inclement weather.

 

Will Smith

The start of a new month## but nothing new for Ballinger## as they continued serenely on their slide towards Division One. Taking the field first there was early encouragement as Will Reid succeeded with an LBW shout off the fourth ball of the opening over. Thereafter it was all in favour of the batsmen## on the now customary batting paradise of a track## until a lightning strike by keeper Richard O'Kelly off Evan Webster's bowling saw the fall of the second wicket on 56. Thereafter runs continued to flow at a rapid pace. This was in spite of excellent opening spells by both Will and Evan## backed up by some of the best fielding shown by Ballinger all season. Both N Little and R Wallace had passed their 50's by the time Ian Maciver managed to get rid of both of them## then Lady Luck smiled briefly as the prolific P Weeracoon pulled a hamstring when he had only made 13## and retired hurt. Meanwhile the fielders were doing everything possible - good catches being taken by Fin Clark and Evan## and a superb one by Will Smith##  Special mention## too for a magnificent piece of fielding by newcomer Brett Hopcroft ( not Luke as recorded below## as the website needs adjusting - Nigel please rectify!!)## who surpassed an already impressive show by a lightning run-out. Will returned for his second spell and promptly took three more wickets. returning 4 for 40 off 10## an excellent effort on such a wicket. Ian finished with 3 for 34## also off 10## and to have confined Holmer Green to 200 in such conditions was a creditable performance.

One person who had been licking his lips at the prospect of bowling on a really hard track was Holmer Green's speedster Steve Jermain. He didn't take long to make the most of it## sending back Danny Draper and Will Smith with only 5 on the board## just the start Ballinger didn't need. Richard O'Kelly was joined by Brett## and they had put on 41 for the third wicket before Brett's increasingly fluent knock was halted by the sight of the umpire's finger. Therafter## chaos reigned## with the uncannily accurate (as well as fast) bowling of J Salter made mincemeat of the middle order. Standing firm though## was David Livingstone. His 6 over extra cover onto umpire  Dick Beard's car came out of the blue## but he perished trying something similar. Not for the first time## Ian came in to play a true skipper's innings## batting 45 minutes for an attractive 18## then the last pair of Fin and Evan## even though batting in a by now lost cause## showed some of the earlier batsmen a degree of tenacity could keep Holmer Green in the field for longer than had at first seemed likely##

Nevertheless## to be all out on such a wicket for a mere 121 served to underline what has been Ballinger's weakness since those far-off successes at the season's start. This was our 10th defeat in a row. Some kind of Club record?

On a hot day in Little Marlow and what looked a nice pitch to bat on## both teams were no doubt hoping they could bat first in pursuit of a big score. Unfortunately## Ballinger lost the toss and it was Little Marlow who had first use of the facilities. Ballinger opened the bowling with Will Arnold and Fin Clark who bowled with great control early on## putting a stranglehold on the scoring and picking up the wickets of both the opening batsmen. Shariff and Hussain began to rebuild the innings but at no great pace as Ballinger’s change bowlers## Monty and Freddie Thompson were getting considerable turn from the surface and bowling a good line and length. Freddie’s figures did not do justice to how well he bowled and on another day he would have had several wickets. Monty picked up wickets at crucial stages to keep the scoring rate down with Hussain the first of these after he’d built a 50 partnership with Shariff. Shariff held the innings together but finally fell when Will returned to the attack. St Maur attempted to push Little Marlow to a defendable score late on with a quick fire 23 however## 155 seemed below par at the halfway stage and credit has to be given to Ballinger’s bowlers who were bowled very impressively.

 

Ballinger got off to the worst possible start to their chase however## as their opening batsman who shall remain nameless decided driving at a wide delivery was a sensible approach to the first ball of the innings and nicked through to the keeper. Tom and Graham started to get the innings going thereafter with both finding the boundary fairly regularly before Graham was well held at 2nd slip. This brought Will to the crease who played some good shots in a quick cameo of 15 before he tried one shot too many and was clean bowled. Tom continued to impress at the other end playing some fine shots and he pushed Ballinger close to the finish line in partnership with Jamie## Steve and then Jake before falling with just 16 needed. Fin fell shortly afterwards leaving a possibility that a Ballinger collapse may allow Little Marlow to win the game. However## Jake saw Ballinger home with a destructive 29 unbeaten## which included a clipped 6 over square leg. 

Basty Richards
Fulmer failed to get a team up - yet again ! Richard and 11 players less than gruntled !

A welcome return to Frieth after many years away and another table topping clash for a 2s team shorn of several of its mainstays as the Firsts holiday period kicked in. Another toss won and Frieth were inserted## with Harry & Matt opening up the attack. Opener Umar was reduced to silence - albiet briefly and for the only time all afternoon - after Matt trapped him LBW early on. Ballinger's bowlers kept things tight## though punctuated with a flurry of no balls and wides that contributed 25 runs to the opposition total over the afternoon. The second wicket partnership of 90 was not broken until after the  drinks interval##when Toby took a good catch off Harry's second spell. Wickets then fell at regular intervals whilst keeping runs to a minmum. the highlight being an excellent catch from Nigel at mid off that he hung on to as he tumbled downwards. However the last few overs proved expensive## yet again## despite a defensive field and Frieth posted a competitive looking 186 for 8.

The opening Frieth bowlers showed why they are top of the league and runs were hard to come by even before Toby perished in the fifth over. Ben & Matt then settled down to construct a good second wicket stand of 49 before Ben slashed at one and picked out the only slip. Nigel then joined Matt and looked very comfortable adding another fifty with his increasingly desperate partner. Nigel then returned a gentle catch to the Frieth skipper and  Matt## with a party to organise and having failed to hole out## despite some aggressive strokeplay## fled the field on reaching his fifty - the opprobrium of his mother being more scary than the censure of his team mates !

The innings unravelled from there as some rash shots combined with some slow batting increased the size of the task. Only a resilient 23 from the Dude kept us in the hunt and when he went so did any remaining hope. The behaviour of a few of the opposition was way out of the line## much to the embarrassment of the Frieth regulars - such a shame the game was disfigured by it## as their captain## their umpire as well as poor old Dude & Nigel found themselves on the receiving end of abuse.

A disappointing result from a game we should have won but hopefully we'll put it behind us next week back at the home of cricket.

Having already penned a slightly abridged version of War & Peace (more War than Peace !) on this game I will try to keep this as brief as possible and focus on our fine cricketing performance.

The skipper won the toss -again- and decided to let the oppo take to the field on a hot afternoon. A lack of KG players led to some discussion before the rump of their team belatedly and reluctantly took to the field. Instructed not to take too much advantage of the situation openers Ben & Tom kept the score ticking over at a run a ball until the final car load of players finally showed up. After a lengthy stoppage in play our brave lads resumed their innings with no drop in the scoring rate. When Duggers departed with the score on 49## Matt (having by now tidied up after his party) joined Tom## who was already taking more than his fair share of abuse. The two of them looked untroubled and put on nearly a hundred as Tom proved to their fielders that he really could bat despite their assertions and threats.

Matt eventually perished LBW## but on a hot day a fresh batsman was unlikely to slow the run rate. Kamal & Tom sailed along at around 8 runs an over and Tom passed his century. With Tom on 125 there then occurred a very rare## and possibly unique## cricketing incident. With all the fielding side bar the wicket keeper by now on the boundary Tom blocked a ball and gave the ball to their keeper. The KG skipper then appealed for his dismissal and declined to withdraw the appeal when asked to do so by the umpire. Whilst there have been around 50 dismissals for handling the ball in first class cricket in the last 140 years Wikipedia does not contain a single incident such as this - the other dismissals involving elements of obstructing the field. The skipper joined Kamal as the last four overs went for 43 and 259 for 6## even on a belter of a wicket## was always likely to be a winning total.

After a fine tea from Heidi (thank you!) Will & Matt were thrown the ball and started tidily. When The Dude pouched one from Matt the writing was already on the wall - given the scoreboard pressure that was being applied. Debutant Dinesh the Destroyer was brought on and the oldens continued to demonstrate that they too can catch as first Nigel and then the skipper held on to their chances. With Sam picking up a wicket as well## the skipper decided to halt the carnage and rested Dinesh. Unfortunately for KG this only meant Tom & Will coming on and wrapping up the remaining five wickets in just 20 balls with the Dude## Matt & Nigel continuing to get catching practice. Of course## in this game## even that couldn't pass without incident and a fullscale row developed when Tom celebrated despatching his nemesis## the oppo skipper## rather too exuberantly - fortunately Heidi dealt forcefully with the unruly KG players in the pavillion.

A big thank you to Miles for keeping his temper whilst subject to constant abuse.

What a game ! We were left wondering how they behave when they think they have a chance of winning if this is what happens when they are totally outplayed. The tranquil - I hope - setting of Downley for the 2s next week - think I'll go to the Lane to watch a gentlemanly sport instead !

 

 

##

A visit to table-topping Ley Hill with a bowling line up so young that only the skipper could bowl a spell of more than 7 overs## on a very warm sunny day## and a lightning fast bumpy outfield## was not a very likely recipe for success.  So full marks to Ballinger for reducing Ley Hill to 104 for 5 in the 24th over. Will Reid bowled fast## and was unlucky to go unrewarded## but Evan Webster and Harry Livingstone picked up a couple of wickets each## with Ian Maciver also in on the act. The fielding## on such a difficult outfield## was exemplary;  Richard O'Kelly contributed a superb stumping## and Stuart Clark a wonderful running catch on the boundary. However## that was the end of Ballinger's success. Try as they might## the bowlers could not dislodge Richard Clarke and the ever dangerous Suranga Daluwatte## and both were unbeaten when the innings closed on 238 after 40 overs. One or two sharp chances were missed## but on the whole the fielders did their very best to limit the onslaught.

Ballinger's reply was a welcome contrast to previous weeks'. From the first over Stuart batted like a man possessed## and had he continued thus## the game would have soon been won. Alas## after his quick-fire 33 (all bar one in boundaries)## he was unlucky to pick out a fielder with yet another attacking shot## with the score on 42. Meanwhile## Danny Draper who had mostly defended solidly at the other end## now started to go on the offensive## supported by Graham Salisbury (making a rare Saturday appearance).The total had reached 115 with only 21 overs gone## when both of them fell to S Dasanayake. Danny was bowled for an excellent knock of 52##and Graham for 18## which included a spectacular 6 off a no-ball. With Daluwatte now on## and purveying his baffling spin## one feared the worst. And so it proved## although the other spinner## L Thompson was the one who dealt the most crippling blow## having Ian Maciver superbly caught first ball off his own bowling. Thus 115 for 1 had become 140 for 9 in the space of 13 overs. Our batsmen should really have been wearing the "baggy green"## perhaps....?   The only enlivening event occuring when umpire Robin Carr## racing to change a broken bail## tripped on the pavilion step## and fell cutting his face. As he had given us no complaint regarding his decisions## he deservedly received sympathy## and was substituted for the rest of the innings. A defiant little partnership between Will and Evan saw us past 150## to gain an extra batting point## but the game ended in the 26th over## with Ballinger all out 155.

Thanks to Derek Richards for standing as umpire. He at least emerged unscathed!

Cublington are occasionally very strong opposition.  The most striking feature of the Cublington team that arrived at a sunny Ballinger was the divergence in age and height – the oldest approaching his 60s and the youngest only 10## the shortest only a little over 4 foot and the tallest about 6 foot 5 and built like a New South Wales sheep-shearer.  Skipper Monty Thompson was unperturbed by the sight of one of his maths teachers amongst the opposition and won the toss and chose to bat in a 40 over win/lose match. 

Ballinger## with a strong and deep batting line-up## rattled along at about 8 an over for most of their innings## but lost wickets regularly## as almost everyone (exception Max Dugdale## who got a good’un first up) found increasingly bizarre ways to get themselves out.  Freddie Thompson slapped what would have been a wide into gully’s hands## Bastie Richards charged down the wicket to a classic Sunday dobber and was stumped## Nick Tegg slapped another wide one into the covers## Graham Salisbury spooned said dobber round the corner off the face of the bat straight into the keeper’s gloves## Jake Cutter pulled said dobber high to mid-wicket## Monty found himself at the same end as his partner having been the only one of them to run a 2nd and was run out## Hamish Sim managed to miss a full toss from our friend the dobber and was bowled## Will Arnold essayed a mighty heave across the line to a double bouncer from a 10-year-old and was bowled## and## after a period of sensible batting for the last wicket## Stuart McGowan was eventually run out by rather good bit of fielding and a direct hit.  None of this really mattered## as the periodic silliness was punctuated by lots of fine aggressive shots## particularly from Bastie## Graham and Monty## and the innings was liberally sprinkled with extras (48 in all – top scorer).  It is always criminal to fail to use one’s overs in a limited overs again (particularly if one leaves 7 of them unused).  However## although Ballinger should really have scored another 80 or 90## the total of 211 all out always looked too much for Cublington.

 

And so it proved … although not without the odd nervous moment.  Matt O’Kelly and Hamish opened## Matt settling into a steady rhythm and Hamish generating some good pace after spraying it about a bit in his 1st over.  They accounted for one of the Cublington openers each## but the real threat came from Cublington’s number 3## Inglis## who at 6 foot 5 used his prodigious reach to smash anything vaguely overpitched through the covers.  He was a little less assured against the short ball and also looked a candidate for caught behind as he went at everything hard.  But he batted very well to get to 51## with partners dropping like flies around him## principally to Will Arnold who took 3 wickets in quick succession.  While Inglis remained at the crease there was still the chance of an unlikely Cublington victory## but he then mistimed an extravagant off drive and was caught heroically at mid-off by Bastie off the returning Matt O’Kelly## who also finished with 3 wickets.  Spinners## Stuart## Freddie and Jake finished things off with a wicket apiece and a victorious Ballinger team headed cheerfully for the pub.

Winless since the 16th May## Ballinger took the field in phlegmatic mood against Downley## a side against whom we traditionally come off worst. A smiling skipper announced that he had actually won the toss## and decided not to risk his somewhat depleted batting line-up on a pitch that had received a couple of days' rain. A decision immediately vindicated## as Will Reid's third ball castled key batsman J Cox## and gave Ballinger an advantage that they never let slip. Will followed this success by claiming the other opener## also clean bowled## with only 24 on the board## and things got even better when Evan Webster had the powerful A Brown well caught by keeper Max Dugdale## without further addition to the score. In his next over Evan struck again## as the stumps went flying## and Downley were starting to look vulnerable at 31 for 4. With both Will and Evan age-limited to 7 over spells## it was now vital the change bowlers maintained the pressure. With a choice of spinners at his disposal## skipper Maciver now opted to try the tantalising leg spin of Freddie Thompson## to such great effect that the runs almost completely dried up## although George Cook went for a few boundaries when he over-pitched. However## Downley's 5th wicket partnership had managed to put on 54 before Freddie had his first overdue success. This heralded a complete collapse## with Ian Davies now in on the act## and the Ballinger fielders holding (almost) all their catches. Some lusty blows by the number 10 merely delayed matters slightly (and unfairly damaged Freddie's remarkable figures!)## and a surprisingly subdued Downley were all out 115## giving Ballinger's openers a potentially uneasy 8 overs before Helen McIntyre's welcome (organic)tea.

Without a recognized opener to partner Danny Draper## Jono Lacey was given the job. The innings got off to a cracking start## the very first ball yielding five off a no-ball - a good omen. Unfortunately## Jono's stay was brief## one handsome boundary going to his head! So## at tea the score stood at 27 for 1. Danny made his usual watchful start## conscious that there was a lot on his shoulders if Ballinger were to defy their batting reputation this season. With Rollo McIntyre also having to curb his natural instincts## it was to their great credit that they saw the score up to 67 before Rollo could restrain himself no longer## and departed caught## for a very valuable 18. A further wicket was lost with the total on 78## when Max edged to the keeper## but Danny was by now batting fluently## and a flurry of boundaries saw him past his 50. Ian Davies## returning after apparently weeks somewhere in the sun## kept him company with a solid display at the other end## and the feared batting implosion simply never happened.as Danny finished the match off with a rasping four## and a superlative 60 to his name. 

Both sides were missing some key players## but not for the first time it was Ballinger's young cricketers who set the tone with their excellent bowling and fielding. Whether this victory will come too late to save Ballinger from the drop is in the lap of the gods## but two more wins from the last two games might do the trick. Many thanks to Roger Webster for standing as umpire.

It is a truth universally acknowledged in cricket that a long batting line-up presents dangers for each individual batsmen feels there is another good one to come after him.  And so## on  a warmer afternoon than predicted## on a track that looked flat and hard## and a quick late summer outfield## we somehow found ourselves 143 for 8 when at last we found in Hamish someone to take on the responsibility of building a substantial innings with a hard-hitting 75 not out.  A club record 9th wicket partnership of 77 between Hamish and Stuart took us to what I thought was a competitive total (but no more) of 234. Along the way it was rather nice to see the amigos Tom and Jake batting together – Tom specialising in hitting the ball with the trajectory of a two iron## Jake going for greater height including one vertiginous five iron that sailed majestically into someone’s allotment of prized runner beans half way to Chalfont and Latimer. Also huge commendation to Max D for walking to a first baller## especially when it was one of those uncertain strangled dismissals down the leg-side. Class isn’t just about the number and way you score your runs## sir.

 

As for Amersham’s innings## there were two positives and one## well## not so positive## not very positive at all## namely the catching. We all joked that we need catching practice but afterwards I did wonder whether we do enough – especially in the deep where often it is a case of learning to hold ones nerve (as well as the ball). None are easy by the way for they either come with time to think about it or no time in which case they come very hard indeed! Ah well## at least the ground-fielding was good## often fleet of foot and kept the pressure on – and we bowled so well – Hamish and Will Arnold and then Tom P and Stuart M - that it seemed increasingly as if the pitch must have deteriorated over four or five hours (it usually takes that many days doesn’t it?). In particular we got a lot of bounce. And we lost no control at all when Jake and James Mac came on to make up the 5th bowling slot. Indeed the stranglehold just grew## and lo and behold we even took some catches and suddenly Jake had a “five fer”. This contrasted neatly with Stuart’s “five-fer” – one wicket but five catches dropped! But Amersham had quietly subsided and we had won by 87 runs.

 

May I finally record what a pleasure it was captaining a youthful side of unmistakeable talent (built on good technique) with two incredibly nice old pros in support (take a bow Stuart and Graham). I hope everyone had a happy time.

 

NB Final tip## when Hamish or James Mac get the ball in the field## be ready## be very ready## for a run-out opportunity is really quite likely

 

Rob McIntyre

The 2s are off to the top of the mountain today when we play Downley. A lovely ground when the sun is shining as it was today.

The skipper is slightly concerned when once again he wins the toss and has to choose to field. His concern isn’t about having made the right decision it was about being three players short – again. There is going to be no delaying the start this week but## fortunately## this time there are a couple of juniors to call on. 

Dom and Tom are given the new ball and all looks fine for a few overs with the captain happy with his choice## as the ball is moving around nicely.  Dom should have had Downley’s captain in his first over but a difficult nick went past The Dude and Ben was fast asleep when one dropped just in front of him. Tom is in obvious discomfort from his back so has to be replaced by the newly arrived Simon. The other late arrivals are also now on the pitch.

The wicket is very bouncy but the batters are making sure that anything short is getting put away. Simon soon puts a stop to that by bowling an excellent spell. Moving the ball around and getting bounce off a length he bowls 6 overs for just 7 runs and removes one of the openers. Big Ben## who immediately gets the ball to turn## replaces Dom and the combination of the Carlin brothers keeps the total down to 57 at drinks. It was a frustrating 20 overs as nicks and miss-hits kept just missing the fielders.

Tom is now back on for Simon but his back is making it difficult to bowl at full pace## Ben is now getting a bit of tap and although he grabs a couple of wickets## one thanks to a smart stumping from the Dude## the ball is now starting to fly around the park. Ben D has a go but cant exert any control. At 35 overs the score has leapt to 170## which still isn’t too bad## but once again we can’t nail the last 5 overs and they go for another 50 runs. 

226 is about 30 more than we should be chasing and the skipper hasn’t had a good day with his field placing.

A pleasant tea is followed by Big Ben and Marcus starting the run chase. Both look comfortable until Ben gets one that shoots and Marcus gets an interesting LBW. Tom and Ben D are now at the crease and labor to just 50 at drinks. They are encouraged to be more positive especially with their running## an unusual comment as it tends to be a strong point with the boys. Stung by this mild criticism they start to run around like scolded cats and Tom begins to unleash his full range of shots. It’s brilliant to watch with Ben making sure he gives Tom as much of the strike as possible. Suddenly at 32 overs we’re in front of the run-rate. Could they keep going? Finally with the score on 160 with just 7 overs to go Tom perishes for a quite brilliant 93. He and Ben have put on 129 of which over 100 are scored in 13 overs.  Dom is elevated to try and maintain the rate but perishes early and he is quickly followed by Ben## who manages to pick out the fielder at square leg. 160-2 becomes 167-5 in the mater of two overs. Nick P and David## both making a rare appearance for the club## are given the impossible task of keeping the run rate going but importantly they make sure we reach maximum bonus points again

 

187-5 was a decent attempt to chase down the total but if we’d managed to control the last few overs of Downley’s innings we would have been in with a shout right to the wire.

 

An enjoyable game played in the right spirit## well officiated ( thanks Miles & Dave C) and we had a beer with the opposition afterwards!

The Ballinger 1st XI started the match hungry for a win which would be likely to take them clear of the threat of relegation.  Ultimately## however## a closely fought game went against them## in what was a microcosm of the 1st XI 2015 season - an effective bowling and fielding performance restricting the opposition to something less than par on a decent track## having lost the toss## but not enough batting firepower to get Ballinger over the line## despite early promise in the Ballinger innings.

Will Reid showed what an effective and quick opening bowler he has become in the 2nd half of the season## since finishing his A levels## taking 3 for 23 in his opening 7 over spell## which at one point had reduced Waddesdon to 10 for 3 in the 9th over.  He has straightened his line## hitting the stumps more and more often## bowling at a pace that is often too much for batters to cope with early in their innings.  Nick Adams contributed some typically tight## rigorously straight## seam bowling from the other end## going for only 3 runs off his 1st 5 overs.  A partnership of 47 between the stubborn Waddesdon number 3## Johnson## and the hard-hitting number 5## George## took Waddesdon to 57 for 3 in the 19th over## before Freddie Thompson’s legspin removed the dangerous George## bowled trying to hit him over long on.  The new man## Mansfield## threatened to pick up where George had left off## striking 3 boundaries in quick succession## until caught by Jono Lacey off Evan Webster.  The Ballinger bowling and fielding remained tight throughout.  Indeed spectators were treated to not one but 2 diving saves on the boundary from Matt Riley## as he flicked the ball back inches from the line.  (The many from the 1st and 2nd XIs who adjourned to The Swan afterwards to wish Steve Carter well in his coming year teaching in Kuwait were also treated to the sight of Matt in goal in a penalty shootout with the teenagers – which he claims he won.  What is this – Joie de Vivre?  Mid-life crisis?  Too much Doombar?  I shall leave you to decide.)  At the end of the 30th over Waddesdon were poised at 122 for 5.  Those last 10 overs could have seen the visitors get away## but Ballinger continued to take their chances## as skipper Ian Maciver opted for pace off the ball in the form of his own slow left-arm and Ian Davies’s off spin for the closing overs.  Davies claimed the stubborn Johnson and Maciver cleaned up the last 4 Waddesdon batters## taking 4 for 15 off 5.2 overs## Richard O’Kelly executing 2 stumpings.

 

Matt Riley looked in fine touch driving fluently to the boundary twice## before being caught and bowled off a leading-edge.  Thankfully Danny Draper was in his now customary unflappable form## again making up the bedrock of the Ballinger innings.  He was well supported for a while by Will Smith before Will attempted a rash slog at an admittedly enticing slow medium bowler## which went skywards.  Nonetheless## at the halfway point Ballinger were 72 for 2 and well placed## needing just over 4 ½ an over## with 8 wickets in hand.  Ian Davies mistimed a drive and was caught in the covers## but with the experienced pair of Richard O’Kelly (dropping down the order from his usual opening slot## after 40 overs of wicket-keeping) and Draper## Ballinger were still in a decent position.  However## a tumble of 6 wickets for 16 runs left Ballinger suddenly stumbling at 102 for 9 after 31 overs## still needing 63 - now at 7 an over (there is nothing like a rush of wickets to reduce the scoring rate in a 40 over game).  Crucially for Ballinger## Danny was amongst them.  His dogged and skilful 45 could have been the foundation of a successful chase## but we needed another score from someone.  Freddie Thompson## coming in at number 10## gave Ballinger some brief hope## hitting a brisk 19 at the last knockings## at more than a run a ball## but after Richard had fallen lbw to an excellent quick yorker## the game had really slipped out of reach.  Still## having secured a high proportion of the bonus points on offer## and our nearest rivals having lost## we in the end increased our slender points advantage going into the final match## away at Aylesbury next week.

Opportunities for the 2s to visit the picturesque Monks Risboro ground have been non existent since the demise of their 2nd team## so for nearly all of our team this was their first visit to one of the League's trickier grounds. Our nomadic hosts Phoenix XI were themselves only playing their second game at the ground they had hired. With the skipper unusually losing the toss BWCC had to field on the hottest and most humid Saturday of the year so the strong bowling line up would be used to its full extent. Whilst it's a difficult track to bat on it's just as hard to bowl on it and our quicker bowlers were always likely to struggle to come to terms with the sloping run ups.

Phoenix got off to a flier but were reined in once their opener dragged a full toss from Duggers on to his stumps. Matt and Little Ben then bottled up the batsmen## runs dried up as did the throats and by drinks at 15 overs the oppo had reached 64 for 2.
