A couple of chances went begging off Matt but when Will started his 2nd spell he and Ben took 3 wickets in successive overs. Some agricultural batting got their score moving again but Big Ben picked up a couple of wickets and the tail was wrapped up after 34 overs for 148 all out.

After a decent tea it was time for the non bowlers to give it a go and with the lesser spotted Duggers making a rare second team appearance he finally got to strap some pads on. Unfortunately he was soon taking them off again leaving Basty & The Dude to carry on the fight. Steve soon followed Max but Basty and Dom built a solid reply. After drinks they picked up the pace before Basty missed a straight one. Big Ben dwelt out of the traps and having reached cruising speed too late## quickly returned to the pavilion. The skipper and Dom built a good partnership but with the former walking singles the latter decided boundaries were more suitable. Paul departed ## caught in front by a grubber## but not before Dom had passed 50 - having no excuses for not batting properly this week ! We were still 34 runs short when he returned a simple chance back to the bowler## but with plenty of batting talent to come the result was never really in doubt. Finn## Matt & Tom completed the formalities.

A game played in a good spirit and another fine team effort. Job done it was off to the pub to bid farewell to the Dude and help drown some first team sorrows.

Well## I would have cancelled the game – it was chucking it down with rain## the boys were off at the Oval## the forecast was not clever but BS (slightly unfortunate initials?) were not giving up and so we opted to play a straight 30 limited overs’ game...and## aside one break## we got through it just fine.

 

Our innings was built on a partnership of I guess 120 by the dos amigos## namely McIntyre (Tom## or TMac) and Cutter. I like sending them out “together” – here at 3 and 4 (if it was a Ryder Cup

I would always put them out for fourballs and foursomes). It’s not exactly an exhibition in running between the wickets## but good basic techniques allied to timing allied with genuine power (the modern addiction to the gym helps here a good deal) meant that first TMac## then Cutter got on top of their better bowlers## then overwhelmed their lesser ones. As to the former his hundred was made in a possible record for the club of a fraction under 20 overs and the latter’s 70 odd included a hit over the longest boundary that I had told them both not to take on!. Disappeared into the road and then the fields of Oxfordshire! Really## really well done guys – most notably for keeping concentrating. Too often I see cameos not innings that win matches. Lusty blows at the end from Tegg## Jamie and Ben D took us to a whopping 223! Nb A little sympathy for Max D and James M who opened and fell early. Neither of you is in form and then “lady luck” can further conspire against especially batsmen  -James with a played-on and Max with a sweet clip that on another day....

 

Perhaps taking sympathy on the opposition## a number of our fielders did not initially appear for the second innings. Perhaps encouraged## their gnarled old dogs started quickly## very quickly## pinging the balll through the covers## out to cow corner and flipped over mid-wicket. Indeed after 10 odd overs they were ahead of the run chase but then we started to reel them in – Finn with some good slower balls## then our supposedly second line bowlers in James Mac (despite an over with a dodgy leg) then especially Ben Dugdale whose darts are perfectly suited for limited overs cricket. We had the game just about won. Jake then bravely took on the challenge of bowling from the top end – got some tap but snaffled some wickets – and Teggers (!) then kindly brought us up to our full allocation of overs. In some ways BS had done well to get to 190 odd but with only two main bowlers we had held up well too.

 

Three NBs!

i)                    Their umpire’s method of turning down an appeal for LBW was to wave his forefinger/index finger ie the same one you use to give someone out. How to give a batsmen a heart-attack...

ii)                   Pity me. I stood at a shortish square leg for a couple of overs with a batsmen of not very slender proportions whose trousers he had forgotten to pull up## or perhaps they simply don’t get round## his ample back-side

iii)                 A bit mean but remember the way we got their best batsmen out? Now Ben will claim it spun feet but actually the old boy had just taken a couple of twos and was blowing hard. So## bowl the next ball quickly (time to deliver## not speed through the air)!

 

Pleasure to play with you all## guys

 

Rob McIntyre

The final league game of the season arrived - another friendly tussle with fellow promoted side Aylesbury 2s to decide the bragging rights for next season between 3rd and 4th place. I must be careful what I write as their skipper ##Nick## is an avid reader of our match reports ! 

Lost the toss against them again but we took to the field with a good degree of confidence as we were able to pick a nearly first choice eleven - but we were soon retrieving the ball from all parts of the ground as their opener## Phil opened with half a dozen boundaries. Tom c&b their captain and then Phil struck a fierce shot off Fin straight at the skipper who had little option but to defend himself and then hang on to the ball. Two down for just 30 runs off seven overs and things were back on track - but the Aylesbury batting line up was to prove stronger than usual. The third wicket pair put on 62 taking advantage of too many loose balls and a couple of chances also went begging. However Big Ben and the return of Tom brought a measure of control## as they claimed numbers 3 & 4 in quick succession. Freddie passed the pads to Duggers at drinks and then made camp at the Football Stadium end whilst Fin returned at the other. Both bowled well but the occasional bad ball was punished and we managed only one wicket in the next dozen overs. At 152 -5 with just seven overs left things were looking ok## but some disappointing ground fielding## a few more four balls and with wickets in hand the oppo had reached 211- 6 before Freddie took wickets with last 2 balls of the innings.

A fine tea from the Clarks (thank you) - with plenty of sausage rolls for everyone - and we were ready to resume. The skipper top loaded his batting order with Stu##Tom##Toby & Nigel## and sat back to enjoy the rest of the afternoon - or so he thought. The opening bowlers kept it tight and we sleepwalked (almost literally in Tom's case) to disaster. By the time Toby was out## Nigel had endured his only lifetime golden duck## and we were rocking at 37 for 4 off 10 overs. Freddie (wickie##bowler and now batsman) was joined by Big Ben and they saw off the opening attack and then made the best of the change bowlers. By the time Ben was out## the total had passed 100 and little Ben then continued the good work. So much so that we had overtaken the Aylesbury score with nine overs to go - an unlikely victory was within our grasp. However Ben and Freddie departed in quick succession and the game was nearly done. Pads and the skip staggered us over the crucial 75% target line to earn the two points that would keep us in third above Aylesbury.

A very enjoyable game played against a decent side (still reading Nick ?) and a good end to the season even if we couldn't make it a winning one. Very many thanks to Miles who yet again umpired both ends - where would we have been without him this season ? Thanks also to Dave for scoring. 

There were 3 tons and thirteen 50s (don't remember that many jugs) from nine different batsmen. Only three fifors - though all memorable ! -  meaning 11 different players achieved a benchmark game. We used 36 players - slightly less than previous years - though only 20 played more than twice## so we kept a core squad together fairly well.

All in all a very good season## only slightly marred by the unpleasantness from Knotty Green 2s - and it appears we are from being the only ones to have endured that this year. The lads have certainly justified the League's decision to promote the 2s at the end of last season and it is to be hoped that the next crop coming through can do as well - who knows we may well be seeing some mixed teams next season ! Of course we now have the opportunity to finish the season on a high by claiming Ballinger's first ever trophy## come along and support us at Bradenham in T20 final next Sunday## 11am start.

If the unknown Aylesbury couple who planned their weddiing for the 29th of August 2015 had only known the significance of their great day.....   The outcome was that half the Aylesbury Town first XI were invited## leaving the rest to face the might of a power-packed Ballinger team intent on clinging on to their Premier League status. Once someone had been found to unlock the changing room## stumps and a scoreboard had been found## a successful call by skipper Maciver saw Aylesbury invited to bat first## and there followed a bizarre self destructive exhibition by their senior players## in the face of superlative bowling by Will Reid and Nick Adams. By the eleventh over they were 39 for 7## even after some woeful catching by certain senior Ballinger fielders## which must have made Will in particular spit nails. That they did not roll over completely was due to some intelligent and watchful defence## mixed with some fortuitous slogging## by their last four batsmen. A couple of good catches improved Rollo McIntyre's day in the field## Will Smith contributed a stumping## and Ian Maciver and Evan Webster saw to it that Aylesbury's recovery was snuffed out## and the innings closed leaving Ballinger with the trifling target of 101 to win.

Cognoscenti of Ballinger batting prowess might raise an eyebrow at the description of "trifling"## but surely.....?  With eleven overs to navigate before tea## Matt Riley and Danny Draper's approach was the antithesis to Aylebury's earlier batting## as maiden over succeeded maiden##and the Aylesbury bowlers showed a great deal more competence than their batsmen - as Matt was to find out## when castled in the fifth over## with the total on 4. In came Rollo## and soon lifted the rate with a couple of boundaries## so that Ballinger went in to tea at 23 for 1.

Suitably refreshed## Danny and Rollo continued with their steady progress## with Rollo## conscious of the utter necessity of victory## batting most reponsibly. Danny## by nature## doing exactly the same!  Nevertheless## both were beneficiaries of dropped sitters## so the "wedding god" was still smiling on Ballinger. With no further alarms## Rollo in particular now started to open up## with a trademark six high into the tennis court netting. Aylesbury tried seven bowlers -probably their captain had never seen some of them bowl before## especially the round-arm slinger in the ASDA T shirt## but to no avail## as Ballinger cruised to victory by 9 wickets. Rollo finished with a very well-deserved 54*## and Danny a patient and increasingly confident 37* - how we have needed his style of batting in recent weeks!

One could not but feel sympathy for our opposition## who were so friendly in adversity!  However## the victory was all the sweeter for hearing that Holmer Green had unaccountably managed to lose to our arch rivals in the relegation stakes## Knotty Green## who must have thought that salvation would be theirs.

Analysis of the final league table points may well show the contribution made by the Umpiring/Scoring section to the Club's survival. So Dick and I would like to thank our unheralded colleagues Roger## Miles## Derek and Liz## who so unselfishly stood in when we were away.

Long Marston is a great place to play cricket on a blissfully sunny## warm## early September afternoon – a top fixture in the Sunday calendar.  Agreeing to play a 40 over win/lose match## Ballinger lost the toss and Long Marston elected to bat.  Ballinger had to take the field initially with only 10 men## until Jamie Kellock was spotted scuttling sheepishly from the car park at about 1:05 – apparently he had somehow managed to sleep all the way through until 12:30 - a cracking effort## of which any teenager would be proud.  The pitch was not the usual batting paradise to be found at Long Marston## being a little damp## giving the seamers some early help## which openers Harry Livingstone and Evan Webster exploited effectively## as long Marston made an uncharacteristically slow and cautious start.  Evan claimed the 1st wicket## knocking middle stump out emphatically## having already had a catch put down at 1st slip.   But Long Marston then developed a good partnership for the 2nd wicket## dominated by their no.3## Doodson## who went on to score 100.  Nick Adams put in a typically controlled and tight spell in the middle overs## as the Long Marston batsmen tried unsuccessfully to cut loose.  Monty Thompson took a little while to settle back into bowling after a few weeks away## but eventually did well under some pressure and would have had a 2nd wicket if his father had not tried (unsuccessfully) to catch one at long off with his chest.  Ian Maciver replaced Nick to show Monty how it should be done## turning in a skilful spell of 1 for 23 off 6## bowling at the death.  Long Marston’s total of 192 for 8 off 40 overs was certainly not imposing and a credit to Ballinger’s bowling and fielding – James McIntyre fielding particularly well at backward point.

 

Ballinger openers Danny Draper and Richard O’Kelly initially found the going slightly tough. Although the pitch had dried out a little## it still required a bit of getting used to for every batsmen at the beginning of his innings.  After a recent run of excellent performances for the Saturday 1st XI## Danny unfortunately nicked one behind## bringing Rollo McIntyre in to join Richard - the partnership which won Ballinger the match.  Both played superbly## ending on not out 82 and 87 respectively## parted by Richard’s dismissal with only 10 required to win.  Both struck the ball cleanly to all parts## Rollo preferring to hit high and straight and Richard creaming it elegantly through extra cover.  The very pleasing number of Ballinger spectators were by this time basking in the late summer sun and the feeling of general well-being as Ballinger were cruising towards victory with several overs to spare.  Even the President and Nick Adams slipped into prolonged## light-hearted and good-natured banter together (later dubbed “the Chuckle Brothers”).  The gloss was not taken off the victory by a late flurry of silly wickets when only one run was needed to win## with 5 overs still to spare.  The 1st victory at Long Marston that anyone present could remember – holding out for a draw usually being regarded as a decent performance.  The victors celebrated with a few drinks outside the Pavilion as the sun went down## bringing another season very nearly  to a close.

Sunshine at Ballinger and a beautifully prepared strip [Thanks Jamie]## Toby our skipper won the toss and decided to bat. Toby felt that 275 would be a decent score to achieve.

Beaconsfield bowlers started their attack against Edward Batchelor and Harvey## both boys finding the boundary in the first over## BEaconsfield were bowling a good line and length and with the ball keeping low it wasnt easy for the boys toi gett the straighter ball away## they did however get us off to a great start heading back to the pavillion on 215 for 1.

James and Cyrus were again faced with some very tidy bowling## but this didnt stop them running lbetween the wickets## stealing singles and two's## James then struck a perfectly timed four  from the middle of his bat that we would all be proud to serve up## the boys left the square without loss of a wicket with the team on 235 for 1.

Victor and Edward Best took their turn and Victor struck a super cut straight between the fielders for four and the pair stole several runs with great sots between the fielders## still with no further loss of wicket BEaconsfield were starting to feel the pressure and mistakes were happening. Victor and Edward drove the score up to 258 for 1 as they handed over to Raphi and Jack.

Raphi and Jack punished the bowlers in their forst two overs and Beaconsfield to their credit changed the bowling attack## Raphi dropped mid wicket and then Jack taken by a yorker## a new bat is delivered to Jack which was a size larger and Beaconsfield bowlers piled on the pressure## Raphi being caught at the second attempt## but the boys had already inflicted the damage 267 for 3 and they handed over to our skipper and his partner Freddie

Freddie took a 4 from his first delivery and panic seemed to set in to the fielding side## but with their strong bowlers on they managed to calm the situation a little## but Freddie and Toby were stealing runs with every error they made in the field and the boys punished two overthrows with a 3 to finish off a great innings. Toby had beaten his target by 3 runs 278 for 4 from 20 overs.

Nicky##Emma##Caroline and the other mums gave the boys a lovely mid match snack which was devoured and mugs of tea were constantly distributed to the scorer and watching parents.

Beaconsfield took to the square and Edward Batchelor opened ## four dot balls a bye and a four## Toby took the next over and slowed the rate down which continued with Cyrus and Harvey## Beacondfield were on 220 after 4 overs.

The next pair were confronted with Raphi who bowled 5 dots and a two## not be outdone our James Best delivered 5 dot balls and a single## the pressure was really starting to build Cyrus delivered four dot balls and two extras and Harvey came in for his second over with 5 dot balls and a bye## Beaconsfield were lagging behind on the run rate reaching 231 from 8 overs.

Freddie lined up and started his over## knowing the tall batsman will connect with at least one of them## first ball goes for four## but Freddie unphased continued and his reward came fith ball as he bowled the culprit. Ballingers energy took a great boost## Toby brought on our next spinner Edward Best## who managed four dots## but a slightly fuller ball went skywards over the boundary## but Edward remained unshaken.Beaconsfield were on 250 from 12 overs for 1 wicket## closing in on the target.

Cyrus cut off a certain four with a sprint and dive which he then dispatched from the boundary straight into Jack's gloves inches from the stumps## quite outstanding.

Raphi came on to bowl at the next pair## a single and 5 dots## then Victor came on and delivered 5 dots and 1 extra## Edward Batchelor then bowled three dots and 3 byes## to be followed by Edward Best wo bowled a wicket maiden## Beaconsfield were still on 250 for 2 from 16 overs## this session had left them with a challenging last foru overs## needing 29 runs to win.

Toby came on and a high ball to the boundary was intercepted by Freddie## he managed to hold the ball but not retain it## he stopped the four## it was a catch that most teenagers would have struggled to control. The boys were not letting anything through.Victor took his second over and was bowling a super length## allowing the odd single and then produced a a wicket## Ballinger were very much in control  255 from 18 overs## Harvey bowled over 19 giving very little away and Raphi took the last over which was Run Out##Bye##Two##Single##Bowled and Run Out## so Beaconsfield finished 32 runs short.

What an extrodinary team and proud winners of their cups.

A huge thank you to Joe Ward for umpiring and doing a sterling job and to the Mums for all of the goodies at the break and for making me tea and also tidying up afterwards.

Mark and Steve as always for helping tidy the nets and the ground with us.

 

Kindest

 

Steve for Nigel

The morning was glorious and preparations had been meticulous (extra training on Friday night and an early warm up before the toss) - what could possibly go wrong....... 

Having won the toss the skipper elected to field first.  With a damp## lush outfield and on a difficult ground to judge a par score## there seemed no other option. Downley set about the innings in a controlled## yet aggressive manner with the score reaching 40 from the first four overs. The introduction of spin courtesy of Freddie slowed the scoring rate to some degree## however after ten overs had elapsed## Downley had advanced to 80 for 0 - the majority of the runs coming from the left handed Birkett## who benefitted from being dropped on the boundary four times in total. With the ball eventually being thrown to six bowlers## BWCC managed to claw back a little of the initiative and restricted Downley to 163## when earlier in the innings something nearer 200 looked possible. Having fielded so well in the previous rounds of the competition## the catching display today was well below the standards that we usually set ourselves## although the ground cricket was good with several 'four balls' being saved. 

With a fraction over eight per over required## there was still hope........ 

Having learned from our last ten overs in the field## and with more than a run a ball needed the Downley skipper elected to protect the boundaries from the start - leaving only a couple of fielders in the ring.  While this made picking up singles easy## it meant that pushing the score on was going to be a challenge.  What followed was a procession of Ballinger batsmen giving their wicket away chasing the game.  Only Tom provided any real resistance with a creative 23## including a switch hit that would have had Nigel out of his seat!  The Ballinger innings was threatening to disintegrate completely## until Paul (27no) and Will (13) constructed a 49 run## tenth wicket partnership which included three of only four boundaries in the innings. Maybe the skipper should have reversed the batting order ! Ballinger finished on a total of 105 - a loss by 58 runs.  Having fielded## bowled and batted well short of our collective abilities## the biggest disappointment of the morning being that we didn't give a decent account of ourselves - no one minds being beaten by a better side when they have done themselves justice## but this was not the case this morning......roll on next season to make amends...... 

A few mentions - thanks to Paul for his idea of putting out a team of (mainly) youngsters to represent the club in this competition - they have all done the club proud. Thanks to Miles for scoring this morning and officiating the earlier rounds. Thanks also to those who turned up this morning to support us - sorry there wasn't much to cheer. 

Following the game I learned from a Downley player that the wife## and mother## of two of their players had been diagnosed with a terminal illness this week.  He explained that this accounted for the levels of passion and emotion from their supporters. While it is never nice to be on the losing side in a sporting contest## it does put things into context.  Perhaps this morning they needed the win more than us.  We wish them all the best.

The Ballinger Sunday steamroller rumbles on!  After completing our 1st win in living memory against Long Marston last week## Ballinger were far too good for Jordans Taverners this week.  An excellent bowling and fielding performance reduced Jordans to 100 all out in just over 36 overs in a 40 over win/lose match.  It took Ballinger only 23 overs and the loss of 2 wickets to knock off that total. 

Jordans had won the toss and elected to bat on a green and dampish pitch.  Openers Evan Webster (2) and Nick Adams (1) both took early wickets and Jordans never really recovered.  Both bowled straight## coping well with a left-right combination## and extracted plenty of life out of the helpful pitch.  Hamish Sim and Monty Thompson then took over## Hamish in particular tying down the Jordans batsmen in a vice-like grip.  Wickets fell steadily## maidens were commonplace and aggressive shots were comparatively rare given that it was a limited overs game.  If it had not been for the very occasional 4-ball sent down by Ballinger (which the Jordans batsmen usually dispatched effectively)## the score would have been very low indeed.  After taking an over to settle in## Monty bowled a combination of heavily-flighted deliveries and superfast darts (verging on the thankfully rarely to be seen “Piggy-pace”)## to claim a couple of wickets.  Freddie Thompson joined the attack (insisting on bowling downhill – an unusual request for a legspinner)## claiming 3 wickets with his heavily spun leg-breaks - and## yes was that a googly?   Jordans Taverners became slightly more expansive as the 30th over ticked by## but a returning Nick Adams then uprooted the stumps of the last 2 batsmen in the same over## so that Jordans ended up failing to use their overs.  Frankly## each of the Ballinger bowlers was on the day too good for the Jordans batsmen.

Openers Nick Tegg and Rob McIntyre gave Ballinger a steady start until Nick drove excitedly at a wide one and was caught at cover.  Rob was then joined by his younger son## James.  The combination and the contrast was striking and effective – James driving elegantly front and back foot## Rob concentrating hard and advising patience; and both taking every opportunity to squeeze a single out of the slightly flat-footed fielding side.  The run rate which had initially been about 3 an over (more than the required rate already) accelerated as James got into his stride. Rob played over one and was bowled for a very solid 27## but Will Smith joined James to see Ballinger home with more than 16 overs to spare## hitting a fine straight 6 which long on caught## before falling over the line (no Glenn Maxwells here).

 

An enjoyable and emphatic end to a very successful season for the Sunday team## with only one defeat – and that was to High Wycombe!

The Meadow in Chesham had a very end of season feel to it on Sunday and the way the Ballinger boys started this Cup final you'd have thought they'd already put their kit away for the season.

Ollie Webb was in charge and he followed in a long line of Ballinger skippers this summer by losing the toss. Chesham chose to bat and## thanks to some very indifferent bowling accomapnied by some very suspect fielding## they were soon rocketing along. Suffice to say that they were scoring at nearly 8 an over for the first 8 overs. 

Edward brought some control to the proceedings as did Archie especialy when he took the first wicket to fall. Slowly the boys woke up and began to drag the run rate back. There was suddenly more urgency in the fielding and about their whole approach to the game but they just couldnt get the wickets needed to bring the score back to a more managable number. A wicket for Tom## who was the pick of the bowlers## followed by a run out from an Edward/Max combination meant that The Waggoners were chasing a sizeable total of 125.  

Chesham had a couple of very good early order batsmen including Tom Hortop## Kieran and Will Gilcrest. All 3 played very positively and made life hard for the early bowlers. I was impressed that we only gave away 4 wides and 1 no-ball. 

A quick check with the captain that he'd got his order sorted and off we went.

The Chesham captain was a bit dis-organised as to who was bowling when but I dont think it would have made any difference to Seb and Raphi who was bowling. They set about chasing the target with such a composed approach it was difficult to believe they were both U11. After 4 overs they had made a sizeable dent in the target by taking 37 runs off them. Some wonderful shots and excellent pinching of singles great to watch.

Fin and Kuran then added another 25 which was excellent because they were facing master Hortop who was quick. Tom and Max mixed cautious defence with some excellent shots and running between the wickets to add another 17 taking the total to 79 at the end of the 12th over. In front of the run rate!

Archie and Edward now march to the crease. Archie strokes his first ball for 4 through the covers. This was the shot of the day and probably the best shot Ive seen all season. Another good over for the batting side follows but then there's a maiden. Sudenly we're still 14 runs short with 5 overs to go. Edward has only faced 3 balls at this stage so when he finaly gets the strike## in what is the pairs last over## he takes full advantage. First ball is over mid-wicket for 4 then the next 2 are drives through the covers for 4. 14 off the over means we're now infront.

The skipper and Tim are up next. Ollie plays out a maiden## the crowd are getting excited## Tim plays and misses then connects with a couple and gets two 4s for his efforts. Can they keep their wickets. Defence is the order of the day but that doesnt register in Ollie's book as he hits his next ball for 2## follwed by a sumptious drive through the covers for 4.

Lots of mental calculations going on as to how many in front we need to be especially as Chesham's  M of M Hortop is back on. He's quick and Tim plays and misses## stops the next one## misses the next but then a snick gives him a sneaky 2 and it's all over we cant lose.

A really impressive## composed run chase with some wonderful shots and excellent running between the wickets. Did anyone notice there was no mention of wickets lost. That's because they didnt lose any. Outstanding.

A wonderful end to the season for the boys and thanks to all the parents who came to watch and support on the day and have done so throughout the season.

Steve has done a great job of managing the boys throughout the season and this result is just reward for all his efforts.
